reviews.review: Glass painting. At the side of the Ethnology Museum, there is an South East Asia museum. On the second floor, there is a room with antique glass painting. So artistic. Never seen any painting like this before.

Well curated and insightful. The museum is very well worth a visit. An interesting modern building that serves to display the exhibits well - although for a newish building it is in worrying condition. Exhibits are well displayed with explanations in Vietnamese, French and English. Much of this coverage of Vietnam's minority people was new to me and something of a revelation. The display of costumes was particularly nicely done and the frequent use of videos helped bring it all to life. The bonus is the reconstruction of numerous ethnic buildings to scale in the grounds behind the museum building. Include it on your must do list in Hanoi

Kind of interesting but very hot. This was rather interesting. They had full sized tribal homes you could go into. There were fans and air conditioners in the main building, but it was still very hot. The tribal homes were cooler than the museum.

Great spot with kids. Went with 2 boys age 6 and 10. Explored museum displays for about an hour which was very informative and well laid out. Then went outside behind museum where kids can run about exploring traditional houses, watch a water puppet show and play. Bonus review: awesome playground across the street from the museum.

Cultural Experience. This is a 'must do' in Hanoi. This well presented (and air conditioned) museum offers a fascinating insight into the melting pot of cultures that make up the country of Vietnam. With lots of visual references and English guides, this museum not only showcases the history and underlying premise of each culture, it also offers a tangible understanding of what makes them 'tick'. The recreated 'village' outside is also pretty amazing.

Well worth it.. The internal displays have a lot to offer and interets people with the range of different tribes across Vietnam. The gift stores are well priced and have some good products. But the best part was visiting the traditional homes in the gardens
What you don't know.. Found this a very interesting overview of the history of the country. Our guide gave us a very good lesson on Vietnamese culture and tradition.

The ethnics of Vietnamese people.... It was a nice museum to learn more about the ethnics of Vietnamese people... There r 54 ethnics if I remember it right... Lots of knowledge about it in the museum... But I like the outside part of the museum more, there r lots and different kinds of traditional houses, u could even come insides of them... There was even a water puppet show when we were there... And the infos r also in English, so I think u could do this even without a tour guide (we did it with a tour guide though)...

Great place to take the kids . We are a family with 3 boys 8 and under and spent 3-4 hours here. We spent the majority of our time exploring the display houses in the outdoor area of the museum. Boys loved climbing the steep wooden ladder like steps to get into the houses on stilts. There was also a bamboo balancing beam that kept them entertained for a good half hour. Our last stop was the discovery centre (top floor) where they were taught how to play a traditional kids game, which we half got the gist of due to age and language constraints, look at paper mâché masks, and do some wooden block stamping. Great value for money and was great for kids and adults alike.
Really interesting. The inside exhibition is not that interesting but seeing the traditional houses outside in the garden was amazing

Wonderful Museum in Hanoi. Vietnam Museum of Ethnology is one of best museum in CITY TOUR, It is really a must see while you are in Hanoi. It is beautiful setting and so much to learn about all of the Vietnamese culture. You should spend 4 or 5 hours to enjoy and visit all of places in this museum!

Great culture. This is one of the best Museum we've been. Displaying great culture of 54 ethnics in Vietnam. You will interested in from inside to outside, there were many things to explore. I loved Public house outside & enjoyed free Water puppet show very much!

Can stay there a full day!. Full of info and a great museum. We went there at 11 and stayed till 5! A great place to visit with kids too as they have a great many things to see including the various houses of different ethnic groups replicated out doors. My 6 year old daughter didn't get bored at all. The south Asian museum in the same grounds is also very interesting. Once done and if you have kids, cross over to the park opposite. Great park and kids will love it!
Wonderful insight. Good choice to visit, especially to understand all the various tribal/minority groups before heading to Sapa area

Great English-speaking Experience. Wife and I got an English speaking tour guide for the museum and they took us through the whole main building. Tour was about a half hour long and got a bunch of info that wasn't on the signs. It may be a bit hurried if you are the kind of person who likes to read all of the signs, but you can always go back through after on your own if you have specific ones you'd like to examine in more detail.The garden behind the main building is especially epic with so many buildings from the various ethnic groups. Real variety and detailed signs guiding you around and explaining them in Viet, English and French.

Excellent Museum but disappointing for us. Don't get tuk tuk from Old Quarter. This was top of our list to spend a half day whilst in Hanoi. We had done much research and reviews and were looking forward to visiting for some hours. But, alas, we made the wrong decision to go by tuk tuk instead of a car. The peddler assured us he knew where to go and after an hour of him stopping and him asking 5 people where it was located we had then run out of time. So disappointing but when we return to Hanoi we will get a taxi and go directly to the museum. This place is worth an excellent vote from our hours of research. If you are staying in the Old Quarter do not get a tuk tuk to take you.

Interesting. Really cool place, you have the air-conditioned museum which shows artefacts of SEA as well as the outdoors buildings of different ethnic groups. This is the only 1 of 2 museum I'd recommend to my friends to visit in Vietnam

A celebration of the Vietnamese people. I was so impressed with the layout of this museum. There was a great amount of physical artifacts that were beautifully displayed throughout. The signage was easy and interesting to read. My favorite part was outside on the grounds. There are 7 different types of homes reconstructed to give an idea of how the different minorities have lived throughout the country. Signs let you know which families lived in each home, at what time and in what part of the country. You can expect to stay here for about an hour, although there is a great restaurant on site if you get hungry during your stay.

Best Hanoi muesum. Best museum we went to in Hanoi. Interesting to learn about them all. Don't know if it was just because it was a Sunday or if it's always there but there was a water puppet show in the garden

Wonderful place showing the history of Vietnam. We went with a tour guide and thoroughly enjoyed it. The display of the traditional homes from the different districts throughout all of Vietnam.The guide advised us that the locals from each region came and built their the homes. School children visiting the site were also a delight and were intrigued by westerners and would practise their english. Beautiful people!

Interesting Information About Vietnamese. About 20 minutes taxi drive from Old Quarter, this museum is interesting for those who wish to understand how Vietnam is composed of various ethnicity. The entrance is cheap, 40,000 Dong. The indoor museum is kinda hot, there's no AC so be ready to sweat. The outside is more fun as you get to see real life traditional houses from different groups. We spent around 2 hours. Worth to mention is the cafe, must visit it as it is philanthropic restaurant.
Visit to the Museum. Provided a snapshot/summary of the culture and ethnic groups within Vietnam. Very interesting and informative
Great visit. Really interesting visit. I felt that the inside focused a lot on some groups over others but the gardens outside more than made up for that. To see the traditional homes was amazing.
Beautiful. Really a must see while you are in Hanoi. Beautiful setting and so much to learn about all of the Vietnamese culture.

Nice. Interesting museum. Never knew so much minorities lived in Viernam. Good displays inside the museum, too bad there is no AC, as it was very hot inside. The outside is amazing. Have some time to kill, visit this museum.

Good. Plenty of things about 54 groups of people in Vietnam. There are documentary films about some unique customs of some groups. It's not quite easy to understand except you discover in real things by contact to local people in different areas. Outside area has many different house styles of Groups which is great.Both the inside and outside areas are nice and probably called rather fairly-organizedThere is guiding service for the inside area which costs 100.000 VND/group. Ticket price is 40.000 VND/pax. Takes 25mins to drive from center (Temple of Literature). Visit time normally takes 1hr30-2hrs.

A great museum about Vietnam's people. . Lynn and I and friends visited the Museum of Ethnology with our Vietnamese guide recently. This is a museum that traces the history of people from the origins of the country. There is much memorabilia here spread over 2 floors. People interested in different native fabrics will find this museum fascinating. We enjoyed the museum.

Imppressive. In the main building is a collection of exhibits reflecting the various groups who make up Vietnem. Outside is a collection of early houses found in the area. It was a delightful experience.

Great for kids!. Taking our seven and five year olds to most museums can usually become a difficult experience... Not this place. This museum takes you on a tour of the ethnic groups from all areas around Vietnam. Inside has some great artefacts which the kids weren't really interested in however going outside into the gardens was just what we were looking for. Original huts and homes from the various groups have been rebuilt into the museum grounds. You can take a walk through these houses and structures and get a glimpse into their way of life. The kids got a great insight and asked lots of questions as they made their way through the homes. Can highly recommend this on your visit to Hanoi!
Interesting and quiet. The place is an island of quiet in busy Hanoi. The different tribes are well presented and explained including their houses.

Informative but too hot. It was nice learning about the different ethnic groups in Vietnam but the museum was way too hot for us to fully appreciate it. The air was hot and heavy inside the museum and I wished it was airconditioned or had more ventilation. Still worth a visit but not on a hot day.

Interesting Museum worth visiting. . Entrance fee is 40k VND per adult which is really cheap. Closed on Monday and Friday afternoons like a lot of other museums in Hanoi so be wary. An interesting insight into the many ethnicities that live in Vietnam. The recreation of the traditional houses in the outside grounds is stunning! You can easily spend a good few hours walking around here and looking at all the various exhibits. There is a cafe on site which also serves food and ice cream. Make sure you bring a fan as it's really hot inside the building - there are fans on the ceilings but some aren't on and those that are aren't powerful! Definitely worth a visit if you are interested in the culture of Vietnam or museums in general.

Fascinating insight into the various cultures of Vietnam. This was a surprise. Our guide was particularly good on this visit. Very interesting to here about all the different cultures. The external exhibits are a must see even if it is warm. The different styles of houses are really interesting.Give this place a visit you will not regret it.

JUST AMAZING!. This is an amazing and incredible museum. I did not know exactly what to expect....but...the information given about all ethnic groups is fantastic and also honours them. The displays are also very very good. Walking around outside and looking at traditional houses etc is just beautiful and absolutely great for photos. I highly recommend to visit and, most importantly, LEARN.

Great place to spend the afternoon. Visited this museum with 3 young kids, they loved the little houses set up so you could walk around inside and see how people lived. Was a great way to spend a few hours.

So many different ethnicities. A visit to this museum will vastly improve your knowledge of Vietnamese history and culture with a fascinating variety of stories to tell of local folk, trade and crafts.
A place which makes you understand about viet culture multiethnical. It is a place where youcan have a look to different cultures in Vietnam based on the multiethnical old culture
Visit. I learned a lot with our visitGood that we chose to have a tour guide, He was very helpful, was able to impart information that help us understand their cultures.Love It.
A Learning Experience. Very interesting and a worthwhile visit. If you have an appreciation for history and open minded about learning about other cultures, then you should visit.

A must for visitors . This museum explains in excellent visual detail, the history of the many ethnic groups that make up the country. We had the benefit of a tour guide to further explain some of the displays but if the time is taken to read the plaques, I'm sure it would be equally interesting. Air conditioned with plenty of places to sit for a rest.

Culturally fantastic. A fabulous place to learn all about the different cultures throughout Vietnam, this museum is a must visit. There is an indoor section and an outdoor section, with replica houses from different provinces. I was there to see the water puppet show which was very entertaining. A must to visit in Hanoi.

54 people groups . Fascinating to learn of 54 people groups with pictures, artifacts like jewelry, pots, houses, baskets. Once you complete the inside your you visit outside going into many homes and community buildings of different tribes.
Really excellent

Best museum in Vietnam. For any tourist who has limited time like me, visitting this museum is the best way to have over view about Vietnamese culture and history. It is devided into 2 parts: indoor and out door exhibitions with arround 15,000 objects. The garden is great. You can see more than 10 samples of ethinic houses with real size. It is wonderful.

Lots of information, don't forget the outdoor replicas and exhibits. There are lots of information on Vietnamese ethnic people. The outdoor exhibits are full scale replicas of ethnic homes. Plan to spend at least 2-4 hours to get the most out of this museum.

Great museum experience. This is a first class museum, well worth a visit. We took a taxi - about AU$7 from our hotel. Its focus is the many peoples of Vietnam, and there are about a dozen reconstructed houses in the grounds, from some of the ethnic groups - just fascinating. Real houses that belonged to real families and were moved there. Also in the weekends, they have water puppet shows which are included in the modest entrance fee. The SE Asia building was great too - we could have spent hours there.

Brilliant museum - so much to see and learn about Vietnam.. This museum offers so much for visitors and has an amazing display of different kinds of houses which are lived in in Vietnam. The displays are really well-organised and a lot of detail has been put into the writing. We spent several hours just enjoying walking around the museum looking at all the displays. The café/restaurant is also very good.
Good for kids. We visited with my 8 yr old son, we enjoyed exploring inside but especially liked exploring the outside and all the different houses in the gardens

Culturally Rich with Information. This is a great museum inside out. I was especially fond of the village houses built outside of the museum, It gives a good perspective of how Vietnamese villagers live. This museum is definitely worth the visit!

54 Minority Groups. Learn about the different groups within Vietnam society. They don't fight between each other as trading food is more important and they don't marry outside the group. They get along and don't fight...this is why Viet Nam people are special ..no prejudice
Great Museum!. Enjoyed our time visiting this. Quite a big ones with many houses of different ethnic groups. Many things to learn about Vietnamese cultures here!

Cultural Vietnam . Didn't know Vietnam has so many ethnic groups. The unique culture of the groups displayed the tools, festivals or language. More interestingly, it showcased the different houses they lived in.

Museum visit . Describes the life style of the different ethnic tribes that exists in Vietnam. The museum has a collection of the artifacts that the tribes used in thier daily life. The museum brings out the diverse orgin of the tribes ranging from China,Thailand etc. The museum would be a good place to visit for a serious student of Ethnology. I would skip it

If you have extra time. If you are interested in the hill tribes it is a great place. They have a lot of interesting videos, unfortunately they are not in English. They advertise a tour in English which would have been great but unfortunately it was not operating when we were there. It has an outdoor area of rebuilt hill tribe houses that are very interesting. I would recommend it

Sort of interesting . Some interesting things here, most of the displays in the museum are not that interesting however and a bit boring. Looking over some traditional houses sort of interesting, certainly wouldn't say it's a must see if you need to fill in time maybe.

Great museum. I really enjoyed my visit to this museum. There are exhibits with models of how Vietnamese & ethnic Vietnamese live which I thought was pretty cool. But I discovered that they had life size models of homes outside!! It was fun checking it out. And make sure to remember to take off your shoes (as we were not aware...) They also have a water puppet show. Downside is the building has no air conditioning so it got really hot!!

Very revealing and fun for the kids. I took my children aged 7 and 9 to the museum. We live in Cambodia so they were familiar with many of the artifacts on display having seen variants on them while staying with their grandparents in their village near the border with Vietnam. They really enjoyed the collection of houses at the museum and the 'hands-on' experience of going through different dwellings from around the country. Highly recommended and informative museum and one that keeps the attention of children

I think it's a must see!!!. The Museum of Ethnology is a bit out of the way and a lot of people seem to miss it for that reason.I think it's a fantastic place; enormously interesting. Give yourself plenty of time to take your time over the outdoor exhibits. And if possible time your visit to see the water puppet theater - get a bit of a feel for 'real' water puppet theater as it developed in village ponds around the Red River delta.

Small Vietnam in just half day. We visited here and enjoying some of Vietnam culture.Our favourite taking pictures of different kind of Traditional Vietnam house which surprisingly it's a lot and have many typesWe enjoy also Puppet Water show here in the middle of this museum, not so much attraction but my daughter love a lot this water puppet show

Excellent Museum. The Vietnam Museum of Ethnology in Hanoi is an excellent museum demonstrating the multitude of cultures that exist and thrive side by side in Vietnam. There are historical stories on the wall describing the unique path of each "tribe" and culture in Vietnam, as well as clothing, artifacts and photos describing the origins of each group. Outside, in the back of the museum there are examples of different housing typical of each tribes, and near the front entrance there is a souvenir centre and a shop with artistic pieces that can be bought for a very reasonable price. Everything is interesting and definitely worthwhile for anyone wanting to understand the history of the country.
Nice museum. I and my girlfriend came here on 10 December 2015Nice museum and should visit if visiting HanoiIt shows all characters of 54 ethnic of Vietnam where I lived when young

Closer view into life in Vietnam. museum shows us more than 50 ethnological groups. In the garden are replicas of real houses, you can explore them, but with respect and without shoes. I recommend this visit at the begin of your journey, especially if you want to visit countryside.

Interesting . Alot to see . We went and it was very interesting . Outside they have recontruction of houses and burial grave from year gone by . You can go inside them . Great fun for children and adults . Plus water puppet show was nice . They also have tearoom . Alot to see . Glad we went .
Tour with Hanoi Kids. The tour was very informative. Our tour guides Ti and Season from Hanoikids are very good in explaining the history of Vietnam. They speak English very well.

Good fun with our 9 year old. We went early on a Sunday a.m. The exhibits were fun and there were lots of engaging activities on the grounds. Taxi from old quarter and price of admission for all of us for under $15USD - so a great value, too!

Interesting ethnology. An interesting museum concentrating on Vietnams minority peoples . The displays outside are fascinating with full size traditional buildings and tombs. A long way from the old quarter though and really only accessible by taxi unless you speak Vietnamese or otherwise understand the bus system. Not much else to do in that area, although there is a rather lively little lakeside park just opposite the museum, which was largely deserted on my visit.
Interesting. Very educational. Loved the museum shop selling hand crafted articles for trade free non-profit organizations that support local villages.

THE museum of Hà Nội. . This place is more a collection of the lives of the diverse ethnic tribes of Vietnam than your traditional "old pot in glass box" kinds.The indoor installations are quite lovely but it is the outdoor houses which really takes the cake.The gift shop is very generic though.I bit more literature on the anthropology of the tribes would be lovely.
Nice . I like this place It is good to spend half a day Great place to bring kids since Hanoi is not a very kid friendly city

Good spot to escape the city . We headed out to the museum with our 5 & 6 yr old. We didn't spend much time inside but our boys had great fun exploring the different traditional houses and building outside in the gardens. Nice location with lots of shade from the large trees. Also useful was a kids playground and lake straight across the road to check out after the museum.

The houses outside are the best part. Visited the museum as part of a city tour. The exhibits inside are ok, with some interesting bits but we really enjoyed touring the different houses in the gardens behind the building. They had some good information about each one and many had a museum employee inside to answer questions.
Great museum, hire a guide. Very good place to learn a lot about the Vietnamese culture and the minority groups. Do it with a guide, totally worth the extra dongs.
interesting place . i like this museum but its hot. so far its awesome. when i went there we have lited time to see all. and i took few good pictures and it was fun.

amazing (If only they will add A/C). It's a little off the main attractions, but we got there with a bus.
the Museum is very interesting, especially the garden. it was difficult to concentrate in entrance building as it was too hot, and the kids kept running to the one A/C that was there. the second building was a little more ventilated.

Don't be fooled by the place name.. Our guide took us to this museum, and we really enjoyed finding out how the People of Vietnam evolved. We would never have gone to the museum had it not been for our guide.

Avoid during rainy days. A good place to get to know the various ethnicity, rituals, and cultures of Vietnamese.
Avoid to go on rainy days, cos the outdoor gardens (where displays of various houses, tombs, etc) get slippery and mosquitos-prone.

interesting but hot. my travel buddy and i visited upon suggestion of our local Vietnam consular officer. it was very interesting indeed however this museum doesn't have a/c and my buddy couldn't visit it due to the very hot temp.I am not such a museum mouse and normally i prefer visiting pagodas and temples but the perks of this museum are all the traditional houses built in the park.Vietnam is a country rich in ethnic minorities and the purpose of this museum is showing them all, their traditional costumes, tools, ways of life and houses.We spent roughly 3h.We even sat down at the restaurant/coffee shop inside.the bookstore is kinda expansive but it has interesting books.the gift shop has stuff you can buy almost everywhere but some few items are of a better quality compared to tourist shops.

Loved water puppets and house making films. The museum was full of things but scarce with explanations. I found that knowledge I had gained from visiting the Museum of Women was very helpful indeed in making sense of what I was seeing. There was an unannounced water puppet theatre performance at 16:00 which was delightful and illuminating. And clambering on the various types of houses was a delight - with very illuminating videos demonstrating how they were built.Well worth visiting but could be helpful to bring a guide of some sort to help make sense of the whole and its parts...

Interesting . Plenty to see and learn about Vietnam's diverse people's with many interesting displays including various housing styles for the various people's in full scale displays in the grounds. Very eye opening.

good insights into Vietnam. This museum gave us a good insight into Vietnam and Vietnamese way of life at the start of our tour of Vietnam. We spent 2 hours here but you could choose to spend more or less time here. unfortunately we could not visit the houses outside as a typhoon had damaged the area.

Knowledge about the life of Vietnam. Outdoors you will experience the rural life of Vietnam which consists of homes from different areas of the country. Inside contains daily life of the many cultures of different ethnic groups from around the country. Worth a visit, but no air conditioning.

Small but wonderful. The interior exhibits are interesting, but it's the re-constructed houses in the grounds that are really fascinating. We went as part of a day tour of Ha Noi but wished we had more time to explore outside.

Worth a Visit. Start with the outdoor exhibits - a series of traditional bamboo and wooden houses of different ethnic Vietnamese. This will give you a real sense of the daily life of the people whose clothes and things and cultures are depicted inside. Skip the restaurant and walk next door to the cafe.

Interesting displays with a lot to see. Vietnam has a varied ethnological history - which is difficult to see in the big cities - unless you head up to the highlands. Although the place is really busy on weekends, full of kids, it is worth a visit. Just take a taxi, parking your bike seems to me a little risky.

Not my thing. I'm not huge on museums so this place really didn't interest me that much. I felt that I had already learnt so much about Vietnamese culture & history that nothing here really added much value. The museum wasn't even cool which is the reason why our guide took us here in the first place!

A great place to see Vietnam's culture. This museum is a testament to Vietnam's diversity and heritage.Other countries may "celebrate their diversity" through words and pap; Vietnam does it with substance in this museum. The indoor displays are well complemented by the various styles of houses together with domestic artefacts in use by the various groups that make up the country's population.A good intro to the country - one can easily spend a wet morning here.The shop is also excellent in that it has a lot of authentic indegeous village/community made products of silk, lacquer, cotton, silver, leather, etc. on sale at reasonable prices.

Excellent museum . This is a fascinating insight into Vietnamese history and the various types of ethnicities that make up Vietnam and Vietnamese culture. I was lucky enough to catch a free water puppet show in the gardens. Also in the gardens are recreations of various types of ethnic houses. Definitely worth checking out.
Great Museum. Comprehensive history of women in VietnamI first saw this 15 years ago and it has improved Congratulations to the Curator
Something unexpected. Really great place make sure you also visit different houses made around the main building. Great Vietnam cultural history.

Fascinating history of vietnams 56 ethic groups. This is a big modern building - but both the museum and its gardens are worth a visit. You can also see a production of their water puppet theatre within the grounds.

Impressive. Museum offers comprehensive view of Vietnamese demographic structure. Way of housing and habits of more than 50 Vietnamese native people groups are presented in organized and clear manner. Must!

Very informational museum. This museum provides information on the more than 50 ethnic groups in Viet nam. It provides information about their art, their beliefs, their customs and even provides the opportunity to visit traditional housing. Well worth the visit.

Best museum of Hanoi. Best museum in Hanoi I would say. I am Hanoian and I've visited the museum several times, however, it still wows me every time I visit it. A diversity of ethnic and religion, many types of demonstration, often organize events. It is going to be the Mid-Autumn festival of Vietnam so the museum will definitely organize some activities for families and children. Can't wait for it!

The most interesting Museums in Hanoi and Vietnam. The Museum comes out of the recognition that Vietnam is a multi-ethnic country and that more attention should be paid to promote socio-cultural diversity. Despite being out of the way compared with other museums in Hanoi, Vietnam Museum of Ethnology is worth a thorough visit, for those who are keen to learn about the multiculturality of Vietnam and for those who would appreciate some green space.ou will be blown away by the elaboration of these architectures, at the same time being thoroughly engaged in traditional games and activities such as water puppet show, calligraphy, stone game (O An Quan). The museum is especially a great choice for those who cannot find time to visit all remote areas where live the majority of Vietnam ethnic minoritie

A Unexpected Surprize. Expecting to be overwhelmed by a chaotic display of artifacts, badly organized and displayed, I was delighted to experience the Museum of Ethnology. Carefully curated, and beautifully designed, the buildings that house this collection are also visually appealing, and a great place to spend to an afternoon or even a day. What took the displays to the next level, were the videos spaced appropriately through some of the collections, showing in detail the process by which some of the artifacts are made. My daughter especially enjoyed visiting the model homes in the courtyard. I would highly recommend this museum, and feel ashamed for my pre-conceived notions as to what to expect.

Great Museum to learn about the different tribes in Vietnam. To get to the Museum of Ethnology you would most probably need a scooter or a taxi ride. The Musuem comprises of indoor and outdoor exhibits and is very interesting to learn about the different vietnamese tribes. each have their own unique art and crafts.
Nice Museum. It is very interesting and information of Vietnamese people. With the indoors and out door museum. Indoor museum was abit hot and humid. No fans

A great museum not to be missed. Well worth the taxi ride to this interesting museum on the different tribes and their amazing arts and crafts. There are a number of fascinating houses and structures from around Vietnam in the grounds of the Museum. A great exhibition too on the people of SE Asia. Good shop and cafe (excellent coffee) too!

Outside better than inside. Inside are details of the multiple different groups of Vietnamese people; their origins, geographical location and numbers left. Outside are full size examples of dwellings from the different groups. Well worth the visit.

A great day out!. A great museum to learn about all of the different ethnicities of the nation. Beautiful traditional clothes, tools, etc are on display and give you a real insight into what life is like all over Vietnam. We also saw a genuine water puppet show which was definitely interesting! Outside there are also huts/houses that you can venture into and explore, if you don't mind the heat!

quite interesting. huge building and interesting exhibits but kind of the same thing each time about each tribe. It is a little far out the city but good if you want to learn more about the people of Vietnam, didn't give much on the history of the country though. I liked that there were some interviews and videos you could watch.

loved it. we went on a guided tour through this museum and it was incredibly fascinating! the outside had hands on exhibits where you can go inside and explore the ancient homes and artifacts. you could really get a feel for the time period.

Best place to study Vietnamese culture. This place has the fullest information about Vietnamese people. They built the models to describe each folks. Compared to other museums in Hanoi this one is highly recommend if you have limited time to travel. You should try to come here on Saturday afternoon to see the Water puppet show as it already included in your ticket. It saved quite a lot for you since you can see more instead of buying another ticket for WPS especially for backpackers.

Interesting place to spend a couple of hours. Gives a unique insight into the lifestyle of different ethnic minority groups across Hanoi. I recommend taking a tour guide (we used Hanoi Kids) so they may explain/talk you through the various exhibits.
Useful and instresting. Here you can get much knowledge of Vietnamese ethnics. There are many artifacts and pictúe, clip á ưell. It really helps you to have an actual view of daily life.

A Snapshot of the ASEAN cultural heritage. The Vietnam museum of ethnology is a big compound with actual houses from Vietnam's cultural groups. What I loved about it was that it also showcased the different ASEAN countries' cultural artifacts and showed how it interplayed with that of Vietnam's history. We went to the three areas:1. The compound which showed the practices of the different cultural groups and the interrelation of the linguistic groups in Asia.2. The southeast asian building which housed the arts and crafts of the ASEAN countries.3. The actual houses of Vietnamese cultural groups.What I liked best were the houses as it was very interactive and you could really see how the Vietnamese forefathers lived.
A wonderful cultural experience. if only the museum was better air-conditioned, this place would be perfect. Notwithstanding, it gives a good introduction to the diversity of culture in Vietnam.
ethnalagy. i like to go to the vietnam museum of ethnolagy because there are many foreigners who come there. i can speak english with them. but after i have gone some times i really like the place.

Lively museum. The real life of all ethnic groups around Vietnam was brought to this museum with in-door and out-door area. Otherwise there is also a place to show some typical ethnic in Southeast Asia. They spend an area for the special exhibition

Would be 5 stars if only they had A/C. Very interesting museum. Take about 2 hours for a full visit. Exhibition inside the buildings is colorful and provides lots of info. In the garden you will find village houses of many kinds.
Visit the Etnologimuseum. Great way to learn about the Vietnamise history and see the difference in the society. With a guide it is very interesting.

Customs preserved. This was the best part for me personally of the APT Tours city tour. While it was busy, packed with tourists, school children, local families and ordinary Vietnamese, it allowed one to understand the hereditary makeup of the people of Vietnam from their origins, groupings, lifestyle, customs, dialects and beliefs. The outdoor museum allows visitors to experience being inside some of the traditional dwellings of some of the groups and a water puppets show if offered for free on Sundays if one is fortunate enough to find a seat for this popular traditional performance. A must-do in Vietnam to meet the people in one place.
Interesting. This will take about 1 to 2 hours to visit if you stop to read everything carefully.There are several fascinating insights into the cilture of the country,so worth a visit.

Amazing museum of both Vietnam & Asia Pacific countries. There are several groups in Vietnam depending on the place of their origin ( like the Viet group, the Cham groups etc)Their lifestyle , house or home models and their culture is preserved in the ethnology museumThere are also open water puppet shows which one can watch while at the museum
Interesting . A bit away but worth the trip. Interesting collection of Vietnamese houses with furnishings. The main building also well curated.

Informative. We spent some time here, with the goal of acquiring a sense of real Vietnamese culture. We certainly gained this, with the exhibits providing an insight into the incredible cultural diversity that constitutes Viet Nam today. Well worth the effort.

Good for raining day if interests you. We went on a rainy day. Good way out of town but taxis cheap. If the tribal aspects interests you then a good choice. Also museum of south-east Asia next door which we did not stay for.

One of a kind . This gives such a valuable insight to the world of Vietnam. I learnt a lot about the people and culture of different parts of Vietnam. United as a country, yet divided geographically with generations of tradition and language. The outside has walk in houses to give you a feel of how they lived or still do in the highlands. It was a great opportunity and I definitely recommend it.
A must during your visit. Viet Nam is so rich in its ethnic groups. This beautiful Museum allows you to take a glimpse at the diversity of this beautiful country. A half day is not enough.
It is OK. Will not purposely schedule a tour of it. The outside of the museum to learn how different groups live is interesting.
Very interesting place to visit. Nice place to visit. It tell you a lot about the history and Vietnamese people and all ethnic groups and their culture.

On the list but could be much better . We came here as still had some time on our last day and thought we would immerse ourselves in a little culture.It was nice and open inside with OK displays but could be bit more interestingly put together to make it more memorable .Just skimmed through the exhibits then left within 45 minutes.I suppose there is s very interesting recent history that pervades North Vietnam that is a world away from this showcase.Since you have to pay to gain entrance I might suggest you try elsewhere first egHCM memorial.TipIf you have older children or students travelling with you showing college / university pass get in half price to all public museums etc. Tip do not get into a taxi if a helpful bystander , someone outside suggest you take this one .We did and the driver just took us randomly around the town with a meter on fast forward and I finally asked him to drop us near the lake as he did not know where he was going to our surprise.This useless ride cost 220K Vietnamese Dong, which was only about 10 US dollars but still be careful.All of our other taxi trips have been between 6 K VND ( 30 cent )and about 60 K VND $3All green taxis and vinasun taxi were reputable and the service throughout other than that one was much better than anticipated.

Mixed feelings. This museum must have started with grand ambitions: vast area housing model villages for each of the ethnic minorities of VIetnam. Today large parts of it are in a state of disrepair. Sidewalks are overgrown with weeds. When we went there (week day afternoon), there were no other tourists. Apparently the situation is better on weekends. The government has brought in people from the respective ethnicities to many of the villages. They are paid to stay there 24/7 and dress up in their national costumes to entertain visitors. We visited two such houses. In the first, the residents were overjoyed to see us because they had been bored to no end having had no visitors. They said they are paid around $60 a month for living there but could earn more had they stayed in their own village. They were very happy to talk with us, perform a song and give us tea. When we offered them a little money as thanks, they didn't want to take it. The second house was a bit more organized (had a shop where they sold clothes and other handicraft) but were equally bored.I had mixed feelings because on the one hand it does not seem right to truck in people of ethnic communities from their original villages and put them on display. On the other hand, a tourist like me who only had time to visit Ha Noi would not have had the chance to meet ethnic minorities.

A must-see in Hanoi, a great museum in- and out-door. Probably the most interesting museum in Hanoi. A great collection of master-pieces and a great outlook on minorities. We could spend hours there. You must also take time to visit the out-door part of the museum with houses of the Vietnamese minorities.

Worth to visit. Proper place to visit to understand the life of Vietnamese people and nice to see the equipment for cultivation and related activities. It is also worth to see the huts/houses where they are living in order to avoid the challenges around the nature.

gud place to details about vietnamese culture and ethnicity. all details minutely placed with gud exposure of what vietn. gud place to details about vietnamese culture and ethnicity. all details minutely placed with gud exposure of what vietnam is all about. well maintained and neat but jus lack air conditioner at few place and fan too is in shortage
Overwhelming. So much to see here. I felt completely fatigued by all the information. But in a good way. Might be worth more than one visit.If nothing else, come to see the tribal buildings outside.

Lovely place for a rainy day. Learned a great deal a the museum. It is definitely a day trip and your head will feel full of new information after your visit, but it is well worth the time. Make sure to visit the village house replicas behind the main museum. It gives one a whole new insight into the groups that populate Vietnam in a way you can't get from words alone.
Great place to visit.. We spent most of our day being shown around here by our guide (Hanoi Kids) this was a really good chance to get an understand of the ethnic make up of Vietnam. Very diverse.

Nice!. Here you could have an overview of Vietnam ethnic groups. Buildings of different groups with customs, cultures through exhibits were very well displayed. You would know how they live no need coming to the their villages. Well worht a vist.
most interesting museum in Hanoi. come here and you will see what i said. Outside exhibition is more interesting than inside museum. they have different houses of ethnic tribes
Amazing!. Beautiful collection from all over asia. This museum offers an introduction to the different ethnic groups in Vietnam.

The best way to deep into Vietnamese Minorities. This Museum is one of the most worth to visit. It is really pleasant and agile to go through. You will find the legend tags in English, Vietnamese and French. I absolutely loved the fact that you find the real size houses open for visiting. Their smell and texture will make you feel as if you were in the real rural environment.

Exotic. The location is not close to the centre. Take taxi from Hoam Kien Lake to there cost 100K VND.As a asian, easier find plenty similar symbols! The outdoor exhibition is better than indoors! The weather is hot and only in the lobby use air conditioner. The ticket price is 20K VND/person.蠻值得一去參觀，但位置稍微遠離市中心（還劍湖和舊城區），我從還劍湖附近搭正常跳表計程車是100K盾。天氣很熱但我認為室外展示區比室內好，室內展區也只有一樓有冷氣。外國人門票是一人20K盾。
Good Museum. A very good museum where display many things about different ethnic groups of Vietnam. It's big one with many houses. Well worth a visit.

Fascinating insight into how the different ethnic groups of Vietnam live. The houses that the minority ethnic groups to Vietnam was fascinating in showing how they lived and how their culture was reflected in their homes and environment. It is definately worth a look.

Not bad but prescindible. Good to get an idea of the variety of the country's ethnic complexities, but not a "must" in the city. It provides a good overview of the way the build their houses but it's advisable to have a guide with you to get deeper explanations.
Good to experience. The museum gives you a good idea of the minorities living in Vietnam. Especially when you meet them during your trip.
Visiting The museum of Ethnology. Very well displayed but an English speaking guide was essential to understand the history of the various peoples of Vietnam.

Excellent contents but no airconditioner!. Great museum having well presentation. Informative! However, it is not a air conditioned building that it was a bit hard to concentrate as much as I could. Other than that, it is great visit.

Understanding the people of Vietnam,. Nice museum . Provides an in depth understanding about the life and customs of various ethnic tribes of Vietnam. Must visit for people considering longer stay in the country and understanding local customs.

People of Vietnam- past and present. Extensive and interesting displays of ethnic people comprising Vietnam of the past and modern day showing their behaviour, housing and way of life. Outside exhibits showing houses are worth a visit as is the excellent display of textiles and art work in the building adjacent the main museum.The museum is well worth a visit.

magnificant handicrafts. My 12 year old son loved this museum. There is an outdoor section with traditional houses and videos showing how they were constructed. Inside is an extensive collection of minority handicrafts. Totally absorbing and a beautifully cool place to wander.
Museum Ethnology. Ethnology museum was a taxis ride from old city but very cheap trip.Well worth the visit, especially if you are going to be travelling to Sa Pa or Dalat.

History of a complex enthnic mix.. this museum chronicals the many ethnic groups that have become Vietnam. Outside there are examples of traditional housing from the different regions, why each style was chosen and how it was used. Inside - the histories of the cultures are examined and artifacts are displayed. Multi-lingual signage allows self exploration, or guided tours were available.
very informative, important to know. It gives you a good insight in the people who live in Vietnam. The museum is a bit outside the old quarter so I'd advise to take a cab

Last minute visit before departure. It wasn't a lot of time (considering it only opens at 8:30 am). But my friend insisted on bringing me to this museum. It is interesting to see the architecture, tools, costumes and culture of the 54 ethnic tribes of Vietnam and you discover that the ethnic tribes include tribal peoples from Southern China and Thailand. Having less than 2 hours did not do justice to the many exhibits although I got to see the inside museum and the outdoor displays. Half a day might have been better.

Museum Dedicated to the Ethnic Minorities. Vietnam has over 50 ethnic minorities, something most people may not be aware of. This museum tries to encapsulate the best of their characterstics in terms of attire, implements, traditions etc. There in an out door display of life sized houses of different styles which is easily missed if you don't know about it.

Interesting and informative. I visited the museum twice; the 1st time a part of a full day tour of Hanoi, the 2nd time was just to enjoy it. It displayed ethnic groups of Vietnam and the cultures in South East Asia. Thoroughly enjoyed it.
Very educational. Lots of reading , very interesting if you do a tour with a tour group , they can explain what it all means ,
Absolute waste of time.. Spending time and money to get there is not worth it, the museum is filled with text and information but the few models lack any real excitement. Better to see!

Very interesting, too bad it is not air conditioned. Very interesting exhibit of the 54 different nations that make up the Vietnam population. Learn about the culture, living quarters and traditions of each people by location and history. Outdoor and indoor exhibits available.

Especially enjoyed the houses. We did not know what to expect from this museum, and were pleasantly surprised. We enjoyed both museum buildings. The Southeast asia museum is the modern building to the right of the book shop as you enter. Many people seemed to miss this. We especially enjoyed walking through the different style houses that have been built in a peaceful area behind the museum buildings. Once we explored all of the houses, we stopped for a nice lunch at the restaurant. Signs say that the people working there are deaf and are being trained to improve their quality of life. We enjoyed lunch there. It was a nice respite after a number of hours on our feet.

interesting place. The place is good insight about cultural ethnic of Vietnam, we were impressed with a high cottage, kids were very fun to climb on the house, which was lovely scene. Exhibited room was so hot, outside atmosphere was cool and windy.

Expected a little more of the first thing to visit in Hanoi. It costs 40.000 vnd/person. A little less than 2€. We have spent 2 hours there. Consequently, it's an excellent price for spending about 2 hours there.But I thought I would a little more impressed by it.I don't really know what was missing but I didn't felt the 'waow effect'.Still very interesting to do. My family was suffering from the heat and were pushing me to speed up. That's maybe part of the explaination.Inside, you can hire a guide which will maybe be able to cheer up the group. I forgot the price, so ask at the entrance of the hall at the 2 ladies on your left.

Outstanding Museum: Admission less than US$2. This is absolutely the best museum I visited while in Vietnam. There are two buildings (one Vietnamese related and one South East Asia related) and an outdoor area. I probably spent three hours here and ate at the on-site restaurant. The museum is located a good distance from the Old Quarter and a taxi cost about US$4.Fantastic museum that should be visited by anyone who goes to Hanoi.

Pretty Average, but cheap souveniers if that is what you are looking for. Worth a visit if you have time to spare, but if you are time pressed, there are better options, It does give you a better understanding of the Vietnamese minorities in the central highlands

Fun afternoon. The indoor exhibits are informative enough but the real draw are the life-size minority group houses in the massive gardens outside. There's also a water puppet theatre. No photos inside unless you buy a ticket, but everyone was taking pictures anyway and it was okay.

A great place to better understand Vietnam. This museum really is a great place to better understand Vietnam. There are both inside and outside displays. You get to see houses from different provinces of Vietnam. A must in Vietnam.
Outside is not so intersting!. You should looking the display house in the middle as long as possible that will help you understand about the local minorities people than outside

Good introduction to vietnamese culture. This museum provides a really nice overview of the different ethnic cultures in Vietnam. A bit too much about the clothing for my taste, but the houses outside were very good. Kids had fun climbing in and out the houses. The restaurant was quite nice considering this is a museum restaurant.

Amazing . So interested
There are many kind of house of each ethnologies.
Different cultures different areas
Local in center , far from old street about 7 km, u can take the bus 14 to here

Awesome structures, worth a visit. Wow I'm not usually a museum person but this brings to life the culture of the Vietnamese.My wife and I went there and although the main museum part was interesting (lots of reading as per normal museum), the best part was the buildings.There is a large landscape of buildings and the best part is you can go in them and have a look.We were most impresses by the 19m high thatched roof one.I'm 30 and not into architecture nether is my wife but we ended up spending a good hour and a half but we would have pushed over 2 hours f not for the rain.I would highly recommend this and also, get a guide from the front that can speak your language.We didn't and we regretted the information that had for people (we eavesdropped haha)

Great collection of ethnic minority textiles and artifacts. If you can't make it up north to the mountains (Sapa, for ex), definitely go to the Ethnology museum for a great collection of ethnic minority textiles, houses (they actually have recreations of the houses!) and other objects. It's well put together and really gives you an idea of the different cultures. If you are going up north, you will see most of the stuff in person, so it's not really necessary if you don't have loads of time! Also, there is a free water puppet show once or twice a day. Great way to see a water puppet show if you're not keen on sitting though a whole performance

Fascinating variety of buildings.. A fascinating combination of open air buildings from multiple ethnic groups within Vietnam, and displays inside the main museum. You could easily spend half a day here if you wanted to.

Great museum in Ha Noi. The museum about 54 ethnologies in Viet nam. It has two part inside and outside. Inside you can see all their image of life, foods, tools... and outside it show house of some ethnologies. I was there few times but I still want to go back there.

Architecture garden with excellent reconstructed huts. Very interesting museum covering the complex array of ethnic/cultural groups in Vietnam in interesting and informative displays. We loved the outdoor reconstructed homes/architecture - we nearly skipped this due to the heat and time constraints, but this would have been a mistake.

Great museum. Good insight into the different ethnic groups in Vietnam. Houses behind the museum building are also interesting. Limited air con inside so it can be pretty hot and sticky. Nice cafe next to the museum.
Okay inside, great outside. The houses and grounds were very interesting and beautiful! Inside is hot, not very well displayed, and not as well done as other museums in Asia.

Best museum ever. The museum has thousands of exhibits, with very clear and easy information for the visitor. It highlighted the ethnic groups of the country and also its rich culture and history. It was worth the 2 hours there. Highly recommended

The best ethnology museum I have been to. Excellent mix of an indoor museum with information on the different people of Vietnam, their clothes, way of life etc, and an outdoor museum with re-built traditional houses. There's also free water puppet performances. Don't miss the modern building to the right of the restaurant - it's a very good South-East Asian summary of artefacts, costumes, and jewellery etc (it's also air-conditioned and cool which is nice after the hot outside stuff). Overall an excellent museum, we spent 4 hours there and were never bored. A nice little restaurant/cafe as well.

Superb examples of traditional houses in the outdoor area and beutiful displays of artefacts. This is actually three for the price of one as in addition to the two seperate musea (ethnology and Se Asia), there is also large outdoor set of exhibits with displays of traditional village houses from many regions of Vietnam plus water puppet show and more. Outdoor area is worth visiting first, especially on a cooler summer morning. There is limited wifi in the new museum building in case you need it. Beautiful displays of textiles, household items. I enjoyed extensive multimedia displays. Good to visit for at least half a day.

Was hit and miss.. Some of the museum was really interesting but it got a bit repetitive after a while and wasn't well air conditioned inside the actual building. The outside huts were fun though and well worth the visit.

Would be Cooler if Cooler!. Inside exhibits were just too hot in the afternoon! Breezed through them quickly. Outside replicas of housing were more interesting although not that different from what we 've seen at cultural museums in Indonesia and other countries. Worth stopping by for a visit. Worth spending an hour or so. Water puppet show on when we visited. Cost 100 VND from Old Quarter hotel.

The best museum in Hanoi :). I think the price to come is cheap, very cheap... museum is so big and many many structures about more than 55 ethnic in Vietnam same as San House, Rong House... With a heart of a Vietnamese, I think this museum is the best choice if you really want to know all about ethnic republic in Vietnam :) oh oh, in this museum has the Aswan house :) that's good for Indonesian, Indian, Laos, Cambodian...

compare to other museum i saw in hcm, this is the 2nd least interesting. Well, i find that the outdoor is more interesting than the indoor museum exp the first part of museum. Because Indonesian also has many of tribes so i feel that the tribe of vietnamese are almost alike that i can find in Indonesian museum.i skipped the 2nd building because i was bored and it was raining, and start to walk around the outdoor it feel different, better and more wow I find lots of interesting buildings outside, ... unique, rare

Interesting. If you are visiting Vietnam this is a must. Try to visit on a cool day as the place was too hot to spend the time I wanted. Lots of interesting info. On the ethnic people who make up Vietnam.

Interesting overview of ethnic groups. We went to this museum on our last day in Hanoi and found it interesting and well set out; however, one downside it is quite a distance from the old quarter.Expect to pay 80-100k dong each way for a taxi. Entry is 40k per adult.The museum itself is partly indoors and outdoors. The indoor portion takes you through the culture of the major ethnic groups, their clothing and ceremonial customs etc.The outdoor section is a large area where they have made replica traditional houses for you to walk through and explore.

Very interesting afternoon. We really enjoyed our visit to this museum, particularly the exhibits in the textile rooms and the model houses on the property. The setting is serene and the exhibits are interesting. Worth a few hours, for sure.

VME. The first 5 or 6 ethnic groups were pretty interesting but the remaining 48 all blurred into the same so it was hard to differentiate. The low wattage light bulbs made it hard to read the descriptions but if you read them all you're probably an anthropologist or have Aspergers

Amazing Museum!. Great place to go, amazing knowledge about all ethical groups of Vietnam. Amazing models of the houses of the groups in the park - quite impressive! Only negative thing is that the museum's location is quite hard to reach besides taxi.

Worth Visiting. Excellent exhibits - provides an interesting perspective to the number of minority tribes in Vietnam. Exhibits and photos provide a better appreciation of their customs and culture. Real life-size houses of the different tribes were most intriguing. My teenage kids were busy climbing into the homes with stilt stairs and narrow doors. The museum 's restaurant serves good local food. It is run by a non-profit organization for unprivileged teenagers.

recommended. I am not a museum person as such, the first part which was inside was good but not the best. The outside part had houses for the differents ethnics, tombs etc and this was good.Definetly recomment to any ine interested in vietnamese ethnology and traditions

Very interesting!!!!!. We went to this museum to pass some time on our last day...soooooo glad we did! Two big buildings of fabulous displays showing not only Vietnam's history, but South-East Asia!There were replica houses built from different eras and regions. We are glad we came and would highly recommend it!!!D40,000 entry feeNeed to catch transport as it's a good 7km out of the city.Uber from Old Quarter: approx D45,000Taxi back to old quarter D75,000

One Way to Learn About Vietnam and Its People and Culture. It is a huge museum and I would add probably a must do on a visit to Hanoi, the museum was divided into different tribes and had depiction of their lives, dressing, culture, living, etc and also their background and history. An interesting way to showcase the lives of the people of the country.Outside they had physical homes as well so that one is able to easily visualise the different types of homes.Other than one portion where there were Australian painting, it was completely non air conditioned and closed, really hot and claustrophobic environment, need to address the same. There is another museum though not completely ready but partly functional, this had an aircon and wonderful paintings. Don't purchase anything from the souvenir shop as really expensive and same things are much cheaper outside. One can decide to spend half a day here easily during a visit to the city.

Interesting if you are into history & culture. There are lots of different ethnics in vietnam. Lots to see and information to those that are interested in the culture & history. The place is a warm and without aircond in most of the area accept the main entrance. We rush through the sections as it was very warm and humid. Only visit this place if you are into museums. As for myself, i could easily skip this activity.

Informative. Very informative, lots of english description and well laid out. Could spend hours reading everything and watching all the videos or browse through in less than an hour. The info is actually a little overwhelming and starts to all blend together though if you're not super into ethnology (i am a bit). Worth the small entrance fee.

interesting but... cool to learn about the different vietnamese people. If you're at all interested in learning about their different customs and heritages check it out. I personally found it to be less interesting than the Ho Chi Minh museum but others may not. Pretty hot in most of the museum except the entrance. Reasonably priced and worth checking out if you are in the area.
One of the best. A really interesting museum. I wish I'd gone before travelling in the north - it would have made my travelling choices better.

Fantastic but not enough time. We only had a couple of hours to experience this facility. I feel that you could easily spend 4 hours here. It is truly fantastic and so much of interest to see and take in.

Never ever skip this place!. To know Vietnam is to learn their nation and history. And here is the place! They have indoor area and outdoor area. You can see their authentic house and decor in their unique styles. And you can watch free water puppet here.

A very interesting and informative museum. They have a free outdoor water puppet show.
The inside section shows a lot of the traditional clothes and tools of different ethnicity in Vietnam; models of their houses were also exhibited. While there were actual houses of different kinds in the outdoor section, which was a lot of fun to check out!

A must visit place in Hanoi. This was not in our initial itinerary but our guide recommended we drop some other activity and visit the museum instead and I am glad we did. The museum provides an overall view of ethnic groups in Vietnam - as a bonus we also were able to attend a water puppet show which takes place at regular intervals.

Interesting history of vietnamese life and culture. The display of the traditional homes was worth seeing. Some of the internal displays of old treasures, and suspect "not so old" gives a good insight into the Vietnamese and their enthinticity. Very hot inside the buildings and rude noisy asian tourists distracting

Bare . If I had the choice I would not of done this. It was disappointing. Three floors and not really filled with exhibits to fill the size of the rooms. It's not air conditioned and so hot inside. The exhibit explanations are in English also.

Amazing house reproductions!. The interior of the museum is moderately interesting, although all the different ethnic groups started to blur together in my mind (spoilers: they all eat rice, all make clothes from dyed plant fibers, and all have markets). Really the star of this museum is the outdoor walk where houses from each of the ethnic groups has been faithfully reproduced (in some cases, by members of the ethnic group). You can walk into a traditional clay and brick house, stroll along a longhouse that slept 40, and climb up a hewn log ladder into a stilt house with 20 foot high ceilings.If traveling in the summer, don't expect a respite from the heat. The indoor part of the museum has air conditioners, but leaves all their doors open, so they're just wasting energy.

Give very interesting information about Vietnameese culture. You should visit this place to get interesting information about Vietnameese culture and history. I advice you to vithit this museum. The entrance is cheap, and the information is full.
Little Vietnam. Bring many friends come here many times. Each time enjoy and get knowledge about ethnic people and their culture. I thought i can be tourguide hahaha

Glad I Visited. Unfortunately, the facility is very uneven. There are interesting displays on the variety of cultures in Vietnam, but very little on the interaction of the cultures ... you would think that every group lived in isolation (perhaps they do). The best part was the outdoor display of traditional homes/communal buildings; the least interesting part the "new" building which has displays devoted, frankly, to the eclectic tastes of some prominent collectors who have donated their trove to the museum (though the building is air conditioned).

Boring. Feels like a mandatory school field trip that the kids hate. If anything, blow through this in 15-30 minutes. It's modestly interesting in parts, but it's a bit dull. It feels like a part of the itinerary that they force you to join out of cultural respect and education. It was dull. It felt like an anthropology mandatory field trip. Seen one mud hut, you've seen em all! The Cham Museum in Dan Nang is much better.

History of native land. The place is quite informative. It tries to highlight the original tribes of the country. It showcases the history and rich culture of the native people of the land. Worth a visit.

Educational and Fun!. Nothing beats learning when you actually have fun doing it. Not only that, what the Museum teaches you are things in their culture in which you will be able to see, hear and touch. They preserved the exact items from the past and made life-sized replicas just so you would be able to see how they do things and the technology behind such products.I love the fact that you are able to get into houses and actually climb up and look around. I also love the fact that the place is very spacious which allows me and my son to walk around. Each place is divided for a different ethnic group or category. This allows you to visualize yourself going into a different village or so.Overall, the price and time spent here is absolutely worth the experience!
Educational!. Very interesting museum of Vietnam. We learnt a lot about the people and culture here. The museum are spac. It is fun to discover house on stilt too

Best Museum in Hanoi. This is a great museum, mostly outdoor... showing the ethnic history of Vietnam. DUring a weekend, the price is slightly higher, but includes a water puppet show that is actually authentic... not like the one in the old quarter. I extremely liked the fertility house exterior :-D The outside shows many example homes that the Vietnamese used to live in, in different provinces in Vietnam over the centuries. It's beautiful and fun to walk around on a sunny morning or early afternoon. The interior of the museum has progressed over the years. I've lived in Hanoi for more than five years and have been here several times and will return several more times. Definitely worth a visit while in Hanoi.

Very interesting! . There was a lot to see here and I learned a lot about different ethnic group and traditional housing. There was also a section of the museum about sex education and LGBT rights in Vietnam which was very interesting.

Totally Amazing Museum. I wasn't sure how interesting this would be. I've been to a lot of museums that cover ethnology, but this one is exceptionally fascinating. I was on a tour so only spend about 90 minutes, but I could easily spend 5+ hours. There are some extremely interesting movies that cover cultural practices related to funerals, home building, etc. The life size homes outside are unbelievable. If I ever go back to Hanoi, I will make a second trip here just to spend more time.

Very informative - go by bus!. Really enjoyed this museum. We had just been to Sapa to spend time in some of the tribal villages, and it was great to be able to learn more about their history. English information was really good.Fantastic examples of different houses by tribe in the gardens outside.Quite a way out of city centre by can go by local bus on the cheap. Number 14. Goes from north side of the lake. Tell the conductor where you're going, he will let you know where to get off (we also followed ourselves on google maps just in case.....)

nice way to spend an hour or 2. loved the various housing exhibits. We also enjoyed the gift shop. I purchased many things that were different than the usual things you find at each tourist stop.Cute little coffee shop next to museum too!
Inside museum only. Visited mainly the inside of the museum as the day was extremely hot when we went. 115 heat index. Great understanding of the country and different cultures within Vietnam.

Nice place . If you want to explore the life of ethnic people that much, I highly recommend you should take a tour to Sapa or Mai Chau. There's much more than just seeing a few typical points in here.
Strange!. Wow. There are many interesting thing I have never seen before. Those house in stilts are very beutiful

Morning visit to the museum of ethnology. Very interesting museum providing lots of information on the different ethnic groups of Vietnam as well as south east Asia. Out side they have a little park with the different house of Vietnam. Good to do early in your trip so you know a bit more about Vietnam and its people at the start. Only downside was they on had fans no AC.

A rather average museum.. Known as "Vietnam best museum" by locals, we had high expectations from this place.This was our first mistake.Our second mistake was that we though it'd take us 3-4 hours to fully explore the museum.Well, the museum is small, the artifacts are rather sparse and most of them don't have enough English information on them.The building itself is almost crumbling with dirty walls and total lack of care.The outside exhibits are just as dull - bug straw huts with very little information about them and their role in the country's history and life.You can easily go through this museum in less than an hour.That's what we did and we did not skip a single exhibit.Ticket is only 2USD.
Interesting museum. very interesting collections,nice gardens, nice buildings , a bit far away from the city center yet worthy to be seen. Nice little restaurant
Nice visit!. This's best of those we visited when in Hanoi. It's very large with many buildings and exhibits of Vietnam ethnic fgroups. Much to learn about Vietnam culture here!
Excellent!. Very informative museum .. set out well .. but hot! Gardens contained real tribal buildings which we could walk through. Had lunch at the restaurant and enjoyed it.

WORTH A VISIT. This museum definitely surpassed my expectations. I was never bored the entire time I was there. Truly an educational tour. Should you want to take pictures, you have to pay an extra fee for this. You have to mention this while buying your entrance ticket to the museum. It is worth your visit.

Very interesting. We visited this with our lovely guides from the Hanoi free tour company. The museum is beautifully set up with lots of space to walk about and learn about the different ethnic groups in Vietnam. All exhibits had descriptions in Vietnamese, English and French. Expect to spend at least two hours here.

a glimpse into the different tribes. this museum was educational as I had no idea that there were so many different tribes in Vietnam. From the traditional dress, to the various construction techniques in housing to the music. It was both inside and outside, outside having reconstructed buildings and homes

Full of interest. If you have any interest in history and culture then I recommend this place. Lots of displays and information for the curious but also lots of places to climb around for kids. I learnt more about Vietnam in a couple of hours here than I did anywhere else. I could easily have stayed longer.
Interesting culture. Great for anyone who appreciates seeing traditional art and culture and learning about the way of life of the Vietnamese from different areas of Vietnam.

Interesting place. We spent about 2-3 hours here, and it was interesting. We had already been to Sa Pa, so some of it was familiar. I would not describe it as a must see museum, but if you have the time it is worth seeing. The best bit is the houses/villages they have outside, you can walk in to the buildings and feel the atmosphere. You will need to take a taxi here. It cost us about 80,000 each way.

ethnic museum vietnamese. When you visit Hanoi, shouldn't miss Ethonogy museum, it was nice, I saw a lot of things about Vietnamese ethics -there cuture, the clothes....I really like it. very worth to spend time!

Interesting information about the ethnic groups. Came here as part of the city tour i was on. Very interesting, well maintained and good escape from the summer heat. Takes around 2 hours to complete the museum tour. Most interesting area is the outside, where the houses of different ethnic groups are constructed. Not to be missed!

Better than it sounds. Who knew there were so many ethnicities represented in this region. There were lots of overlap between the various tribes' lifestyles, but the differences were fascinating. Be sure to check out the houses behind the museum to better appreciate the way the various ethnicities live.

Interesting place. We were in there in May 2016 with 3 adults and 3 kids, 3, 8 and 12 years. It was very interesting to see the inside of the museum showing all the different cultures in Vietnam. But the outside was also very interesting to see. There was build houses as in the old days where you can enter and see then inside. The outside was best for the kids as they could move around. The inside is not that interesting for kids age below 12.It was quite warm when we were there so the inside was pretty hot for all of us. Even though they had fans placed around. If you are in Hanoi some days I think this is worth a visit. It will take you two hours and you have seen most of it.

Great Museum of Hanoi. I had a full day city tour in Hanoi. We visit a temple, Ho Chi Minh museum, Old Quarter and the Museum of Ethnology. This is one of the best museum i have ever visited. Nice and peaceful to walk around. A lot of thing about Vietnamese here. Love the outside area. There was a water puppet show which is really interesting. definitely worth to try.

See it when in Hanoi. I very pleasant way to spend 2 or 3 hours, and get a bit of insight into the Vietnamese diversity. The museum is very new, with modern architecture. It has 3 sections: a large building dedicated to Vietnam people, a large open area with reconstructions of houses, tombs used by the different Vietnamese groups, and a second large building dedicated to SE-Asian people. I would not recommend the last building, unless you are strongly interested in fabrics, etc from SE Asia. However, the Vietnamese building was far more interesting...good exhibits well explained (including English and French). But I found the highlight to be the outside garden. Basically, they had employed craftsmen from the tribal areas to construct full size houses in the style of their home. Fascinating!There is also a nice restaurant/cafe on the site, for recovering from the heat

Actually Quite Good. Went here for a few hours and it was pretty interesting. Gets pretty hot in there though! Easy to catch a bus from the old quarter area over to here. Make sure you check out the South East Asia museum too as it is quite interesting, as well as all the houses around the outside. 40k for everything...worth it.

A sense of historic Vietnam . A little out of the centre but cheap enough in a taxi. A fairly modern building with historic artifacts and information inside, but the highlight is in the rear outside area where they have built full sized thatch authentic communal buildings on stilts that you can walk around. If your into history without a mention of the war then its the place to go

Lots to see. This museum is extensive, with indoor and outdoor exhibits displaying traditional dress, fishing and hunting tools, and a range of handicrafts. If you're into weaving and spinning there's a fair bit to see. Signage is pretty well written, explaining the exhibits in Vietnamese, French and English. The outdoor part is shady and has lots of traditional houses. Do wear slip-on shoes of you want to go into the houses outdoors as you need to take your shoes on and off frequently. The toilets outside are much nicer than those inside the museum.The restaurant on site (not the Cafe next door) is a training restaurant for underprivileged youth. We had amazing coffee and a chocolate brownie that was delicious, the service was very good and the menu, like in many places in Hanoi, was also in English. The shop on site is a fair trade shop selling goods from various ethnic groups featuring traditional patterns and styles. It's well worth a look. Incidentally, there's another of these shops opposite the Temple of Literature.
Nice museum!. The museum was very big with many houses of local ethinic groups of Vietnam. Here we got some cultural and historical information of this beautiful country.

avarege. small museum,includes some clothes,household items,some pictures about the minorities.
One can see some nice clothes from all Vietnam.
