Ethnology. The museum was modern and well laid out. The displays were interesting and informative. There was no better way to get informed about the history and people of Vietnam. Go there your first day so that all other tours and adventures will be more relevant.

Huge museum . This places is amazing because you can see vietnamita culture of the tribus and small towns. Beside there is an entire building where there are information from all over asia. I went on a Sunday and there were many actitivities for free to emjoy with children like water puppets.
houses. I did not know there were so many minority people. I really enjoyed the tour of the houses and hearing how they are built.

Plan to Spend 3 Hours Here. Our family of 5 visited the Museum of Ethnology in May 2016. There is A LOT to see. The main building houses many artifacts, from clothing to pottery to household items of the 54 ethnic groups of Vietnam. A separate building houses an exhibit of Southeast Asia and artifacts and artwork from other parts of the world. Behind the main building, you can see the different types of housing used by various ethnic groups. We spent approximately 3 hours here. Exhibits are nicely displayed with plenty of description through plaques and supplementary videos. Note that there is minimal air conditioning in the main building and it can get quite hot. The outdoor exhibit may also prove difficult if it is an especially hot day. Overall, a fantastic experience for adults and children alike.

Museum of Ethonology. The museum provides visitors with a good insight into the many peoples that make the Vietnamese population. Viewing the various displays which are excellent is a must see before traveling to the hinterland of Vietnam. It is recommended but allow adequate time if you want to have a good look around

Vietnam is made up of Many Peoples. Great museum and there are replicas of dwellings of various ethnic people of Vietnam. These types of dwellings are still in use as we saw when we visited the hill tribes surrounding Sapa.

a cultural tour in a nutshell. A surprisingly comprehensive display.of the cultural diversity of Vietnam; it took us hours to go through it. And we saw a free water puppet show as a bonus. Well worth the visit and quite cheap. Glad we went.

Superb pmuseum. I am not a huge fan of museums but this place really kept me entertained for some hours. Lots of great things to learn about ethnic minorities. Especially if you dont get to go to Sapa or the Central highlands.

Good on a rainy day!! Just..... We visited with our Hanoi Kids ambassador. It's probably the only place to learn about the different cultural groups that make up the Vietnamese people. Exhibits are a little dull perhaps.
Would save for a rainy day when you've exhausted other possibilities.

Well worth a visit. We went into the two museums next to each other.Both were very good.Outside we were able to see a few different types of housing used by the different types of people living in Vietnam.

Interesting, informative and a great way to learn more about the Vietnamese culture; fun for our children. We decided to do the outdoor part of the Museum first in case it rained. The children (age almost 8 years) really enjoyed visiting the houses, looking inside each one, and doing various activities outdoors. It was a Sunday and so maybe they had more outdoor activities. One place had tops you could spin, another had stilts you could try to walk on, and being outdoors the children were free to move quickly from one place to the other. There was also a place making kites. The water puppet show was included in the Museum price, but not as fancy as the one in the theatre near the Hoan Kiem Lake. It was outdoors and quite interesting. There was English translation explaining each activity. Inside the museum there were various exhibits. This indoor 2 storey complex had lots of artifacts and pictures to explain the ethnic backgrounds and groups that make up the Vietnamese culture. Parents with younger children may find this part more challenging, but it was good for primary school and older children and adult. Overall quite an educational experience and one that should not be missed. If you are in Hanoi, be sure to make time for this. There was a bookstore and also a museum shop, but we didn't make it there. There is a restaurant, but apparently they only serve food at lunch-time, but you can get snacks, drinks otherwise. In May 2016 there was an adult price of about US$2.50 and children about $1.80; excellent value. Our one regret was that we didn't have more time - we found 3 hours was not enough and we could easily have stayed another hour. Besides that there is a great park for children across the road, but we didn't have time to spend there - which we would love to have done. If you have pre and primary school children, I would suggest you consider making it a day. You could take a picnic lunch and eat in the park and let the children play. If you are staying over in the Old Quarter or in that type of area near Hoan Kiem lake expect to pay about $5 by taxi to get to the park as it's several km away.

A fascinating look at Vietnam's diverse ethnic minorities. The main older portion, the outdoor water puppets and outdoor ethnic houses are extremely interesting. The newer building less so, but has some fascinating exhibits. An added touch is that it is a favorite place for Vietnamese couples to have their romantic wedding photo album made.

So worth your $2!!. This museum has 2 floors of historical information about Vietnamese ethic minority groups including: fabric weaving styles, dying, embroidery and fashion, home artifacts and accessories. Everything was well presented in 3 languages and there are great videos with awesome footage of all sorts of ceremonies and building or clothing making processes. One you leave the building...DON'T exit!! Walk to your left where the coffee and restaurant is (btw this is a good restaurant to support! It's run entirely by a hospitality school, and you're helping the students learn great service skills so they can get full-time employment after graduation) and you'll see what looks like a small park. Keep walking and you'll happen upon a huge village comprised of various minority group style homes! You can even go inside and check out how cool they are. All or most of the structures were built for the museum by minority group builders and artisans so they are sturdy, and quite amazing! Peeking around the houses took up a big chunk of time. Give yourself 3-4 hrs (including lunch/coffee break at cafe) if you want to see everything. The "craft link" not-for-profit organization shop is chock full of well-made gifts and crafts that seeks to "assist small Vietnamese craft producers to develop their businesses and find market opportunities...generating income for poor and marginalized people." Everything there is much better made than the usual tourist crap on the streets, and actually way cheaper. Go here for gifts!!

A celebration of diversity . Vietnam seems thoroughly proud of her many ethnic minority communities, which frankly, makes a refreshing change. The museum is very well planned and one that our easily distracted child genuinely enjoyed. We were very fortunate to have met with one of the Co Tu communities earlier on our trip and our son immediately recognised the replica structure of the community house the tribe use. We then explored all the others on display as well as taking in the indoor exhibits. Do try to fit this in if you can.

A Great Insight to Vietnam's Cultural Diversity. This is house of superb exhibitions of Vietnamese minority groups' culture. You are strongly recommended to visit the Museum with kids during Mid-Autumn Festival as they held the event featuring a wide range of activities and games such as making lanterns, crafting paper doctors, making moon cakes, pounding young rice grains, kneading coloured dough into paste fruits, decorating iron ship models etc.
Pretty cool . The outdoor houses and artifacts are the highlights to are great museum. And the gift shops are solid with local artisans at reasonable prices.

A brilliant museum. This is a must visit. A great insight to the buildings; traditions ; crafts and skills of many of the minority groups in Vietnam. The buildings are fantastic, as are the superb exhibitions in the main museum.The heat made this a little difficult to spend much time in the grounds, as I felt I could spend hours here. We were fortunate to have Tam as our guide, who offered great insight into the many exhibitions.

Great insight into Vietnamese history . One of the last places I have visited in Hanoi in my two trips to this wonderful city. Went with the HanoiKids tour which also is a must if you visit beautiful costumes and relics from the past but the best part is the original huts in which they lived in really something worth seeing and even better if you have the locals explaining things to you leave yourself around two hours when you visit.

The most interesting museum in Hanoi. This is the most interesting museum in Hanoi. This museum provides a deep understanding about culture, languages, custom of different 54 ethnic groups in Vietnam. It's worth visiting while being in Hanoi, Vietnam.

What an amazing museum! Great for everyone young and old!. One of the most interesting museums which explores the many people indigenous to Vietnam. Who knew there were so many? Fascinating. What is great is that the museum educates you both indoors and out. Once you get introduced you head outside and can explore villages...replicas from different parts of the country. They also have a huge (and awesome) Water Puppet Theater as well as an excellent book store and gift shop. The museum is a bit off the beaten path but is definately not to be missed. It will truly enhance your appreciation of and experience in the amazing country of Vietnam.

Worth a look. Very interesting overview of Vietnam's ethnic populations. This museum would be a great starting point for anyone going into the far north of the country, as this is where most of the ethnic minorities are located. We did not have the time to do that, so the visit to the museum was a great substitute,

Vietnam Ethnic Culture Museum. Good place to better understand the culture of Vietnam people and the many ethnic groups that make up Vietnam. Just good information in a simple set up to help visitor understand.

Vietnam's people .. a interesting educational place. Not really knowing what to expect at this museum, we came away with a greater insight & knowledge of this country's people, their many different ethnic groups,(over 50) heritage, customs and way of life..The outdoors area is amazing.. life size huts, cottages , buildings to show how they lived and some still do..An outdoor water puppet theatre is an added bonusInformation supplied in a modern easy to understand way.. our tour guide was excellent in the additional info too.

One of the best museums. This museum has an indoor and outdoor place, but the outdoor is much more exciting. I went in so many huts and even climbed ladders. It was interesting to see all their things and their beds. My tour guides told me alot about the way they live. Even though their huts and things were simple, they still proved their use .I highly recommend this for all ages. To understand Vietnamese culture, this is a must.

Good Understanding of Ethnic group in Vietnam. Rather than travelling all over the country to know the ethic groups in Vietnam, the Museum of Ethnology in Hanoi give an insight of many ethnic groups who reside in different part of Vietnam. The outdoor portion showcase the houses/living quarters for the difference ethnic groups. There even have the water puppet show every week end. Not to be missed if you have few hours in Hanoi.

Interesting museum & nice outdoor exhibits. We spent an enjoyable 2.5 hours here one morning.The outdoor museum exhibits are very interesting. We particularly enjoyed being able to enter the traditional housing exhibits (most were relocated from traditional villages). The outdoor water puppet theatre is an added bonus. The theatre isn't as impressive as the show we'd seen in the old quarter the previous night but it seemed more authentic, being set in an outdoor lake.The original building (in the shape of a traditional drum) of the museum is quite small but has some interesting background (in english) on the different ethnicities that make up Vietnam, detailing their origins, providing details on the language families and displaying artefacts. The newer building specialises in other parts of South East Asia.There is a cafe on site.It is easy (and cheap) to get to / from this museum by taxi. Don't do as we did and accept a ride from a driver who walks up to the gate, jumping the queue (turned out he had a dodgy racy meter), go to the taxis parked out front instead.

A Museum Treasure. The indoor museum was incredible with information about the different ethnic groups in Vietnam, but it was the outdoor venues that were fabulous. There were examples of the different ethnic houses. You could easily spend a few hours here

Interesting, Best seen with a guide, there is so much to learn about Vietnamese architecture and their building skills.. We weren't sure if another museum would hold our interest but the museum of ethnology is worth it. To see the unique building skills of Vietnamese people is well worth half a day.
ohh great. I came here many time its great place to understand more about the life of vietnamese people . With real cuture , houese , the way to live , agricuture life,

Awe inspiring display of traditional housing. Museum of Ethnology has an amazing outdoor exhibition of authentic traditional homes, including long houses, each featuring a audio visual display of the construction of the saved building by master crafts people from the relevant ethnic community There is also an exhibition of Vietnamese water puppets and extensive collection of textiles, clothes & jewellery from a range of cultures. The shop also has very good quality ethical hand made textiles for sale. Although it involves a bit travel to outside central Hanoi, this museum enables you to imagine many remote & exotic home stays in half a day.

real life look at the different ethic groups making up the Vietnamese population. 2 parts to this Museum . First is a large indoor 2 storey complex with loads of artifacts and static pictures to explain the ethnic backgrounds and groups that make up this culture. 2nd part is located in the grounds and is a mini city comprising a different home style for each ethnic group, life sized and very interactive. Unfortunately the day we visited was raining hard so we only ventured into around 5 of these homes but the weather got the better of us and we skipped the rest. Definitely a good attraction/ well maintained and very informative
Tour. Highly recommend this museum. Extremely interesting and informative. Beautiful outdoor exhibits and gardens. Well worth a visit to understand the mixed and varied ethnicity of Vietnam

Nice. We visited Sa Pa few days before this museum. So we have came in contact with some of the Hmong people during our Sa Pa stay. But this museum gave us a more complete understanding of the Hmong tribe as well as other ethnic group of Vietnam Especially like the tribe houses, which was built according to its original architecture. But unfortunately there was no cultural shows/demonstration during our Thursday visit.

Trevligt och intressant. The museum consists of one interior exhibition and an exterior one. It's all beautifullly done. The outside park exhibition is wonderful. Buildings of various types in lush green landscape. It's a far distance from Hoan Kiem, so you might consider a taxi. Taxidrivers are not to rely on. Mine headed in the opposite direction for ca 20 minutes, so stay alert. Of course i refused to pay more than the agreed 60000 dong, but I had to stand firm for a while there.

Must see in Hanoi. Didn't expect much from the Vietnam Museum of Ethnology, but it was surprisingly fantastic. Learn about the history and the different cultures throughout Vietnam. The gardens, houses, costumes and tools used by the different minority groups were fascinating.

Not bad but not stunning. I am unsure why this has so high a rating... the museum insides are OK but a little sparse. What it does do is indicate the diversity of people in this region (and this aspect is definitely good). This was useful when I went to SaPa as I was aware of the differences between groups. Outside there are several houses of the different ethic groupings - OK but not fabulous. I may be a bit harsh here but I have seen better.

History & Culture. The exhibition hall is thorough in finding out about ethnic minorities of VN. It was decent to see the genuine houses nearby worked as case of ethnic engineering. We ate at the eatery on location - keep running by understudies. Sustenance was pleasant and great administration/climate.
Needed more time. Viewed on a busy day tour. Guide was good but time was against us. Allow a morning or afternoon. Outside walk was very interesting.
like the american museum of natural history in new york. a gold mine of info; but you need the time to read it all & to absorb it. it was also 41c, too hot to meander. but go!
Fabulous museum . Mske sure you allow enough time to visit all the dwellings in the adjacent park. Need a good few hours to visit. The air conditioning isnt too good so avoid on a hot day.
What a Museum!. spent a few hours here, looking around at this very unique museum. I had no idea that Vietnam was made up of so many ethnic backgrounds - a real eye opener.

Definitely worth a visit. The inside of this museum is a mildly interesting, non-air-conditioned, guide to the various ethnic groups in Vietnam, of which there are surprisingly many. The really good stuff, though, is outside. Here there are buildings you can go in or just walk around, some of them spectacular. There are also artworks for sale, including traditional but endangered Dong Ho prints (now made by only two families) which you can buy for just $1 each.

Worthwhile visit. Visited this museum with a guide from City Tours Hanoi and was a nice experience to learn a bit about the different ethnic groups that comprise Vietnam. I am not sure if we would have gotten as much out of it had we just visited ourselves but is a must for those on cultural vacations.

Lets you see another side of Vietnam. Most people immediately think of the Vietnam War when Vietnam is mentioned. This museum features exhibits and an entirely different side of the country. It describes the ethnic mix and make-up of the various tribal factions that make up the original Vietnamese peoples. There is both an inside and an outside to this museum and the outside is probably the best (although don't dismiss the inside).There is a free water puppet show, examples of various ethnic dwellings from mainly mountain peoples and plenty of exhibits of the cultural diversity of this country. Probably best seen as part of an organised tour with either an English or French speaking guide.
Pretty good. There are so many different ethnic communities they talk about that its hard to really retain the info, but the cultural items were cool.
Best of Hanoi!. We visit some famous sites in Hanoi. This is the best one where display buildings of most Vietnam ethnic groups. A must for those who are interested in VN cultures.

Visited with Hanoi Kids, good museum. We spent about 3 hours here, but you could go through it in half that time unless you have a strong interest in the 54 ethnic minority groups that live in Vietnam. Whatever you do, save time for the outdoor experience visiting the mock houses of these various groups. It is very interesting. If you haven't seen or wish to see a water puppet performance, it can be done here at no extra charge.
Boring. Homestly, maybe for the oldies and the humanitarians, but I found this place just boring and too far out of the way in Hanoi.

Important - Very Well Done. Vietnam is made up of 54 ethnic communities. This museum sheds light on the differences in culture, dress, housing, farming and home utensils.
It is very well presented and definitely worth a visit.
If you are truly interested in the Vietnamese cultures, this museum is a must.

Worth a visit to understand how many of the 54 ethnic minorities live.. Very interesting museum depicting the way of life that many Vietnamese have and in some cases still do live in the country. Spacious building with many artifacts as well as video footage, also large outdoor area with true life examples of many of the traditional houses which you can go inside. Nice air conditioned cafe alongside the museum. Is worth a visit if you want to understand the culture.

A must-visit destination for both locals and tourists. The best shortest way to learn about diverse culture of 54 ethnic groups in Vietnam. The museum has a vast and priceless collection of displayed items. There is also a big area to exhibit some major groups' houses. In addition, on certain occasions they hold public events where everyone can partake. Also a great place for families with small children.
Good to see it. If you want to know about some regions and ethnics in Vietnam, visit of this Museum with tour guide is recommended. Later we visited ethnic people in Sapa to see their real life.

The museum you shouldnot miss. Among the many museums in Hanoi I like this museum of ethnology the most. It is a large museum with 2 big exhibiting part : in door and outside. It shows you life of the 54 minority groups of Vietnam in a very interesting way. Real scale house with everything inside. Highly recommend for family with children.

Could do with an upgrade. Travelling in Vietnam at the hottest time of the year, I was looking forward to learning about the country's people, whilst also cooling down a bit.The main building only has one aircon unit at the entrance and the rest of the space is "cooled" by fans + natural ventilation. Really would have liked to stay longer, but could only walk through without stopping at individual exhibits due to the heat. Generally the building could do with a bit of renovation work / a fresh lick of paint.The Southeast Asia exhibit (in a newer adjacent building and also included in the ticket price) is a more comfortable indoor environment. Unfortunately, I was already close to having a heat stroke by the time i reached it and had to return to my hotel.

Great and worth of visiting. Gives a very good view of former life and very often people forget that there are so many different ethnic groups in Vietnam. I really recommend though if you have disability in walking the entrances to some of the houses are very difficult. I have visited the museum three times and I still want to go there with my friends. The size of the museum is comfortable and you can also see a water puppet theater if you wish.

Well worth a visit. Part of our tour package or we might have overlooked it. Gives the visitor a sense of the ethnic diversity of the country and some of the housing, forms of worship, handicrafts and amusements of the past.

Great Place. The museum was very interesting. Well worth a visit. The indoor section was really well laid out and easy to use. The outdoor section, with the different buildings was really interesting.
Interesting museum. A bit far from the old quarter where most tourists stay but definitely worth to come. Lovely indoor and outdoor exhibition where a lot of info about 54 ethic groups are on display

Insightful!!. Really enjoyed and found insightful!
Make sure you visit the outdoor area too ...they have re created real size dwellings of past ethnic tribes.
A 2hr visit here with our guide. This museum is well worth a visit! I particularly enjoyed reading about the many ethnic groups in Vietnam and seeing their re-constructed houses outside as well.

Disappointing apart from the houses. We visited in the heat of the day. The children were buoyed by everything except for the example houses outside. They were quite impressive and nice too view inside.
The indoor exhibits were simply a little dull.

Great overview of culture. The exhibits cover all the regions of the country. There are examples of houses from all areas that are amazing. The South East Asia is also in the complex, so you get more than just Vietnam

Great Child Friendly Museum. This museum while a 15 minute taxi ride from the old quarter is in my opinion well worth it especially if you are looking for interesting things to do with children. Its very cheap to get into and you don't really need a guide as the information is in English as well as Vietnamese. Its a horrible concrete building but the exhibits inside are really good. The best bit tho is outside where you can visit typical houses of some of the minority tribes including ones on stilts which my 9 year old adored. There are also balance bamboo beams and loads of space to run around and let off steam. The café is hit and miss but is a training place for young vulnerable people and the Tradelink shop is a treasure trove of really good quality goodies to tempt . Across the road is a public park with a great play ground so you can easily spend a morning here with kids.

Interesting if you want a breakdown of ethnic groups. We visited the museum with a guide and found it valuable for a history of ethnic groups of Vietnam. It isn't a must and an hour will allow a visitor to gain all the information they can retain. The water puppet show was very good and entertaining .
Worth the visit. Very interesting exhibits on the ethnic minorities. You can tell they are underfunded. The garden is the best part.

loved it. the museum gave us a huge insight into the different tribes in vietnam,there a specially built houses on the huge grounds. there is a new global section which is not fully utilised. we thoroughly enjoyed the vist. you can do without a guide

Lots of interesting artefacts. Great museum to see the different ethnics and their day to day living. I especially loved the outside area where they built huts that you can walk into and explore and really get a feel of how they live(d). You would need around 2-3 hours here I'd say. Bring mosquito repellant tho!!
Overview of Vietnam Cultures!. A must when visiting Hanoi. We got a brief of Vietnam' cultures from different minority groups at this.

Amazing. This is an extraordinary museum particularly on the off chance that you are yet to encounter any of the minority individuals in Vietnam. The gathering of ancient rarities is awesome and best of all are the cabins and houses in the exhibition hall grounds which are interested in investigate. It's a smidgen off the beaten path

Watched a water puppet show and wandered through floors of exhibits. There are many ethnic people in Vietnam. The museum does a good job showing different groups and how they lived. In the back area, there are examples of buildings and people showing things like basket making and weaving. We watched a water puppet show that is done daily. There was live music with the show. There is a restaurant inside providing cold beverages. It was above 90 degrees F when I visited so that was a nice break. The gift shop is small but has some selections worth looking at. I was a part of PeaceTrees Vietnam, a group that helps start kindergartens, plant trees, and find and destroy ordinance left over from past wars. This tour was set up for us to help us see the different ethnic groups we were helping. The choice of "what sort of visit was this" didn't give the choice of a guided tour.

A Collection of Ethnicities that Make up Vietnam. A detailed look at the 54 ethnic groups that make up Vietnam with artifacts inside and traditional houses outside, many of which were brought for all over the country. Worth a visit to know about the make up of Vietnam.

Nice museum and nice typical Vietnamese houses outside. Very interesting museum about the different etnical groups in Vietnam ! We loved the outside area with the typical houses. Very nice for taking pictures. It takes about 2 h/2,5 h to visit

surprisingly interesting outside, Inside forget!!. part of a tour, when we arrived and was shown round inside i nearly made a run for it. very boring but outside was interesting with the different houses

Vietnam. A visit to the musuem is a must if you want to know more about Vietnam given your short length of stay here.It details the tribes found in Vietnam and the achitecture of the houses of the tribes. Very interesting and educational.There is also a water puppet performance held on the museum grounds. Good introduction to Vietnam.Take a taxi there (Hanoi Taxi or Minh Lann-Green) as it is quite far from Old Quarter.

Interesting way to understand Vietnam. It is not close to the old quarter. It takes around twenty minutes taxi-ride. The museum has two parts - indoor and outdoor. The indoor areas lack air-conditioning, so it is not comfortable to walk around the indoors. The outdoor exhibition is much more interesting. You can watch a free but short water puppet show and walk around different kind of houses.
Quality exhibition. We stayed one hour, you could stay longer. Lots of very interesting exhibitions. We went as part of our day tour and met lots of interesting people.

Helps you understand . I liked this museum, because it explained about all the different origins, groups and tribes of Vietnam. It explained the origins, traditions, cultures and lifestyles of the different areas of Vietnam. If you are spending any amount of time in Vietnam, I would advise you to go here sooner, rather than later, as it will help you understand the country and cultures, which I found helped us enjoy our trip more as we travelled through Vietnam.

Culture. I adored this gallery exceptionally cool. They manufacture life measured hovels like the neighborhood villagers. They had two or three cabins and it was so great. I would come here just to see that.

Allow lots of time. This museum is huge and well laid out. The grounds with replicas of the traditional houses of different Vietnamese ethnic groups is particularly lovely to wander around. There's two big buildings - one with displays of Vietnam's 54 ethnic groups, and the other one is the rest of the region. There's also a lovely restaurant which is great for taking a break and recovering from the heat - the buildings are quite cool but not as air-conditioned as some, and if you're used to a cool climate you might need a few coke breaks! Definitely don't get a taxi from right outside when you leave - they're twice the price. Walk a little way down the road and hail one!

Worth the visit. This is a great museum especially if you are yet to experience any of the minority people in Vietnam.The collection of artifacts is wonderful and best of all are the huts and houses in the museum grounds which are open to explore. It's a little bit out of the way but a taxi still only cost under $10AUD.

Lots of reading. Was good to visit to understand the history and cultures of vietnam, just a bit too much reading for myself, would be great if there was more interactive videos or something along that lines. We had a few groups of children (maybe 7-8 year old and uni students) approach us with their teachers wanting them to ask us questions in english and do an interview to help strengthen their english language. Was great to be apart of this and interact with them. However after a while we had 4 or 5 others approach us which got a bit too much. Took around 40mins to walk through the entire exhibition. Cheap entry aswell.

Museum provides good overall insight into Vietnam's diverse ethnicity. The museum consist of an indoor and outdoor part. The indoor provides an overview of Vietnam's ethnic population and diversity and the outdoor museum gives you a feel of their different living styles. We visited this museum as part of a day tour and it was worth the trip. Just right of the main entrance is a café and the museum also puts up a water puppet show. I don't recall the show being advertised in the museum anywhere as we came across it when we left the building to visit the outdoor part. We didn't hover around long and moved on to explore the different house styles, as we didn't think the show was that good.

Far out of town but lovely. The museum is about a 110K taxi from the centre. The museum itself has interesting things to look at but wasn't very concise or informative - no dates or info about the hunting tools, woven baskets etc. Lots of clothes to look at but to be honest you can find them in the women's museum which is a lot closer and has more to read and has a lot of the same stuff. The reconstructions of huts in the garden are really beautiful though! And the museum is next to an exhibition on Indonesian art (again no info and they're all from the 1990's but really cool to look at)

Cultural. We visited the Museum of Ethnology as part of a city day tour. Our tour bus dropped us off at the gate to the museum and our guide escorted us and provided commentary throughout the entire facility.Vietnam has so much history of which the museum captures and presents in an appealing way. Make sure that you leave yourself plenty of time to take In all of the two floors of exhibits.
Very interesting and well organized.. Very interesting to learn more about the almost 50 ethnicities in Vietnam. In two hours you can cover well the collection.

The best museum in Hanoi. For those visitors staying in the old quarter , a taxi is required since this museum is around 10km to the west of the city. Entry fee VD40,000. Some of the exhibits are in spacious modern buildings ( 2). The main building is of semi circular nature with displays over 2 floors. All information is in 3 languages, Vietnamese, French and English. The artefacts are well exhibited with informative details. There is plenty of room for viewing and moving around and seats are installed at several points. There are no internal interactive displays. A recent addition is a separate building concentrating on exhibits from South East Asia. In the grounds of the museum are examples of around 11 tribal houses representing typical rural life. There is also two restaurants side by side, offering a full menu for local food or coffee and snacks. Both restaurants are run by a non profit organisation training students from difficult circumstances. Over 7000 students have benefited from this training since 1996.

Some Parts Were Pretty Cool!. Exploring the reconstructed tribal dwellings outside was a cool way to see village life if you don't have time to visit the Vietnamese countryside for real.Low entrance fee, but need a taxi out there.Much of the museum is detailed, exhaustive information on all the different tribes and to be honest I remember very little of it. Nothing else was interactive and there were just a few small tv screens playing video throughout the museum - it was 90% artifacts behind glass with write-ups beside them. Or large posters with facts and info. If you had to choose between this museum and the Women's Museum I'd recommend the Women's Museum. There are many similarities between the two.

Splendid. A good and educational place to learn about Vietnamese ethnic people, their culture & their houses. Good for the kid to be exposed to other culture. Good outdoors activities can be had at this place. Near the entrance of the museum, you can have a goos meal with good coffee at the only cafe there. The water puppet show is just ok. Better to watch at the Water Puppet Show Theatre near Hoan Kiem Lake.

A must see tourist attraction in Hanoi. We visited the museum as part of out tour and were so lucky our guide was able to give us all the information on the ethnic diversity on Vietnam with all the arts and artefacts from the 54 different ethnic groups that inhabited the country, very interesting indeed. There were many schools children visiting at the same time so and they all wanted to try out their english skills with a hello and were are you from. I was even lucky enough to get a group photo of the children with their teacher. (with there teacher permission of course) I have included it with my review. It is certainly worth a visit.
Great way to see history of Hanoi. Well set out. Beautiful exhibits. Could spend many hours here just browsing. Just watch out for the slippery tiles leading into exhibition if it's been raining.

Learn about ethnic groups. Eat lunch here.. The museum is comprehensive in learning about ethnic minorities of VN. It was nice to see the actual houses on site built as examples of ethnic architecture. We ate at the restaurant on site - run by students. Food was nice and good service/atmosphere.

Good place to help you to understand the ethnic diversity and culture of the country!. An interesting place to spend half a day - and well worth going in order to help better understand the culture of Vietnam.

Interesting visit!. We visited this museum after having read all the positive reviews and have to agree that it is worth taking a taxi to the suburbs for. Especially the outside area is interesting, with life-sized traditional buildings. The entrance fee is quite cheap. There was only one thing we did not like: in all of the traditional buildings outside, employees were sitting around doing nothing or even sleeping...
Do not miss this place. A great educational experience. We learned much about the people, customs etc . A must do on anyone's list
Day tour. Very good day, we did a private tour I think that is the best way to do it , we had a driver & tour guide.

3 hours is not enough. A friend and I headed here to check it out and I absolutely loved it! The museum is well planned and executed, with internal exhibitions showing the evolution of the people of Viet Nam up to what we experience today. The inside displays are set out well, and with enough interactive learning to engage little ones. Outside of the main museum building was my favourite part of the museum exhibition: the life-size examples of architecture specific to each ethnic group. By allowing visitors to climb inside, you can get a real sense of what it's like to live in and share these spaces. Also outside is a water puppet theatre which holds regular shows, so if you hear them calling, try to catch a sight of the plays. We went too late in the day to finish the whole museum (arrived at 2 and they start closing at 5) so I would suggest arriving earlier, pack a lunch, and take your time to really engage with what you're seeing.

Fascinating the first visit, fun to revisit. I've been enjoying exploring this museum's collection over the past year since moving to Hanoi. A lover of tribal crafts and culture, I've visited many museums in Southeast Asia. This is one of my favourites for a few reasons. Firstly, the collections are well curated, set out throughout the building with ample space and good lighting. The supporting information in displays is well written and presented. Although the collection housed in the main building is fantastic, my favourite section is actually housed in the gardens to the rear of the museum. Here, an impressive collection of original ethnic housing structures have been relocated, including the crowd favourite long house and Catu house. Make sure to pop into the Craftlink store on your way back to the car (it's in the carpark). The shelves are jam-packed full of beautiful handicrafts by many of the 54 ethnic minority groups of Vietnam.

interesting museum, much more better as in Thai Nguyen. The building is modern, the displays and information are not old fashion. A really very good museum, before a visit, or after a visit to the etnic groups.

Wonderful place to spend an afternoon!. Great museum- we spent nearly 5 hours exploring. Gift shop has very nice fair trade items which support the hill tribes folk art. Along wth learning about different ethnic groups and traditions, we had a wonderful time meeting groups of school children practicing their English. If you have the opportunity to interact with them, don't pass it up!
Short and Rapid acquaintance with euthenics. If you want to have a short and rapid acquaintance with more than 50 Vietnamese euthenics,this place is the right place.

Awesome museum that's managed very well. I was really impressed with how well-maintained the ethnology museum is. The museum goes into detail regarding the culture and customs of each ethnic group in Vietnam. Since there are 54 different ethnic groups, you can imagine that there is a lot of ground to cover in the museum. If you want to take your time through the museum, this is definitely a half-day trip. But definitely worth it!

A great place for getting know Ethnology of Vietnam. It's a huge place for getting know Vietnamese culture. There, we can see a lot of great monuments. Take a little bit of time, we will able to understand the difference between those ethnics!!!

Good place for travelers explore Vietnamese culture . Big and plenty of information about ethnic groups in Vietnam. They have a lot of house from different place of the country. And sometimes, you can watch the water puppets so for free in the museum. Nice place to visit.

An interesting museum. The exhibits are interesting and there are explanations in English. The best part for us were all the houses outside. These were examples of different types of houses from around Vietnam that you could go into and explore. My children really enjoyed these.
Excellent overview. Worthwhile exhibits that demonstrate ethnic differences of Vietnamese populace. Housing types, textiles, other cultural differences.
Learn about the many ethnic groups that live in Vietnam.. This is beautiful museum. A perfect place for a rainy day. There's a nice restaurant in an outdoor setting.

Nice to visit on a cool day. We decided to come here on a warmest day of a spring in Hanoi.Not a good idea cause it's a bit far out of the central.very interesting place though,u will see how colourful Vietnam is with different tribes and the culture is very different according to the geography.
Guided tour. Great insight to the large number of ethnic minorities and tribes in Vietnam. Size of the museum is just right, displays are well set out.

Aussie Adventurers Abroad. Inside the building was hot and humid. There were many artifices of ancient Vietnamese life. A few dioramas. Outside were cafes and restaurants. There is also a water puppet theatre which was interesting. The collection of buildings were representative of the various minority groups dispersed from within Vietnam.

Best museum in hanoi. Value for money, it's the best museum. The stuff is legitimate and doesn't reek of propaganda like the exhibits of the "Hanoi Hilton" prison. It has an outdoor and indoor area, both are great. The outdoor area was particularly impressive because they are the original huts from villages and not recreations. They literally bought the huts, transported the material, and hired the different ethnic villagers to come to the site and rebuild them.
Visited in 2013. Very good, to see the history of the various ethnic groups in Vietnam - many more than I thought there were.

One of the finest museums we've ever seen.. Excellent displays for the past to current ethnic tribe lifestyles. Good combination of recreations, video, texts and artifacts. Don't miss the adjoining Museum of Asian Folk art and the outdoor portion with recreated buildings and its own water puppet theatre. Even the gift shop was a goldmine with excellent quality but also reasonable prices and great variety.

Very nice. The interior museum is interesting, although not mind blowing. The garden in the back however, is fantastic. Boasting beautiful homes and compounds for the many ethnic groups, it's a must see if you enjoy ethnology.
A cultural assest. Really this is a nice place to visit in Vietnam. It a good place to learn about the culture of this country.

At least half a day worth's. The museums kit very big but sit in some pretty impressive building. The set up and intricate exhibitions can take some time to take in. On the grounds replicas of traditional ethnic houses you must not miss it!

Visited Museum . This museum provide good information on the various ethnics group of Vietnam . It has sample houses , clothing , celebration . Livelihood of the various ethnic group . Good for visitors that want to know the Vietnamese culture

Vietnam's cultural diversity explained!. Great museum. We spent a lot of time outdoors looking at the various houses. Kids and adults enjoyed. The inside is very informative. The kids started to get a bit bored but definitely worth a visit. Too much reading for the kids. Very interesting though for the adults. We went to the restaurant on the premises and really enjoyed the food. Nice menu and prices quite good.

Insight introduction to Vietnam's cultural diversity. Must-go if you have 3 to 4 hours to spare in Hanoi. It takes an hour to get there from the airport, and between 2 to 3 hours to tour the place. I'd recommend that you start with the outdoor exhibits which are re-modeled homes from different ethnic tribes in the highlands of Vietnam. It's very interesting to "climb" into one and imagine the living conditions of the people. The indoor exhibits are also a great way to learn about the history of Vietnam (Vietnam war), its people, culture and costume. Finally, if you have time to spare, head to the separate building for Southeast Asian exhibits. Do leave time for exploring the gift shop, which sells handicrafts by the different ethnic groups. The best thing about this is that there are lockers at the first level of the buildings, which allow visitors coming from the airport to store their luggages while they tour the grounds. Admission fee is between USD 1~2 and it is a great way to spend an afternoon. The restaurant at the museum provides vocational training for youths with special needs, and dining there was a nice way of filling our stomachs and contributing to the meaningful cause.

Great fun, great food!. My kids loved running through the various houses and the food in the restaurant was very good. I didn't spend much time in the indoor museum but the grounds of the outdoor museum were beautiful and well-kept. I also did not watch the water puppet show. This is an inexpensive attraction for families.

Interesting museum that, in all reallity shows how different people live in Vietnam. Peculiar "museum". It shows how people (tribes) live in the mountains outside of the populous Vietnam cities. This is actually a representation as how today they live. It is such an ancestral way that it is not imaginable. The scenario is likely true since we met some members of one of those tribes in an excursion far from the museum.

Great!. The museum is packed full of information detailing traditional Vietnamese ways of life, from religious events to the symbolic rituals of all the Vietnamese ethnic groups, providing a rich tapestry of the culture melting pot existing in Vietnam. The outdoor area presents a range of traditional homes including a Tay stilt house and a Viet house complete with indigenous foliage, each separated by a small stream and reached via little bridges. One of the main features of the museum is to present the artefacts in a simple manner so that visitors can enjoy them without being overwhelmed by detail. The museum is suitable for children and all documents and display signs throughout have been translated into French and English.
Gives amazing insight.. This museum will enlighten you about the culture of Vietnam. The exhibits are interesting and easy to follow - not too much information in each spiel.

VERY INTERESTING DAY OUT. The layout is superb provides a good over view of Vietnamese rural living from the past. Gentle amble through the gardens with the most amazing trees with ample resting places.Puppet show great for kids.l

Beautiful Local Houses. I enjoyed the local houses at the back of the museum. One can even go inside most of them and explore further.The exhibit inside were mostly on the history of the ethnic people of the country and I did enjoy it immensely. I was happy that I was able to get postcards and stamps here too.

Very informative. Lots of information laid out in an easy to understand format giving insight into the ethnology of the Vietnamese people. We were brought here as part of a City tour and this museum added to an interesting day.

Great introduction to ethnic groups of Vietnam. Very interesting museum with great displays from the many ethnic groups in Vietnam .Good to learn much of the history of these groups and the country as a whole
Interesting . A nice interesting experience of Vietnamese diversity. A lot of information, helpful if done a little research beforehand. Do skip the lunch restaurant unless needed.

DO NOT MISS. Totally amazing, well laid out informative. All explained in English. The artefacts and costumes on display are colourful and awe inspiring. As a bonus, outside in the grounds, are traditional houses, built to scale, and wow. Wish we could have spent more time here. Would definitely go back to this one.

Well worth a visit. I'm not massively into 'ethnology', but I found this museum fascinating. It's largely about the 50'odd ethnic tribes found in Vietnam - their culture, origins etc. And they do vary a lot. Mind you, even your guide will admit that as Vietnasm is changing so fast, much of what is in the museum refers to the past. No less interresting though.
Life sized huts to veiw. I loved this museum very cool. They build life sized huts like the local villagers. They had a couple of huts and it was so awesome. I would come here just to see that.

Great way to understand vietnam when you first arrive. We went here on our first morning to get an overview of the country, its people and culture - very informative. Take about 2 hours there. We took a cab from the old quarter for around 100 dong (10 -15 mins drive) and jumped on someone's motor bike to get back!

A must-visit for insight into the life of the hill peoples. It's the Wandering Yank here. Friends highly recommended this museum, but surprisingly it's not listed in the Lonely Planet Vietnam book. It's definitely worth visiting if you have any interest in the Hmong and other peoples.It's quite large, both indoors and outdoors. Indoors is 2 floors of static displays - costumes, implements, art, a house, etc. - with explanations in 3 languages - Vietnamese, French and English. It's all very nicely laid out and spacious.Outside are a number of houses from different tribal regions of Vietnam. You can go into all of them - for some you have to remove your shoes. They're laid out in a very nice garden area. They also have good explanatory plaques.I highly recommend the cafe, Baguette & Chocolat - see my review. It was surprisingly good. And the crafts shop is a non-profit cooperative that has an excellent array of tribal items.I highly recommend this museum for even the casual visitor.

The best museumm in Hanoi. If you want to really get to know what makes up the ethnicity of Vietnam you must visit this place.It's informative, well laid out and packed with loads of displays and totally lacking in propaganda.An easy and enjoyable way to spend quite a few hours.

Well worth the visit!. This museum is a little bit out of the main tourist area but is only about 20/30 mins in a taxi. It is well worth the visit. We intended to kill an hour here before our flight and ended up staying much longer than planned. It is a great insight into the various different tribes in Vietnam, their traditions and cultures. We really liked the different house types that you can visit and walk around in the garden area. Really worth a visit.

A must for anyone working Vietnam. I am so glad I came here and spent three hours absorbing the history and culture of Vietnam's many ethnic groups. I work in the country a lot, visiting several times a year, and training journalists from some of the remotest regions. After visiting, I have a little better understanding about the wonderful diversity of this amazingly creative, innovative and energetic nation. I should have visited years ago. Oh, and if you do visit, stop for lunch at the little cafe by the reconstructed village. It's called Baguette Chocolate and served some of the best food I have had in 40 years visiting Vietnam - and I have has some lovely food during that time. The restaurant is run by the Hoa Sua School for disadvantaged youth and they do a wonderful job, well worth of a review on TA where they got 5* from me. Great afternoon out.

Surprised . Came here with my young family. The main building itself was a bit dull for the kids but once outsideLooking at all the different types of houses etc they really enjoyed it. Only need an hour or so but still worthwhile

Understanding the Vietnamese people. Vietnam is not just North and South. There are 54 ethnicities belonging to 5 main groups and this museum offers an excellent overview of their traditions, customs, costumes, and daily life. In particular the reconstruction of different types of housings in the museum's garden is impressive. Shouldn't be missed!

Insight to Vietnam's people. Spent most of our day here. Great info in english french & vietnamese. Loved being able to enter the houses in the grounds. Gave our visit to SaPa more relevance. Maybe better to visit prior to SaPa. Well worth the trip out.
No. 1 Attraction of Hanoi - Really worth spending 4 hours or more!. Really worth reading and seeing all the artifacts. Gives you a really good understanding of Vietnam and its inhabitants
Really interesting. We spent a lovely day exploring the museum. The authentic houses built outside were great to explore. It really helped us to understand the culture of this fascinating country.

Worth a visit. Although this museum is some distance from the city centre, it's worth the $10 taxi ride. Entrance fee is cheap. Surprisingly large, the museum showcases the culture and traditions of the various ethnic groups and hill tribes of Vietnam. A seperate building houses exhibits from other Asian countries. There are also several full size dwellings which have been constructed in the grounds - Interesting to learn the differences between houses and the materials used in their construction. I recommend visiting the small cafe in the museum grounds which is run by students from disadvantaged backgrounds who are being trained in hospitality. Good food at reasonable prices and located in a lovely garden surrounds. The museum shop has some excellent, well priced items and relaxed laid back staff allow quiet browsing. A very enjoyable day out.

SO INTERESTING!. Coming from China with all that minority groups, I didn't expect this museum to be anything else. BUT it turned out a very very interesting visit with a knowledgeable tour guide! Every house was original, the government had them moved from the villages and rebuilt them in the original way. Getting inside the house and you will learn a lot of interesting stuff about the people. Love the cute little shop in one of the minority houses, selling paintings and every painting has an interesting story to tell. Highly recommended!

Informative and interesting museum. This museum highlights the many different ethnic groups in Viet Nam and is working to keep their cultures in the public awareness. Highlights include native dress exhibits; videos throughout with English subtitles showing different cultural practices; examples of different houses in a park setting behind the museum; and Craft Links non profit museum shop which raises money to support traditional crafts by selling traditional crafts.

Interesting museum outside the main tourist area. Chose this museum based on TA reviews. Interesting displays recognizing the ethnic groups within Vietnam. If you are travelling with children, plan to spend more time touring the outside displays as there are lots of houses to look at and a water puppet show that runs at regular intervals. Outside displays can be stand alone and do not require explanation from interior exhibits. There is also a great park directly across the street with a playground (very busy on weekends).

Fascinating insight into ethnic minority peoples in Vietnam. We visited Museum as part of a personnel guided tour through Buffalo Tours . The guide had an extensive knowledge of the Museum attractions and was able to provide great information on the exhibits presented ( the Exhibits were presented in English and clearly described). The displays were extensive and gave you a good insight into the cultures of the 54 ethnic minority peoples in Vietnam - Guide also provided information on available tours to visit Minorities presented which based on knowledge gained at the Museum would be a great future holiday adventure. High recommend this Museum.

Really fascinating. Definitely one for the history buffs this place is really great. You get the entire history of the people of Vietnam and their culture. I am not one to go to museums but this was great

Amazing museum. Our book said that it would take 2-3 hours to visite this place. At the end it took us almost 4 hours because of the quality of the pieces and the quality of the descriptions. The houses in the garden are the best !As a bonus, everything is translated in english and in french.A must see in Hanoï, even if you had to take a cab to go there.
Absolute highlight. This museum will give you a much deeper understanding of culture and history in Vietnam Nam. Plan for at least two hours.

Interesting look at Vietnam's People. I enjoyed this museum. It provides an interesting and detailed look at Vietnam's many different ethnic groups. The displays are interesting, and the outdoor exhibits make for a pleasant walk. The museum is a bit of a distance from the center of Hanoi, but it's easy to reach by taxi.

A way to get a taste of the culture. Unfortunately it was pouring rain on the day we visited but this is a very interesting place and leaves the visitor with some understanding of the culture and history.

Favourite museum in Hanoi. My favourite museum in Hanoi and the place to visit to get an understanding of Vietnamese culture. There is a lot of information about the different ethnic groups in Vietnam, where they live and from where they originated. Especially liked exhibits of the traditional dress and videos of how they live. In the outside grounds are some of the houses built by the different ethnic groups.

A real insight into the Vietnamese way of life.. A fascinating place to visit. The indoor section is informative, with snapshots of life of the many Vietnamese tribes. The outdoor section has examples of the different styles of houses, many of which allow access to visitors. Well worth a look.

Well curated museum of the different ethnic groups in Vietnam. Well worth the admission (VND40k per adult, children VND10k). We spent 3 hours both inside and outdoors. The indoor galleries showcase items from the over fifty different ethnic groups in Vietnam and the amazing cultural diversity in this country. The exhibits are well curated and the descriptions (in Vietnamese, French and English) are clear and instructive. Outdoors are several real examples of traditional houses from the different peoples in the country, of all different dimensions, long, tall, short!

World class museum. Loved this museum. It was very good, everything clearly explained in English and French. Nice multimedia, rebuilt houses in the garden outside, videos and photos inside alongside costumes and other artifacts. We didn't have time to go to the new Southeast Asia building, which is cool looking in the outside. I would definitely go back. Great gift store with fair prices and high quality. If you want something small look for the little cheese knives or combs. The textiles are great.

Fascinating museum in Hanoi!. Although this museum is a bit far out from the central district, it is well worth the taxi ride! Only open since 1997, this museum is dedicated to the 54 ethnic groups that comprise Vietnam. The staff did a great job of collecting artifacts, costumes, photos and videos representing the various groups that have settled in Vietnam. The building is circular and 2 stories, providing a great deal of space to give the visitor a glimpse into the cultural aspects of many of the groups. There is also an open air section in which you can see replicas of various houses and a water puppet theater. One of the highlights of our visit to Hanoi!
Good place to start a visit to Hanoi. Good introduction to Vietnamese culture explains the country, culture, traditions and tribes. Well laid out and informative.

Ok.... This stop was part of our Hanoi City Tour. Wasn't on our "To Do" list and was ok but wouldn't stop again. Interesting for me but kids, not so much. The highlight for us was the garden out back. Had kids ages 8 & 13 with and they caught a case of the giggles when they saw the mausoleum art .

Understanding Minorities. Located about 20 minutes from the old quarter, you will need a taxi to get to this museum. I did not realize that Vietnam has so many minorities for such a small country. There are more than 50 in all and trying to comprehend the names and characteristics will give you an overload with the differences in each tribe's customs, practices and dressesAfter doing the 2 floors of the museum, another surprise is the outdoor portion where reconstructed houses from the various tribes can be found. The huge council meeting house and the burial area will somehow leave you in amazement at what Viet life was in old times.An added bonus is the outdoor puppet show. Since the show is held in the open, the music from the show would not be as defeaning.

Amazing Place. There are plenty of displays and descriptions (in English) about life in Vietnam by the 50 over indigenous groups. Where they live. What they do. Do spend some time watching the videos as they show you actual footages of various ceremonies (wedding, burial, initiation). You'll be surprised!

Outstanding . I loved this place! The outside area is the best bit but the inside exhibitions were great too. Well designed, thoughtful and informative. The replica traditional houses outside are amazing! Take off your shoes and have a wander, it's incredibly fun.
Interesting. We were fortunate to have a guide to explain all the different sites and which to avoid at certain times of the day.

Nice museum. I went there with 3 of my friends sharing the same car. Quite happy with the museum even it is a little bit far away from hanoi old quarter. This museum is about the hill tribe Vietnamese people. A nice introduction

Worth a visit. . Good museum. A lot of it is SE Asian focuses but a good amount on Vietnam. Probably worth an hours visit if you have time, definitely worth it on a rainy day! Try and get there early or you'll be swamped by fat American tourists but really nice. Really lovely cafe as well.

Very informative. We learned a lot about the different tribes in Vietnam They had great examples of their villages and other artifacts. It helped us to understand so of what other guides would tell us later in our trip.

A good insight to the history of the rural communities. An interesting hour if time allows especially if you are not visiting the countryside. Of particular note were the re-created buildings outside. A little way out of the city.

Tour of outdoor only. We visited and did a tour that was only mildly interesting for the kids. Aged 12 & 8.
At least they could explore a bit. Lots more inside but boring for children.

Very interesting. This museum is considered one of the finest in Vietnam and it lives up to its reputation. You will get a fascinating insight into the 54 minority groups of Vietnam. A good indoor activity.

Interesting and well designed. The inside part of this museum is all about the 54 ethnicities that make up the Vietnamese population, talking about their lives and highlighting the differences between each. More interesting though is the outside part where they have setup various different styles of village houses and buildings. The variation in the different styles is fascinating as is the construction of each. Probably need to allow 1-2 hours depending how thoroughly you read everything.

When you want to learn more about Vietnam, it's a suitable place.. The museum is very large to visit and research. A beautiful view and fresh air are really great. If you come in the first time, you should find a guide to tell you some tale stories about every folks.

Well laid out, interesting . Visited on our first day in Vietnam and we had no idea of the different ethnic groups within the country. Well laid out with exhibit areas for each group Inside, and then outside an area with examples of the houses for each. Prepared us well for the rest of our trip, particularly our visit to the areas around Sapa.

Could Have Been Great. This could have been a great experience. There is a lot of information inside the museum and the houses out back at interesting to look at. However there were HORDES of screaming school children when we were there. If you go on a day without those school children, it might be a better experience. Go if you have time, but maybe on the weekend.

Very Informative. A nice place to learn about the culture and different ethnic minorities that live all over Vietnam. It was really cool that they had some real houses/buildings built by their indigenous people and we could go inside to see what it was like. If you love to learn about different cultures then I'd really recommend to coming here!

Well presented Folk Museum. The intimidating name disguises an interesting folk museum. The main attraction is the recreation of the homes of the hill people in an attractive park like setting. We didn't have time on this trip to visit the interior and welcomed this exhibit. The bonus was the number of local university students whose assignment was to meet English speaking visitors to practice English conversation.

Great overview of the ethnic communities of Vietnam. The Vietnam Museum of Ethnology is located away from downtown but well worth the effort to get there. There are artifacts and houses of several of the ethnic tribes (54, I believe). The Vietnam government seems to be committed to preserving these cultures. The museum is modern well laid out and offers good commentary as an introduction to the tribes. Well worth the time.

One of the best museums in Hanoi. Very nice place to find out the people in Vietnam. It shows real house samples for minority people in VN. You also can see water puppet shows free. If you want to learn about Vietnamese people and culture, I recommend this place.
has to be seen. a very nice museum ,a lot to learn of Vietnam ethnics people,the visit will take a couple hours and it is centralprobably the most interesting museum to be seen in Hanoi

Outdoor recreations of differing Vietnamese living spaces. This was an OK visit, although not my cup of tea. Reconstructions of various types of living spaces by the different groups that make up Vietnam.
Our museum visit. The Vietnam Museum of Ethnology had a lot of fascinating information and numerous interesting displays, including examples of the houses built by different ethnic groups.

informative. The museum shows Vietnamese culture and traditions. It did not really amaze me because I see the resemblance of their culture with my country. What interests me were their history and how their tribes were shown.

Imoressive site which gets quite busy as the day progresses. Lots to see and experience here. Our local guide gave us an interesting insight into Vietname life. This is a polular destination with many and even the locals use it as a backdrop for wedding pictures. Pretty brides in traditional red wedding dresses are so stunning. Well kept museum worth the visit.

Best museum in Hanoi. A very interesting museum about the culture of the many different etnic groups of Vietnam. The museum has a outdoor and indoor part, both worth visiting. Tip: It is better to wear socks as you are required to remove your shoes in order to enter some of the houses. The museum is outside the city center.

Great insight. We had a very insightful tour of the museum. I really had no idea how rich and varied the Vietnamese culture was until visiting here. Everything was well put together and the recreations of the houses was a real highlight. People sometimes can't see much beyond the war when they talk about Vietnam so this museum is a great place to learn what an amazing culture it truly is!

Beautiful place for knowledge. This place provides good information about the rich culture of the Vietnamese. The museum provides a brief knowledge about the tradition and culture of the ancient Vietnamese people.

Vietnam trip . This is one of my all time favorites. This museum is the reason I came back to see more of Vietnam. The display of the different people's and thier dress and style of home, way of life peaked my interest in the northern tribes people. Well work the visit. All so recreation of life and home, inside and out of museum.

fascinating. We visited on a sunday and spent most of the day. The displays of the many ethnic minorities clothes and way of life was really fascinating and extremely well displayed. My only gripe would be the tour groups that go through monopolise the exhibition spaces by stopping in front of a particular exhibit, blocking other visitors. I think it would be better if an audio guide was offered to these visitors and no tour groups allowed. But that aside we really enjoyed the exhibits and then discovered the architecture garden outside. It was a sunday so there were lots of kids whith their parents great being shown their cultural heritage. The reconstructed original traditional houses were amazing to see, you can walk through them or up into the stilt houses. Theyt show very much how they would have been used. We came away with a great sense of the cultural and architectural heritage of Vietnam. Lunch in the restaurant in the garden was also good, I highly recommend this museum.

Well worth a look. Our guide took us here as part of an organised tour. The displays were very interesting and gave us an insight as to how the different minority groups live in their communities. Give yourself at least 2 hours for a good look around.

Fascinating insight. This was a really worthwhile museum because it showed the incredible diversity of the ethnic groups in Vietnam. This is something that I'd previously had no awareness of. Outside there are examples of the different houses. Inside the material was much the same as that in the other museums that I'd already visited (women's, national etc).
Wonderful exhibit. Fantastically informative and well curated museum. A short cab ride from downtown, this museum is a must see.
Not Interesting. Not Interesting for us great Building! nice gardens Cheap Souvenir shop! Great bus service to and from hotel.

Interesting... but don't make a day of it.. We saw this as part of a tour. The most interesting section is the outside where examples of homes are built. It's interesting to see/learn about the different cultures. Spend 2 hours, max.

What diversity!. MUseum is very informative; we had information overload, what with 54 different ethnic communities in Vietnam. The descriptions of the various cultural practices were complete. Especially enjoyed the rituals of mariage and of death for the various groups. We suffered from information overload. Habitat presentations, outside, were excellent.

Do not miss this. Despite the fact that we were not "eager" about going by - this outside (and indoor) exhibition hall surpassed our desires and was truly exceptionally pleasant!! In the event that 'battling for time' in any case, it's one experience that could without much of a stretch be "missed" for others!!

Diving into Vietnam colture. Really interesting place, cared about details and clearness.very interesting from coltural point of view, will make you dive into ethnical history of Vietnam, the garden in the premises, offer you a show of typical village houses and if you like you can enjoy internal restaurants and bars. educative for children and adults, is also suitable and quite safe fo toddlers

One of the Best Musuems ever. This is a well thought out and beautifully arranged museum, well worth a visit. The main building allows you to learn about the myriad tribes that inhabit Vietnam. You view their clothes, their houselhold and religious items. Then, you step outside and visit the different style houses actually built by the tribesmen on the musuem site as representative of the homes they live in or use for ritual ceremonies
focus on the different groups that live in Vietnam. By visiting this museum we got an insight into the different lifestyles experienced in the various regions that make up Vietnam

Very informative Museum. Pretty good way to find out about the Viet culture. Try to go with one of the guides from Hanoi Free Tour Guides (book ahead) so they can explain it in more detail.You could spend up to half a day there looking at all the exhibitions.
Well worth a visit.. Allow a minimum of 45 minutes to see this place - it is very interesting. We made our arrangements with Hanoi Transfer Service on our private one day tour.

Houses of various ethnic groups was the best. The place has a museum showing various ethnic groups present in Vietnam and their life style and culture. It will be good if you can read through all of them. Or you can take a guide.They also made models of houses used by various ethnic groups over the years. They are very different from each other and quite unique. You will definitely love these.

Really interesting place. Went here as part of a day trip unfortunately we didn't have a lot of time but what we saw was really interesting about the many different tribes in Vietnam. Would have liked longer to soak it all in.

The Museum gave us a very good experience of life in Vietnam.. We enjoyed the variety of exhibits and the clear coverage of the minority groups in Vietnam. The outdoor exhibit was particularly interesting.

A Gem. This is a wonderful museum. A person could spend at least a day here. Unfortunately, we had some time constraints and could not see everything. The colorful exhibits covering the ethnic minorities of Vietnam. It's fascinating, colorful and informative. There is a wonderful shop as you leave the museum called Craft Link. They carry beautiful work done by the some of the ethnic minorities. It is a not-for-profit organization that assists small craft producers to develop business and marketing opportunities. The goods here are beautiful and are priced very reasonably.

Excellent museum!. Museum of Ethnology ocuses on the 54 officially recognised ethnic groups in Vietnam. It is widely considered the finest modern museum in Vietnam and a popular tourist attraction in Hanoi, we had a wonderful American guide who gave us a marvelous tour with details of the exhibition. There is an outdoor museum complete with water puppet show and additional buildings that is worth a visit. Highly recommend it.

Very interesting visual presentations of (artifacts of) Vietnamese ethnic minorities'. In main building, there's much to see and learn (also in English and French) about the 50+ Vietnamese ethnic minorities, outside you can admire and walk through some of their typical houses. In the second building you can enjoy a beautiful collection of artifacts from other South East Asian countries. Much recommended, Michelin travel guide awards the max 3 stars for it!
Nice afternoon. Had a nice afternoon wandering around here. I found the outside to be more interesting than the inside. The outside is actual houses recreated in the grounds.
Interesting. Enjoyed a guided tour of this well laid out and interesting museum. Several interior and external exhibitions, with good intrepretation.

Excellent overview over a muli-ethnic society. It's very well done, with great overview of the ethnicities, and an outdoors exhibit with traditional houses of various ethnicities, and water puppet show.

Superior coverage of the rthnic groups!. Far superior to most museums! It provides excellent coverage of the history, culture, origins and current lifestyle of the ethnic groups of Vietnam. As an added bonus, most display are also in English, an unexpected treat for us. Also included is an outdoor museum complete with water puppet theatre show and additional building of Asian art. Plan on lunch at the cafe which serves as the training ground for a school for disadvantaged, or disabled youth.
Wow!. Could have spent the whole day here and maybe gone back again. There is a wide range of things to do and see including water puppet shows.
Great Museum!. This museum definitely gives you a comprehensive look into Vietnam's history and culture. Some of the exhibits are quite fun to participate in as well.
A good place to visit. This is a good place for Vietnamese and foreigners to visit. It has so many types of ethnic houses. It is very interesting. Children can learn about history as well

More Interesting than you would think. This gives a "snapshot" of the many ethnic groups that make up Vietnam and how they lived and live. It was pretty fascinating, if you have time to visit. I wouldn't put it on the top 5 things I would want to do, but it certainly will go on the top 10.

A great over view on the numerous enthnic groups in Vietnam. During our stay in Hanoi we paid a visit to the Ethnology Museum. The hotel concierge recommended that we take some time and see the gardens and the outdoor exhibits. While the museum itself wax well worth the visit, we had to agree that the outdoor gardens and displays of a wide variety of ethnic architecture was the best part of the day. An unexpected bonus was bumping into a rather large number of school age children on field trips to the museum who took the opportunity to par active their English with us.

Over view of Vietnam. If you don't have time to travel from south to north and west to east it is a good passage to learn about Vietnam, with all the different hetnies with their different way of living

Amazing culture. It was amazing seeing all the different tribes in Vietnam and by extension south east asia. Very interesting seeing how all the different tribes built their community, dressed themselves and ate. It's about 30mins from Hanoi center, and the taxis around the museum aren't that familiar with the hotels in the city centre, so be sure to know your hotel or your next destination.

Museum visit. Went to this attraction as part of a day tour. The museum was not a highlight for us but this maybe because we were on museum overload when we got there. The outside grounds are lovely and worth the visit alone.

A Nice Self Guided Tour. This museum is wonderful! There is an inside exhibit featuring historical village scenes and outdoors many thatched roof homes indicative to the different geographical areas of North and South Vietnam. I enjoyed the open air rooms depicting life as it was generations ago and how the people made the best of their natural resources.There is also a room dedicated to the ancient art of water puppets.
