Old wood puppets fill the walls and masters of the art are featured.The grounds are lovely with a small center lake (once used for puppet shows) various wood carvings and bronze sculptures.There is also a small cafe perfect for a cold beer and people watching and at the exit a book and art store.

Interesting introduction to vietnam. This is an interesting museum but the outdoor displays of housing styles throughout Vietnam were of most interest to us. Uni students at various displays can explain exhibits. Most have some English but not all. Inside exhibition was a bit underlit and sometimes difficult to view and read about.
Worth the trip across town. Extremely interesting and well exhibited museum on the various groups that populate Vietnam and their history

Fun and informative . We spent about 2.5 hours at this museum and had a great time. We learned a lot about the various ethnic groups in Vietnam, some of which we'll be meeting later in our trip. The traditional clothing on display was among my favorites. We were starting to get a bit of museum fatigue, so we just did a walk through of the SE Asia building stopping just for the things that caught our attention. The housing examples behind the museum were the definite highlight! We loved exploring the different types and watching the videos on how they were constructed. We walked here from the old quarter (also stopping at HCM Mausoleum, the Lotte Tower, and for a swan ride in the lake by the zoo) and loved it.

Well presented. Excellent presentation of the various tribes, their ethnic origin, traditions, culture and dress. Definitely worth a visit if you are in Hanoi. There was a nice restaurant attached run by a local chef's college.

Understand Vietnam. Visit here at relativity low cost to get a good understanding of Vietnam history. We did know of the 54 different cultures making up the nation of Vietnam, visit and learn in a very hands on way.

Informative. The museum is located on Nguyen Van Huyen Street, Cau Giay District. Take the #14 minibus that runs from Dinh Tien Hoang Street, north of Hoan Kiem lake, to the Nghia Tan stop which is a few blocks from the Museum. Open Tue-Sun, 08:30am-5:30pm. Fees: entry VnD 40,000, guide VnD 100,000, camera VnD 50,000. Time required 1hour.

We had a great time!. A very informative and well-organized museum. The indoor area displays ethnic people's costumes, information about living style, culture,.. But the outdoor was really amazing with replicas of houses in the mountainous areas, some traditional games if you go at weekends,.. Allow yourself around2-3 hour visit to enjoy fully this wonderful museum!

As ethnology museums go ... Pretty good. You have to be a bit of an egghead to go to an ethnology museum. Having said that, this one is not bad and very informative about the country's many ethnic groups.

One of my favourite attractions in Hanoi. Such a great place to visit to learn not only about Vietnamese ethnology but also many other countries in Asia. Definitely check out the building next to the main building for more interesting artefacts.

Another Hanoi "must visit". 54 ethnic groups living within the borders of Vietnam are detailed here with displays of customs, living conditions, dress, commerce and even full scale housing examples. Schedule at least two hours to see most everything. Excellent gift shop as well.
interesting collection of houses and Vietnamese history. Spacious park with houses made from the original ethnic groups. Catch the water puppet shows throughout the day!
Nice museum. This museum is a chance to see all the different minorties that resident in vietnam and their cultures.40000vietnamese dong is the fee

Wonderful museum. This is a fabulous museum, the display is excellent, indoors and outdoors and everything is in English, so you don,t need a guide, unfortunately I had one and he detracted from my enjoyment. There is a restaurant in the grounds which is a training school for young people, it was v good and has tables outside, so pls. Try it, my guide wanted me to go to a place that looked like McDonald's and really tried to put me off, saying it wasn't,t good.
Fascinating museum. This is a must-see for anyone trying to get a better sense of Vietnam and its varied ethnic groups. Beautiful costumes are on display as well as old photographs.

well worth a visit. I spent about 2 hours at this museum during some free time after meetings nearby. I've always been fascinated by the ethnic diversity of Vietnam, and looked forward to learning more about the various ethnic groups. The inside displays are good and helpful, although I couldn't quite grasp the overall scheme for how things were organized. There was a lot to learn if you were interested.The highlight for me was the outside and the wonderful buildings that have been built or rebuilt here representing the various groups. Some of these are quite spectacular. I did not have time to really explore the newer Southeast Asia building, although I appreciated its architecture. Well worth the time if you have any interest in this sort of thing.

Learnt a good deal and most importantly, it was interesting for our kids.. You tell the word museum to your 7 year old and the face of boredom sinks in, but culture you must get, and so he did in a very amusing, interesting and interactive way. We all learned a great deal. Actually, visiting this place first, can give you a concentrated perspective of the country and so help you to shape your visit. The displays were colorful and authentic. And yes, the traditional houses are a must. We really enjoyed our afternoon at the museum!

First Vietnam Tour. This was included in the tour package. It is well worth the time spent to learn about the origin of this country we're visiting. We are visiting the current Vietnam but this museum allows you to learn about its history, people, and culture. Be surprised while walking the outside exhibitions. It's not naughty, it's human.

Outside exhibit the best . The museum was interesting if you're interested in the subject. The exhibits kind of got repetitive after a while but still pretty neat. The outside exhibit of the traditional homes was definitely my favourite and kind of made the whole visit worth it, so definitely don't skip that part!

Excellent Ethnonogical/Ethnographic Musum. We visited this outstanding museum on our first day in Hanoi. Old, moderate-sized, and featuring wonderful outdoor exhibits, this museum has everything, including two great gift shops (objects and books), a terrific café, and very good museum exhibits. I only wish we had several more hours there. While a bit old fashioned, the coverage of the country and it's peoples was superb. Don't miss this museum!

Excellent Representation of Vietnam's Ethnic Groups. Very impressive museum. Examples of how each of the 30+ ethnic groups live/lived. Homes of various groups have been constructed outside the building itself. There is also an attractive restaurant, a bookstore and a gift shop.
Outside is better than in. Go around the traditional houses, forget about wasting time in the central building, poor with no interpretation
54 reasons to go. The museum shows the history and lifestyle, housing of the 54 ethnic groups who live in Vietnam. It is a good place to go if it is raining
Textiles and peoples . Excellent museum and very interesting to anyone interested in the many ethnicities in Vietnam. Excellent displays of costume and descriptions of tribal life. Highly recommended

Very interesting. The museum is essentially in two parts - an outside folk museum where there are 17 different buildings typifying the different types of houses in the different ages and regions of Vietnam. We found this aspect fascinating. Unfortunately we spent so long in the outdoor folk museum part that we had to rush the second part - which was to see the indoor museum which depicted the different cultures, way of life and dress of the many ethnic groupings that make up the country as we now know it. Understanding the complexities of all the different ethnic groupings is difficult especially if, like us, you are short on time. Well worth a visit, but leave plenty of time to explore it all
Informative and interesting. Good displays and the outside homes recreations (some actual homes were rebuilt here) made the visit totally worthwhile

Worth a visit!. I'm not in particular interested in Ethnology, however, this museum offers a lots of interesting stuff of the many minorities of Vietnam. Can be a lot of the same, though. The outdoor exhibition with building from the minorities tribes is amazing!

Surprisingly interesting - Worth a Visit (if time permits). Although we were not 'enthusiastic' about visiting - this outdoor (and indoor) museum exceeded our expectations and was really very enjoyable!!If 'struggling for time' however, it's one experience that could easily be 'missed' in favour of others!!

Good Museum. Recommend allowing upto 2 hours for your visit here. We went with a tour guide here but it is not necessary. The indoor portion of this museum has good English boards. Interesting seeing differences in the tribes. The outdoor area displaying full sized tribal housing i what takes this museum from a solid 3 star rating to a 4. You can enter these buildings and take photos. Opening hours are from 08:00 to 17:30.

Must See Museum. The 40+ different ethnic people's who inhabit Vietnam today are represented in this large, relatively new museum. Their living quarters have been recreated in an outdoor setting while on the 2 floors each group's artifacts are displayed. Explanations are in Vietnamese, French and English.
Outdoor displays better than indoor. Very modern style museum, for my taste not enough interesting exhibits. Some of my friends liked it but not many. Hanoi has more interesting things to see.

A must for Hanoi. Set aside a few hours for a visit to this museum. After exploring inside,take a trip through the villages outside to see the different house structures of the various ethnic groups who inhabit Vietnam. A very interesting experience.

Worth a visit. This museum was most interesting and we spent an hour inside as well as in the grounds.It explains the ethnic makeup of Vietnam and provides an insight to the various groups that make up the country without being too detailed and boring. There is a good mix of written information, in English, that is quick to read.The outside displays of typical houses from some of the regions is again interesting and you can enter the buildings.

Great insight into the various cultures of different Vietnamese ethnologies.... Visited the Vietnam Museum of Ethnology with friends to learn more about Vietnamese culture and it's people. One of the best museums I had visited in Vietnam, which reveals details of the 54 different recognised ethnic groups in Vietnam. The museum was well curated with great exhibits of tribal art, artefacts and everyday objects gathered from across the nation. The displays are well labelled in Vietnamese, French and English which makes it a very informative trip. If you would like to know about Vietnam, it's people and their culture in greater detail then you will enjoy the museum, which is very educational and interesting. But depending on the weather I would advise taking: Sun Screen, Water, Camera, Hat or Umbrella.

STUNNING TRIP TO VIETNAM'S MINORITY REGIONS. This massive redoubt does a classy job of parceling out exhibits of the nations' amazing 54 ethnic groups. The ares are laid out with plenty of space to allow the visitor to contemplate peoples and the tools and customs they use. Do not miss this museum!
Excellent and interesting.. This attraction was part of our tour. It was very interesting, and we were able to go into the various 'houses' Some of the sculptures will make you laugh.

Make sure this is on your itinerary. This museum gives a brilliant insight into the ethnic minorities that complete the cultural picture of Vietnam. The artefacts and displays in the main museum are excellent and fully explained in English but for us it was outside that gave most. There are numerous buildings which show how the different peoples lived - you can go inside ( shoes off in a number ) and get a real feel for how life was and still is in some instances.There is a restaurant on-site where all the staff are college students working their way through their catering studies so worthy of your support.
Great place. Very interesting, has lots of information in English too really through coverage of the various groups that make up Viet Nam I thought

A cultural and educational resource. If you are looking for a place to learn about Vietnamese culture and its diverse minorities groups, the Museum of Ethnology is the place to go.Within the main building are many artifacts and informational placards that will keep you busy. In the backyard, there are life-sized replicas of houses built by tribes people that you can walk through (be respectful and take your shoes off if required).Plan to be there for at least 2 hours. You will want to hire a taxi or a motorbike or a bicycle to get there - it is about 6 km from Old Town.This was one of my favourite museums in all of Vietnam - hope you enjoy it!Tip: Go to Sa Pa and do a home-stay with a Hmong or Yao family ... it will make your visit at the Museum much more relevant.

Amazing architecture of the traditional houses!. The best part of this museum is outside, where you can walk around in many different types of structures, which represent traditional architecture of various ethnic minorities of Vietnam. They're intricately carved and decorated, and it's fascinating to read about the different customs performed in each place.

Opens up a whole world of ethnic architecture. The inside of the museum gives you a very comprehensive guide to the ethnic make up of Vietnam and its history. With many colourful and interesting relics, but the real stuff of interest (for those into architecture, building and such like) the garden is where to head. An amazing collection of life size traditional buildings have been constructed which you can penetrate! From houses on stilts, to those boarded with planking, thatch to tiles, living quarters to those that have ceremonial significance and even one type made from a kind of cob. As soon as you walk into these spaces you come into the traditional dwellers world, where you can begin to understand their daily lives, family dynamics and means of substance. The cob house even has an out building for livestock and where husbands and young men are relegated to after coming home drunk!

Expand your knowledge of Vietnam!. Went here with three other couples and all were impressed. Great modern building and really well laid out displays, with plenty of info in English (they do say 'audio tour available' but that refers to an English speaking guided tour at certain times of the day!). Too much to take in about the 54 different ethnicities, which blur together after a while, so leave time for the outdoor exhibits which are great, with relocated traditional houses etc. We caught the water puppet show too (just heard them warming up as didn't know they were included) which, again, was worth seeing and saved us paying for one in Hanoi.
Best Museum of Hanoi. More interested here. With a lots of installation traditional art, cuture and life of Vietnam. So let's come and see.
Excellent!. So intriguing and enlightening. We went by at new year so there were additional exercises yet the homes and the historical center presentations were great at any rate.
Excellent way to learn more about various ethnic groups. Cool experience and has an awesome boutique! Only downside is it is a little bit out of the way to get to!

Fascinating visit. We loved this museum. It was fascinating to learn about the lives and cultural practices of different ethnic groups in Vietnam. We especially loved walking around (and in) the stilt houses outside!

Educational!. This museum was a very good introduction to the multitude of tribes that live in Vietnam, each with its own unique customs. There are nice displays of clothing, musical instruments, fishing, hunting and farming implements in the main building, with explanations in English. We really enjoyed the video clips that provided insight in specific tribal customs. Outdoors was a large display of a number of housing styles, with an opportunity to go inside each one. This was very interesting and informative.
Excellent Overview of the Vietnamese People. This Museum included a number of accessible housing displays of the various distinct ethnic groups of Vietnam. Background was interesting.

Well worth the trip. A little out of the way but was glad it was included on our tour. Great insight into the different tribes in Vietnam. So many different ways of life. Don't miss the village houses outside.

Good place to learn about Vietnam. Its a wonderful museum with insights into different ethnic groups that are part of Vietnam. The museum also has a water puppet show which is quite nice in case you dont have enough time to visit Thang Long water puppet show

Opened My Eyes!. I knew that the Vietnamese are extremely hard-working, conscientious individuals with a great work ethic and I think that this museum explains the history and why these people exhibit these great qualities.I strongly suggest hiring a native tour guide, if at all possible. I think that anyone will find that there is more than meets the eye and a guide will be able to put the history into perspective!Very interesting and well presented!

A must-see for anthropology buffs. This is a comprehensive, family-friendly museum that shows the diversity of ethnic groups that live in Vietnam. Explanations are provided in Vietnamese, French and English, and you can get guided tours (though we didn’t). There are displays of ethnic costumes, tools, and musical instruments, and quite amazing video clips of indigenous traditional rites. There’s also an outdoor park where you can go inside the different types of housing—including the tall and the long communal houses—and watch video clips of how they were built. (Note there is one tomb outdoors with sexually explicit carvings.) For a little break, there’s a café that provides training for disadvantaged youth. This museum could easily fill an afternoon.

Not to be missed. The original dwellings in the garden are a must to visit. We started there based on someone else's review and this was a good move. We spent over one hour there which was really too short. Inside the museum one gets a bit confused by all the different tribes and their customs, costumes and ways of living. Our kids in their mid twenties also thought it was a very well explained and relaxed place to visit and get an understanding of the numerous tribes in Vietnam

A museum that showcases the diversity of the Vietnamese people. Worthwhile stop.. A museum that displays the unique cultural diversity of it's many peoples. Lots of neat objects to look at. Great outdoor exhibit composed of full scale size dwellings that you can enter. A water puppet show was also presented.

Great place to go on holiday. i usually go to Museum of Ethnology on my Tet holiday. 2-3 times i guess. there are so many things to see in this museum, also a lot of festival activities on that occasion (Tet). A visit here is surely a great chance for not only Vietnamese, but also foreign tourists to get an insight into the rich culture of Vietnam with 54 minorities.
Excellent place!. So interesting and informative. We visited at new year so there were extra activities but the homes and the museum displays were very good anyway.

Best museum I've been to. Loved it. It's amazing. A lot of things to see. Everything has an explanation in English, French and Vietnamese.If I new I would go to the garden outside first, quite impressive.There are puppets water show I think twice a day. I was there around 4pm, there was one.All that for 40vndDon't miss the lake in the other side of the street.Bus 14 goes there from the north side of the sword lake (old quarter)

Quick intro to VN's tribal variety. A surprisingly sparse, beautifully presented interior exhibit gives a good insight into the wide variety of the country's 54 tribal cultures, in an architecturally well-designed setting. On the grounds around are examples of tribal dwellings and community buildings and a water-puppet theatre with regular (loud colourful, enthusiastic) performances. For westerners, it's worth learning how matrilineal vs. patrilineal cultures affect the literal and cultural shaping of the settlements.
Amazing even under the rain. So interesting, you can spend hours and days in and out, you should take at least 4h to enjoy it properly

Get to see the 54 minorities of Vietnam in 1 place. Get to see real replica of the minorities houses here. We really enjoy the tour outside the Museum where we get to go inside the houses to see and feel. Spent about 2-3 hours here.

Insight to Vietnams amazing ethnic mix. A fascinating museum, superbly laid out. Very easy to spend 3 to 4 hours wandering around. A really useful way to understand a little more of the people's that go up to make the modern Vietnam

Very Informative, don't miss the outdoor exhibit!. You should allow yourself 2-3 hours to visit. It's quite far from Downtown Hanoi. Inside the museum, the display of artefacts, videos, information in at least 3 different languages, and a map that shows the locations of each ethnic minority (54 total) were very well done and educational.Don't miss the outdoor display of dwellings, very nicely displayed.
nice museum in Hanoi. it is amazing museum , come here we can understant more about Vietnam and people here, all most is wonderful , good trip
Worth Seeing. Lot of work put in here, and worth the trip out of the downtown core. Can be accessed by city buses 09 and 07.
Very informative. We spent 4 nights in Ta Phin near Sapa and met many villagers from the Dao community. The museum reinforced what we had experienced.

The best museum in Hanoi. Vietnam is an incredibly diverse country with more than 50 ethnicities forming 5 major groups calling it home. This museum is the perfect introduction to this diversity, featuring detailed, well labelled displays that presents artefacts from their everyday lives. The information given is easily the most well written in Hanoi. All exhibits are labelled in Vietnamese, English and French- all perfectly written. The information explains in detail the origins, culture and lifestyle of each group and so you can really get a good picture of the varied human landscape of Vietnam. This makes it an ideal stop off for anyone thinking of heading to Sapa and the North. For me, the highlight is the architectural garden which presents about 20 examples of domestic architecture from the various peoples and if you have children they will absolutely love it, especially the stilt house which reaches over 19 metres in height! At around 16:00 there's also a water puppet show which shows short plays and if you haven't seen a water puppetry show yet, this is an ideal time to do so. This is a highly recommended, well thought out and executed Museum.
Very. Informative. A really hands on participatory experience. Has water puppet show, recreations of village houses, and religious rituals, as well as history of the people.

Informative and extensive museum. We visited this museum recently and were impressed with the outdoor exhibit showcasing all of the traditional houses of all the different ethnic groups throughout vietnam. Well worth a visit. Allow a couple of hours to see everything this museum has to offer.

Education about the Vietnam you did not know about in a lovely setting. Very interesting museum and grounds, exposing us to the peoples of Vietnam about whom I knew nothing (had heard about the Hmong, of course, but there is SO much more!) Beautiful and education indoor exhibits. Do NOT miss the houses outdoors. We also saw a water puppet performance while outside. Should be on your list of places to see in Hanoi

Excellent countrywide collection. A great collection of information and styles from across the country. Well written information boards in Viet, French, and English. The replica buildings are a real treat.
A great insight into the ethnic minorities in Vietnam. Good fun, and easy to get to by taxi from the Old Quarter. The new building SE Asia has much better toilets!

Informative. Well put together displays with good English explaining the complicated web that is Vietnamese ethnicity. Particularly enjoyed the large outdoor section with full size models of various ethnic group's houses. A little out of the way but worth the visit.

Interesting and inexpensive, but not great. This museum provides a detailed overview of the 55 ethnic groups which make up modern Vietnam. The exhibits are annotated in Vietnamese, French and English and there are guide books in other languages. The entrance fee is low (under $2 U.S.). I recommend about 90 minutes for this one. It is not too crowded, and there is food available.
Good for a visit. Visited here on a day it was pouring rain. However it was a worthwhile visit. The outdoor displays are particularly good, especially the Water Puppet Show

Vietnam museum of Ethnology. Great way to learn about Vietnamese cultureA great museum where you can learn about 50+ ethnic regions of Vietnam. Inside was well-organized. well displayed with description in English. I was very interested in colorful traditional clothes of mountainous ethnic people. Outside they have displays of houses. water puppet theater. funeral houses or resting places... You could walk through many different kinds of minority houses outside the museum. A lot to see. well worth a visit. "
Very interesting!. This is a great museum that provides an excellent glimpse in to the many tribes that make up Vietnam and includes various traditional houses.

Very interesting with much culture!. Enjoyed our visit to this museum with good description of the various tribes in Vietnam. Also included are actual model of villages and homes of these tribes. Worth at least 2 hours visit!

Wonderful and interesting and a great gift shop. This is extrremely well put together and very nicely laid out museum. The architecture of the place is vey good also. The gift shop is the absolute best...wonderful selection of ethnic products and very well priced.
Emerge into ethnicity. To be honest this place is not as interesting as other museums but its ethnic collection is worth seeing.

Great way to learn about minority cultures. This was a great way to find out more about the ethnic minorities in Vietnam. Especially loved the photo exhibit on the central highlands in the 1950s and the houses in back. As with other museums in Vietnam I felt there could have been slightly more explanation of exhibits in English (some photos did not have any, though moat did). I also got the impression that some minority groups were not represented (I think they grouped similar peoples together).

Learn about Viet Nam's diversity. Worth the travel. Information on the different ethnic minorites of Vietnam. They have the actual house at the back of the museum where you may enter and climb. Super cool!
An interesting peak into the heritage of Vietnam. Museum is kept up well. Many displays including a full size replica of a house from Vietnamese countryside.

Museum and history of the Vietnamese people. A very good and well prepared collection of houses and villiges from different regions of Vietnam, telling history of some of the locals around the country

Lively family atmosphere . Lively atmosphere, many families with young children (immediately after tet). Informative exhibits with descriptions in Vietnamese, French and English. Nice modern feel to the presentation of historic information. Main exhibition inside, but nice weather means you can enjoy the full museum with additional exhibits of traditional houses outside.

Showcase of Vietnamese Tolerance. Spend the time reading about many, many ethnic group peacefully coexisting for hundreds of years.
Make sure to spend time outside in the garden to see different style houses and temples.

Fascinating insights into Vietnams's different ethnic groups. Only had time to visit the the gardens which contain examples of the different styles of housing used by the different ethnic groups. Really interesting!

Superb cultural displays and interactive buildings. Large museum with fascinating displays showing the history and way of life of Indochina's ethnic minorities. Very good information in English posted beside each display. A guide would no doubt enhance things even further. The museum displays on their own are interesting enough, but behind the museum the ethnic groups have each erected a house or building that showcases their culture and way of life. These buildings are totally interactive - you can enter each one and look around (some require climbing up ladders to enter) and are truly stunning. Allow a minimum 3 hours to see it or you may leave disappointed. First rate family outing.

A good starting point to ethic minorities of Vietnam. It was interesting and very useful to visit Vietnam Museum of Ethnology, this is set among the large parkland area, the main museum is inside a separate building(main one) and displays different ethnic minorities of Vietnam, it is very interesting and i would highlight it into anyones visit to Hanoi

A MUST When Sightseeing in Hanoi. This was one of the best museums I have ever visited. It is an excellent opportunity to learn about the variety of individuals residing in Vietnam. It shows the ethnic groups and their customs - housing, dress, handicrafts, economy, etc. This is a MUST DO! A minimum of two hours should be allocated but in reality three would be best. Be sure to go outside to visit the home replicas. Your entry fee also includes the Museum of Southeast Asia. We went in here too and quickly went through the two floors of exhibits... it was a lot to do in one day. I would not have entered if it had not been included with the Ethnology museum fee.Taxis wait outside or your can flag one down on the busy street outside the gate.

Very informative. I visited here as part of a volunteering stint and found it informative and intriguing. I would highly recommend it and hope to visit again one day when I'm not so tired and strapped for time. It's amazing to see how others live and live so well and happily with traditions that are truly beautiful.

Interesting!. Large building has displays about each of the ethnic minority groups, including costumes, lifestyle, plus on the grounds there are replica homes from many different groups to walk thru to get a perspective on their living styles, which were very interesting.
Introduction to the ethnic minorities in Vietnam. This is a very good museum, with creative and interesting displays and information. Great background for travel within Vietnam.
Great and good place for gaining knowledge. Well, this is good place to visit particularly with your young children. I was there on the Christmas time and I had a great time over there.

Insight into the many cultural groups of indo china. very well put together museum with replica houses and overview of the different cultural groups.
Probably need about 2 hours

Good overall view of history of Vietnam and different communities. Museum has nice outdoor exhibit with homes from different regions. We happened to be there when there was a water puppet show taking place. Lots of information inside!

Fascinating. You will need most of the day to thoroughly view everything in this museum. A guide is not necessary as English signage is everywhere. The outdoor exhibits of Ethnic housing and water puppet theatre performances are not to be missed. The on site restaurant did not disappoint. Our only regret, not leaving enough time before closing.

Fascinating. A very nicely laid out museum giving an insight into the 54 different ethnic groupings that live in Vietnam. In the grounds there are interesting replicas of some of the different styles of houses used by these groups. There is also a nice on site restaurant staffed by disadvantaged youngsters.

Lovely museum, something for everyone. An interesting museum showing the history of the many ethnic groups in Vietnam. Interesting photto exhibition while we were there. If kids got restless, there is a large outdoor area that is part of the museum, where visitors can watch a water puppet show or walk through the long houses.
Insight to different cultures within Vietnam . Good for an hour or so a real insight to culture from the city centre. Worth a visit and is standard on.most tours.

Wonderful insight. With our Hanoi Free Guide at our side, we learned about the fascinating history of the Vietnamese people. The highlight is the outdoor area, with structures moved from their original locations throughout Vietnam showing housing and other important pieces of Vietnamese life in a real setting. Go with a guide to experience the museum to its fullest.
Interesting museum. This museum shows how locals lived their lives. Very interesting displays. Without our English-speaking guide, the museum displays would have been less accessible.

A fascinating glimpse at the diverse ethnic groups of Vietnam. Before visiting this museum, I had no idea Vietnam had such ethnic diversity. This museum explains so much about the Vietnamese culture and all the diverse ethnic groups who live throughout the country. There are both indoor exhibits and a whole outdoor exhibit of different ethnic dwellings and tombs,some of which you can walk through.The indoor exhibits are well-presented, informative and colorful. There was so much information available. The outdoor exhibits were great. We so enjoyed seeing how various of those ethnic groups built their homes. They were very different in style and function. We climbed up and through all of them. The tombs were very interesting.There's even a water puppet theater and an extensive number of puppet exhibits.Unfortunately, no performances were taking place while we were there. This is a wonderful museum and so worth the visit.

Very nice museum . Great museum to learn about different peoples of Vietnam. Recommend a couple of hours spent here. There are tribal houses on the grounds that are fun to explore and a water puppet show is worth dropping in to see.

Nicely surprised. I was highly impressed by the quality of the museum and the effort they've gone to. It was a welcome change from hanging out in the Old Quarter and gave me a great understanding of the ethnic diversity of Vietnam, so I left a lot wiser.
Very interesting and informative. A lovely place to spend a few hours on a cold wet winters day, very informative about the different ethnic groups that make up the population.

Very interesting. I'm don't consider myself a museum person, but this museum was one of the most interesting I've ever been to. It's was definitely worth the trip (it's a bit out of town). Got to learn about the culture of the country and all the very diverse ethnicities that coexist in the region. It is very well organized and put together.I highly recommended!

A very interesting museum. The displays are well presented and labelled. They provide interesting insights into the lifestyle and culture of the number of ethnicities/tribes in Vietnam. In the outdoor area, they have actual dwellings being built by some of the tribes. This museum is definitely worth visiting. Also, be sure to visit the Craft Link shop at the entrance/exit, this is a non-profit organisation which promotes handicrafts from some of the tribes. Prices are much cheaper than other museum gift shops and tourist shops.

Museum of Ethnology, Hanoi, Vietnam. A must to visit! Who would have thought there are 37 different tribes of people who continue to live today in Vietnam, all following their individual customs and traditions. The tribes are supported to sustain their lifestyles but they are becoming fewer in number all the time. The museum is in 2 main parts. Inside there are many lovely photographs of some of the tribes taken in the recent past, along with traditional dress, artefacts and so on. Then outside are several of their traditional houses that you can go inside. Highly recommended!
Amazing must see!. This was a great introduction to Vietnamese tribal communities. Indoor and outdoor exhibits and very informative!

Visit to ethnology museum in Hanoi. Fabulous museum very informative on many aspects of the different ethnic groups in Vietnam Well laid out and good descriptions in English would recommend especially if weather is cold and wet as it was when I visitedThe gift shops sold lots of interesting nicknacks that are ethnically and locally produced

Great. Great museum. Get to know the many ethnic minorities, their art, spirituality, lifestyle and culture. A must see. They even have actual dwellings, built by the tribes themselves. Afterward, stop in the gift shop for their arts and linens. Much more variety than you'll find in town.

Great exhibits, Perfect for history buffs. This museum is a bit costly but worth it. Air conditioned and well maintained, the exhibits provide a relaxing break from the hustle and bustle of Hanoi. Recommend hiring a tour guide in your native language to take you through the museum as it helps you learn even more.

Insight into People of Vietnam. This is one of my favorite museums in Hanoi. Not only does it provide interesting details of the 50+ ethnicities in Vietnam, it is also a mini lesson about the surrounding geography and its culture. This museum is not in the Old Quarters, so from the center, you can take a taxi or uber. Our uber costed us ~ $1.50 from the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum to this museum and was about 10+ mins ride. Highly recommend this museum and would go back again when in Hanoi!

The best thing to see in Hanoi. We had 3 full days in Hanoi. It was very enjoyable but this was by far our most favorite stop in the city. A tour guide we met at dinner one night said we should go. We took a cab from our hotel in the Old Quarter. It was awesome! It is about all of the ethnic groups living in Vietnam. Talks about their history, traditions, dress, homes, etc. They even have actual homes outside in like a garden area that you can walk into. All of the signs are in English, French, and Vietnamese. It was informative and beautiful. The gift shop was the only disappointing part. After seeing all of the unique clothes and handicrafts of each ethnic minority you would expect then handmade gift shop to sell what you saw. Nope. If you don't have much time in Hanoi don't miss this stop!

It was educational . We went there in a group tour and it was educational. A lot of reading about the old Vietnam way of living, the ethnicities of Vietnam, etc. Our tour guide was patient enough to explain everything.

Worth seeing. The museum is worth learning about the different ethnic groups of Vietnam. We walked around quickly inside and spent much more time outdoors looking at the different dwellings that the different ethnic groups lived in. We found it much more interesting.

My favorite museum in Hanoi!. The Museum of Ethnology is beautifully done and a must-see place for visitors and locals alike! There is an indoor museum with one building dedicated to international cultures (less developed, but a work in progress), as well as a building with photos and artifacts representing the various ethnic groups in Vietnam. The most interesting area is in the garden behind the museum where ethnic people were invited to come and construct a house in the style of their culture. The houses are interesting to look in, as well as fun for families with children as it offers a free space for children to run and explore. Best of days with good weather, and plan for 2-3 hours to see everything!

One for bucket list. If you want to understand the people of Vietnam , their history from the past to the present this is the place. It us very well laid out and easy to follow. It's best to visit with a tour guide who can answer the questions and fill in the gaps in the displays.Tip : sunhat , sunscreen, water, tour guide , camera and good walking shoes

Great display of the diversity of Vietnam. We had wanted to get to the mountains to see many of the ethnic groups like the Hmong and the Thai, but did not have time. We skipped the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum to visit this site which truly brings history alive. Best part is the many ethnic groups with their housing, villages, clothes. We went with our own guide but there were lots of young people volunteering around museum who might help foreigners.

Well done!. The history of the people of Vietnam is complicated. This museum does a terrific job of explaining to visitors the diversity of the ethnic groups making up the country. Beautiful displays, with costumes, videos, and exhibits of great quality, inside and out. Don't miss the houses and other buildings on the grounds, with documentation on their history and origins. This museum should be on the Must-see list of every western visitor.

Unique Museum. Interesting indoors museum - the current photo exhibit was a highlight. There is a very large outdoor museum as well which was fantastic. Water puppet show, traditional houses/buildings that you can climb into, burial tombs etc etc. Only downside is it isn't within walking distance of the old town (~6km which isn't worth crossing the road that many times) but taxi fare is only ~100000 dong from the old quarter

variety of VN culture. Inside the museum, different way of life of different ethnic group can be found. There are many interesting houses, items from over 50 group. Imagine how different culture can live in peace within one country. And Museum of ethnology is where all these unite. Visiting the museum is like take a visit to a small vietnam. Just one thing, I didn't have enough time to learn more about thing being displayed there. I definetely come back next time.
The "must see" of Hanoi. great way to immerse yourself in Vietnamese culture. Helped me keep train my eyes to spy what was special in the highlands / rural parts of Vietnam.
Good insight. I wa very interested in Vietnamese culture, and this is the perfect way to get an overall view of the history here. Lots of different aspects to this museum too

My favorite museum in Vietnam!. I spent at least a couple of hours in this museum. It was a great learning about the 54 diverse ethnic Vietnamese minorities. It was worth paying the extra fee to take photos. If you enjoy learning about the Vietnamese culture, this is a must visit.

Quite far from the old quarter, worth it if you're interested in ethnology or your family tree.. It was sort of far from the old quarter of Hanoi, I took a scooter taxi out there and it seems that the scooter drivers have some deal with the museum and some artisans in the area, where they will drop you off on the way to the museum to get you to spend some money.. It was interesting but not worth the time, in my opinion.

Dated museum but great overview and fantastic tribal buildings. The museum is not centrally located, but it's easy to catch a taxi to it. Expect to spend at least two hours here, wandering the museum indoors and the outdoor reconstructed tribal buildings in the garden. (This is probably why it's not so central - it's HUGE!)Do eat before you get here though - the restaurant on the ground was not very good and pretty dirty.The indoor museum has an excellent overview of the many tribes and ethnic minorities of Vietnam, though all of it is a bit dated. It's mostly objects with short descriptions (also in English), but still very worthwhile. The building itself is pretty cool too.The best part is the outdoor area though - don't miss this! It's a bit hidden among the trees but there is about a dozen reconstructed buildings (some huge, some small huts) from different ethnic groups. You can enter them and have a look for yourself - some require a bit of a climb so wear good shoes.If you're going to Sa Pa while in Vietnam, try to visit this museum first. It enriched our stay in Sa Pa as we understood the ethnic groups better and had learnt about e.g. the H'mong people who live there.

Excellent examples of Vietnamese tribes. One of the best museums we visited in Vietnam. Entrance is cheap, exhibits are large and varied, and we really felt like we learned a lot from our trip here. The best bit is wandering through the reconstructed houses outside.

Museum of Ethnologie. This was a Morning well spent, to be able to see the different regions how the People Look,live etc. rebuilding the houses from the different areas allowed you to see what sort of Environment they live in. Especially the Mountain regions that most tourists don't visit it really gave an idea how they live.We also saw a water puppet Show which was really good. The Puppets were made out of special wood which floats and doesnt absorb water it was really cute!We also saw School classes walking around.

Culturally Enriching. Vietnam has 54 different tribes, many of which live in areas of the country not frequented by tourists. A visit to this museum will give you a good background on the various tribes and their customs and practices. We visited with a private guide who was very knowledgeable, but that's not a necessity as all the signs in the museum are in English as well as Vietnamese. Allow 60 to 90 minutes.

VERY INTERESTING EXPERIENCE. Wonderful museum showing diversity of vietnamese ethnic groups comprising the country of Vietnam. Interesting and enlightening plus the buildings and abodes of various ethnic groups were fantastic to see any enjoy.well worth a visit
Part of tour. Normally I would not have gone here. But it was nice to see especially because they had a water puppet show.There is a viet house also to see outside.
Learning history. Good place to spend the day enjoying the history and culture of the many different ethinic groups of Vietnam.

Excellent and definitely worth the trip. Spectacular museum with colourful displays about Vietnam's intriguing cultural diversity. Lots of well-presented information in English, French and Vietnamese. Inside is two floors of colourful traditional clothing, fishing baskets, depictions of weddings and funerals, and endless information on the different minority tribes throughout the country. Outside are full size long-houses and other traditional houses made of rattan and bamboo. We caught the bus there from the old quarter (number 34 & 14), only 7000 per person, which was great as a taxi might be a bit pricey for a budget traveller.

Interesting place to learn more about Vietnamese ethnicity.. A must-visit for travellers hoping to get deeper insight into Vietnam culture and ethnology. There are some funny artifacts as well as jarring ones, some perplexing ones and some colorful ones. It will take maximum half a day to explore the entire museum with a guide, and even without a guide it shouldn't take much more because the English explanations are very clear and thorough.
nice. interesting and a good alternative especially on a rainy day, to get to know 50 + different ethnic groups living in Vietnam

Learnt a lot about the ethnic origins of the Viet people and others. The museum is on a number of levels and covers the history and geography of Vietnam. It clearly outlines the various demographics and the areas where the Viet people live.

Very nice museum. Inside and outside very interesting exhibitions. Try the restaurant where students are learning the hospitality business. The outside museum gives an overview of housing and interiors from all over Vietnam.

Interesting but not a must visit.... The museum of Ethnology is probably the largest that we saw in Hanoi and documents the ethnology - cultural origins, housing, lifestyle, etc of the people of Vietnam. There are large pictoral hoardings of the tribes and their homes in addition to an array of items that they use in their day to day life including some of the metal products, clothing etc. The exterior lends itself to the various types of houses. We visited the museum late in the afternoon and by then there was really nothing available to drink or eat at the standalone restaurant that was basic and dirty. The museum shop was small and obscure and did not really have very interesting souvenirs or products. Its a visit that you can make if you have lots of time but don't recommend it if you want to see the city in a limited time frame. There are a lot more interesting places in Hanoi like the Old quarter, the sunken sword lake, the ceramic and silk villages that you can visit which are far more interesting and different and also give you an idea of the culture of the city.
History you could walk into. The outside of the museum with the different buildings from the diverse cultures was very interesting.

Interesting inside but more enjoyable outside.. Inside the museum are numerous exhibits depicting the various indigenous Vietnamese ethnic people as they live throughout the country. Your can spend a lot of time inside but I preferred the outdoor exhibits.Outdoors are replicas of "tribal" homes from different parts of the country. This is very different from city living. We were able to go into one of the houses and see how its inhabitants lived. We also climbed a tall ladder to access another house. These exhibits were very realistic and educational.

Great ethnographic collection showing the diversity of Vietnam. Great ethnographic museum with an indoor and an outdoor part; you gain an overview over the ethnic diversity of Vietnam where not only Viets live but also a large number of ethnic minorities.

A great way to introduce yourself to the tribes and culture of Vietnam. We came to the Museum on our first day in Vietnam. It was a terrific way to learn about the different tribes that inhabit the various areas of the country, and learn about cultural differences and similarities. It is beautifully laid out. While not close to the Old Quarter or French Quarter, taxis are not expensive and it is worthwhile. If you have time, stop at West Lake afterwards. It's relatively close once you're at the Museum.
viet culture in a capsule. the museum is worth the visit, covers all the ethnic communities of the region. Showcases photos, materials , traditions and customs of each community

A chance to learn about the Vietnamese minorities. Large building has displays about each of the ethnic minority groups, including costumes, lifestyle. A little bit too much info on easy ethnic group, not enough info on many of the objects in the museum. Plus on the grounds there are replica homes from many different groups to walk thru to get a perspective on their living styles, which were very interesting.

Wonderful insights into the minorities of Vietnam. This is a wonderful museum that provides visitors with a comprehensive overview of the history, cultural practices and current situation of the minority cultural groups of Vietnam. In grounds of the museum there are a range of houses built by people who are of the ethnic minorities of Vietnam. For example, Hmong people were invited and paid to construct a home in the grounds. I feel this museum provides much needed insights into the strengths, cultural practices and the resilience of Vietnam's minority groups. An experience not to be missed.

Interesting Place. We were travelling with 2 three year old kids. They loved the outdoor installations of the living quarter of different ethnic people. In fact, we did not bother to look inside the museum for obvious reasons. Dont miss the park opposite the museum if you are travelling with kids.
Really interesting place. I visited this place on Tet holiday and they had so many nice activities for children. It taked me about 3 hours to discovery this place on my own. Very interesting.

Interesting Review of Historical Vietnam. With a guided outdoor tour, an explanation of buildings of Vietnamese cultures was enlightening. Let to knowledge of ancient Hmong, and other remote cultures and their historic practices. Check out the Polynesian burial edifice.

Was alright. Wasn't expecting much, and if your a thrill seeker this is not really a thing you would do, however not the best museum, however if you want to kill time, its an interesting place to go with lots of history

Inside wasn't my cup of tea, but outside was another story. Being able to climb through the house of the various ethnic groups was awesome. I generally find museums kind of boring, but the combo of the inside and outside portions of this one was great

Dont Miss This. We enjoyed this museum muchly. There's a lot to see, well displayed and documented. One building is focused on Vietnam's cultural diversity; while a second building is a comparative display of the aboriginal groups of South East Asia. Then...there's the outdoor displays of village homes, a water puppet theatre, funeral house or resting place. It's a lot to take in.There's a restaurant on the museum grounds. Good food. We spent four hours at this museum.

Nice Museum but .... As part of the city tour, we visited Vietnam Museum of Ethnology. The tour guide was a lackluster so we wander around the museum. It's a nice museum but nothing fascinate me more than to be in the real place among the people. I would recommend to visit some villages if you have the time.

Definitely go if you have the time. I really enjoyed this museum. The museum exhibits were well put together and there were great outdoor exhibits as well. You could walk through many different kinds of minority houses outside the museum. I went up north to Ha Giang a day or two after visiting the museum and I was able to spot a lot of those same types of houses and clothing. If you are going to Ha Giang and beyond I highly recommend you take some time to visit this museum to prep for your trip North.
Great Displays. This is a great museum representing the different ethnic groups in Vietnam. It's quite educational and informative. The rebuilding of some of the houses is great.

Informative museum. I loved exploring this well put together museum. I love the indoor exhibits, but the houses made by different ethnic groups outside was such a unique experience. Great way to learn about the different ethnic groups of Vietnam.

Excellent museum. Spent a (typically) hot Hanoi afternoon here learning about the diversity of ethnic groups that exist in Vietnam. Descriptions are balanced and available in English, French and Vietnamese. Whilst the large gallery is well worth poring over, spend time in the outdoor recreations of traditional ethnic housing, they really give you a sense of the atmosphere and conditions families lived in. Great for families as children can climb up and into these life-sized dioramas and learn interactively about these cultures.Tip: Take a taxi with a reputable company to the museum, it is a little outside of the touristy side of Hanoi.

A fascinating museum.. A fascinating museum, it gives a wonderful insight into the way of life and traditions of Vietnam’s many different tribes and ethnic groups. The displays are helpfully labelled in French, English and Vietnamese.

Very large building for a very small exhibit. The exhibit is not very impressive in our opinion, and the clothes, tools etc. were mostly modern examples and not originals. The information provided only gives a very superficial introduction to the different minorities. We enjoyed the different housing types in the "yard" of the museum though!

Very interesting museum. A great overview of the different groups within Vietnam. Beautiful clothing displays, interesting houses you can enter. Plus there is another whole modern building with exhibits from all around the world. A great activity, especially for a rainy day in Hanoi. Restaurant on site was good too and provides a training scheme for underprivileged youth.
Nice Museum. Enjoyed the visit. It is however a bit repetitive and the route through the museum is a bit unclear. Consider hiring a guide for 100.000 dong.

No War Propaganda. Worth 2-3 hour visit. 50k to take photos Entry not expensive. 60k to 90k by Taxi ( 15-20 min) from old quarter depending on how bad Taxi rips you off ( taking the long way) Interesting buildings and photos etc

One of the best museums in Vietnam. The VME provides an exhaustive overview of the dozens of ethnic groups that live in Vietnam. The wall texts are well-written, and most are available in Vietnamese, French, and English. The content featured is based on extensive scholarship and smart curatorial choices, which are rare qualities among museums in Vietnam. Allow at least two hours to visit the exhibits inside, as well as the traditional houses behind the main building. You can enter the traditional houses but may need to remove your shoes first. I first visited the VME more than ten years ago and am glad to see that it’s still maintaining a high standard of care and display.We had a snack at the Hoa Sua Training Restaurant onsite, which also serves full meals. Our taxi to/from the Old Quarter cost no more than 150,000 VND each way.

surprisingly interesting. The museum is quite a long way out from the old quarter but it is worth the visit. I was anticipating a rather boring visit to the museum - but infact it was really interesting. The displays on the two floors captured my interest and the displays gave lots of information. Certainly worth making the journey.
Ethnic exploration. Love the collections of all Vietnamese ethinic minorities here, so authentic and reminiscent of a peaceful country with many features of culture

A trip back in time. We went to the outside part of the museum first. It was very informational and cool. We learned a lot and I thought it was interactional as well. You could attempt to balance on the log, climb up buildings and take pictures. If you came at the right time you could see an example of the water puppet show. Inside was very informational and I really enjoyed the set up in there as well.

If it's really bad weather... . Ok - but not more. Limited information in English and no guide to be found. The museum is clean and the air is cool and getting there by taxi is cheap if you use the green Mahlin taxis

Unique experience, but not a must-see. The VME provided an interesting overview of the numerous ethnicities residing in Vietnam. The place is well maintained and displays an extensive collection of everyday items, crafts and costumes owned by the tribes in Vietnam. If you are interested in the history of Vietnam/anthropology, this will be the place for you. However, the exhibits can be quite repetitive.

Very Comprehensive. Well done and thorough, interesting, and informative presentation of Vietnam's 50 plus ethnic groups. This is an incredibly in depth museum, almost overwhelmingly so. Best to keep moving and skim the descriptions and wall labels, reading only the ones that are truly interesting. We took our time reading almost everything and realized that, laid out in a large outdoor park behind the main museum building, were various full scale indigenous group buildings--thatch roofed homes on stilts, meeting halls, burial tomb. We walked through most of the buildings. This museum was exhausting and a must see.

Pleasant and Informative. I took my 11 and 13 year old children the the museum in January. They enjoyed the outdoor exhibits showcasing a variety of traditional homes from Vietnam. The especially liked the balance beams that were set around the outdoor area. We watched only 10 minutes of the water puppet show as we'd seen one already - the puppets, live music and story telling was a treat. We breezed through the inside exhibits as the kids weren't so interested in reading the information. The exhibits were interesting and gave us a nice overview of the region's tribes. I especially enjoyed the clothing samples.We had lunch in the restaurant on the property. The Pho was very good and reasonably priced. Overall, we enjoyed ourselves. If I was going back, I might pay the d100,000 for a private guide. Admissions: Adults d40,000, children d10,000
A Must!. Super intriguing and all around clarified, not exhausting by any means, I suggest emphatically, even with children. The outside is particularly worth investing energy.
One of the best things I did in Hanoi. It's one of those things which you simply must see when you're in Hanoi. It's very well curated and the exhibitions on the outside are lovely to see.

Really interesting. Great indoor exhibit explaining many ethnic origins of Vietnam and asian people. Then a whole bunch of authentic houses of different ethnic groups outside. To Top it off a great and reasonable price restaurant by students learning hospitality trade. Allow 2 or 3 hours

Educational. Good to know the history of Vietnam and experience their way of lives.
Amazing place to learn and teach young children about the different ethnics.
Easy going and well maintained place

A MUST GO PLACE. No doubt to say that it was the must go place in Hanoi. Many type of ethnic people groups in Vietnam display here. Huge area to chill with friends. Totally so worth place. Highly recommend.

Great overview of local people . This museum provides a great précis of the >50 ethnic groups in Vietnam. Good if you don't make it to Sapa. The highlight was the local houses out the back. These are real houses from different regions, constructed by the people of that region. In some cases they're actual houses that have been moved on site. Nice and quiet if you've had enough of the old quarter.

A huge thumbs up from an 8 year old. The museum is lovely, with great mixtures of textile and costume examples, as well as videos of different events from different tribes (54 in Vietnam! Who knew?!) It was great to learn about the different groups, but the highlight is the garden, with full size models of 15 homes from different groups. Well worth reading the inside and playing outside. Cafe was also very reasonable and extremely tasty; also served as hospitality training site for young people. Finally, the shop there is associated with Craft-link, and has lovely products from various groups, well-made and proceeds supporting the women in those communities. We spent 4+ hours.
really a must i Hanoi. Super interesting and well explained, not boring at all, I recommend strongly, even with kids. The outside is especially worth spending time.
Good museum. Good displays of various ethnic groups culture and lifestyles. The museum is well organised. Taxi is the best way to get there.
Educational Exhibits In Attractive Setting. This museum details the history of various ethnic groups in Vietnam. The buildings housing it are impressive, and it is definitely worth perusing.
worth the visit. it is an excellent museum with indoor and outdoor exhibits. it should be included in every visit in Hanoi.

Interesting collection of artifacts from Vietnam's 50+ ethnic minorities. There's a fair amount to see and you'll have to do it on your own unless you've booked a tour. It was interesting to us to learn more about the variety of tribes that live here. The grounds feature a number of life-sized tribe-specific dwellings and tombs. Note that there's a cafe and restaurant (outside) on site as well as a bookshop and museum store.

Well worth a visit. Interesting museum highlighting the various ethnic groups that make up Vietnam, particularly if it happens to be raining during your visit to Hanoi. Perhaps slightly better curated is the wing of the museum focusing on Southeast Asia in a newer building set to the side of the grounds that is worth a walk through.

This is a great museum. We came here as part of our family tour and it's well worth the visit. It is very well laid out and the photography and exhibits are great. The outside exhibits are also really good
Interesting . Was an interesting place but I think that I could have found other activities more enjoyable on our short visit to Hanoi

Great experience!. I traveled with my family that includes 3 small kids! This is one of they favorite experience! They loved to see the different type of houses, climbing up and now, the water puppet show and we were still able to share with them some vietnamese culture from the main pavilion that is a nice small museum!

Great Village Replicas. We did the Hanoi Day tour and this was part of that tour. I said that because we didn't spend as much time there as we would have had we been on our own. However, the museum was very nice. It was interesting to see their displays of ethnic clothing and the minorities in the country. The highlight for us was the outdoor museum which had replicas of a variety of ethnic houses still found in Vietnam. They were great!
Exellent. The best place to review Vietnamese cultures. Very natural and I like the art present the Asian style cultural.

Very interesting cultural experience. We visited this very well laid out museum. It was the best museum we experienced in Vietnam with both an interior portion and the outdoor areas that contained buildings from throughout the country. We enjoyed learning alot about the different cultures that are part of Vietname.

The Best.... Found most of the so called popular attractions quite boring in Hanoi except this museum which stands out! The museum had some interesting exhibits on the inside and the outside quite interactive, open house one can interact with various tribes inside those different huts, walk over the lake. Quite a comprehensive display and descriptions of various ethnic groups in Vietnam. There is a library and Souvenir shop where one can buy postcards, books and small handicrafts. This no doubt the best attraction in Hanoi to know about Ethnic Minorities.

Too much information - not possible to digest the various groups identified.. We were interested in understanding where people come from and how they got there. But this is too much detail and frankly hard to swallow that all the groups are actually distinct from each other rather than just variations of an original set of people. The water puppet show was good though.
Take a guide along. Make sure you have a good guide to explain whats what, where to go and when to go. It can get a bit repetitive after a while, so don't recommend spending more than an hour there

Love it. I came from Canada that is known for its multi-culturism, human right n equality of man n woman I was so glad to see the displays in the museum -- the acceptance of many minorities. And the rich, diverse, culture. I came across a few tribes during the visit. Way to go!!! Salute to Uncle Ho!!!

One of the best.... Unfortunately, I found some of the attractions in Hanoi quite boring...I know, I know. But this one was one of the best. The museum had some interesting exhibits on the inside and the outside was quite interactive, open house that you could climb into climbing frames, walk over the lake. It was one of the better attractions we visited. There is a library and Souvenir shop where we got some postcards from. (Go to the toilet before you get here - they were bad)
Good insight to ethnic groups in Vietnam. Quite a comprehensive display and descriptions of various ethnic groups in Vietnam. Best way is to get a taxi if you stay in the old quarter.

Very educational!. I'm quite surprised by the quality of the museum and the exhibitions. It's not a big place for such a big topic but the organizer is able to compose a very concise selection of artifacts bundled with clear explanation of their origins and significance. The reconstruction of exemplary villages is also more informative than the "real" villages you could visit in some day tours off the city. Must go if you have two hours to spend and relax to learn more about the south East Asian ethnicity.

Great afternoon out - living history with all of the tribal houses. Went here based on my parents rave reviews from when they visited Hanoi two years ago. Have to admit it probably wouldn't have been on my list, but it turned out great. The main building houses a collection of artifacts and displays from Vietnams various montagnard and indigenous minorities, which are pretty much what you would expect (I should add the main building could use some sound-absorbing ceilings - even with small numbers of people the sound reverbs make it very loud). But the real attraction are several acres of buildings out back which are full-size village buildings, each actually built by people from each region, which you can walk through. I should also add that the restaurant on the museum grounds is excellent. It was founded as a non-profit culinary school by several retired Vietnamese teachers, and we ended up having one of the most pleasant lunches of our entire stay in Hanoi there

Fantastic way to learn about the Vietnamese People. Great value for money. We paid 40000 dong and spent all morning here. If you wish to take photographs then you must pay extra. If you can come on the weekend make sure you time it correctly to see the water puppet show. When we visited it was on at 10am, 11:30am and 2pm. It's well worth watching.The museum is not close to any other attractions so we caught a taxi there. You get better value if you book one from your hotel. The exhibits have English descriptions as well as Vietnamese so you won't have difficulty understanding their meaning.If the weather is bad take a coat as the exhibition is both indoors and outdoors. The outdoor exhibits include different houses of the Vietnamese People, which are either replicas or have been dismantled and then reconstructed at the museum. They are really interesting. It's worth noting that you need to take your shoes off to enter most of these houses and that some climbing of steps is required.This museum is definitely worth the trek and will set you up with the knowledge needed to make the most of your travels through Vietnam.

Perfect introduction to Vietnam. A French and Vietnamese co-funded museum dedicated to the people of Vietnam. A great place to kick start your trip in the country. The museum is very informative and interesting. Take your time to explore the two main buildings, watch the Water puppet show (difficult to understand the context but beautiful nonetheless), climb the outdoor huts and explore the beautiful museum shop. The cafe supports a charity for young people. Taxi from old quarter 90-110.000 dong.
Boring. I don't understand how this museum has such high ratings. It was very boring, very little information, and very little of interest. Waste of time.

A surprisingly interesting visit!. Our guide persuaded us that this was worth a visit. It was genuinely quite interesting! The architecture of the new building is interesting in itself and all of the exhibits are well-presented with English translations. I kind of got a bit bored wandering the museum after a while but getting outside renewed my interest. There are a series of building that have been resurrected on the site, showing accommodation from different areas of Vietnam and in different periods. Some of them are stunning. If you have spare time in Hanoi, this is definitely worth a visit.
nice place. You get to learn all about the different peoples that make up Vietnam, and a look at how they lived, some remote areas still follow these traditions today, but am sure not for long.
Interesting. A museum with complete collections of various cultures. Spend around an hour there with our tour guide. A must-go for the trip to Hanoi.

Interesting if you like to see how other people live . This museum is very interesting if you like to see how other people live. it clearly depicts and explains the 54 recognised ethnic groups living in Vietnam. It portrays images and objects explaining daily life for these different people as well as, their various cultural and religious rituals.

insightful. the museum of ethnology though located a little far from the main city centre should be a must visit because it gives a wonderful insight into the lives, living conditions, professions and the like of the 50+ enthnic groups in vietnam. do keep atleast 3-4 hours for this.

Great way to learn about the ethnic groups. This very well done museum is an excellent way to get the scoop on the many ethnic groups in Vietnam. Good exhibits both inside the museum and on the surrounding grounds where there are many examples of the various types of houses used by the different groups.

Interesting experience, worth a visit!. Be sure to drop by this museum. I thought it the most interesting of all the places to visit in Hanoi. Able to learn about the many different ethnic tribes of Vietnam and how they made their houses of different materials and styles. Also the way they live and go about life. Worth a visit for sure!

Interesting exhibits, very informative. The exhibits were very nice, with information in bite-sized bits for easy understanding. After the indoor exhibits, check out the outdoor ones for a better understanding of the ethnic minority tribes of Vietnam. We went to the museum after our visit to the Hmong tribes in Sapa, so it really deepened our understanding of the tribal culture and houses. There are quite a few outdoor "houses" so if you're running out of time, just check out the first few at the entrance as well as the communal house (the tallest structure- you can't miss it!)Very educational museum, suitable for students and family :)
Excellent Museum. There are lots of displays and descriptions in English within the museum but outside amongst the replicas of different village houses is my favourite area to wonder.
Worth visiting. Interesting and well organised museum with clear description of ethnical culture. In the garden you can visit reconstructions of ancient traditional houses.

terrific , great fun, interesting visit. uncomplicated, Ernest , simple museum. No high-brow heavy handed cultural talk down. But may not appeal to the intellectual giants.a wonderful outing for the kids.loved the outdoor garden.

Colourful and informative. There are some very interesting displays and videos if you want to find out about the many peoples that make up Vietnam. We went with some Viets who make up more than 80% of the population and seem dominant in most ways. The hut displays outside are impressive and the outside jungle gardens beautiful. So beautiful that many Vietnamese newlyweds have their photos taken there. And many choose to just hang out there on sunny days.Allow at least a couple of hours.

Superb museum; well worth the visit. Museum has informative signage in English. The full sized traditional houses of different ethnic groups surrounding the museum are great to visit, enter etc. There is also at times a water puppet show, included in the very reasonable admission cost, that is equally as good as the tourist one in the city centre. I've visited the museum twice, ten years apart, and came away just as pleased this latter time. Taxi ride to get there, about 100 000 dong or you could take a bus.

Great history of minority groups of Vietnam. This museum provides an excellent overview of the history of minority groups but it is the outside displays that sets it apart from many museums. The houses that Hmong people and other groups live in have been faithfully reproduced, moved from other areas of Vietnam to the museum. The inside displays are not overwhelming, just enough information. The restaurant is set up to provide disadvantaged young people an opportunity to develop careers and they do a great job.

Fascinating with Hanoi eBuddies. For the love of visiting museums,I choosed the famous museum of ethnology with students from Hanoi eBuddies.I was overwhelmed by the wide diversity of Vietnam's cultures and particularly the life style of ethnics.I highly recommend this museum !

Terrific!. This is a great, informative museum with an extensive outdoor area filled with ethnic minority house types that you are welcome to walk in (or climb in as the case may be). We were lucky enough to go before heading to Sa Pa and our visit truly helped us better appreciate Vietnam. If you like textiles, traditional cooking/living, dwelling and boat type then this is the place for you. We understand there are sometimes performances at the museum and suggest you check with your tour organizer or the museum calendar to include one when you go.

One day tour. Even with a drizzle it was such a good place and so interesting to see how the different tribes lived. Also a free puppet show. You will need to get a taxi as slightly out of town but worth it, plus my daughter loved it .

Quite fascinating.... I like the architecture garden where they featured native houses of the Vietnamese people in bamboo and wood, it was really interesting. The other museum has a modern style which also caught my eye.

True history of Vietnam. Had a wonderful time at the Museum of Ethnology and learned so much about the ethnic make up of Vietnam. There is alot if information so glad w went along with a Tour Guide who explained the history and how the different tribes lived. The outdoor display is pretty good and gavce a pratical insight into the different living accomodations.

Worth a visit - well presented. My entire family enjoyed this place. It was great wlaking through the Museum learning about the various ethnic Peoples of Vietnam - well presented artifacts, lots of information .The outdoors gardens around the Museum are also worth a visit - they have life size models of different types of homes built by different communities. It was great fun exploring these homes. My kids loved going in and out of the houses, climbing up to the stilt homes and most of all....it was fun trying to cross the bamboo bridges without falling off. All in all a fun couple of hours.Afterwards we had lunch at the Restaurant within the museum grounds...I think it is run by interns of the Hanoi Hospitality school...very good food, superb deserts - we loved their Creme Brulee.

Less well known minorities highlighted. While the majority of the country is Viet in origin, there are 54 minority groups still living in the uplands. This museum is a good attempt to preserve their history before it disappears. The surprise is that most of the displays, from the costumes to the hand constructed houses in the back were made within the last 25 years.
It was interesting . Im not really this type of traveller so my review is bias. There was reasonable content, alot of information about traditional dress
Interesting . The outdoors buildings showing various construction types from a range of Vietnamese ethnic groups were really good. Ran out of time and didn't make it to the indoors exhibitions.
Nice place. This is a nice place for people who interested in Vietnamese history and people. Its good to have a walk around. Recommended!

Delightful indoor/outdoor museum. If you are looking for a place to escape the relentless motorbikes of the city and learn something about the culture and various peoples, this place is worth a half day visit. On display are model and real size houses (see pic), interesting costumes (totally impractical for the C21st), jewellery, photographic displays, water puppet theatre and other intriguing artefacts. Lovely to walk around and escape the outside world.

Surprised to see this rated so highly. This museum was ok.
