Seeing the reviews here made me think it would be fresh and exciting, but I really didn't see anything I haven't seen before.Out of all the museums in Hanoi, this one definitely was the least interesting. Lots of exhibits were the same. Be prepared to see lots of the same traditional clothes and baskets.

Awesome museum. Very well set up, loads of beautiful objects to admire and learn from.It is quite a long way from the Old Quarter where we stayed, make sure you know what you have to pay for your taxi.Nice place to spend some quiet time too while visiting busy Hanoi.

Updating. Been here several times and always impressed with the array of exhibits. The new SE Asia exhibition only looks to add to he diversity and options. Clearly the best museum in Hanoi for a wide age range and interests.

Getting better. I've been here many times and continue to learn and see new things. The main building has a nice flow through main and upper levels, though stairs are required, and generally portrays well unique and interesting aspects of each ethnic group that occupies the territory of present day Vietnam. Clothing, economy, housing, religion, family and social structure are mentioned, and generally well portrayed with a combination of artifacts, diaramas and video. The external grounds with housing and lifestyle displays complement the interior displays, allowing one to better imagine living in a stilt house, or cooking in a sandbox stove inside a highly flammable house. The grounds also have a nice flow from one area to the next. The piece that is missing here is any sense of "living displays" as is the norm in other such museums around the world.The museum also has some special exhibition spaces, a smaller one in the main building, currently featuring photos from a highlands area taken in the1950s and stunningly displayed, and the much larger and very nice Southeast Asian building which is fairly new, and houses an interesting array of Asian artifacts and some rotating displays, currently a special exhibit of Indonesian glass art.A museum-goer will find a lot to enjoy here; children can be engaged, and the trilingual displays make the material more accessible to anglo- or francophones. Overall, a very enjoyable experience that continues to engage and educate, and is moving towards world-standards for such.

The good stuff is at the back. The museum itself provides lots of information on Vietnam history and culture but it was quite boring for me. We didn't know there are other buildings behind the main building until the last 30 mins. There are houses of minorities outside behind the main building which is very interesting and much more fun.

A perfect introduction . We started our trip to Vietnam by the visit of this museum. It is a bit run down but constitutes a perfect insight into the great variety and richness of the Vietnamese culture. The new extension is also captivating. Lunch at the museum restaurant is also worth the visit!

Outdoor house recreation. The outdoor section of museum was most interesting to me - they have rebuilt various houses typical for different regions and uses. also saw one of famous water puppet shows.

Fantastic museum!. Fantastic venue!Great expos on different minorities in Vietnam. The outdoor display with traditional houses is especially interesting.Need a cab to get there as it is away from downtown area, but really worth it.If you need to have lunch, the food at the café on site is good.

Ideal place for foreigners to explore Vietnamese culture. I have visited the Vietnam Museum of Ethnology many times, but I am always impressed by it. There are so many interesting things to learn more there. Playing traditional games and enjoying water performance were great experience to me.

Well curated museum . This is a great museum to learn more about the different ethnicities of Vietnam.
It was interesting and items were well displayed. You could spend quite an amount of time depending on level of interest and if you took time to read the information.
Well worth the entrance fee.
Meh. Found it a bit b OK and nice facilities but very focused on textiles and a lot of what you can see in any other museum

The best way to know about Viet Nam culture !!!. It was really nice to visit this nice place. Only during 2 hours but We could understand about history and daily life of Viet Namese in the past. Thanks!

Was expecting more. We went here with a guide and after looking at the reviews was expected to be blown away. Maybe we missed something or were expecting too much, but found this place to be a little ordinary. Some parts we found interesting, the park outside mostly. Our guide explained certain building structures for different tribes. Without his company I don't think we'd enjoy this museum as much. Each to their own, but we found the prison and women's museum to be more enjoyable on our trip in Hanoi.

More intersting than most people think. My time at the Museum of Ethnography mirrored a few books that I have read about this and was an entreaty into the lives of many people whom most people who visit Viet Nam would overlook. I have been fortunate to have been among a number of these ethnicities in their own locale. I was in their homes, their pagodas, their churches and temples. I have been with them as they revered those before them, prayed for the lives of their families and friends and looked at the historic places among which they live. I have been invited to ring bells, taught by monks and had a LOT of tea with monks at so many pagodas and even at their monasteries.The Museum of Ethnograhy actually gives you a true experience of life in the "countryside" as they call it. From the farthest reaches to the north with Black Thais, Hmong and Black Hmong and so on all the way south of HCMC, one can get it all right here. You can see how some people still live in Viet Nam. You can get a feel for their lives and their sense of family that holds them together and makes them strong. Hey, you don't need to memorize them all. I certainly can't. However, you will love this place, walking around, going into actual models of homes all over Viet Nam, seeing how people live and wondering about how their lives go on and what they are doing today. Look at the clothes, look how hot it is in one place and cold in another and how that affects what they make and what they wear. This is a memorable peek into the lives of so many. I hightly recommend it. By the way, most materials are in English . . . You won't be lost.

Worth it for the outdoor part. The inside stuff is OK, not bad, but nothing that interested me that much. But the recreations of the many different types of houses out back was very interesting. Its worth a visit for those alone.

Best museum! Note for visitors with kids - go to the park too:. We took an uber from an old quarter hotel and were very happy to get away to explore the museum. Our 18 month old son loved seeing the houses and we loved the exhibits. There is an awesome park across the street too.

For a Glimpse of Ethnic Vietnam. The Vietnam museum of ethnology gives one a fairly good glimpse of Vietnamese ethnicity. The various dwelling houses of people of different ethnic backgrounds is a learning experience of the culture and rituals of the Vietnamese people.

Very Informative . It's a good platform of.understandung the various ethnic group / clans in Vietnam. Their rich in culture is also displayed at the museum. It's one of the best museum I've visited so far in Hanoi. You will never regret visiting it.

Enjoyed the outdoor displays. This museum goes into a lot of detail on the various tribes and peoples of Vietnam, including their histories and lifestyles. It is interesting for a short visit. I most enjoyed the outdoor area with reconstructions of different kinds of houses, boats, etc.

This museum is worth the taxi ride. By far the best museum I visited in Hanoi. Easy to follow narrative in English & Vietnamese. Excellent exhibits on everything from house types through dress, funeral rights, musical instruments, water puppets to dress and religious observance. An impressive phograhic exhibit taken in 1950s. Is a bit coy about the treatment of these minorities since reunification.

A very good place to visit in Hanoi. This museum offers a huge interesting collection of photos, audios, objects, etc of 54 ethnic groups in Vietnam, their cultures, customs, costumes, ways of living. There is also a nice park outside to show real traditional houses of different groups. You can easily spend a few hours here.

Bright and attractive building and well laid out exibits.. Enjoyed this exibition of the many colourful and historic ethnic groups in Vietnam.
Well worth visiting.
A Dictionary of Etnicities in Vietnam. A must visit place In Hanoi to fully understand the diverse Ethnicity and different cultures of the people in Vietnam.

Must see. This museum has exhibits about the different cultures that go to make up Vietnam and outside (the best part) is a garden with examples of the very different styles of traditional architecture

hmmmm; if you have really nothing else to do. it was a very rainy day; decided to go to this recommended museum. to be honest: we have seen much better ones and wished we would have given priority to other attractions.

Great outdoor exhibition!. There is a lot of information in this museum, but if you're short of time, make sure to visit the outdoor area. They have transported real examples of the houses of different ethnic groups in Vietnam into the garden, and it's great fun walking around in their shoes and seeing how life is like in these remote communities.
Nice place ... Takes you back in Time. Nice place ... Takes you back in Time ... Very nicely built architectures and good place for clicking pictures

Filled with Ethnographic Information. Any tourist to Hanoi would spend many hours at different museums. For the most part, Hanoi's museums aren't exactly well-maintained are fascinating. The only exceptions are the Women's Museum and this one.I thoroughly enjoyed my time here. I took about 2-3 hours, slowly reading the many exhibits of the various minority groups in Vietnam. There's information on the history of the tribes, their customs, and the exterior of the museum even had replicas of the houses the minority groups live in. Apparently, these replicas use the same types of wood and other building materials that the various minority groups would use to build their houses.Do note that it's about a 30 minute bus ride away from the Old Quarters. I took a public bus (bus 14) from the famous Ho Hoan Kiem (aka Ho Guom, the most famous lake by the Old Quarters). You'd have to walk a short distance to the museum from where you alight as well. If you're unsure of how to get there via public transport, you can always get your hotel/hostel to book a cab for you. It shouldn't cost you too much.
a summery of Vietnam. The displays were labelled in English and Vietnamese, which showed Vietnam's cultural heritage. Some of the displays were shown humoursly
Fantastic museum. We have been there this last November, great museum but go with a guide, otherwise you will loose the essence of it.
Fascinating view of Vietnam. A local guide accompanied me to this museum and provided great additional cultural information. But even on my own it would have been fascinating.

vietnamese Ethnology. A fantastic museum yo get an understanding of the many ethnic groups in Vietnam. There are maps to cover the various districts and a brief explanation of many of the ethnic groups and some of their customs. We spent 2 hours in the museum but could have spent lots more time if it was available.

A Fascinating Museum. We learned a great deal about the evolution of Vietnam and its peoples, thanks to a very knowledgeable and interesting tour guide - Thai. Impressive exhibits, with an outdoors area full of houses and other items of interest. A good start to our holiday, with lots to see and discover. Worth a visit.

very informative and good for kids. went there with the family and were very pleased with the exhibition.
nice place with loads of things to show and to discuss with kids and friends
A fantastic museum!. This place is great as it shows all the different ethnic tribes that live in Vietnam. I loved the way they showed each tribe with their traditions and attire.

The best museum. This is definitely the best museum in Vietnam, here you can see all the 54 ethnic groups. Built by the French long ago in the colonial time, it's always the must see place for tourists groups
So much to learn there. This was such a discovery allowing you to undrestand the multiple ethnicity of people and their craft in Vietnam. An absolute must in Hanoi

Good museum. This is a good museum. We visited it with a group and a local guide so we had a lot of added narration which made it very good. This is good for a couple of hours of learning about the Vietnamese people

biggest Museum, great place to seeing. Vietnam Museum of ethnology is very big museum, nice to seeing and good to know the special house, copy of minority people. i have a lot photo picture . highly recommend to visit !

Only arts & crafts. 40,000 vnd entry. 8.30-5.30 exc Mondays. Located 5km from the main city hub. It is really just arts and crafts of the various minor ethnic groups in Vietnam. If you are not into arts and crafts and thought culture was beyond that alone, you will be disappointed. There is very little explanation of most of the artefacts e.g. next to the ornamental knife, the sign just says "knife". It does not give any indication of governance, rule of law, society structure; cooking techniques, education and religion are dealt with superficially. So, one is left with no real "feel" of what the various ethnic groups sympathies or pathos lies. It is curious that in every other Vietnamese museum, the Vietnam War is mentioned at every opportunity but not here.

Recently renovated. This is about 5 kms east of the centre of town but is well worth visiting. I went there some 7 years ago and found it disappointing as it was looking very tired and unkempt. However it has undergone a much needed spruce up and is now very appealing and interesting particularly in the displays and explanations regarding the 54 ethnic groups in Vietnam. The attached bookshop and Craftlink souvenir shop are worth going to.

big and nice place. there is many traditional house. Some of them required us to climb it. warn your children ( i saw a little girl crying too scary to go down, his parent took a long time to get her down)

So much to take in. Complete ethnology history of Vietnam.. I spent 2 hours here. It was not enough. Unfortunately by the time the 2 hours was up I was so full of information I needed a change so rushed through a fair few exhibits. My suggestion? Visit over 2 days and spend more time taking it all in.The museum contains copious amounts of information from early history of Vietnam through to recent with the focus being on the various ethnic groups that make up the country.It is very hard to describe what is here in a review as there is just so much.They have guided tours available or you can walk through at your own pace. There are also displays related to other countries that have had an influence on Vietnamese culture over the years.A must visit for any history buffs or people curious about Vietnam's history.

You have to visit this place. Less than $2CDN admission. Very nice café inside. The traditional buildings on the site are incredible. You could spend an afternoon here and be intrigued the whole time. I learned a lot about Vietnamese culture and was fascinated by all aspects of the displays. Also a water puppet theatre there, which was really cool.

Very interesting!!. We really loved learning about the various ethnic groups that make up Vietnam's population. Vietnamese culture is explained regarding the influences from minority and outside ethnicities. It is really interesting to see the different methods ethnic groups use in day to day activities. The displays with dummy's imitating cultural practices were a welcome change from conventional museum monuments

the house outside the museum built by the different people of Vietnam is a must see attraction and much better than the. the house outside the museum built by the different people of Vietnam is a must see attraction and much better than the

Very interesting museum. Went there with my wife and was vey impressed with the quality of the exhibits and the lay out. There are three parts to the complex. The main building houses exhibits about the 50+ ethnic groups that compose Vietnam. It is the older part and could probably use a little freshening. Nevertheless it is vey encompassing and one could easily spend 3 or 3 hours there. There is a new building that houses private collections mostly about Southeast Asia. It is beautifully laid out and there are some very nice artifacts there. Finally there is an outdoor village that shows homes from various tribes. Again, nice layout. Well done, and the entry price is cheap $2.

Vietnamese Ethnology Exposure!. This museum is outline the Vietnamese Ethnology throughout the development of Vietnam. We booked the city tour during our 3 days in Hanoi and this place was included in the trip of Hanoi City. We really satisfied with the knowledge after visit this museum.
Worth visiting!. At 40,000 VND, you can be introduced to Vietnam's beautiful culture, view exhibits and see many artifacts. Really informative and educational.
Good place to start. A fascinating introduction to the people of Vietnam. This prepared us for our travels around the country.

Interesting and instructive insight into Vietnamese people. There are 54 ethnic groups in Viet Nam, and this museum provides insights into the culture of each of these groups. Displays include a wide range of authentic artifacts, from clothing to household implements to housing to musical instruments. There are photos and videos that help to bring the lifestyle of each group to life. The museum provides ample space to wander and absorb the exhibits.We only had time to see exhibits in the main building. There is an open-air exhibition and a separate Southeast Asia building that we didn't even have time to visit - we'll have to see it next time. There is also a Fair Trade shop right outside the museum's front door, called Craft Link, that offers a broad array of beautiful, locally-made products at reasonable prices.
worth a visit. a great introduction to the culture of this beautiful country, highly recommend spending an afternoon here

Great Museum for families. My children and I really enjoyed this museum. We viewed almost every exhibit carefully and my child was intrigued by most of the exhibits there. The outdoor part of the museum was incredible. We enjoyed exploring the traditional houses there.

Well worth spending time on. Both in- house and out - door exhibitions are worthy to see. In - house exhibition brings a lot of information about history and culture. And out - door is so amazing. You can come into some unique houses. It is very interesting. It took me 4 hours to walk around and enjoy all the museum.

Interesting. We was going there guided by our guide from Hanoi Free guide.The place is so huge, we couldn't finish to see all cause we was so tired due to the long flight trip.But at least, the museum helps us to know about Vietnam which we never knew before :)

Insights on Vietnam's history and people. This museum gives a detailed insight into the history and different cultures and people making up the country.Inside there are many artefacts and models and outside there are examples of the different homes people live in throughout the country.If you want to learn about Vietnam this is a great place to go.

Worth taking the time. Viet Dong 40,000 per person entry fee. Taxi from Old Quarter Viet Dong 98,000 and 84,000 back to Old Quarter on Mai Linh. We spent 3 plus hours viewing both buildings of exhibits and the outdoor exhibits. Well worth spending time on. Pleasant environment and very interesting.

Top museum in Hanoi. We took a 20 min taxi ride on a rainy day to visit this wonderful and informative museum, with beautiful recreations of ethnic structures outside. Two temporary exhibits of photography (one from Chile and the other an awesome display of black and white large format photographs from 1950's Vietnam) added to this worthwile spend of 2 hours in Hanoi.

Far away from anything. If you are planning some treking the museum gives you some base line understanding of differences between the ethnic minorities and how they live. The outside displays are interesting because you can enter right into the homes set up on the property. The inside displays are a bit less interesting and aren't worth the trip on their own.The major downfall of the museum is it is a long taxi ride from the old quarter and the taxi fees far outweigh the cost of admission.
Worthwhile visit. A well curated museum, with lots of useful exhibits and facts. Worth visiting if travelling to ethnic minority villages.

A cultural place. Our family went to this museum as a part of the trip in Hanoi. It was amazing. Inside collections gave us a good presentation about Vietnamese people and culture. Also, the real communal house and long bamboo house were particularly impressive.

A great showcase of Vietnamese cultural diversity. I find that the museum is a great preparation before travelling north to the hill-tribe mountain territories. In fact, it can be even a substitute for doing that. Since nowadays the exhibits are also labelled in English the museum has become even more interesting.

More enjoyable than expected!. The museum of Ethnology was interesting and managed to maintain our interest. Perfect activity for a drizzly day. Allow at least 2-3 hours to enjoy walking around the museum- and make sure to leave enough time for the open air exhibition- we didn't and wish we did! The museum is quite far from the Old Quarter- best to get your hotel to arrange a taxi for you.
Visit to get a sense of the cultural diversity of Vietnam all in one place.. the living displays of village experience and architecture are really thought provoking and educational. my kids loved it.
A MUST. Vietnam Museum of Ethnology learn you all about Vietnamese history culture and people from north to south. You can easy spend a day.

A Museum of Ethnicity. There are 54 noted minorities in Vietnam and each have their own culture and language. This museum gives you a historical view of these ethnicities. You will enjoy the experience learning about the origins, lifestyles, architecture and behaviors of these minorities.

A must do!. 40 000VD well spent! Great exhibitions capturing lots of the ethnic groups of the Viet people. Displays are very professional with explainable in English, Viet and French. Don't miss the outside displays of long houses, Meeting houses etc. Really interesting to walk into the huts and see how traditional people used to live. Guides eager to share information if you ask them.

Educational. This museum offers an excellent insight into the different ways of life of the 54 ethnic groups in Vietnam. It offers a structured display of costumes, utensils and housing of the various groups, allowing one to compare and contrast the peoples. Do not forget to venture outside to view life-sized houses and tombs.

Well worth the visit. The external part of the museum is a must see if you want to learn about Vietnamese culture. Well laid out and mostly under tree cover. The museum itself won't appeal to everyone and can be gone through pretty quickly.
Very informative. Very interesting displays about the different ethnic groups in Vitnam. A taxi ride from the lake. It cost about 70 - 80,000 VDN from Hang Hanh St in a metered taxi
Very enthusiastic place!. Really this is very enthusiastic place and also a place where u can learn about the culture of Vietnam. Is is highly recommended.

One of the best museum in Hanoi. Very beautiful, large and interesting museum. When you visit there, you have chance to see and understand more about the life, culture , history of all ethnic people in Vietnam.
Especially, they have many unique sample over there. Nice decoration also. Highlight recommend

interesting open musuem. It's cool that you can actually enter the household of different ethnic groups of Vietnam. The outdoor space are nicely planned that you just follow the path to see each ethnic group. The indoor museum contains too many information, not a bad thing but very easy to get tired in the middle way. I think it might be nicer if they can do a bit blending between "indoor information" and "outdoor experiments".The products of ethnic groups selling in the boutique are nice; if you don't plan to search on the street for the "real ethnic hand-made" good, this is a good choice. There's a cafe located in the museum but we didn't see any outside the museum as it was located on a big street where many governmental buildings (?) addressed.The location is a bit far from the old quarter. there are buses stations in front of the museum, but we took our hotel's advise to take taxi there, which caused about 6 USD.
Very interesting and well worth a visit. Thoroughly enjoyed our visit to this museum and in particular the grounds where many tradtional homes of ethnic Vietnamese are displayed.

Quality museum and exhibits. We enjoyed observing the exhibits in this lovely museum. Showing how the people of Vietnam are a mixture of different cultures (as are most countries), this museum displayed excellent examples of art, daily used items. clothing, etc from different areas. It was very education.
Great trip. I see the museum is very attractive because there are so many rich artifacts in ethnic groups in Vietnam and the museum's works introduce the culture of the peoples of Vietnam.

Vietnam Museum of Ethnology. It was an interesting Museum which showed how the tribes lived, their costumes, jewellery, arts and craft making, beliefs in spiritual practice, housing etc. In the premises you can also get books and there is souvenir shop too. Pay a visit there too.
Richly Innformative. We didn't save enough time to fully explore the outside exhibit of Vietnamese houses--truly fascinating. This is a first rate museum that calls for at least a half-day.

Excellent museum. Great exhibits, outside and indoors. Learned about the 54 ethnic groups in Vietnam, their history and culture, dress, music, etc. Very good museum! Nice cafe on site, which was great to get a cool drink since the museum was not air-conditioned. Took a city bus (#14) to get from the Old Quarter to the museum; involved about an 6-block walk.

Great trip, worth getting out of the centre. We went on a saturday afternoon by taxi towards the museum. Tickets were 40.000d pp. There is a nice collection of clothing, photography, art etc inside the museum. There is information in English and french as well, so you can learn about Vietnams minorities. But don't forget the houses of the ethnic minorities outside the museum in The gardens! There are several old houses built There where you can take a look inside.

A must-see!. Whether you're planning on visiting ethnic minority villages in Vietnam or are just interested in the culture of the country, this museum is very interesting. The main building displays costumes, photos, films and artefacts of the main cultures of the country (including the Viet population, not just the 'minorities') and outside are around 15 houses of the various ethnic groups, which give a fascinating insight into daily life now and in the past. Easily spent a couple of hours here (the restaurant was great too, by the way).
Nice to visit. The traditional houses in the garden are very interesting. In the museum you will learn more about ethnic minorities

Quick Tour of Vietnamese Culture. Do this at the front end of a tour of Vietnam to give yourself a feel for the country, its history and people. Well worth the time. Kids eight and up should find it interesting too. A Definite stop.

Sorry, I was a bit bored.. Ok, I had just come back from trekking around the tribal areas north of Sapa. So saw H'mong and Dao cultures at first hand. If you have time, that is the way to see ethnology. Personally I thought a lot of the exhibits needed refreshing. Don't bother with a guide as you will get too much information.

A must if you visit Hanoi. I rate this as the second place to visit after Ho chi Minh's mausoleum and museum. It is amazing as it takes you through the tribes and cultures of the some 70 different tribes of Vietnam, their migration and history.You can then proceed into the gardens and visit and view the different and vast array of living accommodation and daily lives of the different peoples who have made up the cultural diversity that is Vietnam.A photographic must see in Hanoi. Loved it!
Do not miss if you love crafts and culture. Amazing museum, very informative about different Vietnamese tribes and wonderful displays of traditional houses and costumes of traditional tribes.

A must see. A great little training restaurant in the grounds set us up for our visit. A walk round the museum learning about the different cultures in Vietnam.Outside there are replica of the different types of houses the tribes built. Be ready for a bit of a climb as many are on stilts, all are worth the effortThe a water Puppet show included in the 80 DONG (for 2) entry price
Fantastic.. Very cool. Great information and exhibits. Definitely learned more about parts of Vietnam that I wont be able to visit. Well worth it.

very well laid out interesting museum. This museum is a some distance out from the old quarter Even though we were on a tight budget We opted to take a taxi as we found taxi's cheap and reliable in Hanoi and they save a lot of time I believe public transport is available We spent a few very interesting hours in this museum which is modern ,spacious and well laid The information is clear (available in English )There are a few cafes for coffee food etc Definitely worth a visit It give a fairly comprehensive view of the different tribes in Vietnam

Learn about the Vietnamese tribes/people. This was a lovely place to visit and you learn about the various tribes / races of Vietnamese people which is a very unique to me. It was refreshing to see this place celebrate the diversity in the country and it teaches you history about them all. There was a lot to see here and it was really enjoyable. You would definitely need a guide to explain everything and it is a must visit place in Hanoi. The burial exhibition is eye opening to say the least!!
great exhibit. Very spacious with a great indoor and outdoor exhibit to showcase the different ethnic groups in Vietnam.

A culture experience. This was a fantastic addition to our tour organised by our tour leader. I especially liked the traditional building examples outside. Gave a fabulous in sight into how the various cultures lived in Vietnam. Would recommend that you find time in Hanoi to enjoy

A short trip about 64 Vietnamese ethnic. Fascinating is the only word I could express my impression about this museum. I do not like museums in Hanoi because they are so boring but everything has changed when I visited there. It is not too far from the West lake. It is very large, calm and it composes of many small houses. Each of them is the specific sample house of each ethnic group. You can enjoy, relax and learn a lot about the habits and some interesting cultural characteristics. It takes about 2 hours to visit all. I recommend you to visit in Tet holiday when they deliver a lot of Vietnamese traditional games which are so funny and excellent!!
Worth a visit. This Museum is really well done. I would recommend a visit with the Hanoi Kids! Then it is really educating and interesting.

Very instructive and a cultural treat!. I have been three times now and never get tired of strolling through the permanent exhibition and still enjoy the various ethnic minority houses in the garden. This museum is among my favourites I have visited thus far.
Interesting for kids. Our 9 year old enjoyed exploring the houses outside. They also have balancing poles and had a local handicrafts market outside when we went which was fun.
Diversity Cultural. Very special like a Vietnam miniature. It collect all of unique identity of ethnic minorities. A great space in the center city. Enjoy!
Fantastic Museum. Great overview of the cultural make up of Vietnam. Fantastic outdoor exhibits of traditional built, or in some cases moved, especially for the museum

Worth a visit. We went here on the recommendation of a local uni student who said the of you go to only one museum in Hanoi make sure it's this one. The main building was interesting with great displays of minority artefacts. No air conditioning and dirty toilets which was strange considering the quality of everything else. If we could go back and do it again though we would spend less time in there and more time wandering the grounds where you can enter actual dwellings built by various minorities using traditional methods. That was definitely the highlight! The South East Asia building was fantastic (better than the main building) so make sure you leave some time to look through that as well. Entry was 40k.

Interesting but wish we had more time. Visited this as part of a City Tour. We had an hour which really was not enough to do it justice. The mock houses in the rear are quite fascinating to wander around and gave a good insight into the way some people still live in Vietnam today. Just didn't have time to look at the exhibits inside.

best museum we've been to in hanoi. It has a wide range of items, really interesting, we thoroughly enjoyed it, the replica houses outside were great, its far our from the old quarter but we did manage to walk it in about 2 hours however we got the number 14 bus back to the center which took about 20 minutes. Good price- 40 000 definitely worth a trip
Interesting day out and great houses!. Well displayed, informative exhibits that really tell the story of the Vietnamese people. Nice day out.

Disappointing. It might have been a different experience on another day, but I found the visit disappointing. There was plenty to see and read but the noise inside the museum was horrendous. The acoustics may have played a large part, but the noise generated by numerous parties of nursery age children was extreme. Basically, I just gave up.

the fall of Saigon. I remembered the fall of Saigon in 1975, April 30th but I'd forgotten that day. I was interested in visiting the Cu Chi tunnels and the Remnants war Museum. We were only there for one hour but we could have stayed the whole afternoon. I live in the UK now but had travelled with Tours4 the World whilst living in the US and always had a great holiday, good value for money, and lots of activities, for active people.
Interesting. We had a lovely guide from Asia top travel agency explained us everything about ethnology, about vietnam,

Great Museum!. It is definitly a must to see in Hanoi while here, a lots of things to see, very colourful people, very interesting and it is so useful for someone who gona to travel up to mountain area to see tribes group. strongly recommend it to everyone but you will need to spend few hours here.

Informative. Although some exhibits are showing their age, there is a wealth of information and once can easily spend a day or two exploring the grounds. The small museum shop is a gem, selling beautiful, quality handiwork at a reasonable price. The outdoor huts are a refreshing, interactive way to learn about the homes and living conditions of various Vietnamese ethnic groups.

Amazing Museum with a lot of cultural objects. I think this is the best museum we visited in Vietnam. It got great variety of cultural objects, and very well detailed English explanation signs for all items in the museum. One star off from the dirty washroom and no air conditioning. I strongly recommend people to visit the separate building display Southeast Asia cultural objects. Most of tourists only visit the main building and left. Southeast Asia building got a lot of amazing items, it's a must see. Must visit outside of interesting buildings too!. One admission is 40000VND.

Just: WOW. Wish I had the fortitude of body and mind to spend more than half a day here, at a time, planning to go back, this time Tim a museum-sponsored knowledgeable guide. . The garden display of characteristic houses and buildings is worth its own visit.

A must see for any visit to Vietnam. The museum is very well done, and requires some amount of time to absorb it all. We only allocated about an hour there, and we could have stayed a lot longer. Don't miss the ethnic houses outside.

Fantastic Display of cultural and ethnic diversity of Vietnam. The museum provided a great snap shot of the lifestyle, dress and rituals of major ethic groups of Vietnam. The displays of costumes and textiles were very good. There was also an excellent photo exhibit from the 1950's.

a very detailed museum useful for the academic and the tourist. I particularly enjoyed videos and descriptions of traditional fabric and craft making, as well as the chance to explore traditional dwellings which had been re-built on site.
Good way to learn some history. We had a guide take us here. There was plenty to see for our entire family, and a good way for us to learn about Hanoi and Vietnam in general

Worth a visit. Our 2nd visit. Entrance fee 20,000 dong each (about $1US). We took No 38 bus from outside the hospital. Bus arrived within 3 minutes and was cool and comfortable. The bus dropped us virtually outside the front door. Inside were wonderful precious relics all well labeled but a bit dusty even those in glass cases. We left the main hall after about 30 minutes and proceeded to the garden cafe/restaurant for a coffee and from there to the fascinating exhibits of village huts. I would say that this was almost the best part.. one gets a better idea of village life of different ethnic groups. Walking in the shade under tree lined pathways was a highlight of our visit. We then went onto the new building and marvelled at the many well preserved and well looked after new displays. The building has tall ceilings with lots of glass and concrete. The display of shadow puppets was enjoyable. We were quite weary at this stage so left for our return journey by bus. A very enjoyable 3 hours which can be recommended.

Interesting tour of a "University". Very interesting tour with over 1000 years of history. OK so it's been rebuilt but it's still remarkable.Used by the new University for Graduation Ceremony's, which made it really bright and exciting the day we were there.
Incredible museum. Very beautiful museum, it is definitely worth visiting. The exposition outside where you can see and enter into houses from different regions of Vietnam is awesome

Vietnam. Having asked our tour guide what exactly a Vietnamese person was, having been dominated by china for about a thousand years, then the French, then the American war I was keen to understand. Well this place answered all my questions very well, a pleasant visit with a lot to take in.

Fascinating. Very informative, includes actual houses from local tribes. Wish we'd done this earlier to get a better understanding of the Vietnamese people and different tribes, regions etc. well worth a visit

As a Hanoier i suggest this place. I guided many Japanese to this museum, as I think this is the best place to visit in Hanoi, and the most interesting museum in Vietnam. Usually at weekend you can watch water puppetry for free, although puppetry is always based on Vietnamese traditional folk stories which required a deep knowledge of Vietnamese culture to understand what is being played.

Interesting and well set out museum. One of the better museums we have been too. The set out was good as it told a story as you moved through the building. The exhibits were very interesting and depicted the life style of the locals very well. Good description of items in English and staff were approachable

A bit too much like an academic thesis presentation to me. The Museum presents an extremely comprehensive review of the multiple ethnic groups in Vietnam. It is gratifying to see that the government is taking steps to support and document the numerous minority ethnic groups given the Viet people's 80% dominance. However it was all a bit dry and too extensive a narrative for me - better suited to someone doing academic research.
different culture. One can spend hours there, so much to learn and take in. Great they do share it with visitors. For better understanding other countries it is essential to see these places.

Chance to glance the ethnic spread of Vietnam. It's name may not be sexy but this museum has a huge amount to say about the racial background and traditions of Vietnam. So many different sub tribal cultures make up the population here that it's difficult to keep count. There are displays on cultural ceremonies from funeral traditions to all female thanksgiving ceremonies. I watched the process of making and dying hemp fabric with fascination. Nearly all exhibits have English translations of their information boards which helped me a lot.In the grounds there are fullscale recreations of traditional village buildings. There is a long house and a tall house (a village building for ceremonial whose height gave the village status); a bamboo hydro power plant has been recreated near a water puppet auditorium. A restaurant in the grounds is a training centre for catering students. Service was slow but the project laudible.
Good place to learn about Vietnam. Its nice place with for families to visit. Children will learn more about the ethnology and culture of Vietnam.
Complete overview of Viet Nam cultures. A very interesting visit which we did at the beginning of our tour but sure it is worth at any point.

Nice tribal houses. Overall, it is not a very large place. We completed the visit within less than 2 hours.There is a live puppet show on Sundays, which we missed as we visited the museum on Saturday.

The unique one. All the Ethnic Groups in Vietnam are displayed here. The tour guide showed us about their custom and culture... with many lovely stories. It is a quite big museum displayed outside that make you walk for half day, we had only 2 hours...

An excellent overview of ethnic groups in Vietnam. The museum is very well laid out, displayed and explained. The similarities and differences among the various groups are interesting to see. The outdoor area has a series of homes and buildings that are excellent examples of the variety of architectural styles developed by the groups. A fun place for kids to explore too.

Informative. We visited the museum as part of the city tour.
The focus of the museum is pretty narrow but in-depth, so if you are not particularly interested in the minority ethnic groups in Vietnam you might not appreciate it.

For the History 'Buff'. A most comprehensive coverage of the various ethnic groups that make up Vietnam.
As part of our tour we felt a little rushed in having to get through all the exhibits in a limited time. Nevertheless for a first time visitor to Vietnam I think it is one of those places you should visit.

An interesting museum for short attention spans. This was a really cool museum, and just the right size for us, as we have quite short attention spans. It was really interesting to learn about the different types of Vietnamese people. We did find it strange how there was an area dedicated to Chilean photographs though…I loved the outdoor section where you get to walk through the old houses. You have to remove your shoes when you enter the houses, so flip flops are great for this!

Good, informative, well done. The museum shows the life of some of the many different ethnic groups living in Vietnam. It is really well done, with lots of information, exhibits like music instruments, tools and clothes, pictures and videos of traditional ceremonies, and much more. In the outside area it is able to see and visit traditional houses.This is a really good museum to get an overview about the country's people.

Cultural life. We took a Vietnamese expatriot to this museum and they were fascinated. Inside and out, there are many cultural attractions, well signed and displayed. For the visitor, it is easy to while away some time; for the locals, it is worth several visits.
A nice place to spend 1-2 hours. The best part of the museum is the outside space, where they have some traditional vietnamese houses. The inside was a bit boring.
2 hours happy wandering. Toured the houses outside first and then went into the cooler museum . I found the exploration of the different ethnic groups of Vietnam fascinating

Really interesting . Unfortunately I didn't have enough time to visit this excellent museumIt's amazing to see how ancient people used to liveI loved to rest in the big communal house which was reparing me from the heatIt was great

Well worth a visit!. We thoroughly enjoyed our visit to the museum and learnt much about the many different ethnic groups that make up Vietnam. The displays are thoughtful and well designed and have multiple language descriptors. We especially liked the outdoors section that includes houses and other buildings from the villages and also a water puppet show. It's a bit out in the suburbs but well worth a visit.
Get up and personal with the ancient cultures of Vietnam . Highly recommended. They have real life structures from several of the ancient and original cultures which you can touch for yourself.

Fantastic museum. One of the best museums I have ever visited. Well laid out with plenty of information in English. Learnt a great deal about the many different ethnic groups within Vietnam. In the gardens you have the opportunity to enter different types of housing. Located on the outskirts of Hanoi but well worth the taxi fare. Excellent gift shop.

Excellent presentation of Vietnamese cultures through materials an house construction. The museum contains informative displays of clothing and other artefacts of ethic groups within Vietnam. But don't miss the houses outside in the grounds, each one constructed by craftsmen from the respective ethnic group using traditional materials and techniques. Some beautiful work here as well as ethnographic interest.

Very well-done and educational. We loved this museum, and actually went back a 2nd day because we ran out of time to see everything. The main building houses multiple floors of photos, house models, textiles. The best part, though, are the full-size houses in a large compound out back that you can walk through. It really brings the village experience to life. There's another building with art from all over SE Asia that we still didn't manage to get to. I highly recommend this museum!
Really interesting and cheap. Awesome place to go. Just take a local bus because it's far and it would cost you a lot of you go by taxi.
Excellent. If you want to experience Vietnam culture of 54 ethnics but don't have enough time to go through out of Vietnam. You have to go this museum. Very exciting culture!
Interesting!. about 30' from hoan kiem lake this place was very interesting for you if you want to learn more about vietnamese culture. Houses, custom, working tools... Worth your half day visit.

Nice place to understand Vietnamese ethological. There is a lot of local building and culture materials that you will be impressed in the first time when you be there. The air is fresh in the poison city, there is many tree and local building that was collected frome many region inside Vietnam.
Well worth a visit. Great to go here before going to Sapa, to find out more about the differnet groups that make up Vietnam easy to get to via taxi but it is a 15-235 minute ride depending on traffic

Vietnam Museum of Ethnology is mandatory if you would like to know Vietnam. This museum easy to access in Hanoï should be absolutely visited to see and learn how 54 ethnical groups are living together and in peace...
the best museum in Vietnam. This museum is getting better and better over the years. The collections are nicely setup & the content is always very interesting.

Great place to learn about Vietnam's people. I love the exhibits in this museum. The moment you step into the museum, you will be greeted by a large wall dedicated to introducing the different ethnic groups living in Vietnam. It's a great way to appreciate the diversity of Vietnamese society. I also love their exhibits on the living quarters of the different groups. You will have no problem getting around the museum and understanding the exhibits since the museum offers both Vietnamese and English descriptions.

A beautiful museum. The museum is fabulous. The exhibits - both inside and outside - are well presented and very interesting. The landscaping is also lovely - lots of shady areas to walk around in. It is well worth a visit.

A Great Educational Experience. Even though my wife and adopted two Vietnamese children during the war, we did not understand the diverse ethnicity of the Vietnamese people. This museum is great. The outdoor displays exhibit traditional housing of the various Vietnamese tribes. The inside gives the visitor a lot of visual as well as documented information about the 54 recognized tribes within Vietnam. The displays are very well done and the explanations are is very understandable English as well as Vietnamese. The maps show where these tribes currently reside as well as giving you census data to understand the numbers. I wish that I had more time on this visit.

Very Interesting. This site has an indoor museum and an extensive outside exhibit showing the style of living quarters for all of the minority peoples of Vietnam. It is really well set up and interesting.

Very educational and interesting. It's easy to get to by bus number 14 from near the Hoan Kiem Lake and if you tell the driver or ticket person that you want to go to the museum, they will let you know when to get off. Buses are fairly frequent (about every 15 minutes) and take about 25 minutes to get there. Then there is short walk of about 5 minutes to the museum.I think the main attraction of the museum is open air behind the main museum building where there are real houses built by the different tribes of Vietnam. It's interesting to see the different houses that they live in and also find out a little about their different ways of living. If you are interested in knowing more about the many ethnic groups living in Vietnam, this is a must do!

Interesting. There are 54 recognized tribes in Vietnam and the Vietnam Museum of Ethnology attempts to showcase the life and living conditions of many of the tribes. Definitely worth a visit. Some of the homes are really impressive.

A Must Do in Hanoi. We found our visit to the Museum extremely interesting and educational, we had no idea about the cultural diversity of Vietnam and the Museum's displays certainly taught us a great deal. There were fabulous displays of the different costumes, tools and ways of life, including a typical house. The many displays were very colourful and beautifully preserved, it gave you the feeling of how proud the Vietnamese are of their different ethnic groups. A very enjoyable and educational experience!

the best curated museum in Vietnam. For Vietnamese and Foreigners alike, visits to most of Vietnam's museums leave people scratching their heads....wondering what they've seen. Not here. Walk by a solitary hat on a podium in another museum in town and you'll be wondering what it's importance is? who wore it? why? when? where? There's no signage whatsoever in most of Vietnam's museums. But at the Ethnology Museum, there is signage and explanations in legible, intelligent Vietnamese, English, and French. The displays are maintained are the buildings. It's a peaceful and informative place to learn about the many dozen ethnic minorities of Vietnam.The facility consists of two parts. Inside are the exhibits related to family life, traditions, religions, tools, trades, rituals, etc. Outside you will find reproductions and relocated original structures of the homes, lodgings, and communal buildings of many of Vietnam's ethnic groups. You are free to walk around, in, and through these buildings. This is a lovely insight into the past and into uber-rural life in Vietnam that still exists (for those that won't travel far enough afield to ever see these places that still exist and thrive in many remote places).

Vietnam in a nutshell. Although we traveled through Vietnam for 3 weeks, this is definitly the country cultural history in a nutshell. The inside is rather small, interesting relics and geographic breakdown of Vietnams' divers ethnical cultures. Outside is a magnificent construction of buildings showing the architectural diversity that existed (and partially still exists). Plan to spend approx 2 hours for a deep dive. Recommended!
very interesing visit. We went in a group withh our guide and enjoyed seeing the artifacts from the past. take it slowly because it will be very hot in there

Must go and see the vernacular vietnam. I am an architect came with my friends from others field so I try to see and understand more about Vietnam architectural , local structure in a short time and i meet then.

The outdoor displays are definitely worth a visit!. It's a little out of the way, but the outdoor displays on offer of traditional homes from the various Vietnamese tribes make a trip worth it. These houses were fascinating to wander around, and it was a great experience being able to take a look in each one.The rest of the museum is interesting, but didn't give me the same excitement as the house displays.Overall, it's worth a visit just to see the houses. Inside is worthwhile if you haven't learnt about Vietnamese life from other museums around the city.

Fabulous museum for tribal art and architecture. French-Vietnamese collaboration that has a vast collection of tribal history very well curated. Has many traditional buildings in the grounds that you can walk into. there is also a good restaurant in the complex that is training underprivileged kids in hospitality.
Great day out. All the family loved walking around - very interesting and great to read about the history. Lots of interesting things to see.

Interesting but tiring. Don't try to take it fast, but definitely visit this amazing museum. The outdoor displays are unique and help you understand at least a bit of the amazingly diverse cultures that make up Vietnam. The traditional houses are worth the visit, and the other artifacts and displays are also interesting. We had a guide which we would recommend.
Museum of Ethnology. Great features of interesting collection of artefacts from the hill tribes of Vietnam and offers an interactive experience

Must see place to garner cultural history. Visited the Museum for the second time the first being some 7 years ago with two young boys which were a bit distracting at the time hence this time to really take it all in. You really need a fair amount of time to set aside to give both the interior and exterior exhibits the respect they need. Was definitely worth the second visit.

Well worth seeing and easy to get to by public bus. I spent several hours here and it was great. Outdoor village houses very interesting and the displays inside were brilliant. I would suggest that you go in the morning and walk around the village first before it gets too hot. There is a nice restaurant on the grounds so you can always get a cool drink/food there if you want. I was there just before lunch and it was getting very busy for lunch time.I had read that you could get here by public bus so having time on my hands I decided to try - very easy and the return trip cost 14,000 dong. These are the details if anyone wants to use this way.Going to Museum1 Catch the No 14 bus from the Long Bien (Central near Old Quarter) start/end local station. Ask the conductor for the Ngha Tan bus stop - I wrote it down as they have trouble understanding my poor pronunciation. I also told him that I was going to the Museum of Ethnology. I asked the conductor to tell me when I was at the stop and he did - also pointed me in the general direction of the Museum.2 When you get off the bus (this is on a main road named Hoang Quoc Viet), turn around, take a deep breath and cross the road and walk slightly to the right to a laneway named Pho To Hieun.3 Walk down Pho To Hieun to the end (less than 100m), turn left at the end and walk to the end of this (about 30m) till you come to another main road - D Nguyen Van Huyan.4 At the main road (do not cross yet) turn right and walk down until you come to a walking crossover bridge. Walk up this, across the other side, and when you walk down the steps you are nearly at the Museum entrance.Coming back1 Walk back the same way but at the end do not cross over the main road. There is a bus stop about 10m to your left from the end of Pho To Hieu.2 Catch the No14 bus back - NB it does not go back to Long Bien Central Station, but to the Old Quarter and if you stay on till the end it stops at Hoan Kiem Lake.Information supplied at the museum says you can catch bus numbers 2,12,13,38,39 and 60 as well but I don't know where they stop.

Strictly Avoidable. Visit only when you have lots of time and have great interest in history... Though I am interested in history and fond of museums but found this one to be very ordinary with not great charms... The only part of the museum that you would really like is the model houses from the past...
Highlights the Vietnamese culture. Very well displayed cultural museum about the Vietnamese people.Shows various tribes and the way they live.

A surprisingly interesting museum. I did not know what to think but enjoyed it. Before going, I thought all peoples in Vietnam were from similar ethnicities this museum put me right!. It deals with some very small ethnic groups.
Would any other country have a museum like this, I think not

Wonderfuly laid out musuem, the outdoor homes are just wonderful to see. We went to the Museum on our last day in Vietnam. We had already been to Sapa and met some of the Hmong villagers so we were particularly interested in them. The indoor museum is sectioned off into the different minorities with information, photos and displays relevant to each of them. Very interesting and educational. However, it was outside that the real WOW factor kicks in. There are about 7 or 8 actual houses from a few of the different minorities which you can walk through and around - they are fabulous constructions and just show the ingenuity of these peoples, using the materials that are most available to them in their location. Allow about 3 hours between indoor and outdoor sections. There is a lovely restaurant on-site and it is a training restaurant for disadvantaged kids so it's well worth supporting that (and the food was lovely). This is a MUST SEE location in Hanoi. It is about 5 miles from the centre of town but it doesn't take long by taxi. We paid 110,000 dong to get out by taxi (booked by our hotel) and on the way back we went up to one of the waiting taxi's and he said 120,000 to get back into the city so no haggling required there. The museum is only about 40,000 Dong to get in - unbelievable value for what you get.
Up Close Vietnam. Very informative place to learn about Vietnam people under one roof! The houses outside the buildings is super!

Best Museum in Hanoi. I spend a week in Hanoi and visited virtually every museum in Hanoi. The Museum of Ethnology was the most enjoyable one I visited.The facility was modern and well laid out. The displays were smartly put together and the English translations were very clear and concise.I leaned a lot about the different ethnic groups which help when we continued our trip through Vietnam.The outside displays were very interesting and well maintained. This museum was a notch above all the other I went to.We happened to visit during the mid-autumn festival so it was super crowded but it was still a great time.

A most interesting museum. This one of the most interesting museums I have been in. It is very modern in its approach to the history , people and culture of Viet Nam. The exhibits are colorful, clear, in English. There are cassettes for description as you walk through if you want it. There is an excellent local Crafts giftshop with some very beautiful item of high quality at reasonable prices, actually cheap by American standards....and these are not cheap souvenir store items.

Great place to visit. There are 3 sections. Unfortunately I didn't have much time and managed to visit only 2 and it was really great,.If you are planning to visit will suggest to budget at least 2 hours

Absolutely fascinating. We thoroughly enjoyed our visit to the Vietnam Museum of Ethnology. The examples of different village houses were truly fascinating as was the information provided at each site including the location of the ethnic group represented. Being able to walk through each house outside the main building containing relevant artefacts was also interesting.Inside the modern Museum building were many displays of clothing, jewellery and religious events pertinent to the over 50 Vietnamese ethnic groups. A wonderful and vivid array of Vietnam's people and their cultural beliefs. Well worth a visit.

Great place to get the real feel of Vietnam. This is one attraction I would recommend to anyone visiting Hanoi. Its a great place for kids as they get to climb over everything outside. There's a restaurant and very clean toilets all around the place. Our grand kids loved it.

Lots of history. By going here, you learn a lot of history about the Vietnamese people in the olden days. Be sure to bring water with you when you visit, because when we were there, it was really hot and didn't find a place to buy water.

A not-to-be-missed place when visiting Hanoi. This museum is a great way to show city children different housing styles and cultures from ethnic minorities in Vietnam. The young children we brought the the place were amazed by what they saw. The stilt houses are great!!!

Excellent half day tour. We visited here with our guide Tung from VIVUTRAVEL. The inside section of the museum provided an excellent basic understanding of the Ethnic minorities prior to our trip to Sapa. This museum is not just filled with history but also gives you an insight into the life of many Vietnamese people. The outside section of the museum was just as engaging. Tung took us around and explained it all to us. He was fantastic. His knowledge seemed limitless!! A highlight of our trip, highly recommended for anyone who is fascinated by other cultures.
Genuinly interesting. Great to walk through the life size models of traditional houses. A real feel for traditional living in Vietnam across the ages and many different tribes.

The many cultures of Vietnam. Fascinating insight into the many ethnic minorities of Vietnam. Our tour guide, Anh,taught us a great deal about these different people who make up 14% of the population.

Don't Miss. This museum is a well laid out description of many of the minority groups in Vietnam. With displays inside and housing examples outside it gives the visitor a very good depiction of life of some of these people in 2015. Certainly for the Hmoung people we found what was displayed closely matched our experiences in the villages close to SAPA. The museum cost 40,000 VND per person and was well worth the cost. The taxi ride from hotels close to Turtle Lake cost about 140,000 VND.

Great overview. Since it is unlikely you will visit all of the different areas in Vietnam, this gives an overview of how people live in different areas. Most of the Vietnamese people live off he land and do not waste a thing. They are beautiful and industrious people with most working at two jobs. They fearlessly ride motor bikes, Honda being their favourite, in traffic that would make most of us shudder. Wonderful country to visit!

Highlights the Diversity of the Vietnamese People. The museum is split across 2 parts: indoor and outdoor.The indoor shows various cultural relics of each of the major ethnic groups across Vietnam. Overviews of the history, customs, tools and beliefs are provided across 2 floors.The highlight for us was the outdoor grounds, which has examples of each of the houses from different ethnic groups constructed. Getting to walk (and some cases climb) through helps to bring the experience to life.There was a another building showing examples of south east Asian countries, however the heat got the better of us so we didn't fully explore.

Best museum in Hanoi. Standout museum in Hanoi. If staying in the old quarter it's worth the taxi ride, about 100,000 dong. The museum is well laid out and clearly demonstrates all the minority groups. The outdoor exhibition was fantastic. Great few hours

A place that reflect clearly the life of Vienamese people. There are both indoors and outdoors section. While the in-housed exhibition is particularly informative, the outdoors display and activities make the museum stand out from the rest. There are a number of houses modeling after the traditional architecture of ethnic minorities, especially those who live in Northern and Central highlands.You will be blown away by the elaboration of these architectures, at the same time being thoroughly engaged in traditional games and activities such as water puppet show, calligraphy, stone game (O An Quan). The museum is especially a great choice for those who cannot find time to visit all remote areas where live the majority of Vietnam ethnic minorities.

Not just an indoor museum. A must-visit in Hanoi. A lot of interesting ethnic displays. I went round the museum a little surprised at how small it was and then found a whole outdoor setting full of houses etc. representative of different ethnic groups. Definitely value for money here. You could spend a while reading. Excellent restaurant on-site.

an amazing museum. the whole place is great, but especially the display of houses built by ethnic minorities. The houses are great (you can walk around inside) and the gardens are so pleasant. There are many families around and a nice restaurant also.

You should need the time for visiting the Ethnology Museum !. After did the private city tour then we reached here in the late afternoon. We went straight to the gardens where we were told there were replica buildings worth visiting...and there were. I wished we could have had more time here...and it was pity of us!

Interesting museum mainly covering the housing history. Interesting museum mainly covering the housing history of Vietnam.
It was super humid when I was there and most of the things to see are outside.
So make sure you bring enough fluids and towels or so for the sweat.

Interesting Museum. The museum presents all of Vietnamese tribes and population and is very interesting. You can walk inside and outside and see the exhibits.
The problem was the humidity inside the museun as there is no aircondition, so after some short time, the kids and you are losing the patience.

Very interesting.. I thoroughly enjoyed my visit to the museum and learnt much about the many different ethnic groups that make up Vietnam. The museum was very well set out and the information was in English as well as Vietnamese.

Good for a Morning or Afternoon Visit. This is a really interesting museum that brings together artifacts and exhibits from many of the indigenous ethnic groups throughout the country. The displays are thoughtful and well designed and have multiple language descriptors. It's possible to get a volunteer guide (don't forget the tip!). My kids really like the outdoors section that includes houses and other buildings from the villages and also a water puppet show. It's a bit out in the suburbs but well worth a visit.

Culture . If you don't get the chance to go up north I would recommend this. It gives you the insight to the lives of the ethnic minority groups. Again if you have a good tour guide you gain more information. Private tours are worth the money. After visiting now,I would love to go see the real thing.

Hands on experience of diverse Viet Nam cultures.. Visited this Museum and grounds on a rainy day, but was not distracted by the rain. On the grounds were well marked descriptions and buildings from various cultures through the history of Viet Nam. They were unique inside and out and imparted a feeling for how it might have been to live in each period. Well worth the visit.

Fascinating stuff. Vietnam is a diverse country with many different ethnic groups and the museum gives a snapshot into some of the customs of a few of the tribes. The highlights of the trip for us though were the example houses outside. Built by villagers, they were modelled on actual homes in each village. Several are built on stilts, all have descriptions of where different family members would sleep, eat etc.

Museum Of Ethnology. Covered this in the city tour. A good place to get a knowledge of different ethnic societies in Vietnam however, you cannot cover much in the limited time unless done on your own instead with a tour guide. If you are short for time, get the information from the internet.

Lovely museum. This is a lovely museum, especially if you are interested in the tribes and demographics of Vietnam. It is great if you have or are visiting Sapa. There are some gems within the exhibition and the grounds are worth walking around. It is a few miles from the touristy areas but you get to see more of what Hanoi is like.

A few hours needed at the Ethnology Museum. We were in a whiz bang city tour so by the time we reached this one we knew we had little time to appreciate it. The guide told us we had 40 mins but led us through level one spending 35 mins talking about a few exhibits...leaving us with only 15-20 min max to explore the rest of it...We went straight to the gardens where we were told there were replica buildings worth visiting...and there were, pity we had to rush through it all and missed half of them. They were still revamping the place so many paths were not finished although u could walk around those sections...can b a little slippery if it had rained though. All up...wish I could have had more time here..so much to see, didn't even get to level 2.
Good Choice. Great Museum with particularly impressive outdoor area displaying traditional ethnic housing. Good English descriptions but no air conditioning.

Interesting short visit. We took a taxi from our hotel in the Old quarter to this museum and then paid the entrance fee to the bored looking staff near the gate. The museum had 2 levels of display featuring cultural artifacts from the 50 plus ethnic tribes in Vietnam. The information provided were very interesting and since we didn't have a guide, we relied on the material presented but after a while, it become more and more difficult to distinguish one tribe from another particularly in the heat and humidity of the museum. There were large air conditioners in the lobby and electric fans on the second floor which were unfortunately not sufficient. Displays of boats and the long house and the 'tall house' were outside and also worth a look. There is also a Craftlink shop near the entrance which we visited.

must visit. great presentation of Vietnam culture and diversity. shows the history and make-up of the Vietnamese people and their tribal customs. well described in English as well as other languages. on the day we visited it was a holiday and the grounds were full of children. outside are actual size models of the different tribal houses.
Good site for a day trip. Great layout museum and the architect look very lively compare to real local lifes. Things i enjoyed were short time but you see many subjects.
Interesting history of Vietnam Ethnicity. There are so many of ethnicities in Viet Nam and each one has their own distinguished culture. It is great opportunity to get to know Viet Nam deeper.
For fans of history and culture. The outdoor building exhibits we wonderful. Great for kids to get a tactile and active experience of history

54 reasons to visit. Had a wonderful tour through this museum with a local Uni student guide. It was fantastically set up and the exhibits captured many of the nuances of the 54 minorities. Our six year old enjoyed being able to touch and walk through the outside house display. There was also a very interesting photographic exhibition from the 1960s on display. Thoroughly enjoyed this museum.

Maybe one the true museum in this country. Created with the help of the France, this museum will provide interesting information about the life of all ethnic minorities.I strongly recommend to go there for the pics, texts, clothes and the real houses copy.
Not bad. The museum is overrated and I have seen better, but in the circumstances not too bad. We spent just an hour or so and we could afford the time so it was not such a problem.

Houses outside are great for children. We visited here with our 2 children aged 6 & 9. They were not so interested in the museum which we thought was well done but loved visiting the houses outside the museum. If traveling with young children there is also a play park opposite the museum.

Interesting, and well presented, in a relaxing environment. Really interesting to understand about the indigenous communities in Viet Nam, before going on tour to visit some of them near Lao Cai for example
And the environment is really charming and relaxing
Learnt Something New. Seems like a convenient place tour agencies throw in en route to Halong Bay. I didn't know there are 80 over ethic groups living in Vietnam. There, at least I learnt something.

Interesting museum. Spent a couple of hours pottering around this museum, it was a very interesting place to learn about Vietnamese history. Displays were well presented and there was a good flow to the exhibits, would recommend a visit

Great if you're interested in the people of Vietnam. . I would really recommend this museum. The information is very interesting and there are incredible replica ethnic housed to walk around. A really nice half day visit.

Well worth a visit.. This is deservedly Hanoi's most popular museum. By the end of your visit you will have seen more tribal traditional costumes than you can shake a stick at, but have gained a wonderful insight into the culture of the many minority groups. The highlight for me was walking through, or climbing into, the several reconstructed buildings in the museum grounds which were real examples of dwellings from different parts of Vietnam. There are good videos dotted around the museum showing tribal life and customs. There is also an excellent tribal handicrafts shop where you can by high quality tradional gifts at fixed prices.

Not as good as rated. It's probably famous, and its size is probably bigger than other museums, but this museum is below my expectation. I would expect to see some real things apart from photos in a reputable museum. But over here this is not the case. It's rather a model library than a museum. You can see all the photos and introductions, but you don't see many genuine displays. A good place to understand the Vietnam culture though.

Very Informative and lots to learn about Vietnam. U need latest 2 hours to have a look at the Museum . Real history of Vietnam can be learnt here with facts and figures. Suggest that this is a just visit place for the tourists.

Lovely museum. Definitely recommend this museum. It's a bit out of the way, but it's worth the trek! You can wander through a range of traditional houses from different ethnic groups in Vietnam, and the Craftlink boutique is worth visiting on your way out! Highly recommend this spot!

Great place, enjoyable experience. . From the Hoan Kiem lake, you can take a bus to the vietnam museum of ethnology. This place was a great attraction to visit. It was rather large, so we had to allocate a large portion of our day to exlplore the amazing things this place has to offer.

Wonderful Museum! . Although a bit further out of town than other museums in Hanoi, this was by far my favourite. I recommend wearing slip on shoes or sandals as many of the houses require you to take off your shoes to enter, so it will save time fussing with laces. Excellent experience climbing in and around the different structures. No need for a guide. It can get a bit crowded so budget some time to wait and let tour groups pass through.
Interesting. Very good Museum get the 14bus by the Hoan Kiem Lake drops you very close by, some lovely examples of traditional homes with some very risque wood carvings.

good place to understand the various groups in Vietnam. This is a great place to understand the huge diversity of people's who make up Vietnam. It is well laid out and worth taking a look at the various costumes and lifestyles of the hill people.

Museum of Ethnology is a very informative and interesting museum.. This is a 'must see' museum and particularly so if you intend travelling to the north eastern hill area where many ethnic minority tribes live.

Very informative. Interesting place to educate yourself about the various ethnic groups of Vietnam. There are two parts to this museum. The indoor museum consists of the traditional dresses worn by the minority group and how they earn a living. The outdoor museum consists of the different architectural styles of houses belonging to these various groups. There is also detailed information given on the exhibits. You can finish touring both the indoor and outdoor museum within an hour.

Good to visit before travelling to Sapa. We visited Museum of Ethnology during a day tour of Hanoi. Our children (8 & 10 years) were a bit bored but I found it really interesting and very informative. I suggest doing this before you travel to Sapa (as we did) as it provides so much information about the different people that live there.

The cultural groups of Vietnam. A good way to spend an hour or so looking around this museum at the exhibits about the many different cultures found within the country. It's well presented and easy to follow.
Best Museum in Hanoi. The best museum in Hanoi. This museum tells the story and shares the art and cultural artefacts of the different minority groups in Vietnam. Very well done and very interesting

Well worth a visit. This is defnitely the museum where there's been most thought going into the exhibitions, which are well laid-out and informative in a spacious modern setting. Gives a good basic background on the different tribes and cultures of the country.

Interesting museum. This is an interesting museum. I especially liked the autentic houses of the different ethnical groups of Vietnam, which you can enter. Definetly worth the visit, but not breath taking.

Interesting museum, worth the visit. Very interesting museum showing the diverse ethnicity of Vietnam. It's a small museum so was perfect for taking our children around (only 2 levels). There is also an outside area which exhibits real Vietnamese houses from different ethnic groups. You have the opportunity to walk through these and see how people lived.
