There are staff in each house able to answer any questions you may have.We stopped for refreshments in the Hoa Sua Restaurant which is staffed by students from a local college learning hospitality skills. They were very friendly and happy to help. Prices were very reasonable.

Kids had fun going into the houses. The museum consists of a two story set of displays on the various ethnic groups in Vietnam and then an outside section. I liked the indoor bit but it was very hot and the kids were beginning to glaze over slightly. When we got outside there are a series of houses you can go in of the different types found in Vietnam and the kids really enjoyed being able to go in an wander about. In a couple of them there were videos of them being built which was interesting. The restaurant is a training restaurant and I feel bad reviewing it poorly as clearly the staff are learning but it was one of the few bad meals we had in Hanoi. I would probably use it for a drink and then go elsewhere for food. There was a fair trade type museum shop on the way out and lots of taxis outside to get back to the hotel- negotiate the fare before you get in. They are metered but sometimes the meters seem to have a mind of their own. We needed things to do to keep the kids interested in Hanoi and this was worth a visit.
Worth a visit. Good to understand the diverse ethnic groups that exist in Vietnam. Well presented with displays showing village life styles and traditions.
Interesting. It issue definitely thé best museum of Hanoi. You will learn a lot by going there about South East Asia culture. Enjoy
Must visit in Hanoi. Great place to visit! Wonderful houses on display. I never knew Vietnam had such diversity with over 50 tribes. Wonderful few hours spent with the family

Extensive display of multiple cultures. Vietnam boasts 54 separate ethnic cultures, and this Museum presents detailed information about the. The Open-air Exhibition features life-size houses actually built by members of several ethnic groups. Interior displays show scenes of daily life such as weddings and funerals and clothing and tools.

An average place to visit.. Interesting, but not exciting. If you have some personal or cultural background, this museum may be more interesting. The best part for us was young children (aged 9 or 10) walking up and talking to us, asking us if they could ask us questions, and speaking outstanding English. A real treat.

Ethnic Minorities in Vietnam. I never realized that there were so many ethnic minorities in Vietnam until I visited this museum. Especially the large outside space has brought in actual houses from different areas of Vietnam and has interpretive guides who can explain the houses, which are very interesting to visit.

An usual museum with beautiful objects and interesting insights. This is an amazing museum. Outside there are examples of buildings from different parts of Vietnam and sometimes free water puppet shows. There are two indoor museums: one is interesting but a bit old fashioned with a lot of written information about the different tribes but relatively few actual objects. The other one, in a new building, has a fine collection of costumes and various objects and is organised in much more visually pleasing and enticing way around a set of themes. It is outside the core visiting district of Hanoi but well worth the trip.

A celebration of family. Visited on a Sunday and there were many local people and their families enjoying many activities (art and craft, games). Lovely to see the joy of the people with simple fun activities. The displays of the ethnic groups are well presented and we particularly enjoyed the outside recreation of the homes of different ethnic groups. We visited at the end of our trip so had seen much already in our travels. For people not exploring vietnam to the extent we did the displays are excellent and give you a detailed view of Vietnamese life for many different ethnic groups living here.
very interesting. traces the different people of vietnam, their culture, origins, lifestyle. very informative. plan to spend at least 2 hours. lots of video to watch too.

Comprehensive and inclusive. Worth the taxi trip from the Old Quarter, which will cost up to 200,000 dong, depending on the traffic (middle of the day cheaper than peak hour). A compensate and respectful look at all the ethnic minorities of Vietnam, with lots of artefacts, photos, videos and information, though more dates on the artifices would have been helpful. My favourite exhibit was the bicycle of the Red River valley fish trap salesman, who carried 800 traps on his bike. There is a phto to prove it, as well. The actual bicycle with traps. Outside, they have erected houses of various tribes, which are very interesting to see and walk through. The cafe is used to train disadvantaged students in hospitality, and while they haven't all mastered the trade, the food was good and reasonably priced. It was annoying that the aircon in the museum seemed to be turned off. The fans were not really enough to cool us down on a sweaty day.

A Must Visit. Do not leave Hanoi without a visit to this wonderful museum. The admission fee is VND 40,000 and it is worth every penny. To begin with, the place is huge - with an indoor and outdoor exhibit. The indoor exhibit is a 2 floor building with separate exhibits dedicated to each major language/ethnic group in Vietnam detailing their origin, houses, livelihoods, rituals, festivities, musical instruments, clothing, beliefs and many more. The various types of houses were reconstructed in the outdoor exhibit. We were allowed to enter and explore each house which was the most fun part of our experience at the museum. Spent about 4 hours. If you want a tour guide, the museum provides one (which costs a lot more). Wear footwear which you can easily remove and put back on. To enter the houses in the outdoor exhibit, you would have to keep removing your footwear. Shoes would be very tiresome in this situation. Overall, this place gets a 10/10

Snapshot of Vietnamese villages. We enjoyed the museum totally, walking around looking at al the different styles of housing used in Vietnam. It gave us a wonderful insight into the lives of the various native groups. They had a water puppet show that was delightful. My husband enjoyed it so much he took a Vietnamese friend back to it for another visit, she discovered the puppet show was by people from her village. Well worth going to, plan on spending half a day at least.

Fantastic place - bursting with exhibits and info. It took us 6 hours to go round with 1/2 hour for lunch. Huge place over two buildings and a big outside area of displays absolutely stuffed to the gills with fascinating stuff. We really enjoyed our visit - we don't usually spend 6 hours in a museum. Helped us to understand more about Vietnam as well.

Great experience. We visited the Museum of Ethnology as a family. It was great for the family to understand the history of Hanoi and also to experience how people live in Vietnam outside of the major cities.We were also lucky enough to be there during the moon festival so there were plenty of activities for adults and children. Being able to go inside traditional homes from the north and south was great eye opener for my kids who live in Singapore currently.

Friendly way to know Vietnam history!. Nice place to visit...Friendly environment to walk thru the Vietnam history. Very good and taste restaurant!The information is basic but efficient... perfect to tourist!Its so easy spend many hours there...because you walk thru the Vietnam culture without no pressure...you can create your own pace.

worth a vsit!. lovely museum...no air conditioning inside but there are openngs where air comes in. some very interestng exhibits. was about $6 taxi ride from our hotel each way and nice drive.The meeting houses in the garden are stunning.

Great for a history lesson. We spent an afternoon here and learnt a lot about the local history of the area. It was very hot inside the main building but the exhibits and mixture of videos, artefacts and photos made it a very interesting experience. The outside exhibits are excellent! Climbing up the ladders into the buildings was great! Hopefully the renovations will be complete soon so that it is easier to get around the outside area.

Entertaining and informative half day. This is a great place to visit early in if you can as it tells you about the tribes and their way of living, so if you go onwards to sapa you are much better informed. The outside area is great as you can go inside all the different houses, the ones on stilts with bamboo floors are inspiring!
Nice but a bit far from the center. We spent all day to visit here. Surroundings was very noisy and its so nice. Ticket entering was acceptable.

Great history of North Vietnam. I was an Anthropology major in college so this was of great interest to me. Photos taken in the 1950s of the mountain people was amazing. The entire museum was beautiful. I visited here while on a tour so we were told of the history and culture of Vietnam throughout the history of this wonderful country.

Well Explained - not to be missed. A great Museum - so much information well presented.I don't think there would be a better way to get an insight into the peoples of Viet Nam.The museum offers a lot of information on the various ethnic groups, where they live, where they came from and how the are (and live) different from one another.Lots of models and artifacts with supporting information (in Viet, French and English) in this extensive place.

Very good! . After going around the city for 4-5 daysWe came to this museum; it cost 40,000 entrance feeUnlike the places in Vietnam this is modern building, you have 2 of them; 1. Local Vietnam .2. Asia . 3. The gardenThis is a good place to learn about the people who live in this country. Good to go here in the beginning of the tripTakes about 1.5-2h

so much to see and learn about. this is one of the better museums that I have seen in Vietnam. Interesting displays ,plenty of information available describing the displays. If you are interested in the ethnic background to Vietnam , then this is the place to visit.

Only way to learn about the people of Vietnam. The Ethnicity museum is truly an interesting start to any visit to Vietnam. The history of the 54 distinct ethnic groups that make up the modern day country of Vietnam is presented in a way that you can learn more about the anthropologic aspects of the country in one morning. We went with our HanoiKids.org guides. One of which had briefly worked at the museum and had a great understanding of the story of the people. We spent time understanding the various housing styles and other unique aspects of the people. Vietnam is so named because the vast majority of its citizens are from the Viet tribal group.We went on a Sunday and there were several school groups visiting on field trips from out of town. Several young 8 or 9 year olds approached us in English and asked us many questions. Our guides were astounded at the skill these young children had with both the language and there forwardness towards strangers. It was exciting to speak with some of Vietnams future leaders.
should to go there.. Nice place but very hot in September, I recommended if going travel by yourself instead of tour guide because you will have a lot of time to see and look around over there.

Do not miss the long house. A good place to learn about Vietnam - the people and culture. I notice the similarity of their ethnic group with the indigenous people in the Philippines. This includes the colorful clothes, accessories, and even the weaving designs. Don't miss the long house outside the museum building where you can find two ladders. Try to guess which ladder is for the female and which is for the guests and male :)

Great museum. Excellent place to learn about the different tribes in Vietnam complete with life size houses. Houses were very interesting to walk through especially the long house where the family would add to the back to expand.

Fascinating! We had no idea the number of ethnic groups in Vietnam.. Two floors exploring the tribal/ethnic backgrounds of the people of Vietnam. 54 ethnic groups with the largest being the Viet. Other include the Hmong, Muong, Loa, Khmer, Loo, Chan, etc. All signs are in english, french and vietnamese.
Ethnics in Vietnam. Learn about the different ethnics in Vietnam. Love the architecture of the ethnics houses that was built. Walk, climb, see and explore!
Great background for a photography workshop.. Site for some of our photographic setups. Nice walks and intersting historic material. Easy to get to, clean and well maintained
Outside attractions more interesting. Real-life houses and specimens of the tribal villages. Very hot indoors as no air-con. Spent less than 2 hours here.
Don't miss it. A must see if you re going to Vietnam. We don,t realize how other people live. They have an excellent view on life.

Well worth a visit..... We're typically not museum goers---but we really enjoyed the Museum of Ethnology. What we liked about it was that they have taken the various homes from different regions of Vietnam---from the lowlands to the mountains---and reconstructed them behind the museum so you can really see how people live in different parts of the country.
Costumes, costumes, costumes. The museum focuses on the 54 ethnic groups and their clothes, jewelry and tools. If you like this sort of stuff it's rather amazing.

Great museum provided you are interested. This museum provides a detailed description of the ethnicity of the people till long way back in history. It was very interesting to learn about them. Just like any other museum, you will enjoy it more if you are really interested in it . But a very informative and well maintained museum. There are good descriptions associated with the exhibits, you can take guided tour if you want to.
Hanoi. this museum is well worth a visit and gives a cleare and in depth picture of the diversity of its colourful people.The outdoor displayes are beautifully set via a nice tree shaded walk.Enjoy.
View from the top of a longhouse. Not so exciting. No airconditioning. Loved the outside long houses etc. though. Now that was interesting.
Worth the visit. Great to see the history of the different ethnic groups.Great displays and a lot of school children visit.We were constantly interviewed school children practicing English great fun

Brilliant exhibitions. VME is simply one of the best museum in Vietnam, a must-visit for every traveler when in Hanoi. There are three main areas: one building for exhibitions on Vietnam's 54 ethnic groups, another building for South East Asia's gallery (including some southern provinces of China) and an open-air exhibitions of various traditional houses. Don't miss any!

Unique museum . This was unlike any museum I have every been to, it was really interesting! Particularly liked the outside section which shows the different housing of different ethnic groups. I really enjoyed spotting the different types of homes as I travelled around Vietnam, the models in the museum are very authentic and realistic! If you like learning about culture this is a great place to go
Interesting. One of my most favorite venue in Hanoi. Large space with many trees, big tradittional houses and there are many interactive activities in special occasions.

Not-to-be-missed Museum.. This is an extremely interesting museum that deals with the 58 different ethnic groups that exist in Vietnam. The exhibitions are of good international standard and are captioned in Vietnamese, French and English. There are examples of artefacts, clothing, tools, implements, customs, ways of living. Videos help you to envisage the life of the people. Outside are reconstructions of different types of traditional housing.In the same complex is a Museum about SE Asia generally – less interesting, less than half full, but worth a visit too. In the grounds is a very good restaurant / cafe run by students who are being trained for careers in the hospitality industry.This is the highlight of Hanoi in my opinion.

Good interactive tour... A place to go if you only have a day in Hanoi as it shows all the different ethnics in Vietnam. There is also a kids interactive room where they can play games and do some craft work

An insight into the lives. A small museum dpeicting the lives and living of the area over the years. Some interesting exhibits and easily covered in a couple of hours. The museum shop offers some nice merchandise at reasonable prices

Good to get some background information. The museum and its outside houses ar good to visit to get some background information about the history of the many different ethnic groups in Vietnam. I found it a bit overwhelming and if you really want to dive into it it will cost you a couple of hours to read it all and to get the total picture.We went by Bus (nr 14) from the busstop at the North of the Huan Kiem Lake... costs you 7.000 VND p.p.
history. was interesting but very hot the day we went. take water and sunscreen shows the way vietnam was in the start

All in one place. if you don't have much time in Vietnam, or just want to spend more days in relaxing mode at the beach this is where i recommend you to come. Just 1 day and you can learn and understand most of ethnic culture and Ethnology in Vietnam.

More for Vietnamese people to trace their roots. I think this museum is of more interest to Vietnam people to trace their history. We went as part of a tour and although the different types of houses is interesting, I don't think it was worth the journey time to get there from the Old Quarter. Good for a rainy day though.

Average. Went there with my girlfriend and was not impressed by the selection and organisation of the museum.
Nothing really bad happened it was just not what we expected...

Great Museum of Ethnology. Loved the design and layout of this museum. It showed many different aspects of the variety of people/tribes that live in Vietnam. I would totally recommend checking it out!

Fascinating experience. I've seen other transplanted buildings in museums, but these are really well set off by their surrounding mature trees and gardens. The first gallery in the new se Asia gallery is good, the puppets and hats especially. The original galleries aren't quite as exciting, but the highland photographs special exhibition was good.

Things to do when it rains. well worth a trip on a rainy afternoon gives you an insight to the country and its people. some of the video makes you think twice about how you treat the people trying to sell you stuff on the streets - no easy like here

Large hut, worth a photo that's it.. It's literally a large hut where you can walk in and thats it. Nothing inside the hut, just some picture worthy snaps and that's all. You can spend about 10 mins here and that's enough honestly.

Very good indeed! Except the restaurant !. I was going to skip this visit from the tour, howver it is a very good museum (No AC) showing the diffrent ethics group in Vietnam (around 50 +) and in some case limited to a small group (100). Very interresting. The houses displayed outside the museum are good.The food that is part of some tours in the museum garden is terrible !!!
Must see Vietnam Museum. Every one must see. Take time . If you love history then you will be surprised that how this country has developed

An Educational Experience. While in Hanoi we did a guided day tour which included the Museum of Ethnology. The Museum is split into two parts with the outside demonstrating how people in the different areas of Vietnam live.The inside was more about Culture of the different areas of Vietnam.Note you have to take your shoes off to enter some of the house outside, and there is no air conditioning in the Museum so it hot.

Impressive. Got a taxi from my hotel, it's been on my to-do list for ages. The displays are very good and it's nice to have an equivalent English description for once. I've seen similar displays elsewhere of clothing and artefacts but the whole seems to be so much better here.The cafe is good, helping young adults, the outside houses are very good. You look around and see the past but looming over them all is the future. You can see what we are loosing.

Very good, but do it without a guide. My boyfriend and I found the museum of Ethnology to be very interesting. There are interesting stories to learn about the different ethnic groups, including their history, where they come from, where they live, how they live and what their rituals are. The museum is split in two parts:- inside you can learn about the history of the people, see what they wear, learn about their customs and rituals. - outside there are 10 real houses of some of the ethnic groups. You can go inside and see how the houses are structured and how the different groups live. There is a possibilitybto take a tour guide, who will take you for about 40 minutes inside the museum and explain more. However, we had a guide and were very disappointed by her stories. She did not say anything new compared to what is already written inside the museum, but she actually missed some interesting facts and her English was very hard to understand at times. So I would recommend saving the 100000VDN you would spend for the guide and just go in by yourself.

54 ETHNIC GROUPS all found their history at this museum. It took for about 30 mins drive from Times City. Traffic was ok! When i arrived, i went to buy my 40,000d ticket. It's easy to find because its located next to the main entrance. The moment i went in the building. There's a welcoming tall stick which probably symbolizes festivals. The indoor displays of the museum is really impressive. From the photo exhibits taken in 1950's up the late 2000. The educational or rather the detailed descriptions and each Ethnic groups are truly amazing. They described from culture, beliefs and religion. So much information and i must that i truly enjoyed the visit even when i was alone. After my over an hour tour inside the museum, i went outdoor. It was really exciting and beautiful. You can visit the actual scenery of the minorities, you will see how they built their houses, their fishing boats, etc.. After going around the outdoor museum, i went back and bought myself one book about the Ethnic Groups in Vietnam. Overall, my visit to the museum was really fulfilling and wonderful. I cant describe how happy i am because discovering the diversity of Vietnam is something that i wanted to see. For me, as ASEAN most of the traditions and cultures are like... deja vu.. BEAUTIFUL! Lastly, they also have coffee shop where i enjoyed so much my coffee (after my two and half hours walking...) and small store for shopping. Check the shopping store, they have few collections of good scarf and native bags.

A must for an informed overview of the diversity of Vietnam.. Very detailed explanations. Great artefacts. Explanations in 3 languages, Vietnamese, French and English. The authentic, life-size copies of the various housing styles and the accompanying videos showing their construction were excellent. Would highly recommend it.

Beautifully illustrates the diversity of Vietnam. This provided an accessible and digestible glimpse into the 50+ ethnicities that make up Vietnam. The museum is filled with cultural and historic artifacts, while the compound allows visitors to experience the different styles of construction and varying living arrangements that are practiced across the country. Fascinating!

South Asian cultural experience. If you want to see the traditional culture, this is the place to go. Each housing show what the architectural structure is like. You can walk in to each one. They also have a video for each one how it constructed. In the main building, there are detailed display on different Vietnamese ethnic groups.
Well worth a visit. Not a big museum fan myself, but interesting homes set up to represent the various "clans"is so well done that it held my interest. Don't miss "The Naughty House"!

Educational. The best museum in Hanoi. I wish the inside would be cooler, but they leave the entrance doors open, so most of the cool air escapes and the inside remains a bit humid and warm.The museum is very educational and you learn a lot about the different ethnic tribes in Vietnam. There's also a Southeast Asia part of the museum, so you can learn bits and pieces about the other countries in the area.

Informative and fascinating display on SE Asian history and culture. Tons of displays and information on the rich history and different cultures of SEASIA. There's a collection of traditional houses from various tribes on display outside the back of the museum. Great place to kill time during the day too.

A great place to start. THE place to learn more about traditions and crafts of some of the ethnic groups that make up Vietnam. Ideal to visit before you start travelling out of the city.The best bit was the different houses, that were either built or rebuilt from their original location by people from the respective ethnic groups. Fascinating!

Cultural value. This museum tells the story of the Vietnamese people - their cultural diversity, their origins, their living. A must for anyone interested in learning about the people and culture of Vietnam.

interesting for those who are interested. A good introduction to Vietnamese history. Dont miss the museum shop near the gate, they sell good quality Vietnamese craft which is hard to be found in the street shops.

Must put on the "to do" list. The La Siesta arranged for an English speaking tour guide Sing who was fantastic and very knowledgeable about Vietnamese history, an amazing place, only pity we didn't have more time to spend here.

Very interesting. it was well worth the taxi ride from the centre. We particularly liked the authentic village buildings in the grounds outside. It really gave you a feel of what life in the more remote areas must be like.

Not to be missed when you plan a trip to the North. The museum consists of a building and a garden. In a relatively small space they manage to deal with all the main aspects of life of the different tribes of Vietnam, from birth to funeral. Very instructive and interesting. The garden consists of traditional houses of the different tribes and is situated in a kind of tropica garden. Every house can be entered. If you are planning a visit to the North (Sapa etc.) this is not to be missed. (At the exit of the garden there's a nice airconditioned café/restaurant to cool down.
don't miss in Hanoi. If you are curious about Vietnamese culture, you must visit this place.You will discover a side of historical vietnamese culture

Top museum, outdoor housing exhibition exceptional.. Great facility. You will need about 2 hours to see everything. We found the outdoor exhibits of regional houses the most interesting. These houses were built by the artisans from the region in which they originate. Fascinating insight into use of available resources for construction.
Love learning about different ethnic groups. Went here in June. Interesting with an outdoor exhibit covering many of the different ethnic groups that make up Vietnam

Roth a visit. This museum was worth a visit and explained a lit of the history of the people. Was easy to get to as we just caught a number 14 bus at the terminus at Hoan Kiem lake. We did have a little note from our friendly reception staff at the Golden Suites Hotel to show the driver where we wanted to get off!

We loved all sorts of tribe's customs, ethics and their colorful outfits. All different tribes seem to have a different. It was so interesting that we liked everything. They made a great effort to make this Museum so entertaining.

Highly Recommend!. The museum was an eye opener for people like me who knew very little about the history and cultural diversity of Viet Nam. There's a LOT of info on the different tribes on Viet Nam, their history and traditions. Its well worth the price and time!

Fantastic!. This place is a bit out of the way, but the exhibits are well-prepared and give you an authentic glimpse into the ethnic minorities of Vietnam, including traditional houses, crafts, music, and customs. One of the best museums I have visited here.
Ethnic Museum. Interesting place to tour and learn about the many different ethnicities. It can be really hot in this building. Take a fan and plenty of water

A day well spend. If you visit Museum of Ethnology, try to take as much time as possible. It's divided into two parts- inside collections of different Vietnamese ethnic groups and outside open-air museum with different types of Vietnamese buildings. If you're not an expert on this area, I suggest you to take a guide. It is not expensive and you get so much more from the whole experience.

Interesting museum - Great restaurant!. The museum is nice, it is interesting to discover all the Vietnamese tribes and their culture. The descriptions however are quite redundant and you might walk faster at the end.. and and it is a good idea: take some time to discover the traditional houses in the park and enjoy the restaurant, the food is really good!

Ethnical as well as Vietnam Museum of Ethnology. I have been there many times when i was a student even being a tour guide. I think that it is the most interesting museum and must see in Hanoi. Come here to taste the deep glimpse of Vietnam culture in one museum
Interesting museum. Interesting and well worth a visit, the traditional houses were particularly good. They also do excellent food in the little restaurant outside.
fascinating. Wonderful exposition of the many tribes in Vietnam--clothing, customs and homes. If you cannot visit these areas, a chance to get some sense. If you have visited, lovely to see again.
Great museum. Fascinating collection of buildings with volunteers offering lots of information. Interesting collection of photographs too.

Summer 2015. We visited this as part of the all day city tour and was not disappointed. The exhibit showed the history of Vietnam and the different regions. The regional building and home exhibit in the back of the museum was also worth the walk through as it brought the narrative to life.
Interesting place. A very interesting place to visit. It includes lots of examples of the houses from areas of rural Vietnam

Really mixed feelings on this one. The museum is essentially two museums -- exhibits in the traditional style inside, and an outdoor exhibit of traditional buildings/homes, most or all of which are authentic -- dismantled and brought in from places around Vietnam. The traditional indoor museum is probably worth a few minutes, but exhibits seemed mostly old, tired, ill-thought-out and lacking in real interest. This may have been an artifact of the extreme heat, we were there on a very hot day, and it was notably hotter inside than out. But really, I am pretty sure this would have been a speed-through museum even without the heat. Would have rated it "Poor" if that were all there was to this museum.But the outdoor part of the museum was fascinating to me -- even if almost as hot (and if you can't take the heat, of course, what are you doing in SEA?) Seeing, and in many cases climbing up and into, the dozen or so traditional houses from around the country was fascinating, and I can see it being of interest to children if you happen to be toting any around with you. It would be nice if there was a little more information, and a little more in the way of associated artifacts with the buildings, but still, it was an interesting time to poke and clamber around there.Museum gift shop is worth a stop, small but we found some interesting items that remind us of the folk history of Vietnam.
Well done museum . Nice exhibition in a beautiful setting. If you do the second floor, be sure to take a fan. It was not air conditioned when we went. Outside exhibits were very good.

Helps explain a sensitive part of social structure. The diversity and complexity of the ethnology helps explain the social dynamics of this part of the world and where some of the national and international tensions develop from. There are some interesting and attractive artefacts and exhibits are well laid out to tell a story. You are getting something of a party line on diversity and tolerance for it, but I think that us trend everywhere.The water puppet area was being rebuilt in Aug 15 and this will be a further attraction once complete.Well worth a visit. The ventilation on the upper level is not good, but don't abandon the museum for the air con in shop, move to the outside exhibits where it is shaded and airy

Although highly rated, we were not. This is a nice, but nothing major museum, if you miss it you have not missed anything. not that iot has no exhibits, but the "real" thing is so much better and this is very much a sales talk etc.

Go outside the main building and explore the ethnic buildings.. The kids really enjoyed this museum (as did we) as it was well thought out and the various ethnic buildings were incredibly interesting. Remember to bring a big water bottle with you if you go in summer - it was super hot!

Interesting yet hot and humid. Been to the museum, it's quite a long drive from city center but it worth it. Interesting exhibition. The down side is that it's really hot inside the museum, I've never been to a museum that most of it is not air conditioned inside.

Good facilities, regular exhibitions/shows/festivals. Great facilities, beyond my expectation! The campus was great, lots of outdoor spaces. They have great in-house guides who will show us around the house of each ethnicity and give insightful explanations on each items and the rituals/customs of the people. What makes this museum outstanding from the rest is their regular events which enable visitors to experience culture in a more profound way (traditional festivals 3-4 times a year, plus other shows and exhibitions like water puppet shows, temporary gallery, traditional clothes exhibition, etc....). The outdoor spaces for the last few years have been neglected obviously. There used to be better care for those back in 2010 and earlier (because the general manager of the museum back then was Mr. Huy, also the founder of the museum so he was much dedicated to taking the best care of every corner of it). Now the racks or ponds are way too dry, lots of outdoor items are covered with dirt or got broken. I hope the museum will do something about this soon.
One of the best museum tours I've ever had. Worth having a tour guide, the museum is an excellent way to learn more about Vietnamese history and culture.

One of the best museum in Vietnam . This museum it's really surprising! It shows the way the ethnic people lives in Vietnam. You can see how they do clothes, rituals, weddings, how they treat death, religions.... Then you can also visit real houses. You can go by bus, number 14th from old quarter. It's just 20 minutes and 7k dongs per way and person. It took about 3 hours and a half visit all the museum, so you should plane it well. Don't miss it!
Highly Recommended. The museum is very spacious and the ambient was very peaceful when i visited. Hence, I could see and read the culture of Vietnam and South East Asia in peace.

Worth a visit. This museum is worth a visit when in Hanoi. A taxi is needed to get here and back to the Old Quarter but wasn't expensive. Taxi's are outside so no problem getting one. There are two parts to the museum both inside and outside. The inside has interesting exhibits and write ups in English. The outside has life size replicas of houses and boats which you can explore inside. Allow half a day for this interesting museum.

Very informative and interesting. All of the attractions/ museums we visited in Hanoi, I liked this the best. It was fascinating to see life size replicas of traditional Vietnamese rural huts. I would recommend to visit this place with a local guide who can explain the traditions and the significance of various artifacts on display.

Great museum with fab outside area. Great and detailed overview of the various ethnics in Viet Nam- we really enjoyed the outside area more - the long house and all the other modells, you can go in and experience the atmosphere.

"Greating ethnology museum!". It is a good place for the people all over the world known about the local people in different villages in Vietnam and about how they live and working day by day and the standard of their living.

Very Informative. Interesting exhibit of the 54 ethnic groups in Vietnam belonging to 5 ethnolinguistic families. The exhibit includes displays and objects relating to the uniqueness of each group. Outside you can see some houses of the diverse ethnic groups.

A good museum for all ages. This is probably the one museum you really should visit in Hanoi. We came away having learnt a lot about the history of Vietnam - and our kids (16 and 14) who can find museums dull were really interested. Everything is laid out really well and the houses outside are great fun to look around - really different.

Surprisingly delightful. To get the most out of this museum, I highly recommend hiring a Free Hanoi Tour Guide. We had two young college students--the second was training--and both had great knowledge and personal insight about the different ethnicities of Vietnam. The museum had a great photography exhibit and several actual homes that had been relocated to the museum for display. My favorite display was the old bicycle with hundreds of fish baskets strapped to it for market. Definitely, wear comfortable shoes and clothing as you will be climbing up tall wooden ladders and walking on surprisingly sturdy thin bamboo slatted floors.

Well put together museum. To be honest, I haven't particularly enjoyed many museums in Viet Nam, but this museum was well worth a visit. The information inside the museum was very detailed (almost too much detail at times), but all of the displays were interesting and the items on display were in good condition. What made the museum special though were the traditional tribal houses built in the outside gardens of the museum. There were about 8 of them that were full sized and you could go inside to see how people live in tribal areas of Viet Nam. I would highly recommend this museum to anyone planning a trip to Sa Pa. The information here gave me a much deeper understanding and experience of the villages I visited there.

Worth a visit if you are in Hanoi for a few days. We visited during July and the interiors of the museum were stiflingly hot. Thankfully there is a cafe in the grounds where we sat for a cool drink.There are interesting examples of full scale ethnic housing on display in the grounds and some well presented samples from each of the ethnic/tribal groups of Vietnam. We definitely gained insight into the extent of the diversity of the nation which we probably hadn't quite realised. As worthy as the museum was, I'm not sure I would have it on a must-see list if you only have limited time in Hanoi.

One of best Vietnamese museums. A visit to Ethnology Museum will give you an insight into how ethnic minorities in North Vietnam live and their beliefs- traditions. I would say a must visit when visiting Hanoi. The museum is consists of two separate parts; an indoor and an outdoor exhibition. In the indoor exhibition, there are collections of clothing, agricultural tools, fishing instruments, household utensils and musical instruments. Displays are labeled in Vietnamese, French and English so I could understand easily. The air exhibition area displayed houses of ethnic minorities at different times in Vietnamese history. Very impressive and interesting.

Great overview of Vietnamese culture and tribes. This is a really interesting museum with information and displays on the many tribes in Vietnam - clothing, houses, festivals, special customs or handcrafts. We didn't use a guide but I think you would learn more if you did.

Informative and interesting.. Excellent exhibits with informative signage. Two floors can be very hot in summer without any aircon. Sadly, we didn't know about the outside part of the museum until getting back home and looking at other reviews. A bit out of the way, but well worth a visit to find out more about Viet ethnic groups and their cultures.

Worth two or three hours. This museum is well done especially the outdoor section, has a feel that your really out of the city, and gives an insight into cultural ethnic groups. Helps you appreciate areas like Sapa valley even more. If you get to visit you'll see how life has changed little over the years in Sapa valley, worth a look.

Boring and Too Hot. First you have to pay 100,000 kip ($5US) taxi to get to the place, tickets are only 40,000 ($2US). All excited to learn more about the Vietnamese ethnic mix only to find that the ethnic groups are the same as those found in Laos, Thailand and southern China. Nothing we didnt already know or already see elsewhere in S.E. Asia. Trying to read whilst sweat pours down into the eyes is difficult. I thought National museums are meant to be air conditioned to preserve to the displays - well in Hanoi it isn't and its stinking HOT. We went to the S.E. Asian building which is air conditioned but again - if you have visited Myanmar, Indonesia, Laos, Thailand and southern China then you have already seen what they have on offer here. Not worth the effort...kids found it boring nothing is interactive.

If you plan to visit Mai Chau or Sapa, go here first. This is the most comprehensive and extensive museum in Hanoi dedicated to present the cultural heritages of 54 ethnic groups in Vietnam. It has two parts: the indoors may be a bore with artifacts, clothing, photographs.. while the outdoor exhibits are more fun and eye-opening, showing fullsize models of tribal houses of distinct ethnic groups (the Giarai tomb, Tay stilt house, Ede long house, Bana communal house..). All in all ,I found this museum, which could easily take from 2 hours to a half day to explore, informative and educative and a visit would become especially helpful for those who plan to visit Sapa or Maichau later.
History buff's corner!. It's details the history of the people of Vietnam and how they came about. Quite interesting especially if you are not super aware of their history. Very informative indeed!
NIce visit. Nice place for a day visit. about 5km away from old quarter, 30 minutes by taxi. Excellent place to explore vietnamese culture of past time.

Wonderful Museum To Understand Vietnamese People. I visited this museum before going to Sapa for a few days. Very well done and helped me understand the village people that I would be visiting in the mountains. Vietnam is made up of many different groups of people. These different groups have different beliefs and traditions and how they live their daily lives. Don't miss this very interesting museum.

Interesting place!. Lots of cool stuff to see here, especially the huts outside, some of which you have to climb up ladders to get inside! The museum itself is a bit warm (especially upstairs) so you might find yourself hugging the AC unit in reception periodically!
Interesting and information. Very hot inside.. It is interesting and very informative. My kids also loved it. The only downside is when we visited it was very hot inside.

Lovely Musuem! My Favorite of all time!. My favorite museum of all time in Hanoi !!!!It is worth a visit if you are a visitor to Vietnam - and even for long time residents.The displays are very impressive, with very detailed info if you are into ethnic cultures.It is fun, entertaining, and educating at the same time.

Very interesting. Very educational museum, giving you an overview about life of Vietnamese people in past times and current life of minorities. Indoor part shows scenes of past and present rural life, whereas the outdoor section shows the different historical and present houses/huts types used by the minorities. Furthermore there is a handicraft shop managed by an NGO on the premises, with a good selection of local artifacts.

Had higher expectations. Most people rave about this museum so I went in expecting a lot from it. It is about 20 minutes/$5 cab ride from the center of the city so you need to set aside time for the trip (about a half day). When you enter, it isn't really clear how the museum is laid out. It becomes evident as you circle around that different sections focus on different ethnic groups and are then sub-divided into: cooking, musical instruments, religions, customs, burial rights, hunting, agriculture, jewelry and clothing. Once you become aware of that, it's really interesting to compare each ethnic group's customs. Outside are the model houses. I am not sure what my expectation was, but there was not much besides the houses you could walk into--they were for the most part not decorated. I can see that this place would be interesting for people only staying in Hanoi, but after traveling the country for the past two weeks, I had seen examples of these structures in my travels.
museum. in this museum you can find out the history of the Vietnamese people the way they lived and some of the homes they lived in pretty cool

All in one spot. Went to visit with my friend Penny from London and my cousin Johanna. Really enjoyed the typical traditional ethnic minorities houses, all in one spot. Shame there is not more information in English about the construction, material etc. Still definitely worth a visit.

A big place (inside and out). This is a big place, buy your tickets (cheap) and walk towards the older big building. Its good to start there because it has no real aircon and newer building does have aircon, so if its hot you can cool off before heading outside. Once outside you can see the representations of houses from different cultures. We spent a couple of hours here but did not buy anything as we could not find a suitable souvenir at the tiny, packed but same same souvenir store.
Educative visit. After visiting I feel one should visit this place in the beginning of the country true to understand and explore the country better....
Half day of fun. This is a good 3 solid hours or more if you desire. Lots of great exhibits and tons of info. I would get there about 9am and break for lunch.

Best museum in Hanoi. It provides lots of information about each race group in Vietnam. The travelers will have a better understanding of the Vietnam after visiting this museum. But I found myself bored after 2 hours of visit, since all the stuff on display look similar to me.

Must-see museum. It's worth to spend a whole day here. I recommend everyone to buy ticket of guide tour (very cheap, 50.000 VND for VNese and 100.000 VND for English). The guiders give very interesting information. The Open-air exhibition is brilliant too.

Very interesting.. It was very hot inside the museum but I enjoyed getting to know the different groups and life. The best part was being able to see and enter traditional vietnamese houses at the back of the museum.
Amazing Museum. Modern and interesting museum, which has an extensive collection of ethnological exhibits from various Vietnamese minorities.

Best Museum!. We went to lots of museums when we went around Vietnam, and while we enjoyed all of them - this one was probably the best! In part because we got to learn about Vietnamese history (aside from the war!).
The inside bit is interesting, but the best bit is visiting the houses of tribesmen round the outside.
Important Musuem Dedicated to the Vietnamese People. The museum has a collection of memorabilia and cultural/ historical relics that help visually tell the history of the Vietnamese people.
Great place to visit. Took a local bus from Old Quarter to here for less than $.50. Love the outdoor models of huts. Spent a full day there.

Very Interesting. The museum is well worth a visit. We took a taxi from the city centre to the museum (about 120VND). The inside galleries are well laid out and very informative. The outside displays are excellent showing various types of dwellings, however as a large part of the museum is outside it is probably best to visit on a dry day.
Bloody good museum!. This is a really fantastic museum. The other museums that I have visited in Vietnam are confusing and annoying - this one made sense and made me smile.

Learning ethnic minorities in green park. Our children like this museum a lot! we enjoy in grand green space, and learning naturally about vietnamese ethnic.
Customes, rituals, customs is fully exhibited, very lively!
Some folk games displayed in the garden!
Enjoy!
Disappointing. Most of the exhibits are outside and are sample houses. Avoid it if it is raining as it was very muddy on the pathways between buildings. Was expecting better.

Learn about Vietnam's ethnic minorities. I like visiting museum in general and found this one to be fascinating. I missed the newer SE Asian wing, however. Plan for at least a few hours here to really learn and enjoy.

Must see in Hanoi.. No matter what else you do. Make sure to come to this museum. It can get overwhelming with the breadth of information and knowledge bestowed upon you, but it's worth it. Even if just for the garden with the traditional housing.Most tourists would encounter only the majority ethnicity of Vietnam - Vietnamese. Or at most another minority or two. This is a chance to really see and appreciate the huge variety of culture here.
Enlightening of the VietnameseCulture. Beautifully laid out museum! Our guide was very informative. Enjoyed the exhibits and amazed by the number of native tribes living in Vietnam.

Very impressive. I never expected that I would find such a great museum with amazing ethnological exhibitions here. It's very knowledgable and eye-opening. You will see Southeast Asian people from different ethnic groups, their languages, unique cultures and lifestyles which are very interesting and there are lots of beautiful photos of hilltribe people. Such powerful photography. It's a bit far from Hanoi city centre but it's worth a visit by cab.

A Must Visit.. Must go to this Musueum. Important information about Viet Nam & its various ethnic groups.Ensure you visit the "houses" outside in the garden as they are amazing & will appreciate how they lived & still do.

Super. We loved this museum a lot ...Museum was a brilliant outdoor museum that takes you through the different histories and buildings that they used to use, some are still built this way. Visited the museum with our children 15 and 20 years Old.

Outside. What an informative and interesting museum. The outside consisting of full scale constructions of various styes of housing used by the ethnic minorities is by far the best part and depending on your degree of interest could take up to 3 hours to explore. The inside exhibits consisting of examples of tools, clothing, religious artifacts, musical instruments etc.is also well worththe visit. In fact you could devote a whole day here with a very good cafe run by trainee hospitality students providing a welcome break. Don't miss it if you really want to understand Vietnam.
Can't get enough. Best to go on a sunny day, as there are outdoor "houses" to visit. Very interesting to see the different ethnics in Vietnam and learn their cultural differences.

Interactive and interesting. I didn't read up on this museum but went on the advice of a local. I spent hours there, with easy to read info on the ethnic groups that make up Vietnam. Loved the houses that you can explore.

Museum depicting the history of Vietnamese tribes. Very traditional type of museum, artefacts and reproductions of items grouped by indigenous group, all a bit same-y no aircon or truly special exhibits - not something I would recommend unless you are truly rooted in ethnology

Brilliant historical museum. This was absolutely brilliant, an outdoor museum that takes you through the different histories and buildings that they used to use, some are still built this way. Pay special attention to where the daughter in law has to sleep, quite funny. Best with a guide.

Better outside than inside. Well-rated, this museum is in two parts. Inside there are lots of exhibits but they become a little monotonous. The other bit, outside, is the highlight with lots of reconstructed full size buildings from different ethnic groups in Vietnam. Worth making the effort to climb into the ling house in particular.
So cool to know. Interesting to learn more about Ethnology of Vietnam. The air is so good, cool. Space is large with special things which have their own history.

An interesting and informative glimpse of Vietnam's minority people.. Fascinating place but can be jam packed with tour groups. Go early.The outdoor displays of minority houses are especially interesting. I am interested in the embroidery of minority people and although there are good displays I found the information somewhat lacking.
A great half day. Well laid out and presented - with info in vietnamese, French and English. Gave us a real insight to vietnamese life with brilliant outdoor displays
Great Cultural Experience. Wonderful museum to learn about the Vietnamese people and culture. Very informative - I especially liked the homes on the grounds around the museum.

not something that I take an active interest in but part of a city tour. The museum was OK. Showed different ways of life of the minority groups of Vietnam. The outside area, showing the different types of housing was far more interesting. I gave this average stars because I don't really enjoy this type of museum, but those who do, might find it far more informative

A must see!. We've visited the museum on three occasions and I have found it equally interesting and informative on each visit. It is a great place to start if you are on a tour of Vietnam, as it provides so much information about the people of the country. It gets a bit hot inside the museum as the air conditioning seems to only service the front foyer, but a walk through is well worth the sweat. The outside "gardens" are even more interesting. The new building wasn't complete when we visited, with only the Asian art exhibit available for viewing.

Quality Museum. This museum is in good condition and contains a lot of information. There is a main exhibit space and then there are replicas of tribal homes in a spacious outdoor area that you can enter. Worth a visit of about 2 hours if you are in Hanoi and interested in cultural heritage of Vietnam.
interesting. Nice place to stay with nice houses to explore. Calm place to relax. Good restaurant (students of hotel education)

NICE PLACE FOR LEARNING VIETNAMESE HISTORY. If you haven't enough time for travelling Hòa Bình or Mai Châu (provinces near Hanoi) you should come to this museum. I really love the traditional houses of Ethic minorities. You can get inside some house to take a rest. Despite of the hot weather outside, the atmosphere inside the house is cool. The first time I came here, I spent almost 4hours here to take photos (the photos I share below were taken on that day). I sometimes came back there but I didn't take any photo, just enjoyed the nature and went around to see the exhibited items. The museum organize different activites every month. It's always crowded with children on Mid-autumn festival (or Full Moon festival on Aug 15th Lunar Calendar). They taugh children how to make Vietnamese traditional lanterns, Star Lights, tò he.. There are water puppet shows sometimes.* Opening time:Everydays on 8:30 am to 17:30 pmClosed Mondays and Vietnam New YearHere is the website: http://www.vme.org.vn/index.asp

Must See. Beautiful traditional houses.. Indoor exhibits are educational with English descriptions. The new 3 floors ASEAN exhibit only have one full floor display, only one room open on the second floor. Well constructed and maintained outdoor traditional houses. Reminded me of my grandparents' house. Those bamboo flooring and mats are cool. New, clean, modern restroom. Not as big as the Village Museum (Muzeul Satului) in Bucharest but still an excellent way to learn about Vietnamese ethnology. Easily 2-3 hours visit. Don't miss this attraction. At time of visiting the neighboring coffee house offer exchange to two tickets to one Vietnamese coffee and it's delicious !

Interesting exhibition about Ethnic minorities. We visited the museum with a Vietnamese friend and thanks to her, we know better than just the images of people, architect.
Museum of Ethnology hosted a very good exhibition about people who live on the mountain of Vietnam.

Sharing time with visiting families made this special.. Enjoyed the built to scale real live exhibits. Needed English sign plates to read, understand and truly appreciate what we were looking at. Covered seating for the water puppet show would have been appreciated and an announcement of the starting time. We came across it by chance and pleased we did.

Super and Getting Better- Outside Huge Houses to Experience, Inside Powerful Artifacts from Asia. Pros: 2nd time there in 5 years. Houses outside such a pleasure to walk around. The Videos inside each house detailed the artistic and painstaking time/effort it took to build them. Culturally significant to experience in person. Great photos. Also they had new museum with high quality artifacts from many SE asia countries and south part of China. Cons: Didn't have enough time to check out the other parts of museums. Possible Taxi ripoffs outside--do not trust them unless you know the name of a reputable taxi companies.
Nice spot outside of town. Really interesting perspective into the indigenous peoples of Vietnam. Would suggest going before visiting Sa Pa to learn a bit about the people you'll be meeting.

A walk into Vietnamese history. My favorite museums are ones that include ethnographic displays because you can get a much better sense of time and place. You can also (usually) let your kids run all over the place and 'discover' things on their own. The setting is very quiet which I appreciated after being in the heart of the busy city for most of my stay. Bring an umbrella to help keep the heat at bay. It really does make a difference to help you from getting overheated. The buildings are all accessible but for a few, you have to be willing to climb stairs and/or negotiate a ladder of sorts, therefore some of the buildings are not accessible to everyone. I noticed in a few other posts that people were disappointed that the museum wasn't "interactive" but considering that the setting shows "how it used to be" and Vietnam is basically second and mostly third world, what do you expect? There are not people dressed up in costume weaving or storytelling, or things for tourists to play with. It's straight up, here's the living conditions of what used to be, and for some ethnic minorities, life as it still exists. My family and I found it interesting and most definitely worth the visit. We got a good laugh at the burial house. When you see the statues, you will know it wasn't insensitive for us to laugh out loud! It shows that the Vietnamese had a sense of humor.

Worth two hours. Shows how each of the ethnic groups that comprise Vietnam live/lived. Each has a diorama with props about their customs and village life. Each has its own unique style and lets you appreciate how each culture adapted to their environment. Two hours will suffice to see everything.
Ethnology Museum. A visit to the Ethnology Museum gave us an insight into how the North Vietnamese viewed their role in the integration of the many ethnic minorities in Vietnam.
Informative. This museum teaches you a lot about the cultures of Vietnam and the rest of the area. You can walk into the homes that model what some traditional homes. There is also a cafe here.

The history of Vietnams people. This was a interesting place to visit, it gave you a lot of information on the Vietnam people and where they have come from and their languages. I would say a must visit when visiting Hanoi.

Overrated . It was interesting to see the different ethnic groups of Vietnam, but that is about as far as it goes. There weren't any interactive exhibits. It wasn't the worst museum, but it wasn't the best either.

Good Parts, But Might Be a Bit Boring for Kids. We enjoyed our visit here, it was an extremely hot day (late June). The museum itself I could have spent time in, but our 3 girls were extremely bored very quickly, out the back there are traditional houses that we interesting for all of us.There's a nice open air cafe on site where we had some drinks.The park across the road (there is an overpass for pedestrians) was a good carrot and they enjoyed that.This is a little bit out of the city centre (about $7 taxi fare).

Don't miss this. Loved this museum even though it was exceedingly crowded - school children mostly. Lot of great exhibits and most have translated the descriptions into English. Warning about museums in Vietnam in general - no A/C. Take a fan everywhere you go.

Intro to Vietnam culture. Enjoyable visit and detailed info on the culture of Vietnam. A nice break from the war museums. Had to take a taxi as it was not within walking distance but got to see a different part of the city via taxi. No crowds for us and several floors to explore.

Surprise. One of the best museums in Vietnam. For such a small country did realize there are 53 minority groups and all are represented at this museum. Take your time to explore each floor of the museum as well as the grounds outside. A true gem.

Best Museum in Vietnam. Visiting this museum is a great learning experience for you on the life of different ethic groups in Vietnam. You will learn that Vietnam has more than 50 ethnic groups who have very unique life style and culture. Here you learn about rich culture of Vietnam through seeing excellent exhibitions. You will also learn about history of Vietnam. This museum is great place for your kids. They can play in the garden, climbing on to the long houses of Banah ethnic or visit straw-roof house of Viet ethnic. You can also visit some exhibitions of Southeast Asian culture.

54 ethnic groups in vietnam. We learned that there are 54 ethnic groups and the Viet group made up 86% of the population. These 54 ethnic groups belong to 5 ethnolinguistic families. The museum is divided into two parts; an indoor and an outdoor exhibition. In the indoor exhibition, there are collections of clothings, jewellery, agricultural tools, fishing instruments, weapons, household utensils and musical instruments. Displays are well labelled in Vietnamese, French and English. We got to understand the cultural diversity and the uniqueness of each group and region. In the open air exhibition, we saw houses of diverse ethnic groups in Vietnam . We can enter the houses and see for ourselves the inside of the house. The Bahnar communal home is the most impressive.

It was very educational. But..... I need to preface this review by typing that I love museums. I always go to museums when I travel if possible. I have been to China, Japan, Korea, Europe and the Smithsonian in the USA. Though I felt I learned a lot, this museum was just ok. Honestly, my favorite part was the special exhibit that showcased photographs of Vietnam in the 1950s.Having typed all of that, this is a great museum to begin to understand Vietnamese culture. Was it a must see? NoBut it is a great way to spend a morning or afternoon? Yes

One of our favorite and a must see. Our family lived in Hanoi for almost two years and we went here often. The museum is very modern and done very well. It is "western" in quality and very interactive. It is air conditioned and so it is a respite from the heat if you go during the hot months. For the most part, the communist government does an honest job presenting the ethnic minorities within their nation. Now, if they just treated them more fairly. The Viet are the largest ethnic group and therefore get to the the stories.

Very interesting. I visited in July 2013. THis place is a grat place for an afternoon or morning. But make sure you plan to coincide with the water puppet theatre. It was around 4 pm when I visited. Gave a comprehensive view of the differing ethnicities that make up Vietnam with lots of exhibits and a chance to actually sit in traditional types of residences. I thproighly wnjoyed this museum and it wasn't too crowded. Something different if you actually like to look at the history of the country you're visiting. .

Interesting Exhibits, not much else. This museum had a few interesting exhibits on the ethnic background of Vietnam, but was a bit uninteresting. However, the outside area displayed historical homes from different times in Vietnamese history. This was very interesting. There was also no air conditioning, which made it a bit uncomfortable on a hot day.

A better understanding about "Vietnamese culture". Vietnam has 54 ethnics but you won't easily see all of them everyday. This museum helps you to get a closer look on different ethnics and how they influenced the diversity in Vietnamese culture.Not only good for foreign tourists but also young Vietnamese who's urged to widen one's knowledge. Better visit this before going to remote provinces to take a glance at what you're about to see over there.

Amazing place to visit !. It's an amazing place to visit, I went there with my family and the kids love the puppet show very much.I am interested in the kinds of house, it's very special and difference :)

Nice preparartion for Sapa, we thought, on a hot day. A museum here is not like a museum at home, but it was worth the visit. Walking in the shadows of the trees watching these large variety of minority houses was fun.
Museum of Ethnology. Its a good place to know the various cultures within the culture of Vietnam and also getting preview of various communities within Vietnam.

An excellent introduction to the ethnic diversity of Vietnam. We went here right before going to Sapa, and thought that it really helped us get a better feel for the populations in that area. Very interesting!

Wish we had more time. This museum was a treasure trove of information. We walked in expecting to spend an hour or so, and ended up staying for a lot longer. If you're into this sort of thing, make sure you set aside plenty of time to explore. The various styles of Vietnamese houses outside are the highlight of this place.
Vietnam's culture. If you in Hanoi, you must come there to understand 52 different cultures of Vietnames people! There are alot of things you could find the world.

History plus. Ensure you have a guide with you to explain or you will miss more than 80% of the history. We had several follow our guide along which didn't bother me but I could see they were lost for the true meaning of most of the exhibits.

Very informative. This is a great museum to get your bearings in terms of the many and varied ethnic groups of Vietnam. There are some really good displays, lots of information and its of a size that is not overwhelming. We visited early in our trip to Vietnam and really appreciated what we learned here about the ethnic groups that we then met over the following weeks.

A Fascinating Visit. The museum really illustrated the diversity of the ethnic groups in Vietnam. Glad this was part of our tour this time through Vietnam. The structures were built by the actual ethnic groups (who came from the many regions of Vietnam to construct - very authentic). The boutique out front was well stocked with a good variety and good prices as well.

Best museum in Ha Noi :). The Museum of Ethnology is Ha Noi's best and most interesting visitor attraction... it features a wealth of information about the different cultures and peoples of this fascinating country via well-curated exhibits both inside and outdoors. Although the place can be crowded at times, a bit of patience will enable one to view items without the throngs of visitors (both locals and tourists). Be sure to spend time in the outdoor area behind the main building, as this is where the examples of traditional houses/buildings can be found; within them are videos documenting their construction (most fascinating to view indeed!).At 40k VND per adult ticker (<$2), the Museum of Enthnology is a wonderful attraction that folks of all ages will enjoy :)

Definitely not a 'must see' site on your agenda. Was told by our guide that this was 'the most beautiful museum in Hanoi...the building itself is pretty but the exhibits did not capture our attention and we found that we breezed through the entire display within 45min. It was included on our tour for the day so that was the only reason we went....not our cup of tea
Museum of Ethnology. loved this museum, was good to have local tour guides to show us around the museum, we were able to understand each area better this way.
Worth the visit. Excellent museum, the outside display is very hot in the summer but worth it if you can do it. The inside air con is not very good either.

Facinating. The museum explores the various peoples who make up the Vietnamese nation. It elaborates on and illustrates their cultural and social differences, social and family cohesion and their geographical and demographic distribution. Displays were well constructed and maintained and the museum was well staffed. We did not get the best out of our visit in early July due to it being the hottest time of the year and it was too warm in some display areas.

So much to see. We didn't realise that there are so many ethnic groups and the country is so rich and diverse. Glad that there is such a place to showcase lifestyles and uniqueness of the different ethnic group.

Informative. OUTSIDE: The site of the different types of housing before was very interesting and informative. It was very educational comparing it from our Filipino culture as we have more similarities than differences. INSIDE: The upper floor of the museum tho should be well ventilated or installed with an aircon. It was too hot in there to appreciate the beauty of what is in the museum, we ended up like we came from a sauna after touring the area.

Interesting. A must to visit for all travellers to Hanoi. Good knowledge about Hanoi's culture and heritage and different native tribes. Due to theheatwave during our visit, the Museum was rather humid inside.

pretty average visit. shows the varied culture and ethnicity of Viet tribes but exhibits are boring after a while. outdoor replica tribal homes are wonderful and explorable. Needs better management and funds to engage visitors

Interesting. This is an interesting museum with a lot of interesting artifacts. I was a little "museumed out" when we went there but the full scale reproductions of old style houses was something a bit different and worth the visit. The ASEAN museum on the same site is still being added to so there wasn't much to see when we were there.

One of the best Museums I've seen. I've been to a lot of museums before but this was easily one of the most memorable. The Ethnology museum on the inside is filled with relics, artifacts, and tons of information on the different ethnic groups today that currently live in Vietnam,but that's only the beginning. On the outside are a bunch of houses that are replicas of the type that the ethnic group typically lives in, which you can take your time to see and for some, go in. The museum also has a nice restaurant with traditional food and some shops. The Ethnology Museum is amazing and one of if not the best museum I've been to.

Not my cup of tea. We travelled with 2 adults and 2 kids aged 4 years and 18months.We didn't find the museum interesting and had to get the kids to find each fan in every room just to get them to move through the museum. My husband and I gave spent time with various minority groups in Asia and just didn't find any extra information or value in the museum. I do not recommend this museum for small kids. P.s. There is a park across the road with a playground and dodgem cars that our kids did enjoy.
Understanding their ethnicity . Very informative museumWell set out exhibition Extremely warm inside No aircon so go early morningWalk through "housing" exhibits very pleasant under shade
Interesting histories. Well liad out with English translations. a history of the different peoples that make up Vietnam. Helps to have a guide but not essential.

Interesting for the first time visitor.. An interesting museum to learn about the history of the people of Vietnam. Some good displays of traditional houses from varying parts of the country.Interesting for the first time visitor.

Good to See as a one off.. The museum introduces the 54 different people groups in Vietnam. It's a good way to understand what makes up Vietnam. We visited on a very hot day so we probably won't be back for a while. Its about 120K Dong entry for 2 adults, 2 students and two children. We came here with hanoi kids tour. If your children are young like 7 and 5, their concentration may not hold though. The village huts outside for the minority groups are interesting when it comes to the long house and the high house. I can't remember their names. However if you are strapped for time, try the Hoa Lo prison.

Worth a visit. We found the Museum of Ethnology to be full of fascinating exhibits and gave us a good insight into the History of the Vietnamese people. There were some fabulous photographs of Vietnam dating from the 1950's. There was quite a bit of reading to do. Outside, there were replica houses that had been erected including a communal house. You could go inside each of these and it gave you an idea of what life was and is like for the Vietnamese people. We thoroughly enjoyed our visit to this Museum.
Life and Houses. Easy to see the housing architecture of the villiages without leaving the capital. A reasonable distance from Hoan Kiem lake by taxi but bus 14 travels within 700m of the site.

Worth your time!!. It is a very special, artistic, traditional, cultural, historical place. If you like art and history, you definitely must visit this museum. However it is quite far from main district. Arrange your time, it wont let you down :)
So much history. . Pros. Good job at preserving many different ethnicities. Replicas of houses. Videos. Worth going if you are into history and culture. Cons. Hot!No airflow!

Enjoyable Way to Learn About the People of Vietnam. The Museum of Ethnology is a little bit hard to get to. That said, we were glad we made the trip (about 30 minutes by cab, which costs $5-6--both depending on traffic). The museum includes extensive examples of different ways of life (from clothes, to tools, to art and religion) amongst the many different identities of Vietnam. We particularly enjoyed the exhibit of different styles of houses available on the museum grounds. Note that the museum (like most in Hanoi) was not air conditioned. We were there on a very hot day, which did impact our visit.

Excellent museum. A great display of different peoples, artifacts and photography. A very pleasant atmosphere inside and out. Lots of interest and fabulous traditional houses in the gardens. Definitely go there!

It's a Colourfull World in Ethnological Museum Hanoi.. This Morning we visited the Museum in Hanoi. In about two hours you can see and experience a lot and, learn a lot about the People which live peacefull together in this beautiful Country. Inside, as well as outside we enjoyed our visit.

Great display of cultural diversity. The area offers examples of how 14 different cultures of Vietnam build their houses and live. It's a great immersive experience for a low entrance fee. It takes some time to walk through but is definitely worth the time.

Here you cannot only see, but also go into the houses of ethnic groups. It is clearly one of the most famous museums in Vietnam and it deserves that name. At is a big museum with a lot of outdoor activities for children and many houses that are rebuild in the museum park. And not just rebuild, they are not copies. The Nhà rông, a big community house is built by the ethnic group itself, just as it would be built in their own community including the offer of a bull when it was ready.When you travel in Vietnam, you will be surprised how welcome you are. The doors are always open and when you make a gesture that you want to come in: they will invite you very friendly to do so.What you see in this museum: the open doors, that’s the real Vietnam, especial in small villages: when you enter the houses in the museum, it feels special, it is special but that’s Vietnam. I myself love music. When I hear somewhere music I want to see it. In the old quarter there’s a street with funeral’s. I often visit them because I love the music. They always invite me and to have tea with them. In the museum there’s also a beautiful small construction. My Vietnamese friends wanted to have a picture of them in front of it till I told them it was a construction for a coffin. Immediately thy jumped away, because even in the museum you have to be careful and respectful with everything that is about death.Inside the museum there’s also lot to see… The best is to come back every year, read a bit about Vietnam and every time you’ll find new things in this museum.

Very educational. This is probably one of the better curated museums in the country. It has everything you want to know about the different ethnic groups in Vietnam. I especially enjoyed seeing the different textiles.

Well worth a visit. Very interesting and gives good understanding of the many minority groups and ethnic diversity of Vietnam. We probably would have enjoyed even more if we weren't so affected by the heat.

Lots of History. If you are into learning about the different ethnic groups of Vietnam and Asia, then this museum is perfect for you. Very informative, good exhibits. It does lack air conditioning though (they only have it at the entrance to the museum) so on the day I was there at least it was very hot while walking around the museum. Would recommend.

Great place to see traditional vietnam. Fantastic snapshot of traditional Vietnam. Love to sit and watch the couples who come here to have their wedding photos taken. Always interesting and worth the effort to get there.

54 Collections for the 54 Ethnic Groups. Artifacts from Antiquities to Present. Great Outdoor samples of housing.. Interesting museum of the variety of Vietnamese peoples and cultures. Particularly liked the outdoor exhibits of houses and meeting places that were typical of the people. Also a water puppet show and exhibit. Building and expanding the museum might have more open now. Definitely worth a few hours of exploring, experiencing and learning.

Try to go on a cooler day. A very interesting insight into the numerous groups that make up Vietnam today and a fascinating outside exhibition. Indoors there is no air conditioning so you would not want to dally too long. We had an excellent guide who picked out the important places to look.

must see. Awsome museum indoor and outdoor.
Well worth a visit.
You do need some time to see everything.
I like the houses outside.

Interesting. It was interesting to see the ethnology of the 80+ types of people living in Vietnam. The building is not AC'd very well so you may find yourself leaving early just because of the heat in the summer.
