Ethnology museum. We spent a morning at this museum which gave us an education into the many and varied cultural minorities in Vietnam. If you have some spare time and want to get out of the heat it makes for an informative and interesting visit.
This is an amazing place not to be missed. so much to see, very cleaver design and lots of history, art. go and find out- inside and outside of the museum

"Interesting and Informative". This museum is so interesting and informative in understanding the different groups of people in Vietnam. Later, when shopping the Old Quarter I had a greater appreciation for the different types of handicraft available for purchase.

Very detailed museum. The Museum was recommended to us by a travel guide. We enjoy getting to know the history of the culture and location we are traveling in. It was great to learn about the wide ethnic groups, living environments and lifestyles of the people.

WOW!. A great day! This is the place to go if you want to learn more about the people of Viet Nam. The museum offers excellent displays of textiles, art, and delicate pieces of history. Following a stroll thorough the many exhibits, we made our way to the replica village located behind the museum...WOW! This museum should not me missed.
Fascinating history. Love the houses. genuine relics and artefacts of each ethnic group. Some full size houses built which are amazing. Plenty to see here.
Much more than expected. I spent many hours immersing myself in the museum. It is so well set out and shows the very broad range of ethnicities in Vietnam.

Good place to learn about the history of the various peoples in Vietnam before exploring the country.. Very detailed museum where you can learn about the various tribes who lived in the area. This was a last minute decision to switch as we were quite tired from the morning's tour and better than the planned tour arranged by our tour guide.
Spent a few hours. Very interesting to learn more about the people of Vietnam, so varied and such a deep cultural heritage. I would highly recommend a visit. Try go earlier so that it isn't too hot.

Vietnam Museum of Ethnology - Don't miss. It's worth for taking time to visit this museum. Tourists can explore the life styles of Vietnamese people and Vietnam's culture in the past. All indoor and outdoor exhibits shows you the artifacts and stories of many ethnic groups of Vietnam.

A must visit. This museum is away from the bustle of the city center but gives you a true picture of the cultures and ethnicities found in Vietnam. It's a quiet oasis of information and artifacts. There's even a recreated open air museum that shows you homes from various regions.
Excellent. Best curated museum I have visited could have stayed all day, good coffee shop also. Make sure to visit the outdoor activities while there they are amazing.

A fascinating insight into Vietnamese life. This museum is a short taxi ride from the centre of the city, but well worth the trip. The main museum provides an interesting insight into the different ethnic groups in Vietnam, but the highlight of the visit for us was the open-air exhibition of the houses of diverse ethnic groups that have been moved to the museum and rebuilt on the grounds.

Very interesting look at native tribal people. This was a very cool museum that has the tribal people of many of the native tribes of Vietnam building the structures they live in right there. It takes up a massive area but the tour was absolutely fascinating and the indoor photograph section from the 1950;s was also really cool.

Incredibly interesting museum.. This museum focuses on the many ethnic groups that still live primitively in the villages and jungle in Vietnam. They actually have built houses that you can walk in and see how the different tribes would live. the inside of the museum is full of artifacts and lots of interesting information. Unfortunately, it was so hot that day and the air-conditioning only keeps a couple rooms cool so we left quickly. If they could solve that problem they would have a lot more visitors

OK. Museum has potential but it feels like no one is interested in making it the best it can be. There seemed to be no flow and I have a feeling we missed out on some things due to bad layout. The outdoor exhibits also could be more interesting if the persons sitting in them actually got their heads out of Facebook and offered some information about the houses. We basically had only half an idea of what we were looking at. It was still mildly interesting

Not bad but not spectacular. It provides well-documented facts and stories about the many ethnic groups in Vietnam. If you are interested in human studies this is a must-see. For an ordinary tourist like me this museum is a bit dry and factual.

Good background & nice outdoor exhibitd. As mentioned, the outdoor exhibits are great to interact with, and it's worth a visit when in hanoi. The museum itself wasn't the most incredible experience I've ever had, but it's a good background and has English, French, and Vietnamese translations for everything and plenty of antiques and recreations to give lots of visual information. And yes, there are some funny sculptures representing the circle of life around a tomb structure outside (or so our guide told us). It was my favorite part -- life is really just about procreation I guess. :)
Outdoor exhibits are worth the visit. Nice for visitors with children as the exhibits are interactive. Outdoor models of dwellings and tombs are nice.

A must for family trip. My family and I spent a Wednesday morning there. Trip on a 7-seater from Old Quarter costs about 11USD. Hoping to catch water puppet show there, unfortunately those are only shown on weekends. My four kids, age 3-10 had a blast though, especially at the outdoors. Definitely learnt a lot.

Educational museum to visit. Thought this to be one of the better museums to visit as very educational on the different people making up the country. Life style huts and homes for visitors to see, along with the colorful attire worn by dif ethnic groups.

Good overview of Vietnam and its people. The museum is a little out of walking distance from the Old Quarter but can be reached by taxi. It is well structured with an overview of Vietnam and the various tribes and people that still occupy its lands. All displays have a French and English translation so no need for a guide within the museum. The exterior of the museum also provided insight into the living arrangements with various housing structures. Most are on stilts so expect to climb narrow steps. It would have been far more enjoyable seeing the houses in cooler temperatures though. If you visit in summer, prepare to sweat. Take water and a face towel.

Real house samples of ethnic groups in Vietnam. Worth your visit. They have many sample houses of many ethnic peoples in Vietnam (~60 groups). Size as big as real houses. Material and workmenship were really transported from the land areas. They gathered teams of original workmen of the ethnic group to really reflect cultural features of their people: structure, materials, decorations, religious altar, death burial habits. Really worth a visit..

A must see in Hanoi. Brilliant A relaxing glimpse into Vietnams past. Whilst in the area Literature Temple and Quoc Tu Giam . Architecture was eye catching, Hoan Kiem Lake was peaceful and very relaxing.

Excellent Museum. The outdoor exhibits are absolutely fascinating. You can really get a feel for the different types of construction and ways of life from different places and people of Vietnam. The internal exhibits are very well laid out with just enough information to not be overloaded. If you are planning a trip to Sapa or another area with a concentration of minority groups this museum provides good insight before you go.I spent a few hours here but missed out on lots of the exhibits, so plan your time wisely and prioritise what you want to see.

Worth a vist. This museum was really worth a visit. Lots of detail (in English as well). And the outside exhibits of the different types of villages is really great. Make sure you have plenty of time to enjoy.

Very interesting, worth visiting. The indoor part of the museum is very interesting, with artifacts and stories of the various tribes and peoples that have inhabited Vietnam. It is also the most dimly lit museum I have ever visited , with such bad lighting it can be difficult to see some of the exhibits properly. Outside, there are lots of re-created tribal houses of different shapes and styles . The staff on duty in the various dwellings seems to consist solely of giggling schoolchildren surrounded by schoolbooks but glued to their mobile phones. Worth a few hours

Fascinating visit. Brilliant visit - found the information about the various ethnic tribes of Vietnam utterly fascinating. The models of the locals, dress and homes helped put it all in context. Loved the videos they had showing traditional ways of life. The best bit was the outdoor area where you could view various full scale homesteads and walk around in them. We were lucky enough to see a small photography exhibition whilst we were there - added to the charm of our visit. Definitely a must do.
Interesting.!. I guess this is a nice place to have an overview about the culture and the people in Vietnam. This place will give you the basics you need to know about Vietnam.
Nice. The museum was nice. Not one to spend a lot of time in but one that is interesting with both indoor and outdoor exhibits to show the way of life for the ethnic minor ours of Vietnam.

Very Good, Worth It!. We had a car with driver and a tour guide to see many sights of Hanoi. This museum as cram packed with interesting history, easily allow about 4 hours to work your way through the entire museum. And there is a nice little cafe on site that does great food and coffee.

Surprisingly interesting. Certainly among the best museums in Hanoi, with focus on the history of the people rather than on propaganda. Interesting glimpse into old lilfe styles and old houses. A must to visit.

Really neat museum. I went to the Vietnam Museum of Ethnology with a guide from Hanoi Kids, and it was really a nice time. You get a lot of insight into the various ethnic groups and history of Vietnam, and there are a great deal of artifacts worth exploring. If you have children, they'll probably like the outdoor area of the museum, as it's very interactive.

Not just a 'Women's Museum'. This was a surprisingly lovely museum -- don't be fooled by it also being called a Women's Museum. While it does focus on women throughout Vietnamese history, my male partner found the exhibits interesting nonetheless.
Interesting. Was one of my destination during my trip in hanoi. You can see in there almost all vietnamese living culture. Houses, working tool, clothes... very interesting visit.

Highly recommended!. We were all impressed with the exhibits of the museum, both inside and outside, they are real & nice. We learnt much about the different tribes of Vietnam through this single visit.

Interesting potted history. This is worth a visit as it gives a very colourful potted history of Vietnam and the multi cultural ethnicities that make up this beautiful country. I thoroughly enjoyed the time here and make sure you allow time to climb up and down the exhibits in the external museum also This is a good collection well put together. Worth your time so go there.
Worth a visit. Interesting to see the way they lived and see some of the primitive farming instruments etc.they used in those days. A lot to see, so give yourself plenty of time.
Historic interest & context. Very interesting and provides you with a good appreciation of Vietnams complex social and cultural diversity.

Spectacular visit!. Nicole and I are so impressed on the making of the 56 minorities living structure.It was a very interesting visit and is a must come when you are in hanoi.Good if you engage a tour guide to come along and you will be enjoying a good history of people who are living in hanoi.We are sure you will luv it.Adam NicSingapore

Interesting and fun to explore. I enjoyed the exhibits inside the museum-especially memorable is the bicycle with the 800 plus baskets on it. It really captured the way Vietnamese move about on 2 wheels. The outdoor exhibits and houses were esp. interesting. Great to see how people live in the different areas of Vietnam. I image kids would really enjoy it too. Lots to climb on and explore.

Nice, informative, and modern museum. This museum included a couple of buildings, a couple of restaurants, a clean restroom, and a great museum shop. Okay...so there is no AC in the museum, but it was cooler inside than it was outside. The exhibits were interesting, and you learned about the history and cultures in Vietnam. One of the restaurants had AC, and decent food. The museum shop had some nice items for sale. I purchased a well made water puppet here and it was the nicest one I had seen in the city. This is a must do when you are in Hanoi.
Go if in the area. great insight into the various communities and how they lived - worth a couple of hours of your time when in the area
Wonderful!. One of the best museum in Hanoi with an unique collection of vietnamese cultures. Really worth visiting :)

Highly educational. The museum was crowded and HOT without a/c and most of the fans not operational. Nevertheless, the exhibits inside and especially the dwellings outside were fascinating. The family enjoyed going inside the huts and learning about the different ways that different tribes and peoples in Vietnam live. Would have stayed longer if not for the heat...At least the snack shop had cold drinks and ice cream to help us all cool off!

Interesting but the heat..... Reading all the positive feedback around this, we decided to pay a visit. Whilst the history is interesting and displayed in a very clear and vivid manner, we had to rush through. The key reason: the building did not have good air circulation, was very stuffy inside and no aircon (only two at front entrance). It was very hard to breathe and we just had to get out within 40mins or so.Overall: good museum if you can bear the heat...
Very interesting; very hot.. It was very interesting and well-curated content, and there was lots of it. The downside was that it was very hot and could have been better air-conditioned.

Interesting and worth a visit. Enjoyed this museum and the insight it provided into the people of the area. A little repetitive at times, but worth the visit. The various buildings in the grounds gave a very clear view of the homes etc that the various people lived in and was well designed.

Excellent learning opportunities. The museum is carefully put up to show all ethnic groups that form Vietnam's population.
The guides are helpful and knowledgeable.
So much to learn.
If you are interested in learning, plan at least 3 hours.
You'll love it!
Amazing. A must while in Hanoi.dont miss the tribal festival in October. You get to see the water puppet shaw too.
AMAZING. SO COOL! This site is worth making an effort to get to. You can get into the houses, walk around, and really see how people lived.

Very Interesting. The building itself was beautiful architecturally.The museum had some beautiful pieces on display. In the grounds you could see a long boat, the styles of houses that people used to live in etc.It was interesting but perhaps not for kids. the museum is in the outskirts of Hanoi and its tricky trying to get a taxi back without getting ripped off. Try to get the receipt from the taxi there to show for your taxi back, and your hotel card maybe.

One of the best museums I've been to - ever - and I've visited a few!. This is really worth the trip a bit further out from Hoan Kiem lake etc. and plan to spend at least 1½ hours here. If you have any interest at all in the Vietnamese minorities, you'll enjoy this museum. It's very well laid out, lots of exhibits of minority daily dress and way of life as well as the memorable fish basket seller's bicycle - you know what I mean when you go! Make sure you go around the back of the museum to see the traditional houses for different minorities: all built using traditional methods and men brought in from the specific villages.
Great. Lots of information about the people. Like the special styles in this beautiful museums. I have recommended it to many of my friends so that they can come when visiting Hanoi

Not so bad place. We entered this place with some hesitation asking a question if it is wasting of our time.No, it was not like that. Very interesting exhibitions inside, many nice presentations to understand more about Vietnam culture.Also outside several sample of houses and tools telling us real stories from their life.
Must visit to understand Vietnam!. A responsible tourist should visit this very nice museum to have a unique experience and understanding of the culture of Vietnam.
Unique museum. is worth the visit once you get to see the real native houses , they are really huge nothing you could ever see in the middle of a city. Very fun and cultural experience
Well worth a visit. Very interesting museum. Lots of information about the minority ethnic people and their costumes. Could easily spend half a day there.

Very interesting. We started our tour here. And we really enjoyed it since it showed us how the ethnic groups in Vietnam lives. It is quite big. With indoor and outdoor museum. I also find it amazing how they made life size models of the various houses that were displayed as miniature models inside.

Very striking content. The interior was very modern and spacious. There was a fair bit of emphasis on the authenticity of the model huts built in the back of the museum because the huts were all built by people who lived in the regions where these huts existed

Deep exposure to life among the ethnic minorities. Excellent museum filled with beautiful photographs and examples of clothing, housing, music and agriculture in the highland villages. They also do hands-on cultural activities.

Well worth the visit. We were in Vietnam for a textile tour and this museum provided a wonderful and informative overview of the different Indigenous groups. The displays were well set up. Of particular interest were the various architectural styles in the grounds outside.
Not To Be Missed. A wonderful educational experience and superbly set up. Is included in some day tours. Several hours are needed to absorb the history and cover every area. Very worthwhile.

Ethnology at its very best. This museum is a complex of 2 buildings and an outside display. The main building houses a fascinating display of exhibits relating to the ethnology of Vietnam including its many minority ethnic groups. Displays, with English explanations, are situated at various levels on several floors. Outside in landscaped gardens various types of rural houses have been relocated and restored. A superb new South East Asian annex houses fascinating ethnology exhibits from all the ASEAN countries (the EU equivalent). A nice restaurant provides a range of food and drinks. I visited in the afternoon after the Museum of Women in the morning. I traveled by motorcycle taxi driven by a University student. many offer their services during long vacations to supplement their income.
Very Educational. Lots of history here. A sample of the various villages is on site. The grounds are well maintained. Best to have a guide when visiting the outside exhibits.
Divergent cultures - beautifully displayed. Excellent setup with so many diverse indigenous groups. Wonderful displays both inside and out. Well worth the visit.

Must do in Hanoi. Really enjoyed the museum. It provided a wonderful introduction to Vietnam and the 54 ethnic groups. We took a cab from the old quarter (about 20-30 min) but so worth it. They have a small bookstore and a wonderful shop Craftlink with a fantastic selection of handicraft items. Enjoy!

Fascinating Museum. This was a really well done museum of the many ethnic minorities in Vietnam. The museum has everything translated into English. It is all well organized, too. There is a large outdoor section that has many examples of the homes that people live it, and it is a great experience to get to go inside and see how these places are made.One note is that the inside of the museum was not air conditioned, so it was very hot and stifling when we went. There is an on-site cafe that was an excellent place to get a cool drink and relax from the heat.

Must see in Ha Noi. This is a must see attraction if you are visiting Ha Noi. It gives a great insight to the cultures, history & ethnology of Vietnam, which is far more diverse than you may imagine. The inside takes around 1.5 hours and is very good, but the gardens and dispay houses are fantastic and need the same time.Next time I would take an English speaking guide. And try and avoid groups with microphones, get in front or behind them.

Insight into Vietnamese Culture. An interesting museum that shows all the different cultures in Vietnam. The displays, and videos outline all the different traditions in the regions. The displays on fabrics, houses and tools are really interesting. Time well spent looking into the people they make up such a diversified country.

Interesting but to warm. Interesting to here about Vietnamese heretage but without our guide I don't think I would have enjoyed it so much. What brings it down from 4 to 3 is that there is no aircon, was so extremly warm to walk around in a hot day.

Interesting way to learn about Vietnam. Most interesting way to learn about the multitude of ethnic groups that make up the population of Vietnam.The outdoor exhibits are wonderful although one might be considered as "adult only" (rather graphic).

Interesting place to learn about Vietnam. We took a taxi here from the Old Quarter - it was quite cheap to taxi. The museum was quite interesting as you can learn about the different ethnic groups in Indochina. It's the type of museum where you walk around at your pace and read everything. It's interesting but it also depends on the type of person you are. Given that I have a Vietnamese background, I thought it was quite interesting.
Good to check it out!. It's worth paying a visit to find out more about Vietnamese's culture, how it was evolves from the past till today.

interesting. it was great to learn of all the different cultures and influences on the current environment. different rooms represented different ethnicities. well documented and displayedHowever, the best part was outside - the actual houses and water puppet theater performances.can be done in an hr. good for families.

Boring. The portraits were really cool though. There are a few buildings here, but I only visited a few as the weather was too warm and there wasn't any linkway between the buildings. There were many school children too, hence rendering it too noisy for me to 'appreciate' the exhibits. I would suggest coming on a weekday (except Friday) to avoid the school children. Bought some post cards here, relatively cheap, 5000 dong.

Great museum!. I've been to this museum many times, usually once a month when I'm in Hanoi, and I'm in Hanoi every year for varying periods of time. They change the major exhibit inside, so there is often something quite new to see along with the standard examples of clothes and products from Vietnam's many ethnic groups. Outside in the spacious grounds is a wonderful collection of houses of ethnic groups from around the country. On weekends there are water puppet performances in an outside venue that is probably much like the traditional village sites used in the past. This is an oasis of quiet in an otherwise very noisy city. There is also a small gift shop with some quality souvenirs on sales.

Well curated, wide variety, interesting exhibits. The museum showcases the arts and crafts of many of the indigenous peoples of Vietnam. They also have authentic dwellings constructed in the courtyard. Very informative.

Village reconstructed. This amazing museum has full sized village dwellings, as well as a large selection of handicrafts. Worth the schlep from the tourist ghetto. Make sure the taxi driver understands where you want to go. We ended up at a shopping center the first time.
Great visit. Truly one of Vietnam's best museums. The exhibits in & outdoors are very well maintained. You get a real feel for village life & how things used to be & in some cases still are.

Good place to see in Hanoi. This museum is quite big considering the inside and outside parts of it so make sure you have enough time to wander around, at least couple of hours. In it, you will see all ethnology of Vietnamese groups all over the country.
We enjoyed the outside part where it has all the different houses better though

number1 hot spot in hanoi. after old quarter u must visit this museum. here u can understand old history of vietnam and traditional houses. like another country when I visit here every things r mordern. but in this museum, u can feel to be back.

Will even be better with new wing opening over time. Really enjoyed my visit here, so much to see and learn about all the different ethnic groups, but even rather odd displays like 'the basket seller's bike' can leave you with a broad smile. I was rather impressed about the new South East Asia wing / building, which at time of my visit only had an exhibition at ground level. Nice, modern and spacious, this will hopefully be filled in the months / years to come. Very much recommended

Viet Nam's nicest Museum. A great museum a little bit out of the centre of town but within an easy taxi ride. Well laid out in a modern building and gives an overview into Viet Nam's ethnic minorities. The grounds have a number of traditional houses from various parts of Viet Nam and visitors can enter and see how the people lived.An excellent place to visit.Only one little niggle, I wish they would add more descriptions in English.

Well curated. This museum offers an opportunity to see some of the artifacts, clothing and customs of some of Vietnam's 50+ ethnic groups. It's a small museum with just enough exhibits to provide interest and knowledge without your eyes glazing over. 1 hour is sufficient to spend here.
Very interesting!. Very interesting and informative. All you need to know about the culture and peoples of Vietnam. There was a restaurant on site too, and the food was very good.

Take your time and bring a towel. Lovely place that has all the various minority of Vietnam. It would be helpful if you've read up briefly some history of the country and its region to be able to strike some form of correlation to better understand the cultural influence. There are just too many names to remember so what helped was a map of the place and use it to navigate as you walk through the whole place. You'll also get to appreciate their way of living and the value of food and kitchen. Traditional ceremonies is also something they value alot.Next to this main museum of the ethnic minority (the majority of Vietnamese are known as Kinh), is the museum on South East Asia. It's not as big but very modern by itself and helped to bring together the diversity of the region in a rather structural manner. A good basic introduction. Walking through it, apart of appreciating the diversity, you can try to draw the connection on what are the similarities of the region. There is a second floor that focuses on Indonesia alone. A much smaller exhibit that uses glass painting to share more about the culture.The first has limited air conditioned facilities (available only on the first floor) so I'd suggest to bring a towel, especially if you perspire easily. Whereas the second is fully air conditioned.
Small, but nice. I liked the old traditional houses, but the watershow is not spectacular at all and the whole museum is not as big as you would expect. Do not eat there, rats all over the place.
Good with a guide. Only a 4* as I believe that as with some other Vietnam museums (particularly those in Ha Noi) a guide is needed to get the full benefit.

The structures outside are most impressive. We spent about an hour at the Museum. We viewed the artefacts and models inside the Museum building - quite intriguing to see the history of this country with a diverse ethnic make-up. We found the various ethnic structures outside of great interest.
No need to spend more than an hour at the Museum, but it is certainly well worthwhile.

Great place for history and a picnic. My family loves going here as it's outside, the kids can run around, and explore all of the great houses. We love to picnic there as well, and really enjoy the ambiance.

Great opportunity to learn about diverse ethnic groups and culture in Vietnam. Museum is open 8.30 - 5,30 but closed Mondays and during Tet holiday (Vietnamese New Year).(In 2015, Tet was on February 19th; in 2016, Tet is on February 9th and in 2017, Tet is on January 29th - the actual holiday will last 1 day before and about 3-5 days after the actual holiday. Some visitors to the country avoid this time as transport etc can be restricted but if you have friends there it can be a great time to visit).Our guide did not point out (probably as there was not enough time schedule) that there is an outside park area where houses of diverse ethnic groups have been built that can be entered as well as those constructed inside the building. There are English and French translations with the interpretation materials alongside the exhibits. This is a well organised museum with a good book shop and there are regular demonstrations of traditional arts including educational activities for children such as weaving, printing etc. LIft to upper floor.There is much to see. I would highlight the colourful dresses and garments of the women from various ethnic groups sch as the Lolo or Hoa.
We can learn a lot. Displays of many ethnic group articles were very impressive. We can also enjoy traditional houses of Vietnam.

Cultural and historical regional foundation. Important to digest if wish to be informed about the history and culture of the South East Asia region. Very well produced displays inside the museum. And eminently interesting outdoor displays and structures including the variegated styles of houses and shelters used by many indigenous local peoples.
Well worth the taxi ride. Excellent display of clothing, arts, implements and especially dwellings of various ethnic groups around Vietnam.

Recommended. This wasn't in my to-do list in Hanoi, but our free tour guides diverted us here on a drizzling thursday morning. I was glad they did. This Museum has a spacious property and a separate building for special exhibits. It doesn't feel cramped and there wasn't much people traffic, other than a cute class of kindergartens on a field trip. The indoor exhibits are interesting, but the life-sized native huts and buildings outside are more interesting. They cancelled their 10am water puppet show in their outdoor theater due to the weather (unsure about their exact daily schedules). You will have to remove your shoes prior to entering the huts, so I recommend wearing sandals for convenience.We had walking tour guides (see Hanoi Free tour guides) with us and that made the visit more meaningful as they were able to add important info and answer our queries about the exhibits and the traditional culture. This trip took us about 3hrs.

Great museum. I thoroughly enjoyed this museum. They had a huge collection of interesting artifacts and clothing from the different ethnic minority people in Vietnam. It was great to learn about where all of the different people came from and during what time period. They had interesting displays and the signs were written well in English and very informative. I thought the traditional houses outside were fascinating. There were quite a few, and I could tell a lot of work went into constructing them. The grounds were really nice with pathways, gardens, and trees. There is a newer building across from the museum with art and traditional clothing from other South East Asian countries also. This was a smaller exhibit but also interesting and well put together. The entrance fee was only 40k vnd, so it was well worth it. Some people complained about it being far away, and though it is about six kilometers from the old quarters, our taxi was only 74k vnd each way. That means the whole trip for two people was about $7. We were at the museum for over four hours because there is so much to see and read, so it was worth the price for us.

Must see. 54 ethnic tribes with film and artifacts...recently attractions and buildings have been added to the outside greatly enhancing the educational experience. Admission price very reasonable; but, gift shop is pricey.

Impressed. A lot of stories about ethnic communities throughout Vietnam with different architechture, various languages. My foreign friends & me were impressed with out side museum, it's big, real & nice. All of us liked it.
Interesting. Very interesting museum. Learn about the different tribes of Vietnam. Outside exhibition have erected tribal houses which you can go in to.
interesting. I enjoyed the exhibits but it's very hot t 4his time of the year. Should be bit more iron for people to enjoy it.
15 Days in Vietnam, Laos & Cambodia. This is a very well organized & well presented museum with beautiful indoor displays & outdoor recreations of indigenous homes & community buildings.

Worth a visit. I wasn't sure what to expect, but my wife and I really enjoyed our visit to the Museum of Ethnology. As an American, we don't learn much about Asian history in school, and it was interesting to read about the various cultures that live in Vietnam.

A definite must. Plan at least two hours if you just want a glimpse of Vietnam culture, more if you want a in depth view. Don't forget the outside displays.
A truly memorable visit. Recommend

One of the best museums giving tribute to 50+ minority ethnic groups. You can easily spend half a day at this interesting museum. We had a tour guide which made this visit very worthwhile. We learned about the customs and cultures of different ethnic groups, from him. But all the displays are in English and French translation which helps even if you dont have a guide. The outdoor area has a variety of homes as full-scale replicas. Indoor exhibits feature tribal art, artefacts and everyday objects gathered from across the nation. There is also a museum shop where you can purchase some souveniors for a reasonable price.
brilliant. it was great and very informative extremelly interesting so much knowledge is in the building and surrounding areas

Great experience to learn about the many different ethnic groups in Vietnam. It was a great experience to learn about the many different ethnic groups in Vietnam and Asia. You also learn about how they lived and live now. Takes 2-3 hours, a bit outside, but cheap to go by taxi. A must see!

Great experience to learn about the many different ethnic groups in Vietnam. It was a great experience to learn about the many different ethnic groups in Vietnam and Asia. You also learn about how they lived and live now. Takes 2-3 hours, a bit outside, but cheap to go by taxi. A must see!
Best museum in Hanoi. Very good museum showing different ethnic groups in Vietnam. Go here before going to Sapa and seeing ethnic groups live.

Little but well put together.. This museum was provably my favorite. Very well done. It has enough information to give you a good idea of the different ethnic groups without overwhelming you. I wished they had a shop where you could buy some of the things they exhibit.

Great overview of Vietnamese History & Culture. We attended here in 2013 and had a personal guide with us. It was excellent, and a great capsule of all the different tribes, culture and lifestyles. Highly recommend having a guide as I felt I got much more out of the tour than if we were left to our own devices. Just to have someone go through and explain all the exhibitions for us and to explain and describe every little detail was extra special. Highly recommend this place, if you want to learn more about the Vietnamese culture and history.
Very interesting!. A cool place, goes through the history and culture of all the different tribes. Outside is good too with replicas of their buildings and houses.
Nice exhibition but just a bit hot in the main building. I love the exhibition there but the main building has no AC and it is a bit stuffy and hot. Others are good enough.

Gateway to Vietnam. We had a little help, when we went to the Ethnology Museum, it's called "Hanoi Kids", students took us around for the day. They lets us know a little more about Vietnam and it's cultures. Visit Hanoi Kids

Best Collection in Hanoi. Of all Museums in Hanoi, I love this one. The collection is diverse of 54 ethnic groups in Vietnam. Displays were very well organized and informative. The location is a bit far from the old quarter but it worth the visit. Spend no less than 2 hours there. Water puppet showw also available in the garden.
Small but interesting. This was a interesting place showing Vietnamese people's history and culture. Worth a visit if in Hanoi.

Nice gateway especially when traveling with kids. Worth seeing especially for the outdoor exhibition. We've been there with the kids (4 & 8) and they really enjoyed the opportunity to walk/run around without crowds of people and traffic ;) Beautifully preserved traditional houses of different tribes give true insight into the Vietnamese culture and everyday life (i.e. space separated from the rest of the house for the newly married and guests only :)Very nice cafe with decent choice of food and cakes.It takes a while to get there from the Old Quarter but taxi is not expensive and easy to catch one on the way back as taxis are waiting outside the museum.

should try. introduced by hotel staff for my first visit hanoi and it worth. Very interesting museum with all ethnic culture of Viet nam. If you take taxi from hanoi old quarter it could be 4$ fare. One suggestion for you in hanoi

Really enjoyed it!. We were taken here by our Hanoi Kids tour guide. It was the first place we visited and I'm so glad, as it was really interesting and gave a very good back ground to some of Vietnams cultural background.I learned that there are several different dialects - each state has its own and 5 different cultural backgrounds which make up the Vietnamese citizens.There is an indoor and an outdoor section to this museum. They even do water puppet performances - would need to check the times and days they happen.Go in the morning, as its not as hot then, especially for the outdoor part. Also, you can get 2 for 1 coffee at the cafe, if you have 2 entrance receipts.If this review is helpful, please tick below:

Learn about Vietnam and free water puppet show. We went here with our Hanoi Kids guide. The Vietnam Museum of Ethnology was opened in 1997 and has exhibits representing the 54 ethnic groups of Vietnam. The exhibits are interesting and I wish we had longer to read about the different exhibits. After visiting the HCM museum yesterday this is like comparing chalk with cheese. The museum has great exhibits of the different ethnic minorities and about their lives. I especially enjoyed the outside exhibits of different village houses in the grounds. The most spectacular one is the Bahnar house which is 19 metres tall. The 42 metre long Ede longhouse which you can walk through is also interesting and hearing about how many ethnic groups were matriachal societies. The Giarai tomb and its explicit carvings were also an eye opener!We also stumbled upon a water puppet show, granted it appears to be only one puppeteer but it was still entertaining. If you do go I would recommend a guide to get more out of your visit.
Well worth a visit. Very insightful into the history of all the different tribes that make up Vietnam. The areas outside are very impressive.

Interesting Museum. This may not be everyones cup of tea but if your a first time visitor to Vietnam it is nice to know the background of the country. The museum displays the 54 tribes which make up Vietnam and the museum highlights the difference between the tribes. Outside is a exhibit of the different buildings they dwell in and with a good guide can give a real insight as a visitor.

Everybody's darling . It's almost impossible to recommend this place too much. The huge outdoor are with traditional Vietnamese tribal buildings already elevates this museum beyond the scope of most others I have ever seen. And the two inside areas give an intricate introduction into the Vietnamese/ Southern Asian ethnicities. They are excellently curated and the only bad thing I can say is that some of the exhibits are placed camera-unfriendly behind glass and strange lighting. Otherwise I can safely state that this is a museum for everybody: backpackers, culture freaks, families, or simply fun and entertainment tourists that want to absorb some light culture, everybody will find something here.

Good place for kids. We brought our 4 year old son. Good choice. Theater for kids, climbing the houses. Ge locals bring there children here to. Exibition quite informative compared to other museums in Vietnam. If you want to have lunch eat inside the museum. There is nothing outside. Quite good playground on oposite side of street.

Amazing culture. Vietnam is the other nation-state consisting of a 54 thing tribe. Each of and characteristics of the area, a house, it is very interesting museums to introduce such as customs. Well as knitted mesh basket with bamboo, different forms by the tribe, this is at so I know where if born. Folk costumes of each tribe Yes on display, it was interesting. Model of the house is in the best part, house model of high-ceiling-ed stilts was impressive.

Nicely done. Great introduction to the various cultures and people that make up Vietnam. It was helpful for us to visit to learn more about the Mong people as we were planning a trip to Sa Pa in the next few days after visiting this museum.There are wonderful outside displays of the houses that some of the tribal people live in. It was fun to be able to go through them. This was a pleasant surprise.Also this facility also has the water puppet show which was very good. We have seen 3 water puppet shows while in Vietnam and this was the best one. Note you need to secure a seat early if you want to be under shade when watching this show which last about 45 minutes. It is nice having a band and singers which the others we watched did not have.My wife purchased many items made in the shop to bring back as gifts. You pay a little more here for that but you have a variety of the many products the tribal people make.

Really interesting. I really enjoyed the visit to the museum. Our guide explaine about the regions and ethnic groups that populate them. Outside there were reproduction buildings from some of the types of people that used to live in Vietnam. Lots to,read and learn.
Same, Same, but different. OK, if you are interested and have a lot of spare time. Couldn't tell one clan from the next after an hour
Can't miss. A really well done modern museum and a must if you are intending to go into the hills. Basically it was excellent.

Worth the Trip. Although we had not planned to go, we had an unexpected free morning and went to this museum.
Like many of the museums in Vietnam, there are many photographs with written descriptions. This museum also has a large outdoor area with examples of the homes used by many of the 54 ethnic minorities. Very interesting.

Encyclopedic Reveiw of Vietnamese Ethnology. One of the first things I did in Hanoi was this museum, a delightful space with a dozen or so architectural styles common to Vietnam's heritage, and indoor exhibits of costume, handicrafts, and tools of the various ethnic groups native to Vietnam. While we were visiting, there was a group of very good looking young military officers also visiting - who told us they were from South Korea...Charming young men who practiced their English by speaking with us.The outdoor exhibits are hands-on and allow the visitor to step inside the various types of houses to look around. The building that contains the costumes and artifacts is a delightful space built around a central courtyard with multiple vantage points on a couple of levels. Please note that photos can only be taken when you buy a camera pass that costs a couple of dollars. This practice is much more common in the mid-east, and I saw little of it in Vietnam. I didn't bother.Just outside the main building is a small, but very good book shop and across near the entrance is a very fine gift shop with clothing, bags, very nice spoons and serving pieces made of horn, and framed textiles. I bought some very nice things here.

This is an excellent museum to visit. An excellent museum with indoor history, photos and exhibits. Then a fascinating garden area with differing styles of traditional Vietnamese homes. Don't miss if you are interested in the peoples of Vietnam

Culture without being complicated. Absolutely fantastic presentation of the history of Vietnam and its peoples. If you are in Hanoi and have half a day spare then this is a not to be missed museum. We were lucky in that we had our very enthusiastic tour guide with us who explained a great deal about the exihibits.Peter & Sheila
Excellent overview. Find out about all the different hilltribes and ethnic groups in Vietnam. Fascinating displays and excellent presentation

To see. Nice museum. We really enjoyed having visited the museum before going to Sapa because we were able to recognize few different ethnicities. We took the French guide (we are French speaker) but we should have chosen the English guide as we couldn't understand what she took us.

Interesting but can get burnt out. I thought it was interesting to learn more about the ethnic groups and the identifying aspects of them. Especially after we came back from Sapa, it was more educational to understand their attires and values. However, because it's very similar you can get a little burnt out. The outdoor sections on the housing styles were fascinating.

Pleasant place to visit. It's a nice museum. Well displayed artefacts from different period and real buildings outside for you to climb in. A bit away from the old quarter but a motor bike will get you there in no time.

Wonderful Museum. learn about the different ethnic groups in Vietnam as well as the culture. the display were well laid out, used multimedia and very informative. Don't miss it to learn more about this interesting country

Worth a visit!. Probably the best of the Hanoi Museums we visited!
The outdoor exhibits of traditional houses is very good and we particularly enjoyed the exhibition of costumes and fabrics of South East Asia.

A Hanoi "Must See". A beautifully set out Museum of South East asian Culture and Art.
The Grounds have examples of traditional Vietnamese Housing. The "Water Puppet Show" on the lake is a must.

Great day out. A great place, to spend a half day. Plenty to see and do both inside and outside. Good for the family especially if you have kids. Best to some water, as inside can get a little warm during summer.

A must visit when you come to HaNoi!. I have been here many times. This is very interesting and helpful museum for both vietnamese nd foreginers who want to know abt 54 different types of Vietnamese Ethnology. This is museum that u must visit when you come to HaNoi. Inside the museum u can see many things such as: stuff, clothes, local people, market,..and there is a big garden outside with many kind of houses frm the north to the south of vietnam. U will see how vietnamese people live, how daily life change since thousand years till now. Vietnamese culture is so diversity!

Interesting, informative and eye-opening. You need to spend some time at this museum that includes interior exhibit and exhibits of tribal `houses' at the garden ground. Interesting artifacts, photos and replicas in the interior but it's the different style of mocked tribal houses in the garden grounds that are really interesting. Some you have to climb all the way up and you get to see how people actually live like. Eye-opening stuff from the eyes of civilization.

Impressive Museum. The Vietnam Museum of Ethnology showed me many of the ethnic groups in Vietnam. I saw quite a few examples of Vietnamese life. There was also an outdoor exhibit at the museum, consisting of an Ede dwelling from the Central Highland region. I didn't know what to expect, but was quite impressed by what I saw. This tour was included in a 10 Day/9 night Tour of Vietnam so i don't know how much it actually costs. But whatever it is, is certainly worth it.

Could have spent hours there. This small but fascinating museum was one of the most interesting I have ever attended The displays, photos, and videos showing the traditional clothing traditions and history of the 54 Vietnamese tribes was well thought out and artfully presented. We spent about an hour there, but we all wished we had allocated much more time. Don't miss it!

Great exhibits inside and outside!. Great exhibits about the way of life in Vietnam. Interesting reconstructed buildings. Children are welcome here and when we visited on a Sunday there were water puppet performances taking place. They are every two hours, 12md, 2.0pm and 4.0 pm when we visited in April.Vietnamese families had their picnics and set up in the Long House, which was surprisingly cool, despite temps on the 30sC.We didn't have enough time so will go back next week.

nice place to discover Vietnam. nice place to understand Vietnamese peoplehundreds of items to be discovered in an amazing waythe view outsite is also very actractivea must see place when you have more than a day in Hanoi

Much more than a museum. Really enjoyed the outside displays of structures from some of the many tribes still inhabiting parts of Vietnam. We could easily see similarities between these and those we have seen elsewhere in the world. Fascinating insight into belief systems and traditions - and you can go inside many of them. (Had to come down the ladder on my butt from one of the houses on the tallest stilts, however.) Inside, there is a lot of information about the history and diversity of the peoples in Vietnam and throughout Southeast Asia. Lots of colorful displays and costumes. Well spent couple of hours.

Thumbs Up. It's fascinating to note that Vietnam houses 52 distinct racial dialect groups and its' culture and heritage is lovingly curated in this huge museum. It's really a good crash course on the people of Vietnam. It is especially good to have a replica of most of these people's homes in the museum backyard. We get a feel of how they live and what matters to them. If you are a history and cultural lover, I'd recommend this museum as your first visit before you drop into Ho Chi Minh's museum, as only then would you be able to appreciate how much effort it takes for him to reunite the people.

Very Interesting. Very interesting museum, we were on a tight schedule so crammed all the city sights into one day - so got a little sick of visiting another museum. But apart from being a little weary, this was very interesting and worth a visit.

Interactive. I enjoyed learning about all the 52 groups that call Vietnam area home. The inside has nice displays and artifacts and the outside area houses to climb in and around. Nicely done. I highly recommend this for families.
Get a guide. Wonderful few hours, lots of interesting information. Ensure you get a guide who will walk and talk you through the exhibit.

Positively surprised!. I had low expectations, they were quickly met and exceeded. I found it all very interesting and well put together. We learned a lot and found out how diverse the Vietnamese population is put together. There is a lot written but also many info videos connected to the displays. It's a drawback that there is a 1. floor with only a staircase. So wheelchairs can't access. Outside there is a big area with traditional houses and they are very impressive. We had lunch there and it was very very good, and at quite reasonable prices. There is a water puppet show free of charge. I did not think much of it. But many others probably will, so if curious, go check it out. There are schedules provided outside. All in all, it is well worth the price of admission and it is well kept and upheld. I would go back when in Hanoi.
Great tourist attraction. If you don't get a chance to go to the rural area, then this is a must. Shows all the different ethnic groups living in the mountains. Very interesting and well set out.

The colourful cultural background of Vietnam !. A display of the dress and implements of the many tribes which combined to make up the Vietnamese population. Very interesting . Some of the hill tribes in their colourful costumes can still be seen, notably in Sapa and other highland areas. Then outside of the museum there are a number of dwellings and stilt houses of various designs which have been reconstructed at this site. They enable you to literally step into the lifestyle of the hill people. I'm not much for museums but I enjoyed a long visit to this one. Hanoi doesnt have too many real attractions and this one is well worth your time. The entry fee was 30,000VND per person.

Open exhibition stood out. The museum was a part of a tour which, after plenty of stops at souvenir "stores", was a relief to see. Learning about the 50-odd ethnic groups of Vietnam was interesting, yet the open exhibition of the houses stood out to be the best part of it all as you got to go inside each house and walk around at your own pace. It was easier to remember as it was more interactive than merely reading some signs that displayed information. Recommended if you are running out of places to see or things to do, but it wouldn't be the first choice.
Excellent overview of Viet Namese ethnic history. Beautiful collection. The guide supplied by the Museum was invaluable in explaining the exhibits. Very complete, beautifully displayed
Interesting. This is a very interesting museum great layout with villages in full layout in garden a rear of museum. recommended

worth the visit. I havn't been recently but have been twice before. you need a whole day as there is so much to see and recently met some travellers who had a day there and thourally enjoyed it and agreed you need the whole day.

Interesting exhibits. Well arranged on two floors, showing the diversity of the Vietnamese ethnic groups, with a large open air display of houses and building examples to walk around outside, a little restaurant and obligatory souvenir shop.

A must to really understand the culture of Vietnamese people. Walking around outside through various houses. Favourite was house on stilts built so that mountainous villagers can have an elephant pass under and see house from mountainous regions. Puppet show was great and although in Vietnamese there is a universal understanding of the good vs evil theme.

Surprise, surprise. This unorthodox museum is quite small but really interesting. That is, of course, if you have any interest in Vietnam's ethnic mix and native/cultural history. Even a passing interest in the subject will result in you being informed and surprised. The outside exhibits of dwellings, etc., are truly fascinating.

Informative . A good presentation throughout - very informative and everything had english subtitles.
We thought we moved pretty quickly throughout but still managed to spend 2 hours there

Worth missing. We did hit this on our only group tour on a very hot day. Everything you could find online and not well kept up. Vietnam was great, but there were probably other places we could have gone instead of here.

Necessary visit to understand its 54 minorities. A cultural key to understand Viet Nam, especially if you do not have much time there. The costumes are superb, the gardens with the ancient houses are just as interesting especially if you lack time to go in the country side to see them for real.

A must see in Hanoi. I'm not a regular museum visitor, but this is well worth the visit. Plan on spending at least 3 hours. The outdoor display with the various homes to tour is fantastic. A great way to learn about the different ethnic groups that make up Vietnam. very well done.

A great break from the noise of Hanoi. A well laid out, interesting museum. It's not over stuffed with objects so you can really see everything. The star attraction has to be behind the museum though- the reconstructed houses from all over Vietnam are seriously impressive and well worth the visit alone.
Remember to buy a permit to take photos if as you enter!

First trip to Viet Nam. Museum of Ethnology is an excellent way of knowing basic information of the Country, people, history, lifestyle of Viet Nam. In my opinion it' s a "must see", more important than other spots.

One not to miss!. A fantastic way to spend a few hours. A wonderful combination of exhibits and history with amazing reconstructed buildings outside of the main exhibition areas. A must see during a visit to Hanoi.

Excellent.. Very good presentation with English subtitles of the various ethnic groups that make up the population of Vietnam. A bit off the beaten path for us as we stayed in the Old Quarter. Definitely a cab ride distance. The exterior exhibits of the various village and housing types were well done and fun to explore. We would recommend it!
Fascinating.. If you need to know about Vietnam then this is crucial - so interesting. Great exhibits and realistically reconstructed villages.

Provides a Great Perspective of the People and Culture. Had not visited this attraction in previous visits and glad we did this time. We spent 1.5 hours and felt that was plenty of time. Most displays had an English translation. Some people had employed guides but we did not feel we had missed much by not doing so. Friends also purchased a 100,000 dong ticket to allow them to take pictures in the museum. A yellow sticker indicated they had this right. Interestingly many people were taking photos and they had the only sticker on that I saw. The moral to this story is that it seems you do not have to pay for this.Stopped at the lovely cafe outside the entrance run by a charity for disadvantaged youth. Food and service great and prices were reasonable. Taxis always outside- no issues with return transport

Interesting museum with excellent outdoor part. We spent about 3 hours at this museum which we found very interesting. There is heaps of information available to explain how the different groups live and their customs, texts are in English, French and Vietnamese. Exhibits include traditional clothing, tools and musical instruments for almost every group, but also many others, for example a funeral and even an entire house inside the museum.Also very interesting and not to be missed is the outdoor part behind the museum which displays houses of several groups either built on site or moved here. You can walk into the houses and get a feel for the way these people live.To save on a taxi ride you can take bus 14 or 38 from the city for 7,000 dong (April 2015 price).

Insight to Vietnam's Culture. The first thing that I saw in the entrance of the museum was the TripAdvisor Award sign. It boosted my desire to visit the museum. The museum is a must-see,must-visit place to a tourist. It was amazing to learn the ways of life of the numerous ethnic groups that comprised Vietnam and how they evolved in time to be the Vietnam that we know today. The good relationship of Vietnam with other countries like Norway, etc. were shown in the well-maintained houses and structures built around the grounds of the museum. The building housing the Southeast Asia relics, traditional costumes and other paraphernalia seems to still have ample space for other materials that may be exhibited to the public. The buildings showing the culture of the various ethnic groups were airy and had benches/stools to sit on if one wants to view an audio visual presentation or if one gets tired of coming up the stairs or roaming around.The only thing that marred my visit there was the foul smell that emanated from the restroom at the ground floor; otherwise, my rating would have been excellent.

really well thought out. it's a taxi ride away but taxis are very cheap ($4 from the old town). Plan to spend three or four hours to get the best out of it - we thought an hour and a half might do but there is lots more to see including the grounds so we had lunch at the cafe inside the facility half way through (No more expensive than an indoor restaurant outside the gates).
Great place to learn. Honestly I was ignorant of how diverse a population Vietnam traditionally had. It was an eye opener. I found the different houses and lifestyles quiet interesting.
Educational. If you want to do more than shop and learn about some of Vietnam's history and culture, I highly recommend visiting VME. The diversity of Ethnic groups in Vietnam is astounding. Enjoy!

Hanoikids do this well. We only visited the outside areas as our kids got a little tired of museum visiting and we'd promised them a park visit (there is a great outdoor park for kids nearby). But we all found it very interesting. Get Hanoikids to take you, they fill in all the gaps beautifully.

Fascinating look into different subcultures of Vietnam. I really enjoyed my time exploring the Museum of Ethnology in Hanoi. I was only there for about an hour and a half, but I wish I could have taken more time to read and wander. It's a decent taxi drive from the old quarter, so plan for a bit of travel time on either end. Make sure to look at the outdoor exhibits! It really brings everything to life.

Very well done museum. Shows lifestyles of the 54 ethnic groups in Viet Nam, although the Viets are 85% of the population. Most live in the inland hills. Replicas of their homes are built in the outdoor garden. Could spend a long time in the museum and a guide is helpful. But descriptions are also in English.
Visit to Vietnam Museum of Ethnology. The exhibition in the building was ok but a little passive to visitors.The outdoor exhibits of local tribal houses were very interesting and wonderful to visit.

Great intro the the culture of Vietnam. If you are planning a trek in the Sapa area to visit various minority ethnic tribes, this is an especially useful and interesting introduction to the various ethnicities that call Vietnam home. Everything is well labeled in multiple languages. The grounds include examples of of traditional houses. It's not a huge museum and won't take that long to go thru, but I thought it one of the best and most informative sites in Hanoi.
A Must See!. The Museum is just what the name implies. Going back generations highlighting the different ethnic groups of Vietnam and different parts of the country

Cultural stop. I spent more than 2 hours to explore it and I enjoyed my time here. The museum includes 2 main parts. Indoor exhibits show the typical normal life of many tribes while the outdoor is real tribe buildings. I loved watching videos and make a comparison with I saw when traveling to Sapa and Central highland of this country. Great experience!
learning area!. Learn more about Vietnamese people that consists of numerous tribes. There is also an open-air museum of traditional tribal houses
Badly arranged. Interesting topics but really hard to navigate and get much from it. Since it is a bit out from where we were, I would not have made the trek if I had known.

Great indoor and outdoor experience. The Vietnam building of the museum contains many nice exhibits, among them many models of traditional Vietnamese buildings. When you have gone through all the exhibits, you can go around the building and see full scale models of many of those same traditional buildings. You can even walk into many of them. Amazing.

World-class presentation, great introduction to local culture, decent museum cafe, good for families. My friends and I came to this museum on a Saturday afternoon, hearing that it was the best museum in Hanoi. It did not disappoint. The exhibits are well-presented, and in the garden in the back there are many relocated houses from Vietnam's ethnic communities. I could imagine that this would be fun for families. I wish I had more time to read everything carefully, as after a day of museum-going I was a bit over-saturated. I'd recommend seeing the garden first, and then the central museum, and if you don't have time the Southeast Asian hall is not really necessary. Note that there is a decent museum cafe with Vietnamese standards, as well as a branch of CraftLink, in case you'd like to buy arts and crafts afterwards.

A Look At All The Ethnic Groups. liked it for a quick look. It has many displays of all the groups of people who make up the population. See depictions of every day life, costumes and the like.Interesting couple of hours.

Unbelievable amount of information!. We really enjoyed the Vietnam museum of Ethnology. We ended up booking a tour with the Hanoi Kids for this Museum, and our tour guide was awesome at explaining what the signs left out. She was also very helpful in getting a cab all the way out there to the museum (It's about 15 mins from the Old Quarter).The full-size homes constructed on the property are amazing, but built with a "natural selection" theme in mind...mind your footing or you may take a tumble.Highly recommended if you would like to learn more about the ethnic groups of Vietnam.
Culture of Vietnam. Worth seeing learning the culture of the Viennese people and seeing the villages setup in the back of the museum.

Most enjoyable museum !. I am a person that does not like museum but this one is different. It has both outdoor and indoor exhibits. I loved the outdoor one as you see the different houses of the ethnic group in different parts of Vietnam. You can also see a tomb. Between the houses, there are trees indigenous to the area of each house, zigzagging paths and a meandering stream crossed by small bridges.

A Good Way to Understand the background of Vietnam. If you only have time for 1 Museum in Hanoi make it this one. Our tour guide took us there and it was a great way of understanding the history of Vietnam and why it has such a large number of minorities.

A surprising place to see!. I loved this place, this is the one where I could see how most of ethnic group in Vietnam, I saw how each of them build a house, equip the house, and how they make traditional clothes,...I found a a real house for Tay group ( living in North East area), a big difference from the Kinh one. I love the one for Kinh in the North (may be because my grandmother is Vietnamese woman in the North?)I could explore how the children play local games ( so funny!!)Advice: Visiting this place, you can know well Vietnam more than any other oneIt is around 20 minutes by taxi from the Old Quarter ( 5 $), and entry fee is around 2 $Welcome any question!
Best museum in Hanoi. You learn a lot of interesting things about Vietnamese differents 54 ethnics.The displays are very moving, telling

If you have time for only one museum in Hanoi, make it this one.. Don't know the difference between Viet, Cham and Jarai? Then you need to visit this museum, which has eye opening collections covering the 50+ ethnic minorities living in Vietnam, complete with full-scale reproductions of some of their more unique houses. Regrettably, we had only a couple of hours here so couldn't see everything - half a day would have been just right.
Very beautiful museum, a must go. traditions of the different ethic groups living in Vietnam.Even id the museum is a bit far from the city center, it is worth to go.

beautiful and interesting. great place to see and read about all the different groups of Vietnamese ethnics and to see their homes.
i enjoyed this place

interesting view of the different ethnies. we liked to see the different houses, one per vietnamese ethnie
especially the very high one and the long one

Essential if you are visiting Sapa and Lao Cai. This museum gave an excellent introduction and explanation of the history of the ethnic peoples of northern Vietnam. Having then gone on to the Lao Cai region we really appreciated having visited this museum first; it informed us and gave us many ideas of what to look for. Exhibits well presented. Allow a couple of hours.

Good museum to understand the people of Vietnam. The museum is well designed and has some interesting exhibits, however it is a bit long for children to absorb. the quality of the exhibits was great and did provide a look into the people that populate the country.

Impressed by this. The objects and documents on display are very well chosen. The many explanations other hand, do not really illuminate the visitor to the complex multitude of ethnic groups and sub-ethnic groups that seem to distinguish (but is it really possible?). In contrast, the outer part with the houses reconstructions is simply exceptional. A unique experience that makes this must-see museum in Hanoi!

excellent museum with many exhibits, both outside and inside. A bit out of town but worth a visit - a taxi won't cost too much. Lots of interactive exhibits and information on the different ethnicities throughout the country. 40,000dong entry.
Can skip if not much time in Hanoi !!. The museum is just about average . Decent insights into the tribes and ancestral history of Vietnam and its people . Can miss if short on time

Very informative. For those who are interested in the various ethnic groups of Vietnam (there are 54 of them) then this is an excellent place to go. The photos, models and explanations are very helpful. For just getting a general impression, an hour would be sufficient. But for those who are deeply interested, it will take more time because there are many video clips at various stages of the two-floor display. Photography allowed. There is a shop at the end with books.
For the serious minded. This is not fun, it is very interesting, and have been there twice. Both times spent many hours learning about the various cultures that make up Vietnam today
Vietnam Museum of Ethnology- a must Visit!. Would liked to have had a much longer time when visiting this Museum, it was extremely interesting on the history of the Vietnamese people.

Insights into the cultural heritage of Vietnam. Take an hour or two to visit this museum. The exhibition was informative with translations in both French and English. Building techniques, costumes and tools were laid out in well structured displays. The outside part with houses of the various peoples were interesting and would allow children to run off a bit of energy after being inside. The whole exhibition really opened my eyes up to the wealth of culture in the nation and made me want to come back to Vietnam to discover the more remote areas. The museum shop had plenty of items made by ethnic groups with funding going back to those areas. I bought some embroidered silk pencil cases for about $10 and some watercolour paintings for $10. I would have liked to buy some water puppets but I thought for more than $60 they were a bit too expensive.
Great for kids, good to start VN Tour. Great overview about the 54 ethnic groups of VN, laid a good base for the following 2 weeks tour through VN
Informative. For culture lovers.Amazing place with lots of statues, photos and real life evidence of the Ethnic Minorities.There's a small souvenir boutique.

Very informative. The Vietnam Museum of Ethnology had some very insightful information regarding the various populations within Vietnam, as well as their histories, lifestyles and traditions. We visited as part of a city tour so had the added bonus of our tour guide giving his own perspective and injecting his own life experiences. The outdoor garden area is also a great addition for kids as there are things for them to climb and try. There is also an outdoor water puppet show.

Touring with a student volunteer guide. It is worth considering and hiring a student volunteer. Check out Hanoi Free Tour Guides on the internet. The service is free and student volunteers are more than happy to take you around Hanoi. Museum of Ethnology is definitely worth a visit to get a feel of Vietnam culture.

An excellent outside exhibit experience. The Museum building is a well-displayed set of carefully chosen artifacts, although it is fairly limited and doesn't take long to view. The real attraction here is the outside displays of traditional housing. We were fortunate to have an english speaking guide to walk us through the exhibits, but even if we hadn't, there is enough english signage to manage. Well worth the visit!
not a bad way to kill an hour. not anything special but pretty cool to learn about especially if you are about to launch into Vietnam for more time.
Very informative museum. We visited the Vietnam Museum of Ethnology when we were in Hanoi and it was wonderful. Lots of displays on the outside grounds as well as inside. Well worth seeing.
Interesting also for children. We saw all the puppets dressed in ethnic folklore dresses. Then my children went out and climbed into all the houses outside

First Class museum Learn how the 54 Different ethnic groups live. Really good museum . Interestng exhibits in spacious galleries Outside there are buildings for the different groups . Easy to spend half a day here .I just caught a cab here and it was easy to get one back . I was so interested I bought a lovely book featuring the different groups
Very informative. Interesting and informative. Lots of pictures and examples of different ethnic groups. There are also mock homes set up outside the museum.

A trip down Vietnam culture.. The paintings, figurine, carvings, etc were very interesting. We fell for the lacquer paintings. We were interested in Vietnam's past heritage and links with our culture.

History of Viet peoples. Excellent displays, but a bit disorganized. The experience is enhanced if you can read Vietnamese. If not you can get the gist of what is being said by looking at the maps. Some displays also have English, but not all. I wish I had more time at this sitre to be able to fully appreciate all the items.

interesting!. can see the ethnic minorites' life around Viet Nam.
Also can see the Water pupet show with very cheap price (less 2times compare with Water pupet Theater near Hoan Kiem Lake).
Ticket to visit is cheap, too.
Very clean and large.
Valuable.

One of the Better Museums in Vietnam!. I found this museum to be the best of all museums I visited during my stay in Vietnam. The outdoor reconstructions of different houses really brought to life the information learned inside the museum. The children loved exploring the homes, and loved climbing into some of the more unusual houses. The outdoor section is definitely the highlight of the museum.The museum itself contains more information and artifacts than I saw in most other museums in Vietnam. Though there is a section devoted to photographs, there are also examples of different clothing, toys, tools, and writings from various ethnic minorities. Definitely worth a visit. My one regret is that we did not book an English speaking tour guide. Although there are signs in English throughout the museum, I wish there had been someone there to whom I could have asked questions. Outside of the museum, there is a cafe that is also a charity for disadvantaged youth. The deserts there was great.
Very interesting. Definitely should come if you are visiting Vietnam. You would learn alot about the Vietnamese cultures and the diversity of languages spoken in Vietnam.

Tells the interesting story of the Vietnamese people and tribes. As part of a private tour, we visited this museum. The Museum tells the story of the many tribes of people, which Vietnam is made of. Outside the museum, many traditional houses from the different tribes have been build to scale, and it is possible to get inside the houses, which is a great experience.A great visit if you are interested in the ethnics groups of Vietnam - or just want a bit of culture :)

Excellent - a must. Thus is a really good museum into the ethnology and culture of Vietnam's ethnic groups. I ended up spending over half a day here. The outdoor exhibition of buildings is especially good.
Great museum. This is a must if you are in hanoi, really interesting museum tells the story of vietnam very well and in great detail

There are 54 different ethnic groups and their lifestyles..clothes, homes, dances are shown here. Good for the sociology buff but not a must see. They have a water puppet show and it is free after you pay entrance

Museum of Ethnology. The Museum of Ethnology is a great museum, and If you only are going to visit one museum in Hanoi this is the one…! The museum covers the culture of the various ethnic groups in Vietnam and consists of an indoor exhibition and a huge open-air exhibition. The indoor section has exhibitions of clothes, agricultural tools, fishing instruments, musical instruments, and religious artefacts - belonging to the many ethnic groups of Vietnam. Outside the museum there is a huge open-air exhibition with several houses of ethnic groups: the Tay stilt house, the Bahnar communal house with an impressive height of 19 meters, the Ede longhouse, the Viet house, the Giarai Tomb, and more…
Interesting. A good insight into the Vietnams ethnic minority groups. We enjoyed the outside house reconstructions. Inside was alright but limited

Describes the Ehtnic Communities of Vietnam. Very informative. Worth a visit, we did not get much time to visit this centre, but whatever time we spent did give us a overview of the Ethnic distribution of the people of Vietnam

Interesting. This place was fascinating. Without a guide though a lot of the interesting parts would be lost. Worth going to but take a guide to fill in some of the gaps. Can be a bit long if you are not into the subject.
Must see place in Hanoi. The museum is well-organized, gave you an understand about 54 ethnic groups in VN. If you can visit the museum right after the Tet holiday, there are a lot of activities.

Great way to understand Vietnamese culture. Museum shows culture, ethnic dress and customs of the 54 ethnic groups making up Vietnam. We had a local student guide with us but most all signs are in English and French along with Vietnamese so it would be possible to do it without guide. We spent about 2.5 hours there which I thing would be the normal amount of time. The full size native houses outside were really interesting. We really enjoyed the visit.

Insight in to ethnic minority life. We visited the museum with our guide and this was very useful to help us understand the outdoor exhibits. As there are 54 ethnic groups in Vietnam there is a huge diversity of style of building, several of which have been constructed at the museum by members of their particular group, so are entirely authentic.The static displays inside the museum are equally diverse and feature colourful clothing, day to day items and reconstructions of household scenarios. There is also an excellent display of photographs. Allow plenty of time as there is so much to see.
