Understanding. To gain an understanding of the culture and somewhat history of the people and their belongings, this is a must, the most enjoyable attraction , we enjoyed in Vietnam . Part of the one day city tour.

Well Worth the Visit. Gives a great insight into the fifty four ethnic groups that live in Vietnam, complete with customs and costumes and other examples of the different areas. Try to visit when it hasn't rained. The walkways to the outside exhibits showing the varied housing of the ethnic groups can be muddy. We were definitely impressed with the museum, both inside and outside.

Nice design and architecture, and very interseting museum. It was the second museum, that we visited this day after the Ho Chi Minh museum. Take time (2 min.- 3 hours) to visit it inside and outside (many bamboo and wooden huts outside in the park) - I recommend that you take a guide to help you through your visit to better understand what stands behind the things displayed; we did not stop at each one of them, but it seems that our guide took us to the most interesting ones, and of course helped us for other less striking pictures or things that we asked him about. We went there by taxi from downtown for a couple of dollars. We enjoyed our visit all the more given the pouring rain outside

An interesting couple of hours. Our guide took us here and as it was just him and us, it was very interesting. He knew a lot about the displays. Worth a visit if you are interested in the Vietnamese people.

private tour. I think the museum would have been a lot better had we gone through it on our own. We had the curator or his assistant give us a private tour and although she was very kind and nice there was a huge language barrier as she understood very little english. She had a rehearsed speel and when gotten off course it just didnt work. I ended up reading the plakards to answer questions asked by our friends. More than once we told her we were ready to just go to the outside exhibits, she would shake her head yes in agreement then move to the next exhibit on her list! It became rather commical !!One of our group was able to escape and we found her sitting down stairs "waiting" on us!!I guess if we had gone through on our own I would give this experience a higher rating but I still have a sour taste after the two hour tour of trying to figure out what she was saying on her pre planned non waivered semi english tour. I am pretty good at broken english and I could not keep up. At one point she told us something that my husband was interested in and I had smiled and said yes or cool like I understood her so we cold move on and he said in front of her "what was that she said?" I gave him a look like please be quiet then when we turned told him not to ask me because I am just agreeing with her with out understanding half of it so we can be done!.

Comparative architecture of the tribal homes. Brilliant exhibitions and it was useful that we had already toured the North West and North Eastern areas - realized that the culture was different further south.

You have to visit this one. This is a place located in the heart of Hanoi where you can see how they lived (and still live) in different areas of the country. They have real replicas of several types of buildings which you can go inside (you have to remove your shoes for entering some).The museum part is also very impressive explaining all the different races that compose the Vietnam population, their costumes and clothing.Just a great place to visit but try to go on a "dry" day otherwise it may get a bit muddy in the garden outside.
A Must See. Each tourist should visit the museum to get an impression about Vietnam in former days. We were lucky as therewere not many tourists. Our private guide explained very well.

An insight into Vietnamese history and culture. This was the first place we visited in Vietnam. And I am glad we did, for it gave us a wonderful peek into Vietnamese cultural history- it's vibrant ethnicity, the individuality and richness of the various groups that make up Vietnamese society : their traditions and customs, homes and hearths, musical instruments, weapons, hunting and fishing implements..........The Museum is well laid out as are the exhibits.

History buffs. Very interesting museum. It's a bit of a trek from the center of Town so take a taxi. Be careful what taxi you hire when you leave the museum - lots of tricky drivers just waiting to con you!

An interesting visit. As there are 54 ethnic minority groups in Vietnam this museum is very interesting especially the buildings outside including the long house & house with a tall roof. At weekends a water puppet show is performed in the grounds at 10.00 & 11.30.The craft shop at the entrance is well worth a visit with reasonable prices.Allow 2.5hrs.

Great information on traditional Vietnamese life, housing examples fun for kids. The indoor exhibits provide excellent exhibits and details on traditional regional life, including crafts, industry, agriculture, dress, etc. The outdoor exhibit of indigenous housing types is terrific. The museum relocated a variety of buildings from around the country, and you can walk into them to get a feel for how it was (or is, since many of these housing types are still in use) to live in them. Kids will enjoy climbing up into the raised houses and feeling the bounce of the bamboo flooring.One note: the museum shop is excellent. Many of the items are produced by cooperatives and other supportive organizations, not souvenir factories. This was one our first stops in Vietnam, and I didn't know what we'd find elsewhere, so I only bought a few scarves and a hand-painted greeting card. In retrospect, wish I'd loaded up here. No pressure, no bargaining, low, fair prices, and they take US$ and credit cards.

Worth an hour or so. vietnam has a very diverse ethnic population, all "tribes" are represented here with some creative and fascinating displays.Outside are 10 or so reconstructed village dwellings from different groups.These are extraordinary.

A really interesting museum. This was a very interesting and informative museum. About 85% of Vietnam's population belongs to the dominant ethnic group. This museum is dedicated to the 53 other ethnic groups that make up the remaining 15% of the population. The exhibits are well organized and try to portray how each group lives. There are some beautiful crafts on display--with the best being baskets and cloth.

Well worth a couple of hours. Don.t waste your money on the organised tours. They are rush - rush and way overpriced.Take a taxi or a local bus. The Museum guides can be paid for on entry. We thoroughly enjoyed exploring the various ethnic houses in the Museum grounds.

Excellent museum. This was probably the most interesting museum in Hanoi. Manageable size and excellent real life exhibits of ethnic minority buildings including a very impressive reconstructed long house.
Interesting insight into ethnic minorities. Well created with interesting and informative exhibits. The recreation of different houses is fabulous. You can even see a water puppet show!

One of the best in South east Asia. Allow a couple of hours to visit it properly, both inside and outside. Take bus 14 from the top of H.Kiem lake, 7.000 dong, and ask the controller to be got off for the museum, which is '10 walk. You save money and have good views of Hanoi 4km murale done for the millennium anniversary in 2010.
Fasinating. A wonderful introduction to this amazing country. Even if you have only one day, you should see this small, lovingly created museum.

Amazing Tour with Nhi!!!. We had the most amazing experience learning more about the cultural groups of Vietnam. We had not booked a tour group or guide in advance. When we arrived at the ticket booth we saw one could be hired through the museum for $5 so decided to try it. We could not be happier as our guide, Nhi, was the curator for education and had actually visited the villages, collected the artifacts, and helped set up the exhibits. The knowledge she provided was simply incredible and it was very interesting to learn how the communities have changed over her time visiting. Would absolutely recommend for your time in Hanoi and booking a guide directly with the museum for more insight into the cultures of the country. One of our favorite days here in Vietnam.

One of the best museum in hanoi. This museum exhibit the ethnic groups of Vietnam. There are lots of collection, documentation, conservation, exhibition and preserving the cultural and historic patrimony of the nation’s different ethnic groups. The museum also serves to guide research, conservation, and technology that are specific to the work of an ethnographic museum. In its planning for the future, the Museum intends to present the cultures and civilisations of other countries of South-East Asia as well as in the region.

A Super Learning Place on Ethnicities. Well laid out; logically structured with discussions of many ethnic communities in Viet Nam. Great gift/souvenir shop specializing in ethnic community handicrafts.
Good museum. We toured museum as part of city tour. Good exhibits and would have liked more time to see them. Excellent outside exhibits too.

Great perspective on the different ethnic tribes of Vietnam. Very interesting place to visit if you want to learn more about Vietnam's indigenous tribes and regions. Best if a guide accompanies you to explain the differences of each ethnic group.

A good trailer of what you will discover in the Northern mountains. This museum is a good display of the cultural diversity of all the ethnic groups in Vietnam. You can see the many different costumes, really gorgeous, and how they are made and dyed from leaves, jewels, wares and music instruments, and architectural diversity with the typical houses built outdoor. You get an idea of their lifestyle with the videos on display, at the market, in their houses, at work, ceremonies... I can't think of many countries where there are still so many lively and vibrant ethnic group! Of course, the best is to go to the mountains and meet them in person in their amazing costumes and jewels, go to the markets and realize they still live like hundred years ago.

Very Pleasant Experience at the Ethnology Museum. I don't normally enjoy museums much but this contained many cute eye catching pieces, such as ethnic clothing, embroidery and water puppets that were easy on the eye, with just a little information to read on each section. No long overly detailed explanations here! It is a good size inside - a manageable area to walk around and real life traditional countryside houses outside, that are tastefully presented., It is somewhat far from the beaten track - about 30 to 40 minutes, but not expensive by taxi and well worth the effort!

Best. Best museum in Vietnam. They had international help setting this up. Very informative. It traces all the SE Asian people groups where they originated, where they ended up and mixed with other cultures. Fascinating. There is a mock village outside the museum in the rear -- this has some traditional houses etc.Should be top of the list as far as museums go for this country

Just wow..quiet, serene and informative. This museum was just great, with full size exhibits and a garden filled with ethnic minority houses built full size, you get a real sense of the diversity of Vietnam. This is a MUST, although the cab ride out was harrowing, it is well worth it.

Super Idea on a Cloudy Day. So interesting and historical - we loved it. We went on a cloudy day so it did not interfere with our beach time and outdoor activities. Great visit and it gives you an idea of where you want to go and visit next in Vietnam for the whole country has so many different peoples, cultures and ethnic tribes.

Rain made it feel more authentic. As it was a rainy day, we thought it would be good to visit the Museum. The indoor exhibits are great -- lots of English explanations and great exhibits. The outside buildings are fascinating and in the rain, just muddy and drippy enough to feel like the real thing. The museum itself is on the outskirts of Hanoi so a taxi is a must.

Architectural and ethological delight. Did you expect that 54inorotoes live in Vietnam! A great exhibition of the most important ethnic groups and their customs is expecting the visitor. Don't go with a guide - they just repeat what is actually well explained in English and French and they are obnoxiously loud with their shallow explanations! Don't forget the new museum wing on South East Asia and the out door exhibits. They put the whole in a friendly regional context. And both buildings are also from an architectural point of view a great experience. Last but not least the garden café serves tasty and affordable food.

Very informative and interesting. We found this museum very comprehensive and informative about the history and culture that contributes to what makes Vietnam today. We could have spent more time there and enjoyed it.
Free Walking Tour. Had a great young lady that took us there for the morning. Well worth the visit. Look up the Free Walking Tour. Im sure anyone will enjoy it as much as we did

Don't miss this museum.. This was a surprise to a westerner that there are so many different people who make up the country of Vietnam. The different houses they have outdoors to signify the different ethnic people were terrific and not to be missed. Both an indoor n outdoor museum.
Get to know. Is a good experience to know the different types of houses were occupied by different group of people. To know where are they settle in which part of Vietnam.

Really wonderful collection of ethnic dress, instruments, and homes.. This museum highlights the variety of ethnic groups in Viet Nam. I found the display of instruments, baskets, hats, dress, and implements very, very interesting.There were also some videos to explain certain ceremonies and traditions. I could have stayed longer here, and I would recommend going by yourself and just enjoying this museum. It's a beaut!

Great place to learn more about the 54 cultures. Visited during the Tet holidays. They had many activities for kids like traditional swings and balance beams. Loved the "villages" built on the grounds. Wonderful gift shop filled with gorgeous craft items.
Awesome. I often guide my foreign friends discovering this place and they all love it, there're many thing that you can't find anywhere but here.

Interesting houses outside, inside somewhat boring. Went here with a family of 5, the kids were mostly bored with the inside. Once we got outside, the 4-5 houses they had built were really interesting and the kids loved that part. Recommended for a couple hours. Restaurant there was ok, had better Pho elsewhere though.
Model huts the best part. Loved the outside portion of the model homes/huts. Fun and educational for the kids as well. Didn't take us very long to get through.

comprehensive overview of different ethnic groups and their artifacts. worth the trouble to hire a cab the place has a very nice collection of objects. Particularly several models of houses and graves

Interesting!!!. Went there with wife with the assistance of new found friends. The place showcase the different ethnic groups in vietnam and their cultures. Interesting and educational. Worth a visit!!

Vietnam Museum of Ethnology. Vietnam Museum of Ethnology is a quite good place for people come to see how was the Vietnamese history. Actually, it will be worth if we just go by ourselve because the ticket for that was really cheap, just 2$. Don't spend much money for some agancies like this.

A Complex Society. The museum explores the many different ethnic groups that comprise Vietnaese society and sets it in the historical context of how this complexity arose. The religious and day to day life of different groups are displayed. Of particular merit is the external display of houses occupied by different groups and these were erected by members of the tribe represented, providing a guarantee of authenticity.The museum was provided through France, the former colonial power, and one has the impression of minimal maintenance thereafter, nonetheless well worth a visit!
Interesting and well presented. Traces the development of the Vietnam peoples. Very well done and the exhibits are clear and in Vietnamese, English and French.
It's okay. Nice museum that gives the history of all the different tribes in Vietnam. There are lot's of old artifacts and pictures and mock displays.

Very interesting. We had to take a taxi out to the museum, but well worth a visit to get an overview of all the different tribes and their traditions who live in Vietnam. Loved the reconstructions of the various houses. It is set in a large park like area, so it is quite pleasant to wander around. Saw a performance of the water puppets in the grounds. Museums aren't great in Vietnam, but this one is .
Must visit. Excellent view of the background of Vietnamese civilization with marvelous exhibits and demonstrations. Great fun to go at New Year when children's games are in full swing.

A must- visit museum in Hanoi. Coming here, visitors may find out that the Museum has successfully recreated the daily life together with the religious rituals and the symbolic festivals of each ethnic group in Vietnam. All displayed objects mingle and supplement one another to create a colorful and diversified picture of Vietnamese culture.

Very interesting, but should be better taken care of. It gives a very good and deep idea of the different tribes that compose Vietnam, but the internal side lacks some comfort. The external side iv very interesting and is worth a visit

Well worth a visit, to gain an overview of the people. Not sure of the fee, but tells the story of the five main ethnic groups and their sub groups and their different culture and dress types as well as an inside into how they live.Can be a bit overwhelming as there is a lot to take in.

Ethnic Minorities. A great way to spend a few hours and learn about the lives of the many minority groups. Lots of weaving, basket making and jewelry examples to see. Best prices on ethnic crafts at the little gift shop. Don't miss it!

If you're going to Sapa, come here first. This museum is a good place to visit before going to Sapa. The exhibits were interesting and there is much to learn about the ethnic groups in Vietnam. This information was helpful when we visited the minority villages in Sapa a few days later.
good museum. This is very good museum I have seen during the time I go for vacation. A lot of kind people also go there for visiting with ancient showing product.

Interesting to learn history of the country. This Museum is 7km outside he old quarter past all the Embassy's and H o Chi Minh mausoleum which could be seen the same day. The museum reveals that Vietnam has a long tribal history with many diverse cultures and languages having evolved. The exhibits are typically labeled in three languages including French and English although they could be more informative a very old hand made rifle just has Rifle written against it rather than its age, who made it, used by etc etc. There are other exhibits if habitation in the grounds and a newly constructed building containing Southern Asia exhibits of pictures on glass and garments.
surprisingly good. Our guide took us here. It is actually quite interesting, explaining the diversity of the country. Worth a visit.

Very interesting museum. I thoroughly enjoyed looking round his museum. I recommend going at the weekend where here is a free water puppet show which was fantastic to see. The outside exhibits of different local buildings were particularly impressive.
A Great Cultural Review. A very well presented and organized museum. A must for travellers who like history, culture and regional clarity.

Great Museum. We spent a few hours at this Museum - both inside reading about all the ethnic groups in Vietnam and then working through the gardens looking at the various houses these groups built. Well worth a visit.

Awesome Experience. Good time spend there to have more information about the old days of Vietnam!!It is widely considered to be the finest modern museum in Vietnam and a tourist attraction in Hanoi.It was great being able to walk in the different types of traditional housing that have been moved into the grounds here. The inside exhibits we also interesting, particularly the videos, which gives you little bit idea about the era.The coffee shop hear the entrance did an excellent pho and if you have 2 tickets will get 1 coffee free with Free Wi-Fi.Beware a taxi driver who does not understand the English and they make money by taking unknown roads to reach this place. I had paid 60,000 VND extra to reach here which could not be more than 40,000 VND.

Great afternoon out. It was great being able to walk in the different types of traditional housing that have been moved into the grounds here. The inside exhibits we also interesting, particularly the videos, though they were of poor quality. The coffee shop hear the entrance did an excellent pho. Beware a taxi driver who waits outside the military museum. He added a 100k extra and then didn't have change, so offered a terrible dollar exchange rate. His meter screen was scratched to stop you being able to see.
nice. satysfing and nice location, i expected more but liked it a lotvery interesting :) gotta visit. i especially liked the typical houses from the countriside, from the mountains

Large complex with good variety and lots of explanation. Used media and lots of exhibits to explain the culture as well as having a brilliant free water puppet show outside. Useful leaflet, helpful staff and a free coffee at the next door cafe. Also plenty of real buildings make up the outside exhibits, built by locals. Only 40000 vnd but a bit further from the centre - we caught bus number 14 and the driver told us where to get off.

Ethnology Museum better than you might think. I have visited the Vietnam Museum of Ethnology twice. Of the many museums I have visited in Hanoi it is the highest quality experience. Excellent examples of regional housing and indigenous art. International collection is good as well. Big bang for the buck.
A comprehensive history of the people of VietNam. Large outdoor display of historic tribal homes and customs. Indoor display and exhibits even better. Very nice gift shop
Good cultural background. A well exhibited museum of the different ethnic tribes/people of Vietnam. A good background filler for understanding the Vietnamese
Fascinating. We spent approximately 2 hours here...great displays and a lot of information. Ell set out and interesting.

Vietnam in a nutshell . Although this museum requires a cab out of town, it is well worth it. They have well curated exhibits, covering all of the groups of people who live in Vietnam. The textiles were particularly amazing. We really liked the ceremonial pole at the front of the museum. Everything is in clear English, Vietnamese and French.

Top museum in Hanoi. IMHO this is the top museum to visit in Hanoi, especially if you have interest in the people and culture of Vietnam. Be prepared to spend >2 hours (we went there around 2PM and stayed until closing). For 40000 dong or <$2 USD, it is great value. It is filled with well put together and researched information on the various ethnic groups that make up Vietnam. It has the various ethnic houses on the outside. It also has an outdoor water puppet show (last show was 4PM on Sunday). It's a must see IMHO.
save time for outside. The outside exhibits are wonderful. And the cafe was inexpensive and high quality. It is a training site for underprivileged kids, with great chef guidance.

Interesting museum. Some nice features inside telling of the various ethnic groups in Vietnam and a fantastic photo exhibition when we went. The examples of ethnic housing outside were the best bit - even the rude carvings therein!

Lots to see. Its a long walk around the entire area going though all the history and culture of Vietnam. Carry water if you need as once you are in you have to walk back to the entrance to purchase anything. Also note where the toilets are in advance.
This was a great visit. This museum is a must when you visit Hanoi and see how and why lived the way they lived as shown in the museum

Interesting exhibits. It's just amazing to visit this museum. You can literally spend the whole day because there is so much to see, to experience and the amount of photos you can take here.The museum is open daily from 8.30am to 5.30pm. It is closed on Mondays and public holidays. General admission: 40,000 dong each pax. For guided tour will be much more expensive. If I'm not wrong, for a English speaking tour, it's about 100,000 dong.anyway we just bought the general admission tickets. Start from the indoor exhibits and after that proceed to the outdoor exhibits. Try to go in the morning because there is so much to see. There is a water puppet show everyday at about 2.30pm.

If you only go to one museum in Hanoi.... It's a shame that there aren't more museums in Vietnam like this one. It showcases all of the ethnic minority groups who live in Vietnam, and promotes an awareness of their culture and livelihood. Coming from Australia, our government could learn a thing or two from this place, and how to best go about educating the community and schools about our many indigenous nations and ethnic minorities.

Ethnic Minorities. It is the best place in Vietnam to get an overview of the many ethnic minorities in Vietnam and to see a bit of their cultural backgrounds. It is useful before visiting such places as Sapa or Dalat. Material is well presented and visits to houses on the grounds in great.
vietnam culture. nice, interesting. was not as I expected. i thought it would provide more reality and a showcase of vietnam lives.

Best museum in Ha Noi :)). The Museum of Ethnology is the best museum in the city of Ha Noi and really worth your time to visit. The exhibits are well-curated and of excellent quality -- and each interpretive display has translations in French and English. The main building is shaped like a traditional bronze Vietnamese drum, and has two levels that contain great information on all of the ethnic groups in Viet Nam. I especially enjoyed the life-sized dioramas that depicted the traditional activities, as well as the expertly-crafted miniatures of boats, houses, etc. as well.In the large outdoor area behind the museum building, you will find examples of the traditional houses used in different parts of the country. These have been moved from their original locations & re-assembled at the museum, or are replicas constructed by the craftsman from the respective regions... seeing and walking through each of these was like taking a trip across Viet Nam :)) Take the time to sit inside these houses, and imagine them filled with folks engaged in their ceremonies, daily activities, etc. (Hint: the guides take people at a brisk pace through these, and so you might want to walk through & enjoy them again after the tour is concluded).Not to be missed is the famous Water Puppet show, performed in the outdoor theater (complete with musicians and narrators)... I was really pleased to be able to see this marvelous art form again (having already viewed the show at the indoor theater in the Old Quarter) -- and the lighting was much better here (making for better photos/videos). Be sure to find out about the performance schedule and visit when these are taking place.The museum gift shop is operated by the non-profit Craft Link organization, and has excellent quality handicrafts at reasonable prices (w/o the hassle of bargaining too). The crafters are given "fair trade" prices for their very nice works, and so a purchase here will benefit them well... There are a range of prices for items small to large, so it's easy to find something that you can afford :))Enjoy my favorite Ha Noi museum!

A must visit in Hanoi. The well appointed museum offers extensive exhibits of Vietnam's ethnic minorities including costumes, crafts, body adornment, music, dance, and unique ceremonies marking life events such as birth and death; others reflect shamanistic practices. Open-air exhibits of rural architecture are not to be missed. A minimum of two hours is needed to see gem of a museum. KZFung

Indoor + Outdoor. A great mix of museum and park, that shows the different ways of life from the the north to the south. You can climb through the various buildings, see all the tools and instruments used to live and learn the history of the many different people throughout the country.

a great museum. The Museum of Ethnology is a great museum, and If you only are going to visit one museum in Hanoi this is the one…! The museum covers the culture of the various ethnic groups in Vietnam and consists of an indoor exhibition and a huge open-air exhibition.

Vietnam Museum of Ethnology - Impressive. Come to Vietnam Museum of Ethnology, I was known the traditional 54 ethnic groups Vietnam with the Tay stilt house, the Viet house with tile roof, the Cham house, the Hanhi house,... Very impressive!

A nice place to visit before heading to Sapa. We booked a city tour from Vietnam travel Consultant and our guide recommended us to visit this museum before going to Sapa and yes, it is very nice place to discover about ethnic group minority before going to Sapa.
Must see!. This is a must on everyone list if interested in culture and make up of the Vietnamese people. Loved it - my favorite Museum in Hanoi.

Insight into daily life and culture of vietnamese people. We were recommended to this museum as being the best museum if you only have time in Hanoi to visit one. Superbly laid out it describes clearly the different ethnic groups in Vietnam their daily life and culture using wall displays and actual life size scenic displays of various activities accompanied by photos and films. Also surrounding park has a number of houses constructed which you can enter showing you typical houses of different ethnic groups. Well worth a visit. We were not disappointed.
put at top of your list. Women through history in Vietnam showed so many ways. Well done. Gift shop good value and profit goes to help women

Informative and well presented. The museum offers extensive information about the ethnic communities in Vietnam. In particular, the photography exhibit was compelling - enough so to make me contemplate a trip to visit the hill tribes. Step outside for a tour of the various housing styles that are utilized by these peoples.Shoppers, take note: the museum also has an excellent shop run by Craftlink, offering beautiful and authentic merchandise, also fairly priced. I wish I'd known then that I would not have the same opportunity to find this selection.

very enlightening. Highly enjoyed the museum - had to get there by taxi as it in not close to the old quarter (at least we didn't want to walk there).The museum's highlight is the different houses shown on the outside by the different tribes, it gives a very authentic experience to the culture.Inside you have the 'set up' exhibitions, showing the tools, clothes and various aspects of the daily life of the tribes. Definitely a good way to get insight into the different tribes around Vietnam.

Informative; good descriptions; nice outdoor displays. With 54 ethnic groups in Vietnam it's worth understanding how different they are. The museum has excellent English language descriptions, nice pictures and artifacts indoors, and a dozen authentic tribal buildings outdoors, worth a nice walk in pleasant weather.

A great museum. I really enjoyed visiting the ethnology museum. The best part for me was outside where they have reconstructed houses in the styles of all of the main ethnic groups of Vietnam. It has been very well done as they actually got people from the villages to come into the museum to construct the buildings themselves. Inside the museum you'll find more information about clothing, the culture and history of the groups.The museum itself is not in the main part of Hanoi but you can either take a bus or a taxi.

Interesting, Educational & Loved Walking through the Reconstructed Tribal Homes. The museum brought to life the astonishing ethnic diversity in Vietnam. We learned there are presently 54 different ethnic groups that inhabit the small country of Vietnam. I hadn't realized Vietnam still had so many ethnic groups, and, that each one had distinct cultures, homes, costume, etc. The museum was interesting and contained photos, instruments, pottery, art and artifacts from the various ethnic groups. Inside the museum were detailed descriptions of minority groups, with examples of their traditional clothing and way of life. The abundance of information was overwhelming. The museum would have been a fabulous starting point for any student studying the ethnic groups. Outside were faithful reconstructions of traditional longhouses, cemeteries and other distinctive ethnic buildings. We truly enjoyed walking through the tribal homes and buildings. It gave us a literal sense of how they live.

Great museum - well worth a visit. Great place to learn about all the different ethnic groups of Vietnam. Inside is art of the peoples. Outside are houses showing their homes and living conditions. Great inexpensive souvenirs in the gift shop made by ethnic groups. Not to be missed in Hanoi.
Great museum. Really got some history of Vietnam through this museum especially liked the outdoor exhibit of the minoritynliving quaerters. Loved the fishing basket bike...

Wonderful and educational. They have done a creative job of demonstrating the cultural history and architecture of the ethnic groups. Wander through the outdoor area to explore a dozen tribal home and buildings. You can walk in and really get a sense of them. Inside the building there are two floors of costumes, instruments, pottery, etc., along with a photo display that is very well done. Highly enjoyable and worthwhile.
Good musuem. Old buildings and structures brought in from all over Vietnam. Well worth a visit when you visit Ha Noi

A Small Viet Nam. Museum of ethnic is the place that you can discover all the ethnic group living in Viet Nam boundary without traveling around Viet Nam. you will find there the brief introduction about the ethnic groups and the model of the house, customs, clothes...of each ethnic group.
Not to be missed!. Beautiful authentic village sets. Lot of pictures and beautiful costumes. You will learn about the various cultures of the region
Very interesting!. This is a must-visit museum in Hanoi. Very unique. We love it very much. You can easily see lots of tourists here everyday.
Surprisingly interesting. A good way to experience Vietnamese ethnology. Md ont miss either the gift shop, or the full sized home replicas outdoors.
good for taking a brether from the mad dash of the city. the outdoor space is great for family with young kids. there is also a nice cafe-restaurant in the gardens.
Incontournable!. Worth a visit to have a better understanding of all the ethnic groups living around Vietnam. The outdoor buildings are excellent. Bonus if you get to see the water puppet show.

Fascinating Museum of Ethnology. My husband and I traveled to Hanoi and visited the Museum of Ethnology. I was surprised to discover that Vietnam had so many ethnic minorities, and that each group was very distinct from the others. It was fascinating to see each ethnic group's history, language origins, clothing, food, dance, and other cultural contributions. We had opportunities to walk into houses used by the different groups and learn about ancient rituals that they practiced. Overall, we had a very enjoyable time.
so meaningful. You can get all things about Vietnam Ethnologies here, this museum shown me everything about the history of Vietnam

Interesting, But Not A "Must See". Viet Nam is populated by over 50 different ethnic groups, if you are interested this is a good place to learn about them. This isn't a big museum, but not a bad place to spend an hour or so.

Super interesting Museum. I super love the Museum inside and outside, we also hired a super super tour guide and got some many information about the Museum and the story of the Museum and the different ethies in Vietnam. I think all the countries should have the same type of Museum.

Best Museum in Hanoi. This is a very well presented museum, which gives lots of information about the lives, traditions and history of the people who live in Vietnam and the neighbouring countries. The various rooms are well presented, with a good overview for each region/people and lots of interesting artefacts, photographs, videos etc. The one thing that wasn't made very clear was whether the thinks being displayed were about how these people live now, or whether it was largely historical; it would have been interesting to know whether people still follow the traditions that were being described or not. Of particular interest is the collection of houses and other buildings that have been brought from around Vietnam and displayed outside at the museum. This gives a really interesting insight into the different styles of building around the country. Overall, having been to most of the museums in Hanoi, I thought that this was the best presented by far.

Informative and Entertaining. This is one of the top museums in this part of the world. Exhibits give visitors an excellent overview of each of the 54 ethnic groups that live in Vietnam. If you come to Hanoi with the intention of going to Sapa or another "hill tribe" area, come here first and learn about the people and their culture - it will really add another dimension to your trip. There is a large outdoor area in addition to the main exhibits in the museum. Here, you can see the different houses that people live in, go inside and explore. This is informative for adults and lots of fun for the kids too. Though the museum is located a few kilometers from the city center, it's definitely worth making the trip. If you don't want to take a taxi (about $5 or $6 from the Old Quarter), you can also take a public bus there.

Interesting. The museum itself is well laid out and has some very good descriptions written out for English speaking visitors to see. The museum itself is not very big however. Don't forget to see the donated native architecture outside.

Very interesting. This museum is a must see in Vietnam to understand the culture of Vietnamese people. You see pictures, clothes, tools and other items of the life from minorities in Vietnam. Their also rebuilt houses of different minorities. It's a very good preparation if you go to the northern mountain region.

Liked the outside house replicas. What struck us most about this museum was the real life houses and huts that were on display outside. INteresting to see all the different ethnic groups that lived in vietnam and al the different customs and cultures that exist. Most expensive museum we visited but well worth the trip.

An excellent cultural knowledge of Vietnam in one hour.. Very good museum if you are interested in history and cultural knowledge in just one hour ( with a Good Guide) . Also has a good Souvenir shop . Special attractions were Viet ritual dolls, Viet shawn, Muong funeral scene, Nung hat, Hmong skirt, Lolo women garments, Sedang back basket,, Giarai zither, Cham buffalo cart, Hoa wedding dress. Timings are 8:30 to 5:30, Monday closed.

Interesting stories unimpressive building. The museum is a study of tribes and indigenous cultures in and around North Vietnam. Some of it is interesting but, most is pretty poorly put together. A lot of reconstructed huts, structures and artifacts but, seemed like a lot of wasted space. The garden areas were nice. Would be a fun place to bring children who like to climb

Don't Miss It!. Vietnam comes alive here, with communal houses, models, carvings, videos, and so much more. Adds a new dimension to Vietnam. And the chicken noodle soup at the restaurant is delicious!

great!. The Vietnam Museum of Ethnology is a valuable centre for the exhibition and the preservation of cultural heritages of the 54 ethnic groups in Vietnam.The museum also serves to guide research, conservation, and technology that are specific to the work of an ethnographic museum.

a decent museum to visit for a while. Learn about the cultural heritage of the Vietnamese people by visiting this museum. It's a bit dated, but you'll see exhibits on the historical clothing, tools, housing and customs of the many groups who have lived around the country. There's a main building with two floors of exhibits (which are self-explanatory), and a small park out back, with full-size examples of some village housing. It took me about an hour and a half to walk through the museum, but I keep a fast pace when I visit museums.Also, there's a gift shop and restaurant onsite, and it's easy to grab a taxi out front (to get you back to the city center). Entrance cost was $2.
Very educative!. No visit of Vietnam would be complete without touring this museum!Highly recommended! Take rwo hours for a thorough visit.

a place of nationality and humanity. Been there with friends from UK in late of Oct 2014. Such a great place to know and feel much more about the country and the peoples of the nation.Many things showed from the early days of the nation: tribes, how they lived and what survived nowadays. If you come to Hanoi, don't forget to take a visit, worth your time.

Great Experience. It was treat to see the old Viet culture. Bamboo work, husbandry, handiwork, tools, weapons,clothing, the ceremonies etc.Its a good practice so see what the prevelant beliefs and practices are and this trip brought to light the genesis of Viet culture. Its ironically romantic,
Worth a visit. Great back ground info to the conflicts in Vietnam explains the different peoples and philosophies amongst the Vietnamese peoples

Great museum!. We had limited time so we went and looked at all the various houses outside. This was simply fascinating looking at the different house designs based on the groups of people. A very interesting covered burial sight. The covering is not put on for a few years. The day we were there there were school children on a field trip.

To Know all 54 different Etnics Groups in Vietnam. A very interesting place to visit. You can see the respect for all etnics groups in Vietnam. The highlights are the houses constructed outside the museum.Take a look the museum shop. Good gifts to by with guarantee of precedence from ethics groups

Make this a first stop in Hanoi. Vietnam has some 54 different ethnic groups. This museum opens the door for more research and study, but is a nice head start on understanding Vietnam's various ethnic minorities. Maybe see this museum before heading to Ha Giang or Sa Pa....it will help with cultural understanding.
Don't miss the water puppets. very interesting in terms of the history of the various peoples. We loved the water puppet show, listening to the live music, watching the delight of the children

Introduction to Vietnam. This is an amazing museum showing the diverse culture of Vietnam's 54 ethnic groups through a collection of clothes, textiles, musical instruments and many other items from daily life.
Everything is well displayed and texts are in English.
Well worth a visit.

Wonderful museum to explore in Hanoi. Our second trip to Hanoi and we returned to this museum to explore again. The museum is both indoor and outdoor, so be sure the weather is good when you go. Great place for kids and adults as you can climb a bit into the different houses to experience the layout. Additionally, the cafe offers delicious food and the museum store has interesting handmade items that make great gifts. We also bought rice paper woodcut pictures from an artist on site in one of the houses. Excellent!

Nice Museum of Ethnology. when you would like discouvery about old vietnam Please coming to here, you can show have so much the old picture, old video say about all of vietnamese from 1945 to 1975 in vietnam. the same say eveverything about the war france to vietnam and American to vietnam. this infomation is easy for you understand about old vietnam poeple.

probably the best museum in Vietnam. This is a great attraction. Indoors there are nice exhibits on the history and people of Vietnam. Outside there are examples of houses from the different minority groups and an outdoor water puppet show. You can spent several hours here. If you go in the summer, try to go early: you'll avoid the crowds and won't be walking through the outdoor areas in the heat of the day.You shouldn't miss this if you're visiting Hanoi.
amazing museum on Vietnam. very informative and well laid out, with both indoor and outdoor exhibits. Plan on spending at least half a day to see everything.

Don't miss.. This is a wonderful museum, easily approachable with lots to see and learn. There are many authentic outbuildings you can explore. The water puppet theater there is included in the cost of admission. A group of musicians gave a wonderful performance on unusual instruments and we really enjoyed that. Inside there are interesting displays with descriptions in Vietnamese and English. Costumes, tools, transportation, housing, and religion are all explored. This is a don't miss when in Hanoi.

Interesting and informative. This museum is a little out if the way but worth a visit. It shows a lot about the lifestyles of the many ethnicities that make up Vietnam. The outside exhibitions are very very good as is the water puppet show.

Great museum, allow enough time. Very interesting, comprehensive collection on display. Well curated. Better than average information is available in English. Allow enough time to see the garden which contains a collection of real traditional houses and is really nice.
Like it. Great place to sight seeing and learn more about the locals here. I have recommended it to my friends

Amazing outdoor exhibition. If you come to Vietnam and want to gain a deeper insight into the diversity of Vietnamese ethnic groups, then this museum is your stop. The indoor artifacts are fascinating, with many never-before-seen-elsewhere items. The outdoor area is even more amazing with many traditionals houses and tombs of different groups from all over Vietnam. Some houses are a bit scary and murky. A wonderful experience!
Get an idea about the country. This isn't the best museum but it gives you an idea of the history of the country. Taxi ride from old quarter is cheap. Entry is almost nothing.
Intriguing. Very interesting. Loved learning about the vast number of ethnic groups in Vietnam and their individual cultures, building styles, clothing, and beliefs.
Very nice museum. Especially the outdoor replica of different ethnic groups houses. Also, has a nice list of all ethic groups with photos in the main lobby.

a little gem. visit to this museum is a must for any traveler who has any intrest in the history of the indiganous people of this region, it has two floors of artifacts photos and information but the most impressive and high impact are the life size building to the rear of the museum where children are aloud to interact and get involved in the structure

Great information and displays!. Our hotel organised an amazing guide for the day around Hanoi. We were so happy that he took us here as it was fantastic! The information was very easy to read and very informative. The displays and artifacts were really lovely and well presented. A really great insight into the culture of Vietnam
An excellent overview. An excellent way to get an overview of the 58 different ethnic groups in Vietnam. Well presented. The restaurant right next to the museum is very good also.

Nice place.. Very nice place for visitting.We from old quater come here by local bus with number 14.this place so beautiful and very clean.We understand more about counture very belong befor in Viet Nam.Hightly this place to every body.We will come back if we come back Hanoi.
You will learn a lot about Vietnam. Very interesting displays about Vietnam's history and the ethnic minorities.Their history goes back thousands of years.

Lovely museum - very enlightening. This museum shows, in detail, the various ethnic groups that comprise the hill country of Vietnam. I only wish there was more explanation of the artifacts and clothing on display

Great Museum in Hanoi. This museum was SO interesting. I had no idea there were so many different ethnic groups in Vietnam. A little far from our hotel in the Old Quarter, but still only a $5 USD taxi ride (one way). Would love to go back.

The museum is very informative. It exhibits the minority ethnics who live in Vietnam. It's very informative. It shows their culture and daily life. What I like the most is the ethnic groups house which is displayed outside. It will be much better if they also shows about the history of these ethnic groups and how they formed in Vietnam.

worth to see if you are staying in Hanoi more than 1-2 days. Actually I liked this museum more than other famous attractions in Hanoi. Especially outdoor exhibitions. You can walk inside different types of Vietnamese houses and feel life of the people in the villages. It is better to wear socks as it is not allowed to walk inside the houses in the shoes. Also there is a copy of water puppet show there.Indoor exhibitions is less impressive but still can spend 1 hour for its observation - mainly different types of clothes and tools of plenty Vietnamese tribes.If you are staying in Hanoi for more than 1-2 days, it is worth to see this museum.

must see in hanoi. it's give you a vision to understand more about vietnam, ethnics and tribes have been living on this beautiful land , very interesting .. if you aren't only fancy of seeing and staying very touristic places just take a taxi from the old quarter in ten minutes you will be there and taxi cost 70.000 vnd (3.5$) entrance fee is 40.000 vnd (2$) ..

Great outdoor exhibits. The outdoor reconstructions of traditional Vietnamese homes was so interesting that we never even made it into the museum building. This museum is a bit far from downtown, but the taxi ride is well worth the cost.
How to spend an hour. The indoor part of the museum is interesting but the out door area is a little under whelming. You can see the whole thing in an hour or so.

Modern museum with interesting exhibits. This is one of the more professional museums in Hanoi. However, unless one is really interested in the ethnology of Vietnam it may not be very thrilling. I found it represented basic information about the ethnic composition of Vietnam and was educational. However, it does not deal with the contemporary discrimination indigenous peoples and ethnic minorities confront in Vietnam as a result of official policies.

Important and Interesting. When you visit a country, it’s good to learn about its people, culture and history. Vietnam has 54 indigenous ethnic groups and the Museum of Ethnology introduces visitors to many of them. The space is dusty with neglect and poorly lit. But still gives one an essential perspective on life outside the bustling cities.
Architectural garden. Go for the architectural garden. You can safely skip the insides of the museum if you are short on time.

A fascinating review of tribal life. Included in our itinerary by our tour company, Cosiana Tours. Thank you, Mr Mike!Vietnam has 54 tribes, each with their own culture and dialect. This museum lets you learn about the history and view artefacts and well-presented tableaux about the life of just a few of those tribes. Very well presented, educational and entertaining.
Tribal stuff. A great surprise and really interesting. Could have planned more time. Well laid out and some fine displays.

Wowww. The indoor exhibition is good, but what i love better is the outdoor ethnic house. The highest house and the longest one were totally amazing. If i had enough wood, i would build one for myself and use as a bungalow!

Informative museum. Totally enjoyed myself in this museum. Learnt a lot about Vietnamese culture and its minorities tribes in different geographical locations in the country. The outdoor larger than life village-feel wooden houses of these minorities tribes were awesome. One of the best highlight that no tourists should miss when visiting Hanoi.
Great overview of Viet Nam Culture. This was an excellent way of getting prepared for our upcoming travels. The outside house exhibits were especially fascinating.
See This. A place with great displays of the various cultures from all over Vietnam. It really helps to explain some of the history and ethnicity of the country.
Worth a Look. There are several things to see at the Museum. It is not interactive, but full of pictures and artifacts worth seeing. It is worth a look while in Hanoi.

Nice museum. Loved the outdoor part more than the indoor section of the museum. However i need to point out, the facts are well presented on the 54 ethnic groups living in Vietnam. The outdoor section presents 11 houses which you can visit. The elevated bamboo structure houses are my favourite. Recommend to visit before going to Sapa to learn more about Vietnam and its people

Informative. Worth a trip there to learn more about the historical background of not just the Vietnamese people but also those in South East Asia. Also remember to check out the various full sized tribal homes on display in the museum compound.

Worth a visit. A worthy effort to describe the various people that make up Vietnam. Not very accessible for those in wheelchairs or strollers. Also, the museum and grounds could use some TLC. The best presented spot on the grounds of the museum is the Craftlink gift shop. But, still, worth a visit.

Interesting but too much for small child.. Wanted to visit here as didn't get out here on last two visits to hanoi. Had small child with me this time who's attention span didn't last the duration I would normally give to a museum. Very interesting to see all the ethnic groups of Vietnam outlined here , including their traditions for marriage and death , their cultural history and some wonderful exhibits of their dress and homes . Outside the life size ethnic homes were a better attraction to the small ones. It's further out of city than most other sites so do on bus tour or taxi here. Guide books available in a no. Of languages and all display signs in English as well as Vietnamese. Lots of stairs and some slopes for buggy . Not much in way of sitting areas for the elderly or tired feet.

Fun place to take kids. We took our four-year-old daughter here and it seems to be a very popular place for Vietnamese families--there were lots of kids there! They have about 18 structures around the grounds to demonstrate the architectural styles of various Vietnamese ethnic groups, most of which were purchased from actual villages and people from the group were hired to come and assemble the structures at the museum, so they are quite authentic, and truly beautiful buildings. And you can walk around inside them! The displays inside the museum are also very interesting--even our kid thought so! But the highlight of our visit (according to the kid) was the water puppet show...we had to see it twice!
Good insight into traditional life.. Probably only historic insight now but well laid out buildings and displays. Rather dry subject matter made significantly better with guides from Hanoikids

A good cultural experience. This exhibit consists of the museum as well as the exterior grounds housing units of the various minority native people. We spent a lot of time touring in, up and through some of the various houses each very unique its own way. Our guide explained each of the units, living quarters and other activities of the natives. We spend so much time on the grounds that we had a limited amount of time to view the interior.The interior museum building housed artifacts, clothing, work tools and other items used in their day to day lives. There was also a special (Nguyen) historical photography exhibit on display. There are restrooms, elevators in addition storage lockers located at the back of the museum. Open from 08.30a-5.30p, closed Monday and certain holidays. Recommended.
incite of the people in Vietnam.. very interesting place to visit. it was a pleasurably walk around this life-sized museum , with beautiful well kept gardens.

What a wonderful museum. We were not sure what to expect, but the museum contains so much to see. To see each ethnic group, is a true education into the culture and history of Vietnam. Great exhibits, beautiful artifacts.Take some time to visit this museum, inside and the outside buildings.

Interesting Museum. Interesting museum, although not for everyone. If you're interested in anthropology or ethnology (duh), don't miss it. If traditional houses, clothing and tools don't float your boat, there are plenty of things to see closer to the center of Hanoi.

Clever propaganda. I enjoyed this museum so much that I did my own research afterwards. Like some of the other museums and historical sites around Vietnam, you are shown what they want you to see. I was dismayed at how indigenous peoples have been marginalised to 'minority' status and their histories re-written to make them seem primitive. A visit to the Mỹ Sơn temples will quickly teach you that the Champa people were not merely the 'pirates' that were described by one of my tour guides.I encourage you to explore this museum, especially the garden with the indigenous/'minority' houses. Please also educate yourself (Google is your friend) so you get a less biased view.

Discovery of Vietnamese culture. This museum is really interesting, though the visit you discover about all Vietnamese minorities and understand more about their culture. During last 2000 years, the 54 ethnics built the vietnamese identity. In this museum you will visit each ethnic group one per one, discover their life and habitations. Understand why Vietnamese people thinking on a different way than other country (like the importance of family relation). The Vietnamese culture is not easy to understand for foreigners because the history of Vietnam is complicate. This museum his like a tool to allow you to know more Vietnamese people. The conception of the museum is perfectly built and allow you to understand easily all without be lost. I advice you to buy the book of the museum at the entry, because you will learn a lot and forget. Definitely worth it during your visit in Hanoi!

Amazing walk through the unseen parts of the country. Lots of exhibits from the rural areas of Vietnam - the parts which are the real Vietnam. Inside, there is lots to look at. We particularly enjoyed watching the videos and seeing local customs and traditions being performed. My 8 year old still talks and laughs about the rolling man 6 months on! By Western standards, it was a little dull for my 10yr old and 8 yr old inside as it was lots of looking, and I was sad to see other Western kids being allowed to manhandle the exhibits by their parents.Outside the building was the real highlight of the museum. There are many buildings outside to explore, which are different types of houses from different ethnic groups. A fantastic job inside of recreating how the houses would be in the rural areas, although it was a little daunting watching the kids climb up the thin ladders into the high community hall...and scary trying to climb back down! Those steps are steep!!!One of the highlights of Hanoi for us. Allow at least 3 hours.

Great museum with full size examples of hill tribe dwellings. This is a bit far out, you'll need a cab to get there from the city, but it's well worth a visit if you are interesting in understanding some of the history of the minority ethnic groups in Vietnam. Allow at least 3 hours for the visit, especially iof you want to catch one of the water puppet shows that are held in the gardens.Don't miss the carvings on the funeral house in the gardens!
very interesting. it tells all you need to know of the history. Pleasant building, even when crowded. Foresee at least 2hrs to be able to see all

Love it!. The best museum to visit in Hanoi as you will have the opportunity to do an immersion in Vietnamese culture and civilisation. Outside the museum there are a lot of Vietnamese traditional houses in their natural size (a sort of Village Museum).

Vietnam is more diverse than you think!. This museum does a great job of describing the 54 different ethnic groups. You can experience their lives, culture, homes, jobs and so much more. The grounds with the replica homes should not be missed.

Interesting and well organized museum. We went here with a tour guide, but I actually think I would have preferred to visit without a guide. The inside is well organized and has interesting exhibits about the lives and culture including dress, arts and crafts, musical instruments, cooking styles, etc. of the minority groups in Viet Nam. Outside is where the fun is: there are "mock" homes and village buildings representing some of the different minority groups. Fascinating place to explore, and there was a free water puppet show going on outside while we were there.
Do not miss. Information of all the 53 ethnic minorities in Vietnam.The real life models of the different houses that have been created in the yards. It was really interesting.
Investing & informative. I liked seeing the old style houses, some of which still exist. Learning the history of the country's different ethnic groups

Culturally informative and well organized. This museum has taken attention to the care and presentation of its exhibits.min formative,educational, colorful. Be sure to go to the gardens and the recreated buildings.
Inside museum and outdoor villages. Not all boring. Great exhibits and education. Outdoor buildings and cultures to explore. I think a not to miss experience.

Very fascinating . We had a tour guide giving us a detailed explanation of all the fascinating groups in Vietnam. Learning about the cultures and customs was very interesting. It was great how the museum also had life size huts/ houses on display around the garden because you could really grasp the way that the different people lived. I would highly recommend visiting this museum and having a local guide to help explain the diverse history about the people and the country.
Break from chaos. A greAt way to kill a couple of hours when the blonde baby needs a break from cheek pinching. Kids can climb in to different samples of houses, and run free!
Good and interesting. Quite interesting museum telling you about the many ethnic minorities in Vietnam. Good value for money.

A Different Kind of Museum. Inside the museum, you get to know more about the people and how they live. Then the real treat comes when you go outside and climb into the actual homes built by the people themselves.

You need a tour guide to make the trip interesting. Book the free guide tour with Hanoi Kids.
You can arrange the places to visit and have lunch and dinners at good restaurants often ate by locals.

Brilliant !. A must visit when in Hanoi - a complete history and information of all the 53 ethnic minorities in Vietnam so well captured and detailed out via pictures, videos and artefacts.
Do not miss out the real life models of the different houses that have been created in the yards. That was the best part.
ethnology museum. we have lot a funny thing to take picture inside ethnology.good experience to know all the history from Vietnam.
OK. We saw this as part of a tour. Our time was rushed and our guide wasn't very easy to understand. The textiles and outbuilding were the most interesting part for me.

Outside Great, Inside Ok. Set in beautiful parkland, the outside exhibits were fascinating reconstructed houses of many of Vietnam's ethnic minority peoples. There was also a water puppet show taking place.
Inside the museum itself were artefacts and reconstructions of ethnic minority ceremonies. Unfortunately there was no air-con, and it was so hot that the visit was rushed.

Very informative. It might perhaps be better with an informative tour guide. I was there on my own but the exhibits were well explained. The outdoor area, with the houses of the various Vietnamese tribes, was really fascinating.
Nice. Reminded me of the Polynesian cultural center on oahu. Interesting! Not somewhere I would have chosen on my own

Very interesting and educational. A great way to learn about all the different ethnicities that make up Vietnam. Well presented -- highly recommended if you want to learn more about the people of this beautiful country.

Worth a visit!. The indoor exhibits are pretty sparse & uninspiring, but the rebuilt ethnic houses at the back are very interesting. The variations of buildings from tribe to tribe is really worth a look.

nice museum. It would have been a better experience if we had had a better tour guide, who could explain various things to us. Doing it on your own can be exhausting. But it's very informative and enriching.
Worth a visit.. We could have spent a full day here, ( but hunger got to us ) after looking at the exhibits inside we went outside to see more of the ethnology of past and present life.

Very nice museum of Vietnam's culture. Modern preparation of Vietnam's culture with different usage of media and huge number of exhibited pieces. I also enjoyed the outside objects like the long house, where you can walk trough. I think this is even nice with children.

If you want to understand Vietnam better.... Vietnam does not consist of one people or ethnographic or linguistic group. If you want to learn more, then this is THE museum. The indoor exhibits finds a fascinating counterpart in the outdoor ones. It is one of the best laid-out museums I visited in Vietnam and one of the most interesting. It's a bit out from the centre, about a 10 - 15 minute taxi-ride, but well worth it. if you time it right, then you might even catch a short, open-air waterpuppet show.

Well worth a visit. A really good insight into the diversity of the Vietnamese people and a great museum shop! A bit far out of town but we paid 6 usd in a taxi from the old quarter and well worth the visit!

Not with kids. Came here with my 2 kids 17 and 12. The outside exhibit was interesting but the museum proper was rather boring unless you want to know in detail about the more than 30 ethnic tribes in Vietnam. To really see the whole place you need at least 2-3 hours. So visit only if you have time to spare and definitely not with kids :)

Wonderful Museum. A must-see museum, even if you are not a "museum person." Terrific overview of the country and its peoples - displays fabulously done - beautiful and vast outside displays also of home, temple, tomb, garden, sports of the Vietnamese peoples.

Insight into the ethnic groups throughout Asia. This wonderful musuem, not only explores the ethnic groups in Vietnam, but also the distribution of these peoples throughout Asia. Give yourself several hours to explore this museum
Educational. Real insight into the tribes that occupy the surrounding countryside. Great for craft lovers! Give yourself enough time to visit the outdoor space.

Interesting. Good way to learn about the 50 odd minorities that exist throughout Vietnam. Inside are typical museum style displays while outside there are several impressive life size examples of the various forms of housing particular to each minority...very interesting couple of hours.

this should be more popularly known. One of the top attractions in Hanoi. Beautifully presented, with respect for ethnic groups and very informative. I really enjoyed this visit. There is also a cafe on site where there are trainees learning the job, the food was quite good and I think it's great they are giving people these work opportunities.
Very Interesting. This museum was surprisingly interesting. The outside display of various ethnic housing was especially good.

Place to know the people, culture of Vietnam. Visiting this meseum let you learn the life, culture of the minorities of Vietnam with thier tradtional houses, dress on display. Recommeded to spend at least half a day to see this museum there are lots of things to see if you like local traditional stuff

The best museum in Hanoi - take the bus. It's a bit on the outskirts of Hanoi, but don't let that stop you from going. Getting there is easy. You could take a cab or moto, but I prefer to go around the city by bus. Just take the number 14 bus and get off at the stop "Nghia Tan" (you can always ask someone at the hotel you're staying in to write it down for you in Vietnamese and show it to the bus attendant), and the museum is a short walk away.I can really recommend getting a guide. I was fortunate enough to have my friend guide the museum for me which gave me a deeper understanding of the things on display. This was the best museum I went to in Hanoi and I hadn't gone had my Vietnamese friend not recommended it to me.

A MUST do when in Hanoi!. A MUST do when you're in Hanoi. Cost about $2-3USD to get in (adult). Three main portions to the museum (1) Vietnamese history + tribal history (2) Outdoors exploration of 'villages' and traditional homes (3) A newer Southeast Asia exhibit in the newer building next door. If you time it properly there is also a water puppet show a couple times per day (save you from the tourist trap in town). Not a lot of people went to #3 but it's free (part of the fee) and includes (at the time of writing) a great collection of art and history for the different countries in SEA. And for those who care - super clean bathrooms in the new building (just ask reception where it is).

For sure not a boring museum. You can spent hours there if you are really into ethnology and if not you can still enjoy the walk in the awesome outdoor "village" with traditional houses from all around Vietnam. If you are lucky you can watch some of the traditional arts as water puppet theater (check the museum's schedule). The tickets are really cheap, actually cheaper than most of the museums in Asia and there is much more to see.

Good experiences. I visited this place was very impressed to learn to dress Tribes in the past, which is what I do. Using the lives of people in the past. And outside the building also houses the size replica of the real. Which we can touch and hold an image I like Office down behind a puppet theater and dance under water circulate. Working day and night for the show. For which I am still surprised today that he held it together. And it remains a mystery to the tourists. Really impressed

Great museum. The best part about this place was the outside exhibits that we could climb in and see. Very interesting. It's just a little hard to get to if you're finding your way, as we were on a moto. The one way streets made it hard to navigate but worth the visit.
Visit. An interesting museum which unfortunately lacks air conditioning.It was very hot and humid in July.

Nice one. 125K taxi ride from the Old Quarter. Essentially 3 separate museums. Open air tribal houses recently built by a number of varying tribes with details about each of them. You can go in or climb up depending on the house. There is also a Southeast Asian building on the right as you enter the grounds with mostly handicrafts of SE Asian peoples

Lots of Info Especially about the Hill People. Very interesting! Lots of info about indigenous hill people including native dress and costumes. There is a puppet theater and outdoor exhibits of various housing structures.
Enlightening visit, well worth doing if you are genuinely interested in the country. Spent a couple hours here with a guide. Very interesting, loads to see and study. It is air conditioned.

Interesting and well management Museum. The Museum is about 7km from downtown Hanoi, getting there by taxi is about 6 usd. Entrance fee is only 2usd (40.000 VND) per person. You are able to explore the culture of 53 ethnic group living all over Vietnam. With very nice presentation and clear instroduction in Vietnamese, English and French, you can just visit the Museum without guide. There are also many video clip about life of ethnic groups Vietnam.This museum is really worth to visit

Worth a Visit. Didn't know that there were so many diverse ethnic groups in Vietnam. I think it was 54 or so? Anyhow this museum gives a good overview of some of the different lifestyles and cultural differences in the country. We were lucky to have a Hanoi Free Tour Guide with us and she brought some more life to the place with a range of information.

Wealth of information. I was very interested in the history of the tribal villages in the north because I was heading to Sapa from Hanoi. The exhibitions were very well mounted and informative. It was a very worthwhile experience.
Nice half day trip. Good overview on the multi-culturality of the country. Not amazing, but not bad either. Worth doing for half a day for sure.

Excellent collection of the cultures and their way of life of the tribes living in Vietnam. If you would like to understand more about the cultures, traditions and habitats of the different tribes in Vietnam, this is a must go museum. It has an excellent and wide collections. They even have miniature and built to size houses of the mountainous tribes.

Outstanding Vietnamese architecture & culture. Very informative with incredible feat of architecture & a blend of exquisite Vietnamese handicraft...excellent collection of antique photos and display showing the history of Vietnam.

A superb museum. This is a really good introduction to the ethnic mosaic of Vietnam. Clear descriptions, maps and signage make an interesting and understandable museum. The outdoor buildings are well done if slightly twee.

Gives a good foundation before touring the country!. Well worth the cab ride and the entry fee. We were here on a Sunday and the puppet show was a lot of fun to see, despite the language barrier. It was not crowded. Climbing in and out of the different ethic homes, rebuilt on the grounds by the ethic groups was a highlight! We got a good understanding of the people of VietNam before our bicycle tour (thru VBT) of the country.

Entertaining for kids. We visited as part of a Hanoi Kids tour. The place is full of interesting displays of the different cultures and ethnic groups that make up vietnam, but our kids (5yo & 3yo) especially liked the recreated villages outside. Took us a few hours to get around, the kids didn't want to leave and could have played outside longer.

Very interesting and well presented museum. The 2 storey building provides a great insight into the ethnic tribes throughout Vietnam. The written info gives detail and the exhibitions provide a visual of life in the country, very well presented. A number of houses have been gathered in the garden and offer open access to see how the people lived in various parts of the country

Nice place for walking around. The museum was built in a wide area where they plant a lot of trees around.
It is a good choice for children playing.
Also the exhibits volume is large and in wide range from 64 ethnic groups of Vietnam.
There they even built the traditional buildings which look very nice and worth to explore.

Amazing. Informative about Vietnamese cultures
Loved the rebuilt structures in grounds
Taxi driver got lost as out in suburbs but not a problem
Well worth the fare

Very interesting. We opted to visit this instead of the History Museum and I would say it was a good choice. A lot to be learned here. Allow a couple of hours to visit inside and out The museum has 2 floors with some lovely authentic displays which give a good idea of different Vietnamese culturesDont miss the Discovery room-fun and educational activities There is also a book shop and a museum shop and a nice little cafe/bar in the grounds.

Great museum. 125K taxi ride from the Old Quarter. Essentially 3 separate museums. Open air tribal houses recently built by a number of varying tribes with details about each of them. You can go in or climb up depending on the house. There is also a Southeast Asian building on the right as you enter the grounds with mostly handicrafts of SE Asian peoples. Finally, there is the large museum of ethnology which details information, customs, and linguistics of the very large number of Vietnamese tribes. Come on Saturdays or Sundays when there are water puppet performances throughout the day. Our favorite museum in Hanoi!

Vietnam Ethnic houses. This museum housed the culture and way of life of the difffent ethnic groups that made up the population of Vietnam. A full scale ethnic houses and dwellings were also on display in the compound of the museum complex.

Thumbs up for the garden. There is a lot of interesting things to see and read (in Vietnamese, French and English). I loved the garden with reproduction of houses of different people living in Vietnam.

A Must Visit.. The Museum Has Indoor and Outdoor. Lots Of Information And Knowledge. I Believe This Is The Great Place iF You Wanna Get To Know More About Ethnology. This Place Has Everything Information You Would Ever Need. Outside Museum is More Interesting. I Enjoyed The Visit So Much. Would Definitely Be Back!
Interesting museum. well set out, interesting exhibitions. The reconstructions of the different ethnic groups houses and funeral chambers in the grounds are a highlight

lnteresting insight into real Vietnam.. Really worth a taxi ride from Hanoi. Great insight into house building, and general ethnic minorities. l especially love the textiles. Make sure you climb up the very steep ladders into the houses. Great cultural experience.

Worth an afternoon. Did not take tours into countryside, such as Sapa, but was able to learn a lot about various tribes and ethnic groups in Vietnam at the museum.
Well laid out with English signs, and small enough to visit in 2-3 hours.
sonye1

Worth a visit. Very nice museum, showing different cultures of Vietnam. Very well laid out with monitors that show rituals, burials, and clothe making etc. Outside the museum, in the back are models of actual homes from different cultures of Vietnam. You can walk inside and see how different cultures live.
Must visit. The in-situ houses alone are worth the cab ride to this museum. Don't leave Hanoi without visiting this museum.

Second visit added new depth. This was my second visit, mainly to attend an annual Ethnic Craft Day. It seemed as though most if not all of the 54 Ethnic groups were represented in some way. I was recommended and purchased a really interesting book at the Museum Book Shop, it is called 'Wandering Through Vietnamese Culture" by Huu Ngoc a wonderful read (of over 1250 pages). I wish I had found it 5 years ago. I had a great meal at the Café and another look around the entire Museum. Un fortunately this time I was short of time. You need a few hours to get the best out of outside alone.
Interesting. In 30 minutes we could understand the generalities of Vietnam's ethnology. Good way to start a tour through the country.
Good. Would have liked an audio guide in English. Otherwise very well presented and informative. About 130,000dong cab ride from old quarter.
