Very interesting. Great overview of the ethnology of the country. As someone with very little knowledge of Vietnam before this trip, this museum provided an interesting and informative overview.

Everything you need to learn about Vietnam. The museum is well done. Not big but contained so much information. It was two stories and an outdoor area. When we were there they had a water puppet show. Something I didn't think we'd have time to see so it was a pleasant surprise. If you have a couple of hours, I'd highly recommend stopping in to see and learn about Vietnam.
Background knowledge. I loved the information - great to have prior to Sapa visit. Interesting although a little plastic. Enjoyed the visit
Worth a dip into the past. Well laid out museum with the different groups of Vietnamese tribes and their wares on display. We spent a couple of hours here and could have spent more time.

Worth a visit but can be crowded. I enjoyed this museum less than the Women's Museum because some of the rooms were poorly lit, display signs were difficult to read with the crowds and some of the labels not particularly informative. "This is an axe." We went as part of a small group tour- 6 of us, but the visit felt rushed and the museum was crowded in the afternoon. Go on your own, perhaps first thing in the morning and take your time. This museum is a good place to get an introduction to Vietnam's cultural and linguistic diversity.

Beautifully presented museum with lots of artefacts. This museum is extensive and has both indoor and outdoor exhibits. The outdoor exhibits consist of various styles of Vietnamese architecture from around Vietnam.
Well worth a vist. It was excellent, but do allow a few hours, as there's much to see, both inside and out. You can get there easily on a local bus - very cheap.

Small but well presented. The museum has a range of fascinating ethnographic displays with really interesting reconstructed houses from selected ethnic groups within the grounds. As you can see from the attached photo, school groups abound and can make it a bit chaotic at times. More of a problem are certain tour operators who have electronic microphones to blast their manic spiel to the most disinterested stragglers in their group (and unfortunately to anyone else within a 100 meter radius).Suggestion to the museum management - get rid of the tour operators with megaphones!
Very interesting. It was fascinating to learn about all the different ethnicities that are present in Vietnam. The pictures and displays were pretty good.

Best museum in Hanoi. I loved this museum! I learned much about all of Vietnam's ethnic groups from the museum inside and enjoyed seeing the full size homes representative of the style used by many different tribes. It is rather far out of town but is not to be missed!

Informative & interesting. The museum offers a wide range exhibits and information about the different tribes in Vietnam. Outstanding was the outdoor exhibits which include life-size houses of the tribes.
Worth a visit. We went with our guide so he was able to explain everything. Interesting to see life across Vietnam - worth a visit

Interesting and Inspirational. I like the displays. Each houses and structures exhibited have corresponding write-ups that are written in Vietnamese, French (I guess?), and English. Inside the museum building (which we almost did not get to see because we thought it was another office building like the first building we entered), they have exhibits for different tribal costumes, religious paraphernalias, and even a house, with accompanying videos reenacting some facts about the tribes where those stuffs belong to. I like those. I wish my country has a similar museum devoted to our own tribes.If I have to gripe about something it would be about the large wooden map you will encounter near the entrance. It is difficult to read. I had no idea how to interpret it and I cannot exactly pinpoint where we are on it. It has no signs of where we should begin and where we should go next. I guess it would have helped to get a guide but we didn't so we were a bit lost sometimes and we just followed a troop of kindergartens with their teachers.

Closed on Mondays. This review is quite late. We visited the Vietnam Museum of Ethnology to see the model houses in the different regions of Vietnam but unfortunately they were closed during Monday. Much as we wanted to come back we have an early flight to catch the following day.

Great museum. Don't forget to get your free coffee! . My husband and I enjoyed this museum. It was worth the bus ride there. It is quite extensive and a lot of effort has been made to ensure visitors enjoy their time there. The outdoor traditional huts are quite fascinating and inside there is a lot of information about the tribes of indochina. Don't forget to visit the coffee shop where you get a free coffee with every 2 tickets!

Vietnam Museum Ethnology - Interesting place highly recommend. Vietnam (Hanoi) is not famous for museum like France (Paris) or Italy, but Vietnam Museum Ethnology is one of the most interesting museum in Hanoi. It is attractive not only the foreigners, even Vietnamese people who almost don't like museum :)Everything is displayed and explained very well, both of the indoor part and open-air Exhibition.And sometime Handicraft Bazaar is opened there, it is very interesting.One place should experience in Hanoi.
A must see. Excellent museum. Lots of interest (and not too much to get bored!) and fabulous traditional houses in the gardens. Definitely go there.

Very informative. A great display of different peoples,artifacts and photography related to the inhabitants of the past in the area; a very pleasant athmosphere inside and out. In every room a sample illustrating with beautiful replicas of old houses, furniture, tools and art the way of life for this people.

An excellent museum.. We went here as part of an organised tour. The museum has two parts; an indoor area and garden. The indoor part takes you on a trip past all ethnic groups and their way of life in well organised and perfectly laid out exhibition. The museum shows the way of life, traditions and housing. Everything is very well explained in english. Outside you can find a garden where typical houses for all ethnic groups are rebuild. From what we have heard the museum hired people from the specific ethnic groups to build the houses on site using original building materials. As such they are replica's but very close to the original houses. You can enter all of them.We only had about 2 hours to visit which was too short in my opinion. I think you should spend at least 4 hours but it is easy to cover the whole day if you go slowly. The museum has a restaurant in the garden if you get hungry.

Interesting. Given the complicated history of Vietnam and it's people, this museum does a great job of presenting it to you. I would suggest doing it with a guide if you can, but otherwise allow plenty of time for reading.

A must when you are in Hanoi!. Worth the cab ride - marvelous description of different tribes that make up this country: customs, crafts, housing, dress. The outdoor architectural exhibits are fascinating. The restaurant is not to be missed. Run by an organization that trains students for the hospitality industry, the food is excellent and the prices super reasonable.

Interesting well laid out museum. We visited this museum while on a Gate 1 tour of Vietnam. It presents a great overview of the different ethnic groups in Vietnam. The outside part of the museum has several typical houses from a variety of groups that you can go into. They also sometimes have a water puppet presentation,outside as well. The gift shop is very nice and prices are good.
Excellent Ethnology Museum. Excellent and interesting. Very well curated. Go to Ethnology Museum BEFORE heading to Sapa and tribal areas in Northwest Vietnam.

Very interesting and informative. It was a good 2-3 hrs spent in this interesting museum definitely worth a visit. Wonderful insights in the culture of Vietnam. Very informative and educational. Large area n good exhibition.

Compact view of the country and roots. Full scale reproduction of each cultures native environment, house, lifestile. Spend a day. All exhibits are hands on and walk through, not walk by. Some of the climbs up into and through the dwellings are a bit strenuous. Don't miss the erotic primitive exhibit.

A good afternoon out. Attractions in Hanoi area little thin on the ground, but this proved to be surprising good.
In the end we spent over 4 hours here and learnt a lot about the different clans in Vietnam, and how they lived. The housing displays outside were particularly interesting, and we were lucky to catch a water puppet show.

Educational. I like it that they preserve their cultural heritage. This place is a great place to learn and to understand Vietnamese culture.
A great place to bring children

Very interesting. This is very good place to learn about tribes, ethnics and culture in Vietnam through pictures, artifacts or mock ups. The information is very detailed and realistic. If you take time to read every single information board it may take a day to finish it.
Ethnographic accounts of minority life. An impressive collection of Vietnamese minority group artefacts, information and exhibits. Very well curated. Probably too much to see in just one visit.

Quite interesting. We went to this museum with a Hanoikids Tour, interesting to see customs, housing and clothing of all the different ethnic groups in Vietnam. There is also a small rustic water puppet show, but nowhere near to the standard of the one in the theatre in centre of Hanoi. Good way to spend the afternoon, there is a lot to see.

Some Insights into Vietnam. Definitely worth a visit to get an appreciation of how the various ethnic groups in Vietnam lived and still live today in parts of the country. We stayed for the water puppet show which was okay.

lots of information. great museum. there was lots of information. first the inside part and after that the inside part. I felt like a child again. I loved all the different customs. but if it would be a bit more interactive it would have been perfect.

A must see!. Thoroughly enjoyed my visit. My understanding of the Vietnamese people has increased immensely. The museum consists of indoor exhibits over 2/3 floors and an outside space with houses built by ethnic people. I would pay way more than the 40,000vnd entrance fee for the visit. Plus there are free water puppet shows at certainly times at the weekends - not the standard you get from proper performances I suppose but I can tick the box of seeing a water puppet show. For the ethnic houses - they are so many of them. You can enter most of them to see what there living conditions are like. I was very very impressed to see that they could build such waterproof houses in a matter of weeks. Inside each house they play videos of how the museum got the ethnic people to actually come to Hanoi to build the houses and the process of the houses being built. An eye opening experience and the highlight of my trip. Please go - it's about 100,000 taxi ride from the old quarter and well worth a visit.
great for visit. They have outside exhibition and inside exhibition. I like outside exhibition, esp Bhana house and Long house. Very relaxed

The museum flagship. The "old" part, covering Viet Nam is impressive, the new building covering all of South East Asia is not completed but looks very promising and the open air part with buildings from the different minority regions is a must. Take your time, this institution should be enjoyed in small portions at the time.

A good choice. You will learn lots of Viet story. There are houses full size you can visit. Inside the Museum there are various explanations of how the Viets are divided as tribals and so...Very interesting place to go - don't miss it!

Vietnams history made interesting . The ethnology museum is a great way to learn about vietnam and its culture in a visual and aesthetically pleasing way.It's has re created the rooms and houses that would have been traditional to vietnam. You can climb up the stairs to each one (remember to take your shoes off- as they will tell you off) and re live each type of house. The site is humongous so leave at least half a day. It's definitely worth a visit. The restaurant however is not so great- massive wasps nest is rather distracting!

Nice museum. This museum has both indoor and outdoor areas. It is quite nice to walk around for a few hours. When it is hot outside, you can go inside. You will learn about different ethnics and their culture in Vietnam.
To know about Vietnam in detail. The outdoor is better than the inner museum, you have to look for it by yourself due to one will be there to assist you. Great place to take pictures outdoor.

all rolled into one. beautiful museum with an indoor part and a large outdoor area. Very kid friendly as you are allowed to touch many objects. Inside you can find artefacts, clothing and customs of every minority you can find in Vietnam (54 groups). Outside you can look inside the different houses and get a feel for the life they lead.

Worth a visit. It is definitely worth taking the time to visit. I found the houses on display on the outside of the museum of most interest. The visit here was part of a tour and the only downside was the water puppet show. I wandered off and had a look around on my own while this was happening
Good place for tourist. Many tradition thing of Vietnam you will see such as ethnic house, culture and many funitures from ethnic people...
Open Air Museum. Great to be able to see these old buildings reconstructed here. And to have the life styles explained by our guide. The indoor part is good, too.

Good overview of Viet culture. With over 50 ethnic minority groups in the country it was difficult for this museum to give enough coverage of the distinctions. However they did pretty well. The traditional buildings erected in the gardens were quite interesting.

Very Interesting. The Museum of Ethnology was very interesting! We didn't know that there were so many different Ethnic groups in Vietnam.The kids especially enjoyed the outside displace of life size traditional houses which we were about to go inside and look around.There were also a couple of examples of children's games/toys in the outside area - which the kids loved playing on.

A great place for both Vietnamese and foreigners to explore. The museum provided me and my foreign students a great experience. With the help of 2 Hanoikids members, we learn so many fun facts about different ethnic groups in Vietnam and were particularly impressed by the outside houses and water puppet show. As a Vietnamese, I am even surprised with so many great things I got to know here.I'd definitely come back next year with another group of exchange students

Wonderful museum a little out from the center of town. this museum is perfect for a half day tour. It is open airy,and does not have an overpowering number of displays. Half of the museum are the buildings outside. Only thing to be wary of...some of the videos show animal sacrifices that are pretty hard to watch!!

One of the best museums of its type. Displays both inside and out were well curated with maps to show the regions where the different tribes live, descriptions in Vietnamese, English and French. Very good cafe on site run as part of a school to train disadvantaged young people. Only downside was that in some places the lighting was dim and it was difficult to read the information beside the displays.
Worthwhile. If interested in the tribal area of the North like Sapa,and other areas, this is a must see. Very well presented.
Interesting!. Interesting museum showing the crafts and the way of life of some of the minority ethnic groups of Vietnam. The textiles are extremely beautiful.
interesting. Enough to keep you interested without being bored. Highlights are the photo exhibition and the tribal huts out back

Life-sized dwellings to explore - highly recommended!. Besides the humid environment there really isn't anything negative to say about this wonderfully informative and interesting cultural establishment. The life-sized dwellings that have been built in the grounds of the museum were definitely a highlight and I loved being able to climb up and explore their intricate beauty. I also enjoyed the water puppet show and exhibitions that gave me a real taste of ethnic minorities in Vietnam. A must if you're in Hanoi!

A great Museum for kids!. We took our kids there (whom we adopted from Vietnam 12 & 15 years ago) and it was a great museum for their age to see things of their past culture. There were several videos showing things like how to make the Vietnamese hat, how a Vietnamese funeral is conducted, how they made traditional clothing and dyed their material, and the background to different traditional ceremonies. It's not a greatly in-depth museum and it doesn't take long to go through it, but for our kids, it was perfect for learning some culture in an interesting way.

Great place to know more about culture. Im not keen on visiting museums but the Vietnam of Ethnology was very interesting even your are Vietnamese. My highlight of this place is some real house of ethnic minority outdoor
Highly recommend it if you want to know more about Vietnam

A brief overview of the ethnic diversity of the Vietnamese people. This is an easy to navigate museum that is worth a visit but not on the must do list. It isn't information overload and should only take about 30 minutes to walk through and absorb the information through visual displays. I was expecting a little more in depth information and would have liked to have been told more about the history and the modern day lives of these ethnic minorities through videos. Maybe our guide could have told us more but he didn't seem to have much knowledge except broad outlines.
Eye opening. The Vietnam Museum of Ethnology was fascinating and highlighted the diversity of the people. It was bright and colourful and would be interesting for people of all ages.

Give yourself plenty of time. Our guide informed us that the bulk of this visit here would be outside. It was! Houses/abodes/huts were purchased from indigenous, minorities, dis- then re-assembled on site. The variety of design, embellishment, materials was amazing. We had an excellent guide - I'm not sure what is offered to those poking about on their own. I would imagine that the first stop would be inside the museum itself.After our tour guide left us to our own devices we headed inside to do a quick exploration. The textiles and native dress were fascinating as were the tools and instruments. This place makes the more remote and exotic areas of Vietnam come alive.

Amazing place. Large museum showing information on the tribes of Vietnam. The highlight was the outdoors where there were full size tribal houses which you could climb up into, a great day and well worth a visit.
Worth seeing. Could spend quite a bit of time here. So much to see and do. Very interactive. Great for all ages. Lovely grounds and water puppet shows in the afternoon
like "little vietnam" plus plus. slightly out of centre, but well-connected, this is a interesting site to learn about the country's diversity and history
Museum. Great to know more about the people. Make sure you have enough time to absorb everything there is to see.

Very interesting. We were lucky to have some local girls guide us through the complex explaining the set up. There are several houses typical of different ethnical groups constructed on the site and you are able to go inside to see how the people lived. The first few you have to take your shoes off so it's better to wear sandals. There is a small entrance fee. We enjoyed it. There is a cafe on site where we enjoyed ice creams at the end of our visit.

museum of ethnology. We went here on a day tour of hanoi with our tour guide alice. It was a very big place, as well as looking in the museum itself , there is lots to see outside the building itself. Going with a guide was the best way to see it as everything was explained to us as we went. Small entrance fee

Spend an Hour. Well worth the time to learn about the 54 different ethnic groups here in Vietnam and to see some artifacts. Be sure to go out to the garden area where the exhibits continue and visit the long house and the men's house and other displays.

Interesting outdoor exhibit and water puppet show. Spent most of the time outdoor. Museum bought the houses from the different ethnic groups, they look authentic. You can enter the exhibits, brief explanations were displayed. Indoor part was less exciting for me. Be sure to catch the free water puppet show outside (twice a day i think, do check timings). Am glad i saw it here instead of paying for one at a theatre.Overall had a good time

Coolture!. I went on the Hanoi City Tour and visited the Ethnology Museum before lunch. It was almost like the same boring museum tour except that the Vietnamese people and culture was so interestingly showcased. The different costumes, wares, tools, architecture of all the tribes were represented. The 2 highlights for me were the old pictures (before the influx of visitors) of remote tribes and the lifesize houses just outside. It was awesome as you could actually climb in and explore the huge traditional buildings. Excellent!

Pleasant. Interesting to see how people lived, their culture etc, this is an outside museum, wear a hat and comfy shoes and a bottle of water. There us a traditional water puppet theatre on every day. Close to hotel did not take long yo get there.

Hands on information. This museum is in two parts. The first is more like a traditional museum housed in an old colonial building. There's lots if information here but the museum suddenly because better when you step outside and see the real houses of the different tribes of Vietnam. You are free to explore these houses, climbing the steps to the communal Ianding or showing respect for the tribal burial chamber. A fantastic place to visit.
Really funny !. When you are in this city, you should visit this place. It is around 10km from the Older Quarter.It is so interesting ! Try it !

Educational.. Liked looking at the range of houses in the Museum grounds, built by the different ethnic groups , weather up on stilts, or the clay walled houses. Also the displays in doors , showing the different crafts and arts.

worth visit. A must visit place when you're in the city. It's quite far from the Old Quarter but here you can learn about Vietnamese cultures. On the backyard, you can also experience the traditional houses from every ethnic of this country. It really is a "Vietnam in 1 day" experience. Don't forget to have a look at the building next to the museum where they have collection of traditional wave cloths from South East Asia countries
A delightful day spent at this museum. This museum was so interesting , we spent many hours there learning about the amazing history of the fascinating people of Vietnam.

Very good museum. Great explanations in different languages, works of art very well presented, good museology, free water puppet show on week end so you don't have to pay for the one in central hanoi, wonderful vietnamese houses in the parc. Definitely worth it, even though a bit far away from the center (a cheap local bus takes you nearby)

An Interesting trip to the Vietnam Museum of Ethnology, Hanoi. In August 2014 during our tour of Vietnam, Cambodia and Laos with the excellent company Indochina Pioneer my wife and I visited the Museum of Ethnology in Hanoi. For anyone interested in the history of the people of Vietnam the museum gives a very comprehensive description of the ethnic groups and their customs. One of the advantages of doing a visit with Indochina Pioneer was the in depth knowledge that our guide had of his country and ethnic groups making the visit all the more rewarding.

A great place. A great place to explore if you have a history/ethnology-geek inside. The exhibitions are really great and informative - and its great to get a break from the otherwise very propagandist museums around the city - not a bad thing as it is how it is in this country, but a break from it is still nice. The houses are great and a walk through the museum is something that you can spend a lot of time enjoying.

Interesting museum. Good to go here when you need a break from the old town. Bit far though, take a taxi. Entrance is cheap, about 40000 VND. A tour guide will help you to understand the differences between the single ethnic groups better.
Fantastic experience.. I learnt a lot about the different ethnic groups in Vietnam. The cultures of each group were quite different from eachother. Fascinating!

worth a visit and do lunch there. This museum was informative and well set out with individual houses out the back which show how the different ethnic groups lived. There is training restaurant in the grounds which was reasonable able good food.
Very interesting. Loved the outside section with all the old buildings and were fortunate to catch the water puppets show which is only performed on Saturday and Sunday.

It was a good day trhere!. Far from the central of Hanoi Old Quarter but it is easy to get there by taxi or Local Bus. Inside have alot of histories about their local people which you should come and see!

Lots to see. We visited before spending time staying in Homestays to try to develop an understanding of Vietnam's tribal groups. The museum has so much to see but helps you to understand how diverse the history and people of Vietnam are

Interesting museum. You can get a better sense of the ethnic diversity in the region. See the photo exhibition from anthropologists who were here when Vietname was still colonized by the French, learn about the diverse languages, clothing, etc of the more than 100 minorities present in Vietnam.

Great place for kids to let off steam. With an amazing restaurant and coffee shop on the grounds, we all had an amazing visit. After exploring the museum inside, we could walk through all the traditional Vietnamese houses. The kids created an imaginative village and we left them to continue their game while we settled down for lunch! Very informative and interactive.

comprehensive look at vietnamese tribal life.... visited the museum after spending a week in north Vietnam living / visiting with several hill tribes: it proved a coda to week of touring, tying the first hand experience together and filling in any 'blanks' I might have missed along the way... artifacts -- antigue water puppets, gongs -- beautifully displayed. an excellent way to spend two + hours in Hanoi!!
Interesting museum.. Vietnam has 54 different ethical groups. This museum gives an idea about the diversity and ritchness of the Vietnamese culture and traditions. It is a must see in Hanoi.

Excellent story of the Vietnamese people. I really liked this museum despite the difficulty getting to it. Ask your guesthouse to help arrange a taxi so you do not get ripped off. The best part are the full-scale models of traditional houses (approx. 10) on the grounds.

Worth a visit!. A short taxi ride from Hanoi central but worth the visit. It demonstrates the diversity of the people of Vietnam and their various lifestyles in one place. A quiet haven away from the bustle of Hanoi.
Interesting and informative. The number of different ethnic groups that comprise Vietnam was really surprising and the exhibits are well done. Worth spending an hour to see.

Look behind you!. Or at least, look behind the main building when you've finished touring it (one hour max) - there are lots of typical reconstructed village houses from different parts of Vietnam in the gardens, and a small lake where your can see a water puppets show. Worth seeing.

Very good perspective on the diversity of Vietnam. I was not aware that Vietnam had so many minority groups. The museum was a very nice introduction to the diversity of Vietnam's people. The outdoor exhibits provide a great glimpse of the housing of some of the minorities.

Wonderful museum. My husband and I thoroughly enjoyed this museum and it made us excited to return to Vietnam to explore more remote areas in future. We especially enjoyed the exhibits of traditional clothing and the different architecture of the houses of the various tribes. Well worth the visit!

Very interesting. Vietnam is home to over 50 different ethnic tribes and this museum is a showcase for their cultures and lifestyles. We found it very worthwhile, indoors and out. The grounds contain examples of different housing structures, as well as a demonstration of the water puppets. Better to see this here than going to the show.

Best museum in Hanoi. This museum is definitely worth the taxi journey out! From the old quarter it cost us about 150,000 VND to get there by taxi, which really isn't much at all. Considering how cheap it is to get in it's worth it.The museum has really interesting displays detailing various periods of Vietnamese culture (with lots of displays like clothing or tools that Vietnamese people have used throughout history).The highlight is certainly the old buildings outside though - you can go inside all of them which is really very cool. An eye opener for me and very glad I spent 2-3 hours there!

Static and staid. A popular destination for tourists, especially with historic Vietnamese wooden houses out the back, the museum wasn't that interesting to me. However, at only $2 for entry, how can you go wrong?
Museum. Lots of interesting artefacts and the displays were easy to follow learnt a lot about the different villages

Excellent way to spend some time. A great place to learn more about the minority groups that make up Vietnam. Well laid out with clearly presented information in three languages. The outdoor displays are very good. Saw a free water puppet show as it is a Sunday. About 20 mins from Old Quarter.

Traditional museum experience. Very informative and interesting if one likes history, as I do. Loads of artifacts and interesting background info on vietnamese ethnic variety. Also in English. Easy to access by local bus from Hoan Kiem Lake 7000 Dong per Person.

Worth the visit. This was surprisingly interesting and filled a lot of gaps in out Vietnam knowledge. I did not realise how diverse the Vietnamese people were until we went there. Some amazing building exhibits outside. If you have time, plan a trip here.

vietnam's ethnology. it is good to see and learn about vietnam's ethnic history.
some of the photographs reminded me of those seen in Andaman Nicobar islands.
nicely displayed,explanation/legends good and clear.
I learnt so much. This museum taught me so much about the people of Vietnam. The displays were well written in English and French and the museum was set out well.

Museum is a bit hard to follow the 54 ethnic groups of Vietnam but the example housing outside is fascinating. The museum is worth a visit and has English explanations. The example housing on the grounds that allow you to visualize how they live is the most interesting. Climb into the homes for its full effect.

Great way to learn about Vietnam. Its Vietnam in one building. Spend some time here and learn about the ethnic groups of this country and how different they are. It has some great displays and is a must to learn about this land and its people. Well worth a few hours and make sure you look at the exhibits in the grounds.

Well worthwhile. The museum is large and we did not have time to do it justice, however I can recommend it fully. The Vietnamese are proud of their 54 ethnic minorities and this museum shows off the different cultures, building styles and customs of some of these tribes. The videos are excellent, showing how various crafts are made, although sadly we could not watch them all. It is fabulous that the buildings in the extensive grounds are real houses with family histories that have been dismantled and re-built in the museum grounds. The gardens are lovely and any shade and breeze is a bonus! It is shoes off in most houses, so I confess we were too hot and tired to cope with that more than a couple of times! Age is showing...

A must-see.. An impressive museum in Hanoi which gave me a bunch of interesting information about different ethnic groups in Vietnam. Furthermore, it also gave me an overview of Vietnamese culture.
In conclusion, a must-see museum that help traveler understand more about local culture.

Knowledge of the ethics. Great knowledge of the ethnics with a water puppet theater.
Would be better if there are real ethnic ppl with their dresses is visible physically.
Great. The museum teaches you about all different ethnic groups in vietnam, really nice. It is a bit out of the centre but it is worth the bus/taxi ride

Very great museum. The museum is a bit far from the city center, but it definetely worth it! Plus it's a great escape from the bustling Hanoi! I'm usualy not a big fan of museum, but must say that this one is fantastic. I especially loved the photo exhibition in the end. Great job of research in there. Loved it <3

Mini-tour of the whole country.... Away from the city center, but worth it. The grounds feature buildings from ethnic groups around the whole country - almost a tour of the entire Vietnam in one place. Don't miss the brand new SE Asian museum building. Arrange a car service from your hotel to avoid extra meter run up by taxis...

Really helps to understand Vietnam and its diversity. As a Vietnam tourist, you will have heard it many times: There are 54 ethnic groups living in Vietnam. However, the place that will actually show you the incredible diversity of Vietnam's people that number stands for, is the Vietnam Museum of Ethnology. If you can spare one to three hours - depending on where you stay in Hanoi - and you are interested in Vietnam´s rich culture, a visit to the museum is well worth not only your time, but your kids' time as well. I took my 9 and 12 year old sons and they enjoyed the visit too. But be prepared: It's huge and it can be quite hot and humid!Basically the complex consists of two areas - an exhibition building and an outdoor exhibition park. Indoors you'll find characterisitic of each ethnic group from colourful costumes, furnitures, tools, weapons and artifacts to photos and videos. The outdoors lives from authentic houses typical for the different groups, some donated by former owners and transported to Hanoi, and a Water Puppet Theatre.If you are taking kids, the latter is quite entertaining for them, so make sure you ask about performance times. Kids will certainly enjoy exploring the houses too, like climbing up some unusual, narrrow and steep stairs. Mine did and also enjoyed the indoor videos. However, having been to quite a lot of museums, they would have appreciated a more kids-interactive exhibition. Having said that, their "verdict" for the museum was 'very good'. They learned heaps about Vietnam and its people.Probably the best way to make the most of your visit is to get a guide, so you can take in information while you are looking at the exhibition instead of spending a lot of time reading all the information signs. A plus is the big space of the museum. It does not feel overloaded. A great way to "debrief" is having some yummy iced coffee or tea or food in the museum's café close to the exit before you leave.
Interesting. Great insight into the peoples of Vietnam.Take a fan and water as there's no air-con.Gardens have traditiional houses and a training coffee shop,cheap coffee!

Museum of Ethnology. It was a nice experiences to visit this museum in Hanoi. People can have a good idea about the history and culture of Vietnam through visit this place. Particularly those ethnic houses were really unique. I would recommend everyone to go there who will visit Hanoi, a must go place for those who are very interested about history & culture.

Fantastic exhibitions, a must-see for any visit to Hanoi!. This is probably the best museum I have ever visited.  The combination of still exhibits of clothing, instruments, puppets, weapons and other artefacts, and a beautiful photographic exhibition, alongside the rather awesome reconstructed dwellings means that the experience is very diverse and has a great element of interaction. It's fascinating to see how these houses, community buildings and tombs are made and feels like quite an honour to be able to look through them all. It's important to leave yourself a good 3 hours or so to go through them all. There are 2 cafés, but the one on the left when you're heading into the museum is by far the better one. It got resounding votes of success from my 12 year old and the others I visited with, so definitely take the family. It's super cheap to get in (only 40 000 VND), and well worth it.
Interesting - But may need a tour guide. Really interesting to see the culture - most of the museum is outdoors and shows the way of life over the generations.

Great ways to see all Vietnam's tribal groups. Loved the displays of artefacts and info on all the 54 ? groups across Vietnam. Then culminating with an outdoor tour of numerous family homes / structures. Made it a real experience to visualise the family lifestyles across the various groups.
To finish with Coffee in new Helios cafe near exit - wonderful.
Top class presentation. We were impressed by the high quality of ALL exhibits. Very extensive museum which provided an enlightening historical perspective of Vietnam. Highly recommend a visit.

Well organized museum of ethnic groups in Vietnam. There are 3 sections, one of which is outside. The outside area has homes built in the styles that different ethnic groups have. Inside are not only clothing, musical instruments, etc., but also videos of events that these ethnic groups celebrate. Gives a good overview of groups that may tourists may not see.

Must-See in Vietnam. This national museum is a microcosm of what Vietnam is.
The open museum is a must-see, but make sure to bring umbrella to protect you from the scorching heat of the sun or from the rain.
Worth the taxi out of city center. A snapshot of the many different cultures in Vietnam - their cultures, houses, clothing. We didn't much time but really glad we made the effort!
Interesting. Well designed, and comprehensive study of vietnams breadth of tribal communities. Quite interesting.

All of Vietnam in one place. The museum inside has alot to see but not very well explained. The experience is to go outside and see all the houses from the different areas of Vietnam and see how they live.
Rain!!. Getting caught in the open air museum when typhoon swept in and the rain pelted down for 20 minutes - umbrellas useless. Impressive museum exhibits internally and externally.

The most interesting museum in Hanoi. I visit this museum many times and surely will come back. It's not only informative but also very interesting. Good place for both children and adult. As its name indicates, it is dedicated to the multitude of ethnic groups making up the country. It indeed presents the 54 ethnic groups living on the Vietnamese territory.I saw many many traditional costumes, musical instruments, jewellery and weapons along with impressive outdoor exhibits all combine to provide many illustrations of the traditions and customs of all these peoples. You can also meet with an expert from the museum to lend your visit another dimension. If luckily, you can have a waterpuppet show for free in the museum's garden (nearby Kinh's traditional house). I forgot the schedule, but you can easily check with the museum in advance.There are many activities and evens held to attract tourists, especially children (for example full moon festival, kite making, pottery making, Dong Ho painting making...). Almost is free. I luckily took part in Dong Ho painting making and had chance to see water puppet show at noon, and it was great experience.I highly recommend tourists to visit this museum to understand about Vietnamese culture in general. Should spend at least half day to explore this amazing museum :)

Nice experience. I was there with my 4-year-old-son and it was his first museum. he was excited especially of garden part where there was many vietnamese houses of all ethnic groups of Vietnam. We could explore it inside. The Museum is very nice for older, many information supported by films, colorfull expositions, photo galery.
wonderful. great place, learn about the minorities of Vietnam- be sure to go outside and see reconstructed village buildings - spend as much time as possible,

Unique museum!!!. In my opinion, this is a great museum, gives visitors the basic visualization and accuracy of the ethnic groups in Vietnam, besides the traditional games on the campus museum is also very attractive walking on stilts, swings, water puppet show ..... I will come back again if i have condition
Ethnic Museum. Interesting insight into the numerous ethnic groups residing in Vietnam. Viewings of their individual cultures and dwellings. Their trades and past living conditions.It was amazing.

Information Overload. Wonderful to see that the melting pot of ethnic groups that make todays Vietnam the country it is are honoured and represented here - complete with houses!!! Would have loved more than an hour or so here. Definitely worth the visit.

interesting. The museum has a garden and you find many houses of severals minority people. Very nice to go inside and take a cup of tea.
Sometimes, there are water pupeat shows outside.
I think its a good place to go before going to the north, you will understand more about vietnamese minorities.

A great place to start. We live in Hanoi and often come to the Museum of Ethnology because it has a wonderful garden with lifesize models of ethnic minority houses that continue be a pleasure to explore. The round museum building is a beautiful setting for the quality permament exhibition, and we like to bring our out of town guests here first to get a broad view of the diversity of cultures in Vietnam.The bookshop and Craftlink gift shop sell authentic handicrafts at reasonable prices. The Hoa Sua restaurant is well-staffed and offers good fresh food.Over-all it is a great place to bring your family and friends for an outing in Hanoi.
Was OK. This was ok but very small, the grounds were the best part with life size models of traditional homes etc

Best way to understand hill tribes. Northen Vietnam has one of the most different hill tribes in Asia; this museum gives you a good insight in these little and different cultures. They have the normal info like photographs and little movies, but outside you can find different types of little buildings that they rebuild like the way the hill tribes did. This is specially a bonus when you're thinking about doing a trek to one of the tribes, like Sapa or Mai Chau.
Well presented. Learned a lot about the many cultural groups in Vietnam. Well curated, with interesting life size models.
Good but need at least a day. Don't need a guide, well signed in English and other languages, need at least a day to see it properly.

Get an idea of the different hill-tribes.. A good introduction to all the different cultures and tribal regions of Vietnam. Particularly useful if you are going to e.g. Sapa to get an overview of the local tribespeople.
Museum of ethnology. We had a good guide who really knew his stuff. He took us round the whole museum. It was fascinating as none of us had any in-depth knowledge of the Vietnamese people.

Great fun. The main museum is good, but only good. The main attractions are the outdoor exhibitions of buildings, shelters and temples built according to various Vietnamese cultures and traditions. Kids love this museum as they get to explore and there is so much to explore.

Best Museum in Hanoi. Our group really enjoyed our visit to the Museum of Ethnology in Hanoi. So much to see. Terrific value. Water puppet show included in tour. Well laid out, very informative. In my opinion, not to be missed when in Hanoi.

Amazing museum. This is the best museum I 've spent so many times to visit. I'm really keen on this place although I've been here over ten times This construction included 3 parts: inside, out side and asian. It takes me 5 hours to see all. Fresh air and comfortable for walking and . They have free traditional water puppet show at the weekend at Viet house area. Absolutely amazing talented skills in making traditional house in 54 original ethnic group people with colorful meaningful. Very interesting habits in daily life. Highly recommended for sure.

One of Vietnam's best museums. Although this museum is out of the center, it is definitely with the trip! The budget-minded traveler doesn't need to take a taxi to get there -- you can just take the number 14 bus to get there (7000 dong each). Use the public transportation feature in Google Maps for details. The outside exhibit provides lots of great photo ops, so don't forget a camera!

One of my favourites. The exhibition is quite huge but still cannot cover every aspects of Vietnam's ethnic groups; however, they did a great job of creating a panorama view of how Vietnamese people and culture are. And I love the humanity in the way they create temporary events to promote people's awareness of social issues or help children/people approach Vietnamese culture through traditional games and products (Games, events for children are often taken place during Lunar New Year, International Children Festival, Mid-Autumn Festival...)Almost forgot, it is one of few places in Vietnam that creates wheelchair access - which very nice and thoughtful.

Interesting inside, but it's the houses outside which bring it to life. Inside the main building this is a solid museum with masses of information about the various tribes and ethnicities which inhabit Vietnam - too much, really, as after a while you suffer information overload and it all starts to blur together.Outside, however, the large grounds are full of full-size dwellings from different cultures and time periods, which you can explore and learn about. These really bring the museum to life, and would probably be even better if the information about the tribes was scattered around them so you could digest it a bit easier.
Quite warm!. A good place to spend if you happen to be around town.Nice infos about the locals in Vietnam & cultures.Water puppet shows, free coffee, gift shop... overall a nice place to enjoy!
A Must see, well worth the taxi ride. Well organized museum with wonderful displays of the different cultures in Vietnam. Fee $2 plus $2.50 for camera.
Neat to see. Inside wasn't that great but the structures outside are quite interesting. I would recommend that the provide some more structure to the museum and a summary of each section.

Well worth a visit. This is a wonderful museum providing excellent insight into Vietnamese history and culture. Examples of traditional clothing, photographs and interesting insights into the war as well as marriage and family traditions.

Highly recommended if you plan a visit to any ethnic group. This museum spread across two floors with well presented displays and a fair amount of information in English on all major ethnic groups. It is plenty of life-size models, photos, musical recordings, videos, and also includes an example of a Bahnar communal house. It is worth a visit.
So Well Done!. This museum brings its exhibits to life by making many of them hands-on and full-scale. You can actually go into the various types of tribal houses and enjoy exhibits in English.
Great outdoor displays. A great way to find out about the myriad of tribes that are the Vietnamese people and find out how and where they live.
Really excellent. The ethnic buildings in the grounds were really amazing. There was loads of information about the different ethnic groups living in Vietnam.

A great way to understand VietNam. This is a great museum worth going to. The indoor displays lay the groundwork for understanding the various people groups that make up VietNam. The outdoor buildings are incredible.

the first museum in Hanoi I would consider. Vietnam has 50+ ethnical groups possessing a huge diversity of culture and custom. This museum is a fantastic place to learn about them all. The museum offers a relaxing mixed with adventurous atmosphere (sound weird, right?), suitable for everyone, from children to adults, artist to scientist to ... anyone. I would recommend at least 2 hours (if you only skim everything).The only cons: location. Probably you should get a taxi.

World-standard. For a good insight into the ethnic minorities, this museum is second best to a Sapa vist. Not that busy with a few good displays and a fun outdoor section of some ethnic houses that have been recreated. Budget about 2-3 hours for the visit.
Very interesting if you like ethnology. I loved reading all about the different ethnic groups in Vietnam and seeing the displays of their clothing, houses etc. Well worth a visit.

Educational, historical, ethnic diversity. Probably the most informative Museum in Vietnam and a big tourist attraction in Hanoi. Here you find a wide variety of different cultural scenes of many an ethnic group in Vietnam. Our guide gave us an excellent tour of the museum e.g. explaining the Muang funeral scene inside the building as well as the different housings outside. Here you get to enjoy little clips into the lives of the different groups that live together with their different cultures and value systems. The 54 officially recognized ethnic groups of Vietnam are introduced. The exhibition building was designed by the architect Ha Duc Linh, a member of the Tay ethnic group, in the shape of a Dong Son drum.It would be great if other countries would appreciate their different ethnic groups with a similar positive perspective. As a group we experienced a very informative and eye-opening visit. Thank you to all.

you shouldn't miss this one!. visit this place before you set off to Lao Cai! Especially if you don't have the time to go to Sa Pa, be sure to go to the museum.You'll have some idea of what the minorities look like and what their life is like.

Our first joining the group tour. We went to this attractive place in our first day in Hanoi. We joined the group tour associated with the hotel and one of the 5 or 6 attractions is this Museum of Ethnology. Me & my partner really didnt enjoy the visitations because the tour guide is always in hurry up or want to go fasts to one place to another inorder to finish the tour. We went here for a couple of minutes just to glance the exhibition and no time for taking photos and reading those captions written on each section. But I appreciated those what I have seen in the museum.I suggest if you want to go to the public attractions better to go by your own effort or by your own self just pay the necessary entrance fee and stay as much as you want no one can distrurbe your precious time because time can't return anymore if it is passed.

Surprisingly Interesting . While going through the museum proper, I was starting to feel somewhat disappointed. The displays were mostly relics of the different artifacts from the different ethnic groups, but without much fanfare or pizzaz, if you know what I mean. Then, it started to become interesting when we stepped outside, behind the main building, where all the replica native Vietnamese houses were found. I was amazed at how they built their homes using local materials, and how they structured them. I also liked the garden where the different herbs, vegetables and spices were found, that make up their staple diet. Most of all, make sure to watch the Water puppet show, which already comes with the entrance fee. Not only is it amusing, but it is a lot more expensive if you watch the same show at the theater by Hoàn Kiếm lake.

One for the chicks :). Great museum to leave your partner at checking out tribal fashions and styles while you go check out the war museums.If you do happen to get pw'd to be here there's some interesting tribal house engineering to checkout in the outside area behind the museum. In particular the tall house and the long house. See what you think of the internal framing all done with no nails. Interesting eh!

Definite must see. The museum is a short taxi ride away. But worth a visit as it gives you a greater understanding of Vietnam! Museum is quite big and you can spend a lot of time here and learn a lot!

The outside is maybe more interesting than the inside. The museum is ok. The outside has some buildings that are pretty interesting showing how the people lived. We played the games on the outside and it was fun. We also painted masks which were nice but took time to dry and were kind of messy. You can probably run through the inside of the museum in about 15 minutes.

Very interesting.. The most well done museum we visited during our stay in Vietnam.A bit out of the way, but well worth the effort to get there.Very interesting history of the numerous indigenous tribes of Vietnam. A visit is well recommended.

I think it is the best museum of Vietnam. You will have an overall view about 54 ethnic all over of Vietnam here.. A "must go to" place in Hanoi. Come here, you can enjoy water pubpet at the weekend. I spent one day just to visit it.

Very informative without being boring. The museum is not too big, nor too small; informative without being boring. Very informative regarding ethnic groups that settled in Vietnam. Very colorful displays, costumes and there were clean bathrooms as well as very helpful staff...

What a neat museum!. I found this museum extremely interesting. The displays and attractions were very cool, especially the ones outside. I loved how you could walk through the dwellings. I only wish that I had given myself more time here. I'd recommend at least 2 hours.

I learned a lot. Very nice displays and lots of explanations in Vietnamese, English and French. They are also short films showing ceremonies and the daily life of the different ethnies. Outside, you can visit a dozen of typical houses. This museum comes as a nice complement for those who had the chance to visit ethnic minorities throughout Vietnam and will give others a good overview of the rich ethnic diversity of the country. Stop by the little cafe next too the main building for excellent, real Italian expressos and excellent bakery ( try the chocolate tart) for an amazingly low price. A museum not to be missed if you are visiting Vietnam.

Taste of Hanoi history. Visited this with a tour guide leading us around Hanoi- which is the best way to see Hanoi.Good displays of family life inside and outside examples of different types of dwellings- this could be better signed to give a little more information but gives a real flavour of past and present Vietnam.

he Vietnam Museum of Ethnology. The Vietnam Museum of Ethnology is a museum in Hanoi, Vietnam, which focuses on the 54 officially recognized ethnic groups in Vietnam.This locates at Nguyễn Văn Huyên street, Nghĩa Đô, Cầu Giấy, Hà Nội which show the various cultures from 54 minority groups in Vietnam.If you have time in Hanoi, do not forget see this museum.

Informative... If you want to know the "Old" Vietnam, then you should go here. They have many paintings and sculptures, etc to show you how the Vietnamese were doing in their old times.The place consists of many rooms and floors. It will take you about 1-2 hours to enjoy everything. Overall, it was good!
Great Place. this area so nice and all of information about the old vietnamese so amazing and enought for all of guest when come to here discovery about the war of france to vietnam from 1945 to 1975
Too much information. Too much information but still a must to cover all the different ethnicity of Vietnam. The outdoor garden was a lovely visit.
Myvisit in February 2014. Very interesting museum, a must whenever you visit Hanoi. Very informative, with short movies, maps, nice set up pertaining to each minority

Totally compelling - do not miss!. I spent four and a half hours being fascinated at this museum.The best part is the outside reconstruction of different styles of traditional living (love the matrilineal tribes with breast decorations!) behind the main building. Go there first! You walk around and visit Cham, Ede, Viet, etc. houses, communal areas, tombs. It is peaceful (there are some sleeping watchpeople but they do not have a spiel) - the whole architecture is simple wood and bamboo and strikingly austere interiors, with straw mats for bedding and limited privacy in most cases. The high-quality descriptions on the walls (French, English, Vietnames) give a good sense of some of the customs. The exhibits have been developed with support from Nordic countries and France and are world-class. Probably a good introduction to visit tribal areas and unmissable if your itinerary does not allow such a visit. The whole place is peaceful, unrushed, with no tourist folk costume or dance displays.Inside is almost equally wonderful. If nothing else, admire the ceremonial totem pole in the hallway. The two levels are full of costumes, baskets, tools, and good information on important customs and ceremonies (with some video) of the different ethnic groups.I have also visited the Ethnological Museum in Saigon and the Cham museum in Da Nang. This was a favourite by far, although the Cham sculptures are also worth seeing. Nice to see e.g. a Cham house after seeing Cham sculpture in Da nang and Cham ruins in My Son near Hoi An - it all comes together.Tips:One tomb is very explicit - may make you blush!Some of the outside houses may be difficult to enter for those with restricted mobility. The 'staircases' carved out of a log are really fun if you have a head for heights.Toilets outside among the most pristine I have seen in the country. Accessible, too, I think.If it gets too hot, you can head for the over-air-conditioned cafe block near the exit. If you get hungry or need water, there is a reasonable restaurant run by students of a catering/serving school. My pho was a little watered-down but served at the same price as on the street!The museum is not near the lake in the centre of town - you need to take a taxi.The gift shop looked nice but alas it was too late to visit.Would visit again in a flash. Really stayed with me.

Fascinating. Will take all of three hours if you want to do it justice. Ethnic costumes, crafts, maps, histories, ceramics, art. All of Vietnam in a nutshell, and then there are life-sized houses of each minority built in the park - well worth the visit.
Good museum. Provided a good sense for the people of Vietnam. Interesting displays. If you are short on time though, you can skip it.

Museum of Ethnology. The museum was filled with photos, artifacts and information about the different tribes that exist in Vietnam. This was especially informative before visiting Sapa and hiking through the different villages. The houses outside were fascinating. There is no AC throughout the museum, it was sooooo hot, but they give you free coffee with 2 admission tickets, which was nice!

One of the best museums I have visited. Although I do not normally make it a point of visiting many museums I would highly recommend this one. It shows clearly the different ethnic groups that make up Vietnam. It has many authentic displays indoors and beautiful original ethnic houses in the gardens outside. Definitely worthwhile for £1.20 (40,000 dong) entrance fee. It explains the rich diversity of the different tribes in Vietnam really well.

Great Museum. Vietnam Museum of Ethnology (Vietnamese name is Bao Tang Dan Toc Hoc) is a great place that attracts both children and adults. I loved everything about this museum from its rich materials, well displayed exhibits (inside and especially outside), to the tour guide. The three things that the museum could improve are: 1) the air conditioner or at least fan system: There was air conditioner only at the reception hall and there were few fans here and there around the museum. In the summer, it was a torture for both children and adults, especially the children. They couldn't stand the heat, the sweating and thus they couldn't really enjoy the great exhibits or learn much about Vietnamese people and cultures; 2) the discovery room's location and hour: Although the museum opened from 8:30am to 5:30pm, the discovery room closed between 11:30am to 1:30pm and it wasn't officially noticed on the museum's website, door, or brochure. If we had known, we could have planed to visit at the more proper time so the kids could explore the room and had some hand-on experiences. My kids were very excited to go to the discovery room to work on paintings, ceramic, etc. only to learn that it was closed. In addition, the room was on the attic of the museum. You had to climb a very narrow and dark stair way to get to it. In my opinion, the discovery room is as important as any other part of the museum, it should be placed at a better location, not such remote place. Possibly, the discovery room is the best part of the museum to the children. It was such a disappointment here; 3) The stairway: There wasn't any elevator or escalator in the museum. Therefore, it was impossible for the disabled to visit the museum's second floor and it was difficult for families with small children. We visited the museum without the kids' dad so when we climbed up the stairway. I had to make the kids go first and follow them with whole bunch of bags and stroller while still have to looking after them. It was the same thing climbing down, only I had to go first this time with baggage and made the kids follow so that I could probably catch them if they fell.

A must see place. I've been here 2 times. This museum is ideal place to learn about 54 Vietnamese groups, their cultures, lifestyles and architectures. The collections of traditional dresses, stilt houses always amuse me. This is an interesting place for kids where they can play in stilts houses and large ground (we've been chosen the museum for the trip of 50 kids)

Restaurant disorganized and exhibits dangerous. Okay, I made it through the outdoor exhibits without falling. Success? No. Once it began raining, my husband and I decided to eat lunch in the Bagette & chocolat. Big mistake. We weren't greeted, so sat ourselves. I found the chair that broke under my weight. We were then ignored for about ten minutes until asked to move. When we moved two men took our places and were served immediately. We were then ignited again for about 15 minutes until I retrieved wait staff who took our order and then did not take it to the kitchen but instead began helping a table of eight who strived long after we did. Weird. We left without eating.

Great museum. This museum gives you a very good idea how it was to live on Vietnam years ago. It also explains very well the different ethnics and minorities in Vietnam. It does not take too long to visit. even if you are not a museum fan this is nice to do.

A very different musuem. Large museum with indoor and outdoor exhibits. I especially enjoyed the outdoor exhibits the hot weather. Popular architectures of some ethnic groups were presented. The interior of these architectures were mimicked to resemble the actual. Despite not being much of a museum goer, I’ve enjoyed this visit very much.

Good to learn about Vietnamese history. It was part of our organised private tour. We liked it, despite the fact that's quite warm in August and it would normally not be one of the things we would be doing on our first day. There are some nice examples of different houses in the garden. There also is a puppet show (for free - included in ticket price).

Beautyfull museum giving insight in the different tribes who live in Vietnam. One building contains the overview information. Very well presented. In the garden 10 houses of different tribes are rebuild in real size. During the WE you can enjoy a water puppet theatre performance. The museum is located 10 km from the centre. Use a taxi.

A great museum. Typical of a history museum with lots of pottery, jewelry and explanations if the various indigenous groups. Lovely gardens out back where you can explore authentic structures from the various ethnic groups.

Educational experience. A little bit out of town, but glad we went. Charts the cultural history of Vietnam with really interesting exhibits. We had a guide who was able to help explain all the detail and really brought it to life for us - Maine if you went without a guide the experience wouldn't be quite so good.

Out of town but worth the trip. The museum of ethnology is out of town but a cab gets you there quickly. They have a lot on display about al the different minorities that live in Vietnam and the rebuild houses in the garden give a good insight in how the tribes (used to) live. Great to do with kids.
Uneventful. More props than historical artifacts. Doesn't help when it's scorching hot (35C) outside. The outdoor traditional houses were alot more interesting.

Must be one of the most interesting Museum !Don't miss it!. Must be one of the most interesting Museum !Don't miss it!You'll need at least 3 hours to see it all , pictures , pottery , water puppet shows , original homes of minorities .... just beautiful and very interesting. I would suggest to reserve a guide in advance or go very early to be sure to get a guide.Don't miss it it's really really good.

Excellent museum worth the trip. Located about 25 minutes by taxi outside the old quarter this museum is definitely worth a visit if you are interested in this field. The outside exhibits are also interesting to wander around. Signs were in Vietnamese, French and English.
VietNam Museum of Ethnology. VietNam museum of Ethonology where is discovery VietNam culture and I think it is very good to us,special who want to our children.Thank you

Best museum in Hanoi. It's my favorite museum. It illustrates the different culture of ethnic groups in Vietnam.I am very happy to be a volunteer here each summer. If you travel with family, you should take your child come here. They will feel excited and understand more about Vietnam's culture.

Highly recommend. This is a really well planned and interesting and educational museum. It has reconstructions of type of long houses, tall houses and other village structures in the gardens and inside you get a very good sense of the ethnic diversity of the country. There are maps of language areas, tribal areas, displays of some amazing traditional crafts and when I went a fabulously displayed exhibition of photos taken in the 1950s. This is a well-thought out museum. Good for kids and adults. Takes about two hours to do and there's a nice cafe there too, which trains kids from disadvantaged homes (well more disadvantaged than most I imagine). Takes about 20m to get to from Old Quarter and costs about 100k dong. I found this a much better museum than the army museum for instance, which really is a middling experience for anyone interested in the Vietnam war.

Several cultures in a small location. An excellent place to view the various ethnic houses of Vietnam. We were accompanied by excellent HanoiKids tour guides who were very knowledgeable. The contrast of building styles and living customs were fascinating. More detailed information signs would be helpful for those without guides.

don't go if it's raining. I went to visit this museum twice, once on a sunny day and the other, rainy! Opt for the first as this is an outdoor museum and is extremely interesting. It's well organised and has alot of interesting ethnic houses to visit.

don't miss it!. My favourite, and most people that I met, favourite museum in Hanoi. Very well organized. They have one room on the first floor that they reserve for temporary exhibitions. While I was there in the winter of 2014, they had one on Sex and Youth. And the rest of the museum is very traditional in a historical sense, long write-ups accompanied most objects and images. The write-ups were in proper English as well, reviewed before displayed, unlike the numerous museums around the Old Quarter. The series of longhouses outside is fascinating. You really need to take out more than 3 hours to properly see the museum.

know your hosts. Viet Nam translates to "southern ethnics" so a visit to the beautifully designed Ethnology Museum will give you a much greater understanding of the Vietnamese and their relations with the rest of the region.

excellent. The museum covers a wide range of the ethnological history of vietnam! Very interesting if you want to understand how the population ended up to what it is now. The building is very nice too and you can have a walk or a coffee in the gardens.

Ok but don't worry if you miss it. A museum to show you the different tribes of Vietnam. It's quite good and have seen all the tribal houses etc but we are well travelled in the area so probably don't need to do this
Excellent!. Unique museum in Hanoi. We spent 2-3 hours there. AN NGON restaurant called Hoa Sua is in the grounds for a good lunch. Worth visiting
Worth a visit..... this museum has a basic culture of the local ppl in Vietnam. if u r interested in learning abt their life style and culture then this is the best place to visit.

Great place to visit. Really nice place to spend an hour or so learning about some history.There is a coffee shop attached on the same property, if you go there don't expect much. They have a food menu but you can't order half of it as they don't keep their food supply well stocked.
Short visit. Never had that much time, but still managed to see almost everything we wanted to. Easy to get to as well.

Excellent introduction to traditional Vietnam. Located on Nguyen Van Huyen Street in Cau Giay District, about 8 km from the city centre, the museum covers the culture of the various ethnic groups in Vietnam and consists of an indoor exhibition and a huge open-air exhibition. The indoor section has exhibitions of clothes, agricultural tools, fishing instruments, musical instruments, and religious artifacts - belonging to the many ethnic groups of Vietnam. Be sure to check out Mr Pham Dang Uy's bicycle - loaded down with some 800 wooden and bamboo fish traps! The outdoor open air exhibition has houses of different ethnic communities. A water puppet show is also there for the visitors

History of the ethnic groups of Vietnam. While the Viet make up 86% of the people of Vietnam this museum shares the history of 53 other ethnic people. There is area if artifacts and an area if reconstructed villages/ houses. A gift shop sells very reasonable handcrafts and the restaurant excellent food offering training for young people

Interesting and fun for children. We visited here (2 adults and 2 children) in late June. It is a taxi ride from the old town (about 90-100000 dong). From memory it was 15000 dong each tom get in. It was very informative and a good way to give my children a quick lesson on the many ethnic groups living in Vietnam. Inside are displays of costumes and traditional tools, machines used. Outside there are large grounds with life size houses which have been built for each of the ethnic groups. My children loved climbing on them and seeing how mother people lived. We spent a morning there (about 2 hours) which was enough for my children (ages 10 and 11) as it was really hot the day we went.

Learn about the Ethnic Minorities in Vietnam. I love this place. You can really get a good understanding of the lifestyles of many of the 54 Ethnic groups in Vietnam. They have water puppet performances every weekend and temporary exhibitions.

Worth visiting. The museum has many artefacts which are characteristic of the 54 ethnic groups in Vietnam. The Viet form tge largest population with 53 others being the minority groups. The museum is not very well kept and it can get hot inside, but it is definitely worth a visit.
An overall look. See examples of the 54 different ethnic groups. It is a nice walk throughand certainly worth a visit

Well worth the trp. This museum located a ways from the old quarter was an easy breezy bus trip away!!! This is a very well done museum with a fantastic gift shop with amazingly reasonable prices for top quality items. Ask the tourist info desk in the old quarter on how to take the bus there. It was cheap and super easy and turned us into instant fans of Hanoibus! The museum rocks too(-:

Great for the kids and prior to a Sapa visit. We had 3 kids (10, 8 and and 5) and this was a fantastic outing on a hot day. They got a great feel for the ethnic minorities prior to our visit to Sapa and loved climbing in and out of the various houses.
AMAZING EXPERIENCE!. Beautiful place and AMAZING EXPERIENCEreally nice , is A MUST TO SEE in HanoiAlone, or with friends or with kidsneed go to feel the ancient Vientam on you

Great visit. Great museum to really understand the ethnic and cultural diversity of the country. Really enjoyed the outdoor part, especially if you do not plan on heading to the hills to see all the tribes yourself!The museum store had by far the best quality shopping we found in our whole Hanoi stay. Not street cheap, but also not street bad!

Very interesting and informative. We went with a tour guide and he explained everything to us. Very informative and learned a lot about the different ethnic of Vietnam. We especially love being able to get into all the ethnic houses.

A great snapshot of an aspect of Vietnamese culture. Great museum in inside and outdoor spaces. Kids can climb around outside. We also had a guide and that helped make even more sense of what we saw. If in Hanoi worth an hour or two of your time

Interesting, but worth paying for a guide. This museum is definitely worth the visit, however, I would highly recommend getting a guide to show you around. The museum gave an insight to all of the ethnic groups in Vietnam, as well as their traditional way of living. There was a main building, which lacked a/c, however the layout was easy to follow. The second new building was had a/c, but only one exhibit as it was new. The houses were well worth the visit, they were built according to the traditional ways, and were still functional as we found out, due to the heavy rainfall. There was english and french plaques and a chance to watch videos, however the labels on the exhibits were "hat, belt, hat, crossbow, women's clothes..." etc, and the plaques only described the peoples, with little information about the actual exhibits themselves. We ended up eavesdropping on several guided groups to find out more information about (for example) what each hat represented, or how things were created and used. You could definitely go exploring the place yourself, but I would recommend getting a guide if you want a full experience.

The new Southeast Asia Building. has airconditioning!!!!!!! We were at the Museum with my husband's folks who are over 70, and the lack of AC in the other halls was difficult for them. The new building was an oasis.

Interesting and informative. Good summary of different ethnic groups in Vietnam. We had to rush through as 3 small children can only be entertained for so long... Gift shop excellent and funds go back to rural communities making the gifts. Worth a visit.

Rich and comprehensive!. This is a Museum interactive, inside you can read and listen and watch about ethnic groups living in Vietnam, as well as observing the cultural materials associated with them. Outdoor you have the opportunity to watch the famous water poppet show as well as the fabulous houses made from woods and bamboos!
Enrich your knowledge!. I have been here several times and this museum is mesmerizing! Even though I'm Vietnamese, I have learnt a lot about the minorities of my own country.

More of a miniature village than a museum. The museum building itself is okay, with several floors of clothes, weapons, instruments and displays of the ethnic minorities in Vietnam, where they come from and where they are now.What was really special was the area out the back, where you can spend at least an hour wandering from mini-village to mini-village with lifesize houses that you can go into and look around. Despite being in the middle of Hanoi the exhibits and surrounding trees and rivers make you feel as though you are in the country side, it truly is as close to authentic as it gets.There is a lot of english, and few people which made it all the more peaceful to roam around and explore these amazing buildings.This was my favourite museum in Vietnam, would happily come back next time.

Good place but hot. We liked the traditional houses outside very much in this museum. Inside it was so hot that it was hard to concentrate and read the few boards that were in English. An OK place and do go to see the houses but perhaps with a guide would be better.

Fascinating insight. If you had time to visit only one attraction in Hanoi, I'd recommend the Museum of Ethnology. A fascinating insight into Vietnamese culture, and the ethnic groups that make up the country. We went with a guide, and while it was really helpful having her there to explain various exhibits and offer personal insight, everything was very well labeled, and there was a lot of information on each of the ethnic minorities, as well as each of the different regions in Vietnam. I especially loved all of the traditional costumes and textiles. There is also an outside area where members of each ethnic minority have been invited to construct a house in the style typical to different groups. There's also a smaller Asia section in a separate building, which was really interesting. Interesting to see some of the similarities with other Asian countries. This museum was recommended highly to me by both Vietnamese friends and Australian friends, and I was not disappointed.

Vietnam Museum of Ethnology. An extremely well set out museum with excellent displays in door of the various ethic groups and their customs and costumes. it shows how diverse the population of Vietnam is. If you are traveling into the hill tribe areas it is a good starting point to learn about them. The display out door of the various dwellings adds to the experience. it is interesting to note next door there is being built a South East Asian museum of Ethnology.

Amazing. Such a good insight into the history and different cultures that there is in Vietnam, also the different style of traditional houses that were on display was stunning.
Worthwhile trip.
Vietnam Museum of Ethnology. Very interesting and well worth a visit. We went with a tour group Gate 1 and thoroughly enjoyed this experience. would highly recommend it to anyone visiting Vietnam

Hanoi Museum of Ethnology. Other travelers will probably like it even better than I did. A must if you're going anywhere in the mountains and visiting the minorities. My only criticism is based on the fact that I have a higher level of interest in the minorities than average and therefore am disappointed in the quality of the material. Several years ago when this museum was opened much better material was available and the government did not avail itself of that opportunity to create a world class example when it was still possible. Do go and also go to the Natural History Museum behind the Opera House. Between those two you will have a pretty good idea of the history of the region.
