Visit to Hanoi Ethnology Museum. }One of the very best of its kind worldwide- inside and out. We were most taken by this splendid museum. An Indo Chinese highlight

Colourful and Educational. 4th day and we had organized a city tour through Awesome travel, first stop, Ho Chi Mihn, a Temple and then to the Museum of Ethnology.The Ethnology Museum fills in a lot of the gaps in gaining a knowledge of a very diverse culture and is available on all city tours.My wife and I enjoyed and were intrigued at the same time by the many colourful costumes for different occasions.The Museum is very well put together and a must to put on your to do list for your Vietnam Culture experience.

A "Celebration" of Ethnicity!. We headed here because our tour guide wouldn't budge and insisted it was so important. It was mildly interesting about the various ethnic groups in Vietnam, but nothing fancy.

Interesting. It wasn't the best nor the worst museum. It held out interest for about an hour. We enjoyed the outside exhibits the best. Small restaurant outside was very good considering it was a place for students to learn the restaurant business of cooking as well as serving customers.

most wonderful museum in Hanoi. unique museum in Hanoi, a hustle and bustle city, this museum is really impressive with real model house of 9 peoples in vietnam. Love the outside area most! really must see when visiting hanoi

If you have an interest in history. . Nice place to visit, especially the full sized homes that were built in different groups through out the years. We found it was a nice 2-3 hours to spend. An NGO restaurant called Hoa Sua is in the grounds for a good lunch. Worth doing.
A must see museum. It's nice to see a country that gives importance to its cultural minorities and this museum is a proof that Vietnam is in touch with its roots!

Visit here and have a look at Vietnam. This museum is really interesting museum to visit and know more about Vietnam. You can explore all of information about Vietnam such as: history, culture, beautiful sights and people. After vistitting this museum, you will have a look at Vietnam and decide where the next place is to visit in Vietnam. Welcome to VME! Welcome to Vietnam!

Appreciated the Videos. We thought this museum worth the cab ride and didn't think the heat too bad in the morning. We enjoyed touring the various houses and especially appreciated the videos that accompanied many of the exhibits, giving the items displayed context. The only place during our 2 week travels that gave us perspective on the 54 different ethnicities and rural life.

Wonderful Place To Visit. Tickets for our family of four was around 3.50.total. Great museum telling the story of the people of Vietnam. Inside exhibits and artwork. Outside loads of replica houses. Takes about 2-3 hours to see it properly. Couple of good shops on grounds and a great little café. If you are in Hanoi for a few days a must see.
Go before visiting the north. Great for getting a preview of the ethnic groups you are going to meet up with in the rest of Vietnam. Only problem is the lack of air-conditioning!

Teaches you a lot about the history and life in Vietnam. This was quite a unique experience, as you are transformed into a completely different world. Separated into regions, this museum really explains what each part of Vietnam is like, their rituals, customs and clothes. It was a mini-trip around the country and we learned a lot. Do come here in the morning, as it was quite difficult to walk around the traditional houses in the garden in the heat.

Really interesting. We really enjoyed this museum. The taxi from the hotel was cheap and so was the entrance fee. You do have to pay extra to take photos... But it's pennies really. It may not be to everyone's taste, but on our 2nd day in Vietnam was a great way to learn a little about the culture and history. We did go on a lovely sunny day, which probably makes a difference. Nice grounds, well laid out. I'd say definitely worth a couple of hours of your day.

Not worth the trip!. I'm not sure why this is so well reviewed! The museum inside is underwhelming. The outside is okay, at best. It's about 100,000 each direction for a taxi, making this a very expensive excursion. I would not suggest it.

Good. The museum here is quite ok, but you do not necessarily have seen. There are many products of minorities in Vietnam and shown also shown homes that inhabit people. Also there is a water puppet theater with a 45-minute presentation. Then saves you extra to buy a ticket for a performance.May 2014
Interesting. This museum is well laid out in nice grounds with a range of tribal buildings housing interesting displays from the very diverse ethnic tribes of Vietnam.

Most enjoyable. Found this museum worth the visit. The museum is set up to display the social, cultural and architectural/structural lives of the many ethnic groups in Vietnam.Unfortunately our visit was on a very hot and humid day and there is no air conditioning. MOst unpleasant.Again our person guide was very informative Out the back of the actual museum is a large land area given over to replicas of houses/community buildings from the various ethnic groups

Not my cup of tea. Interesting enough but not really worth it unless you are absolutely strapped for something to do. Lots of information on different cultures in Vietnam and presented in an excellent way (all exhibits have good English information displayed) the outdoor examples of houses is very interesting but somehow I lost interest after a little while.

Everything about Vietnamese under One-roof. If you enjoy learning about other culture, this is the place that you must visit. Spend half day at least to really appreciate Vietnamese cultural heritage.

Vietnam Museum of Ethnology. Vietnam is a heterogeneous country composed of 54 things tribe. It is a very interesting museum to introduce and local characteristics of each house, and customs. As well as net woven basket in bamboo, form varies depending on the tribe, of Where born I seem to see in this. Folk costume of each tribe is Yes on display, it was interesting. Model of the house is the best part, model houses on stilts with high ceiling was impressive.
Very good. The museum shows the different kind of people that lives in Vietnam. Also show their costumes and clothes.
Very Cultural. A very good display of models and artefacts , gives you a distinct a good idea of way of life of vietnamese people. Very informative and a must visit .. the to this museum...

You don't have to be an anthropologist to enjoy this ... I promise .... The ethnology museum is a few things collated together in one place: it is primarily a collection of authentic dwellings collected from the various ethnic groups of Vietnam to show in one place the different building types deployed and explains the reasons as to why there are these different building styles. All of the buildings are open for you to wander around and this gives a fascinating insight into traditional tribal living in Vietnam; some of which is still practiced today.The second key exhibit is an indoor collection of clothing, tools etc. from the various ethnic groups of Vietnam and an explanation as to their origins and history of immigration in Vietnam.The museum is clearly well maintained and the exhibits are all of a really high standard.Aside from the building exhibits and indoor exhibits there are puppet shoes, cafes etc. and other tourist attractions on site.
Really interesting!. My husband and I really enjoyed seeing the tribal homes the most! We would recommend adding it to your trip list!

More understanding of Vietnam!. This museum is so interesting for two of us. we have a great time here and understand more about the ethnic minority groups in Vietnam. This museum helped us so much for our tour along Vietnam. Must to see when traveling to Hanoi.

nice museum. a great effort for tourist from local government for understanding ethnology of country. interesting and informative, one will have fun at water puppet show after knowledge round of museum!!

Interesting. An informative and interesting visit which explains the various ethnic groups in Vietnam existing over time by way of pictures, puppets, photographs, videos, models of houses which are in the open and one can walk around and even enter the models to get a better picture of their living style.
Interesting. The Museum of Ethnology is very good and not to be missed even if you are not a fan of South East Asian history. The displays, videos and pictures are very informative. I learnt a lot.

very interesting!. The museum give you a good idea about the minorities in Viet Nam, there is an ouside part with real scale reproduction of traditional houses from the villages and you can walk in... very interesting visit!

Great weekend outing. Recommend you visit on the weekend when there are daily water puppet shows, presented by small community puppet groups from outside of Hanoi.
Make sure you have lunch in the café (a training restaurant).

Interesting and informative. A well laid out and documented museum. Descriptions in English of exhibits were much appreciated. Would suggest increasing the number of fans in the Museum, especially when it is as hot as it was at the end of May 2014. The outside exhibits were also very interesting.

Interesting place to see. We at Cosmos Travel Vietnam Co., Ltd advise travelers to see Museum of Ethnology to understand how many ethnics live in Vietnam. Travelers have an overview before exploring Sapa, Bac Ha or North-West provinces of Vietnam

Fun way to understand the different ethnic groups. A good and interesting way to see a very informative display of the different minorities in Vietnam, their divere ways of life and wonderful cultural practices.

Ethnology history. we went here with 2 tour guides the day before we travelled to Sapa. This gives you a insight into the old buildings that you will see in the Sapa region. We were luck enough to go on a Saturday where we witnessed the great family day out with loads of families sharing the good location. also on a Saturday there is a water puppet show on. We visited at around 10am & took around 90 minutes to visit but this was with guides detailed knowledge.

Informative and not over-long. We spent 80 minutes exploring and understanding the different ethnic groups that make up the people of Vietnam. The exhibition is a mixture of indoor and outdoor. The latter has reproductions of the different homes of the different Vietnamese people. The former has examples of clothing and household goods with some explanatory writing.It was a bit warm on a late May afternoon. But, there is a fancy Vietnamese coffee shop next door to offer you sanctuary.

Learn about Vietnamese culture. Where better to learn about the different groups of people and their culture that make up Vietnam than at the Museum of Ethnology. You will be amazed at the number of different groups at populate the country. The museum shows a a very good range of well laid out displays including relatively recent photographs of some of the groups that can be found in the country. The costumes are full of colours and fascinating patterns. The best part is in the grounds where examples of the type of houses these groups live in can be found. Some have be reconstructed from original buildings. They are truly amazing. This museum is a must to visit, helped by the fact that information about the displays is in English as well.

Excellent International Museum. The French government has extended a huge amount of help in the construction and cataloging of this place. The end result is that it is one of the best kept and most professional museums in the entire country.

The best museum in Hanoi. I have been to many museum in Hanoi. I think this museum is the best ever. You have chance to see a lot of house of vietnamese ethnic people group in the whole of Vietnam. They have many kind of things to display such as usual clothes from many minority people in Vietnam, a thousand picture of daily life of Vietnam's different generation etc. It's the biggest one with a great atmosphere. If you go with your family I am sure that all of member would love that.

amazing information. so much to see and take in here- we should have got a guide to condense all for us!! great displays and helped us piece together what Vietnam is made up of. lots of houses to see inside . interesting for school aged kids.

Fun way to discover ethnic Vietnam. What's inside the museum? 1st you will be welcomed by hefty information about the minorities in different provinces in Vietnam and then you'll go out to see replica's of ancient houses so you'll get to feel it! Very fun and interesting way of discovering how minorities live their lives! You can spend a lot of time here as there are plenty of places to rest in-between enjoying the great replicas!

Best museum in Hanoi. Excellent museum, fascinating and it's free! Highly recommended. There is also a beautiful garden with traditional houses, and a water puppet show, among other programs. A 25min taxi ride to the museum will cost you around 100,000 Dong (3.5 euros). Make sure the taxi meter starts at 9 or 10,000.

Cute Cafe. Simple and comfy restaurant serving some delicious tradional Vietnamese spring rolls and pho. The terrace seating was quaint with a part view of the museum. The staff was polite and the concept of teaching them culinary skills while on job was particularly impressive. The choice of desserts was a bit disappointing though.
Beautiful to see...but.... Nice to see but it is SOOOOOO HOOOTTT over there that it is very uncomfortable to try to look at the attraction.

Fasinating. Very modern and air conditioned - make sure you see all the displays as they are spread out. The costumes and diversity of this amazing country is so interesting and this is the best way to see it all in one spot.

great museum. great museum. gives information about all the different tribes in vietnam and they have replicas of their houses in the museum yard. the café is also nice. unfortunately they don't give information about rivalry of viet and the minorities which is part of the truth, too.
Easy to ignore but a must see. I never realised the diversity of the heritage of the Vietnamese people. It was a true "eye-opener".

Interesting museum. A lot of information on the tribes of Vietnam. Many interesting exhibits as well as the reconstructed houses of the different ethnic groups. Definitely worth a trip down and spend an afternoon here.
Good impression of Vietnam. Although we could only visit this museum for 1 hour, we got a very good impression of Vietnam and it's culture.

Good place to learn about Vietnamese tribes.. This is the most interesting museum in Hanoi that I visted. I thoroughly enjoyed the out side exhibitions - there are many different houses of different ethnic group. They all look strange.You also can learn about their culture, tools to work, types of clothing and their spirit life.But Ethnology Museum is quite far from centre of Hanoi, if you stay in Old Quater, you have to catch a taxi instead of walking.
Do not miss this amazing museum.. So much to learn about Hanoi, about Vietnam, about the some 34 tribes. Beautiful building. Outside are replicas of various tribal houses.

A Fascinating and extensive exhibit which showed dioramas of many of the diverse groups of people who make up Vietnam. . Their cultures, tools, homes types of jobs, methods of growing food, types of clothing, types of local celebrations of births, coming of age, weddings, deaths as well as local ceremonies , festivities, types of religious ceremonies and instruments used in the practice of those ceremonies. There were 17 very different types of houses the grounds, as well as restaurants and concert halls. Ethnic minorities played thir native instruments and sang.You could spend several days wandering through this beautifully designed museum and ethnic homes exhibition.

Very different Museum. We didn't have very long here which was a shame, but the parts of the museum we did see we really enjoyed.If you are going make sure you have several hours to look around, we had only one and I feel like we missed so much.It's not a typical museum, but it is very well done, a very wide range of different exhibits, definitely worth a visit.
A good intro to a diverse ethnicity. This museum provided a great intro to the 54 diverse ethnic groups that make up Vietnam. Well worht a visit.
One of the best!. I loved the exhibits and the examples of traditional homes that are located on the grounds. We also saw a water puppet show in the museum garden. Wowie!

if you are into museums.... I visited this place cause i was suggested by a friend! is not the " normal " museum that's why i could still enjoy it ! The cutest part is on the outside where there is a representation of the typical houses in different area of Vietnam! the visit is fine but yes it takes some hours to go around :-)After all i'd say is worth to go there!!

Interesting museum with nice garderns.. The museum is nice to wander around to learn about the different ethnic groups across Vietnam and the rest of SE Asia, I think it is definitley worth visit - especially if you plan to go into the rural areas to visit some of these communities. The gardens are pleasant to browse and the houses are interesting to observe and explore. Price is reasonable, and it is helpful that the displays are in English and French and not just Vietnamese, so you don't neccesarily need a guide. Nice to kill a few hours and keep out of the sun!

Interesting tribe houses - thats all. We decided to visit this museum because of the excelent rating in tripadvisor. The museum is located about 5km from Ho Chi Minh mausoleum. The main building has a lot of display and stories about the ethnics of vietnam. Because we are not really into the stuff, we got bored after 15 minutes.The ethnic houses behind the main building are more interesting.

Nice view on the ethnic people of vietnam. It was great having all the displays of all the ethnic group of Vietnam all under one roof. Gave me alot of insight on where the people come from, what they specialise in and where are they now.

Understanding Vietnamese culture. Describes very well all the different people and lifestyles of Vietnam. Really interesting but a bit too detailed for a normal tourist. Nice exposition of houses, clothing, tools etc. Absolutely worth the visit. Good museum shop with some traditional textiles

A Must see in Hanoi!!!!. I have been to Vietnam four times since the war. I have spent a total of about seven months in Hanoi, but never got to the Vietnam Museum of Ethnology. I did so last week.I have to say, as a lover of Asian culture and Vietnam, it is a treasure waiting to be discovered.The displays are done very well and, if you want to really understand Vietnam and all of SE Asia, you must spend a couple of hours here. It is very enlightening. Vietnam has 54 different ethnic groups and all are celebrated. Well worth the visit. Definitely make it a point to go there when you are in Hanoi.
Well worth it!. Great exhibits, detailed explainations, reasonable fee and English guide service available. Also, gift shop and student cafe great spots to browse and have a cool drink.

Don't go out of you way. Unless you are specifically interested in details about the several Vietnamese mountain tribes I would give it a miss. Found it very boring and it is well out of the city centre so requires a separate trip to see.

Old fashioned inside but the replicated ethnic houses outside good. The inside displays are very old fashioned by western standards. Outside the replicated houses from different ethnic groups of Vietnam are much more interesting. The museum is included in many of the day tours of Hanoi.

Learn about vietnam cultures. inside is pretty standard museum information on the different vietnamese cultures and their backgrounds. Outside makes this a must do. There are the actual houses from each group. They are really interesting and have information on each in different languages. The staff are mainly young volunteers who are really keen. Let them try your language as they are keen and enthusiastic. There are also musicians and examples of water puppets. A nice restaurant is there too with good coffees.

Glad we went. If your visit to Vietnam doesn't include tours to more remote areas or to the mountain areas, this is a great place to spend a couple of hours learning about the different ethnic groups of Vietnam, where and how they live. Interesting replica buildings to visit in the grounds. Worth some of your time.

astonishing museum-a good place to learn. A good place to learn about the over 50 ethnic groups that live in Vietnam, and how they were treated throughout history. A good display of photographs. A big section of the museum was reserved for a display of sex educations for young people which has very graphic pictures of genitalia and many Vietnamese elementary school children looking at the pictures, giggling and taking photos with their cell phones. There are sculptures made out of condoms which the children also found entertaining. Outside, there are styles of Vietnamese houses built to scale. In some, one has to remove one's shoes to enter. There is also a small lake with a free water puppet show. It was raining when i was there, so tourists huddled under café umbrellas to stay dry. The French café at the museum is wonderful, it is an open terrace with a roof, with comfy plush seats and very friendly service. The sandwiches, coffee and ice cream are excellent.
Museum. Our guide suggested this museum, and it is a fascinating look at life all over Vietnam and through the ages.

Dreary and over-rated. I found the whole museum dark and dreary with unimaginative exhibits for the most part. How many fishing baskets, hats, etc do we need to see to get the idea? There was also a very bizarre installment at the moment on sex education for young people. It was surprisingly graphic in places, and just seemed out of place in this particular museum.The examples of ethnic houses outside are by far the most interesting thing here and definitely worth a look, but a quick whizz round in an hour would have been enough for me! The Women's Museum was a much better use of time...
Most interesting. Informative and well presented. Gave great information about the astonishing array of ethnic groups in the country and their cultures. Well worth a visit.

daytrip. As part of a tour that we were on we visited the museum. On the outside it had different types of houses that had been built to scale. These were the houses that the diverse ethnic monorities lived in, these were the people that we would encounter on our trip to Sapa. On the inside there were many displays showing how these people lived their daily lives. We found the trip to be interesting and it showed us what we would see on the next leg of our tour.RegardsBaslady

Fascinating history of life in Vietnam for a long period of its history. Gathered much information on how people live. All was of much interest and very informative. The burial ceremonies and rituals was of special interest, as well as the houses and contents, also styles of dress for the many regions.

A must see especially if you plan a visit to North Vietnam. All the essentials about some of the ethnic minorities in Vietnam, the re-built houses outside give a good idea of how they look in the villages. The partly opened new building is impressive with some very well presented exhibits. Don't miss the caffee, used for training young people hoping to improve their employability.

Must come when you are in Hanoi. Its really good for whom wants to discover Vietnamese people. I had chance to work as a volunteer here for a month. It was a great experiences!. You will see the culture of 54 ethnic groups of Vietnam via their houses, garden, labor tools, costumes etc. If you visit on weekend, you will have chance to see water puppet show inside museum. Its free. Normally, there are two big festivals, one is on Mid-Autumn Festival, and others is after "Tet Holiday". There are many activities in this festival, such as: Vietnamese Folk Games (about 20 games), Vietnamese foods trying, Vietnamese traditional arts (Dong Ho painting, To He, etc.), Vietnamese traditional music (Ca tru), etc.

Interesting museum. All the Vietnam part in 1 museum from North to South , from mountain to the sea. Amazing place for explore Vietnamese Cultural. We lost more than 1 hour in here ,but we really enjoyed our time.

Top Museum. This museum is a little out of central Hanoi, but it is a modern structure in lovely grounds. The museum is well labelled and takes the visitors through the different ethnic people that make up Vietnam. It shows via photos, demonstrations, exhibits, artifacts and panoramas the life styles of the ethnic Vietnamese from the top to the bottom of Vietnam. It makes one realise how diverse the cultures are in Vietnam - but intermingled from province to province.There was also a section devoted to children and sex education. It is very explicit and there appeared to be a number of teenagers taking a great deal of time in this section. We were told that this section houses temporary exhibitions and it changes its theme from time to time.After exiting the museum building, the surrounding parkland has a number of ethic house reconstructions scattered through it. The grounds have a couple of cafe/restaurants to refresh oneself (it was extremely hot on the day we visited), and the always present shop selling arts and crafts. It appears to be a good destination for locals and their children judging by the number of people visiting.
City Tour. Had good tour guide for this trip so it was really worth the tour, recommend doing the tour of this Museum

Educational Museum. Gave a good insight into the geography, ethnology and history of the Vietnam. And the cafe was set up to help disadvantaged students gain the expertise and experience they need to find jobs in the hospitality industry.

An interesting couple of hours. Spent several hours wondering around this interesting museum. If you are remotely interested in the native population & heritage of this region I strongly urge you to spend a little time meandering around here.
Well presented & interesting.

Really Interesting. I went with a guide from Hanoi Free Guides, which was a great benefit. I really like learning about other cultures, so this new museum was right up my alley. The exhibits give you a good idea of the different ethnic groups. The signs are in English, so you get the full benefit. The many videos show you a fascinating view of cultural events you would never get to see. I especially liked being able to see the different types of housing and walking through, trying to imagine how people lived in these structures.
Interesting. An interesting museum where we can understand out Vietnam Ethnics. For those who love photography, you may find the houses in this museum interesting. They are really beatiful

A must see if you plan travelling to the highlands / west of the country. Vietnam's history is complex and characterised by conflict. Caught up in the periphery have been the hill tribes on the Cambodian / Lao border.This museum provides a terrific insight into the diversity of cultures that make up the fabric of Vietnam.Knowing something of the history of the French and American wars I was also aware that some of these groups were indifferent to the unification objective and some sided with the losing side, so I do wonder what became of them. I saw no mention for example of the Monignards.That aside this museum is a very good quality presentation of the way of life of these tribes.The thing I found most fascinating were the houses constructed in the grounds. Some were simply stunning in their functionality and the techniques used in construction. They were all off the ground and generally incorporated features that promoted airflow Reality was less impressive when we got to Sa Pa and visited a Hmong village which exhibited the impact of poverty and a changing environment. Folks lived on the ground rather than above it and the structures although solid, were windowless and dark airless places. Perhaps it is a reflection of declining control over their environment and economy as their land and lifestyle is being enroached upon by the new Vietnam as ethnic Viets buy up surrounding land.All that aside though the Museum is a great place to inform one's grasp of Vietnam's ethnic diversity.

Great museum. This is an excellent museum. There is a good amount of information in the main building. The outside portion of the museum is great. There was even a water puppet show going on while I was there. Don't forget the building to the right of the main museum, which has information and artifacts from other south east Asian countries.

Great way to learn about Vietnamese culture. This museum teaches you about the 54 different ethnic groups in Vietnam, their cultures and traditions as well as life size houses that the different groups live in. You should not miss it.
Fastinating. A great insight into the 54 ethic groups who make up Vietnam. The outdoor houses are especially interesting

Very interesting. I visited this museum just before travelling to Sapa and it really helped me to understand the diversity of the ethnics in Vietnam. Good amount of displays and videos of ceremonies from different tribes. Sadly quite far away from city center...

World-class museum - but go for the houses on stilts!. Brilliant museum with a large outdoor area with lots of full size examples of different traditional houses and information about how they were constructed. Totally recommend this - kids will love scrambling up the ladders into the stilt houses and adults will appreciate the relative calm away from the old town in Hanoi. A truly excellent world-class small museum.
worth a visit. worth a visit don't miss it when you are around. Their outside real time structures are beautiful. liked the water puppet show.
Worth a visit. This was really interesting, especially the outside display of houses. A guide is a must. The costumes of the different ethnic groups were quite amazing.
Insight into Vietnamese Traditional Living. Many different styles of houses to walk round, different cultures and experiences. Indoors lots to see too.

Don't miss the SE Asian museum next door. The museum of ethnology is very good but most tourists seem to miss the South-East Asian museum next door which is part of the museum and is new. It's more object-focused comparing items from across the region. The cafe nearby is also good and the young trainees are very eager to serve.
Comprehensive but monotonous. The collection of displays covers a huge number of tribes. Comprehensive and well maintained, but a bit monotonous after a while.

Fascinating museum highlighting different cultural groups in Vietnam.. This museum is great, with so much interesting information showing the way of life of different ethnic groups in Vietnam. The outside garden is especially good with actual houses from each of the different groups and you can see how they live. You could spend hours there exploring and reading everything. Lots of artefacts and videos to look at.
very exciting!. not too far from centre of hanoi, there are many interesting ask and answers question around vietnam museum of ethnology, which i found very posive!

A bit of history. We enjoy getting to know the history of the culture and location we are traveling in. The Museum was recommended to us by a travel guide. It was great to learn about the wide ethnic groups, living environments and lifestyles of the people.

Really interesting look at rural life in Vietnam. We visited in April 2014 with guides from Hanoi Kids. Having them along to explain the exhibits and answer questions made for a really positive and interesting experience. I'm sure we got far more out of it that way than we would have just wandering around on our own.

A great introduction. Not far from Hanoi centre, this museum gives you a great insight into Vietnam, its culture, ceremonies and differing areas. There are a number of houses that have been built in the grounds of the museum which are very interesting.
This museum is well recommended as a first stop before you launch into the wider Vietnam.

Worth a visit. Fascinating place. Minimal charge to enter. Great historical display inside regarding the ethnic diversity within Vietnam plus an excellent outdoor display of regional houses and other exhibits. Something for adults and kids alike.
Vietnam culture in a nutshell.. A really concise way to understand the vietnamese culture. Of course there would be so much more but a wonderful introduction. Beautiful peaceful place to visit.

A Day Well Spent!. What a wonderful cultural experience! In every respect this educational attraction fulfilled our expectations. Having visited museums the world over, we were still enthralled with the presentation and high quality of exhibits. We took countless photos, but choosing several to display here couldn't begin to capture the *timeless magic* conveyed by this experience. Do watch your head, if you're tall. Remember that our generation(s) are far taller than those before us. While an uplifting experience is one thing, a head-whacking encounter is quite another! :)
People diversity. Museum well laid out . learned a lot about the ethnic minorities of Vietnam . Maps and tools used very effective
Amazing museum. I go a few times every year. Number one place I recommend to visitors. Fantastic outdoor exhibits. Great place to bring kids.

Well worth spending time. Glad we had a guide.. We visited with guides from the Hanoikids guide service and they were utterly fabulous. The housing exhibits were interesting but our guides bought it to life, especially for my boys.

Amazing and interesting. I visited the museum yesterday. I was amazed with both the in and out door exhibits. Very interesting information on the minorities tribes. The outdoor exhibits on the houses of the minorities were wonderful - you can actually go into the houses and look at the different structure & layout. Don't missed it !
Fabulous Cultural Costumes and model Homes.. I would recommend this museum to everyone who has an interest in Vietnamese culture. There is lots of room to grow in its new building.
Interesting. By the end of the visit we had a greater appreciation of the origins of Vietnamese people. Very interesting displays.
Do not miss this. This is a brilliant museum with lots of dwelling places from different tribes to explore outside and wonderful costumes and other exhibits inside
Great. Information was good. The museum was full of interesting things about past Vietnamese culture. Interesting buildings in the gardens.

Worth it just for the model houses. We visited Sapa and saw lots of H'mong houses but it was really nice to see some examples from the ethic minorities across the country. Again we'd seen lots of traditional clothing in Sapa but it was nice to see even more here. Teen sex and relationships (temporary I think) exhibition was actually pretty funny (condom sculptures) and also interesting (modern teens views on homosexuality and sex before marriage etc).

Don't miss this museum!. This museum has great exhibitions about the many tribes that Vietnam is comprised of - including actual houses, clothing, etc. They even have water puppet performances. Several people told us to see it instead of the art museum

Interesting for adult and children. The most interesting museum I have ever gone! I go here every year with my foreign friends or some children. They hold many interesting activities on Public holiday.
Very interesting. One of the fine attractions in Hanoi. Lots of history about the ethnic groups in Vietnam . Well worth a visit but allow 3 to 4 hours

A oignant reminder of the sacrifices of the Vietnamese women. A beatifully constructed display about women, not only in the war but also of the tribal areas. Captions are in English with lots of videos. Worth a gentle wander and a great tribute to women. We have nothing like that here.

Overview of the peoples of Vietnam. Well presented, good displays which were well maintained. Good examples of homes in the outside open-air display.Provides a good understanding of the many ethnic groups in Vietnam.

Vietnam one stop for all!!. The museum was really educating with their collections, including clothes, video, tools, even houses that built by original tribe. There are around 10houses also tomb put as out door exhibition. Some houses were brought directly and rebuild in the museum.There also puppet water show on weekend start around 2pm (no fee for this - entrance fee 40k vnd).If you come during special even (during tet - Vietnam new year and spring festival) there will be some traditional game as well, where you can join.

Concentrated Glimpse of Wide Ethnic Diversity. Interesting exhibits cover the 54 ethnic groups that spilled over into surrounding countries like Thailand, Laos, and Myanmar. We particularly liked the outdoor exhibits which included houses typical of the Cham, Tay, Hmong, Bahnar, Giarai, Ede, Yao, Hani, and Viet.

Give it the time it deserves. Came here as part of a tour, and really wish I'd been able to come alone and walk through at my own pace. This museum sheds a lot of light on parts of Vietnamese culture most people visiting probably have no clue about - learning just how many ethnicities make up Vietnam, as well as their different traditions and cultures was fascinating, and wish I'd had time to properly appreciate it.The highlight is definitely the houses built in the gardens - have water puppet theatre too so make a point to check it out after the museum.

54 ethnic groups. We were quite surprised to learn that Vietnam has 54 ethnic groups. The museum is not just one building but several life sized models of dwellings of the major ethnic groups. Visitors may enter those dwellings. There is also a main three storey building which one will recognise as a 'proper' museum. Interesting and informative. One will need 2-3 hours to go through all the exhibits.

Very little to see in museum.. Inside museum very little to see. Disappointing. We looked at the houses from different parts in Vietnam, outside in open area, and thought them fascinating. Overall worth a visit.

A lot to learn. Loved all the exhibits on the different ethnic groups that live throughout Vietnam. I didn't realize the diversity of the country.
Only not good thing is that the restrooms were disgusting- worst I've seen anywhere!

Worth a visit. We ended up being rushed through this by our guide but really enjoyed the experience. We felt it was well set out, a variety of displays and a good break from shopping. We were a little surprised the ethnic displays seemed to mostly cover the northern areas with less attention to southern fringes, but maybe we missed that bit??

A good start. It was our first stop in our itinerary for the day. The taxi didnt exactly know where it is. He made a few stops before we got here. It was nice to get a glimpse of all the many ethnic groups and their culture. Even though it was raining, we walked outside where there were replicas of the houses of the different minority groups and had fun taking pictures. You can actually go inside these houses.

Museum's aren't my thing. To give this place credit, where credit's due: it is educational and has some interesting aspects, but I did feel that I could have got this from searching the internet. Others in our small group enjoyed it more than visiting a temple, but I just found it boring. Models of the houses alongside photographs. Some ethnic minority costumes in cabinets basically sums it up. I was also biased as we were lucky enough to be spending 4 weeks in Vietnam and seeing a lot of the exhibits over the course of the trip up close and more personal than visiting this museum.

The best museum in Hanoi. You need a few hours for this one..There is a nice display in the museum and the new south asia wing is very interesting but the highlight in my eyes is the outdoor exhibition.Genuine village houses built especially for the museum, very interesting and authentic.you can go there with a local bus from the lake, its very easy.recomended..

Great for the kids!. This was good for the family to see the traditional homes set up, you could walk around to discover the different homes form different areas of Vietnam. Inside they also had items that were used in day to day life. There was a performance at lunch of a water puppet show. It was a hot day and the kids were very tired after.

great place to start your vietnam adventure as it explains all about the country. It is a little bit out from the old quarter VND100000 taxi fare to get there we all enjoyed this museum as it explained all the different tribes of vietnam in all facets of life we also went outside and climbed thru the different types of housing definitely worth the visit there 2.5 hours

Good. An interesting museum. Well laid out. Lots of information in a variety of languages. Gets a bit repetitive after a while though. Favourite part was outside where they have replicas of some buildings that you can go in.
Small but beautiful. Perfect for foreingers want to explore Vietnamese cultures and ethnics. however the museum is quite small.

Good overview of Vietnam's Ethnic minorities. The inddor museum needs a refresh -- seems to be dated from the 1960's, but does give an overview of the ethnic peoples in Vietnam. The outdoor part of the museum has various structures from local villages, relocated to this museum in downtown Hanoi

Set a foundation for enjoying and understanding the rest of our trip. Our guide suggested altering our itinerary to go here, and I'm glad we did. We're not much for museums, but this one really helped us understand the history of the Vietnamese people. In the following days as we toured villages outside Hanoi and later Sapa, Ha Long, and Hue, we were able to refer back to what we'd seen here. I feel like we gained a greater appreciation for the traditional lifestyle that is still very much alive in the rural parts of the country. The exhibits were excellent, comprehensive, and most importantly if you don't have a guide: translated into English! It then continues outside, where there are a dozen or so example traditional homes as built by people in different parts of the country. We visited on a weekend day, and so at the time they were inhabited by members of the tribes which they represented.Really interesting and ought to be a stop on any trip, especially if you plan to travel up to Sapa or visit any of the other smaller villages.

Learn about the peoples of Vietnam.. Included as part of a day tour of Hanoi. There is an extra charge if you want to take photographs with anything other than a compact camera. Given the choice I would rather have visited one of several other museums in Hanoi, but there was plenty of interest to see, especailly the ethnic clothing and textiles.The weather was poor during our visit, so we didn't take in the outside exhibits, but you can walk round the outside of the first floor of the museum to see what is going on.

Culturalistic. It's fun and interesting getting to know the cultural of the different ethnic in Vietnam. What I like the most about this place, is the the outdoor park which allow one to personally experience the lifestyle of the different ethnic. I came here with Hanoi kids, which serve as our tour guide in explaining the unique history of each ethnic group. It will be easier if you hired a local tour guide or Hanoi kids to go with you. There is an indoor museum as well, but to me it's not as interesting as the outdoor park

Fanscinating. This was one of my favourite places to visit in Hanoi. Gives great insight into Vietnamese culture, history, ethnicities & traditions. Our time here was limited but would have definitely have liked to have stayed longer to fully appreciate all it had to offer

Really a wonderful presented museum on the 54 ethnic Vietnamese minorities. Definitely worth a trip to this great museum. Very good descriptions in English however the videos throughout are only in Vietnamese but well worth watching. Not to be missed.

Worth the trip out to the museum. Nicely done museum describing the culture and heritage of the Vietnamese people. It was helpful to learn about the Viet and the other ethnicities throughout the country to better understand the culture. Outside of the museum are neat full-size displays of typical housing from across the country. We also planned to attend when we could see the water puppet play. The water puppets are uniquely Vietnamese, so while some of play is lost in translation, it's something you need to see. If you're in Hanoi for 2-3 days, I would recommend making the trek out.

Beautiful museum. You can learn a lot about the people of vietnam, the viets and the 53 minorities living there. Pictures and things tell you about the culture.For all people who visit vietnam I recommend to visit that museum.

Great museum. I liked the replicas which had been built outside showing the different ethnic housing. Inside I also enjoyed seeing the different ethnic clothing and how they were made. It was interesting to see the maps of Vietnam and where the different ethnic groups live and where they came from.

Great insight in the vietnamese culture. Rich museum with full explanations in English and French. Beautiful recreations of everyday life and special occasions. Outside the museum offers the possibility of visiting recreation of typical housing from all over Vietnam.

Interesting. Interesting and insighful view of the Vietnamese culture and its various extensions. Spend an hour here if you are into museums. Not the best attraction in Hanoi but insightful nevertheless.

Great museum to learn about the 50 and more Vietnamese ethnic groups. We spent few hours in this museum during our Hanoi visit as suggested by our guide. The museum is about the cultural background of the more than 50 tribes/ethnic groups present in VietNam. Very interesting to understand the cultural diversity of the various groups. I would recommend to visit it with a prepared guide that could focus your attention on specific items making your visit more profitable.

Well worth the visit!. The displays at this museum are excellent and really explain a lot about the different ethnic groups in Vietnam. You get to see the different dress, different ceremonies as well as different dwellings of each group.

Probably the best museum we visited in Vietnam. Very interesting museum about 20 mins drive from the city centre. Explains the various ethnic groups in Vietnam - how & where they live, their customs etc. There are also full scale mock up houses of the different tribes in the surrounding gardens. Probably the best museum we visited in Vietnam and certainly worth the drive out.

A lot of information to take in.. This is a well thought out museum. With so many ethnic groups in Vietnam it is impossible to memorise everything that is on display here. Our guide was helpful in focusing on only some of the groups providing us with interesting stories about each group (e.g. the belief that a man who drinks a lot of alcohol has a big heart!). The reconstructive house gave a good insight into the lives of some groups.

54 ethnics in Vietnam. Visit to this museum chose my guide in Vietnam. I do not regret this visit. Very interesting. Great to see at one place houses, history and way of life of different ethnics in Vietnam.

take a half day & enjoy !. If you are travelling with senior, be prepared. We used wheel chair , but it was broken, and elevator not working.We had lunch at the restaurant (also a school) and is very good. Price was very reasonable as well.

Top Flight Museum. This was a really fascinating museum, with an outdoor array of traditional living quarters that you can walk through and get a sense of how different ethnic groups lived. The indoor component was really well laid out and gave an eye-opening overview of the 54 ethnic groups in Vietnam. We were lucky to find there was a water puppet show on the grounds the day we were there. That was really special.
to go. nice area full of nice shops and great things to see, shame we could not buy inside :) this give you a good understanding of the region

The best museum. The Vietnam Museum of Ethnology is a research centre as well as a public museum that exhibits ethnic groups of Vietnam country. The mission of the Museum surprised me, which are scientific research, documentation, collection, conservation, preserving and exhibition of ethnic groups of the nation. This museum serves as a guide to conservation, technology and research that are specific to the work of an ethnographic museum. They obviously collect a nominal entrance fee and that is usually included in tour price itself. I am a history fan but my wife was more interested in understanding what cloths or food that the different ethnic groups used. Therefore, it was so interesting for her also.

Ethnology museum-Hanoi. This museum is situated in the Cau Giay-district and not very far from the old quarter.The building is modern and the interior spacious with exhibits of the 54 ethnic groups of Vietnam.Inside there are rich collections of antiquities, artwork, costumes, jewelry, music instruments, and agricultural tools.Outside you will find different types of ethnic houses : Tay stilt house , Ede long house, Hmong house, Viet house with tiled roof.The garden has little paths, ponds and bridges and because of TET, different ethnic groups were performing.We liked best the outside part although there were huge crowds with MANY loud children ( school-vacations for TET )

Best way to learn about the different ways of life. My husband and I enjoyed learning all about the life styles and beliefs of the different ethnic groups within the population in Vietnam. Performances of crafts, artisans and traditional art As well as being able to go through their housing styles were so interesting. We never made it into the actual museum as we spent our time mainly outside with the houses of the different ethnic groups. I also found the Museum shop had many craft items that are original and interesting.

What a fantastic museum!. What a fantastic and educationally rich museum. The out door exhibits were fascinating and very rich in detail and history. We spent about an hour visiting the replicas of the various houses. The large building has so many exhibits and much new and exciting information about the various ethnic groups in the North.You need at least three hours to take in all the data. Great displays and lots of information. The new building has only one floor set up, but well worth the time to walk through. The gift shop is amazing and had many artifacts for sale. This was one of themost interesting museums we visited during our trip. Now I am very interested to visit the indigenous peoples of North Vietnamon my next trip.

Really Good. I have to admit, I'm a museum hater, but after visiting the Ethnology Museum in Vietnam, I could well become a museum lover! This place is awesome, mainly because of the fact it has so much going on outside. Outside there are mock ups of various tribal houses, they are beautifully put together and unlike with many museums you actually get to go in, climb up and experience a little of what it must be like to live in these huts. Also outside was a puppet theatre, which was cute too! Inside there were lots of interactive attractions and unlike most museums everything wasnt behind glass. Well done Hoi An you made me like a museum! Definitely worth a visit.

We stayed all day. This is one fascinating museum! From the displays, dioramas and explanations of tribal life to the various traditional houses outside, we now have a better understanding of life in Vietnam. There was also an excellent temporary exhibition dealing with sexuality. We stayed all day, and ate in the museum restaurant. Highly recommended!

Fascinating. If you are a little bit interested in the country you are traveling, you must see the museum. It explains a lot about all the minorities in Vietnam and you will be able to understand better if you go then to Sapa or any other area where ethnicity are living.
Interesting Museum. If you like museums, its not too bad. Something for everyone. A museum you can wander through fast or slow and still get something.

Culture Exploration. You want to know what I'm going to say about this place :D,It extremely amazing.You can watch many cultural item like clothes and other stuff.Hell,even the people over there is nice.Do not miss it and do not turn your head off this place or you will definately miss this place and i assure about it.This is a must come place

Well Worth a Visit. We found this museum very interesting. As well as the excellent presentation of the diverse ethnic minority groups, the section covering the present-day school system, particularly regarding social and sexual education is very impressive and made us think that we in the west could benefit from this open approach.
Do not miss!. Cannot say enough good things about it. Information on the many ethnic tribes living in Vietnam and their cultures, clothes, etc.

Excellent insights to Vietnam's ethnic groups. The outdoor exhibits showing different ethic minority living quarters are very interesting. Good place to stroll around and learn about the tribal groups in Vietnam.

Ho Chi Min was a great leader and loved by his people. A not too biased view of the results of the American War on Vietnam as seen from their perspective. Well worth a visit, at least its open more than 8 hours a day, not like the Ho Chi Min Monument.

This museum is a must for any visitor to Hanoi.. The museum is an outdoor museum with an excellent explanation of the way of life in earlier days. Visitors will be interested in the unique "homes" and burial traditions of the time.

"never getting bored". in the Tet festival in the museum, i had chances to play many traditional games of ethnic people, listen to Muong people share about their real life and enjoy very interesting stories. Each time i come to the museum, i find something new and kind of strange. House models and the way they build the house are really impressive. in each house, there are some students who are doing internship here. they friendly, enthusiastically give you very interesting information about the house and special customs. If you just look through then leave, it;s pity because you will never know many stories around, and even, stories that you need to learn a lot in your own life. come and enjoy!!!
Very interesting. A guide is necessary to understand the meaning of this nice museum. Games in the garden makes the visit pleasant
A gem. One of the best places to go to in Hanoi. More information than what you typically get in Vietnamese museums. Outdoor part is best, great spot for kids

Very interesting museum. This museum is very interesting and informative about the 54 ethnic minority groups which have been identified in Vietnam. Our guide's family are from one of the tribes and this made our visit particularly interesting. We spent 2 hours there.

Interesting with a Vietnamese guide close to you. The museum is just huge and interesting but you may get lost with so much information if you do not have a Vietnamese tourist guide. The guide will help you to focus on the most interesting things of the museum the same tine you get a wider and perhaps most interesting overview of Vietnam's multicultural society
Excellent. Very interesting with modern displays of ethnic minorities. The model houses outside were also interesting
museums in Vietnam. This was a great museum and a very interesting way to learn about the different tribes and cultures of this Beautiful country.

Wow! Wonderful! Go and enjoy!. This new-ish museum, which is a 15 to 20 minute cab ride from central Hanoi, is worth visiting. Covering the 50 plus ethnic groups in Vietnam, the museum is thorough, but not overwhelming. The curators have done a wonderful job of selecting items and displaying them attractively. The textiles and basketry are stunning. And, besides the interior display, there is the garden with wonderful ethnic housing! Stunning architecture and a great insight into how these diverse communities lived. Plus a water puppet theater with a show included in the admission price! The on-site restaurant is very good and helps train disadvantaged youth. And the museum shop is managed by Craft Link - a non-profit organization that helps small Vietnamese craft producers. Their items are great souvenirs and gifts and more attractive than what is available in most tourist shops. Enjoy!

Ok for children. My children are young and they weren't very interested in the static museum displays. But the outdoor area where they put up replicas of tribal houses was a draw for them as they could climb in and out of the houses. This museum is fairly interesting for adults too.

Pretty interesting. I'm not a big museum fan, but quite enjoyed this one. There are heaps of displays (inside) on the different tribes/ethnic minorities in Vietnam and their traditions. With my short attention span, I made it around but was ready to go outside! Outside they have examples of the various types of houses - full scale and most of them were actual houses that have ended up at the museum! You can go inside or just look outside - and as long as you paid some attention inside the museum, you'll know what everything is for :) If you are interested in people, you'll enjoy this!

Ethnology museum. Good overview of the different ethnic populations inside and outside where there was also a folkloric performance.As we have seen so many quite similar museums we were not very impressed also because there were a lot of famiies with many LOUD children ( Viet Newyear vacation )

It was a really interesting community spot.. The Museum was nice, but there were outdoor events the day I went that made it even better. There are things to see on the grounds as well as their own restaurant that has good tasting local dishes at a good price. You can relax and eat indoors or out. It was a nice rest between the museum and the grounds.
Worth a visit in Hanoi. Don't miss the outdoor section where you can wander through the different types of traditional homes. The craft link store on the way out is worth a visit as well.

Indoor and Outdoor Museum. You have a chance to enter homes through the ages, and to see people working at traditional crafts. There are plenty of staff to answer questions in the outside bit. Inside it is just as good. Some bits still being added.

Great museum- must go. This was very unique museum. It shows a large background of all ethnic groups in Vietnam. It explained for connect relationship with some countries in South East Asia. They show many information with picture, video in history and at the present and real ethnic's houses indoor and outdoor. I were very excited in getting information and knowledge about that. If you are lucky, you can get water puppet show outdoor at weekend noon under great performance. You will need around 2 hours to sightseeing and enjoy it. That is very worth to see.

Very interesting and well done museum. This museum flowed well and the displays were excellent. The child/youth area was very well done. This would be a good museum to bring children to because of the displays. If you haven't seen a water puppet show you can see one here.

Fascinating. While not fancy by modern museum standards, this museum does an excellent job of depicting the various tribes and cultures of Vietnam which are far more diverse than I previously knew. a very enjoyable learning experience. Be prepared for a lot of reading but kids may be interested in the various cultural diplays.

Interactive and engaging. This was a great background of all the ethnic groups in Vietnam. I really enjoyed the outdoor activities - the museum had volunteers running the different activities and educating visitors.

A Good Insight. A very modern, well organised museum detailing the 50 odd different tribes of Vietnam. Especially good were the outside buildings, where authentic replications of various dwellings were on display.

Very informative about the tribes of Vietnam.. I went to this museum after taking a 9 day motorcycle tour of northern Vietnam. I can definitely say that it is a good representation of the different tribes of Vietnam. The museum has many lifelike scenes as well as videos that show you what they are like. There is also an extensive display of artifacts here as well. I think I could have spent more time here if I wasn't trying to see so many other places. Definitely recommended if you get to Hanoi.

Less is more. A well-laid-out, modern museum that does not try to do too much. Inside some carefull-chosen exhibits covering the 53 ethnic groupings in Vietnam, with good tools, textiles and use of videos. Out back transported longhouses and other dwellings from around Vietnam, also a water puppet theatre that does brief shows. An excellent restaurant offering opportunities to disadvantaged youths. We spent 5 hours there and had a great time.

A must-see for visitors interested in the cultures of Vietnam. Carefully designed by ethnology/anthropology experts. Informative, reliable and interesting. A great place for children too, with an extensive garden. The restaurant inside is OK.

Excellent visit - give yourself Plenty time. First tip, get a taxi there - long way out of the Old Town. Second tip - get there for the first free water puppet show at 10am - this one is a little quieter than the later shows. Third tip - enjoy! Great museum - particularly liked the houses which recreate traditional tribal houses. Great cafe as well which is run as a training school for disadvantaged kids.

Great insight into different cultural groups. Very informative museum with good selection of exhibits and insightful, interesting information provided in good English. The collection of traditional houses outside were a particular highlight.

Authentic Museum. This is an interesting and educational insight into the living traditions of the Vietnamese. It has many different displays and objects relating to craft making, arts and spiritual practices.

Museum could offer more. Maybe the museum is constrained by its title but in the main it seemed a little repetitious in it's display format. The relief comes from a faces display board and a (hidden?) water puppet show. The format makes the sex ed. section (including venereal disease) appear out of place. Is this section restricted to youth? It certainly is targeted to them. Maybe it shouldn't be, health is an important constituent of Vietnamese ethnic society.

Great little museum. Shows the diverse backgrounds of the Vietnamese people, including their origins, their way of life and the variety and range of cultural activities in the different parts of the country.
Ethnic Culture. Visited on a weekend when the museum was filled with families and kids. I'm not sure which was better the families or the displays of ethnic minorities. Both were worthwhile.

Definitely a must -- gives you insights you won't get elsewhere. This may not be to everyone's taste, but it was just what I wanted! Visitors to Viet Nam should go, it is a very enjoyable experience. Yes, there were the standard cases of ethnic costumes and implements, but they were extensive, well done and explained, and flanked by VERY useful photographs and some videos. Then there is the external "museum" -- several ethnic houses replicated on site which are totally accessible and give you a real look at how these people live. And this is still "in the here and now". A great way to spend a couple of hours -- heartily recommend.

Excellent insight into Vietnam minorities. Great place to explore many Vietnam minorities and ethnic groups. Beside closed exhibition, you have a outdoor area with houses from different ethnic groups and regions. A must visit in Hanoi.

LOVED IT!!. Quite far to get to from old quarter about 100,000VND. But bargain with taxi driver for less! Really great exhibition on sex ed written by vietnamese teens. That really made the day for me. Great restaurant nearby. Waterpuppet shows were sweet. Childrens playpark with lots of fun activities all free. The museum was 40,000VND - gives you a good idea of the history of vietnamese culture. Pretty to walk around outside. DEFINITELY WORTH A TRIP!
That Great!. I will come here, it very nice.If you go to Vietnam, you should visit the place.Amazing houses from different parts of Vietnam. Worth seeing!
Ethnic. Good overview of ethnic groups in Vietnam, but if you are pressed for time would suggest you only give it an hour or so
very nice. I don't really like museums but this one was different. Very interesting, especially the part outside. Amazing houses from different parts of Vietnam. Worth seeing!

Many ethnic minorities. The museum is well organized and one can see many facets of life in Vietnam. I was surprised to learn how many ethnic minotrities are in Vietnam. If you go to Vietnam, you should visit the place.

Interesting & creative displays. Although a bit further out of the city & taxi driver not sure where to go. We found the displays & information fascinating. It was also pleasant to walk aroung the grounds & enjoy the gardens.

Off-the-scale smashing. When we arrived in Hanoi our guide offered us three museums as our first treat. To be honest the thought of a museum fest after a tiring flight and chaos at the airport was not thrilling. He seemed disappointed so we asked for his recommendation. Thankfully he chose the museum of Ethnology. if only more museums were like this - tons of share-and-do-it stuff, loads of reconstructions to wander around and a very precarious bamboo house on stilts that I just had to climb and see for myself.I'm 62 and felt like a kid for a day.Absolutely brilliant.

Worth visiting, but a guide will help explain the exhibits.. We visited with a private guide who was accompanying us for a tour; he went round the museum with us, undoubtedly helped us to understand the exhibits. The main building is full of life-size tableaus of life in Vietnam and depicts various crafts being practised. But outside there are groups of authentic buildings that have been taken from their original sites and rebuilt in the museum gardens. The guide explained how people live in the different communities that exist in Vietnam (which has many ethnic groups living within its borders, although the majority are Viets). He showed us the kind of house in which he grew up as a boy and explained how the generations look after each other, and how the various indigenous crafts are practised - very interesting. At the end of the visit we saw the Giari tomb, which is surrounded by primitive wood carvings encircling the wooden tomb which are intended to depict the life cycle, but includes notable examples of priapic men and pregnant women; the figures are intended to accompany the dead into the afterlife.

Worth the trek. This museum is west of Hanoi, BUT, easily accessible by the #14 bus which leaves from the north side of Hoan Kiem lake (takes around 30mins and costs a measly 5,000 dong, the tourist info office across the road will write the details on a page to hand to the bus driver if you ask them, this compared to the est'd 140,000 charged for a taxi...)Well worth going to see as it has loads of info on all the different minorities in Vietnam and life size reproductions of at least 6 types of ethnic housing around the back.Cost is 40,000 without paying for camera or video rights, there are also water puppet shows, which I didn't see so can't comment on. The cafe does a lovely lemon tart though...

Well done museum & worth a visit. We thoroughly enjoyed our visit. Excellent displays, well maintained, well signed. Terrific cafe in the garden which is highly recommended for lunch. Ethnic homes in the garden are super. Museum in the morning, shopping in the afternoon!

For whats in the Garden alone!. its a little bit out in the 'burbs but well worth a trip - especially if you have travelled to Sapa. For many the highlight is whats in the garden - a large number of tribal houses recreated in great detail. They are fascinating and bring whats inside in the museum to life. For me the highlight of the museum is the bike with the 800 fish cages - its a feat of structural engineering!!

Interesting and nice. In a modern building of a good architectural quality, an interesting image is given of the dozens of ethnical groups living in Vietnam. The display is attractive and the artefacts interesting, whereas the videos show the tiny world of these communities, subject to a rapid change in customs and beliefs. In the well kept garden a nice series of traditional buildings.

Fabulous!. Wasn't looking to going but boy, was it worth it. So very well done - we were unfortunately in a bit of a rush so couldn't take it in as well as we would have liked. Could have spent so much longer there learning about early Vietnamese life and how their 54 ethnic groups have come about. It's fascintating and well worth a trip

Modern Museum. We needed to get a taxi to this museum but it was worth the effort. The highlight is being able to walk through the various houses. The museum is very modern and you walk away with a better understanding of the the make up of the Vietnamese people. When we left we did not have any problems getting a taxi.

Very interesting museum. We did this museum on the last day of a three week holiday in Indochina, and it was a great way to remind us of what we had seen, and put it all into context. The old houses are very interesting, and if you go at the weekend, there are water puppet shows.

Outside is more interesting - take a guide!. We came here with our HanoiKids guides, who made it a good experience for us. The traditional houses outside were quite interesting and we enjoyed trying to balance on the bamboo monkey bridge... I think this could be a bit boring (although perhaps still worthwhile) without a guide to tell you about it all.Not expensive anyway at 40k for adults or 10k for kids.

Great place to visit in Hanoi. Went to the Museum of Ethonology as part of a tour. If you want to get the most our of this museum I would recommend a tour guide to make this all the more worthwhile. The museum itself gives you good insights into the country and tribal living of many of the Vietnamese (a large Vietnamese population actually lives in tribal areas). The outdoor area makes this museum a little different from others as well. A very interesting museum and well worth a visit.
Plan enough time. We did this as part of a tour but didn't have nearly enough time there. It was a great display of the hill tribe cultures.

Good insight in minority groups!. THE museum is not in THE center, but worth THE trip! I liked THE outdoor part very much! In THE weekends they have waterpuppet shows. There is à Nice restaurant, when you enter at THE right Side ( youngsters can learn à profession in this restaurant). At THE left there is sn other café, but that is more expensive.You can easily spent 3 or 4 hours here.

Best museum in Hanoi. This is definitely the best museum in Hanoi. The main building is well-laid out with educated an informative exhibits. Unlike many museums in Vietnam, everything has been well-translated to English...a giant plus.The real highlight of this museum are many of the original/purpose-built replica dwellings from various ethnic groups scattered around the museum grounds. The Ede loung house and the spectacular Tay house built on stilts are really quite interesting and unique. I've been told that some of the staff actually are living in these dwellings which give them an interesting feel beyond mere museum artifacts. This museum is a little bit outside of tourist Hanoi, so plan on spending $7-8 for a cab ride from the Old Quarter each way. The cafe onsite was pretty disappointing for food and drink, so feel free to give it a pass, although it was a nice place to sit and rest midway through our visit. If you only go to one museum in Vietnam, this is the right museum. Interesting exhibits, good translations, and a minimum of propaganda.
To learn about ethnic minorities in Vietnam. Not a huge one , but well organized and nicely displayed. Especially the presentation of ethnic minorities across the Vietnam.

Outstanding new building just opened. Don't miss the new portion of the museum with the hill tribes treasures and video. The outside features the actual houses that the different tribes live in that were relocated to the museum and you can go inside!

Great museum!!. The museum has three sections, the main museum with the history of Vietnam, a second smaller building with information about Southeast Asia in general, and a section with real-size examples of indigenous houses. Each part of the museum is incredibly interesting. The houses shouldn't be missed. You can walk in the houses and it is truly impressive. We also had lunch at the museum's restaurant. It was great! The food, service, and prices were all excellent!
one of the better museums. as with all the museums in vietnam, none of them are really amazing this one is one of the better ones but is out of the old quarter and not walking distance.

very good. definitely worth doing this before going on a Sa Pa tour to learn more about the different ethnic groups in Vietnam (there are more than 50). got a little overloaded with information towards the end, but then I discovered all the ethnic building (e.g. traditional houses on stilts) in the outside grounds which were fun to explore

Very interesting and great out door setup. If you are interested in minority tribal culture this is the place especially before going to a Sapa.The museum has a specially great out door set up a collection of tribal houses that you can visit and see first hand tribal living and different set up. Really interesting

Great intro to the ethnic minorities and day away from the madness.. If you need a day/half day away from the madness of Hanoi...a taxi ride out here is well worth it! Get your hotel to book a taxi and ask how much is the normal fare...I recall about 140,000 Dong to be about right.The great things about this place is that it explains the history of vietnam, which for us was great as it really set the scene when we went to Sapa.The place is very well laid out and maintained.....its nice to be inside during the hottest part of the day too. The outside is excellent too...visiting the houses was great fun for 2 big kids like us.The water puppets is comedy (probably not 5*)...probably not like the one in central hanoi but still gave you a flavour.....if time is limited in Hanoi then just catch the puppets here and save some time etc.We didn't get a tour and it was fine...we found that if you got a tour it might be a bit too factual and long...there is so much to see....that said maybe print off some facts etc before you go...it will help understand the exhibits.Thanks for reading.

Great Experience. My husband and I really enjoyed this visit. We found it very informative and authentic. We appreciated the English language descriptions and subtitles and thus, did not require a guide. There are numerous displays, videos, maps, and photos with helpful summaries. Information included daily life, ceremonies, spiritual beliefs, and origin of the particular ethnic groups. Outside the museum are reconstructions of traditional dwellings and essentials for daily life. We highly recommend this museum for anyone interested in learning about culture.

Consider this Museum if travelling with kids. Great for kids, I baulked when Hanoi Kids Guide suggested a museum as this isn't usually what my 6 & 7 year old would call a good time. We didn't even go inside, the outside has all the different types of traditional houses from the different regions which they really enjoyed looking at.Also, on the weekend they run a free water puppet show. Across the road is a kids park, you pay a couple of $'s but great to let little legs roam for a while.

Loved it. 52 ethnic groups broken out by linguistic families all represented. A great combination of full sized models, audio visual, photos and text gave a comprehensive overview of all 52 groups. Local young people had also made up a wonderful if temporary display of information, survey results and interviews about sexuality geared toward their peers. I was pleased to see how open they were and how accepting they were of same sex orientation.

54 Ethnic Groups. This museum was truly an eye opener to the diversity of the inhabitants of Vietnam. Each ethnic group has unique architecture, eating habits and clothing that occasionally are truly other worldly. My favourite part of the museum was the outdoor area with buildings made by the ethnic groups themselves, brought in by the government to display their ancestry. Some of the amazing dwellings made of either wood, bamboo or a mixture of both were made in one or two days by 3 or so carpenters, truly an astounding feat.

Not bad if you have nothing else planned. Not one of the most exciting museums in Vietnam, but if you would like to see how some of the old fishing villages lived and their traditions then it's worth the visit. Overall it only took us about 30 minutes to view the whole museum, and it was 20,000 to get it ($1USD).

Amazing place. This place is amazing, and we were all impressed with it, especially the outdoor exhibitions that showed life size houses. It really helped understanding what you had seen inside. The museum gave a great display of the different natives and their way of life. Great having a guide who knew her information and told us lots of information about what we were looking at.

A bit out of the way, but very worth seeing. This is not a giant museum, but does contain quite a lot of material worth seeing, including replicas of houses of the many types found in rural Vietnam. It is opening a new building (which we did not get to see), and that will probably make the exhibits even better.

More than you can absorb. This museum presents an introduction to the many ethnic groups of Vietnam. There are many more details presented than one can absorb. Location, dress, housing, and much more are covered for each group. The outdoor portion of the museum has full sized examples of houses for many of the groups. It was fascinating for this traveler.

great museum with something for all the family. Very interesting museum here with so much history. It helps to understand what Ethnaology is before you start and then it all falls into context. Great visual displays and my kids loved all the houses outside which they could get into and explore. There is a good restaurant in the grounds as well which supports kids from disadvantaged backgrounds and teaches them the trade. Food was good and fast service if not a little wonky! Water pupet show here as well, but the indoor one much more enthralling.
