Many beautiful artifacts. Learned a lot more about the different ethnic groups in Vietnam and the history of the country. The museum is modern with excellent displays and also has a large outdoor area with life size models of the different houses of various ethnic groups

Half day of interesting exhibits at Museum of Ethnology. I went to this museum with a young man from Hanoi Free Walking Tours, which was a good idea as he was very knowledgeable and made it possible to get there by local bus. I like to be able to use public transport to get a better feel for a place. We spent a good part of the morning at the museum - and was able to picture the dress and some of the culture of the many different ethnic groups which make up Vietnam. A very worthwhile trip, especially the replica house behind the main part of the museum.

A must when in Hanoi. Very simple. This museum is a must when you visit Hanoi. On some floors it displays brilliantly all the minority groups of Vietnam with their traditions. Also the most common group, Viet (86%) were well represented. It gave us a lot of insight as the days afterwards we visited minority villages in Sapa.Interestingly, there was a major exhibition, maybe temporary, about childhood, puberty and adolescence in relation to sexuality. The exhibition was very explicit and graphic and served children and young people to warn for sexually transmitted diseases, unwanted pregnancy, sexual harassment, sexual violence etc. There were some pieces of art that, looking closer were made of condoms. It was amazing and very positive to see how progressive and open Vietnam presents this. It should serve as a sample to many western countries.A great 3 hours spent here. Recommended !!

Very interesting and fun to see!. We learned a lot about the ethnic groups of Vietnam, there are 54, and how they lived. Many beautiful artifacts and little videos to watch and learn from. Interesting for the entire family.
Ethonology what?. I didn't know what ethnology was but I was glad I learned it the quick and dirty way here. Wonderful slices of culture so you don't have to gulp everything at the same time.

Informative and Interesting. Different ethnic life-styles and residential! Interesting and a cool experience but I wish our guide was able to explain things better as we were confused on some of the exhibits!

Enjoyable for a quick visit. We had a guide who brought us here and he probably kept us here a bit too long but it was very interesting, particularly the outdoor area with the recreations of typical residential houses and tribal village long houses. I would recommend a1 hour visit.

Best museum in the land. This is a fascinating place with its well presented exhibits relating to the various ethnic groups in the country. Inside the main building are exhibits of clothing, tools, utensils, items associated with weddings, funerals, festivals and daily life in these communities. All have printed information in English, unlike many of the museums, and many include video presentations. Outside, behind this building is a collection of homes built, or transported and rebuilt here by craftsmen from the various ethnic groups. There is a great variety : the traditional Kinh (the majority group) home, a 40metre bamboo longhouse, a Bana communal house, and a mud house from the Mekong are a few examples.There is now a spectacular new building in the grounds housing the Museum of South East Asia with cultural artifacts from the various countries of the region. Only the ground floor is open at this time. It is also worth some time. The museum is a few kilometres west of the old quarter but worth the effort of getting there- there are buses, but the taxi fare is not high. Entrance fee is currently 40 000. I rate this as the best museum in the country. Set aside at least two hours. It is very easy to spend an hour exploring the houses outside.

Interesting little museum. It's quite a little gem for educational purposes.Brand new building which will deteriorate very fast unless it is well maintained: floor has not been cleaned since opening day, I think...Very unfortunate

Tribute to a Rich Diversity of Ethnic Groups. This place brings to life and puts you in touch with the homes, customs, clothing, arts and cultures of the many ethnic groups in VN - and the cafe has good food, is very reasonably priced, and the proceeds serve a worthy cause. Definitely worth spending time here on your Ha Noi visit.

A big day out. Could have spent hours here. 2 large indoor museums to get through and a huge walkway taking you to various 'villages'/huts set up outside. Great opportunity to see a water puppet theatre performance for about 10 mins rather than sitting through an hour at the main water puppet theatre. Beware the huge fun fair over the rd selling balloons and fairy floss if travelling with little ones, it was hard to convince them we weren't going there! Again, mostly pram friendly, a few steps to get up to main museum, outside trail was manageable with pram. We alternated staying outside some hut exhibits with baby while others ventured up and into huts.

Excellent. This is the best Museum in Vietnam. The exhibits were very comprehensive and chockfull of excellent information. The different ethnic groups were clearly displayed with an outdoor area where visitors can see and go into homes indigenous to each region/minority group. Very highly recommended.

Very worth a visit.. Fantastic place to get a great rundown of all the ethnic tribes in Vietnam. How they live, their dress, their handicrafts, even the village houses in the yard at the back of the museum.
Very good.

Must do. This is a well organized museum showing the history of the various cultural groups in Vietnam.
Includes many photos and displays showing clothing, utensils, housing and other stuff.

Large and interesting site. Worth a visit especially if you are interested in the different tribes and their culture in Vietnam. They have reconstructed old village houses, also water puppet show, etc.

Save time for the outdoor exhibits. The main building shows how Vietnam's ethnic groups live with exhibits featuring their attire, household objects and other artifacts.Leave time to tour the outdoor exhibits, including reconstructed homes. This is favorite part of this museum. At least two of these buildings are on stilts, so you'll need to be agile and use hand-carved ladders to climb up more than six feet.Our guide told us construction is underway on a new building adjacent to the main museum. We're not sure how it will be used.

Good to understand the 37 different ethnic groups. The Viet people are the majority, well worth the trip in order to understand the region and understanding that there is a natural north/south divide.

A little out of town. Fantastic museum on the multiple ethnic groups that make up Vietnam. Give lots of information amd can be overwhelming for small kids. The outside has real representative houses of different groups and is great. This is a must on list of things to do in Hanoi. Likely the best museum in Vietnam!

Wonderful exhibits. The museum displays a large number of artifacts from the 54 different ethnic groups found in Vietnam. The woven textiles are superb, the costumes and customs of the peoples are displayed pictorially beside various instruments of daily living. Out side, the typical homes and other structures of the peoples are arranged on a large grounds that is well landscaped and quite lovely. A museum shop is available.

Interesting but becomes a bit samey. This was interesting, enabling the visitor to understand the different ethnicities that make up Vietnam. There are a lot of different coloured costumes, but there are too many to keep my interest up. Don't let that put you off though as there are exhibitions showing the types of houses that they live in and the types of tools that are used to live there everyday lives.

worth a 3 hrs visit before heading to Sa Pa. start from the outdoor exhibition of authentic homes from different minorities. All accessible and very well kept. Then inside a quite complete view of the complex ethnic puzzle of Vietnam. A must before heading to Sa Pa for meeting these population in person

Good Introduction to Vietnam. Large spacious building which was well laid out and provided an insight into the people of Vietnam and the tribal culture and the buildings in the grounds provide the opportunity to see a lot more of traditional Vietnam crafts without having to travel extensively!
Forget all other museums.. This is the museum to go to. It has a great deal of detail about the history of Vietnam. The outdoor exhibits are extremely well done. Plenty to see and well laid out.

Nice to see if you into Ethnology. Quite average but good to see if you have time to better understand the Vietnamese culture and their homes and traditions. Nice outdoor displays which can be quite interactive depending on time availabilty.
Worth a leisurely visit or two. 54 ethnic peoples make up the nation of Viet Nam and they are well represented in photos ,decorations, handcrafts as well as full scale houses, and boats.

should do this on the first day. Very informative museum. We spent most of our time at the outdoor exhibits where the children enjoyed exploring the different ethnic houses. They have the water puppet show here so you can skip the than long puppet show and save your dongs if you just want to see what it is!!

Exceedingly worthwhile!. I'm not a museumaholic but, having been to Sapa, this really added extra to my North Vietnamese experience. Brilliant exhibits done in a very respectful, sympathetic way, interesting text too. Fantastic real houses on about 8 hill tribes outside built by the relevant villagers. Had a excellent coffee and pork skewers in a oven hot bowl (sizzling) in the cafe(not restaurant). Ace!

The outdoor section is better.. If you like museums, chances are you'll like this one. Among the interesting things you get to see are model houses, a water puppet show and fascinating tombs (you'll understand when you see them for yourself). Of course, this museum is not without the various equipment, craft work, clothing etc. which reflect the culture of the people of Vietnam. All these are located in the indoor section of the museum. The explanation provided in different languages (English, Vietnamese, French etc.) is understandable. Brochures are also provided in different languages (English, French, German etc.). Personally, I liked the outdoor section of this museum more, perhaps because of its uniqueness. All in all, a good place to visit.

Well worth a visit.. A bit far from Hanoi center of Old Quarter but Vietnam Museum of Ethnology introduces the musical instruments, the representaion of varied vietnamese lifestyle and other important cultural artifacts. The origins and cultural heritage of the 54 ethnic groups in Vietnam. Informative and interesting place to visit. Well worth a visit.

Really interesting - a must see if you have time!. Vietnam is a large country (almost 90m people) and the museum helps showcase the diversity of its people, their ethnicity, language, livelihood, clothing, crafts, etc. There displays are well laid out and everything is explained at a layman's level in English, French and of course Vietnamese. The model houses outside are really interesting. Also a water puppet show and a couple of cafes. The gift shop and bookstore are quite good too. If you have time in Hanoi I would rate the museum a must see. Cab ride is $4-5 each way. Entrance is about $2.Across the street from the museum is a lake with nice park that was full with families on the Saturday afternoon and women exercising to music, men jogging around the lake - a nice view into the regular Hanoi life.
World Class!. A great museum that helps you understand the diversity of the people of Vietnam. Lovely gardens out back where you can explore authentic structures from the various ethnic groups.
Small but interesting. Can go they this museum in about two hours max. Typical of a history museum with lots of pottery, jewelry and explanations if the various indigenous groups.
learned a lot. We had no idea there were so many ethnic groups in Vietnam. Museum gives a good appreciation. Outside display of the different house styles was impressive.

Very well done but not my choice - Vietnam Museum of Ethnology. Highly recommended by the hotel, we took the long taxi ride to the Vietnam Museum of Ethnology in Hanoi. We didn't stick by our rule to use only Mai Linh or Hanoi Group taxis and paid a high price for straying away, despite the taxi being an official looking one. It is a long way out of the city centre.The Vietnam Museum of Ethnology is extremely well done but we found it boring. It could be that we have travelled to various countries in the Far East and have seen the various ethnic groups and their homesteads for real, so seeing this set-up/scenario of Vietnamese ethnic group living, felt very staged. This is clearly my viewpoint, and I think for many other people, they would find it a fascinating worthwhile place to visit.There are exhibits outside set-up as various Vietnamese homesteads and villages, as well as a huge new building housing various exhibits inside.The highlight for us (a little juvenile perhaps) was a homestead with various wooden carvings, mainly of naked men & women.We used the toilets linked to the restaurant and they were disgusting. On this basis alone I would not eat at the restaurant at the Vietnam Museum of Ethnology.
Good museum. Interesting place, impressive to see some good informative spots and easily reeachable in hanoi. Must go! recommended

underwhelming. This was given such a high rating on TA that I had to visit it.1 hour is more than enough to go through the museum.after going to other open air museums, I was slightly disappointed to see only a few ethnic houses. Still, this is better than being inside the museum.

Kids loved the outdoor exhibits. The indoor exhibits were educational but what was really fun was to visit the houses of the different tribes/ethbic groups in the outdoor garden. It would have been better if they had those self activated walking tour devices for more explaination.
one of best museums in Hanoi. Really interesting museum, probably the best I visited while in hanoi. Really interesting and detailed information, about the history and culture of Vietnam.
Fascinating!. This is a fascinating museum that uncovers the origins and cultural heritage of the 54 ethnic groups in Vietnam..well worth the visit.

Not bad. Not bad but do not know why sex education for youngsters at exhibit in this Museum. There was quite a few good video clip talking about different ethic group in Vietnam but it will be better if there are English subtitle in the video clips.

discover vietnam's diversed culture in one place. it is interesting to learn of vietnam's diversed culture in just one place. of course, nothing beats the real thing but for tourists like me and my family, visiting the ethnography museum was an opportunity for understanding Vietnam better as a nation. the miniature houses and boats, the clothings and costumes of each group of people, the musical instruments, the representaion of varied vietnamese lifestyle and other important cultural artifacts make the museum a must see place while in Hanoi. picture taking is allowed inside the museum so make sure your cameras are charged so you can click them for as long as you want. bring vietman with you as you go home with the pics that you will take.
a must go. Wonderful, good introduction to Vietnam and its culture. Specially nice are the traditional costumes.

Best museum in Hanoi. The Museum of Ethnology presents the variety of peoples in Vietnam, including dress, customs, relics, religion, language, houses. Besides original costumes and artifacts, the presentation media include photographs and videos.It's the only major museum in Hanoi without a political objective and appears to be the only one that has hired a real curator. The exhibits include informative, objective descriptions and are educational.A major bonus is that Craftlink, the non-profit crafts store, has a shop just inside the entrance to the museum grounds.What I liked best: it was a real museum that seeks to educate, not indoctrinate. That's unique in Hanoi.What I liked least: it's a 20 minutes taxi ride from the Hoan Kiem districtAllow 1 1/2 to 2 1/2 hours to explore the museum and its grounds. Photos are allowed, so take a camera.

Very nice. A really big museum with lots of information about the various ethnic cultures in Vietnam - lots of artifacts as well as recreations of various dwelling structures. Block off about two hours for this museum.

Must do when in Hanoi. Make sure you do this excursion - very professionally presented, excellent displays inside and out. The artefacts were exceptional and there's a new building recently added, housing a beautiful collection of SE Asian stuff. Highly recommend this for all ages.

An exceptional place and a must to visit!!!. The visit to this attraction on our itinerary was a bit of an unknown at first but turned out to be an exceptional, informative and interesting place to visit.Not really knowing a lot about the ethnic diversity of Vietnam this museum was certainly a place were you could learn a lot about the 53 or so ethnic minorities that make up about 15% of Vietnams population.The various informative displays are spread over two floors as well as outdoor displays of various styles of housing styles utilised by a number of the minority groups. We only had about an hour and a half at the museum but you could easily spend much more than this.All in all an excellent place to visit and should not be missed by those wanting to know more about the ethnic diversity of Vietnam.
Nice place to know Vietnam people. It is a very good start point to get to know Vietnam people who live where, culture and location. It is well organized and nice educated expirience.
Fascinating. Delightful and informative about the different cultures in Vietnam. Well laid out with many nice displays. Well worth a visit.

Interesting. Request for our tour to include this museum in our itinerary, and we don't regret it! probably the best museum we've visited so far. not many people when we visited, don't need to bear with the crowds to get close to attractions. got to know about cultures and lifestyle of different ethics, and with sample houses for each ethics too. was able to climb up the tall and long houses built by bamboos and woods to really feel what it was like to actually live inside. strangely we saw some teenagers studying and doing revisions alone inside some of the "houses", tucked away at the corner, probably this is the cosy place for them to revise.

Don't miss this. We will never forget the insights given us into the people of Vietnam from visiting the Museum. The presentations were scholarly and yet very attractive. We came as tourists and were humbled by the quality and depth of work put into the displays. The three hours we had there did not do justice to all that we saw and learned about Vietnam. No person who visits Vietnam should miss this Museum, Sure country has its own unique beauty but here we learned about the beauty, history, language and talents of the people who inhabit it.

Great tour. This museum is well organised and set out the different types of home from across Vietnam is well worth the visit. A guide here is worth the money to explain how areas in these homes were used we had Hanoikids who were excellent.
Mid autumn. Visited mid autumn festival and had chance to walk around inside museum. Good history of North people and presentation.

An interesting insight into Vietnamese life. I kept wondering why our guide referred to Ethnic minority groups so much, but a visit to this museum puts the variety of cultures and tribal groups into context. Interesting mix of indoor and outdoor artefacts, including tribal housing and ways of life

Very good museum. You won't regret coming here. Exploring the 54 groups in Vietnam through displays, artifacts and housing, with descriptions in English and French, this museum won't disappoint.
The highlight for me was one of the temporary exhibits on puberty, sex and sexuality. Totally irrelevant, but probably the best sex ed I have ever seen.

Amazing place to help understand Vietnamese cultures. There are so many ethnic groups here and this museum makes them real. You need 2 hours for the tour, but it is well worth it. The outdoor part is of different regional architecture is amazing and tells lots about the social structure of different groups and households.
So much to absorb. There is so much to read & see at this museum. It is really well done & informative. We spent about 4 hrs there & could have stayed longer

Up culture. We spent for whole this afternoon for explore this Museum. Really up culture there. We was very interesting and excited to spent time for get how much acknowledge from here. We like this place alot and will be back if have chance.

Nice if you have an couple of hours to kill. You can get here from the Old Quarter by the number 14 bus (5000 Dong)
Interesting place with good displays of clothing and buildings outside from the minorities. Slightly over-rated and not a must see museum.

Interesting exhibit. What I found to be the most interesting were the various replicas of indigenous people's homes outside of the main building. It is worth a walk through to observe. The inside exhibits were fairly predictable. Worthwhile if you have an interest in the many indigenous groups of Vietnam .

Never new there were so many different cultures in Vietnam. Very nice museum and worth a visit (along with the Mausoleum and Prison). The information and exhibits were well laid out - good summary in English too. Most of the exhibits are visual in nature, so it is not like you are going through the museum and feel like you are reading a book. Some reviewers commented on the kids groups that go through, and yes, there are a ton of kids, but how often do you get to see Vietnamese school children on field trips - enjoy it. They go by real quick and then they are gone!

Interesting but I can read about the history.prefer to see other things. Too much time given over to this place.I can read history etc on line and sometimes when you are travelling you are given too much information which tends to get lost in memory

Interesting place. Spend an hour to visit. partially understand about Vietnam.not only people and culture. Comparing many museum, it is quite simply and downgrade. There should be a guide can explain about since the entrance fee quite expensive.
Interesting!. If you love history, this is a must in your itinerary. I am not bored of museums but for some, they might find it boring. It took us about 3 hours to finish the private tour.

Interesting particularly the houses outside. Lots of information and felt well informed about the different tribes. Though got a little confused as to which tribes were which by the end of it. It was interesting and inspired us to see the morning market when we were in Dong Van (north Vietnam).We enjoyed seeing the outside of the traditional houses and it was interesting to go inside the houses and get a better idea of what they are like. We got there by local bus, which you can take from the side of the lake, near to the water puppet theatre. About an hour away.

Good displays, easy to view. An easy introductions to the various minority tribes. The outside area shows actual traditional homes in different styles so don't skip this part. Good photos and informative posters. Don't need a guide. Useful if you will be visiting any of the minority villages.

Underwhelming. After reading the positive reviews I was very underwhelmed when visiting this museum. There are a couple of interesting artefacts on display but I feel a lot could be done to improve this museum.

Only half an hour away from the cetre. One of my most interesting experiences. Especially after we have visited an ethnic group in the Northern part of Vietnam, it was interesting to see how divers Vietnam is, and to get an idea about the cultural heritage of this country.

A bit of a mish mash. Not a very easy museum to navigate, it is housed in small rooms (for a museum) and each is labelled with the century it referrers to, the only problem is, there is no logical route to follow. There a good number of artefacts, but unfortunately, not for my taste.

So much fun for templed out children.. Our 3 and 5 yo were a little templed out and this was a refreshing change! The museum is awesome for little ones who need a break from the thriving metropolis that is Hanoi. The houses on display are amazing, accessible and fascinating. There was even a goat thrown in for good measure. We had a lovely lunch at Baguette e Chocolat which is just next door. Perfect!

Beautiful. This is a particularly good museum for English speakers with all the exhibits having good English information. Very beautiful both inside and out. Overwhelming number of ethnic minorities to sort out.

Great for a rainy Day. We really liked this museum but we were there when it seemed every school group was there. They had a very interesting exhibit on puberty that kind of surprised us. They museum was well laid out and told a great story. Great displays and use of Video, need to understand the culture a little more to enjoy this museum. DO NOT MISS the outdoor exhibits this is wear you will see actual homes remade here. You can go into them and see how allot of the rural people lived. That is what made the Museum Excellent. On Sundays they have the water puppet show. There is a cost it amounts to about $2.50 a person.

A Visual History of Ethnic Groups. What I really liked about the Museum of Ethnology was the visually attractive displays that showed the lifestyle of each ethnic group in Vietnam. The museum does a good job of highlighting the jobs, the crafts, the lifestyle and the traditions of each group including real sized homes of various groups. It is an interesting place to learn more about Vietnamese culture and minority ethnic groups that make up this country, The museum has a shop right at the exit gate and some of the things are good quality products and reasonably priced too,

Nice place. Very nice place for a day visit. During Tet (Lunar new year) or full moon (mid autumn festival) and some other times in year they have special events with games, foods, prints... from the minority themselves, and volunteers of the museum. Much fun and very special time to learn about the diversity of culture. If you're not going well with the local food or want a decent place to rest, there is a Hoa Sua restaurant at the entrance of the museum (at the right of the front ground of the museum to be precise). Very nice museum also for their amount and depth of the items. We always go to this place with kids at Lunar new year though it's a bit far from the center.

Extensive indoor and outdoor exhibits. Took about 20-30minutes via taxi from our hotel area near the old quarter. Taxi fare cost around 110000 dong each way. Entrance fee for the museum was 40000 dong.Was there on a Saturday and there was a bazaar going on. There were many ethnic minorities there selling handmade souvenirs so we could do some shopping. Not sure whether this happens every weekend.. There were both indoor and outdoor exhibits, which were all very well-maintained. There were also signs in English so we could walk around the museum ourselves and take our time to look at all the exhibits. My favorite area was the outdoor exhibits where the actual houses of some ethnic groups have been moved from their original location to the museum. We also managed to catch the free water puppet show at the outdoor area as it was the weekend.This is a great place to spend around half a day if you are interested in learning more about the 54 ethnic groups in Vietnam.

Outstanding. This is the most unique and interesting museum I visited in Viet Nam (I went to quite a few). It's a bit out of the Old Quarter but a $6, 15 minute taxi ride or a longer, but really cheap, bus ride, is well worth it. Admission is incredibly low, as with all museums in Viet Nam.The museum seems fairly new and modern, or at least well maintained. Exhibit signs are educational and objective and written bilingually (V'ese and English, maybe French?). They also have a museum guide available in several different languages. The exhibits indoor are top notch. Here you can learn about nearly all of Viet Nam's 54 ethnic groups. Some have less than 1000 members and live in such remote locations that this is the only place to get a glimpse of their lives. The real stars of the show are the traditional ethnic homes on the grounds behind the museum. The museum is a must visit if you don't have a chance to visit actual ethnic communities. And if you do, then this museum will have even greater significance. All the homes were built by members of the appropriate minority groups on-site. This place is a gem in Ha Noi and well worth at least a half day of your time.

Museum of Ethnology, Hanoi. A treasure trove of Vietnam's history and culture. Such beautiful pieces on display. We loved the jewellery worn by women in the palace, such delicate and intricate work. A place of peace and quiet in a busy city. We also had coffee in the Museum's cafe. Service was great. We needed a cab and they called one for us which arrived in about 5 seconds. Very courteous service
Gate 1 Tours to Vietnam Museum of Ethnology. Very good history of the people who lived in Vietnam & the changes over time. Need as least 4 -5 hours to really enjoy & learn more.

A great place to visit. We both enjoyed this museum, and had the fun of travelling there by public transport, bus, and then a short walk.It was well worth the effort. Very well displayed, not over-crowded exhibits clearly marked with English captions too. I particularly enjoyed the tribal differences, seeing their crafts, needlework, carving, pottery, and how things varied from tribe to tribe. This was useful when we then journeyed to Sapa and met several tribes of women whilst trekking.

Fascinating and relaxed environment. We spent several hours here in the museum, cafe and the park surrounding it. The main building features artifacts from the many different ethnic groups in Vietnam and these are presented alongside explanations of their significance. The park contains typical buildings from different parts of Vietnam and you are encouraged to enter the buildings and look around. I really liked the inclusion of vegetable gardens and the odd friendly goat.The cafe is a training centre and the staff were really friendly and pleasant. We only had a coffee there but the pastries and other food looked very good.

Interesting place, well worth a visit. This museum gives you a good insight of Vietnam and the different cultures they have. We made the mistake to do visit it on our own, and I believe it is better with a guide. As tehy would be able to tell you more about the way they live, history, clothes, tools, houses,etc...Also be carefull when you get out of the museum. We just took the first taxi that was waititng and it turned out that this meter charged double the amount of what we paid to go.
Well worth a visit. If you have the time, fit this in if you are interested in the history of the people. Very nicely done and extensive.

All about culture of vietnam. To know more about the people of vietnam and its culture, you should visit the museum. There you will see the life of thier ancestors and how they live, make things like basket, tools to hunt animals for food, how they dress, everything about people in vietnam you will see there. Such a nice place if you are interested in those kind of things.yes there is an entrance fee...but remember when you are in vietnam everything is affordable... no need to worry about your budget. Coming to vietnam for 5days, eat whatever i want, roam around the city...i only spend 500$ including 4tours in other area of vietnam and lots of gifts i had shop for my friends back home. The cheapest travel i had.

Nice place. To know more about the people of vietnam, you should visit the museum. There you will see the life of thier ancestors and how they live, make things like basket, tools to hunt animals for food, how they dress, everything about people in vietnam you will see there. Such a nice place if you are interested in those kind of things.yes there is an entrance fee...but remember when you are in vietnam everything is affordable... no need to worry about your budget. Coming to vietnam for 5days, eat whatever i want, roam around the city...i only spend 500$ including 4tours in other area of vietnam and lots of gifts i had shop for my friends back home. The cheapest travel i had.

Indoor/Outdoor display of the many cultures of Vietnam. The best part was the outdoor display of actual houses and buildings that are occupied by the various minorities in Vietnam, most actually built by craftsmen from those villages and territories. Although understanding 54 different minority cultures is daunting, the museum's displays made it possible for us.
Very interesting. This was recommended by our tour company and we were not so sure at first. We were pleasantly surprised at the quality of the displays both inside & outside.

very relaxing. you have the opportunity to admire costumes, embroidery as well as outside stilt houses and habitats from the different groups.All displayed objects mingle and supplement one another to create a colourful and diversified picture of Vietnamese culture.The museum has successfully recreated the daily life together with the religious rituals and the symbolic festivals of each ethnic group in Vietnam.The indoor permanent collection occupies the majority of the exhibition space. However, there is a separate area for the temporary exhibits. The permanent collection is divided into 9 main sections, each of which includes objects displayed in glass cases and dioramasAn open-air exhibition in the museum’s spacious and peaceful ground features ethnic houses from all over Vietnam. “Walking around here makes me feel like I were in a beautiful park, very relaxing!”

Boring Museum very overrated. I found this museum disappointing. It seems the Vietnamese can't do a good museum. Exhibits outside were OK, but seen one wood hut, seen them all. Would rather go to Ho Chi Minh's Museum behind Ho Chi Minhs Mausoleum and to Hoa Lo Prison AKA The Hanoi Hilton. Museum of Ethnology not worth the trip and very overrated.

Historical context. We went here with our Hanoi Kids guides and were glad we did. Their local historical knowledge and explanations made everything more interesting than if we attempted the place ourselves. We found the outdoor exhibits more engaging than the internal ones.

Some good exhibits especially the houses outside.. Interior exhibits similar to those at women's museum. The village of homes from various ethnic groups was interesting. The experience was spoilt by lots of noisy people talking loudly and another group who spent their time screaming at their children who ran loose
worth a visit. This is worth at least half a day - its really interesting and the recreation of life size houses are amazing.

Fascinating outdoor exhibits. The indoor collection is somewhat small, but the museum grounds contain several reconstructions of ethnic minority homes that you can enter and look around. Quite engaging and interesting. Budget 2 USD for admission and 5-7 USD for taxi from the Old Quarter.

Vietnam's other people. A great museum that introduces you to the various ethnic groups other than the Viets that make up Vietnam. A wonderful mixture of colour, heritage and diversity.
We went there as part of another stop in the full day city tour. Will recommend if possible to take half a day to explore in detail.

Outdoors Great, Indoors Disappointing. There are two parts to this museum- indoor displays and an area outside with relocated or recreated traditional buildings (kind of a "pioneer village" concept) of various ethnic groups. The indoor displays were a bit disappointing as the space is limited and tour group crowds made viewing of the displays difficult. Also, the washroom in the museum was the only unclean toilet we had found in any public facility in Vietnam. The outside however, was a real treat. You can enter all of the structures and they provide an excellent insight into traditional living spaces and construction. This museum is worth the visit, but I would suggest focussing on the outdoor areas and if you do want to visit indoors, do it very early in the morning before the tour buses arrive.

Informative and interesting museum. Hanoi has several museums but this one is definitely a must visit. The museum is very informative. It exhibits the minority ethnics who live in Vietnam. It's very informative. It shows their culture and daily life. What I like the most is the ethnic groups house which is displayed outside. It will be much better if they also shows about the history of these ethnic groups and how they formed in Vietnam. Tips: hire a guide it will be more interesting since they will tell you interesting story about display

Can't wait to see Sapa.. I loved the fact that there were external exhibits showing a variety of housing. We were particularly interested In the Northern styles of the Red Zao and Hmong people. so excited,

a different kind of a museum. a great museum to see before going north to sapa region. It portraits the different ethnic groups beautifully with films clothes and actual houses in the back yard of the museum

Definitely not worth the trip. There is a big buzz about it in TA, thats why we went, but it is no big deal. It talks about minorities, but not their history and how they formed vietnam. Its no WOW on the pieces they show and the building itself is no big deal (lonely planet said it was remarcable). It's far away in town, and 130,000 vnd each way by taxi. They charge 50,000 if you want to take photos, but no one seemed to care or enforce this.Its not a bad experience, but its not a must see museum.
Good, well kept. The trip here was good. A wide area to walk. Could get a vast knowledge of the different tribes in Vietnam.The place is clean and well kept.A good place to go for all museum lovers.
Worth a look. This museum is worth a look as it traces the history of the different tribes throughout Vietnam A great selection of native costumes and artefacts to view

Excelent experience. Vietnam Museum of Ethnology has small image of all ethnic in Vietnam. You can see the Vietnam traditional clothes, how did they live in many years ago, how does their houses look like and so on.Especially, Every day, in Vietnam Museum Ethnology also has water paper show.You just have to pay more than 1$ to get inside Vietnam museum of Ethnology.
ethnology. excellent display of the range of ethic groups in Vietnam. Especially liked the outside displays of buildings

Beautiful museum. This is a particularly good museum for English speakers with all the exhibits having good English information. Very beautiful both inside and out. Overwhelming number of ethnic minorities to sort out. The life sized homes and lodges on the grounds were especially nice to walk around in

Nice exhibits to learn more. A friend and I went to the museum independently after arriving in Hanoi in the morning. We taxied over although it is not too far from Hanoi center, since it was raining outside. There was a lot to learn and the information was bountiful, and we had a good time really taking in the environment. The museum is fairly well organized and pleasant to stroll through. Although we weren't really wow'd by it all, it is a good place to pass an afternoon.

Good background on Vietnamese culture. Visited here with two guides from Hanoikids which definitely added to the experience. Particularly enjoyed the outside exhibits of various traditional houses and buildings - we were here prior to heading to Sapa where several of the Vietnamese ethnic minorities live, so the background information here added to our time there. A new SouthEast Asia museum is being built next door so this should be even more interesting once that opens.

So much diversity - so little time. We are told there are 54 ethnic minorities in Vietnam.., presenting that diversity and scale has been achieved well at this museum.The exhibits are displayed in glass cases, with information provided to explain purpose of each item and location. there are scenes from village life, and a house has been included as one display.As with all museums, there is never enough seating to ponder and absorb what is being presented. If taken at a slow walking pace, it fails to do justice to the depth and breadth of information, I came away with a glimpse of the diversity that makes up Vietnam - I wish I had time for a second or third visit.

Good place to explore different ethnics in Vietnam.. The museum is not too far from the Hanoi centre. The best time to visit is October - November when the weather is cooling down. The best bit is to climb up the tall bamboo hut. Handy to have flat shoes. Some traditional costumes are amazing.

Do not miss this. A bit far from the central city, but this is a "don't miss" on your visit to Hanoi. There are excellent exhibits on the various ethnic groups in the main museum, but where this place really shines is one the grounds where various traditional buildings have been constructed. You can climb into them and check the interiors. This one is well worth the effort to visit.

Real experience & traditional. Went here 2 times and really impressvie with me. Very large space, traditional games are vivid. Of course, you can join them. Specially, it would be more games show in special day as Tet festival or Tet of the children (1 June).Had forget experience to see and know deeply about house for person died (it called Nha Mo), popular in Tay Nguyen and make us have colorful imagine.Be advised to visit here once time for some nice photos and enjoy how culture of Vietnam.

worthwhile. Very interesting way to spend a morning/afternoon. You can go by taxi or catch a local bus near the lake & short walk to the museum. The exhibits are wonderful & gives you a fascinating insight into the culture. Best part is outside the museum in the grounds where the traditional buildings/huts have been reconstructed & you can walk into them (may need to remove your shoes on entering some of the buildings so wear something that's easily removable.)

Fascinating and colourful. This museum illustrates the lifestyles of the large number of minority races in Vietnam. Lots of costumes, artefacts and a remarkable collection of full-size replica native houses which you can go inside, one of them nearly 20m high. It is well laid out and easy to reach
Quite interesting. Quite interesting museum, especially the garden area with tribal houses and nice to visit with kids. I recommend.

Superb information and replica houses.. Came here with my Vietnamese girlfriend and spent a very good few hours here. A lot of information about all the ethnic groups in Vietnam and presented in interesting indoor and outdoor exhibits. The outdoor exhibits are the best, for the replica houses. Lots of good photo opportunities.
Interesting. A very interesting museum with lots of great information. The outdoor exhibitions of minority houses were fantastic.

Fantastic if you are not planning to venture of out town. Love it, teaches you about the other 50+ tribes that makes up Vietnam besides the majority who are called the Viets. Nice collection and great place to spend time on.

Fascinating. Some interesting information about the minority groups in Vietnam..lovely costumes and full size houses that the children really enjoyed. It always seems to be raining here so take a raincoat and umbrella and get a taxi as its quite far out
Fascinating. Very interesting and excellent displays. The replicas of accommodation that the different groups used was very well done and gave a good insight into the life of the people.

Worth the trip. Go in good weather because it is mostly outdoors. There are indoor exhibits that explain the variety of minority groups in VietNam and their customs. Good for young and teens because it is small and not overwhelming. Several examples of homes indicative of minority villages are interesting and it is nice to exit the motorbike madness in central Hanoi.

Very interesting. Great insight in the vietnamese culture. Rich museum with full explanations in English and French. Beautiful recreations of everyday life and special occasions. Outside the museum offers the possibility of visiting recreation of typical housing from all over Vietnam. Don't miss it!
Don't miss this. Well organized, informative and provide me with much deeper understanding and appreciation of the diversity of ethnic groups in Vietnam
Cultural. This is a great place to visit to get a good understanding of the cultural history and diversity of Vietnam. Its really well done, and quite fascinating.

Fascinating Museum. Lovely displays inside of the different ethnologies, and then outside some authentic houses and tombs. A great way to start a trip and beginning to understand Vietnamese history and culture.

Fascinating place. Worth the 90,000 dong (entry plus photos) we paid. Great way to see a lot of different cultures within Vietnam, especially if you're only on a short trip. The authenticity of the tribal houses is impressive - all put in place by the tribes they belong to - and it was interesting to compare the different styles of building. Sadly the water puppet show that was supposed to be on wasn't on, but we spent the whole afternoon at the museum anyway. We got there by public bus, number 14, which runs from Hoan Kiem Lake or just north of the Old Quarter, followed by a short walk. The conductor helped us with the right stop and it took about 30-40 minutes from getting on the bus to arriving at the museum. If you don't mind walking a bit, this is a much better way of getting to the museum than a taxi.

My Favorite Museum. This is my favorite Museum. The best part is all the model houses of ethnic minorities that you can actually freely go in. Makes it not as boring as many museums. If you are interested in culture you can't miss this place. Certainly worth a visit and to put on your list of things to do while in Hanoi.

Excellent. This museum is wonderful!!! It is so well set out, very informative, and the displays are excellent. It is so interesting even the children loved it!!! The children loved the life sized scenes displaying the people, farming, culture and the costumes. The biggest surprise was the replicated villages and houses displayed outside of the museum including a giant stilt house!!! Highly recommend visiting and spending a few hours here.
Worth the visit. I wouldn't normally have visited here but my tour guide recommended it. Well worth a couple of hours

Cool place. It is really interesting. I was totally impressed by the Gia Rai Tomb House and Ede Stir-House which is really long. These house and artifacts are something that in Spore we dont have. I specially like traditional games in Ethnology Museum. As I and my friend traveled there on Sunday, there are water puppet performance and camp activities. It is really a unique and exciting museum. Worth a visit!

Enlightening!. Not sure if it was a combination of our exceptional guide with the pleasant layout of the museum but I'm so glad this was on our itinerary. I normally wouldn't choose this kind of museum to visit with only a few days in this extraordinary city - but I'm glad I did. The stories behind the artifacts and the recognition this country gives to its 54 ethnic nationalities is enlightening. This museum even has the actual homes some of these nationalities lived in, which you can walk through and obtain a real appreciation for the many cultures of this country without actually have to go into the regions is a blessing (especially if you don't like to travel on Vietnams railway system). Worth a visit!

Wonderful experience. This would have to be one of the better museums i have been in anywhere in the world. It gave a wonderful appreciation of the variety and diversity of the different cultures that add to making Vietnam the country that it is. it most certainly held my interest, and is well worth the effort of getting to it.

Rare insights. This museum does traditional culture as it should be - just artifacts and information. There's no unnecessary waffle or pseudo-science. It's a bit small and when I went the other buildings listed on the map were inaccessible. But really worth the time.

Interesting and fun. This was one of the best museums we went to in Vietnam. The museum itself contained lots of interesting information and exhibits with some beautiful artifacts and photos. The village of full-size model houses around it showing the different types of house in Vietnam was great fun to explore and very informative. Worth the little taxi ride out of the centre to explore it.

A Museum and Research Centre. This circular museum and research centre is the best peek you will ever have of the unique culture and tradition of Vietnam's 54 ethnic groups. The Discovery Room offers demos on craft making and other performances unique to Vietnam's ethnic groups. The architecture of the place lends really well to the displays. You can also get books on Vietnam often not accessible in the local book stores. Of course, the Museum Shop is a good stop for souvenirs. You don't have to haggle here and the prices are reasonable.

Museum of Ethnology. This is an amazing museum. The display of real house from around Vietnam is fantastic. Well worth the visit and our guide Son was very knowledgable. We really enjoyed this and recommend it to visitors.

Very interesting and engaging. We went with our children and they were interested the whole time. We could walk through replica traditional homes from several Vietnamese ethnic groups.
The museum was also interesting to look through.
We didn't have enough time there as our tour went to a few other places on the day. I would allow at least 2 hours. Thoroughly enjoyable.

nice museum. We started our tour in the out side with the houses of the diverse ethnic groups - nicely laid out and very well done. Then inside to see the many displays of the many different ethnic groups - again nicely done. They have a nice museum shop by the entrance with great examples of their local crafts

Museum of Ethnology. I have visited this museum on several occasions, both with friends and a larger school group. If you don't have time to get to the more remote parts of Vietnam where you are likely to see the many ethnic minorities this is the next best thing. A combination of the static displays inside and the recreation of ethnic house styles on the outer areas. Like all Vietnamese museums entry price is tiny BUT remember museums are closed on Mondays.

Vietnam Museum of Ethnology. If you love this subject (ethnology), you will love this place since it provides you with so much information about the origin of the Vietnamese peoples, the different tribes and their cultures. And even if you don't, I am sure you will still find other interesting things - the model houses built real-size in the outdoors are amazing.Budget to spend about an hour and a half to two hours here. If you are the type that reads the captions accompanying the pictures, then maybe a little more time is required?

Very interesting. We really found this display very good, especially for those of us with limited knowledge of VN history. Particularly liked the outdoor exhibits of primitive achitecture and living conditions. The Vietnamese people touring the village were lots of fun too, especially the youngsters!

Vietnam Museum of Ethnology. the experience is what you make of it. It is not crowded, so you can leisurely see all you want. The costumes and objects of the many ethnic groups in Vietnam's history are interesting. So are the various building types, some of which most city dwelling vietnamese have never seen. It's a roomy, modern building, unlike the Hanoi Hilton whch has to be old an representative.One of the major delights at this museum is a free, small Water Puppet show everyone will enjoy

Wonderful experience. Both the indoor exhibits and outdoor were fascinating. The outdoor featured native Viet huts and housing of all sorts of tribes. The indoor featured their traditional foods, baskets, clothing, and more information pretaining to each tribe. Very interesting and colorful.

A Cultural Playground. I enjoyed the indoor exhibits, but the outdoor exhibits of native/traditional types of Vietnamese housing stole the show with our 3 kids. They loved climbing, exploring and running around!

nice trip. My visit to this museum was with my boyfriend, and our visit was nothing less than wonderful. The museum is divided into 2 big parts, the outdoor part, and the indoor one; in the outdoor part, we could learn a lot about building and houses of traditional Vietnamese tribes, and we could also interact with the structure.For my personal taste, the information is all provided very well in English, so a guide won't be a real necessity; but it will take some more time for you to read the whole information on an exhibit, so prepare a longer time.
for the history buffs. If you are really into history you'll love this place. I prefered the outdoor exhibit to the indoor one.

Well worth a visit. We have just got back from here and loved it - so educational and interesting - it covers the various minorities in Vietnam including but not limited to various living structures outside, a water puppet show and a gaggle of Vietnamese teenagers wanting to practice their English - we stayed there much longer than expected and even my husband was not bored.....This is a must see.

History and Culture lovers must do. The Museum offers great insights to the history, culture and beautiful arts (textiles, ceramics, metalworking, more) of the many ethnic and tribal groups present in Vietnam. It is well worth a visit.

Diverse inside and out. This museum gives a real window into the many ethnicities that make up Vietnam, and includes comprehensive depictions of each group. The museum grounds outside the main building have a host of ethnic villages set up, a fitting accompaniment to the smaller and more personal items associated with each ethnic group inside the main building. There is also a pleasant and affordable restaurant on the grounds where you can get that great Vietnamese coffee. It is well worth the taxi ride to get here.

Information packed!. A really worthwhile visit. Lots of interesting information on all the different tribes that make up Vietnam. Plenty of displays including full sized houses in the gardens to wander through. A water puppet show runs throughout the day. A great little cafe on site which trains disadvantaged kids in hospitality.

Definitely worth visiting! So much to see (visual displays, information boards, and houses). There are so many different ethnic groups in Vietnam so the museum is really interesting to look around. The information here at the Musuem is fascinating and plentiful (in Vietnamese, English and French).Part of its attraction is also the grounds which have replica houses to explore representing many ethnicities and are fascinating to look through. I wear my plastic poncho and walk tightrope style on the thick concrete kerbs of the paths, occasionally needing to leap to the next concrete iceberg. If I misstep it will be into a miniature brown river complete with small swimming frogs passing by me.The different ethnic groups differ so much. Housing styles, clothing, customs, patriachal / matriachal villages. Many of the houses have great meaning to their design and the compass orientation of the house is important (as is the direction of the head while sleeping). I love that the houses here have been actually built on site by the respective tribe according to custom.I watch the water puppet show and look through the exhibit. There are 15 active troupes in Vietnam and they take turns performing here. The stories they perform are unique to each troup and the ways of the puppetry are closely guarded secrets. Traditionally invitation to join has been from father to son although that has relaxed a little now.I also visit a not for profit & disadvantaged youth restaurant on the grounds. I have a comfortable wicker seat on a semi covered porch, a breeze, and the sound of rain overhead. They have Nem cua be (fried spring rolls with crab) and when I ask the waitress which Viet dessert she recommends selects Che sua chua nep cam (sweetened black rice porridge with yoghurt). I loved the dessert and wasn't able to find it exactly again!

Real Life Vietnam in One Place. The best part of this museum are the real buildings outside that have been moved here. They are from different areas in Vietnam showing various aspects of life in Vietnam.
well worth the visit. fantastic pictures and exhibits representing the entire country. There is also a very nice shop just outside with local crafts.

Excellent - don't miss the village huts and the food. An interesting sample of Vietnamese history that would benefit from air conditioning as it gets hot and stuffy on warm days.The examples of village huts in the grounds were good to see and walking through the range of buildings and styles from the different regions helped showcase the materials and designs used by different minority groups across the country.The highlight for us was the restaurant in the grounds "Baguette and Chocolate". The food proved to be excellent and included some interesting deserts, we particularly loved the treatment of black sticky rice and apple crumble and wish we had been able to save room for the pastries. Prices were reasonable and the social benefits associated with the restaurant are a plus.

Well worth it if you are going trekking in Sapa. I am not normally a museum person. The biggest attraction of this museum is all the model tribal houses outside that you can wander through. The main museum inside is interesting but you get confused with all the different tribes and their artifacts. Very hot inside, no air.

Charming museum of diverse cultures.. This newish Museum in Hanoi tells the story of the 54 various ethnic groups who make up the population of the old Indochine area of SE Asia. There are some very nice artifacts displayed with labeling in both local languages and English and one can arrange for a guided tour. A number of displays of the various costumes and cultures are well set out. You do get a feel for the diversity of the various tribes and groups that have existed in SE Asia for so many centuries and how they interact. The large floor area is however fairly sparsely occupied and it would have been nice to see more in the collection, maybe this will occur over time. The entry fee is modest (some 40,000 VND). Access is a bit difficult as the Museum is some way out of town and best serviced by a taxi if you are not comfortable trying local buses. Fortunately there is a taxi stand outside the Museum so that you can return easily to your hotel. Allow 1-2 hours.

A must to visit!. A museum of modern design (setup with help of france and its experts) very educational. In this museum we take an overview of all the peoples and minoritis living in the territory ofVietnam. The customs, the tradition, the origins and history of these people, are explained by means of installations that repriduce the homes. Outdoor muesum are displaying housesin diferent Architeture of difernet region of vietnamIt is really worth to visit!
Useful!. I found this museum so interesting and worth visiting. I like the houses of all minorities in Vietnam. Have to spend the whole day to explore everything here :)
interesting museum. very interesting to get to know the story of the 54 tribes of Vietnam. Not very big, you see it all in one hr.

Museum of Ethonology a quick cheap interesting tour.. This museum surprised the tour group i took. Our tour guide Toi (from Footprint) was very knowledgable and a bit of a character which made everyone relaxed and thirsty really interested in learning at this museum. We all loved it as it was a fairly quick easy tour. Look for the push bike loaded up with 800 fish traps. For a quick cheap interesting cultural visit i would recommend this tour .

Ethnicity Museum worth a visit. There are a number of museums in Hanoi, we have chosen to visit this museum. It tells you how diverse Vietnam is. There are many ethnic groups living in Vietnam, can easily spend two hours here.Definitely worth a visit.

Not to be missed. Lots of information about the many tribal groups in Vietnam and the surrounding region. Well presented and every was well described. The demonstration villages were particularly interesting.
A History Lesson. Informative and enlightening. A great experience. You should definitely visit before going on tours. It will give you a lot of information.

Very cool museum. This was one of the highlights of our trip to Hanoi. The inside was very cool, with a lot of detailed information about the various ethnic groups living in the region and a lot of models built in miniature of ethnic dwellings. However, outside is where the real fun was. The built to scale traditional homes that you could climb in and out of, as well as see how the people really live, were incredible. It's great to see such a large scale cultural investment in action.

Very Good Visit. Vietnam Museum of Ethnology – On a recent business trip to Hanoi, I had some free time so I decided to visit this museum. I have always been interested in different cultures and found this to be a great place to learn of the 54 ethnic groups in the country. While all the exhibits have English captions, I took one of the guided tours which I would recommend to others. The only drawback was there was no a/c in the building which made for a hot trip, but still worth seeing. The outside garden with authentic houses is also very nice.

Highly Recommended. This museum will initiate you to the fact that Vietnam is a meltpot of diverse ethnicities. There is much difference from one ethnic group to another and this adds to the charm of the country.You will see the different ways of living based on where they live and how they adapted to the area. We loved also the exterior houses to visit. Just make sure you wear footwear easy to put on and off as you need to take them off going Inside those houses.There is a small cafe by the museum so you can have a refreshment pause during your visit as it is usually hot and humid out there.This is not to be missed and will give you an insight on the living conditions.

The full of colors museum. The museum is very interesting and the items exhibited in the inner part are full of color! In order to visit the minorities traditional houses in the outer space of the museum in most of them in order to get in you have to be barefoot. There are hundreds of schoolchildren visiting the museum so there are cheerful loud voices.

So interesting!. This was an excellent stop. It was especially great to learn more about the Hmong tribes before we continued on to Sapa. My only word of caution is that this place had no air conditioning. We were traveling with small children and grandparents and our visit was cut short because they were overheated. If the weather was milder we certainly would have spent more time. I highly recommend!

A revelation. Visited becos of its high rating on TA. Deservedly so! A real eye-opener to me, someone who was an ignoramus when it came to Vietnam's history and ethnic landscape. A visit will enrich your understanding of the country's culture, so plan to go the beginning of your Hanoi stay. Not a large museum by any means, but it's supplemented by a fabulous outdoor section which has several life-size buildings built the traditional way. Getting there is not difficult - we stayed in the Old Quarter and the cab ride was US$6 and 20 minutes long. Figure on spending 2 hours there as an absolute minimum. 3 hours would be nice. There's a cafe there but we didnt try it... seemed popular enough.
Interesting. This was a fascinating insight in to the culture and traditions of Vietnam. Lots to take in but well worth a visit.

Really cool and worth it!. I'm not one to spend a lot of time in museums when I'm on holidays, but this one was highly recommended by my hotel. It turned out to be one of my best memories of Hanoi! I'm really interested in traditional culture, so to learn about Vietnam's was fascinating for me. The best part is the open-air museum at the rear of the main building, where you can see and actually go inside life-size traditional buildings. All throughout the museum are informative signs in English. Unfortunately, I went on a day when it was pouring rain, so while it was nice to be inside the building, the flooded footpaths made it difficult to access parts of the open-air museum - all part of the fun I guess!

A Few hours well spent!. Great museum and good value, worth spending 2-3 hours there if you can, so leave time to wander outside with replicas of authentic housing from different ethnicities - kids will love it!

Vietnam Museum of Ethnology. Yeah. I visit here last year with my classmate. And we like thí place. The museum is large and you can gain much information about ethnic people ( custom, tradition,etc). You even can enjoy some kind of food here, We try "peanut candy" with tea and all of us love it. You and your group can find somewhere to relax cause there are many house on stilts. One more thing is that ticket, food is very cheap.

Short on Time, one of two museums to see in Hanoi. We have visited almost all the museums in Hanoi and this is by far and away the best... takes a couple of hours to see, most of it is outside so you are in the heat, go early. During Vietnamese holidays it is packed but fun... Very interactive and great for kids... some food there but nothing unusually.

Enjoyable afternoon. With just one free weekend during a business trip, I was able to turn a rainy afternoon into a delightful and educational experience. This museum has an impressive collection of artifacts from throughout Vietnam, topped off by an outdoor exhibit of life sized examples of structures from the various ethnic groups. Water puppet shows are held at regular times throughout the day: try to time your visit so you can take this in too.

a snapshot of the real vietnam. Loved everything about this museum, it shows you the great diversity of life in Vietnam, completely different to the big city nature of Hanoi.
I imagine in the future that this museum will be updated to show the growth and progression of this absolutely amazing country!
A fun morning out. This is an interesting and engaging museum with thoughtful and well-presented displays. The outdoor replicas of ethnic minority-style buildings are particularly good fun.

An interesting way to spend time in Vietnam. I took all my family here and even though my brother is not really a big fan of museums and cultural venues, he actually enjoyed the experience. Me and my boyfriend, we were extremely impressed by this museum, especially since I am a bit obsessed with history and I love spending time in museums. So this was a treat for me and the museum is incredibly rich in artifacts and a great way to spend time in Vietnam if you are on a budget. Even if you are not a big fan of museums you should definitely visit this one especially since it has both indoor and outdoor display. If you really want to immerse yourself in the culture and understand this fascinating country better, this is probably where you should start.

An excellent overview. I can't say I'm a huge fan of Ethnology museums, but was taken here during a morning in Hanoi; well put together, an incredible amount of artefacts and there are even full-size examples of buildings outside that you look at replicas of inside.A great starting point if you are considering an excursion to Sapa or remote areas of the highlands.

Yes, highly recommended!. This museum is absolutely worth the visit. Take a taxi as it is not located in the very center od Hanoi.The museum is quite big so you should focus on the outdoor part and if you have some extra time get to visit the inside.Outdoor you will be able to visit the traditional houses reconstructed by the local Vietnamese minorities, so different in style from each other.Some of the buildings have actually been removed from the original buildings and some others (of huge size) have been built on the spot by ethinc minorities.Not only you can see the houses from outside but you can enter them and see how people use / used to live and how the communities were organized.Very interesting and unexpected!!!

museum of ethnology. Good for families to visit with inside and outside displays. Very interesting with a guide. No so good for people with very young families. Displays are static models. Quite hot inside.
Interesting. It was a bit hot so maybe that influences the capacity for a museum visit. However, it shows the many different ethical groups and their culture very well.
Very interesting. This museum explain a lot about Vitnam culture, and people diferencies. After you finish ti, you feel like you understand the country much better.

Great, a decent distance from town but worth it. This was cool. There was a lot of interesting info about the way people used to live and loads of miniature houses you could explore. Don't miss the ones in the garden in the back. Well worth it.

Interesting. Very well done museum. Everything was very well presented in English, French and Vietnamese and there were a number of interactive and audiovisual features. Highly worth a visit. There's a lot to take in so make sure you're on your game prior to getting into the museum.

A part of Vietnam most visitors miss, or don't even recognize. While the Viet ethnic group makes up about 88% of the population of Vietnam, there are 53 other ethnic groups in the country. This large museum presents an overview of these people and their cultures. Due to different languages, religious belief systems, and family structures, there is little mixing of these groups, and so even today there are persistent communities remaining. Difficult to visit, this museum offers you a chance to see and learn more about this diverse array of interesting groups. The museum buildings themselves are large and take a long time to get through, if you proceed carefully and thoughtfully. However, the highlight of the place are the spacious grounds outside, where a collection of original buildings have been assembled: houses, community gathering buildings, temples, etc., of some of these other 53 ethnic groups. We spent hours there, and found the collection totally enchanting.

Very informative and worth a visit. We were on a bit of a worldwind tour of the city and called into this place with our guided tour. I would have liked to have spent more time there to really look and see. It would take a day to look at everything.

Good intro to ethnic minorities in Vietnam. Visit the different ethnic homes outside in addition to the interior displays.Visit Craft Link shop in front of museum for excellent quality souvenirs. For lunch, there is a Baguettes and chocolate restaurant on-site. Food ok, but could be better.
not to miss. this is my fourth visit and I always enjoy this the visit. It is wonderful educational experience that provides a balance to the endless shoping

Museum of Ethnology. Well made and detailed museum, my favorite together with the women's museum. I made some bad and medium experiences with the museums in Hanoi, some of them are small, boring or simply without or with hardly texts in English. With a friend I went to the museum of Ethnology the first time, the two hours we spent there were running by quickly. There's so much different material and pictures/videos etc. to see. For example an authentic funeral ceremony of the Black H'Mong minority is beautifully made with dolls and original material like the coffin and dresses, altar etc., also the video of a ceremony can be seen. On another floor there's a huge house showing the authentic design and rooms with dolls and furniture. Maps and information on different tribes and minorities accomplish the great experience. Only minus is that after a while it becomes hard to focus as there is so much to see and do but in Vietnam there are so many minorities and developments that it is hard to see through. The outside area is wonderful. Houses, boats, a coffin house and a water puppet theatre show in originalsize the life of different groups.
Really interesting museum. Had a great visit here which was made all the better by our guide taking us to the key exhibits and explaining everything without having to read the notes!

Great cafe - unexpected and welcome find. Great cafe with young trainee staff producing good lunchtime fare, albeit with some western offerings too. Good service, lovely outdoor location, and good pricing. A great asset to retreat to after spending time at the museum. Note sure why the facility is not flagged up on the museum publicity.
Interesting history. This help to give a timeline of the history of Vietnam. Worth a visitto help you appreciate the history of Vietnam.

A little disjointed. The museum holds a LOT of artifacts used by the ancestors of those occupying the land today, and some instruments are fascinating. However, to me there didn't seem to be much else to it. There is a section on the many ethnicities of those living in Vietnam today, but nothing stood out as being particularly interesting. That said, those into anthropology would be fascinated by it. The outdoor exhibition of different styles of home is recommended.

Los of good exhibits. This place is very well laid out with both indoor and outdoor exhibits. If you wish to learn about the cultures of the Vietnamese then it is great. We quite enjoyed being able to explore the outdoor area where you can wander through the buildings.It took around 2hrs to get around and fully appreciate.

Very Informative. We really enjoyed the Vietnam Museum of Ethnology on our trip to Hanoi. Our guide lead us through the entire museum to describe all the villages and tribes customs in Vietnam. It was enlightning to learn about each of the villages with the different houses, rituals and farming methods. Walking through the recreated villages huts in the museum gave us a sense of village life for the people.

All-in-One Museum. If you want to learn about Vietnamese ethnics, people and cultures, this is the place to visit. We enjoyed most of displays and learned a lot from them, even without any tour guide. The videos that show different ceremonies are fascinating. Our two young kids loved them.Unfortunately, we didn't explore much outside as it was downpouring, but we were quite pleasantly surprised to learn that they were also showing a water puppet show.
facts. It was interesting but no air conditioning and for us it was like a sauna. The museum shows all different cultures and villages, very very enjoyable.

Love this museum!”. I went to this museum with two local college students and really enjoyed it! Learning more about the Vietnamese culture was fascinating. Excellent information. The huts outside were very cool

Don't pass over the 13 houses outside!. We went here with a free hanoi kids tour, therefore we had a free English guide (hanoi kids tours are free, and you can make a donation to their organization). We didn't read every placard or stop and watch every film because we had limited time. We maybe spent an hour indoors and then went outside to see the houses. Because we were in a downpour of rain we only ran between 6 of 13 houses because we weren't as prepared as we should have been!Additionally there is an outdoor water puppet stage here. I haven't seen anyone comment on the show so I can't speak for it but it would be interesting to be outdoors. Out guide said they have shows on the weekends.I would recommend wearing sandals or shoes that are fast to be taken on/off to see the outdoor houses as you are required to take your shoes off most places.

Good Museum. We enjoyed this museum although we wished we had an English speaking guide so that we would have understood more about the exhibits. It was interesting and definitely worth the money. Great activities for kids in the discovery room.

Really interesting, a great hands on place to learn about Vietnam. This place has a vast outdoor section which will teach you all about the different houses and cultures of minorities in Vietnam. There are signs on all displays in English and French which is brilliant.

Hot inside and not in a good way. Museum was interesting and displays were colorful and artistic. But it was so hot inside it was hard to enjoy and hard to listen to our guide. Grounds were pretty and free trade gift shop Craft Link had great items and gifts. And was not as hot. :-)

Worth a visit!. Loved the outside display of all the ethnic houses.Did not enjoy the inside displays as much because of the heat.The building is old and doesn't have air-conditioning and the humidity was high. Great displays but difficult to really enjoy while dripping with sweat.

Love this museum!. I went to this museum with two local college students and really enjoyed it! Learning more about the Vietnamese culture was fascinating. Excellent information. The huts outside were very cool.

Not for Everyone. Unless your really knowledgable in Asian languages and customs it can be kind of boring, however I'm a teenager and it could just be me! It's really not for everyone but again if your familiar and interested in the topics it would be ideal for you.

Definitely a must see!. I spent quite a few hours at this museum and this one, along with the womens, were the highlights of my Hanoi stay. The museum has many exhibits from the tribal groups of Vietnam and I found it really interesting the diversity and cultural differences of the groups. I loved the huts outside and think it is really a great place for tourists to gain a deeper understanding of the Vietnamese people, their history and cultural practices. I appreciated that the signage was in English so I was able to understand more of the information!

If you can not make it to Sapa, this is a must..... For travelers who do not have time to visit Sapa, and are interested in the ethnic cultures of Vietnam, this museum is a must do. It has both internal and external exhibits. The latter is mainly a display of minority style houses which are interesting. Inside the museum there are numerous displays depicting the 50+ minority tribes clothing styles and cultures.
Lots to see. Definitely worth while going to the museum, I especially like seeing the huts outside, really gave you an idea of how the people live

Facinating Displays on the 54 Ethnicity of Vietnam. Name of Museum in Vietnamese Language - BẢO TÀNG DÂN TỘC HỌC VIỆT NAMEntrance Fee - VND 40,000/paxDuration - 1.5 to 2hrsAircon - Only at main entranceFans - YesSeats - availableI am not a museum person but this one is worth a visit. You will see many interesting artifacts of the various tribes in the main building.
