There are also separate tribal buildings outside which are great for photography.There are interesting video documentaries at some locations. Food and drinks are available outside main building. Warnings:1. Don't go when your legs are dying for foot reflexology. 2. You will perspire a lot if you go during hot weather as there is lack of a/c inside the main building.3. You will be disappointed if you expect detailed explanation of every artifact.If you love seeing tribal houses, clothes, tools and traditions, you will love this place! They have some very clever innovations. Enjoy!

Museum of Ethnology. It was hard to take in all the information from the indoor exhibits. The outdoor exhibits, where the traditional dwellings of the different ethnic groups within Vietnam was much more interesting. The gift shop at this museum just as you go out the gate has some lovely things that make great souvenirs or gifts.

First University. Well you can feel how they appreciate confusius , place like you see in movies , flash back old century , devide into 5 buildings , on weekend have free tour guide & they speak good english

Great Cultural Site and Into to Sapa. Sapa has 54 ethnic minorities, but to get there requires 2 overnight train rides. This museum has a lot of the styles of houses the different minorities live in and offers good glimpse of their life. This is a great introduction to Sapa, or a good substitute if you cannot go up there. It also has a good restaurant where young people are taught the restaurant business in very professional ways. I would recommend the museum and lunch there.
very educational. Very educational. The grounds was sprawling. It had a good enough spare for gardens, walkways and exhibits.

Great Musuem. The Museum of Ethnology provided information and insight to the cultural and ethnic make up of Vietnam. There are plenty of ethnic groups in Vietnam which make it a culturally rich country. I got to learn about the different way of life of each ethnic group. The highlight of the trip is the area where the traditional houses were placed.Note: There is a 50,000 VND fee if you want to take pictures inside the museum which is separate from the actual entrance fee.
Not worth the trip. Boring old school museum , exhibits have little explanation and at the time of year we went hot and uncomfortable

Learnt something. I am not a great person for museums but it was lovely to get into the airconditioning after the heat! It was mildly interesting to me and I learnt something - that Vietnam has got lots of different people living there!
Excellent. have a lot of exciting activity like games foods of cultural and have few house of Vietnamese peoples. all i can write and say to you about it its come and try it :D
cultural heritage. full of information detailing traditional Vietnamese ways of life. very interesting!!! there is outdoor area presenting of traditional homes

Worth the taxi ride or long walk from city center.. I love the variety of houses they had on display in the yard, and I loved the abundance of artifacts and displays in the museum. I definitely learned about a wide range of the 54 ethnicities of Vietnam.

why. i have no idea why lonely planet and trip advisor recommend this múeum so much. it was crowded, hot, and boring. it was just a bunch of posters and old artifacts but i feel like you could learn more about hanoi from just walking around. i definitely considered this a waste of my time in hanoi.

Informative but needs an upgrade. We visited the museum with out three young children. They (and us) were duly impressed with many of the exhibits but on the whole the exhibits need to be upgraded and refreshed. They ought to be made more interesting as they all require lots of reading which was did not go down well with the kids.The outside area showing different homesteads was impressive and would be of interest to children. But, perhaps we were very hot and tired (the air-conditioning is not very effective) from the tour inside, we just wanted to move on.

a discovery of Vietnam's diversity. very helpful museum to understand the diversity of the country, good snapshots about the diverse ethnic groups of Vietnam. The visit of the houses in the park is also very interesting.A great visit

VMW. Best museum of the lot with 4 good floors and much more indepth explanations, all translated to English and French. Good A/C and good displays. War section is the pick but was surprised to find the textile/clothing exhibts also interesting.
Informative. We enjoyed our tour of the museum, especially the outside garden which has houses from different periods.The gift shop has some lovely items and it is run by the nonprofit, Craftlink.

Great Chance to See Different Styles of Housing & Village Life. This building is very open with no aircon so on 35 degree heat day we found it a little too hot. Great Displays.
The outside area is a must as you get to explore the different style of houses from one province to another.

Fascinating Overview of Vietnamese Culture. We went to the museum with a guide. Although the museum does have English captions on all of the displays, there are a lot of displays! Best to have a guide lead you through. The interior of the museum is not all that large but gives an interesting introduction to the ethnic minorities of Vietnam. Outside, in back of the museum, are a series of reconstructed traditional Vietnamese houses - everything from mud huts to longhouses to tall A-frame houses. Fascinating and well worth a visit.

One of the best Museum in Vietnam. Many of the museum we were taken to in Vietnam certainly had the habit of just sprouting the same old government line, which was annoying. This was the case in some parts here, but the outdoor exhibits certainly were very impressive. With our guide walking us through the exhibits and being (rarely for the trip) honest about what was overdone and what was more realistic, we had a great walk through getting to understand more about the very diverse people that make by Vietnam. Well worth the visit.
worth a visit once. the outside exhibits were outstanding. Have a guide to explain the different cultures and traditions.

Not enough time. This is a fascinating museum to visit to get a sense of some of the "ethnic groups" in Viet Nam. There is a fair dose of official views on ethnic issues in the country, but the actual exhibits (especially the houses outside) are very much worth the trip out to the museum. Do have lots of time though as it will take time to do the museum justice.

Great museum, needs A/C. This museum is a great overview of the different ethnic groups living in Viet Nam. Perfect if you are taking a tour to Sa Pa. The only bad news is that it has no air conditioning, and it was the same temperature inside as outside. They did have numerous fans which made it almost bearable. There is an inside section with typical displays of clothing styles, household items, and photos, which are very good but the best part is the outdoor section with actual houses built in many different Vietnamese styles. You won't believe how different they are!
Interesting Museum. Terribly hot with little ventilation indoors. It was far more comfortable viewing the outdoor exhibits.
Informative. The detail was impressive considering the large number of groups that make up Vietnam's population. Put aside at least two hours to see inside and out.

1-Hour Spare - then visit. A well spent hour in a very interesting museum. OK you had to concentrate - but it shed much light on this bloke about the depth of the Vietnamese and SE Asian dispora. Worth taking your time and good value for entry fee.

Very interesting and informative. Loved learning about all the different tribes in Vietnam. Loved going inside all the different types of houses outside. The museum was a little hot but there are plenty of fans so you can recover slightly if you rest frequently underneath one of them. Well worth the visit.

You want culture? This is the place to be!. As a Vietnamese, I often thought museums in Vietnam were very boring because while growing up, I was taken to all war museums and looked at terrifying photos taken during the wars. However, this museum changed my mind. While living in Hanoi, I always proudly took all of my international friends to this museum to show them how rich our culture is. And I can tell that they were absolutely amazed. In Vietnam, we have 54 ethnic minorities and each has their own amazing culture. Instead of spending a lot of money and time to travel to mountainous areas to visit these minorities, you can spend a little more than 2 dollars for the ticket and 1 hour of your time to learn about all 54 of them. Inside the museum, for each ethnic minority, they have displays of their costumes, tools used in their daily life and custom. Here and there are TVs playing documents about some of the customs which, nowadays, are fading because of development. If you've ever watched Discovery channel where they show some customs in Africa that creep the hell out of you, you'll find the same feeling while watching those videos. Of course, creepy but extremely interesting! My favorite is the bike to which hundreds of bamboo nets are attached. You'll see a photo right next to the bike in which a man is actually riding the bike to sell the nets. Those are for fish catching. The models of tombs and typical houses on stilts on the garden outside are pretty impressive! Almost everything is available in English, French and Chinese. You can find flyers and instructions right at the entrance in those languages too!

enjoy, learn, eat. after our trip to Sa Pa we were intrigued by the ethnic mix of people in Vietnam. This well designed museum provides you with insights into the lives of the many groups who make up the Vietnamese population.A monsoonal rainstorm diverted us from the outdoor displays to the wonderful little cafe. This is part of a scheme to train young people in hospitality - eat your heart out Jamie Oliver. We enjoyed a couple of pizzas in the relaxing surrounds.The service was great and we enjoyed talking to the staff.
One of the best museum in Hanoi. Green and peaceful space in Hanoi where you can get to know more about Vietnamese people and culture. Children can enjoy different interesting activities here as well

Best museum in Hanoi. This place is one of the must-be-seen in Hanoi when you are here. Located in the large area, this museum may bring you the overview of Vietnam Culture with 54 peoples, their house, their working tools, their traditions...At special events in year, there're a lots of outside activities for children and tourist.

Best Museum in Hanoi. just 20 minutes from our hotel there by taxi and took 30 minutes visiting the Vietnam Museum of Ethnology.should need the guide to take you around and really interesting in details.History of the Country& 54 Ethnic Minorites of Vietnam.

Definitely worth the trip!. It seems a bit out of the way, and I hadn't planned on visiting in advance, but like the Lonely Planet says, it is a really great museum. Inside, they show all kinds of objects and outfits that are used by the different minority groups in Vietnam. Outside, you can visit numerous traditional houses, all with really good explanation on how the people live, and why the houses look the way they do!

Very Informative. It was fascinating to learn about the different minorities of Vietnam. My short trip to Vietnam is just taking me to major cities. After seeing the exhibits, I want to return to Vietnam and travel to rural areas. The houses in the outdoor exhibit were a must see. There were several school parties but it wasn't crowded. The kids were cute and some practiced their English with us.

Really interesting. Liked the good range of exibits including full size ethnic houses outside the main building.A little crowded in some areas as there were several school groups there when we visited

Wonderful to discover 54 ethnic minorites of Viet nam. My husband loves discover the history of a country. He told me to go with him to this museum. He read all the details about each ethnic, It took us the whole day inside this museum. He sais it's really beautiful to see how is the variety of ethnic in a country. It's like a garden of flowers with many colors. Do not need to make all the flowers the same colors. Each one has its beauty. I was conquered. Thanks for this visit with my husband. I discovered things about my own country.
Highly recommend. Fascinating learning of the many different ethnic groups that make up the Vietnamese people. Very well displayed.Highly Recommend a visit
Interesting and informative. The museum give us a great view about the ethnic minorities' culture in Vietnam, however, the display objects are rather simple

Great insight into Vietnam. A terrific place to gain a little understanding about what makes Vietnam tick. So many exhibits that are a real glimpse of the culture and growth of this fascinating people.

Great Museum - Wear Flip flops. Great museum, spend most of your time visiting the houses outside. The inside is nice but the descriptions can be a bit repetitive after a while and it gets very hot (no A/C). You need to take your shoes off to enter many of the houses so I recommended wearing flip flops! Cabs are easy to find by the entrance.

Museum of ethnicology. Who new there are 54 different tribes in Vietnam with the Viet being the largest one. This museum is best done with a guide. Well worth a good hour or two to relies the diversity of all the tribes

Go with Hanoi kids. We visited with our guide from hanoi kids and i have never met such a passionite young lady - her knowledge of this amazing museum was outstanding. The village was a great way to understand the different ethnic groups past and present who make up Vietnam. Not boring,one of the best museums ever visited. A must see and if you have a good guide it will make the day even more special.

Worth a trip in any case. Very nice made museum about the culture of the ethnic minorities in Vietnam. It gives a good insight of the culture of these people, their traditions, buildings and other. Take your time and read the plates, if you can book a guided tour, the better. The park is nicely made, the houses are in very good shape and some events are regularly organized. Negative: no A/C in the building. However, one of the highlights in Hanoi!

OK if that's your thing. Was very hot inside when we visited (late June) which was uncomfortable. We found the outside exhibits of the different style houses to be the best part, and interesting. Inside exhibits were a little boring.
Interesting. A good, interesting perspective & overview on the diversity of the people of Vietnam. Helps to explain the region.

yet another museum. i think after visiting museums in every city you visit you kind of get 'over' them. this occurred to be a long time ago, yet here i am still visiting the museums and feeling disappointed about an attraction in which i didnt even want to really see in the first place !nothing overly interesting or thrilling at this one .
interesting. Museum gave nice presentation on the different peoples of Vietnam and their history. Two floors of exhibits inside and a number of exhibits outside.

Fascinating. Knowing very little about Vietnamese history and ethnicity, this place was a wonderful experience. Information written in Vietnamese, French and English to explain the vignettes of each tribal or ethnic group. About a 20 minute taxi ride to get there cost us 70000 dong ($5) to get there and 170000 to get back because we were foolish enough to get a cab with meter cab sign on roof but not from a proper company. Oh well live and learn!
A good way to spend a couple of hours. This museum was an interesting way to spend a couple of hours. It looks at the "minority" cultures in Vietnam as well as the Viet.

50+ Ethnic Groups. The inside portion of the museum featured exhibits and maps showing the lifestyle and locations of different ethnic groups. On the grounds were actual living structures of various types. It was a neat way to get a feel for the diversity of Vietnam.
Traditions. Excellent, well worth the look for short interesting exhibits. It's hot so make sure you have water with you & take the time to visit the restaurant in the grounds.
ok if you are into clothing. This museum was OK, however the gift shop was excellent. Made the trip out there worth it alone. There are better things to do in hanoi

Excellent and Informative.. LP says a lot about this museum and it is very well worth a visit. Don't expect to see it all in 2 hours,though! Interior and exterior exhibits are superb, particularly on the tribes and their houses, some of which have been re-constructed.

The unique space for ethic groups in Vietnam. It might be said that Vietnam Museum of Ethnology is the nicest museum which attracts lots of foreigners. Going there, you can have experience to enjoy 54 officially ethnic groups, you can see their house and the place they gathering. Also you can participate many ethic games which are so fun and interesting. I played "ca kheo" - it is so difficult to stand up and move in 2 canes, but when I can, I felt like heaven. You should try this game - so interesting.

Inside and out a great museum!. The exhibitions inside were very informative, but the outside buildings, the traditional buildings were also interesting. We climbed up an unusual ladder to go into a large communal building. This kind of museum experience is what I wish more museums could do to acquaint you with life as it was lived (admittedly by some) in a country's past.

boring. it was a five minute walk around of old staues and ladies trying to get you to buy flowers, also you have to pay to go to the toilet only a $1 but we had no change and you had to put the money in a box there was nowhere to get change so it cost me $5
love this museum. This was my second visit; the first was with a tour group and there was just not enough time! This prepared me well for trips into more remote areas of Vietnam.

Visit with kids. Not the most interesting museum in the world, good for a quick walk around, the outdoor actual size house replicas were fun for our kids to climb in. Good to visit, dont need to spend too much time there.

Great knowledge if you are visiting villages. Our tour operator recommended a visit because we were going to Sapa, to understand the different ethnicities and customs, and it was really useful.
Great display of art and artifacts, and seems to be nicely curated and cared for.

Fantastic Museum!. At first it would seem to be far too big considering how specific a museum it is, but the exhibits are fantastic and extremely well laid out. Helps give a great appreciation of the variety of ethnic cultures found in Vietnam, and the Archaeological Garden is a fun walk.

Interesting. We annoyed the Museum of Ethnology. The kids especially liked the native homes in the garden area and the water puppet show which was very interesting. The homes felt authentic and were in very good condition and well cared for. The kids had a lot of fun watching the water puppet show which is included in the cost of admission. The displays inside the museum were interesting but not for the kids who couldn't wait to get outside and see the homes in the garden area. The whole site can easily be seen in one hour. We would recommend a visit to the museum.

Ethnology rebuilt, history comes to life.. The main building itself was interesting with stories of the people and customs, but what I enjoyed much more were the houses that replicated typical Vietnam housing in the different regions, and it was very well done, with stories of how the spaces are used. They also had a water puppet performance while we were there, which was a nice treat. Worth a trip, but plan for at least 4 hours, or more if you are a history or architectural buff.

Good place to learn about Vietnams Tribes. We got bus 11 here (walked the last couple of hundred mtrs) Its well laid out both inside and out. If its your first visit to Vietnam, its a good place to learn about all the various tribes that make up Vietnam
beautiful museum. a very interesting place with great information about more than 50 ethnic groups around Vietnam. the shop there is great too with very cheap and beautiful souveniers
Not that great. I wasn't impressed at all. Plus no air con in super hot Hanoi made it even worse. My boyfriend thought it was ok, but really nothing here is a must see.

Great. The outside building exhibits are all genuine inside and out. They provide a very unique glimpse into rural Vietnamese life. A visit to this museum will make you a lot smarter of the non war aspects of the country.
Loved the outside exhibits museum. The inside of the museum lacked excitement but I loved the water puppet show and homes featured on the grounds of the museum.

A lovely morning. We loved the museum. We spent very little time indoors with just a wander round the ground floor for 30 minutes or so. There are some interesting items to see but very little information about them. We spent a couple of hours wandering round the different houses in the grounds, which was lovely, shady and very interesting. Would be amazing with kids as there were many hands on items and some of the houses had ladders to climb to get in. we strolled around for a while and also sat & read the guidebook for ideas on where to go next in the grounds.The cafe is pleasant and employs students from disadvantaged backgrounds working for catering/hospitality qualifications. The food was good, not particularly expensive & there was plenty of choice. If you want to avoid the taxis why not take the bus. The 14 drops off a ten minute walk from the museum & you can catch it from the north end of the lake. There are also buses that drop you off/pick you up right outside but those don't go from/to the old quarter. That said you could get the main train station & change or have a walk back from near the temple of literature. The buses are easy, comfortable, air-conditioned and cheap (5000VND per journey). You can buy maps from the post office by Hoan Kiem lake that include bus route details & from what we understood all the services in the city centre run every 10-15 minutes.

Well presented Historical presentation. I could spend all day in a museum. I like to read the fine print and get the feel of bygone days. It was easy to do that here.Get a taxi from wherever you are, its always cheap compared to home and so is the addmission. The outdoor display of early life is well set out and can take an hour on its own.The indoor presentation is well defined and interpreted in 3 languages including English. If it gets hot outside ( and it certainly does in May/June ) you can while away a pleasant tour inside with the air-con looking after you. It is more meaningful with a local guide who's english is good.

interesting place to know about vietnamnesse culture. this museum is same with the other museum, little bit bored. But if you love historical about ethnic maybe you would love it. You can learn alot about vietnamnese culture, if u want to know more, better u hire a guide, they will explain u alot than the text on the information board

Desperately seeking attention. We visited the museum whilst we stayed in Hanoi. The collection itself is interesting however it's very sad to see a significant historic collection with little supporting investment in its preservation. There was no humidity nor temperature control and in some places sunlight was streaming in on some objects. There was also very little information on any of the labels if they were there at all. The houses outside we're interesting and worth seeing.

Nice to go. It's an interesting place but I wouldn't say exciting. Nice to go if you are interested in the Culture of Vietnam ethnic groups, but if you only have very limited time, I'm not sure it is worth missing other sites for. The taxi ride from Old Quarter is about $7.5 and 25 mins each way, which is not cheap according to the local living standard. Tourists need to be very careful when getting a Taxi on the street - stick to MaiLin or Taxi Group otherwise you might have to pay more...

I like the houses so much. This is not just another museum. This is a museum where you can go into the houses built by different minority people. There is a big open area outside the museum building where they rebuilt houses from different minority goups. They are of different structure, built from different materials and of different shapes. If your time is limited and can visit just one museum, this is the one you should go. The Long House and the Tall House (according to my own naming system) are the highlights of the whole museum. Be sure you don't miss them.

A learning experience??????. Not sure what to expect here but we learnt a lot about Vietnamese culture in a short space of time. Well set out and educational. No air conditioning though so was very hot inside. The outside exhibits appeared to be a number of wooden huts all of which were much the same, just bigger or longer than the one before.As well as buying your entry ticket if you are carrying a camera you get charged a camera fee as well. I have no idea how they deal with Iphones etc as I didn't see anyone being asked to pay to take them in.
Great Museum. Great to show the different ethnic groups in Vietnam. The display of the housing out the back of the Museum is great.

Great insight into Vietnamese people. Chieu, our Buffalo Tours guide, provided a running commentary on the different ethnic groups that make up the Vietnamese people. A really interesting place to visit.

Well worth it!. This museum was probably the highlight of our visit to Hanoi. Because we were unable to travel up north to personally see some the ethnci tribes of Vietnam, we had to settlle for a trip to the Museum of Ethnology and it was well worth it. The museum does a fabulous job of explaining the diversity of tribal groups that occupy the country. It presented information in a variety of mediums. The videos were particularly interesting to watch. Even though we were unable to see different ethnic groups in person, a visit to the museum proved to be the next best thing. We came away feeling as if we had actually made trips to distant areas of the country where the tribes and clans live today.The outdoor area of the museum provides numerous examples of the structures occupied by different ethnic groups. Walking into these different structures provided a first hand example of what life among the different groups is like. This is an excellent museum, and a great primer for anyone planning to travel to oulying areas of the Country where the ethnic tribes live. Definitely worth seeing if you have the time.

Well presented, informative and good value,. My partner and I really enjoyed this museam. I would go as far to say it was the best museam we visited in Hanoi. Its great value for money with a lot to see. It is a little way out from the Old Quarter, but well worth the journey. All the information is well written in English and gives a very nice overview of the different ethnic minorities in Vietnam. The highlight was the reconstructed buildings in the grounds, which were fasinating. Leave at least 2 hours to get the most out of your visit- to look around inside, grab a drink (there is a nice cafe- good iced coffee) and then explore the buildings in the grounds. However, beware the taxis outside, the one we took back to the Old Quater was so expensive we eneded up getting out and walking!
Cool. Good exhibits compared to a few others we went. Informative! Loved the replicas of the types of houses of the different minorities in Vietnam.
Nice museum. The houses outside are really nice. It's also nice to go with the city bus to the museum (you have to walk a little but the experience is nice).

Interesting insight into Vietnamese tribes and ethnic groups. I really enjoyed my visit here - if you're already interested in this topic then I definitely recommend it. I especially liked the outside area with different style houses. The gift shop was also great and had lots of souvenirs made in Vietnam from different areas. Watch out for the taxis that try to pick up tourists from outside it - a lot of them have dodgy meters so look for a reputable company or walk away from the museum to find a taxi,

Reflects the French influence. Been here on the first day we were in Hanoi and I honestly did not find this place stunning. It's definitely for those who are into arts, etc. My daughters seemed to be okay but weren't too excited either. A bit far off from the old quarter area, costing us about $8, the most expensive taxi ride we've had in Vietnam.

boring. There's no air con but instead some ancient ceiling fans that did little to push the air around.We didnt really learn a lot but found ourselves looking at picture after picture of slightly different vietnamese tribes. Personally we wished we'd gone to the Vietnamese musuem of history instead.
worth seeing. You can learn a lot about the diverse culture of Vietnam. Spend at least an hour or so rather than a rushed abbreviated tour that you will get in a packaged day tour of Hanoi.

Worth a visit. This museum was about a 20 minute taxi ride from the Old Quarter but well worth the ride. Very interesting information on the different Vietnamese people and their ways of life. The outside area with full size houses is brilliant, very educational and the non profit gift shop has plenty of locally made souvenirs at reasonable prices.

Museum and Grounds. This museum was very interesting. I particularly liked the grounds where they have reproduced many older buildings. To ensure you have enough time to explore properly and take in the culture allow at least 2 hours and take lots of pictures.

Great trip to Museum of Ethnology. Amazing visit to the Museum of Ethnology. Never have I seen a museum where ethnic diversity is celebrated and displayed in such a proud way. This is a MUST SEE during your visit to Hanoi.
Not too bad. The outdoor exhibits are interesting. Inside not so much, but still worth a look. We spent 2 hours which was plenty.

Enlightening. Found the info really interesting. I had no idea there were so many different ethnic groups in Vietnam, and the displays of tools, instruments, clothing etc were fabulous to look at. (the air conditioning was a nice relief too)

Not my thing. We were hot and tired and found the museum a little boring - but at the same time its not really my thing.
The outside is pleasant to stroll around. We ate lunch at the on-site restaurant and that was excellent.
If you are interested in this sort of thing I think you would enjoy the museum.

Nice outing. Divided into the main building with posters/displays of the many minorities of Vietnam, and the surrounding gardens with real life models of some different traditional houses. The info details immigration timelines, language, regions of settlement, social and economic structure, traditional clothing and other interesting facts of the different groups.We ate at the site restaurant where the staff is disadvantaged youths attending hospitality scool, and to be honest the food was just okey.This museum is around 7 km from the main tourist area, and a metered taxi will run around 150-200k dong.

Interesting People. 54 ethnic peoples make up the nation of Viet Nam and they are well represented in photos ,decorations, handcrafts as well as full scale houses, and boats. Worth a leisurely visit or two.
EXCELLENT. Of all the Museums I have visited in Vietnam, this is my favorite. Beautiful displays, easy to navigate.

Rather samey!. Guess we could have been a bit tired following our flight the previous day but although it was interesting finding out about the make-up of Vietnam, we would have been happier sitting on a pavement drinking a cold beer and watching life pass us by! The displays were a little samey and our attention did start to wander, The Water Puppet show was very good - in fact we thought it was better than the one we saw at the theatre.
Great Museum. Super interesting, especially liked the Long House in the back section. Didn't have time to go inside but just the outside buildings were great.
understanding the different ethnic groups & living conditions, real houses!. climbing to all houses & understanding their culture, it was a great experience & really worth it to go!
Does it float your boat?. Easy taxi ride, suggest if this is your thing, then a guide is better, tickets for all museums are cheap.

Good for those wanting to see the history of Vietnamese people. This is a well organized museum showing the history of the various cultural groups in Vietnam.
Includes many photos and displays showing clothing, utensils, housing, musical instruments and other items.
No air conditioning but relatively cool on the ground floor. Probably best to do earlier in the morning for this reason.
Good collection. Nice restaurant as well as great displays in English. Easy to get to by public bus - catch it just opposite information office.

Interesting museum. As with manyof the museum tours in Vietnam - the translation requires review. Poor signage was a little disappointing- however the relics were excellent- a quick visit is warranted- possibly on the way to another sight seeing opportunity.

Worth a visit. Museum gives a good insight into the variety of different groups in Vietnam. Outside exhibits are more interesting than inside - but note that it gets pretty warm outside so we were able to cover the lot in about an hour with our two teenage boys.

Great Museum. We really enjoyed discovering this museum that describes the various ethnies in Vietnam and their way of living. Nice documentaries and good descriptions in English and French. Gives you a good undertsanding of the people of Vietnam.

Excellent showcase of Vietnam's people and culture. A collection of different type of traditional dwellings, arts and craft of the various ethnic race in Vietnam (there are quite a few). The museum is awesome and they allow photography (without usage of flash) inside. The museum is closed on Friday and Monday and its opening hours on its opening days are 8.30am to 5.30pm. Enterence fee for foreigners are at 40,000 dong/person. The Museum is quite far from the city center and would require a taxi or taking the bus to reach.
Ethnology museum. Very interesting museum containing a wealth of history and knowledge, particularly liked the reconstructed village huts in the grounds.

very interesting. This is a very interesting museum that gives an insight into the different sub-cultures in Vietnam. Some very interesting displays and the traditional houses are great and worth the visit alone! Also be wary of cab rip-offs- always choose Hanoi, Hanoi Tourist or mai linh for the cheapest and safest ride!

Fun Afternoon. I work in Hanoi, and drive past this place every day. So I finally decided to go for a visit. Despite the fact that there is no air con and it was 40 degrees, it was still a great excursion. The inside is very informative.It's the outside though, that gets you. The reconstructions of minority villages are fantastic. As well, any place that can block out the city noise is worth the $2 entrance fee. Be prepared to explain to your kids why all the statues have...well, you will see.

Fantastic Place !. we were recommended from my friends about this Museum, when we came there and so surprised, there are many information of Vietnamese cultures are displayed. they looks so fantastic !! we could not say enough how we love it, if we have time to come back to hanoi vietnam we will certainly come back here

Museum Of Ethnology. We only came to this museum as it was recommended by some work friends we bumped into in Hanoi (small world). So glad we came it was one of the highlights of our time in Hanoi. We have boys 6 & 11 years and they loved it here, as did we. It's an amazing place. You should set aside a few hours to get there and back and to take your time and enjoy it. Outside they have water puppet shows so try and be there when they are happening but even if you miss them the interactive outside area overall is amazing and so interesting to see the living environments of the ethnic groups that make up Vietnams population. Lunch in the cafe run by disadvantaged youth is a great way to end the visit. A must see.

A must see place!. We had great fun together. All the houses from all over the country are displayed here as one huge collection. We already figured out our next destination to go thanks to this interesting visit.

Ethnic Diversity. Vietnam has 54 ethnic minorities in its population. This museum attempts to recognise the place of these groups in Vietnamese society. Many of the groups are in danger of being swamped by the dominant Viet Dao culture and the headlong dash for modernisation of the country and its economy.It is a vast museum and the information overload is intense - but - if you are visiting an area with ethnic minorities present as we did in going to Sapa - the museum provides a useful introduction to what you might see.

Interesting and yet informative. I think it's very interesting as we get to learn a lot about Vietnamese but I think they can do better with their South East Asia exhibition. If you like Kuching cultural Village in Sarawak or Bangkok's Rattanakosin exhibition center, you will definitely love this place too!

Plenty to see inside and out. Well worth a visit and a relatively short taxi ride if staying in the old quarter. There are examples of the different types of houses in the grounds outside and interesting exhibits inside.

What a nice way to spend your last day in Hanoi. We have just returned from Sapa where we saw many of the ethnic groups which are described in detail here. The museum is very interesting inside if a little arm but the buildings outside are outstanding. Which we had gone before our trip to the Highlands. Your taxi driver may need some help in finding this as it is off their usual track. Was so surprised that are so may distinct grous living in close proximity and keeping their individual identities.

Fascinating museum. A really good museum, with excellent signage. I'm a guide at a museum in a neighbouring country and this place really impressed me. I was confused by other visitors who seemed split on whether a guide was necessary or not. I think those who say a guide IS needed, must have paid for one (you pay when you buy your entry ticket) and then were justifying it. Hopefully the guides are good and add something extra, but really they are not necessary. Just pay for your ticket and the extra for your camera if you like taking photos. Enjoy!

interesting museum of different minority groups. spent the afternoon here, ( great lunch in the grounds) . inposing columns and the paving has not been finished. approx 50 tribal groups represented here, clothes, marriage customs, housing etc. beware the stairs - one of our group twisted her ankle on the inside steps. toilets are clean. you seem to wander in circles never coming back to where you started, and there is an outside verandah that takes you from room to room (maybe for the folk who are board or want to smoke?) anyway good view of the hospital from there. the grounds are the most interesting, all the many types of homes have been recreated in life size and you can wander into the homes. have to take your shoes off first to protect the soft floor coverings. relaxing wander in and out of the homes and displays. lake offered puppets but we were going to the ones in the city of hanoi so we did not stay to see the show. and the whole palce was tidy and we watched the staff working outdoors planting ground cover. well we had seen all the houses by then.
Pros and Cons. The museum itself I found quite boring but the area outside and behind the museum was more interesting with the displays of different types of houses
Respect. It was beautiful and sad the people still have so much respect for this once great man. Nothing to dislike

Interesting ... Would have liked more in-depth info on the different tribes introduced in the museum.. That aside, it gives visitors a basic/introductory glimpse into the different ethnic tribes in Vietnam.

Very Interesting Museum. Our visit to this museum gave us a much better idea of the diverse ethnic groups of Vietnam. If you go to the most common tourist spots you don't get to see this. At the museum I learned about these different groups and know where I want to go on my next trip.

nice place to visited. one of most nice place to visited at Hanoi. far from Hanoi old quarter ( about 10 KM ) you can go by taxi or motobike but we choosed go by bus ( bus number 9 from Hoankiem lake)
The many people of Vietnam. Very informative about the make up of Vietnamese people, the diversity, colourful costumes, variety of villages/livlihoods etc

An hour well spent. Well laid out, informative about the different ethnicities in the country. Great film on the courtship of couples which is short and very interesting. The costumes and other displays are excellent, very reasonable entrance fee. Gift shop is very good and very reasonably priced items to choose from.
A must see.. Fantastic history with lovely human touching stories. We really enjoyed it and it was very easy to find on the map.

A whole country in the city. This museum is well presented, and the outdoor displays give a lovely, informative glimpse into the parts of Vietnam that may not be on your itinerary. Free water puppet performance (twice a day?) may even allow you to kill two birds with one stone!

Fabulous Museum. Well worth the taxi ride as it's a little out of the centre. Could happily spend all day here watching the various films and walking round the grounds looking at the various village houses. There is a cafeteria in the grounds for drinks and food. One of the highlights of my stay in Hanoi.

Not a boring museum. I like the museum's outdoor display. There are different houses of different ethnic groups in Vietnam. You can relax inside, outside or under these houses. There are some traditional games to play, you should try the Vietnamese bamboo spring swing. There are the free water puppet show sometimes. It is lucky if you can see this show because it is very interesting. Check their website for the events http://www.vme.org.vn/index.asp . The museum is closed on Monday. Must pay extra money for using camera, but the small digital camera is normally uncharged.

A must see place. Yes, it is a must see place when you stay in Hanoi. The museum is displaying many cultural characteristics of Vietnam ethnic people. After visit the museum I can realize how variety Vietnam traditional culture is. Abundant and Unique are true words for the culture of Vietnam. I heard that there is another traditional cultural village in the West of Hanoi called National Ethnic Village which are more things to see.

Excellent for seeing traditional houses. The inside of the museum has some interesting displays but all fairly static. There is a new wing being built so maybe in the future this will be more interactive. However, the garden is lovely and there are some excellent examples of traditional ethnic houses that you can climb inside, which we personally loved. There is also a free water puppet show, which is average but fun. The cafe inside the complex is great for a cold drink or pastry, and the gift shop supports a local initiative that funds local artists business so is good eco shopping. Kids particulary would like this place.

Good museum so long as you know its purpose. We went to the museum because it was #1 on Trip Advisor. It was a well presented museum so long as you have any interest in the history of the different tribes and people of Vietnam and Southeast Asia. We had such a minimal understanding that most of the museum was over our head and thus less enjoyable for us - that is not to say it's a bad museum. I think it's just intended for a very specific audience.

Wonderful visit and full of knowledge. My visit to this museum was with my Vietnamese close friend, and our visit was nothing less than wonderful. The museum is divided into 2 big parts, the outdoor part, and the indoor one; in the outdoor part, we could learn a lot about building and houses of traditional Vietnamese tribes, and we could also interact with the structure. All the exhibit are well maintained, so the visit was enjoyable and we took many great pictures. The indoor exhibition was full with artifacts and tools, clothing, and the story about the culture. We can still take some pictures here. All the exhibit outdoor and indoor was very informative and revealing; if you're from Indonesia like me, you'll find some fascinating similarities and same root for some parts of the culture, like batik and clothing of some tribes. For my personal taste, the information is all provided very well in English, so a guide won't be a real necessity; but it will take some more time for you to read the whole information on an exhibit, so prepare a longer time.

Worth a look. It was eye-opening to see just how much diversity exists within Vietnam - 54 different ethic groups in all. The museum does an okay job of presenting information pertaining to the various groups but it seems somewhat abridged - perhaps when the new wing is commissioned it will address this. Definitely worth a look if you are spending a few days in Hanoi.Make sure you leave time to explore the different types of housing that are on display behind the museum building - they are many and varied and according to the blurbs are actual abodes purchased from the original owners.(There is an extensive section dedicated to the cultural history of a sister city in France - it jars slightly with the rest of the exhibit and I struggled to comprehend the relevance unless it was part of a funding arrangement for the museum.)

Make it top of your list if interested in ethnic populations!. Visited here as part of a Hanoi City Tour and I wish we had more time (only less than 1 hour). Very well laid out and descriptions in English, French and Vietnamese. I had just returned from Sapa (H'Mong, Dazo, etc.) so it was particularly interesting for me. They explained about the ethnic groups' lifestyle, clothing, food, housing, livelihood, and much more. Very close connection between these celebrations/traditions and those of the French. Great combination of photographs, actual clothing, models of houses, and more so visitors don't get bored with just one medium. Also, great little store selling postcards,books just outside.Also, an off-shoot of Baguette & Chocolat (from Sapa) a training restaurant helping disadvantaged Vietnamese kids. I visited the one in Sapa and it's a great little coffee/dessert/snack cafe, plus it goes to a great cause.
Important Museum. This summarizes the larger ethnic groups for an overview. Having a guide is essential or it just looks like a lot of wooden structures.
Very educational. This is a must while visiting in Hanoi - provides a picture of the ethnicity of this wonderful country and architecture of the houses in the villages (HUGE HOUSES).

Well worth a visit in order to capture the ethnic history. Entrance fee is very reasonable for what insights one gets of the mutiplicity of tribes, who lived in this part of the world with emphasis on their living conditions, customs and clothing. The outdoor section shows old style boats and dwellings. Well worth a visit.
Worth a visit. It was an interesting use of an afternoon. It was lovely to see all the ethnic diversity of Vietnam being celebrated.

varied and interesting minority group museum. This museum has an outdoor area with many ethnic culture houses that can be climbed into and studied. We also saw a free water puppet show, as it was a Sunday. The inside of the museum has cotume and cultural displays. It is worth battling the heat to see these. A very very good modern style museum.
Great Museum. We loved this! Make sure you go outside and see the houses too. Allow about 3 hours - it's definitely worth seeing.

Interesting attraction. Worth exploring as it gives you an insight into all the different tribes etc in Vietnam. It was very helpful to us as after Hanoi we travelled to Sa Pa and this is where these tribes are prevalent.
Far away from the center but it's worthy to go. Definitely need a tour guide for this amazing place. There is a water puppet show at late afternoon.

Interesting outdoor exhibits, indoor ones require a guide. Great to see and go inside the various ethnic homes. For the indoor exhibits, we went without a guide thinking that we could decipher meaning through the descriptions but were really dead wrong. The descriptions are lackluster, which made it all seem boring. Kids were all hot and tired and didn't have the desire to read through them all. I wish we had a guide or that the descriptions made more sense.
Enjoyable. Very interesting, but it was very hot in the museum.I really enjoyed the exhibits outside. There was enough english explinations.

Visit if u are interested with ethnicity of Asians in this region. I'm not a museum person, but there is only so much to do in Hanoi. This is one of the biggest museum in Vietnam. It showcase the history, background of the different ethnicity and culture of people in this region. The museum is very well kept, exhibits are plenty and there are alot of walking space, hence, u are unlikely to rub shoulders with others. Other than the indoor exhibits, u can also wander around the outdoor, whereby some replicas of the village house being showcased. The houses are nice and unique, but it is also slightly similar to some other village houses in Java or Bali, mainly because people migrate and influence each other cultures in the olden days.The museum can be completed within 1 hour, not within walking distance from French and Old Quarters. It should be included in the itinerary of most 1 day city tours.
Best Museum in Hanoi. I visited the museum with Hanoi Kids, and I am really glad I made the trip to the museum. It was very informative, and the exhibits were well-documented and explained.

Interesting . . . for a while. The outdoor exhibition is really interesting with traditional homes reconstructed and furnished as they would be seen in their original settings, but inside, we found ourselves overwhelmed (read: bored) by display after display of artifacts from various ethnic groups. It may have also been that we were cutting it too close to lunch time!I would definitely encourage a visit but perhaps a limited one, especially if you are traveling with children.

Good way to learn about various tribes in Vietnam. The museum documents the history of various tribes of Vietnam. The indoor portion focuses on the daily pastimes and history of the various Vietnamese tribes. The outdoor portion mainly exhibits the tribal residences. The museum invited the tribal folks to come down specially to reconstruct the houses.There is also an outdoor water puppet show just by the Viet house. They have several shows per day, and last around half an hour each.We stayed much longer than we initially planned for the fascinating exhibitions. A great learning experience for the young and old.The museum is a little out of the way from the main tourist areas so take a cab (from a reputable company like Mai Linh or Hanoi Taxis) here.
great place. This venue was really interesting and gave a terrific overview of the ethnic tribes of Vietnam. The outdoor houses exhibit is tremendous.

Great intro to Vietnam. The highlight of the museum are the traditional houses, though the main display area in the museum does a great job of providing insights into the many diverse people groups of Vietnam. Having lived in Cambodia for over 5 years, I appreciated the way that the museum did a great job of discussing cultural dynamics within SE Asia as a whole, and provided insights into the people groups that live within the region (i.e. both with Vietnam and Cambodia or Laos and Vietnam). Also, they had a water puppet show (only on weekends), which was a great way to see this show without having to go to a separate show (we were only in Hanoi a short time). Definitely recommended!

Unexpected gem. We decided to visit the Museum of Ethnology, way out of the Old Quarter where we were staying, as it was an opportunity for our 4 year old to run around a bit in the tribal homes in the grounds. But what an unexpected treat the museum was! Not only were the houses totally authentic - each one built by tribal members who were invited to reconstruct the building at the site and featuring insights into tribal village life from around Northern Vietnam - but the indoor museum was superb.The circular building featured exhibits depicting life and skills from each tribe, several videos showing processes such as making and lacquering bamboo items, as well as costumes and textiles, cooking, festivals and children's toys. There is a small bookstand with some interesting titles, a museum shop selling beautifully crafted items at very good prices (cheaper and better quality than the tourist shops in the Old Quarter) and a good restaurant, which trains and employs young people recruited from deprived areas of the city. So sorry that my camera battery had given out earlier in the day! Well worth an afternoon of your stay.

Why are the reviews of this place so high?. I cannot understand why this museum is rated so highly. Admittedly there is a lot of information, but it is displayed in such a text heavy, old-fashioned way. The France/ Vietnam photo exhibit was badly lit, sometimes it was quite difficult to read the signs. Also I really didn't get the point of the exhibit. Videos are not labelled, so you have to watch for a while just to figure out what is going on. I visited several museums in Hanoi and enjoyed this one the least. If you are a backpacker or on a limited budget I don't think its worth the time or expense to get here. The Woman's museum covered a lot of the same information regarding different ethnic groups, agricultural practices, ways of life etc (albiet from a female perspective) in a more interesting, interactive and informative way- I'd recommend you go there instead.

The most outstanding museum in Hanoi. Whenever my foreign friends ask me about museum, I would answer this is my most favorite one. Located in the suburb of Hanoi, the museum is very large, consisting of two parts: indoor and outdoor. Although the indoor area is a lil bit overwhelmed of information, the outdoor is just fantastic with buildings from the ethnic groupsHighly recommended to children, and to those who are interested in the various Vietnamese culture!

Take it from a retired curator. As a former museum curator, this is an impressive museum. The collection itself is not huge, but the museum communicates its message well and the outdoor structures out back are most impressive, especially the huge communal structure. We were on a tour and did not get to linger in the interior of the museum as long as we would have liked.

Very complete explanations. If you want to learn about the tribes of Vietnam and Southeast Asia, this museum is the place to go. There are many photographs and videos all in excellent English. There is a large park in the back where different types of houses and community buildings are displayed. You can spend several hours here. It is not air conditioned so can be warm on a warm day.
fascinating. Very well done. Self guided tour with explanations printed in English. Covers the diversity of cultures and geographic locations in Vietnam

Bit boring. Very confusing with all the different tribes, and more confused when we left museum. Large outside area with examples of different dwellings. A lot of pre schoolers and young students when we visited. Wouldn't recommend to my friends as a must see in Hanoi

Well worth the taxi ride!. This museum is often overlooked by the average traveler to Hanoi as it's a few kms out of the centre. It has the most amazing display of the customs of the various ethnic groups that make up the Vietnamese population, in a stunning purpose-built building. Outside there is a large garden area, with full-size houses of each of the different tribes, which you can wander in and out of. It's a fabulous museum, and well worth venturing outside the chaotic centre of Hanoi.

Don't Miss this Museum. This was by far the most interesting museum I saw in VietNam. For me, the best part was the range of re-constructed village houses in the grounds around the main building.The museum is unfortunately a considerable distance from the centre of town, but there is a very comfortable cafe/restaurant that is not only a good place to relax for coffee or a meal but is an interesting project in itself. The restaurant was founded by retired teachers as a training programme for 'disadvantaged' young people, who receive a training here and are afterwards place in jobs in the hospitality industry. Food was excellent (try the shrimps-with-sweet-potato-pancakes!) and very reasonably priced, and the young staff were efficient and friendly.Tip: plan your visit to arrive around 11.00, to avoid the hordes of schoolchildren (some of them only 4 or 5 years old!) who are dragged around the museum in the name of education in the early morning hours. The children are individually charming, but as a group they are horribly noisy - but you can always take refuge in the cafe!

You have to go. take 2/3 hours in your day to stop there, the walk in the garden along the ethnic houses is really pleasant, if you go with kids you can enjoy the puppet theater (that is much nicer than the traditional in town one).This is a real chance to discover the Vietnamese architecture in one place.If you can find a guide I guess this is even more interesting

Ethnology Museum a must.. The Ethnology Museum is relatively new with modern exhibits and text in both Vietnamese and English. Organized in traditional euro-american style with an breakdown of ethnic groups by language groups, regions and ethnology. There are several interesting dioramas that features production methods such as conical hat making and weaving, as well as artifact exhibits detailing life among ethnic minorities. Excellent features included a reconstructed long house, boat models (unfortunately without object labels), religious and ceremonial displays, and textile and ceramic exhibits. The grounds surrounding the museum features reconstructed traditional houses from several areas, a display of real boats and a water puppet theater more like what you'd see in the countryside. There are several performances each day. There is also a very nice cafe, a nice book shop and a gift shop. While the book shop had an excellent selection of books, the gift shop had a very limited selection of real traditional craft work. There were some nice things but mostly the kind of thing you could see in other shops around Ha Noi.
Interesting. Got a good overview of the ethnology of Vietnam. The buildings outside was really interesting. If you don't have time to visit the villages it gives you an idea of how they live.

Do not miss this!. The inside of the museum provides video, photo and mannequin displays of the 54 ethnic groups which make up Viet Nam. These are very well done. However the highlight is the true to life houses rebuilt outside which give a faithful representation of life for the Hmong, Dzao, Tay, and many other fascinating cultural sub groups. Really helped consolidate our understanding after having spent some time in Sa Pa.

Great display of the many ethnic groups. This museum has an excellent outdoor display showing the different buildings the many ethnic groups of Vietnam lived in.Inside is a very good display of artefacts and displays on the many cultural groups that make up the history of Vietnam.Allow one hour to hour and half for the visit.Worth the visit.

Up cultures of Vietnam. All Foreigners loves to visit Vietnam Museum of Ethnology, even you come, you will also love it. Here you can see and get more acknowledge about 56 minorities of Vietnam. They are very full colors with cultures, hystoric,..Come & See

Fantastic fun for the kids. The 4 children we took, aged between 4-7 all loved this attraction. We spent about 4 hours here inlcuding lunch. The best bits were the original houses out in the gardens - the children loved exploring these. There was also a water puppet show on whilst we were there (maybe only weekends?), but this was even better than the one in the centre of Hanoi as it had a storyline to it. The food we had at the restaurant here was great and not bad value. The smaller kids got in free. I think we only paid for the 7 year old.

Great for the kids. We had a great morning at the Museum of Ethnology. The kids loved the interaction of climbing over the ethnic buildings. We enjoyed it as well and found the reproductions of the structures to be a great way to learn about the various ethnic groups. Its a little hard to find as its off the main tourist map of Hanoi (which all the hotels seem to issue) but plan for a 30 minute cab ride from the old quarter.

A must before visiting the minority groups in the North around Sapa. If you have time for just one museum, then take a taxi (50,000 Dong from the Center)here, especially before visiting the minority groups in the North, near and around Sapa. It really helped us to better understand the life and customs of the groups we visited during our 3 day stay around Sapa. Lots of info on the H'mong! Exhibits include costumes, utensils, even life-size constructions of typical houses and dwellings. There are clear explanations of the customs and origins of most minority groups and tribes.Most guide books indicate that you will spend 3 hours here. We read everything and took our time . Yet we were "finished" and out in 1h35 minutes. A must!Check out the restaurant, gift shop. And, if you plan to send postcards buy them here. They sell beautiful postcards and stamps too.

Great location for a family. We took a taxi from the Old Quarter - our hotel kindly organised and spoke personally to the driver on the way there, however on the way back the driver took the opportunity to take us the long way home!! The museum was very interesting as it explains all the ethnic groups of Vietnam, however the kids found outside the best with opportunity to climb into all the traditional houses and explore. Great experience with all information also provided in English. The cafe and garden were also very pleasant.

Go see if you have time. It's a little out of town, but in a taxi costs only 130,000 VND (GBP4). Entrance is 40,000 VND (GBP1.30). Main building houses artefacts from each of the different ethnic groups - really interesting seeing the diversity within just one country. Outside are typical houses and buildings from the ethnic groups - absolutely fascinating. They're not ancient, some have been lived in as recently as last year! Really interesting. It's not very interactive and took us only 1h45m to go around it all - but if you have time, go.

Great for all ages! Bonus park across street. This museum is fantastic! It gives an excellent overview of all the minority groups in Vietnam. Beautiful costumes and well preserved artifacts. We wish we had more time to explore the inside however the kids were too excited to get outside.Outside they have so many houses the kids loved crawling in and out of. They loved exploring each one. We loved seeing how the different groups live. Simply amazing and eye opening.Bonus, when you are done with the museum right across the street is one of the best parks in all of Hanoi!! We love this park!!

Surprisingly good. Really nice museum, and fascinating history of the Vietnamese tribes. Especially good are the 10 or so example village houses in the garden - some great examples of different living styles.

worth a visit. Excellent overview of all the minority groups with costumes, artefacts and real houses to enter. Well labelled in English. Good restaurant onsite supporting disadvantaged kids. Beautiful books on sale as well as handicrafts.

Delightful. This museum is fantastic. It ranks right up there with my top museums in the world. There are displays and objects relating to craft making, arts and spiritual practices of tge 54 ethnic groups. There is a spectacular communal house built in 2003 by villagers, a tomb of another ethnic group with large wooden figures encircling the tomb, intending to accompany the dead to the afterlike. The figures are sexually explicit carvings symbolic of fertility.

Excellent museum; full-size typical houses.. We learned a lot about minority peoples we had encountered earlier on our trip. We really liked visiting the reconstructed houses outside the museum building. (But the French and English translations of the Vietnamese comments are inaccurate--and sometimes contradict each other).

Much more interesting than it sounds!. Great museum, with enough detail to get a decent understanding of the many diverse ethnic groups which make up Vietnam, but not so much that you drown in it. Displays are well explained in English, French and Vietnamese. The outside space with the reconstructed houses is really interesting and brings the displays to life. All in all, well worth a look and the best museum in Hanoi.

Definitely worth the trip. This museum is located outside of the main part of town. I took a taxi from Quan Thanh street (Northern perimeter of the Old quarter) and it cost around 100,000DNG to get there. It was worth the effort. The main building of the museum is not too dissimilar from many other museums I have been to. The highlight was the outdoor area. Lots of traditional houses from different ethnic groups have been relocated to the museum and rebuilt on the grounds. You can enter the buildings and take a look inside at the layout and organisation, all giving insight into the way of life for the people from these groups. Much more engaging than simply showing photographs and looking at replicas.

One of the most interesting museums in Vietnam. This museum has very good reputation for being an outstanding museum, much different from many old style boring museums in Vietnam. Even for a Vietnamese, there are still a lot of interesting things to learn here.They have both indoor and outdoor exhibition. They even have water puppet show on certain time. There are also samples of tribal architectures from different ethnic tribes.The museum is really worth the money and time.

Well worth the money. Excellent place to visit. Well laid out both indoor and outdoor displays - even a 'water puppet' show at certain times of the day. Like most places in Hanoi, it has no air-conditioning, so take a fan and some bottled water.

Great way to get to know Vietnam. All I can say about this is that it is a great way to get to know the history of Vietnam. Even though you should not skip the national war museum, this museum is definately more worth the try. The museum tells vietnam's history ellegantly and dramatically - just as it is.

Useful to give background to the country. Good information in English. Found it interesting, but only really appreciated how much it helped us to understand the country as our tour of Vietnam unfolded.

Informative and kid friendly. Very informative on Vietnam's different ethnic groups and lifestyles. Enjoyable for both adults and kids because of the different kinds of tribal houses. Their water puppet theater also seemed more authentic since it's outdoors.

Excellent way to learn about the ethnic minorities.. We visited this museum in the afternoon with our 9 year old daughter. We had a guide which really helped to explain everything that was going on within the museum. The internal displays are interesting and well placed - no bottle necks of people even though it was busy. My daughter enjoyed photographing lots of the exhibits. We stopped off at the cafe for a spot to eat and the food there was delicious - definitely worth a try.The external exhibits were even more amazing - the replica houses were a fantastic experience. We really enjoyed this visit - especially as later on in our trip we were going to visit Sapa for 3 days and could then enjoy the experience first hand with some knowledge about the different ethnic groups.

Excellent Museum !. The museum displays information on the many ethnic groups of Vietnam, from the hill tribes of the north and centre to the more populous Kinh. Informative displays show the very varied and elaborate dress of each minority tribe, along with exhibits of their way of life such as weaving, fishing and making baskets.The variety of dress styles demonstrate the skill of the makers, and the colors are stunning.It is all very well documented, though the written content could be written larger as everyone had to stoop to read it.Outside, spreading throughout the grounds are samples of traditional housing used by the many minority tribes, quite different and often with steeply pitched roofs. Good fun to wander through and marvel at how cleverly they create all their housing needs from simple,available materials.The museum also serves as a research centre for the many (54) ethnic tribes in the country.It is a museum well worth a visit and at which to spend a reasonable length of time. There is a small restaurant run by a training school.It is a distance from the centre of the city , but worth the taxi ride.

Ethnology museum plus Hanoikids guides makes for a wonderful combo. we booked a half day tour with Hanoikids and asked to go to the Ethnology Museum. We were so impressed at the quality of the museum's exhibits, collections and dioramas. We especially lved the different types of houses from the different tribes that they built on the grounds.With our 2 young guides, we had so much to talk about. Great day.the museum has a nice snack bar on the grounds.

Good to visit. Visited here today and were pleased with the museum. A taxi ride from the old quarter (approx 120,000dong) and a 40,000 entrance was worth it for us. You can also pay for a guide to go around with you but we opted not to as we had limited time and needed to get back to check out of our hotel. Interesting exhibits and artifacts on display.
Interesting. Had a good look around here and the restaurant was nice,it shows you all the different areas of vietnam and how they live

The army museum. Lots of great information worth a visit! My husband was in Vietnam and it was a very confronting visit for him, but read and found information was more about the USA, not to much about the Aussies. But we knew we were there to help. Bit still great to visit

Nice place to visits. It is a nice museum of the life of Vietnamese tribes and people. Entrance not at all expensive. I think we paid 40,000 vnd per person. It is very good value, especially if you can watch the water puppet show, which, we so wanted to. But, when we got there, we understood, that the water puppet show was only during weekends at the museum. So, plan accordingly. You can cover both the museum and the puppet show in one place.

Great Insight into Ethnic Groups. We visited the impressive Vietnam Museum of Ethnology. It gives a good overview of the 54 ethnic groups that make up Vietnam, including costumes, customs and replica housing. We walked through the museum first and got a great understanding of the different ethnic groups. There is lots to see for all ages.Don't forget to walk the grounds where you can see how local people lived and walk through life size models of the different houses of various ethnic groups. We ate lunch at the reasonably priced restaurant which was yummy. It is staffed by young hospitable people.This place is worth a visit when visiting Hanoi.

A nice informative Museum - not a must visit. Check out the outdoor water puppet theater. I would not go out of my way to make a visit to this museum happen if on a short travel to Hanoi but for those that stay a bit longer ad very good place to get a sense of the ethnic diversity.If in doubt hop onto the bus to Mai Chau for more immersion - be however aware that the Vietnamese government tends to organize and put up a pretty village facade for the tourists.

Fascinating even though hot and incredibly crowded. Lots to see - good explanations - but crowd made it somewhat pressurised. Interesting to see the ethnic mix of the whole country. Reconstructions of houses in grounds good.
museum visit. very interesting lots for children to do. Outside you can see how local people lived and go in the houses. the kids loved this, climbing all the steps to get into the traditional homes.

Fascinating. Gives a good overview of the 54 ethnic groups that make up Vietnam, including costumes, customs and replica housing. Lots to see for all age groups. In the grounds there is a restaurant staffed by people saved from the streets and trained in cooking, waiting on and hospitality - reasonably priced and a worthy cause.

Inspirational. We were really impressed with the Vietnamese people ( 54 groups in all) as shown in this museum. Their products, houses, artworks were full of creativity and resourcefulness. Outside the building are replicas of houses of Vietnamese people in different regions and groups.

Interesting. Gives a great insight to the mix of minorities and the total community making up Vietnam. Details history of people movements over the centuries giving a better insight to what makes the country more interesting.

Worth going to. This museum has two sections. One indoor with displays and information of Vietnam's many different ethnic groups, and one outdoor with walk through Long House, Community meeting house, H'mong house and Vietnamese house. Also a burial house. The whole place is very interesting and worthwhile to see.

WORTH A VISIT. An excellent insight into the ethnicity of the people of Vietnam. Great displays also copies of buildings of ethnic peoples which you can enter and feel as though you have been transported there.

One of the better museums. A little way out of the old quarter,well worth a visit. Probably the only museum that doesn't have an agenda. The exhibits are well presented and the replica houses in the grounds are a good insight into life off different tribes.

Indispensable for understanding a tour to Sapa. It is very helpful to walk through this museum with well-prepared exhibits and easy-to-understand explanations prior to a trip to the minority-tribes areas of Viet Nam, especially to Sapa.

An Interesting View of Vietnamese Clothing, Ethnic Culture and More. We spent some time here on a trip to Hanoi. Indoor exhibits, including history, clothing and more, were presented. Outdoors, there were replicas of buildings of varioius Vietnamese tribal groups. They had rather different styles, and this was an interesting part of the museum.

Interesting Museum. Learnt a lot more about the different ethnic groups in Vietnam and the history of the country. The museum is modern with excellent displays and also has a large outdoor area with life size models of the different houses of various ethnic groups. these houses are all open for access.

Another must for a cultural tour of Vietnam. This trip provided so much information which was imparted to us in a coherent way by our guide, explaining about the many different ethnic minority groups that make up Vietnam. This became a good knowledge base for later tours as we travelled North to South.

Good way to learn about Ethnic Minorities in Vietnam. I liked the pictures and exhibitions of the Ethnic Minorities and I finally appreciate what it means to have a unique culture with various tribes and tongues. It also made me appreciate things around Vietnam and how culture evolved with history
Interesting. Visit this site on your own, there is some very interesting information. If you go with a tour group you don't have enough time.
Do not miss it!. A must when visiting Hanoi and Vietnam, provides an excellent overview of the many cultures that made Vietnam.
Nice museum. a very nice museum. especially the houses in the garden were impressive. Also a very good restaurant

This was worth the visit. We visited on the final day of Tet celebrations and walked into a good old fashioned carnival in the grounds that was basic, fun and thoroughly enjoyable for it's simplicity. We used Hanoi Kids who were great people and full of knowledge.
Interesting place to visit. Who knew there were 54 different minorities living in Vietnam, many with their own language and culture.
Very interesting place. It is worth to go there, and look around. Especially to wald outside the museum and see the different houses.

Loads of History. The museum is comprised of loads of information on the 54 tribes that make up Vietnam. Inside there are two floors, rich in displays, as well as, outside displays. We went right after lunch, so it was a little hard to read up on every display but it was well worth the visit. We suggest that you go early, so you have ample time to take in all the history offered through the many displays.

A bit out of town, but maybe worth it. This place is full of information about the ethnic variety that is Vietnam. There was a bit too much information for me to take in after earlier sightseeing, but it is well displayed and if you have the time to take it all in is probably worth the trip.

Excellent attraction. This is both an indoor and outdoor museum with excellent displays. Very popular with both locals and tourists alike and, as an added attraction, there are free performances of a water puppet show.
Very Interesting. Our visit we found interesting, lots of interactive things to do here and the outside area with the different houses was very good.Worth a few hours of your time.

So much to see - get there early!. Fantastic exhibits inside, various examples of houses to explore outside, plus a water puppet show - all for 40,000VND entry - amazing! Cafe is also very reasonably priced. Taxi from Hanoi Old Quarter was 120,000 VND.

Do not skip this museum. This museum is enlightning about the 58 or so different ethnicities in Vietnam. There are beautiful artifacts, fabrics, pictures and depictions of daily life. In the garden there are several houses built by tribe members. If you have time try also the little restaurant in the museum. It is managed by young people being trained in the restaurant business. Very good food.
dense but wonderful. The best, most scholarly display in all of Vietnam! The 54 cultures of Vietnam explained in great detail.

Time better spent elsewhere. I'm a cultural anthropologist who appreciated seeing their collection of pictures and artifacts of groups who have migrated from China to Vietnam. However, your time is better spent elsewhere by riding through the streets of Hanoi and seeing how the people live and work.
Modern. This museum is well worth a visit with nice colourful modern displays. Given the variety of tribes in Vietnam it is very educational.
Interesting Museum. My interest is in the ethnic minorities so I found this very interesting. It whetted my appetite to buy a book on the subject whilst there to study further

Definitely worth a miss. I was expecting to find more interactive displays , actual people from each of the tribes within their style of hens, selling their wares, but no this was not to be found, I would not recommend this to anyone.
