most enjoyable. I have visited three times in four years and would go again if possible. So much information, changing exhibits. Short films, real size homes of ethnic minorities. A gem!

Great place on ethnic. You can spend hours , if you are interested on ethnic of vietnamese you can visit here.
They display different type of ethnic and their cultures.
Since this is part of booked city day tour, so very limited time for me to browse through since my tour guide go 'express'.

Good insight to Vietnamese culture. Varied outside collection of traditional buildings. Well set out costume displays in main building. Museum cafe gives very good value for money as does the shop - some fabulous kites!

Best museum in Vietnam. This was a fantastic museum. It describes the 54 different ethnicities in Vietnam. If you have or will travel the country...it is a must! They show the lifestyle, traditional dress and outside the traditional housing for the different hill tribes. The taxi ride varied from 143,000 dong and 200,000 dong. The best luck I have had so far with honest taxi meters is the green little cars called My Lin taxi service.It is worth the visit!
Vietnam's ethnic make-up. Interesting insight into the ethnic groups that make up modern Vietnam, their traditions and culture

Excellent museum. A very interesting museum. The highlight for me was the outdoor exhibition, which consisted of reconstructed houses from many of the minority tribes. The indoor exhibition was ok but not as well organised and the information not quite as comprehensive as the Women's Museum. A new building for the museum is nearing completion and the quality of the museum will go up a step when this opens.

Educational and Enjoyable cultural option!. This museum is both indoors and outdoors. Very informative about all the peoples of Vietnam and shares their vast history in physical form. Very informative and interesting and laid out in such a way that you feel you have visited the past.

A great venue - add to your itinerary!. This place was like the hidden gem of Hanoi for us!I didn't expect much but I was pleasantly surprised by how much I learnt about the people of Vietnam and their customs. The best part - it was the first time/place in Hanoi that we saw the Vietnamese having fun and smiling. Many of the staff were young (perhaps university students?) - they spoke great English and worked hard to involve tourists in the many cultural/historical activities on show. One of my highlights in Hanoi - so thank you!
Most interesting museum. Brilliant reconstructions of the homes of Vietnamese tribes. You can climb in them and walk around. Definitely worth a visit!

Interesting insights. Recommended. Don't miss the water puppet show.. Although a little out of town (taxi approx 1500 dong from old town) it is worth the effort. The museum is spilt in 2 parts , an indoor exhibition area with primarily costumes & exhibitions of local culture and an outdoor area with reconstructed buildings in the style of various ethnic groups. Both are worth visiting. The outdoor area has the bonus of water puppet shows (at 10,1130, 230 & 4 pm when i visited) These are in daylight and very authentic in the sense that the majority of the audience is Vietnamese who are clearly enjoying the show. It was very noticeable that the majority of tour guides hurry their groups past the water puppet show obviously on the promise they will be attending the Thang Long Water puppet theatre (see separate review). Its their loss. The museum show is a lot more comfortable, more relaxed , and has better photo opportunities although it is a little less polished. Whilst the museum is not the best iv seen of its type. its certainly not the worst and is well worth the effort to get to. The water puppet show(s) is/are a huge bonus.

Just excellent. It had exhibitions of the clothes, articrafts, every day utencils, interiors of houses of many tribes which leave in the country except the Viet people who are the dominant population. In the garden there was a Pavillion where one can seat and eat or have coffee and sweets. The food and desserts is prepared or rather created by future chefs (students of a chefs school).Don't forget to drink vietnamese coffee, very tasty but not light at all.

Worth a visit. This museum displays the 54 different ethnic groups found in Vietnam. It was fascinating to discover the rich diversity of cultures in Vietnam. It was wonderful to see aspects of these 54 cultures proudly displayed. Well worth a visit.
Very interesting. Especially liked the replication of various housing used by different ethnic groups. There is also a very nice restaurant run by students on the site with very tasty food.

A perfect way to spend Saturday in Hanoi. Loved getting a glimpse of the minority ethnic tribes, like my son's, and seeing how they live[d]. Really loved how the museum brought the exhibits down to the children's level, so they could bang the drums, use the kitchen utensils or play with the swings outside.

worth the trip. one reviewer found this museum very boring probably perhaps he was expecting an EPCOT like atmosphere with all the fireworks and the rides. But as lovers of Vietnamese culture, this has to be one of the major stops in Hanoi. You can feel how the Vietnamese appreciate their culture, the hill tribes, the uniqueness of their people. I love how they recreate the different houses ranging from the classical Chinese-inspired courtyard to the high roofed thatched houses. This place is a veritable photographer's Disneyland with many angles perfect for that "Vietnamese" Shot. Lastly, their museum shop is filled with affordable art objects and handicrafts not found on the tourist strip.
Interesting. Found this museum very interesting. The day by day of the many tribes shown gave a good insight into the lives of these people from past to present.

One of the few places to keep little ones attention!. We went here with our five year old daughter and had both a very enjoyable and educational time. While it lacks the polish of some museums, it makes up for that with some fantastic life sized reconstructions of different ethnic homes around Vietnam, which you can climb into and look around. Our daughter loved it and it made a refreshing change from dragging around a whinging child for hours! There was also a water puppet show included which was also fantastic even if we could understand the language. If you have any interest at all (however fleeting) in the ethnic makeup of SE Asia, and/or have a sprog to entertain in Hanoi, then visiting this place is a no-brainer.
Found this very boring. I personally found this very boring, I think if you are 50+ it might be more interesting but for me it was a waste. Taxi was about 120k dong each way if you put on meter
Interesting views on Vietnam's history. Museum gave nice presentation on the different peoples of Vietnam and their history. Two floors of exhibits inside and a number of exhibits outside.

Worth going out of your way to visit. Very interesting museum, with the most compelling exhibits outside -- actual houses from different regions that you could walk around in. Also had games for kids and adults to try (stilt walking, walking on a bouncing bamboo pole, fish catching), which we later saw in "real life" at a village Tet festival near Sa Pa.

A must be seen museum. The first time i've been there. Very nice museum with alot of attractive objects, minor ethnic houses along Vietnam. If you pay it a visit with a local giud he will show you full knowledge about various peoples in Vietnam. Try and experience.

Do Not Miss. If you have some extra time in Hanoi I recommend the Museum of Ethnology. We hired a local guide who showed us through the museum. There are stories of the many ethnicities that have a long history living in Vietnam. There is an amazing outdoor display of actual sized homes built throughout the country by these different tribes if you will. I would allow 3-4 hours plus travel time.

Worthwhile museum. Not far from city center, check the opening days, good introduction to the diversity of the vietnamese peoples, best part was the numerous outdoor villages and buildings (can enter and walk around) which demonstrated the diverse cultures and architecture.

This is a must see. We spent 3 1/2 hours at this very interesting museum. It is a little out of town but definitely worth the trip. We visited it on our first morning in Hanoi and are glad we did. Who knew there were so many fascinating ethnic groups in Vietnam. The exhibits are all vwery well labelled and it is easy to navigate.The outside building exhibits are all genuine inside and out. They provide a very unique glimpse into rural Vietnamese life.We went with some very un museum people who loved it too. A visit to this museum will make you alot smarter of the non war aspects of the country
Worth a visit. Short taxi ride out of town. Gave a good overview of the people of vietnam and their ancestory, lives etc... Great cafe on site run for and by young people in poverty.
Fascinating.. This was the only tourist site we went to in Hanoi and delighted we did. Tells you the fascinating history of Vietnam and well worth the education!

Good detail, plenty of English. I was here just over a week ago. A fairly modern Museum with plenty of information in Vietnamese, Chinese and English. Well laid out, it describes the differences between the different ethic groups in Vietnam.Entry was 25,000 dong for both locals and foreigners. A few thousand extra if you want to park your moped.

Fun, quirky. It seems this museum must have been at least partially funded by the French as there is an inordinate amount of space devoted to all things French. But there is a lot of fascinating stuff here. I especially loved the bicycle loaded with fishbaskts. Definitely worth a visit. Bought a great purse in the gift shop for $15.

A "must" visit. If you want to know more about Vietnam and its cultures, you must visit this museum. Don't miss the various types of ethnic houses outside surrounding the building. Worth the time and short taxi ride.

Understand Vietnam tribes. The museum is not really in the center of town, but it is worth the additional drive. Very interesting if you want to understand diversity in Vietnam. Don't miss the large garden featuring the different tribe housing.
OK ish ........ As part of our tour we were taken there - not quite our thing ......History of the Vietnamese people etc, etc - preferred the War Museum !

Great attraction. We were taken to the Museum by our tour guide and hadn't heard too much about it beforehand. It is a pretty new and modern museum. I would recommend going with a guide who can explain about the different ethnic groups found in Vietnam and how they got there. It tells you about the people that have shaped this country, there is a hugely diverse community. Outside the museum there are recreated villages, you can go inside some of the buildings and imagine how the community lives. It is definitely a must see in Hanoi!

A Great Museum. Thoroughly enjoyed this museum, in particular the outdoors area, where you can go into ethnic houses and meeting rooms. Well worth visiting. The on site cafe has wonderful ginger and honey tea.

A great place to visit if you wish to know the people of Vietnam. I love the fact that places in Hanoi is not all about war. The places we went to in HCM are all revolving on the war and it feels a bit heavy on the heart. I love the outside area of the museum actually and just breezed thru the inside part.

Make sure you find the outside exhibits of stilt houses - the outside area in the back is amazing and easily overlooked. Don't just go inside - go around the back to the replicated villages outside! Kids will love climbing up into the houses and running around!
Greate Place. I liked it, is a review very convenient to the different ethnic groups of Vietnam.It's help me leaern about my country history.Greate place for student.

A thorough insight into Vietnam's past. The outside is made up of different houses that come from different ethnic groups in Vietnam. They are brilliant to go inside. There are also boats and a water puppet display. Inside there are displays of farming implements,fishing tools and means of transportation before vehicles. It is well displayed with descriptions in English & French.

Learn About Vietnam's Diversity. This was my favorite museum in Hanoi. If you like folk art, minority cultures, and learning in depth about village life, this place is great. My favorite part, though, were the life-sized replicas of various minority homes behind the museum. You can climb in them and walk around. So fun. Just take off your shoes first :)

nice architecture. A nice museum with beautifully chronicled artifacts, a wonderful garden and very charming addition of busloads of school children will flock around you! The French and Chinese architecture is a nice blend. I think it was not too large of a museum that you could enjoy within a few hours.
Interesting place to visit. Lots of history, well thouth out display and very informative. The communal buildings were great to get a feel for how the people live.
Museum of Ethnology, Hanoi. Excellent coverage of the people of Vietnam. Well worth the entrance fee. Have to pay additional fee for Camera.

Highlands in the city. If you can't make it to a place like Sapa to see the ethnic minorities, then this museum is essential viewing for a better understanding of Vietnam's people. Beutifully presented and fun for children.

Excellent attraction. The museum itself is very interesting with detailed information about Vietnam's various ethnic groups. Located on the museum grounds are numerous replicas of traditional houses which are very authentic and interesting. In some cases the actual tribes people from the village were brought in to help construct the house thereby achieving a more authentic feel.

A jewel in the crown of Vietnam. Unlike many museums in the West that cover the field of Ethnology in a broad multiethnic range, this museum is devoted exclusively to the ethnic groups of Vietnam, but as there are no fewer than 54 of them, this allows for a very large exhibit, beautifully displayed on two floors of a lovely modern building. Essentially, one walks around in circles, and the signage could be improved to provide a more logical route than that offered by mere chance. While there is an inevitable overlap between the material representing each tribe, the range of variation is really quite surprising, and it is astonishing that they can maintain their individual identities right up to the present day. You will see the history of each tribe displayed through plaques and captions and an array of highly effective photos and illustrative paintings.These are supplemented by actual exhibits of their dwellings, implements, crafts, birth and burial customs, cooking and food habits, dress and costumes, crops, crafts, and mode of transportation. It is as exciting and educational an experience as I have ever had in any museum anywhere. This is no place to cut corners. Take your time, and remember to leave at least an hour for the other attractions: the large open-air reconstruction of full-scale dwellings, communal centers, schools, and places of worship of selected tribes; the excellent restaurant and cafeteria; and the gift shop that offers a staggering array of items way above the quality of the trinkets available elsewhere and at better prices. After all, there is not all that much in the way of culture in Hanoi that can compete with this jewel in the national crown.

high recommended visitting!. Vietnam Museum of Ethnology is one of the most interesting museum in Hanoi. It is where you can have a full image of 54 ethnic groups in Vietnam. Each group contains different characteristic to be distinguished with others. I'm really impressed with the variety of culture in Vietnam. besides, on some special occasions there are many traditional games held there for visitors to try. You can enjoy how ethnic people life.
Shows you life as it is in Minority areas. Short of going to the Minority Villages, this museum gives a good view of the life styles, culture, textiles of these peoples. Definitely worth a visit.
Good museum. Good presentation of the people and culture of Vietnam. Our children were adopted from Vietnam. It was good for them to see samples of what might have been their lives.

Allow plenty of time -- much to explore. This museum does an excellent job of presenting the cultures of many ethnic groups of Vietnam. Ceremonies and costumes are well-depicted. Behind the main museum are a variety of typical houses with explanations in English. Definitely worth a visit!

Great for children. Really interesting museum. Well set out and my children enjoyed it as well as getting a great deal out of it. Helped reinforce what we'd started to see and learn on a trip to the mountains a few days earlier.
A museum with a twist. Regular museum explaining difference between regions. But outside, there are houses built by each tribes and moved around the museum.
Best museum ever!. I loved this museum, contemporary style exhibits and the outside house displays were fantastic! the cafe onsite has great food, so you can spend hours here!

Vietnam Museum of Ethnology – Find Research Center and Educative Videos. One of the best places for research and finding out educational videos is the Vietnam Museum of Ethnology. Located on the Nguen V Huen Road about 8 km from the city center in Hanoi, this museum represents the diverse cultural traditions and heritage of Vietnam in an excellent manner. Highlighting the background of settlers and different ethnic groups in the country, the museum also displays various aspects of their history. It has an indoor part with exhibition building, research center, office, library, storage, technical lab and auditorium. Outdoor area highlights different types of houses existing in all parts of Vietnam. The museum has over 15,000 artifacts, 42,000 photographs, 373 videotapes, 25 CD ROM and over 3,000 slide among others. All in all; the experience was very interesting.
Cultural diversity. Complements a tour of Sapa well by providing background information on Vietnam's different ethnic minorities.

Vietnamese Culture. Excellent place to learn about current and past Vietnamese culture and lifestyle. Learned that there are 54 different ethnic groups living in Vietnam. The gardens contain the houses of different ethnic groups.

Historically Interesting. Vietnam has so many ethnicities and cultures that it's hard to keep track of everyone and their place in history. This museum highlights all of Vietnam's cultures, the backgrounds of settlers and ethnic groups and much of their respective histories. Very interesting.

very interesting. very educational the videos were very good be careful when you leave to get a proper taxi. We were not careful and got into a taxi that had his ID over the meter and we paid way more than we should have

Detailed and informative, a bit far. This museum is a bit out of the way compared to other attractions in town. It cost 130,000 VND by taxi (about 6.50 USD). Displays are quite extensive and detailed. With 54 different ethnicities in Vietnam, there is quite a bit to get through and it can get overwhelming. Outside the museum are reconstructed houses of different tribes, which are interesting.It is a very well put together museum, if you have the time to get out there and back.

Interesting place to visit. Found most of this fascinating. Drawback was being with a guide who kept wanting us to move on to fit his schedule for us. I am not really a museum perso so finding two absorbing places was a big deal for me.

good museum of ethnic cultures of Vietnam. an interesting museum of the different cultures that make up vietnam, even has houses outside that you can walk into and see the rooms. Translations into english were OK

If you have kids they'll have a fun time and the museum is well presented but to be honest we found it a bit boring. The outside where they have reconstructed the houses is interesting and they have a water puppet show in the unlikely event you missed the main one in Hanoi. Some of the inside I liked - the wall with the pictures of all the tribes, for instance, but I have seen wooden utensils/looms/straw huts before and it didn't float our boat. If you have a short stay and no kids I would put this well down the list of things to do in Hanoi.
nice museum. it pays to have a tour guide here. so you will appreciate it more. book a free tour guide from Hanoi Free Tour Guides. It's free.
Very interesting.. We like this open-air museum featuring various types of dwellings of Vietnam's ethnic people. We visited on a Sunday and there were free water puppet shows.
Excellent Museum, the best in Hanoi. If you want to know the history of the tribes of Vietnam, visit here an excellent day really first class exhibits

Visual History of Ethnic Minority Groups. We were impressed with this museum. The layout of the displays made it really easy to understand the timelines of the many different ethnic groups and how they came to be in Vietnam.Our teenage kids really liked the outdoor displays of the various styles of houses, life size replicas, of the different Minority Groups.
Great visit - worth the $6 taxi ride. Really enjoyed the inside (all the ethnic groups, well laid out) and outside (very interesting selection of re-constructed traditional housing) exhibits.

Worth getting there. A little out of the way (ie away from the Old Quarter) but an easy 30 min trip on the No 14 bus from Hoan Kiem Lake bus stop. Nicely set out in large grounds, you get a good picture of the multitude of the ethnic groups who make up Vietnam. A big indoor and outdoor area. Dont miss the Baguette restaurant and coffee shop on site.....this is a training restaurant for the disadvantaged youth of Hanoi...and their banana flower salad is tops!

Worth a visit. If you don't have time to go to the hill tribes then make sure you go here. Make sure you walk around the outside and see the different kinds of houses, it's the best part of the Museum! Went with kids aged 9& 12 and they thought was good also and they don't normally like museums.

visit it if you can!. Enjoyed it thoroughly and was totally interesting. This is an excellent place to visit in Hanoi. Not so crowded, too. It's excellent that they're adding an Asian Museum to this!Too bad I didn't get to buy anything at the museum shop, which was closed (for lunch) when I finished.

interesting. great to visit before going to the villages. It gives a lot of information on the ethnic situation and it helps understanding when travelling through villages, for example from Sapa, etc...With the guide it was a lot more fun and having his understand of the ethnics was very helpful. of course it can be done without a guide but it is certainly not as information as having a local explaining the museum

Good Place to visit. The Museum of Ethnology was recommended by a fellow traveller however it was not as good as all the reviews were saying. The house reproductions were great, especially as we didn't get a chance to get out to see any ethnic groups. It was small and some information was very similar to the Women's Museum that we had seen the day before. We caught a taxi to the location as it is a little out of the old quarter and the taxi driver waited for us at no extra cost! We did not pay the extra fee for photography, no one checked.

Wonderful place. You need a day to absorb all that there is to see.Displays are at a high standard and maintained the interest of our teenage girls.You learn first hand the diversity of the culture in Vietnam.

Amazing experience. A visit to the museum is like a journey along the S-shaped country of Vietnam. We can find miniature Vietnam here and see its all ethnic groups with varied traditions and customs shown in objects, video clips, real houses around the museum and folk games that can only be seen in festivals. It's also a peaceful place to unwind our mind right in the bustling capital city. The food, drink and other services are also excellent. We really enjoyed our time there.
not to be missed. excellent displays of traditional costumes, living areas, etc. with good video footage too and a very high quality fair-trade gift shop
very Interesting. If you are interesting in Ethnic culture, here is the best place for visitting, I really like it here.

Worth a look!. The Museum of Ethnology in Hanoi is dedicated to the culture and traditions of the various peoples of Vietnam. Having visited a few museums over the last month in Vietnam, this is probably the most accessible, with a range of displays, good, solid English and French translations and video to fill in the gaps. Inside the museum you'll find a range of artifacts from different minority tribes, with descriptions of daily life and culture. While these are interesting, the gaps between the different groups are not as large as you might think, so it does become a bit same-y after a while.The real strength of this place are the ethnic habitations outside of the museum. Having a close-up look at how different groups build their houses gives great insight into the daily life of the people, and the differences here ae fore more striking. You need to take your shoes off in most places, but they also supply foot-coverings if you can't be bothered! For the money, it's well worth the visit. Don't spend too much time on the interior, but make for the habitations and you'll be glad you did.
Wonderful Museum. A great place to got if you want to learn about the different ethnic groups in Vietnam. Good explanations in English, French and Vietnamese.
Worth a visit!. Very interesting, and well set out, exhibiting all the minority groups of Vietnam. You could easily spend a couple of hours there.
Interesting. Very interesting to learn about ethnics all around Vietnam. The best part is outside where you can visit real size ethnic habitations.

enlightening center to learn about minority tribes. I would love to have tried the cafe where tribal specialties are served. I enjoyed learning about the matchmaking & wedding traditions of remote tribes and seeing their clothes.

Interesting museum. It's a great museum to visit if you want to know about all minor ethnics in Vietnam. You can see their customs, tools, habits, lifestyle... very interesting. It's also a a peaceful and relaxing place. We spent a whole day there. :)

Well worth a visit. It's about 150,000 VND taxi fare from the city centre but thus place is quite interesting especially if you what to get an introduction to the cultural diversity in Vietnam. There's also a restaurant /cafe that supports and trains young people and a garden with more exhibits.
Interesting and well put together. A great museum away from the centre. Fantastic way to learn a but more about the country and its people. We did it with a guide that made it particularly good.
Each to their own. We had seen a number of other places already so didn't really get much out of this place. Only go if you want to add some more detauls to your trip or have the time.
Very Informative. What a great museum, i learnt alot about Vietnamese culture, history and old architecture. It was very interesting.

Educational. Ok I am not one for "educational" museums because I like to see "famous" things but this was a great museum. Make sure you walk along the different houses in the back. If this is your first time to Vietnam it's a great intro to the different ethnic groups of Vietnam and provides a back story to everything you do.

I thought it was boring. Our HanoiKids took us here as they said it is quite popular. However, it wasn't really my kind of thing. It's all about the different tribes/ethnic groups in Vietnam and their traditional dress, houses, lifestyle etc. If that kind of thing does interest you, I am sure you will love it. It's got labels in English which are pretty informative, but it was just too information dense to stand and read it all. I preferred just chatting about life with the HanoiKids! It's a little away from where we were staying (Hoan Kiem Lake area) so we took a cab which took about 10-15 minutes, but this wasn't expensive at all - 102000dong/about $5. Also a huge modern looking new museum is being built on the grounds, which will house similar kinds of stuff but for ethnic groups in broader SE Asia. Not sure when the opening is planned.
Great introduction to the peoples of Vietnam. Vietnam is a country made up of over 50 tribal groups and this is a great way to understand the diversity of this wonderful country!

Very good museum. Hard to absorb all the info unless you have prior knowledge of some of the minority groups - unfortunately I'd only heard/seen the Hmong. But interesting nonetheless. Be sure to check out the thatched houses and rude wooden statues outside.

Very interesting. Museum focused on Vietnamese local tradition with particular attention to minority groups. Water puppet shows and very well-made reproductions of traditional houses. Definitely worth a visit.
Very interesting. Who knew Vietnam was comprised of many ethnic groups? I really enjoyed seeing the different influences which have come together to create the Vietnam of today.
visit this musem before traveling to Sapa. I liked the exhibits. it is best to wait (if you can) for the new and expanded museum nest door is completed in 2014
Great 2 hours, and suprisingly good food.. My 4 years old had the the highlight of his holiday, climbing in and out of all the ethnic home reproductions. Good cafe in grounds.

Experience 54 ethnic groups in two hours. This was by far one of the best attractions in Hanoi. It was a great way to get an insight into the various ethnic groups around Vietnam by seeing how they dress, learning about the various ceremonies and seeing the different types of houses. Definitely worth a visit if you're not likely to venture of the beaten track to experience the groups in person. Even if you do head up to Sapa into the mountain regions you're only likely to see two - three groups so still make the time to drop in.
Diverse. The musuem gives you a glimpse about the diverse ethnic culture of Vietnam. Well presented. There is a new block under construction which should make it even better.

Great Museum about tribes in Vietnam. A great way to learn and know about he culture of various ethnics groups and tribes in Vietnam. Get to feel and visit the tribe houses outside the museum. A very interesting place to visit.

Worth Visiting. Visited the place based on reviews from Tripadvisor. Definitely worth a visit. Can spend a whole day there. Lots to see. Remember to allocate time for the ethnic houses outdoor. Very interesting place.

good museum. The outdoor exhibits were really cool. Inside there were lots of good pictures and exhibits as well. It would be better if it talked alittle more about the culture. Like why is their hair so long? Why does this tribe shave their eyebrows. Etc. But overall worth a visit.
Starting point. Great starting points for traveller to know the different tribes that live in different part of Vietnam.

Very good, but the garden with the houses and water puppets show is the best!. The museum covers the local habits and culture of all types of ethnic people that live in Vietnam, It is interesting, but after some time very tiring.The best of the museum is actually outside, at the garden. Outside you can find replicas of local houses of villagers that are quite interesting. Besides, they also have a theater to perform a water puppets show, very traditional in Vietnam.
great museum. Great cafe, which supports a local school. The outdoors section with houses from different ethnic groups is great. The museum is fascinating - and a bit overwhelming.

A place to learn more about people in Vietnam. A very interesting place to visit if you like to learn more about the various ethnic groups in Vietnam. Real size ethnic houses can be found at the outdoor exhibits. It might be worth to visit the place in the morning where it's less crowded and you can take time to view the exhibits and take pictures. Entrance fee is 25,000 dong.
Museum of Ethnology. Great for families. Our children loves the different houses outside. The water puppet show was really good also.

Into the Oast. I have been there three times and enjoy it very much. It is well worth visiting. I esp. like the displays of how different ethinic groups lived and are still living today. There are inside and outside displays. There is everything on display from art to a small water puppet theater. When visiting Hnoi I would recommend this tour.

A nice way to learn about the culture of Vietnam. i didn't know Vietnam comprised of such a large number and diverse ethnics. going to this museum give you a deep knowledge about different culture and history in Vietnam.

Meh.... I do agree with the guidebooks - if you have time and energy for just one museum, this is the one. The taxi ride from downtown can be a little harrowing, but it's better if you avoid rush hours. The entry is reasonable, and many of the displays interesting. We went on a cold and rainy day, so we missed the outdoor house museums - if you can arrange it, make sure you hit the museum on a dray and sunny day!

Don't miss this museum!. This was my 3rd trip to Vietnam and I always make time for this museum. It's informative and educational - all about the ethnic minority groups in Vietnam. The best part is climbing into the houses on the museum grounds. It was a good place to visit before our visit to Sa Pa where several ethnic minority groups live. Please support this great organization.

explanation of craftmanship in Vietnam. I was impressed with the craft and artmanship of Vietnam. After visiting this museum, I understand the origin of craftmanship of the country. There were so many ethnic groups and their crafts and arts. We had only 1 hour and we could spend half a day there.

Amazing museum - one of the best. This museum, although out of town slightly (about 110VND in taxi one way) was very interesting. The best bit is outside where there are many wooden and mud houses from the different hill tribes around Vietnam. Great activity to do with kids too as they can climb in and out of the houses.  The shop, run by Craft Link, has superb gifts of a very high standard - certainly worth purchasing here than the tacky tourist shops in the city - and it goes to a good cause supporting various Vietnamese crafts from the hill tribes themselves.
Vietnam Ethnology. This does cover all the different ethnic groups in Vietnam but it is rather dry after a whil. There are no interactive displays and you really need a guide which we had
November visit. Liked the exhibits and the buildings - gave excellent background to the different minority groups. Colourful, bright, excellent descriptions

Museum of Ethnology-Tribal houses. I did not know that Vietnam consists of so many different ethnic groups and cultures. The area behind the museum with several tribal houses and a Water puppet theatre is the most interesting part. Great fun to have a closer look at the tribal houses and get an idea what water puppet theatre is about.
must see museum. wonderful examples of different ethic buildings in the ground. A good selection of artifacts in the museum itself.
Required Visit. If you are spending more than a day, this museum will give you an excellent basis to understand the cultures that make up Vietnam

Worth to Visit. I found the tribal houses especially interesting. There you can see the lifestyle of various ethnic groups in Vietnam and able to step into their house to have a closer look .It located a bit far from the old quarter but you can easily get there by bus No.14.
Good Museum to visit. Lots' of interesting displays, very informative. We also had lunch/brunch at the restaurant there and the food was good too!
Good to visit. Good to know about the various ethnic groups in Vietnam and the history behind them. Enjoyed the visit to the tribal houses located behind the museum

Interesting Museum. Spent a couple of hours wandering around, absorbed in the different exhibits. Truly informative - I hadn't realised how many diverse cultures there were in Vietnam alone. It was not crowded when I went, which gave me ample space to take in the exhibits. Do spend the time to take in some of the videos as well, as they have helpfully provided little stools. The gift shop is also worth a visit.

Loved it. It's about a 15 / 20 min taxi journey from our hotel in the old quarter. Entry is excellent value. A very nice modern building with many interesting exhibits. I loved the outdoor components - we climbed up ladders into these huge authentic Vietnamese replica huts.

Informative and entertaining. We really enjoyed our short visit to this Museum, all exhibits are in English and are informative and give a good background to the minority cultures present throughout Vietnam. It's easily reached by taxi or bike from the Old Quarter (although our driver had a few issues finding it).
The best Museum in town. Good collection of exhibits and well displayed. The out door exhibits are amazing especially traditional houses of ethnic groups living in Vietnam. A must see museum

Fantastic museum. We spent a day visiting this fascinating museum. The grounds have full scale examples of the types of dwelling that the different ethnic groups of Vietnam live in, quite interesting. The exhibits in the museum are well displayed and explanations of the exhibits are available in English. There are also videos showing many of the different ceremonies and the daily life of the people. It was an extremely interesting day. We had lunch in the restaurant in the grounds. This is run as a training facility for underprivileged youth. Our meal was quite enjoyable and very reasonably priced. The gift shop on the grounds is also very reasonably priced.
A quick intro to Vietnam's cultural diversity. A whirlwind tour of what makes up the Vietnamese people, the diverse cultures, culinary experiences and lifestyles

Very nice place to explore.... Interesting museum with the display of artifacts and videos of the Vietnamese village life and outside the musuem, you get to see the live sized houses that the different ethnic groups of Vietnamese people once lived in. You get to enter the houses and take photos of the inner. =D

Fascinating, well laid out -- terrific museum. I loved this museum. It is small enough to be very accessible and not overwhelming, and the outside displays are very helpful. I was taking a group of students to Vietnam to study minority cultures and this was the perfect stop.

Fabulous museum. It's a long ride from the Old Quarter, and no one we talked to wanted to go because of the distance, and they lost out. This is a wonderful museum, with good displays, videos of many facets of village life, great artifacts. Many of the displays include the names of the merchant, artist or craftsman/woman who made the object. Really good museum if you are interested in the jigsaw puzzle of ethnic groups that are cooperating and making this country function.
ethnology museum. a really interesting museum and well worth the trip out to it. I loved the video installations of various tribes and the examples of different houses in the garden of the museum.
Excellent. Excellent museum. Very useful to understand the minorities culture. It is great to see and to visit the minorities houses outside. The explanations are very educative.
One Stop and Know Them All. love the outdoor part of the museum, get to see the real architecture of each ethnic group all at once... walking around was fun

best museum in Hanoi. We often go there just to sit in the outdoor grounds and enjoy.. read a book in the cafe and enjoy a light meal. The best is the shrimp cakes! Service staff are training so do not expect too much. I think it is a great place for weekends as you will also get a free water puppet show. Beware the noise level. However it gives you a bit of what is to come at the better water puppet show downtown. The museum itself is quite interesting and much to see and takes about 2 hours or more. The outside exhibitions is stunning.. remember this is Nam.. so this museum for me covers quite a bit of minority understanding if you do not have time to actually go and visit other places for some authentic experience. It costs 25,000 dongs and kids are free.
Fantastic insight into Vietnam's diversity. It is not a big museum so it is good to visit with small kids. I like their outside parts with authentic houses from regional areas.
Very well thought out. Great museum - lots of information and colourful, interesting displays that really informed the visitor well,
A cultural heritage. an understanding of the social practices and tradition of the ethnic groups and the social history of the migration of various minority groups into Vietnam.

Amazing. They actually moved the whole house from the village to the city and even a stone also made it as original as it was... What a good presentation! Amazing! If your phone have GPS, just take a bus and have some walk.... Then you really can experience the current and past ethnology of Vietnamese.

Perhaps Hanoi's Top Attraction. While we lived in Hanoi (2007-10), we hosted several dozens of guests, and all were happy that we steered them to the Ethno Museum. It's not downtown, and many tours omit it, but for a visitor who can spare half a day, there's plenty to see. Exhibits introduce the remarkable diversity of Vietnam's 53 minority ethnic groups (altogether about 10 percent of the population.) The museum's got a uniquely (for VN) excellent way of presenting its exhibits, thanks to a collaboration with the Musee des Hommes in Paris.

You must do this. We are travelling a a five, my husband, his parents and our daughter. The insight into the culture and traditions is so enlightening. It is not boring in your standard museum manner our 7 year old was able to read and enjoy the exhibits too. The outside arena makes this experience. You see so much of what it is like in the villages in terms of houses, storage and resources. They are currently making a huge new museum and we were told that the exhibits will be bigger. This is the best museum I have been to in Vietnam. The ride out for the old quarter was also an interesting experience!
nice peaceful change to Hanoi. A bit out of the way but worth the 3 dollar taxi ride.A real feel for authentic houses in the countryHave lunch at the little French cafe there, very good.
Definitely a place to drop-by after Uncle Ho. Really enjoyed seeing and understanding the 52 different cultures in Vietnam. Great outdoor replicas of the different Vietnamese houses!

Super Interesting. Very interesting overview of the 54 ethnic groups in Vietnam; definitely focused on a few, but it would be impossible to give equal detail about all of them without an even greater space. Outside exhibits were really interesting as well. Recommended.

Vietnam in a nut shell. All the tribes of Vietnam are epicted in this museum Well worth a visit. The gift shop is a special find. Many interesting hand crafted items for sale at very reasonable prices.

Wonderful way to learn about Vietnam. One of the best things about Vietnam is how they try to preserve their heritage and culture. The Museum of Ethnology is rated as one of the best museums in the world so you should go and see. There, you will experience a glimpse of historical Vietnam, from the time of their ancestors and how they lived their lives. Great learning experience!
Best Museum. Excellent museum - make sure you have at least half a day to enjoy all it has to offer! Well laid out and presented with many hand on sections. An excellent outdoor exhibit.
Nice displays. The stuff they showed indoors can be expanded on. Visiting the different types of homes was much more enlightening

A worthwhile trip for those interested in the ethnic groups!~. Went there with our Hanoikids guide. There are well detailed English signboards. Thus, without a guide, you can also explore on your own. But of course, with a guide, you can know much more about the culture of the different ethnic groups. There are a lot of information in the museum, be it indoor or outdoor exhibits. I love how they have outdoor real houses for tourists to take a look so as to better understand what we saw in the indoor exhibits. Really interesting!You can spend up to about 2hrs there or even more if you are extremely interested in the exhibits :)It is quite out of the way from Old quarter but really worth a visit if you want to gain an introduction and understanding of Vietnam's ethnic groups!

Very excellent museum. Spent roughly 3 hours at this museum. The indoor exhibits were rather boring but the outdoor exhibits cannot be missed. No doubt one of the best museums around in South East Asia. The cafe outside the museum also serves pretty good and very cheap western and vietnamese food.

Museum far and not a lot of content. The museum is dedicated to showing the various cultures and ethnic tribes of Vietnam. However, it seemed to not have a lot of content regarding the different groups. The museum was also far from the Central part of the city.

A worthwhile visit. This was a great way to try and gain an understanding of Vietnam and it's people. There is just so much information to take in so prepare yourself to spend a couple of hours here. It's fascinating to see how many different ethnicities make up Vietnam and the subtle and not so subtle differences between the tribes.
Best museum in Hanoi. Excellently laid out with English information and interesting DVDs depicting various cultural event amongst ethnic groups. Lovely gift shop attached run by Craft Link

Very interesting - worth the trip out there. Very extensive collection of exhibits, particularly the outdoor collection with some very unique pieces. There is also a good indoor area with displays and information about the 500 odd minority groups that make up Vietnam - helps bring all the outdoor into perspective. Well worth the trip out there, particularly on one of the local buses.

Interesting Place. Interesting place with well thought out displays. Having an interest in tribes of Southeast Asia I found this museum particularly interesting and informative. If staying in the Old Quarter the museum is too far to walk so would recommend taking a city tour which includes the museum. If you have any interest at all in the culture of Viet Nam this museum is a must see.
Interesting. A very interesting museum to know more about vietamite people and their history. We like very much the local houses and how they make the typical hats!!!
One of the best museums. Meet this nice multi etnic people and know its history and costums.You will fill inside the country and the vietnam life in a very intensive way.

A quick trip around the museum is all thats needed. There is an overload (but in the good sense) of information here. A lot of the outdoor exhibits are interactive which is good and it is easy to navigate too. Just be sure to purchase your ticket, I missed the ticket window and the ticket checking guy had to point me in the right direction.
Interesting ethnic museum. Worth our time to have a first hand knowledge of all ethnics groups in Vietnam. Would suggest all travelers to visit.

Must do introduction if you are touring the country. We were on a tour of Vietnam which was going to take in visits to some of the ethnic minority areas. This was an essential introduction but you can get rapidly bemused by the different groups and sub-groups. Generally well set out, especially the outdoor exhibits.

Probably the most important 'must see' in Hanoi. This museum is fantastic. If you want to really understand the ethnology of Vietnam, there's nowhere better. Each of the 53 minority ethnic groups is well covered, as well as the majority. There are some wonderfully authentic and detailed ethnic houses spread around the grounds and a free water puppet show (11.30 am) which is well worth seeing (go early to get a seat). There is also a nice restaurant/coffee shop in the grounds staffed by disadvantaged youth under training - try it. Give yourself a couple of hours at least for your visit. You can also take in the Ho Chi Minh's Mausoleum, houses, museum, the Presidential Palace and the One Pillar Pagoda on the way back to the city. A great and educational day out!

Worth a visit. Does a nice job of showing the various ethnic groups that live in Vietnam - there are over 50! This museum has indoor exhibits, and full size/scale outdoor housing and temple buildings.
Great place for kids to explore. Our 4&6yo children enjoyed exploring all the different houses and having the chance to run around outside.

Indoor and Outdoor. This musuem really captured the cultural aspects of Vietnam and was a great follow up after spending time in Sa Pa. The outdoor areas have a wide variety of traditional houses that you can freely walk around and experience. It is fantastic!

Small but worth visiting. Outside exhibits are great as are some of the artifacts in the museum. We heard the women's museum too has tribal crafts but didn't get an opportunity to visit. We were fortunate that they had an extensive handicrafts exhibition with tribals selling directly to customers the weekend we visited the museum.
Good day out. Would have preferred more 'hands on ' exhibits indoors but outdoor section was very interesting and we felt more involved.

So worth the taxi fare!. I was aware of the fact that Vietnam is a very culturally diverse country, however this museum really gave me a much clearer understanding of its history etc.The museum is out of the centre so make sure you organise a way to get there where you pay a fare amount. We paid 120K for a taxi from the old quarter. Used Hanoi Taxis and that worked well.Ah, also the museum has lots of interactive displays of all different types of dwellings and a water puppet show outside, so plenty to do for kids in there too.
Awesome.. An absolute must of a visit. Set aside an entire morning to appreciate it though. Highly interesting and insightful look into the Vietnamese people and culture.

“Wonderful museum”. Fantastic museum, displays are excellent and portray Vietnamese life and culture. Grounds are good to wander in and have several typical old houses to view.Take the no 14 bus from Hoan Kiem lake.Ride costs 5p! approx 7 km.

Really well displayed. Highly detailed, well designed displays worthy of many world class museums. Don't try to rush it. Discussion of,the dozens of different ethic groups is the most detailed I have seen anywhere.

Wonderful museum. Fantastic museum, displays are excellent and portray Vietnamese life and culture. Grounds are good to wander in and have several typical old houses to view.Take the no 14 bus from Hoan Kiem lake.Ride costs 5p! approx 7 km.

Interesting look at cultures outside the main cities. The Ethnology museum depicts the clothing and lifestyles of the 50+ ethic groups who live in Vietnam. Most interesting were replicas of the homes of the mountain people which are vastly different from what most tourists see. The courtyard of the museum is set up as a craft fair for the tribes who are represented at the museum and vendors sell items not typically found for sale in the larger cities.
outstanding museum. I love this place, was located out of town, but town has grown to meet it. Worth the effort of getting there.

Great place to visit. I visited it with my family and tried to get there using the local bus, which wasn't such a good idea. But once we got there, it was definitely worth the trip. The Museum itself is worth it, but the Ethnic minorities traditional houses outside were absolutely great. Really worth the trip!!!

Great place in Hanoi. Just a bit far from Hanoi old quarter center, it takes about 15 minutes by taxi to get there.
At this place - museum of Ethnography is exciting place where almost Vietnamese groups lifestyle and culture samples show up as the house, furnitures, dress... It is worth to see.
Fascinating to see how the 54 communities of vietnam lived. Tall house and long house are amazing.... This is the most interesting museum in Hanoi..... And i think i have done hem all....
If you museums yes!. This was a bit far out - had to take taxi and you have to spend a lot of time there to see and experience everything!

very interesting. I could have spent more than the 1.5 hours our tour allotted. if you are interested in ethnic groups and their history, dress, housing etc, be sure to see this. it was very interesting. The outdoor part had a series of ethnic traditional houses fully built that you could walk through.

vietnamese tribal cocktail. the museum map and tour is obvious, you can4t miss it.
exhibits are well explained and sufficiently motivated with example, DVD, graphics.
also the garden with re production of some minority houses is amusing.
you can choose your own pace, min 2 hours - could spend half a day and have a drink in the resto

Very interesting place. It was interesting to immerse ourselves in the local culture. Excellent coffee shop there was well with unreal hot chocolate. We spent about four hours at the location and really enjoyed it. Recommend it to visitors as it gives one a better understanding of life in Vietnam.
Make time. Many diverse peoples populate Vietnam. If you want to know about them, this is the place to go. Two floors inside and an outside area also. We caught a water puppet show here!

Very nice. This is a very nice way to see high-quality exhibits in a short period of time. We recommend a guide to explain all the exhibits so that full value is delivered. Soon a new museum of ethnology will be open next door, but for now the current museum is a nice way to learn about the 16% of Vietnam not represented by the dominant ethnic group, the Viet.

Outstanding Museum. We were very pleasantly surprised by our visit to this museum. The display of different tribal groups and activities was done extremely well and the real houses they brought into the park to get the full life size feel of things was great. As a bonus they have one of the best little gift shops in Hanoi with some very high quality merchandise.

Ethnographic Delights. A fantastic museum. There are 53 ethnic minorities in Vietnam. The museum has clothes and artefacts from many of the groups, and fascinating buildings from a smaller number of the groups around the main museum building. Wonderful. Almost worth a trip to Hanoi to see just this.

Great and getting better. A first class museum. Will show you wonderful artifacts and give you a good overview of the different ethnic groups. The only downside is no A/C inside the building, nice in the outside exhibits, but inside it is very hot.

Excellent overview of Vietnamese culture and ethnic make-up. Honestly we weren't sure what to expect and were a bit skeptical, but we now regard this museum as a must-see in Hanoi. It's incredibly well laid out, and the outside "exhibits" of actual homes from various ethnicities is really quite amazing. We've spent time in villages in Vietnam and the exhibits are extremely accurate and detailed. Would recommend to fully understand Vietnam's many facets!

Nice peep into Vietnam. A short (2-3 hours) visit to this museum will give one a very good glimpse into Vietnam, its peoples, its tribes, its geography, its products, its industries, its culture. Vietnam's history has been colorful and, sadly, largely ignored because of the spectre of the Vietnam war. It's history and culture are certainly more colorful than just the war. There are agricultural implements, fishing implements, textiles, masks, medical artifacts, traditional houses and even traditional medicinal plants. Rich indeed!

Very interesting and light-hearted after the Museums.. A wonderful place to see. Look at how the Vietnamese used to live. See the improvements they are making to this tourist spot, to add to your emjoyment. A nice light-hearted way to end your tours of museums and the mausoleum etc.,

'Ethnology' - Wow. It's Ethnology, not Ethnography! Names aside it's a fantastic museum, in fact I don't believe I've been to a better one in Europe. After going to the Louvre I didn't want to look at another piece old Renaissance art for the rest of my life and the Mona Lisa was much smaller and surrounded by a much bigger crowd than expected. Cynical I know but so many European museums are 'overcollected', that you lose the interest because you get drowned by the options. This museum is perfect, with more space dedicated to real life ethnic buildings than old paintings - you really get a feel for how people live in the ethnic minority villages of Vietnam. You've also got all the historical info you could ever need inside with artefacts and timelines etc I've been lucky enough to get out and into some of these villages and the museum has done a wonderful job. Hats off to the Vietnamese authorities and the French benefactors in putting it together.Oh and the museum shop has reasonable prices and money goes to charity - you'll probably get a better deal here than trying and failing at haggling in the old quarter for your nick nacks.

Excellent outdoor and indoor display!. Before travelling to Sapa, we had 2 days in Hanoi. We decided to visit Museum Ethnography. Not only does this Museum have an excellent outdoor display, the Indoors display is excellent as well. The Museum has a large collection on display of objects of daily use, like knives, baskets, mats, etc., used by the different 54 ethnic groups in Vietnam. It also has the clothing collection, agricultural tools, fishing instruments, musical instruments and jewellery belonging to the 54 ethnic groups of Vietnam.

Interesting for all. outside the museum building on the museum grounds are reconstructions of various huts of ethnic tribes that you can go inside and check out. Some have decorations and instruments that you can try out. This is the most interesting part of the museum and worth checking out !

A must see museum in Hanoi. If you really want to get an understanding of the peoples of Vietnam then this museum is the place to go. I thought we would spend a couple of hours there and five hours later..... Very informative and interesting displays and videos of the many groups of people who make up the Vietnamese, most notably the minority groups. The museum is a little far from the Old Quarter so make sure you agree a price first for the taxi.
Unique. That was one of the most amazing place i visited in Hanoi, the place for all past Vietnamese people. They showed some traditional & unique things from ethnic minorities in Vietnam.
interesting for etnic costume. the outside garden is nice to have an idea of vietnamese special houses and you can even climb in one house or visit some inside.1 hour is enough to visit

My favourist place in Hanoi!. That is a great place, I like to enjoy my weekend to stay at Ede's home and read book, really fun, esp in summer!. Especially at weekend, there are a lot of children come here and play traditional game, you can join with them, or some time if luckily you can listen to "Ca tru" and watch water puppet here. Recomend you to visit here when you are in Hanoi :)
Wonderful and enlightening experience. A great opportunity to learn a little more about the people of Vietnam. We were shown around by members of Hanoi Kids and that made it even more special.
Awesome. The Vietnam Museum of Ethnology was very interesting and enjoyed learning about the many ethnic and culture groups of people in Vietnam

Really interesting museum especially the outside exhibits. Worth a trip to see to understand the huge diversity of Vietnam and all the various tribes living in the country. The houses which have been erected in the outside part of the musuem really bring the culture to life and give you a great insight into the country and its people.
worth visiting, but could be better. Nice exhibits, but only a bare minimum of information provided for each display. For example, most artifacts didn't include an estimated creation date,

take your time. enjoyed sitting on the stools provided and taking time to read as much as I could about each of the different groups. Fascinating. If interested in reading more buy the book of your choice from the museum as I found it difficult to get the same choice of titles on ethnology elsewhere in Hanoi.
One Stop History Shop. A great place to give yourself an overview of the development of Viet Nam. Excellent displays, hands on and plenty of audio visual displays
A good picture of Vietnam. This museum needs time for a visit with its inside and outside exhibit. Has good information at each area
Extremely interesting &good value. This is an extremely interesting museum and good value too.It provides a good introduction to Vietnam, as well.

Great museum. Nice museum that gives a clear overview of the etnic diversity in Vietnam.Well maintained with clear displays in English and French.Also nice temporary exhibition.A pity that the new part wasn't open yet for the public.
Typical. A lot of information about the minor hill tribes but it was the typical soulless communist presentation. A lot of cats but no real attempt at understanding the people.
Fascinating. Great prelude to visiting the mountain regions and seeing it all for ourselves, we'll worth a visit! Defin enriched our visit to Vietnam

Favorite museum in Hanoi. This is definitely my favorite museum in Hanoi. I recommend hiring one of the museum guides, as they provide additional color and make it more interesting than just reading the plaques. It's fascinating to understand the ethnic make-up of the country and to read more about the rich history of the Vietnamese people. Highly recommended!

Amazing museum!. Our tour guide Mr. Kiem is an awesome guy. He told us many amazing things about many ethnic minority people's life. There were namy types of houses too. The house was built with wood and above from the ground. I was intersted in many stuff showed there. What an amazing culture! Amazing museum!

Very informative and very original. The museum shows the ethnic groups of Vietnam with the costumes, traditional houses and a lot of information about the way of life. There is a path in a kind of beautiful and cool park where I visited the typical houses of each tribe. Very informative and very original. Beautiful museum that makes us discover Vietnam through these traditions, the customs and everyday objects! Do not miss the puppet show water occurs outdoors several times a day, very nice when it is sunny and not too hot.

A must do in Vietnam!. There are 54 different etnic groups in Vietnam, but unless you travel to the very north or some specific places is Viet people you will see. The Museum has a wonderful lay out and exhibits to better understand all of Vietnam. In the inside, traditional dresses and artifacts, in the outside whole houses. The little restaurant inside is like an oasis in Hanoi and is staffed with young people coming from difficult enviroments. The store provides very good quality and very atractive priced souvenirs manufactured by people from the different etnic groups.
our Cambodia and Vietnam trip. the educational value and the life style of the people throughout the regions were very interesting and well presented. Their gift shop is a "Don't miss"
worth the trip out there. If your interested in the hill tribes of Vietnam, this is a must visit.They even had a water puppet show that afternoon

Historic women. this place was nice, the helpful tour guide talked many useful things about Museums, i enjoyed it because this place showed almost of ethnic minorities in Vietnam, each of them has located in a small place, it could be more amazing, many people coming inside as well. the ticket was not expensive, over us$1 i remember.
The history of Hanoi. I like it because it tell tourist Hanoi is make up of different groups and yet lived a harmony life. Each group have their own costum and headdress.

Ethnology Museum. We got the local bus, number 14 from Hoan Kiem lake (north point of the lake where the buses stop for a few minutes). The bus cost us 5000vnd and took around 20 minutes in clear traffic. We had a note from our hotel written in Vietnamese to give to the bus conductor (or anyone else) which explained where we wanted to get off. When the bus drops you off, you need to cross over the large road and backtrack slightly to the first main turn off. A 5-10 minute walk past some large buildings and you will find it on your left. On the return trip just get the same bus on the opposite side of the road.The museum itself was pretty good; lots of things to read and artefacts to look at. There were lots of impressive traditional clothing outfits. Outside you can see, and walk into, lots of different styles of houses etc. We stayed for about an hour and a half in total.. I don't see how some reviewers say 4 or 5 hours can be spent here though? While the museum was good for information, we felt it lacked a little in excitement, or interaction - maybe something to note if you want to take young energetic children, they may get bored. We spent a long time stood around trying to read long information boards while hoards of noisy children bustled past us; it was a little hard to keep focus at times. Also with no air con it got a little hot in there.Overall I think it's worth going for half a day.
The place to be!. Really interesting information about Vietnam's population, loads of young people and children wandering around, making the most of this great facility

Exceeded expectations. Intended to visit for an hour but it turned into two. Internal exhibitions are nicely laid out and easy to follow / understand. Outdoor examples of different types of house very impressive. Kids will enjoy this part. Highly recommend.

Understanding Vietnamese culture. An amazing number of ethnic groups live in Viet Nam, but you must travel to remote area to see them; or go to the Hanoi museum of Ethnology to understand the diversity of culture in Viet Nam. The Long house is amazing!

Informative and respectful display. It was enlightening to see great information about all the ethnic minorities and provided great insight and appreciation in advance of our visit to Sapa and spending time with these minorities.

Surprise gem. The museum is a little out of the touristy heart of Hanoi but it certainly is worth the small taxi fare to get there. It showcases the various ethnic groupings of Vietnam, their ways of living and some artifacts. Easily done in an afternoon.

A long way - but worth it. This is a great museum especially for children, the outside area with life size reconstructed ethnic minority houses is brilliant. There is a lot of great information and you can easily spend 4 - 5 hours here - there is also a great restaurant from the Hoa Sua chain (charity for helping Street Kids) Definitely worth a visit.

Unravels the ethnic background of the Vietnamese. This museum is worth a visit just to help understand the complicated mix of ethnic backgrounds which have created modern Vietnam. It is not somehere that you need to spend hours at, unless you are the very studious type and the external relocated tribal buildings is probablt the most informative area to spend time.
Cultural and Historical. Love to see the museums but this museum always let me deeply in love with this because it offers so much things cultural and historical info about the ethnic minority people.

Must visit to understand Vietnamese life. In August and September, I had the wonderful opportunity to live in Hanoi for two months. I lived with a Vietnamese family and being there for researching purposes In the afternoon I went to Ethnology Museum in Hanoi with my roommate. It 'a great museum, very interesting and with the rate 1:1 scale housing and rites of ethnic minorities (more than 50!) of Vietnam. What I would recommend is to make a visit to the museum, and then a trip to Sapa in northern Vietnam, to get to know these wonderful ethnic groups.

Great Musuem. This visit was part of our day with our "Hanoi Kid" and if you like musuems (and I do) it is not to be missed. If you are not going to have the chance to visit some of the countless ethnic villages in the north then this will give you some insight. If you are lucky enough to get out into the villages then this will help to prepare you. We stayed more than 3 hours but could have easily stayed longer.
the heaven for anthropologist. It is absolutely amazing place, you should go there before your trip to Sapa so you can understand more about their tribes.

Interesting cultural visit. This was an interesting place to visit, it tells of the various cultural groups in Vietnam. The outside walk/gardens were really pretty and it has some great displays.We had a lovely meal in the restaurant on the grounds which is run by disadvantaged young people.
first museum in hanoi. Prince1 hotel's staff was recomment visit this museum ( it is a little far from hotel) but i dicided to visit, it was nice and funny

This is a don't miss place. This museum is worth an afternoon and should be on everyone's short list of places to go. Effective exhibition of artifacts relating to the 52 ethnic groups of Vietnam, including full-size house replicas in the garden. A very well-done and authentic representation of the diversity of Vietnamese life.

Very realistic. Very accessible for tourists as there are texts near the exhibits in English, French and Vietnamese. The houses looked very real (and some resembled the ones I had seen in/near Sapa). Nice overview of the different social groups living in Vietnam.

Lots of interesting village dwellings to explore. A relaxing couple of hours can be spent here, followed by lunch at the restaurant.All info signs are in Viet., French and English. Free English pamphlets are available just inside the main building entrance. While the internal displays are interesting, the highlight is the various buildings built or transported and reassembled by the various ethnic groups. This did not seem to close for lunch, like the History(?) museum. Entrance fee 25k VND for an adult.

Very interesting. Very interesting place and well put together. Saw the mini water puppet show that was very funny! The displays are very interesting , but it can be a little overwhleming with all the information. Cool examples of houses and clothes.
All about ethnic minorities in Vietnam. Excellent. I could have spent a day, but I only had an hour to spare. Explains the customs and living patterns of various ethnic minorities in Vietnam.

Don't miss the cafe. The museum is wonderful, particularly the outside exhibits. You can 'feel' the village way of life so realistically portrayed. The cafe is worth a visit. It is a training place for aspiring young people to learn the skills needed in the tourist industry. Food was great.
Interesting. We enjoyed our two hours exploring the history and ethnology of Vietnam. Learning about the many different ethnic minorities gave us a good insight into Vietnam's real culture

Undergoing renovations for there new Location. Takes about 2 hours to go thru this place on hot days they sometimes run the a/c at the entrance . Good ideal to wear sandals as you will be taking off your shoes going through the ethnic houses. And they do a nice free Puppet show ...Careful on rainy days as outside can become slippery and muddy.

Ethnology Museum. Every one must love it when you come to visit. There are so many things to learn about Vietnamese people and culture from here. Nice place to visit and can spend half day to see everything.

i was really impressed with Vietnamese culture. there were so many strange things there. Just surprised about life of people in minority ethnics. their house was so strange and very attracted me some how. There was a lot of information for tourists to read about things showed there. You may not need a guide :)

Great place to visit. I like culture of Vietnam and special culture of ethnic minorities people. There was all detail of culture with picture, real meterial, tools, and video was deslay in here, many things to experience

Worth a visit. This is definitely worth a visit especially if you are heading to Sapa as well. Gives you some background to the different tribes living in Vietnam, the different houses outside are especially good.

Museum of Ethnology. Important museum to visit if you want to gain some idea of all the ethnic groups that make up modern day Vietnam.
Don't miss the outdoor displays of common houses and huts of the various ethnic groups.
Could be more display descriptions in English, however.

Excellent - well worth it. Although the inside was interesting and informative, I thought it was a little bland and got bored. However, I was really impressed with the outside exhibits around the grounds. There are many buildings to explore which all give you a great insight into Vietnamese culture. You can climb up into the traditional community structures, interact with the guides and wander around the gardens and discover many hidden treasures. Take a camera as there's lots of highlights. The cafe was lovely too and provided a welcome retreat from the heat. Well worth a visit

Value to visit. Ethnology Museum in Hanoi is value to visit, that is nice places to know about Vietnamese country. The Museum is quite big and well display, especially I love the part of out door, they display house of Vietnamese ethnic Minority from the North to the South... the atmostphere is beautiful...
Insight into Vietnamese culture. Lots to see of the minority groups, their lifestyle, culture and customs. Very colourful and well set out. Worth a visit.

Not my kind of museum but maybe intersting for other tourists. You will learn a lot about the different Vietnamese tribes, the culture and history. You will also see a LOT of traditional clothes. The original huts in the outside area are impressive, though.
Not worth a visit. Not for the young and adventurous. Showcase the minority ethnic group of Vietnam. Will needs further enhancement to really attract the major crowds.

Good place to visit. Good exhibition of the various cultures in Vietnam. Inside the building was a bit stuffy, but there are many interesting cultural buildings in the compound... especially the tall house, water puppet stage in a pond, and fertility figures around a tomb.

interesting ... shortened by rain. Inside exhibits ho-hum. Outside villages may have been interesting but the rain came and we left. the inside exhibits would have benefitted from some strategically placed fans.

So many things around us. You can discovery in Vietnam Ethnology Museum with stranger emotion because people in here lovely and very hardworking. I and my friend standing long time watching they make traditional conical hat on the television very interesting and so difficult.

A real insight into Vietnamese Life through time. Our first full day in Vietnam (and Hanoi) was a Sunday. Our Hotel suggested we wander over to the Museum of Ethnology. We thought we knew something about Vietnam but a visit to this museum showed us just how superficial our knowledge was of this vast, complex and populated country. So many young Vietnamese were ther, we thought it must have been a special day, but no, they just liked being there to celebrate their culture. An excellent display housed in the main building was complemented by what was going on in the grounds - a traditional water puppet show in an outdoor water theatre (thankfully it was outdoors because the fire breathing dragon puppets set fir to the stage curtain!), several life scale traditional houses were set up and you could go in and explore how some villagers lived and some examples of traditional burial buildings were set amongst the gardens. We were amazed at just how many discrete ethnic communities make up modern Vietnam and we enjoyed so much speaking to the young Vietnamese who approached us shyly just to practice their english and satisfy their curiosity. It was such a great day.
Great experience!!. Love the outdoor exhibition here. Overview about different tribes of Vietnamese. Notice the time of outside water puppet theatre, it will be very interesting

Ethnology Museum. It's worth to come there to learn about vietnamese culture. It's very nice collection of clothing and stuff from different hill tribe living in Vietnam. Explanation in English and French. You must love to see it

So amazing about minority ethnics's customs!!!!. this place is awesome!!! People can learn about many ethnics in Vietnam. They have many strange and interesting and unique custom. Cant believe it ^^. Very informative insights to the culture and traditional values of the different ethnic groups in Hanoi. There are a lot of English explanations, so you don't need a guide but if you want to know about the stories behind those amazzing thing showed there you should have one guide ^^. i walked around and took a lot of photoss outside the House. There are many types of house of others ethnic. i loike "nha san" which is built of wood and higher than the ground. So beuatifulllll....

see the different cultures throughout Vietnam. Vietnam has 54 different ethnic groups all of which have been allowed to maintain their identity in this culturally diverse country. This is good museum which gives you a chance to see how some of the groups live in various areas. excellent visit

If you can only see one museum in Hanoi.... Experience this one. You can explore the village and mountain life, all without leaving Hanoi. The exhibits are interesting and in English. An afternoon spent here is kinda of like Vietnamese Culture, 101.
Don't bother. No air conditioning, displays similar to a primary school fete. Toilets disgusting, little by way of explanation of exhibits
Worth a visit!. Very informative insights to the culture and traditional values of the different ethnic groups in Hanoi.
Suprisingly good. There are a lot of English explanations, so you don't need a guide. The outdoor exhibition is very neat, bring some time to walk around.
Ethnology museum. I had no idea so many varied groups of people with so much culture could live in such a small country
Museum. The exhibits were great. You need time to really read everything if you want to immerse yourself into the different cultural histories.
The value life. I concern to the House, how can they build these houses, look so high and very difficult but they did it for normal life. it is fabulous

A place to learn Vietnam in half a day. This museum is worth a go if you are in Hanoi. The exhibit from inside to outside is really vast. We are lucky to have a guide (paid separately) that help to explains the details of the exhibits. The inside gives you the typical stuffs like photos and video explanations. The outside exhibits were replicas of the house and there were people that actually living in it. Also there were water puppet show in the park. Overall, it is a very informative place to go.

Museum of Ethnology Number 1 museum in Hanoi. Well this museum is one of the last for me to visit and now takes top spot. It focuses on the many cultural groups that inhabit parts of Vietnam.
