The easily accessible and user friendly facilities ( including a free guide book by friendly staff) offer a clear and detailed account of peoples lives, their traditions, housing, food, tools, weapons, agricultural implements and items which make their lives unique to their environment, country and South East Asia. The outdoor exhibits include huge houses to clamber into and are simply fascinating. Even a free water puppet show on a Saturday afternoon!! A must to see so don't wait or let the location (a little out of central hanoi) put you and family off.

Is a full size full scale museum with excellent and numerous exhibits.. Well finally. A museum that's on par with those we expect to see in other countries. No, it's not got the breadth and depth of the Met, Louvre or British Museum, but had the feel of Museum of Natural History on a small scale. It was great to walk through the outdoor full scale ethnic villages and get a sense of their digs. It's reminiscent of the Fort Casper pony express historic site. Another place, another time, but similar feel.Absolutely get a tour in your language.

Vietnam Museum of Enthnology. The visit to the Museum of Enthnology was very intresting and
helpful in some one who is having a first visit to Vietnam. The vist
will give you a first hand knowledge of the country.

Fascinating - be sure to visit (allocate 3-4 hours). If you want to really understand the diverse races, people and cultures of Vietnam, this is *the* best place to start.. you can also get a real sense of their style, the various village lifestyles from south to north, and the gardens contain 10 full-size (furnished, incredibly detailed) village houses of different styles, which you can walk through, and spend time in, discovering stories about the different racial groups as you go.. making this a perfect destination for families, students, and first-time visitors

Wonderful site. This museum has come a long way since my first visit in 2006 when the signage was limited and the grounds undeveloped. This museum and the Women's Museum have similar ethnic minority displays. The outdoor offerings, including the Water Puppet show, were the highlights for me.

history and Cultural Lesson. I liked learning about the different ethnicity groups in Vietnam. The statistics were good. There are two floors to explore inside the building, as well as models of house demonstrating different architectural styles outside, We spent 90 mins there and it was ample time. It is definitely worth a visit.

There are not many museums of ethnology anywhere.. This was worth a visit. The interior showcased a lot of minority groups in Vietnam and the region.Do not expect great exhibits like the museums in Europe but hey how often do you find a museum dedicated to ethnology of asia. I was especially impressed with the tribal houses which were built and erected on the grounds which you can enter and have a look and feel of the interior and gain a better understanding of how these people lived.

Interesting insight. We enjoyed visiting the museum, there is so much to see, we found it to be an interesting look into the minority people of Vietnam. It is hot tho as others have posted take plenty of water

Shortcut to the homelands of Vietnam's ethnic minorities. The museum is a very interesting. It gives you an insight in the diversity of the ethnic minorities in Vietnam, even though the museum carefully avoids any reference to the sensitive issues, which are very important to fully understand the complex relations between Vietnam's Kinh majority and the some 50 ethnic minorities.A visit to the museum may also inspire you to visit the Bana people, the Hmongs or the Black Thai in their own homelands, in the mountaneous areas along the borders to China and Laos or in the highlands of Central Vietnam.Visiting the museum on a Sunday afternoon can be a particular joyful experience - the Museum grounds with the magnificient replicas of ethnic house structures are a popular picnic spot for Vietnamese families, and they are almost always happy to chat with visiting foreigners.

The best museum in town and by the way it is museum of ETHNOLOGY. I was first taken there 10 years ago by a swedish friend who was a professor working there. Since then I always take visitors there. The museum interior is a bit crusty, but really you are there to see the collection of traditional ethnic buildings around the site, ranging from Kinh houses to long houses, the death house and the massive meeting house pictured. Watch out for the special events - the regular water puppet shows, special cooking and other exhibitions and craft fairs held there. I once saw a guy there who showed old films through a kind of spectacles arrangement run by human power. A really live museum.

A Simple Museum. The red bucket behind the glass case provides an example of how simple this museum is. It traces the history of progress in Vietnam and the bucket is an example of how it made life easier for agricultural areas. Thiswas a good visit and well worth seeing

Totally do not understand the rave reviews for this. It is just like any other museum only perk perhaps is you get to watch cultural performances at the outdoor area for an all-in fare. The museum though is certainly nothing to shout about especially in comparison with museums in the region. You get the impression that every bit of information it provided would have been just a wiki page away. None of the artefacts (if you can even call them that) were particularly impressive or historic.
Interesting but uncomfortable and boring if tour too long. Loved the preservation of their past. Hot place so take water. A Tour Guide is an absolute must for first time visitors to Vietnam.
Get a view of the country without leaving Hanoi. This is where you can see how the people of Vietnam (minority people) live, what kind of houses they build and how they use these houses.
Learn about the people from the country. Good information about the people in this country, just need more information how we can meet the ethnic people there in some festivals

Museum of Ethnology. This trip is for the history buffs like me, extremely enjoyable!
Don't go here if you don't want to learn.

Vietnam museum of Ethnology. Well designed and laid out with information regarding the 54 ethnic groups in Vietnam. The garden area outside had a water puppet show in progress for the children. The museum was not air conditioned so visiting in the afternoon could shorten the visit.
fantastic. great set out good things to see it opened my eyes to what happens in our life i would recomend to every one to visit this museum

same with other museum. The same museum with other museums here its much discussed but less applicable vietnam culture no people living in it.
little bit bored in there

well Worth the taxi ride. This is a wonderful museum and well worth the taxi ride to get there. The building itself is lovely, though not well air conditioned. If you are planning to visit Sapa the museum provides and excellent background to the experience, with excellent displays f clothing and artifacts. Outside there is an outstanding collection of native houses that have been transported to this location. It was interesting and fun.

No A/C but cool outside. The historical huts that were outside were very interesting and informative of the way people live their lives. The inside was interesting however it was hard to pay attention in the heat inside (hotter than outside) when there was no air conditioning.

Recommended experience. The museum is small and it's like 40% indoor and 60% outdoor. It shows the history of the different ethnic groups (54), for me the best part was the outdoors where you can see the different house styles in the country, the layout is easy.

Interesting but not a must-see. We enjoyed our visit to the museum. There is a lot of interesting history and the displays are modern and impressive. But I wouldn't do it if I only had a day or two in Ha Noi - there are other more "must-see" things that make Ha Noi an unforgettable experience.

Shows the variety of the country. Some good artifacts and displays show the variety of ethnic groups in Vietnam. Outside you can view typical houses that have been built. there is also a chance to see an outdoor water puppet show. Disliked the loud noise from families, esp children!

Do not miss this out. The museum is located far away from the centre but do not miss it out. The exhibits are excellent. Also, I saw my first water puppet show here. It was amazing. I would have liked more time to view the museum attractions as it is a big museum.

showing hill side homes and ethnic makeup of the country. 85% of the country is made up of one ethnic group but the other groups are celebrated..Vietnam area has been under constant warfare for centuries. the amalgamation of many ethnic groups and religions has resulted from a period of what was called French Indo China....

Worth the cab ride out to it. Not air conditioned very difficult in such hot, humid weather.
But the varieties of sample housing you could view and enter in the central outdoor courtyard was great, the displays of ethnic tools/dress, etc. of interest to me, I'd give the museum at least 2 hours.
Interesting but no amazing.. I think this was more suited to the local people of Vietnam. Very hot and no air con. Some items were interesting but also interesting to see the diversity.

Very informative. If you like museums, don't miss out on this one. Lots of information on different tribes in Vietnam and Southeast Asia. Loved all the artifacts and video clips of actual tribal people. The first floor is cool, but the second floor was hot so dress cool and take a bottle of water. As for transportation, my husband and I paid 150,000 vnd ($7.50) for one way from Old Quarter on two motorbikes.

Lots of information. There was lots of very interesting information on the ethnic minorities as well as the majority Kinh people of Vietnam. They also have a free water puppet show on the lake within the museum grounds and a nice cafe that doubles up as a working/training centre for young vietnamese.The only improvement would be to have air conditioning installed around the museum as it can get rather hot and stuffy even with the fans going.

Interesting museum. You need to do it with a guide to really understand the importance of ethnology in Vietnam. We really enjoyed our visit to the museum, the outdoor section was really good for the kids as well. The cafe was great as well!
Ethnic museum. It was ok, nothing amazing which is a shame because the range of ethnicities is so huge. The real huts outside were great, but again I like more interactive stuff.

With kids, a must to visit. In Ha Noi, there aren't many places to visit with young kids. Parks and zoos are not satisfying in sense of hygine and safety. Museum itself is very interesting and I get to know more about various ethnic groups in Vietnam. Rather, I preper the outside of the building. There is a huge garden and many exhibitions are there. Kids can run around and experience the exhibitions themselves. The best part of this museum is we can enjoy waterpuppet show outside on free every Sunday. Need to check the schedule from the web before visit. Quite interesting place.
Actually worth a visit. An insight into Vietnam's different tribe with replicas of buildings in the grounds of the museum. The outside displays are far more interesting than the inside

Wonderful, wonderful. Wonderful place, a place that not only foreign visitors but also Vietnamese citizens have to visit to discover the best about Vietnam. The museum displays almost all things related to Vietnam 54 minorities. You can visit indoor displays and outside space with lots of funny activities. Do not forget to take photos as many as possible. Strongly recommend to every one!

Good presentation of Vietnamese Ethnic Minorities. Good overall spread of exhibits showing the culture, daily utensils and way of living (inclduing houses) of the Vietnamese Ethnic minorities. Worth the short visit.

Lovely Museum. Great information that was well-translated into English, interactive exhibits and lots to look at. Loses a star for allowing literally hundreds of children to run around climbing all over the exhibits and screaming while I was there, and the museum staff only shouted with them to get them more riled up. It was difficult to tour around with so much chaos.The outdoor exhibits were great and very interesting. Definitely worth a visit.

Worth the Cab Ride. This museum is located out of the way but is worth going to. The museum houses lots of information on the many ethnic minorities in Vietnam. In addition, there are numerous traditional homes that have been built on the site which are available for visitors to explore. There is also a Craft Link store onsite, which is handy for buying authentic goods at good prices to take home.

A great place to visit. This museum is really intetesting, we had a great afternoon there and learned so much !! There were fantastic displays and actual model houses to see, we would recommend this place highly

Definitely, not to misss!. The Museum of Vietnamese Ethnology is not located in the historic centre of Hanoi. Still I decided to give it a go as it was not too far from where we stayed, Hanoi Emotion Hotel. This museum is in it self an interesting artwork. Its exhibition building was designed as a Dong Son drum by Ha Duc Linh, a Vietnamese architect coming from the Tay ethnic group. Its interior design was completed by the French architect Veronique Dollfus. Loved its rustic exhibits of Vietnamese ethnic house models. Definitely a must for those intersted in architedture and culture.
Interesting to examine the cultural diversity of Vietnam. This is one of several cultural sites worth visiting in Hanoi. We had our own guide which means you can speed up the visit if you like.
A worthwhile visit. Though little out of town $10 cab fare) , this is a good insight into village life...many houses you can go in to see how the people live,

Perfect to become acquainted with all the ethnic groups of Vietnam within an afternoon. Really great combination of indoor and outdoor museum.
In the rainy season, watch your step in the outdoor section while climbing the houses on stilts.
Interesting Museum. I like most of the things there .I also love the little shop with many interesting books about Ethnic communities all over Vietnam .

Learn about the 54 Vietnames ethnic minorities in one place. Spend 1/2 day here. Visit the exhibits inside, and then take time to tour the houses and other full-size displays outside.
You will learn about all of the 54 vietnamese minorities here.
If you have children, this is the first place to take them when you arrive in Vietnam.
Nice visit. We enjoyed the museum. It gave us good insides on the rituals, different cultures and values of the country.

Great museum, a must on the circuit!. This was definitely an outstanding museum in a city full of so-so museums. I found the highlight to be the different minority houses out back. It was really neat that they were built traditionally, and that you could walk around in them. Much less awkward than trying to walk up to some village and try and communicate an unguided tour. I actually saw some houses constructed in the same fashion during a recent road trip down the HCM trail around Hue, so I can vouch that they are indeed authentic. Inside, the information and display items were presented well and were very informative. There was a lot more than I had the attention span for, I could have done 2 days in here. HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!Side note - My French speaking girlfriend said that the French translations were better than the English one. Odd quirk, but a bit more enriching for the Francophone visitors.

Very nice museum to take a break from the city. Our kids did like in particular the garden with the beautifull, real size wooden houses. It is really quiet compared to the noise pf the city. The museum is worth a visit in particular ahead of a trip to Sapa. Finally, the coffe / restaurant is also nice and good.

Not as interesting as I had hoped. Liked - A fair amount of historical documents, costumes and other historical pieces.Disliked - No air-conditioning, too hot to visit in the summer. Presentation was kind of boring.

Museum of Ethnology. Inside it describes all the different ethnic groups within Vietnam and Asia but it isnt very big. Outside there are various different traditional homes which you can go inside and read a bit about each.They also put on a water puppet show (which is a must in Vietnam) included in your entrance fee (cheaper then seeing a show in the Old Quarter). The shows are only on at the weekend, so best to go Sat or Sun.

a great insight to the ethnic mix of Vietnam. If you are at all interested in the diverse mix of ethnic people in Vietnam, this museum is a must. It shows the cultural background, types of clothing and examples of housing and habitat. Great displays of conical hat weaving, local customs (including funerals), all in a spacious building and surrounding grounds. Life-size examples of traditional houses to climb around. Fun for the kids!

So much to learn. Interesting museum with good information in English. We did a tour of ground floor before going out to see the various houses in the grounds then came back todo the next level and cool down. An interesting museum.

Great museum. We went to this museum by taxi right after visiting HCMC Mausoleum. Taxi was about 80.000 dong or so. First we saw the exhibitions inside of the museum building - they were very nice.Next we went for drinks and ice cream to the restaurant. We liked this little restaurant / school for disadvantaged youth so much that we decided to come back later for lunch. In the mean time we went to the outdoors exhibition where we could walk in to several houses and see how Vietnamese people used to live in various regions of the country. After that we went for lunch. Had a tuna sandwich, shrimp fritters and spring rolls with crab meat. Food was fantastic. By that time - it was a time for a siesta. We walked outside and among many not so honest taxis we found our taxigroup taxi (white w/red &blue letters) and for 140.000 dong we returned to the Old Quarter for siesta before dinner. What a great day.

Excellent museum well worth the journey. Loved this museum as it gives really clear written info into the history of Vietnam's minority people. A must for anyone interested in the culture of Vietnam.http://hfbartist-abrushwith.blogspot.com/
Ok, but a bit bland. The museum was just a bit dated and unexciting. They also had an outdoor section with various historical buildings which was a bit better than what could be found indoors
Ok for a museum.. Quite interesting but not a highlight of my trip. Shop got some nice stuff in and not too expensive.

Best Place to visit the hill tribes, well at least in Hanoi. A great museum that explains in English, French, and Vietnamese the various tribes (ethnics) in Vietnam. A nice outdoor museum for visiting the prototype homes and an indoor museum for explaining their lifestyle. A very professional and well done museum.But, take some time to visit the real-thing with home stays in Mai Chau, Sapa, or many other places to meet and great the local hill tribes.

Go with a guide. We went with a guide who was most enthusiastic and helpful. I would dare to suggest that without him, a lot would have been lost. You can only read and digest a certain amount, but to have him detail things was a great help. Worth a visit, but try to take a guide who knows.

mUst visit to understand Vietnamese life.. Quite interesting museum, even has the history on how the vietnamese conical hat came to be. Vietnamese huts outside shows exactly how beautiful their local architecture is. traveling in July is hot & humid- the rains did not make it easier.

Excellent way to know Vietnam's culture. It's interesting to see the cultures of the various ethnic groups in Vietnam. The models of the houses of some cultural groups are unique and a must-see when you go to the museum. The houses are located outside the museum building.
Best museum of the city. Best museum, underappreciated, location makes using a taxi almost mandatory. Authentic minirity homes on grounds amazing.

Tribal history. If you are interested in the anthropological side of Vietnamese culture, and in particular the linguistic particulars of the many tribes, then this will be of interest. Not restricted to Vietnamese culture - old building with modern foyer, Staff no0t very good at English.

Great place to visit. Love the experience to learn about the different ethnic groups in Vietnam and their culture. Very informative musuem.
Visited replicas of the village houses onsite. Fantastic experience !
Fascinating, excellent exhibits.. Great introduction to VN culture & history. My kids loved the garden exhibits of ethnic villages, especially the log bridges.
Worth a visit. Well worth a visit and make sure you have a walk around the gardens.

We can get to know about a race.. This is a museum about the race of Vietnam.
Vietnam consists of about 50 races, and also is a nation-state, and has a custom in which each races differ.
Here, we can know in detail about the custom.
Clothes changed with races and were the most impressive.

If you are interested in architecture.... The Vietnam Museum of Ethnology has great reviews overall. Lonely Planets describe this museum as one of the best in Vietnam. Perhaps our expectations were very high and we were not that impressed with the indoor museum exhibits. Yes, they do provide a good history of the different ethnic and linguistic groups of Vietnam. I learned some important things. The challenge was that the reviews said that children loved this museum. My two kids were quite bored. However, all this changed when we saw the outside exhibits of the different traditional house structures of various ethnic groups. The museum is worth seeing simply for this. The kids loved exploring the houses and the adults in our group were mesmerized by the different building structures and materials used in making them.

Definitely worth a visit. This is a neat opportunity to see the diversity of cultures within Vietnam. A well laid out stroll through full scale replicas of Vietnamese housing. Also inside an interesting museum building there are additional detailed exhibits. Definitely worth a visit
Great place to visit. Lots to see. Great restaurant to eat with disadvantage kids being your host

Good introduction to minorities in Vietnam. This partly outdoor museum provides a very good introduction to the minorities in Vietnam. It shows the costumes and lifestyle as well as some of the houses used by the various tribes. Overall a good museum which takes about an hour to go through.

Well worth a visit. Excellent and well explained exhibits introducing you to the different ethnic groups that make up Vietnam. Good signage in English and French as well as Vietnamese. Interesting displays, and dont miss the houses out the back. The shop is good too as it is run by a non profit organisation, and its fixed prices.
great. What a wonderful museum! The historical collections of different minority groups was amazing. Great collection, one of the best museums we visited.

Educational and interesting - English friendly. Great variety of exhibits, very informative and the information is translated into both English and French. Guides are available for a small fee, though not necessary. The outside display of typical housing of the different tribes is spectacular. There's a small French cafe outside too that claims to support local disadvantaged kids by teaching them hospitality skills - very tasty selection of cakes, pastries and drinks to choose from! Awesome afternoon spent here, make sure you take your time to appreciate it all!
not what I expected. The museum is small, so it was a really short visit.

Start here.... This is the best place to start your education on the diversity of the people of Vietnam. Good exhibits, well laid out and don't miss the garden and the back with examples of various ethnic dwellings.

Loved looking round the different dwellings. We spent a little time inside looking round the main building which is quite nicely done with a mix of exhibits behind glass and scenes set up for you to look at there are also some great video clips. What we really enjoyed however was looking round the different "typical" dwellings for the different groups that have been erected outside which were really fascinating.

Great place with plenty of information.. This was a good place as you could walk around and look at things as you wanted. Theres lots of traditional architecture outside which you can wander through at your own pace and some of the buildings are breath-taking.
Great experience. A bit far from the city but presents a fantastic overview of the ethnic groups throughout SE Asia. I wish I had been able to visit much earlier in my travels!
Museum. This is a very interesting. Very informative and it show you the many amount of cultures that are in Vietnam and on how they lived
It's worth the visit. It gives you a good idea on where people in Vietnam come from, how they live according to their culture.It was summer and the air conditioning is not very good.
Wonderful ethnographic museum in Hanoi. Fantastic display of Vietnamese minority artifacts and houses with excellent English information labels.

Very Interesting. This place is great the way it explains the history of Vietnam. this is the second time we have been there, the first time we had a very good English speaking guide, which explain everything very well, the second time the guide didn't so we had to explain a few things to our friend. Must get a good English speaking guide.

Great place - overload of information. I was fascinated by this museum and had an overload of information. Vietnam has more than 50 ethnic groups and it is impossible get a deep understanding of the differences between them in such a short period of time. I could spend days in this museum.
Headless artifacts!. Disappointing when you are looking at an exhibition of artifacts that are all missing their heads because the French have taken them and put them in a Museum in France!

a must go to. this museaum gives you an insight into the people and places you are going to visit. Each province has something unique about it and there are something like 54 different ethnic tribes which are referred to througout the trip. Seeing this first prepares you for abetter understanding of why and where people are from around Vietnam.
Brilliant. best museum I have been too! lovely lunch in the grounds also....really worth the trip. very insighful
Interesting!. It was very nice to find out more about the inhabitants of Vietnam!
Water puupet show, embroidery practice, transversal house and more .... Water puupet show, embroidery practice, transversal house, gotta check out the Bana Hoise too and more

Interesting. We were taken through the Museum and thought that it definitely enhanced our trip through the
Indigenous areas of VietNam.
A good place to get to know the Vietnam people. A look back at the origines and history of the Vietnam people, and its many cultures.
Great but don't go on a hot day.. There is lots to see here both inside and out, however the inside is not air conditioned and gets very hot.

Inside boring outside great. Found the inside of this museum a bit boring but the outdoor display of tribal houses were among the best i have ever seen. I compare it to Skansen outdoor museum in Stockholm and think they are on par.
Outdoor/Indoor Museum. Great place to view the way other people live and get a feel for their history. FYI, indoor museum is not completely air conditioned--generally just in the reception hall.

A really good museum; defintiely worth going to.. This is a really interesting museum; a bit out of the way (you will need a taxi from the centre of Hanoi), but worth the effort. The outside part has a lot of traditional buildings from different ethnic minorities in Vietnam with clear explanations. The museum itself builds upon this and provides a very informative guide to the range of ethnic groups that make up Vietnam. There are very good displays and some great little videos. Put the two together and you get a really good feel for traditional Vietnam. In addition, there is a very good restaurant in the grounds, which is a training restaurant for disadvantaged youngsters. The food is tasty and good value.

Worth the confusing trip out. Straight up - this place can be difficult to get to BUT once you're there, it's pretty amazing. Unlike other museum, zoo and aquarium efforts in Vietnam that need some developing, this joint project with France is very impressive. Inside, artefacts from Vietnam's 54 ethnic groups have been professionally curated and detailed descriptions are available in English, French and Vietnamese. Outside, real houses of the ethnic groups have been re-established on the grounds (be sure to check out the amazing Banar house) and, come at the right time, and you'll experience a water puppetry demonstration.There is a French influenced cafe on-site that trains disadvantaged kids and serves up tasty Vietnamese dishes and cheesy baguettes for a decent price. The adjoining giftstore is also fantastic for set price items that are very reasonably priced; think AU$7 silk scarves, buffalo horn hair combs and salad servers that pay the producers a fair wage.
Nice layout and information. Spacious layout and info of exhibits. Loved the houses exhibits outdoor but the water puppets show needs a better sound system

Much better than expected. The museum is in two sections. The main building houses the exhibitions and wall mounted information and the fairly extensive outside area contains copies of the houses that have been reconstructed of the various ethnic groups from around the Vietnam villages ( 10 No ).Although I am not an avid museum visitor normally , I really enjoyed spending a couple of hours here but it was so hot outside that I had to step indoors a couple of times for the luxury of the air con.

A bit far from the centre but worth a visit. A very nice outdoor compound, with house types of various ethnic groups. I learned a lot there. It was a Sunday, and they had a water puppet performance. Good!

Drab from the outside but bursting with exhibits inside. Exhibits here are really fascinating. The museum does an excellent job of laying out the various ethnic groups across Southeast Asia. It then displays their daily life, tools, and culture (beyond the stock pottery). Videos are sprinkled throughout and cover weddings, funerals, and more. Give yourself two hours for this small museum - you will need it. Also, the gift shop just outside is quite reasonable and stocks some good merchandise.
Museum. This museum was totally amazing, informative and very interesting to say the least - My sister and I enjoyed the variety of cultures so much.Well worth the visit. Very enjoyable!!

Worth a half hour drive!. For Europeans, the Vietnamese may seem quite homogenic - but it is just the contrary. The exhibition of the Museum of Ethnology shows how diverse the Vietnamese society is. Informative, yet not too long tour inside (they have great English guides) and the buildings outside are a great introduction to Vietnam and a superb way to start your visit in this county. If you are lucky, you can watch the water puppets show for free (i.e. included in the price).Nice sorroundings make it perfect half day escape from buzzling centre.
A good overview of Vietnam's multiple tribes. If you intend to visit the Sapa area, this museum will show you all the diversity of Vietnam's population

Best museum in Hanoi. This is the best museum in Hanoi, by a mile. It's well organised, has tons of exhibits, is easy to navigate, and is in a quiet, but easily accessible location. Plus the architecture of the place is very nice. From the centre of Hanoi it's about 20-30mins by taxi, or longer if it's a busy day, so leave yourself time to get there and back.There's also a good café, and look out for the live performances year-round in the grounds. If you don't manage to get to Sapa, this is probably the closest you'll get to ethnic minority culture in Vietnam. Plus the information is much better laid-out than elsewhere.You can also buy some lovely textiles in the shop, although they're much more expensive than in the market in Hanoi or Sapa.
interesting before Sapa. We had a bit of trouble finding this after catching the bus but got a better idea about Sapa before going there

A very nice museum. I was really surprised when i went to this museum. They have a indoor and outdoor museum and both parts are really good. You can go with kids without problem. There is things for them on the outdoor part. Climp the pillar houses and so on. This is the museum I really try to take my visitors to see.
Gives you an overview of the different tribes but nothing to shout about. Compared to the Sarawak Cultural Village, this does not measure up. It was ok but not great.

To know more with Vietnam ethnics. If you are interested to know more about the culture and minorities about Vietnam, then this museum is worth to visit. As Vietnam got a lot of different ethnics, the museum able to show most of their history, culture and places to lives. Especially for those going to or back from Sapa.Museum itself don't have air-cond so is quite hot when we visit. We visit this museum after we went to temple of literature, we took taxi and it's cost abt VND75,000. Hope this help for those plan the trip.
A point of interest.. Definitely worth a visit. A museum that is not all indoors. Go on a nice day, overcast but not raining.
excellent to see old and new vietnam. saw water puppet show here wonderful to see how people had lived good museum
good place to learn more about the history of vietnam. its was a great location with so many insights to Vietnam's enthic history along with great replicas of the past. Loved it!

Great learning experience. I went to the Women's museum after visiting the Hoa Loi Prison. It was a great way to order the sightseeing because after learning about the women who engaged in revolutionary activities and fought in combat, the Women's museum added another side to the story. I left the museum with a lot of respect for Vietnamese women. I learned about marriage ceremonies, birthing and motherhood, field working, clothing, and their service in the military. It's a must-see.
a 'must see' in Vietnam. There are so many ethnic groups in Vietnam and to know a little bit about them this museum is well worth visiting. It is interesting and very informative.

Beautiful displays and not too big. I loved the displays. The crafts and textiles were amazing! The museum is informative and just big enough. It's not overwhelming and can be visited in detail at a leisurely pace in just one afternoon.
places to see in Hanoi. This place helps you to learn about the Vietnamese people living in different parts of Vietnam in different times. Very interesting.

A bit of a hike, but worth it. This was a very interesting museum with some great displays about the minorities in Vietnam. The best part is out around the back of the museum where they've built traditional houses from many of the minorities. It is a hike from the Old Quarter, so if you're only in Hanoi for 2-3 days I wouldn't bother. If you're in town for a longer visit, I would definitely spend a few hours here.

Amazing museum that is really hands-on for kids. The museum is really well-appointed and has a good amount of exhibits (ie: to too few to leave you wondering and not too many to exhaust you). Some of the traditional costumes and dress and very vibrant and beautifully woven and you can see them up close and personal. The best thing about the museum, however, is outside. Surrounding the museum are something like 10-12 traditional ethnic houses, the large majority of which you can enter, walk around in and climb up to. Our children certainly loved the fact that they could touch and feel things like mats, drums, weaving, puppets etc. and they really enjoyed climbing up some of the ladders to get into 2-3 of the houses in particular. One issue: the museum is a little out of town to the west of the city; however, that said, it is a small inconvenience to go and visit something that provides and informative insight into the lives of ethnic Vietnamese. I would highly recommend this museum to anyone-especially those with children.

Put the Vietnam experience into context. A place to learn and be surprised about the different Vietnamese ethnic groups, their origins and different cultures - which put our Vietnam experiences into context.
Worth a look. Good history of Vietnam. Allow a couple of hours to get through it.

Well worth finding the place!!!!. Very interesting to see the hill tribe traditional homes laid out in the grounds of this museum. Gives you an insight into the lives of the various ethnic tribes who inhabit Vietnam. The museum was OK, but enjoyed the buildings outside much more. The little cafe there is also good value and a nice setting.

Don't forget about the waterpuppet show!. Here is the water puppetry show schedule:Sat & Sun only 10:00/11:30/14:00/16:00It's free with paid admission, donations accepted.I highly recommend this museum. It's very informative and laid out well. I had such a blast roaming around the outside houses. I felt like I was actually in the villages, except with all the modern buildings and construction around!Be careful of taxis though. To the museum it was 100,000d, but back to town was double that! Don't remember the name, but it was a yellow taxi. Should have been more cautious.

Very interesting. Musuem a good introduction to Vietnamese cultural and ethnic groups. Descriptions in English as well as Vietnamese (and possibly French but I can't remember). The garden area is amazing with lots of examples of traditional houses. Worth visiting.
Fascinating. Very comprehensive exhibits. If you can't get about to visit the ethnic groups this is the next best thing

Amazing Place. We spent many hours here and the entry fee was so reasonable. It is a pity it is a bit out of town but taxis are so cheap and our driver waited for us so knew where to take us back to the hotel. Fantastic exhibitions and great explanations and the houses in the grounds were fascinating

LOTS of reading. there is a lot of reading to get through and often a lot of tour groups in the museum at any one time. We where unfortunate enough to have a rather loud group complete with intepreter.
Great Day Out. Very interesting to find out about all the different Ethnic groups within Vietnam. The replica houses of all the ethnic groups on the site was an added bonus.
A look back into history. A good museum that gives the visitor a look back into Vietnam's diverse ethnic past.

Worth a visit. it is a little far from the center, about a 100,000 Dong taxi ride. But worth the visit especially if you plan to visit ethnic minorities in Sapa. Educational, and I loved the life size models of the homes they have outdoors.
Interesting place to visit. Good overview of the various ethnic minorities. Worth a visit, particularly if you are going to be heading into other parts of Vietnam, to give you some context
Interesting place. Interesting place. Understand more about Vietnamese people
Worth some time. Shows villiage life in years gone by, quite well done and shows rural lifestyles of various ethnic groups
Wonderful museum. Really fine collection of ethnic textiles from rural tribes.

Outdoor displays show the diversity Vietnam's ethnic groups. The large grounds are covered with various long houses and other structures that give you the flavor of how life was (and in a few cases, still is) lived in the further reaches of the country, such as the central highlands. Seeing these structures, and entering some of them, gave an amazing insight into the not-so-distant past of this quickly modernizing, dynamic country.
good to visit. This is a place i can understand more about vietnamese people, how they live.
Informative on the culture and FUN. The family loved it - especially the outdoor area with houses resembling the different areas / tribes and activities that the kids could take part in including dad

A must when visiting Hanoi. It takes a little while to get there from the centre of Hanoi but the Museum is a great way to learn about the different ethnic groups in Vietnam and visit some of their buildings which were re-errected in the gardens of the museum.There are also water puppet shows but you need to check the times of the performances.In the grounds there is a cafe/restaurants where disadvantaged youngsters learn catering skills. Give it a try and encourage the students!

Wonderful place to see in Hanoi. In this museum you have opportunity to see 54 ethnic nations of Vietnam. It takes you at least 2 hours for visiting this museum. A destination to visit for Hanoi city tour

Very interesting and well done. If you can't make it out to the hill tribes, this is the next best thing. Very informative and not filled with Communist rhetoric. Very nice examples of tribal houses. Be careful of taxis with fast meters waiting out front. Look for the reputable companies...Hanoi Tourist...Mai Linh etc.
Really interesting place. Really interesting place and a great please to get out of the heat and away from the noise and chaos

Impressive. After the Hoa Lo prison museum, this is a place to go. For 25.000d you will get a LOT of informations and beautiful displays to watch. Traditional houses of different ethnics behind the museums are a gem, students are hanging inside of them, escaping from the hot weather.There is a bus no.14 going from the top of the Hoan Kiem lake..once you cross a small "river" channel, just get off, then follow the road and turn left..you will see a sign.Right in front of the museum there is a bus #38 leaving, and you can get off close to the bottom of Hoan Kiem lake..possibly better option than the #14.
Ok, not great. Not worth going out of your way to see the museum.

Should do!. I spent 2 hours to visit the museum. It was really good place to see. It has 2 main parts with many exhibits providing wide knowledge of different groups in Vietnam. I was interested in the real houses in the outside part, traditional games...It is worth to see! Highly recommend!
The decoratation of the museum is outstanding, both outside and inside area. I high appreciate the way of constribute some kinds of ethnic monority stilt, they are very distinguished

A Must. This is a wonderful muyseum, slightly outside of the old center of Hanoi, but well worth going to. The recent structure is set in a park-like area with different habitat structures set up on the grounds, so you can actually visit the different house types. Inside, it is air conditioned (if only they closed doors and windows!). The visit is well organized, the exhibits interesting and comments are in English also. Many videos make clear the use of the objects and customs. There are also two commercial places worth visiting on the grounds. Both are run by NGO's: one is a little store, selling a very nice selection of artifacts, made by local communities. It saves you a trip to another area of town for their main store and it provides beautiful objects with an ethical twist. The second is a restaurant also run by an organiation training deprived youngsters in hospitality jobs.They are building a new museum next door (for South East Asia), so soon there will be even more reasons to go there. Count on spending a good 2h30 if you want to go carefully through every part of it and shop!

Very nice museum. We had a deep understanding in Vietnamese history after visiting this museum. The museum was amazing with many different and colourful things of 54 different goups in Vietnam, especially minority groups. This is a good place for you to get to know Vietnamese history and people. Don’t miss!!!
Different Group in Vietnam. I like this Museum, it have a lot of video that help visitor like me to understand their other Ethic's culture easy. It is great!!!
History of Vietnam. No explanation in english or german language, but a lot of very nice pieces to see.
Just ok. Little informative but not sensational. Fair way out of town and wouldn't make the effort again.
worth a visit. a little outside of the city center. The different buildings out in the garden of museum are great. Also good info of the displays.
one of the top museums in hanoi. interesting to learn about the myriad of cultures from vietnam

The biggest & most famous museum of Vietnam. I already came there some times to research information about Vietnam ethnic groups, and the museum brought me so much exciting. It was really big and took me nearly 3 hours to see all objects.The museum includes 2 different sections: inside and outside door with about 15000 objects relate to the culture of 54 ethnic groups in Vietnam.Outside area exhibits some houses which are local residence in different regions in Vietnam. Saturday and Sunday offer some water puppet shows.should to come and see.

Museum of Ethnology Was a Wonderful Stop. Vietnam, liberated from France in1954, has 54 different indigenous ethnic groups. The Viet comprise 80% of the population, with the other 20% consisting of 53 different minorities. The Vietnam Museum of Ethnology is a wonderful indoor-outdoor space that educates visitors about the distribution, customs, religions, dwellings, and commerce of virtually all of these groups. We are reminded of the Inuit Museum outside Anchorage, as both are informative, respectful to the subjects, and incredibly interesting. This was a particularly well timed stop in advance of going to SaPa, as we saw exhibits about the Black Hmong and Red Dao. You can read more about our travels at http://maketrax.blogspot.com
Well worth a visit.. The kids liked it a lot. They climb the houses and there was a lot of space to run around. This was my second visit and I will probably go back again. Its a very nice museum.

A real adventure in an outdoor museum. Whilst somewhat out of the centre of town, the Museum of Ethnology (don't be put off by the title) is the best in Hanoi. It houses or rather its best point is houses, as the grounds are full of the different houses of the ethnic groups of Vietnam and include a pond where they regularly perform with water puppets; working kitchens, and a host of buildings to look around and climb over. Children love it and parents do too. Inside are some regular exhibits and often exhibitions not to be missed. One unforgettable one was about Hanoi in collectivist times - the 1950's to 1980's - and included room settings including the family pig in the urban bathroom! Even the partly outdoor restaurant is run by Hoa Sua, the street children's hotel and catering training school and offers their great pastries and good coffee.A real must for any vistior to Hanoi.
got a bit boring at the end. Very informative place and the outdoor area is lovely but it did get a bit boring and repetitive at the end
Worth the cab ride. Thios place is fantastic. Many different types of community type buildings from around the country. Gives a great idea of Vietnam's diversity.

The best place to visit when we arrive in Hanoi. - Various culture from North to South Vietnam. It divided 2 parts: inside-house and outside-house. They still keep the original of Vietnam in the past till at present.

Definitely Worth The Visit. What a terrific museum to give you an insight into the ethnic groups in Vietnam. Most museums can be a bit overwhelming and leave you exhausted from taking in so much varied information. This museum is focused on ethnic groups in Vietnam so you can just focus on the ethnology exhibits which have French and English translations. The museum provides a great overview of the cultures, different housing styles and costumes. It provided a good preview before we went to the hill tribe area around Sapa.

If you don't have the time to see all of Vietnam, this is the place to visit.. This museum gives and extensive overview of the ~54 different ethnic groups that make up the Vietnamese nation. the displays are well organised and easy to follow. Information boards are written in English. Outside there are reconstructions of various types of housing.
Out of my expectation. There are no words to describe this.Come and enjoin by yourself.
must see. one of the best mueseums in all of vietnam, great insight in the life of the tribes and the population.
Museum attraction. It is an attraction to be viewed, it is a personal decision, review befor you go and decide

Best Museum in Hanoi?. Certainly worth the visit. A well-done museum of the various ethnic groups, their art, history, and living arrangements. If you don't have a local who can take you, hire a reliable guide to explain the importance of each group. Outside are replicas of housing for each group as well as the Water Puppets which are unique to Vietnam. Allow at least half a day. Food and beverage service is available.

Top Notch, for Vietnam. I have been to nearly every museum in Hanoi- I even took my students to the geology museum, which was beyond terrible... But, thankfully, the Museum of Ethnology was wonderful.It is really great to see Vietnam celebrating it's cultural diversity now, wheras years ago this would never happen. Pros:-Wheelchair Accessible; while I, nor anyone I know in Vietnam, is in a wheel chair, this is one of the only places in Hanoi that has ramps. I bring this up because while i was there, there was a group of Viet in wheelchairs doing a tour, and it made me think that there is just nowhere for them to visit easily.-Layout; there has been a lot of thought that has gone into this one, which is great to see, because the typical thought in Vietnam is quality over quantity. -Houses: I was really happy to see the houses from the tribes surrounding the museum. I also applaud the government for bring locals in to build their houses. For me, this was a highlight.Cons-Distance: It's definitely off the tour trail, being way out in Caiy Dau district, which will deter a lot of people. It also gives taxi drivers a chance to cheat you even more by taking you longer ways, or using a rigged meter. Be careful. Negotiate before you get in.
Very good exhibitions. The full size model houses in the Museum yard are well worth a visit
Fabulous Insight into Vietnam.. This is a must see. If you are at interested in the culture, go here for a half day!

Worth a visit. Definitely worth the visit after a few days in Sapa admiring and chatting with the woman from some of the tribes, it was a great Museum to visit and learn more about the ethnology of the Vietnamese. My only tip make sure you get a taxi or a driver as it is to far to walk.
Well it's better than looking at a dead body. A good idea but needs more work. The central museum building was well presented but the sample buildings in the ground needed more information and detail
Interesting. It is quiet interesting to see the different tribes of Vietnam
Hanoi. Very informative.Had excellent tour guide to tell us more. Reasonably easy to understand.

A great collection. A bit of a distance from central Ha Noi but a beautifully presented collection. When we first came to Viet Nam in 1992, there was little mention of the minorities (except for a small section in the main history museum) so it is great to see this. The restaurant is a training one, and a good shady spot on a hot day, as many of the exhibits are outside.

Interesting view of several cultures. We were lucky to have a guide to take us to this museum and to explain much of what we saw there. I particularly enjoyed seeing the various costumes which are all beautifully hand crafted from scratch. We also enjoyed the small exhibitions which illustrated the differences between each minority group. You may also see life size examples of the different types of native dwellings which have been constructed are are in situ within the museums grounds. Allow a couple of hours to do justice to this interesting place.
Gives a complete view on history of Vietnam. Ho Chi Minh struggle for freedom & 5 major ethnic groups are well covered in this museum
Incredible Museum with lots of interest to see. We spent a lot of time exploring this museum and thought it was of real interest. Several floors to see. Worth the time to view.

Very interesting. This museum provided a good overview of the different cultures that make up Viet Nam. While the exhibit is interesting, the ability to walk around in the traditional Vietnamese architecture is the real highlight.

Don't miss it!. This was my favorite stop on our tour of Hanoi. The museum has great displays inside the main building which show you how Vietnamese from around the country work, live, celebrate, etc. There are videos, photos and displays to really make it come to life and even the kids enjoyed it. Even better, they have an open-air museum outside with several different types of traditional houses built on the museum grounds. It was fascinating to see them and walk through them. If you go to only one museum in Hanoi, make it this one!
Worth the visit.. An interesting museum to visit and I was lucky to find the water puppets playing outside during our visit. Nice cafe in the grounds.

A well laid out and detailed educational insight into the history of the people. Loved the 1/2 hour water puppet theatre; the museum was spacious and interestingly arranged with plenty of visual stimulation.

Not very exciting if you haven't visited sapa.. Maybe it was just me, but I didn't find the museum that interesting. I think it would have had more relevance if you had visited Sapa and some of the hill tribes first.

Vietnam Museum of Ethnology. This is a very well laid out museum that highlights the different native dress and customs of the indigenous people of Vietnam. Re-created village scenes, video coverage, and artifacts are well chosen.

Great place to understand the diversity of Vietnam ethnics. The showcase of homes/accommodations of different ethnics outside the museum is another plus point. You'll get to see the actual size and rooms in each house.

What a shame!. The museum is poorly laid out and the exhibits of the ethnic minorities are dull and fail to convey the liveliness of the Dzay and the Tay families we had the pleasure of staying with. Very disappointing. Needs an entire overhaul.

A great overview. Great museum, in need of some updating, but the work is underway. To get an overview of all the ethnic minorities in Vietnam this is a must not miss opportunity. the restaurant on site is also very nice, you can easily make a 1/2 day trip out of this destination.

Surprisingly good for Vietnam. A good job illustrating the many ethnic groups in Vietnam. Did you know there are 54 of them? Good use of props and models showcasing the types of housing they build and tools used for hunting, fishing, weaving and spiritual traditions. I did not hire a guide like I usually do because I have found that most guides in Vietnam do not pronounce English clearly enough for me. Be sure to eat and drink ahead of time as the restaurant seems to have just pastries and coffee. I did not sense that the kitchen was safe enough to eat from

Spend a good 4-6 hours. Walking through recreations of ethnic housing a real treat. Great deal of information on the Ninh (Vietnamese) and all the ethnic minorities. Well presented. Sometimes the written info was hard to read as lighting was low and contrast in colour of background and print was poor. A bit of a ride in a taxi (175,000 dong in April 2012). Don't take any of the taxis outside the gate, get the staff inside the museum to call a reputable firm for you.
very interesting. It is a great opportunity to find a little more about the different peoples that populate the country
Awesome place.... Seeing how the ethnic groups are. Really awesome experience. First class museum. Well worth the trip. Problem is they charge you to take photos. Only negative

Hanoi experience. Hi, A place well worthy of a half day visit in Hanoi for culture buffs and those into the history of South East Asian tribes and origins. Quite fascinating to be honest. It guides you through in an air conditioned well laid out museum. Artifacts you can touch and a full explanation in English and French as well as Vietnamese. It has in the grounds of the museum (and beautifully laid out with descriptions on each point of interest in various languages) the different types of housing built by the tribes, the different costumes and customs, and their ways of living. You also see their skills and crafts and the tools they used.It has maps showing you the migrations of the different peoples and it was a lot of information to digest. A great day out for those minded and interested in such things in a calm well laid out setting. It also has well equipped facilities regards toilets for men, women and disabled visitors.Also a comfortable indoor eating and drinking place that is well furnished for customers.
small but interesting. Small for a city but concidering it is in vietnam it is great. very interesting history of the chinese minorities complimented our recent trip to sapa as well

Vienam Museum of Ethnology. We visited this Museum while in Hanoi and would recommend a visit to here, we spent a afternoon walking round and seeing all the sights here. think there should be more information for any other tourists to visit here.

Really interesting Museum. Very nice experience. The museum offers a very good explanation of the racial/cultural differences between the various ethnic groups in Vietnam. Great exhibition covering in various levels of detail the 54 ethnic groupings of Vietnam. I enjoyed to see photos of all the ethnic groups. The outdoor 'cultural playground' is really interesting.
Visit Museum before Sapa. save time to spend for outside structures and the museum gift shop

Nice and interesting.. This was a stop along our day tour. Not a place I would've personally chosen to visit but it was interesting, especially the outside area where you see and can visit homes of vietnamese tribes. The cafe had tasty pastries and good, strong coffee
Wow. A great way to see the history and wonderful artefacts of Vietnam.

Not sure what the fuss is about. From the reviews i was expecting an amazing museum, i was a little disappointed. it was very spacious and had some great displays but after reading about a few cultures i couldn't read any more. the outside area was lovely to walk around.
The most interesting museum in Vietnam. I liked the replicas of the indigenous houses the most -- they are outside and are built to scale. That part of the visit is enjoyable in the nice weather.
Very interesting and educational-a must see. We liked the scale models in the museaum and the real life replicas outside. It is a must see.
excellent. Excellent cultural experience... wow there are so many ethnic minorities!

Fascinating place. This museum does an excellent job of explaining the 50 plus ethnic groups that make up Vietnam. The displays are very well laid out and the information is easy to read. We were only given 1 hour here as part of a group tour early this month, but could easily have spent another hour
Fine museum to visit. Had cool traditional residences of the ethnic tribes on the museum grounds.
Very interesting place to visit.. We liked to see how the houses were built in ancient times. And we liked the restaurant very much. Very nice experience. Even if it rained.

If Going to Sapa, Go Here First. The museum offers a very good explanation of the racial/cultural differences between the various ethnic groups in Vietnam. I found it very useful/interesting before heading to Sapa and staying with a Red Dao family. To get the most out of it I think you’d be best off by hiring a guide. I am sorry we didn’t. We wandered through the outdoor areas appreciating the differences in the buildings on display, but didn’t really have a good understanding of what we were seeing.We spent just under two hours here (my personal limit for museums) and thought it was well worth the taxi fare from the Old Quarter. Don’t even think about walking.

Good, bright displays but some misleading information. It was very interesting and the displays were great. We visited the museum after we went to Sapa, so it was nice to see the displays and get some information after we had met some of the tribes people. I was a little bit concerned, however, about one quote on a display. I paraphrase, but it basically said that the lot of the tribes people is dramatically improving and has been doing so over the past decade. It is clear when I visited some of the villages near Sapa that there are still people in some very shocking levels of poverty and not everyone in Vietnam is enjoying the fruits of a growing economy and a boom in tourism.
Perspective. This gives you a perspective of your surroundings and how different people lived adn still live in Vietnam!

Best way to start your trip. This museum gives you an overview of the country's different ethnies as well as their daily living habits. It situates you and helps you understand the people. It is a must if you want to get the most out of your trip.
Very Informative & Extensive. So much information about the Country and how it is different from others we have visited.

interesting overview of different Vietnamese cultures. The inside of the museum is ok and helps you understand the different ethnic groups in the Country however it is the different houses outside which are worth the visit. Definitely worth a trip.
Very interesting the best of Hanoi. Easy to view and enter the locations many displays, all in English, and the details of each exhibit were excellent

Allow time for this one. Great exhibition covering in various levels of detail the 54 ethnic groupings of Vietnam. There are outside exhibits of different houses and structures including a water puppet theatre, and a large museum centre which has quite detailed exhibits, so make sure you allow time to cover everything. The cafe serves very good food and the museum shop is a Craftlink shop so the items for sale are very good quality,at reasonable prices. If you are not part of a tour group take a taxi to get there.
Must See. I enjoyed to see photos of all the ethnic groups thet make up "The Vietnamese"

positive surprice. It was a great surprice.I took bus 14 from the lake. the bus men said when I must go off an go 700 m. to the museumthere were a lot of things to see.Water pupple shiow and other things.I have been two times before on group tours where I not go to see it.Now I travel alone it is one of the best things in Hanoi

A must-see corner in Hanoi. I have come here several times, some with friends and also some alone. It is really an interesting place that shows us the cultural diversity of ethnic groups in Vietnam. I could find how people work, how men and women dress, where they usually spend their time, how and why they have those life-style... Not only the in-door-room (that gave information in general) but also the out-door-exhibition step by step take me to deep understanding about Vietnamese people's life. Each time coming here, I get new experiences. All of them are great!

Excellent Museum. There are displays from all of the major ones, featuring dress, artifacts and religious items. This is a great museum that really gives a great look at the minority groups of Northern Vietnam.The outdoor 'cultural playground' is really interesting.

A fantastic museum and packed full of info about village life of Vietnam. I paid about 100,000dong in a taxi to go out (70,000 to come back to the Old Quarter) and only 25,000dong to get in! Anyhow, it is a large museum with interesting and informative displays, great explanations (English, French and Vietnamese and a pamphlet in other languages) and excellent artifacts. The amount of information is almost overwhelming but there are enough visual displays for those that can't be bothered reading everything. The houses and outdoor displays are fascinating too. I thought the whole museum was excellent and high quality. A worthwhile initiative given the high number of non-Viet in the country. I took my time but could have spent longer and was there for about 3 hours. There's a restaurant but I didn't go in. Highly recommended!
Impressive. This is a big place, covering a city block. While we enjoyed it, it would have been greatly enhance if we had hired a guide to explain the remarkable history of this place

Interesting, but really may be abetter use of your time. This is an interesting indoor/outdoor museum devoted to the various ethnic groups that comprise the population of Vietnam. There are displays from all of the major ones, featuring dress, artifacts and religious items. Outside, there are examples of different structures used by these various ethnic groups, which can be toured independently. As I said, it's interesting and informative in a general way, but if your time is short, this may be one that you can skip.

Wonderful Museum. This is a great museum that really gives a great look at the minority groups of Northern Vietnam. The houses, which have been transported and rebuilt on the site, are particularly interesting.
spacious museum with interesting indoor and outdoor exhibits.. Well worth an hour or two. Clean and shaded.The carvings around the burial chamber are something else!!!!!

A perfect pastime if you have a few hours available before leaving Vietnam. This is a nice place to visit that gives you an overview on what you saw and maybe missed while visiting Vietnam. It is worth the 60.000 VND taxi drive from Hanoi centre, everything what is written in the last version of Lonely Planet about this museum corresponds with what you will find there. When we visited the museum was flooded by thousands! of schoolchildren and we still enjoyed showcases on the so-called minorities and the rebuild houses outside the museum
Great place to visit. A great place to visit. very interesting . they change the setting often and it worth to visit every few months. They do a great job here!!! high recommend
worth a visit. there is an open air water puppet show on weekends. the outdoor 'cultural playground' is really interesting, especially the different kinds of wooden houses.
excelent museum. the indoor is ok, but the out door is so muddy when rained
interesting. Well set out and worth visitng especially if you can't get out to the local ethnic groups

Really interesting and informative. This is a modern museum and of all the museums we saw in Vietnam this one probably came closest to what we would expect to see when visiting a museum in the U.K. The building is quite European in its architectural design. Internally the exhibits were good and informative with English translations. However, the best is undoubtedly outside the museum where they have erected many different types of huts from the various different regions of Vietnam. These also had different everyday objects used in these huts with explanations. Visitors can walk around freely inside them. Unfortunately, as this was part of a city tour we had to leave before we could explore as much as we would have liked to.

Best bet if can only go to one museum. Go on a day with good weather so you can visit all the native house exhibits on the property and attend the water puppet show too. Indoor museum is small but included several permanent displays plus traveling exhibits. Cafe on premises.
Interesting Museum. This museum provided a very interesting view of the numerous ethnic groups in Vietnam.

Wonderful. I won't spoil the surprise - this place (and the amazing restaurant) is a a great place to visit. The museum shop has some of the most beautiful and inexpensive stuff we saw in this part of the world
Good place. Lots of history, mixed indoor and outdoor exhibits. Easy to navigate.

Worth seeing. The Museum houses fine exhibits that help to explain the background to a busy modern city and its environs. Understanding of the different tribes and their way of life is developed by an array of costumes, reconstructed buildings and a variety of artefacts
Must see venue to assist beginning to understand vietnam. It shows in magnificent detail how the Vietnamese people and their country have evolved

Interesting look into various cultures. We liked the houses of the various ethnic groups in vietnam. We got to go inide and walk around, see how these people live. We liked the outfits that the different ethnic groups wear. It was really interesting.

Obligatory spot in your Hanoi itinerary. About 6km from city center. Take a taxi and no need to worry how to get back to the city as there were number of taxis waiting at the gate. It is quite Western type museum, starting from the architecture and also the way exhibitions have been set up. Exhibitions were good and informative with French and English translations, but the ultimate highlight is outside the building  where they have erected more than 10 different type buildings from different parts of Vietnam which also include different objects used in these buildings along with explanations. Visitord can freely roam inside them. It was clearly one of the highlights of the Hanoi city sights.

A Wonderful Trip Through the Culture of Vietnam. It is hard to believe how well this museum does with little staff and funds. Several past reviewers have been disappointed that it didn’t look more like many European Museums, but if you slow down and take your time, the curators of the Museum of Ethnology will take you on a unique and illuminating tour of the culture of Vietnam through their exhibits. The displays of houses and buildings out side are not to be missed. When you leave beware of the cab drivers outside the gate, have someone phone for a cab for you. This will save you lots of money.I have been to this museum many times and each time I find something new that I missed the time before. It is a must if you are interested in the culture of Vietnam.

Excellent museum. If you're heading to the north-west Vietnam, or really any of the minority ethnic people's area, you're well advised to check out this museum first, as it gives a good introduction to all the Vietnamese minorities.
NO camera allowed.... camera not allow when step in, but still can carry in to the museum.
Nice museum. Outdoor buildings great. Exhibits inside just nice.
So informative - a must see. An insight into how Vietnamese people have lived & perhaps still live.

Gives an excellent insight in the different cultures in Vietnam. The displays were informative without information overload, the outside areas Have reconstructed houses you can visit to show the way people live.
Beautiful replicas in the garden. This museum exhibits the varied minorities of Vietnam - very nice museum, well organized. Te garden outside with the replica huts was incredible.

Excellent exhibits!. Good outdoor exhibits of the minority homes! A must visit for those who are interested in the culture of Vietnam's ethnic minorities. The museum is a bit far from the city center. Get the help of your hotel to book for a reputable cab service or be prepared to be scammed. For those who don't mind a short walk, the museum can be reached by taking Bus 14 which stops at Hoan Kiem Lake. The bus fare only cost 3,000VND.
Very detailed museum. It is a very thorough museum with all 50 or so ethnic tribes described in detail so it can be overwhelming.
Very interesting.. A very interesting museum and outdoor exhibits .Surveys the many ethnic groups, art, dress, housing and customs.
Water puppets. really cool outdoor water puppet show run by local puppet society.

Best museum in the city, hands down!!. I mean, all the other museums are like, boring, so the bars aren't that high. But this one has really interesting exhibits, and the greenery surrounding it was very soothing
An overview of ethnic population of Viet Nam. About daily life and housing of different tribes. In the garden some houses are built up (e.g. a longhouse)

Cultural experience. Very interesting, worth a visit! There are a multitude of ethnic groups in Vietnam and this museum has an indoor and outdoor exhibition demonstrating the many ways of life in this incredible country.
Learning. A great way to understand the ethnic/cultural differences in Vietnam.
Interesting place to visit. Really enjoyed learning about all the ethnic groups living in Vietnam. Very interesting.

History of the different tribes. The museum did a good job of explaining the origin and migrations of the different peoples that currently inhabit Vietnam. It also showed their different clothing, tools, and habitation.
Worth spending 2 hours there, if you are interested in ethnology. The outdoor exhibition area is unaffordable to miss. Life-size houses and huts are displaying Vietnamese ethnic groups' living.

The best place to visit in Hanoi. If you have one day in Hanoi, this is the best place to visit!An excellent place to go to get a really indepth look at the peoples and places of Vietnam! Very clean and foreigner friendly. We have a lot of fun there. You can take the bus number 14 from Hoan Kiem Lake to this place. Ask the reception for the bus or taxi to avoid the spam taxi outside street. It takes 7 kms from the Old Quarter to this place. Highly recommend!

Well worth a visit. This museum gives a great amount of information about the makeup of the different groups of Vietnamese people and the outside display of buildings is wonderful. One tip - maybe don't go first thing in the morning as the school groups tend to be there then and the noise is deafening!

Excellent museum in Hanoi. Visited the museum on the recommendation of the staff at our hotel and were not disappointed. English interpretive signs throughout the modern and impressive museum. The large outdoor area has replicas of the houses of the hillside tribes that you can enter and visit.We also ate at the restaurant onsite and had a good meal there.Definitely would recommend this museum to anyone visiting Hanoi; a bit out of the way, but taxis are so inexpensive in Hanoi, it was not a problem.
Interesting insight. The museum has great displays and the original (relocated) buildings outside are really interesting.
a surprising visit, a fantastic museum. very complete and good organised presentation. Very interesting for all who are for the first time in Vietnam
Great for kids. Great fun for kids and worthwhile for adults too with lots of ethnic history and bric a brac

Many different cultures. I didn't realise there was so many different cultures with such a rich history in Vietnam!! An excellent place to go to get a really indepth look at the peoples and places of Vietnem. Very clean and foreigner friendly. Highly recommend

Excellent!. The Ethnology Museum is a must visit. The museum presents well organized displays highlighting the different tribal cultures living in this country. A combination of photos, displays, and videos helps in understanding the exhibits. Suggest planning your itinerary to allow at least two to three hours so that you are not rushed and have time to watch the informative videos. An English-speaking guide will enrich your visit.

Enjoyed this Museum and The On Site Restaurant. This gives a great overview of all the ethnic groups in Vietnam. It is very informative and beautifully presented. There is a training restaurant on the grounds, and by eating there you can help support youth who are training in the hospitality industry

Great museum. Very interesting museum, well laid out and far more detailed than many other museums in Asia.I tried to get an English speaking guide on arrival, but they didn't have any...I would recommend calling in advance to arrange a guide if you want one (I saw a French family with a guide, but I'm not sure if they pre-booked or not???)
Modern, interesting, worth a visit.. If you are only visiting the city, this gives a good taste of rural life.
A great insight to Vietnamese culture. Very informative with great exhibits . An english speaking tour guide was extremely beneficial
very insightful collection of artifacts. The 54 ethnic groups are well represented by this modern and well lit museum
If you have some spare time. Dropped in to have a look. Some interesting displays, they are building a new museum next door , lots to look at but a lot same same

Great peek in to the peoples of Vietnam. Super interesting, definitely go through all of the houses of the different tribes of Vietnam. In fact, we didn't even go inside the museum! We spent all of our time outside. We didn't get a tour, but ran into another tour group and the group leader was definitely sharing interesting facts that you wouldn't learn just be reading the plaques.

Great museum. Although we had to take a taxi out to the Museum, it was more than worth the trip. The indoor exhibits were informative and well-presented, but the best feature were the outdoor houses which really gave us an idea of how the different ethnic groups live. The cafe in the museum also serves good food at reasonable prices.
Really interesting!. With our Hanoi Kids guide Ruby, we really enjoyed hearing about and visiting this musum

Interesting a worth the ride out. Got short changed by the lady in the ticket office - count your change but worth a visit. It has a free water puppet show outside which was great as we could not get into the one in town

Interesting. Good for a few hours and gives a good (though a bit shallow) insight of the Vietnamese ethnology. Would be great with more items on display - though it looks like they are building an annexe.

A great look at Vietnam's Evolution. This museum is divided into two parts; an indoor exhibit of the country's cultural groups and the outdoor exhibit of the buildings they lived in.In each exhibit there is a great deal of information provided the allows the visitor to step back in history to imagine what daily life would be like in the respective tribes.Special note should be given to the attention to detail that the curators made when transporting the authentic village structures to the museum

what a great day!. we went to the Museum because there was a special event outside, celebrating the culture of ethnic minorities. That was a lot of fun. We went through the outdoor houses, and watched everyone playing games. But we were blown away by the museum when we went inside. It is so well-laid out, and not overwhelming with detail, and easy to walk around. It was a great day.The cafe on the grounds is okay too.

A must see if you're not travelling in the North. This museum gives you a good idea of the rich heritage provided by the ethnic minorities of Vietnam (55). If you go to the museum after visiting the highlands and North Vietnam, it will be a little redundant.
Best museum in Hanoi. Interesting collection, especially outdoors, nice shop

Comprehensive and professional. This well-managed museum presents the broad scope of ethnic minorities in Vietnam and area. The people are diverse and colourful. The structures on the grounds are most impressive.
Great fun. Exhibition was quite good but the real size huts outside was genius.
