Definitely worth a visit. Wonderful displays, both inside and out. Outside are replicas of traditional houses and inside are some wonderful ethnographic exhibits.

such a well designed outdoor exhibit. Such a beautiful and educational outdoor exhibit. Once inside, however, the pieces in the exhibits maintain their high level of quality but the displays and space show some lack of attention to dust, poor lighting and (I'm guessing) lack of funding to maintain.
Very Good Museum. One of the best museums I've visited. Excellent quality of information.
Well worth a visit. Very informative in regards to the many cultures that make up Vietnam. Well worth a visit.
History review. Excellant exhibits, both outside& inside. Trace history of different tribes etc.
Outdoor museum is very good. The [sanitized] authentic dwellings of the many tribal people of Vietnam is a good introduction to visitors who have not seen similar jungle dwellings of South-East Asia.

Outstanding - very interesting. great info about the 54 ethic groups in Vietnam. Lots of easy to read info and very good displays. Outside are many of the typical houses or village meeting buildings. we really enjoyed it, well worth your time.
History of Vietnam. A lot of fossils that you see in many museums. The tribes of Vietnam were interesting

Great place to learn Vietnamese culture. We stopped at this museum as part of our Hanoi City Tour. It is a fairly small museum but packed with information and exhibits about the Vietnamese culture. Plan to stay for 1-2 hours.

Great overview of Vietnam's ethnic tribes. Our family (2 teenagers, aged 15 and 13) spent a good part of a day at this museum. It gives a wonderful overview of all the different tribes within Vietnam, with English translations to boot!
Plus they have recreated various traditional houses in the back which do a great job in supporting the overall educational experience.

Well worth a visit. Fascinating oasis in Hanoi. Well worth a visit with lots of well presented and interesting exhibits. The gardens, with traditional houses dotted around, are a peaceful oasis in what can sometimes be an overwhelming city. It has a nice restaurant. It's a bit out of town, but well worth the effort.

What a find!. We thoroughly enjoyed our visit to this museum on our way to Ba Be National Park. This is really an educational facility where you can learn about the different lifestyles of all the ethnic minority tribes in Vietnam. Excellent displays, all presented in an interesting way. All around the building there are life size models of huts, temples and farming techniques depicting their way of life. The little shop in the grounds outside sells great Vietnamese coffee! A wonderful place to visit at the beginning of your time in Vietnam! Highly recommended.

Well worth a visit. The grounds have copies of different tribal huts that you can go into (some of them you have to climb up quite tricky ladders so be warned!). Very interesting museum. We got a taxi there and there were plenty of taxis outside to take us back to the centre.

Ethnic groups all in one place. Take a taxi here about 7km it is worth it. Make sure it is a reputable company or you will get ripped off. This place has the most remarkable houses of each ethnic group reconstructed by the ethnic people in the grounds. Dont miss them. Lots of vietnamese couples were having wedding photos taken on our visit. The restaurant in the grounds is a hospitality training place but was excellent.

Best museum I've been to, Could have spent all day here. Must See.. Only $1 to enter. Best value for money yet! This gave such a valuable insight into the ethnic minorities living in and around Vietnam for travellers who, like us, were visiting vietnam for the first time and only going to the tourist centers. Make sure you allow enough time. After going into the museum you head around the side to see some replicas of housing used by these minorities and traditional Vietnamese people (I can't be 100% sure if all where replicas or if some were original but they are amazing regardless). Make sure your camera is charged because you will take a lot of photos! Very impressed. I'd recommend watching the videos that play inside the museum too.

Easily the best thing we saw in Hanoi!. We loved exploring this outstanding museum. My friends' two-year-old was easily entertained exploring the traditional architecture displays set up around the outside of the museum, and so were we! I learned so much about all the various groups in Vietnam, all in an enjoyable setting. Inside the building there is beautiful folk art and displays of traditional costumes and the ways of life of so many different ethnic groups, it was almost overwhelming. Definitely a must-see in Hanoi; it really helped me get a much better sense of the country's diversity.

Set aside plenty of time!. This is 7kms away from the Old Quarter. I hired a motorbike and driver and set off. The museum itself is very cheap 25,000 dong and 50,000 extra if you want to use a camera. Loads of information about ethnic groups. Be prepared to do plenty of reading as there is a lot of information on display. Best of all were the buildings outside the museum. I spent 2 hours there and easily could have spent a whole day.
A little far away from old quarter but worth a visit. Don't miss out the ethnic houses that have been shown

Sapa Preperation. Small but intresting. If you are in Hamoi and intend to visit Sapa it is worth a vist to get some intresting background on the ethnic minorities.
Try the Cafe/Resturant
See the outside. Outside exhibits are fascinating. Homes (long house, tall houses, etc.) of different ethnic groups. Inside exhibits static and not as interesting.

my favorite visit in Hanoi. The interior of the museum is nothing special, but the outside exhibits are fascinating, including live size replicas of the traditional tribal housing and a water puppet show.
Museum Visit. A very interesting introduction to the myriad of ethnic groups which make up Vietnam. They have gone to great lengths to re-create aspects of traditional Vietnamese life.

Worth a visit. Be prepared for a fair bit of reading at this one which provides signage in VN, french and English. Or you could just browse away a couple of hours looking at the indoor and outdoor exhibits. Inexpensive abt A$1.25 per person.

Educational and relaxed. Nice exhibits. The facilities are average but the displays are pretty good. Some of the ancient items I can't believe they just have sitting out behind thin glass!
I learned a lot about the Vietnamese history here. Good way to spend a couple hours.

Fascinating. A fascinating glimpse into Vietnamese life.
Well laid out museum inside with outside area as well.
Water puppets Saturday & Sunday

Gorgeous place. Quite interesting, well laid out. Covers a lot of tribes. Make sure you leave enough time to go to the open air exhibit, the real life size houses are great! Would be good for kids too.

Great. A wonderful place to learn more of the history and heritage of the Vietnamese people. Excellent exhibits with good signage. Obviously well curated and cared for. The outside exhibits displaying the architectural heritage of the country are most interesting. The adjoining coffee shop serves excellent coffee and meals and provides employment to disadvantaged youths.

Very visual - read as little or as much as you want.. The layout of this museum is great as the visual displays were really well set up. You could stop at a display that interested you and then read the information panel for more detail - French, English and Vietnamese. The outdoor area with all the authentic buildings constructed by the people they represented were an added bonus. The sound quality of the water puppet show was a bit jarring on the ears but if you haven't seen a water puppet show it's a nice introduction.
Worth the Journey. Despite the journey into the suburbs, the museum was top class, both outside in the compound and inside the main building. It also boasted a good restaurant.
A must visit place. I learnt a lot during my visit there. If u r interested in the culture and tradition, then don't miss this hidden jewel.

A taste of Vietnam. This is a good museum to go to learn about the various cultures in Vietnam. It definitely saves time and money travelling all of Vietnam to see the houses and handiwork that this museum features. I especially liked the houses where you can climb in and walk around. It has a certain authentic and adventurous feel about it. There were a couple of houses I opted out of climbing because the ladders had very high rungs. I would recommend visiting it on your own rather than in a tour group because then you can truly explore. As it was, we only had an hour, and that is definitely not enough. I recommend about 3 hours. I took away a star because for a cultural treasure like that, the government needs to tighten its management and finish the new building that was under construction but was never finished due to corruption schemes.

informative to bus travellers. If you want to learn about the old vietnam its very informative lots of items to view with English translations, although if you have been travelling through vietnam and this is at the end of your travels its not a must
Don't miss the houses behind the museum!. Good collection in the museum but the highlight for me was the wonderful collection of buildings in the park-like setting behind the museum.

Excellent museum. We found this museum fascinating and informative on the different ethnic groups in Vietnam. There are English explanations with everything, plus interesting videos. Many beautiful artifacts. Outside, there are a number of buildings and complexes that you can go through, again with plenty of explanation in English. There are houses, community halls, farm buildings, etc. We spent almost all day here, and had lunch in the restaurant that is a training venue for Vietnamese students who want to work in restaurants. The food was very good and the ambiance very pleasant. We would definitely recommend this museum, which also had a very nice gift shop.
Great show case of ethnic culture. Great introductory insight into the different culture of the main ethnic groups.. The tall roof, the long house and the water puppet shows a must for visitors....

Must go. Truly enjoyed the exhibits,, especially the outdoor exhibits, where they build replica of houses of the various ethnic groups. Plan at least half a day at this place. The museum shop outside (Craft Link) has interesting knick-knacks

good if you have the time,. its out of town, so you need to arrange transport to get there. the no 14 bus will get you there from the bus stop north of the lake but even then its a bit of a walk to get to the museum. it should cost 3000 dong. lonely planet rave on about this museum, but it was OK.
tribes of Vietnam. Good way to understand the ethnic minorities. The museum is clean and spacious. Some interesting items.

Informative, well-organized museum.. Well-organized and informative with interesting write ups and exhibits on the various native people groups in Vietnam. Especially good was the outdoor exhibits, at which we could climb into prototypes of certain native housing types. On weekends there's a water puppet show at the outdoor exhibit area which is worth catching if you've not booked tickets at the water puppet theatre at Hoan Kiem lake.

Very interesting!. This is worth a trip if you have a bit of extra time in Hanoi. You need to take a taxi as it is located outside the centre but it's certainly worth it if you are interested in learning more about the mix of different minorities in Vietnam. The exhibits in the museum are well presented with lots of information but the highlight is the reproduction houses in the grounds. The museum have sought help from the minority tribes people to ensure that the replicas are accurate and you can climb into the houses and have a good look around. Add to that a quaint little coffee shop and a Craft Link shop and it was a lovely way to spend our last morning in Hanoi.

interesting place to learn about minorities. we spent 4 hours in the museum, passing through the different minorities and their way of living, dressing, working...An outdoor exhibition shows original houses built by minority people. Worth a visit!

Informational - visit when you're fresh. The Museum of Ethnology is heavy on information on the different peoples of the region. We made the mistake of doing this at the end of the day and it was difficult to enjoy the museum and process the information when we were tired from rest of the day's adventures. I definitely suggest visiting when you are mentally and physically fresh, as there are a number of exhibits to see and a lot of informational placards to digest. The outdoor area is a very nice touch, where they've built replicas of a number of the different styles of homes in the region, many of which you can go inside and look around.It's a bit out of the way, and I wouldn't rearrange my trip around it, but if you're looking for something to do for a couple of hours while in Hanoi it's a pretty good option. It was one of the more expensive tickets in Hanoi, though still extremely cheap by Western standards.

Museum of Ethnology worth a visit (even for non-museum buffs like me). Fascinating exhibits about the different ethnic groups in Vietnam, including built-to-scale houses for each ethnic group around the outside perimeter of the museum. Those houses were constructed by builders from each region, and were open for building - they taught us more about the family structure and traditions of the ethnic minorities of Vietnam than any article we could have read.

Only for the nostalgic (bit boring). The Vietnam Museum of Ethnology houses a collection of art and everyday objects gathered from Vietnam's diverse tribal people. LOGISTICSThe museum is around 7km from the city centre and somewhat hard to find. Best way to get there I feel is to take a taxi. For memory it cost around 60,000 dong. Just be careful with Hanoi taxi's (lots of scams). According to lonely planet you can take a moto for 30,000 dong one way or take bus 14 (3000d) from Hoan Kiem Lake and get off at the junction between D Hoang Quoc Viet and D Nguyen Van Huyen. REVIEWAlthough this was a well set out and thought out building which had numerous objects, displays and explanations, at the end of the day it was a museum and museums are boring. As a 23yo male with a 22yo girlfriend I guess it was out fault for selecting this place but I was hoping to see more artwork. Instead it was just a collection of everyday objects taken from the million or so tribes of Vietnam. There was heaps of information but it was almost too much. Was like reading a book for each of the million or so tribes. We got bored after half an hour and left.CONCLUSIONAlthough the museum is very well set up and informative it is still at the end of the day........a museum. It can be a little boring for some so you have to ask yourself "Do I want to go to a museum?" before you come here. If museums are for you, you will enjoy it. If they aren't you will find yourself bored and looking for the door like we were.CONCLUSION
Worth a Visit. Interesting displays, inside and outside. Outside water puppet theater, free. Check for show times.

Educational, inexpensive, fun, with peaceful gardens.. I've been in Vietnam for 3 months when I visited the Museum of Ethnology. I went with a local vietnamese who had been there before. The museum is medium-sized with 2 floors and enough to keep you interested for 1-2 hours. The gardens are beautiful and peaceful. They include some authentic village buildings that you can go inside and see. There was traditional live music when we visited, too. I did not find any food or drinks available inside, but easy to find street food or restaurants close by. Also, there was a small (5 m x 5 m) gift shop plus a very small book and postcard store.

worth going a little out of the way. This was a cab ride from our area in the old quarter but it is a lovely museum, highlighting different cultures, history, and an outdoor village with lots of information. I was certainly glad we made the trip. There is a nice little coffee house on grounds that is connected with a cooking school for disadvantaged kids that had great pasteries/coffee as we were there for 2-3 hours!

Amazing. Even though it was pouring rain, the kids and I all loved it. Video presentations, lots of artifacts, so much to see outside-housing structures of different minority groups, hands on, climb on, very interactive.
Not worth it. Its pretty boring and a very poorly designed, built museum. Not worth your time.
Surprising shop.. Great shop avaliable at the Muesum with lots of local handicrafts and at a reasonable price.

LIke visiting a number of different areas in one. Get a local guide to take you here. There is so much to look at and you would get lost wothout a guide explaining all the little intricate details of the various areas of Vietnam and their specific cultural differences.

A mini world.. Really fascinating! Out in the garden they have full scale examples of traditional homes found among the different peoples in Vietnam. Things are labeled well. or i can get the assistance from student docents who are happy to practice their english and show you around. Inside there were a lot more exhibits-- all informative. Great place to while away the time and the on site gift shop has great samples of traditional crafts.

Excellent museum. Easy to get around - however, a guide helps! We wnet there as part of a tour and only had about one hour there. I would have really liked a few more hours to take my time and absorb information about different tribes.

An enjoyable experience. We spent an enjoyable morning here. This Museum is a quick way to gain insights into the 54 cultural groups that inhabit Vietnam. We did have our own Vietnamese tour guide who aided our understanding. There is an excellent cafe here, where young hospitality students learn their trade - reasonably priced and nutritious food. There was a wedding party in the grounds of the Museum while we were there, with about 50 young people thoroughly enjoying themselves. A worthwhile visit.

So much better than I expected!. At the end of our two weeks in Cambodia and Vietnam we spent three days in Hanoi. I wasn't really looking forward to the Museum of Ethnology, but my wife and I were enthralled once we got there. The exhibits were both interesting and informative. At just 45 minutes, we didn't have enough time to soak it all in. If you are at all interested in history and peoples, definitely go here.

Interesting if you are this way inclined. There are some interesting aspects to this museum, particularly the outside exhibitions, if you are interested in ethnology and cultural aspects but my personal preferences lean more to historical sites such as the temples and old quarter.

Museum in a park. This museum is one of the things on the "Visitor To Do List" for Hanoi and it was a pleasant morning's outing. Most of the display consists of original ethnic/tribal housing moved into a parklike setting. It was certainly interesting and makes a change from the noise and crowds of the city centre. We went with our guide, a "HanoiKids" guide and so we made the most of having a local guide and we caught a local bus (No. 14) from the Lake to near the Museum. The ticket cost 15 cents each and it was a fun experience.

A different kind of museum. Good place to spend an afternoon- the exhibits inside display artifacts and customs of various tribes in Vietnam. More enjoyable are the exhibits on the grounds- houses from various parts of vietnam, some of them impossibly high. Adults and kids also have an opportunity to try stilt walking and other activities- kids enjoyed it. On some days there is also a water puppet show that lasts half an hour, but it is out in the open so the effects are a little less dramatic than those seen in a proper water puppet theatre. Worth spending 2-3 hours in this place.There is also a cafe at the back to rest your feet and recharge
Must do. Perhaps the best museum in Hanoi. - it tracks the history of the minority groups.

very interesting. it gives a perfect overview of all the ethnics, specially the traditional style houses in the outside of the museum are very impressive and give a good overview of the real houses, which we saw before in the different areas.

outside exhibits are best. We spent some time inside and outside. I liked the houses in the gardens the best--more insight into how people live. The displays inside were quite informative, but a little lacking in vibrancy.
Fun. Lots to see and kids will really enjoy visiting the different houses
Facinating museum. The William Burchett display gave me another perspective on the man and his relationship with Ho Chi Minh.
hot. a worthwhile afternoon - but take plenty of water - it's hot in there!
A bit school tripy. This place was little boring for my liking. The place is well maintained and quite pretty. But did feel like a school trip.

a little out of the way but the best thing to visit in hanoi. inside was very interesting but the highlight for us was the outside ethnioc houses. Plus very good english notes. Check out the Hmong house and find out why women are banned from going up to the mezzanine level.
very interested place for culture. we like the outside musseum and drinking tea with nut candy in the ttraditional house on stilt.

Pre Sapa must!. To learn a little about those you will see in your mountain travels north and west of Hanoi (Sapa), it is well to spend at least a few hours here. Ask for a translator to help (at the main desk) to enrich the experience.

Don't miss it. There is both an outdoor and an indoor museum. If you are planning on going up north, visit this first. We saw a water puppet show outside. Hint: The musicians are the essence of the show and they were wonderful. I got chills during a flute solo.

Must go for everyone interested in architecture. After taking a overall look on the inside I spent the rest of my time on the outside part - where you can see different types of housing from Vietnamese groups. Very nice and interesting.

Interesting exhibits. Worth a visit if you have some time. There is water puppet theatre at the courtyard of the museum too, but sadly i missed the last show of the day. Make sure you reach there in time to catch the show!
Interesting. It was very hot the day we visited so I was not an enthusiastic participant and did not have a great interest in the museum.

Well Worth A Visit. The best parts of this museum were the houses outside, which gave you an opportunity to see how the ethnic minorities live and the water puppet show that took place while I was touring.
Far away from the center but interesting to visit. it is an outdoor museum. You don't get much from history but you can see some funny old buildings.

Where everything can be seen. it is the place where every ethnic groups can be seen in Vietnam. 54 ethnic groups with diffrent culture and customs. The museum also give you the best outdoor exhibition.
More History of Viet Nam. Wandering through here gives you much of Viet Nam's past.
Good choice. Gives you a better understanding of the Vietnamese people and culture.

Great Information. This Museum is simple and not to European or North American standards. But the information provided is excellent and is a definite must see in Hanoi. It provides invaluable information about the people of Vietnam and their origins.

Interesting if you're the History / Museum Kind of Person. Our city tour took us and the guide was good to explain most things. There's an entrance fee, usually included in the tour price. I am a history fan but my wife was more interested in understand what colours/ cloths / food different ethnic groups used, so it was interesting to her too. Another couple from Malaysia in our tour (we were the only 4 in the tour) also enjoyed, they found many similar tribal things and vibed with the displays there. There are very informational videos going on, I wanted to watch more but the tour guide was pushing us forward, I think would be best if you reach there yourself, keep half a day, watch the videos and walk slowly around, you'd understand more. Many artifacts have captions / explanations in English, so you don't have to wonder what each is. There's a wide variety of things from history of Vietnam, life and times of the different ( 40-50 ) ethnic / tribal people from all over, if you're starting your Vietnam tour from Hanoi, it would be best to start from here, you'd enjoy the country with more perspective, I wish we had done that instead of starting from Saigon. It's a colourful display of many things, would recommend about 2-3 hours and can stretch easily to half a day. The restaurant looked deserted, tour guide said not good (probably motivated to take us elsewhere),

Brilliant exhibitions. Always visit here when I'm in Hanoi. Take the time to explore the outside displays of minority group housing. Some reno's happening on level 2 at the moment - so not as many displays at the moment - but still worth a visit.

A great museum. This is a terrific place to learn about the ethnic cultures of Vietnam. The setting is peaceful and makes for a great time to get away from Hanoi's bustle while learning about the country. Fun to climb in and around all of the houses. Highly recommended.

Allow plenty of time for this museum. Very interesting. Focus is on the ethnic groups that are a part of the early history of this country. English and Vietnamese written materials available at all displays. You do not need a tour guide to thoroughly enjoy this museum and the displays outside the main building. Wished we had several more hours to spend, as this was one of the most interesting museums we encountered.

A "must see" for me!. Not the easest place to get to, but taxis are plentiful and are sometimes willing to wait. We've gone at least 3 times and each time I see more. I tell anyone who asks that this is a place not to be missed! (I'm a history & cultural fan, so this is high on my list.)
An extensive collection giving insight into Vietnams Culture. The buildings outside were very interesting and well explained.Craft shop at the front gate was good value and high quality.

visit only if you have nothing else to do. A lot of information on Vietnamese hill tribes, probably worth a visit only if you have a specialist interest in this area. The exhibits were more replicas made by the museum to give you a feeling of what these places are like.

Museum of Ethonology in Vietnam.. I don't like to go museums, but the Museum of Ethnology in Vietnam to make me feel beautiful and like coming here. Ethnics minorities are well represented, their culture, their habit. Museum so large and exhibited in the outdoors. 54 Ethnic minorities which represent the Vietnam was a wonderful discover. It is just great and really give you a sense of the country you are. When come in the museum I found myself a bit rich, the colors of the people always have a special appeal to me. I will come back here in the near future.

Visit the Vietnam Museum of Etnology prior your trip to Sapa. We spent some 2 hours in the Museum with our guide from Exotissimo. It was very interesting to visit it prior to our trip to Sapa as you first see how people live in our days and then while a homestay in Sapa you can "touch" this life yourself! Dontt miss the Museum's craftshop: a very good selection of gifts for your family and friends, and also a good selection of books in the bookstore. Also there is a cafe there so you may cheer up with a cup of coffee or a glass of beer!

So many things to see. This was a very modern museum with a lot of artifacts and videos that captured the craftmaking of the different tribes.Outside, they had life-like replicas of the different architectural structures of the tribes, which you could actually enter to get a feel of the place. There was a water puppet show going on when we went, but it was all in Vietnamese.Their Craft-Link gift shop was one of my favorite shopping places as they had quality items at affordable prices. They even had a restaurant, which I regret we didn't get to eat at.Overall a great deal and an opportunity to learn about the different tribes without making the trek to Sapa.

Learn more about Vietnam's diversity and rich array of traditions. This was a very informative museum. It's worthwhile and very interesting. There are a plethora of traditional artifacts on display. It gives you a great perspective on the diversity of the country.

Worth a look. We found this interesting and worth the trip. We had two boys with us who loved the outdoor part of the museum especially all the swinging bamboo and the trees to climb. You could spend a few hours here easily provided the weather is good. The inside part would only take 45-60 mins to view.

Good collection of local clothing and household goods. Displays are well put together. Nice collection.
Excellent (but small) gift shop selling genuine hand made crafts under not-for-profit model.

Must see.. I usually get bored with museums after about half an hour, but this one is my favourite museum. I enjoyed this place very representative of Vietnam. Ethnics minorities are well represented, their culture, their habit. It was set up modernly, interesting to look at it. The organisation, managing was very professional. 54 Ethnic minorities which represent the Vietnam was a wonderful discover. It is just great and really give you a sense of the country you are.
Noteworthy. Excellent source of information about Vietnam. Hear the story of Ho Chi Minh and how he spent his last few years there. Step into his house and see the simplicity of it.
Ok!. Not great many disturbing images and portrays the americans and english very bad.. also beggers target you

a real surprise. very interesting and a nice building. very moving exhibition on AIDS/HIV in vietnam on te ground floor. dont miss visiting the outdoor stilt houses around the back - including a burial house surrounded by copulating figures!

Unbelievable!. This museum is worth the cab ride! We were blown away by the outdoor area, where visitors can experience the different living conditions of Vietnam's various ethnic groups. It was an amazing hands-on experience, and we also got to take in a show at their outdoor water puppet pavilion. Inside the musueum was also enjoyable, especially the exhibit showcasing recycling workers. Don't miss the outdoor cafe on your way in (I can't recall the name), but it employs disadvantaged youths so they can attain job experience and practice their English.The service was great, and the baked goods to die for.
Wonderful building. Old French classical architecture with reasonably interesting displays. Useful English titles.

Wrong muesum to go to a rainy day :-). There are many museums to visit in Hanoi, but this one is better if it's not raining. The best part of the exhibition is the outside constructions showing different houses etc from different ethnological groups in Vietnam. It's also very good for kids, since you can visit the houses and see what they look like on the inside.The exhibition indoors is ok. There are so many minorities in Vietnam so it's difficult to show them all in this museum, but you can get a nice picture of them (if you have enough energy left after spending a lot of time on the outdoors exhibition).If you're hungry there's a nice café/restaurant. The young persons working here come from "troublesome" backgrounds and working here is a part of their education in the restaurant business. The food is good and the terrace is nice.

Come and explore the diversity in Vietnamese culture. We come to the Museum just not to visit or entertain, but also to learn about these ethnic groups, Vietnamese cultural diversity and the uniqueness of each group and region, as well as traditional values throughout the Vietnamese country. For this reasons, we are attracted to the Museum. The artefacts of the Museum are not only priceless antiquities, but many are everyday objects. These objects reflect tangible and intangible cultural heritages of the communities, representing lives and creative activities of the people. We were so impressed by knives, baskets, garments, flutes, pipes and mats which were used in daily life. Everything was so alive. We took many photos and would highly recommended to my friend.
Interesting if you have half a day to spare. Nice museum for those interested in the Vietnam minorities.

Keeping minority groups tools, clothes, way of worship and house prototype. Good to explore if you like to know more about Vietnam minority groups. This museum display all kind of tools, clothing, way of worship, arts for different kind of group. Outdoor of this museum also have house prototypes in actual size. You even can get into the house to snap photos. This kind of house only appear in rural areas. Most of the minority groups in tourist spots like Sapa, no longer using this kind of house. I really enjoy looking at the house design and know about different group live in different kind of house and why they design like this. 1 or 2 prototype houses shows photo how they built the house.

A must visit - Excellent history of Vietnam. Not to be missed for a history of Vietnam. Recommended by the hotel - see the pushbike with 800 fish baskets ! The museum shop also supports charity and is good value.

Wonderful museum for understanding more about the people who make up Vietnam. Excellent displays showcasing the culture and daily lives of the many ethnic minorities in Vietnam.The restaurant at the museum is also great and not expensive.

OK for a rainy morning... I was expecting really good things from the museum but it was overall a bit disappointing. Lay out was confusing and it really needed a better introduction to the history of Vietnam. Captions werent terribly informative. The outdoor exhibits looked good but difficult to get into any as overun with local school children.
A plethora of artifacts and information. If you like museums I highly recommend this one. You can make it a half day trip if you really see it all.

Not necessarily the number 1 destination. Not on top of my list. There are lots of others that could be ranked asNumber 1. Maybe, the architecture of French colonial homes. MaybeThe 5th on my list.If you have time to spare, you could visit this place.

Outdoor exhibits are worth the drive. I figured this museum would give me a good look at the tribal way of life, since I'm not making the journey to Sapa. Of course, nothing really compares to going to see the people in person, but this is a fairly good alternative... Though it does take a while to reach from the Old Quarter (taxi is about 5-6 USD) the museum is worth the drive. The open-air exhibits feature a number of different huts, each from a different tribe. Upon removal of shoes (only for certain dwellings), you can poke around each of the musty rooms while reading about traditional housing arrangements and constuction. Beside the houses, there is an informal water puppet show that runs for most of the day which is complimentary. The indoor exhibits are worth a quick look - most have traditional clothes and textiles on display. The museum closes at 5:30, so you'll want to at least arrive by 3 (includes time for a bite to eat, puppet show, and thorough exploration of exhibits). While you're at the museum, check out Baguette & Chocolat - a cafe located on the grounds with tasty lunch items and drinks. The hot chocolate is good, and the chocolate mousse is a must! An especially nice place to wait-out a thundershower...

A Must-See Before Venturing into the Rest of Viet Nam!. This wonderfully planned museum, created with help from the Musée de l'Homme in Paris, France, is a fascinating and thorough introduction to the many peoples who live in what we now call Viet Nam. Not only does it capture the great diversity of ethnic backgrounds, but it also displays wonderful examples of actual homes, clothing, tools, festivals and many other cultural aspects of life from all of these peoples. It would be difficult to see every example of the varied cultures in Viet Nam in any trip, long or short. A visit to this museum is an excellent introduction to what you will see during the remainder of your visit in S.E. Asia.

Beautiful museum!It's a wonderful way to spend a few hours in Hanoi. The museum had great information on the people of Vietnam through out history. They had videos playing at about every exhibit to show how the people would use the objects on display. The garden out back has walk through exhibits that are peaceful and worth the stroll. If your hungry the cafe out front has got a great shrimp and sweet potato lunch for $2;)

Most interesting museum we've seen on our Vietnam trip- I'd go just to see the open air exhibits!. A very interesting museum if you're interested in learning about the tribes and groups in Vietnam. Lotd of handicrafts, clothes and information about traditions on show. Outside are about 10 huts and structures built by people from the minority groups demonstrating the structures their people live in and build. Some very impressive buildings! Have a look!

A must for those visiting Sapa. The Museum of Ethnology is the best museum we've visited in Vietnam. It displays artifacts, clothing, and memorabilia from the many ethnic groups in Vietnam. Plus, there are several examplesof the building styles used by the various tribes throughout the country. It is an excellent prep course for the trip to Sapa (or any other area where the various unassimilated ethnic groups live), as it explains how long they have lived in Vietnam, and some of their local customs, like funerals. The weaving information is particularly helpful. There is a Craft Link museum shop as well. Take a taxi - it's a long way from the Old Quarter, but much more interesting than the Ho Chi Minh museum, mausoleum, etc.

Great Musuem, must visit!. Far from the old qtr. but definitely worth a visit. A taxi will be faster but more expensive compared to taking a local bus. We opted to take the local bus with the help of our hotel who wrote down in Viet to ask ppl how to get to the museum. If you are adventurous & have time, you can take the bus no14 at Hoan Kiem Lake by the Tourist Info Center. Once you get on bus there will be an attendee going around collecting the bus fee. We showed him the note from our hotel written in Viet. He let us know when to get off. On the way back the bus's last stop is at the Lake. There is a walk to the museum and sadly we had to cross a really wide street so we asked a taxi to drive us the 300m. Our hotel warned us about taxis scamming when you leave the museum so best to take a reputable taxi like Hanoi Taxi or Mai Linh.It's closed on Mon. Open 8:30am-5:30pm. We didn't get a tour guide but there were English signs explaining the exhibit. Very extensive display about each of the 53 ethnic groups. There is an outdoor display of the homes they lived in which you can actually enter and look around. We spent about a total of 3hrs at the museum including indoor and outdoor displays and lunch at the restaurant (Baguette & Chocolat)on site. Also, there is a gift shop that is associated w/Craft Link which works w/local artisans. Recommend checking out the restaurant and gift shop.

A long taxi drive from Old Quarter, but worth a couple hours. Nice introduction to all of the minority groups in Vietnam. Wonderful photography of day-to-day life. Although the videos are poor quality and dated, the stories capture unique cultures (religious traditions, burials, etc). Informative and timely exhibit on HIV/AIDs -- English translations. Great way to spend the afternoon.

Interesting place - beware taxis. I share the opinions of other reviewers concerning the Museum. It is informative and a nice mirror of life in rural Vietnam even in recent years. Explanations in English and French. The outdoor exhibit provides illustrative examples of relatively recent dwellings from various parts of Vietnam. Admission fee: 25'000 d. Closed on Mo. On site restaurant with simple but good food. Guides available (fee). A bit far from the Old Quarter (15-20 min. per taxi). Nice way to spend a morning or an afternoon in Hanoi.Tip: beware of taxis parked in front of the museum. My taxi back to the hotel had a tinkered meter charging about three times the normal rate.

An interesting and well presented museum.. The museum was very informative and well presented. I really enjoyed the traditional architecture exhibit in the grounds. Good to see the ethnic culture of Vietnam is being preserved for future generations to learn about.Excellent value for money.

Not to be missed!. To understand Vietnam, a trip to this museum is a must! If you are a 'museum person' you could probably spend a good part of the day there! We had an late afternoon flight and only spent 3 hours. Admission was 25.000VND and we paid another 50,000VND for an English speaking guide. The guide led us on a tour of the inside of the museum and provided a very good overview of the cultural heritage of the 54 ethnic minority groups of Vietnam. We then went outside and explored the different styles of housing of each of the groups we learnt about. If we had have had more time, we would have gone back into the museum to learn more. This museum is a credit to the Vietnamese government as it encapsulates the heritage the country may lose as it becomes more westernised.

Don't miss it. I recently made a second trip to this museum. I thoroughly enjoyed it the first time but did not have time then to walk around the typical traditional houses on display in the grounds of the museum. This time I did the lot. The ethnic minorities are gradually being overwhelmed by modernity and the rapid pace of change affects them as it does the Kinh majority. This may be the only place to see how some ethnic minorities dressed, were housed and lived their daily lives. It's one of the most interesting and colourful museums of its kind that I have ever visited.Since my previous visit Craft Link has opened a shop near the front entrance and Hoa Sua has established a restaurant in the grounds so it's possible to support good causes during your visit. There is also a bookshop outside the front door with a wide range of books, postcards, pictures and charts. For 150,000 VND I bought a book of beautiful coloured photos of all the ethnic minority groups in Viet Nam.

Great way to spend the afternoon. Great outdoor display of the different tribal homes. We were shown around by a young student guide from Hanoikids and was pleasantly surprised by how much she shows and shared with us... with the displays providing evidence and samples of how things were done by the "tribes".Recommend to leave at least 3 hours to visit the external exhibits, then the internal ones.

Interesting Museum, Great Cafe on site. Although the explanation boards in the museum are somewhat biased - alike other Vietnamese museums, the outdoor display is good fun. This is especially if you don't have the time to go to other parts of Vietnam to see the ethnic minorities.
Also, I love the Baguettes and Chocolate cafe in the Museum - try their yummy chocolate tarts!

A good way to spend half a day in Hanoi.. We spent half a day here with our 3 young kids and they had a good time exploring all the model houses and trying out the games in the grounds. The water puppet theatre was boring but there was plenty of other things to keep 3 kids amused for a couple of hours.

Sprawling grounds - great for kids!. We spent a pleasant three hours here with a tour guide from HanoiKids. We were traveling with a two year old who had his fill after only touring the expansive grounds and reproduction houses, so we didn't even get to see inside the museum, but we had such a fun time outside, the rest of the museum will be on our must-see list when we return to Hanoi. The historical houses are incredibly varied and interesting, though climbing up and down those teeny ladders is not for the faint of heart or poor of balance! We were lucky to catch a water puppet performance on a Sunday afternoon. Would rate this an absolute must-see for families with young children. Highly recommended. Easy cab ride from the city, and easy to catch a cab outside again when you're done. Pleasant stroll outside really makes this museum special.

Local life and different culture in one country. This is the first time i came to Vietnam Museum of Ethnology. I can see a lot of different culture in the same country. How they where, how they live and how they working. How they do their traditional cloth, hat, working equipment ... etc. A lot of black and white picture and a lot of video about the daily life. They also provide a sample of each different catalog of Vietnamese culture: Ethnic Vietnamese, The ethnic Muong, Tho, Chut, The ethnic Tay - Thai and Ka Belt, Nations middle communication and the exchanges of culture... etc

An Excellent Introduction to the Minory Tribes in Vietnam. This museum is set up to help the local people and tourists alike understand and appreciate the over 50 different minority tribes in Vietnam - each with their own culture, language, and style. It is very interesting, and provides lots of information in English so you can really learn about these interesting people, most of whom live in Northern Vietnam. You can see how they live now and in the past, what their cultures are like, and out back of the museum, you can even see houses of several of the tribes to see how they live. These houses are built by the minority people themselves, and are now popular with locals to take their wedding photos.This museum is best visited on your own, as there is plenty of signage to open your eyes to their cultures here, and is definitely worth a visit, especially if you'll be going to Northern Vietnam where these people are so prevalent - you'll have a clue what you're reading on your tourist brochure for the area now. The museum is well done and informative, and definitely worth a couple hours of your time. It's pretty cool to walk through their homes and see the different styles of the architecture from tribe to tribe.

one of best museums in hanoi. I just saw the new exhibit on George Condominas's anthropological study of the highlands ethnic group Mnong at the Vietnam Museum of Ethnology. It just opened on December 11, 2007, and was really well done. A great compilation of artifacts he collected, photos, and excerpts from his fieldwork journal. The permanent exhibit was laid out in an interesting way too. The complex is modern but its location is far from the other touristy destinations. Getting there by taxi is well worth it. This is definitely one of the nicer museums in Hanoi.
Worthwhile. Very informative--and especially useful to visit prior to a trip to Sapa.

A Perfect Museum. Vietnam's Museum of Ethnography is all that a museum should be. It has informative exhibits, information in several languages, and can be viewed in approximately two hours. The museum focuses on the 54 ethnic groups in Vietnam and explains each of them separately. Be sure to stop for the videos--most of them display the death rites of many of the tribes and as you go through the museum, you get a better understanding of the nuances of the various groups. The museum is not located close to any of the major hotels, but the taxi ride is typically under $4 US.

Loved the photo-voice exhibition. I had visited the museum once before, but with my husband in tow, instead of my daughter, we spent a leisurely three hours absorbing the information in the fascinating exhibitions. Loved the displays of garments, material objects, tools, and explanations of how they were used, and their history. All the ethnic houses were fascinating, and we were fortunate that our guide contacted a volunteer who explained about the houses. This enhanced our visit. Especially fascinating for me, as a visual anthropologist, was the Hmong exhibition. The exhibition, placed in the Hmong house, was a fine example of having people who are often photographed by others, taking the opportunity to use cameras themselves and photograph their own lives. Their comments indicated their view of, and acceptance of, tourists, a fine sense of humour, and insights into lives that we would not otherwise see.
